title: ANALOG DEVICES IS BUYING BCO OF NORTHERN IRELAND
description: Analog Devices Inc., a maker of high-speed communications chips, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy BCO Technologies, an electronic-components maker based in Northern Ireland, for about $150 million in cash. Analog Devices, which is based in Norwood, Mass., will pay 402 pence ($6.08) for each BCO share, 6.5 percent more than BCO's closing price Thursday. Shares of BCO, which employs 90 people at its Belfast plant, had risen 66 percent since May 10, the day before it said it was in talks. BCO makes chips used in optical switches, devices that direct the flow of voice, video and data traffic.

For now, foreign companies are permitted to list only so-called B shares on the country's two exchanges. Those shares, denominated in foreign currency, are off limits to Chinese nationals. China's market regulator has said it is considering allowing foreign companies to sell shares to domestic investors, but has given no timetable for when that might happen. Craig S. Smith

title: CHESAPEAKE ENERGY IN DEAL TO BUY GOTHIC ENERGY
description: The Chesapeake Energy Corporation, a natural gas exploration company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a rival, the Gothic Energy Corporation, to add reserves after gas prices have doubled in the last six months. Chesapeake said it would pay $28 million in stock and assume $316 million in debt. The deal values Gothic shares at about $1.50 each. Gothic, based in Tulsa, Okla., owns gas fields in the central states. The purchase will increase Chesapeake's proven reserves by 25 percent, to 1.6 trillion cubic feet, and increase its daily production 22 percent. Chesapeake is based in Oklahoma City.

title: AMERISERVE FOOD IN TALKS WITH WAL-MART STORES UNIT
description: AmeriServe Food Distribution Inc. said yesterday that it was talking with the McLane company unit of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and other parties concerning possible ''strategic alternatives,'' including a sale of assets or a partnership. AmeriServe, which distributes food to chain restaurants like KFC and Pizza Hut, filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law in January. AmeriServe, which is based in Addison, Tex., called the discussions ''preliminary'' and subject to bankruptcy court approval. McLane, which is based in Temple, Tex., provides distribution services to convenience stores, mass merchandisers and fast-food restaurants. It is owned by Wal-Mart.

title: Columbus Circle Re-Imagined
description: At the moment, the Coliseum, on the west side of Columbus Circle, is little more than a hole shrouded in ragged walls gouged out by demolition crews. It is hard to believe that New York City has lived with the Coliseum, which was built by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority and is the legacy of Robert Moses, for 44 years. When it was built, it was a conceptual stepping stone toward the future Lincoln Center, toward a new and controversial vision of the West Side. But it was also a hideous stepping stone, an emblem of unsettling discontinuities in architecture and traffic patterns, an unwelcome barrier to the city's western horizon and, ultimately, to redevelopment of Columbus Circle.

Victor Navasky is the publisher and editorial director of The Nation, the Delacorte professor of magazine journalism at Columbia University and the author of ''Naming Names,'' a study of the Hollywood blacklist. For many years they have disagreed, often vehemently, about the issues that shape American life. For this Fourth of July weekend, The New York Times asked them to discuss patriotism. description: Embraer of Brazil, a leading maker of regional jets, intends to raise $307.5 million in a public share offering in Brazil and on the New York Stock Exchange. The company will sell up to 52.8 million new nonvoting preferred shares to finance a new factory and research complex in Sao Paulo. Three Embraer shareholders -- Simonsen Financial Holdings Ltd., the Bank of Brazil's pension fund, Previ, and the Brazilian National Development Bank -- will sell an additional 31.2 million preferred shares. Embraer is one of Brazil's most successful companies and demand for its regional jets has been growing in recent years. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Ugandan Vote Backs Leader On Keeping His System
description: Early results of a referendum on Uganda's political future showed today that more than 80 percent of those voting want to continue with the current ''no party'' system advocated by the nation's president.

The country star, making a rare club appearance to introduce her latest album, ''New Day Rising'' (Mercury Nashville), projected enough self-confidence and loony charisma to pass as a female reincarnation of the King. She even did the karate moves and muscle-flexing.

title: Let's Not Put a Man on Mars
description: Supporters of a manned mission to Mars have been out in force since NASA's announcement last week that there are recent, perhaps even current, sources of liquid water on the planet. They argue that water will enable human colonies to thrive. But it would be foolhardy to bend the findings to justify a manned mission.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rescue of Retail Chain May Threaten Recovery in Japan
description: Japanese financial authorities bailed out a highly indebted department store company today, averting a major corporate bankruptcy but reigniting concerns about Japan's economic future just as it is showing signs of breaking out of a decade-long malaise.

title: Yankees' Payroll Reaches 9 Figures
description: The Yankees did not need Sammy Sosa or Juan Gonzalez to establish a historic payroll plateau. The acquisition of David Justice did the job just fine.

title: Heels Look to Williams As Guthridge Walks Off
description: Bill Guthridge expected to serve another six years as men's basketball coach at the University of North Carolina. But after returning from a European vacation in late May, he found he lacked the appetite for drawing up plays, making appearances and speeches, or spending part of the summer recruiting players.

title: FLIGHT TESTS SHOW IRAQ HAS RESUMED A MISSILE PROGRAM
description: Eighteen months after American and British warplanes badly damaged its missile factories, Iraq has restarted its missile program and flight-tested a short-range ballistic missile, Clinton administration and American military officials said this week.

title: STEADY CANADIAN OUTPUT
description: Canada's gross domestic product was little changed in April from March, as a fall in manufacturing output and weak retail sales were offset by growth in the petroleum and communications industries. Economists had expected Canada's output of goods and services to fall 0.2 percent. April's output of goods and services was 774.6 billion Canadian dollars ($522.8 billion), compared with March's revised 774.9 billion Canadian dollars, Statistics Canada said. Gross domestic product rose 4.3 percent from April 1999.

title: Attendant at Remote Gas Station Is Killled
description: An attendant at a service station in a remote spot overlooking Interstate 78 in central New Jersey was shot and killed Thursday night by a robber, who then fled, the police said.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen fell in thin trading ahead of the holiday weekend and Tuesday's release of the Bank of Japan's business sentiment survey. In New York, the dollar settled at 106.23 yen, from 105.06 on Thursday.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN FALLS. Corn fell nearly 4 percent after a government report said farmers planted an unexpectedly large crop. Corn for July delivery fell 7.25 cents, or 3.7 percent, to $1.875 a bushel.

title: ABBOTT WITHDRAWS APPLICATION FOR AN IMPOTENCE PILL
description: Abbott Laboratories and Takeda Chemical Industries said yesterday that they had withdrawn an application for approval of the impotence pill Uprima, once seen as a possible competitor for Viagra, which is made by Pfizer. The companies, working in a joint venture called TAP Pharmaceutical Products Inc., said they were conducting additional studies of the drug's safety and efficacy, both of which were questioned by an expert panel of the Food and Drug Administration. The panel did ultimately vote to recommend the drug for approval. TAP said it hoped to resubmit the drug. The decision to withdraw the drug was not completely unexpected, analysts said, because of concerns raised by the F.D.A. reviewers that the drug's dangers outweighed its benefits. Use of the drug was linked to syncope, a temporary lack of consciousness.

title: QANTAS MAY BUY JUMBO AIRBUS
description: Plans by AirbusIndustrie for a gigantic superjumbo jetliner, the Airbus A3XX, got a further lift after the Australian carrier Qantas became the sixth airline to express interest in buying the plane, which will transport at least 550 passengers. The others include Air France and the International Lease Finance Corporation. James Strong, chief executive of Qantas, said Qantas was interested in 10 of the jets, for delivery between 2006 and 2010. John Tagliabue

description: AT&T Considers Spinoff Of Long-Distance Business

description: At the Sidaokou wholesale market they have been snapped up, these strange golden orbs bedecked with American flag stickers and the name Ocean Spray.

description: The scarecrow in the field of thriving marijuana plants here was meant to keep birds away, but instead it drew the attention of an airborne police officer this week.

description: AT&T is considering spinning off its long-distance telephone operation, the largest in the nation, as a separately traded tracking stock, people close to the company said this week.

description: A committee of the Arkansas Supreme Court filed suit in Little Rock today asking a state court to enforce its recommendation that President Clinton be stripped of his law license for falsely denying under oath that he had a sexual relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

description: Representative Rick A. Lazio has collected roughly $4.5 million in donations since entering the New York Senate race six weeks ago, benefiting from the same antipathy toward his opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, that helped propel the fund-raising of Mr. Lazio's predecessor, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: CELGENE, THALIDOMIDE MAKER, ADDS SIGNAL
description: The Celgene Corporation, the maker of thalidomide, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay about $196.6 million in stock for Signal Pharmaceuticals Inc., which develops drugs that regulate genes linked to diseases. The acquisition of Signal brings Celgene into the area of genomics-driven drug discovery, a field that its existing programs and products did not include. Signal employs more than 70 researchers, holds 38 patents worldwide and has more than 80 pending. Celgene, based in Warren, N.J., said it planned to move three new Signal drug compounds for cancer and inflammatory diseases into clinical trials soon. The acquisition nearly doubles the company's research and development spending. Signal is based in San Diego.

description: To the Editor:

description: Family Reunions in Korea

title: Unheralded Players Share the Lead
description: Three players with little success on the L.P.G.A. tour had the most success yesterday in the opening round of the richest 54-hole tournament on the tour.

title: French Turn Vandal Into Hero Against U.S.
description: Fearing that the trial of Jose Bove would turn their quiet little town into an actual battleground for the forces of anti-globalization, most store owners kept their iron gates closed today. The McDonald's restaurant, which Mr. Bove is charged with ransacking last year, was blockaded by two dozen police vehicles.

title: $11.2 Billion Spending Bill Is Readily Passed by Senate
description: Without dissent, the Senate approved today an $11.2 billion emergency spending bill whose centerpiece is an aid package to equip and train Colombia's security forces, who are battling drug traffickers and their rebel allies.

title: 2 Koreas Finish Deal to Reunite Families
description: Red Cross officials from North and South Korea signed an agreement today to begin reuniting families separated by more than 50 years of conflict on the Korean peninsula.

title: Mexican Presidential Candidates Campaign in U.S.
description: The Mexican election has come north of the border.

title: H.I.V. CASES JUMP IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: A small but sharp rise in new infections with the virus that causes AIDS has been detected among gay men in San Francisco over the last three years, San Francisco health officials said yesterday.

title: State Extends Program to Enroll The Poor in Managed Care Plans
description: After citing ''serious concerns'' about flaws in an initiative by New York City to move one million poor residents on Medicaid into managed care health plans, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall approved a two-year extension of the program yesterday, along with a list of recommendations on how to improve the effort.

title: As Rocker Sits Out, Bullpen Collapses
description: John Rocker sat in his specially canopied bullpen, helpless. The bleeding from a callus on his left thumb had stopped, but that was because he was not throwing a baseball.

title: Editorial Observer; A Summer Campaign With a Long Way to Go
description: The Senate campaign in New York already has an overheated quality, like a machine that is revving at full throttle minutes after a jump-start. Four months before Election Day, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick Lazio are hammering each other with a ferocity that usually does not surface until October. Their intensity raises an intriguing question. What are they saving to use after Labor Day?

title: VIBRANT FRENCH ECONOMY
description: French unemployment dropped to 9.8 percent in May, its lowest level in nine years, from a revised 9.9 percent in April, as vigorous economic growth continued to generate fresh jobs. While still above the 8.5 percent average in the 15-nation European Union, unemployment in France has been declining steadily since 1997. John Tagliabue

title: BUYOUT OF RESCARE IS HALTED BY INVESTOR GROUP
description: ResCare Inc., which provides education services to people with mental and developmental disabilities, said its proposed $700 million purchase by an investor group was canceled by mutual agreement. ResCare did not give a reason but analysts said concerns about ResCare's profits deterred investors and lenders from financing the transaction. The company, based in Louisville, Ky., said second-quarter earnings would be less than the first quarter's 23 cents a share because costs had been higher than planned.

title: Doctor's Antitrust Hopes Face a Roadblock From Lott
description: Elated with a big victory in the House, doctors opened a campaign today to persuade the Senate to give them an exemption from antitrust laws so they could bargain collectively with insurance companies over fees and other issues.

title: Technical and Other Difficulties Delay Plan for Online Death Certificates
description: Last winter, 159 funeral directors from around the city crowded into an Italian restaurant on City Island to watch a long-awaited computer demonstration by city and I.B.M. officials: on display was a software program designed to create death certificates online.

title: A Show of Force
description: The police will keep a playoff-sized army of officers assigned to Shea Stadium for the duration of the Mets' four-game series with the Atlanta Braves to ensure that the fragile truce with John Rocker holds through the weekend, officials said yesterday.

title: Downturn in Underwriting As Markets Show Volatility
description: On Wall Street, the second quarter roared in like a wildfire then fizzled to a campfire.

title: Looking Past Georgia's Drought, but Still Seeing Brown
description: THE long drive leading to the water treatment plant is bordered by grass that is suspiciously green, with flowers that are clearly healthy and -- can that be a purely ornamental fountain recklessly gurgling water in the midst of one of the great droughts in Georgia history?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PILCH, TODD DAVID
description: PILCH-Todd David, 7/1/61-1/15/99. Happy 39th birthday in Heaven. There isn't one day that goes by that I don't miss you. I will never stop thinking about you and wondering if you are O.K.-that's what big sisters are for. With all my love, Su

description: American crews competing at the 151st Henley Royal Regatta continued their winning ways yesterday at Henley-on-Thames, England.

title: John Aspinall, Gambler and Zoo Owner, Dies at 74
description: John V. Aspinall, a rakish millionaire who made his fortune in the port-and-cigar world of upper-class gambling tables in London and devoted it to creating country estates for breeding gorillas and tigers -- species he said he preferred to humans -- died on Thursday in London. He was 74.

title: Make Cabs Accessible
description: To the Editor:

title: A Very Busy Legislature
description: Albany is quiet this week after a frenzy of legislative activity unlike any seen for many years. With a budget approved early and a vital election a few months away, the Legislature squeezed in the time to approve almost 700 bills to go to Gov. George Pataki for signing. The list includes a strong gun control package, an important hate crimes bill, a bill requiring fire-safe cigarettes and another providing for public access to critical data about doctors and hospitals, to name only a few. Still, legislators failed to reform the campaign finance and ballot systems, revamp the antiquated Rockefeller drug laws and restructure the state courts.

title: Expanded Border Policing Clogs the Courts and Jails
description: Five years after the Clinton administration and the Republican-led Congress began an enormous law enforcement buildup along the Mexican border to fight the war on drugs and illegal immigration, federal and state courts are buckling under the strain of the resulting criminal caseload.

description: In percent

title: BARRICK BUYS NEIGHBOR
description: In a further consolidation among gold miners, the Barrick Gold Corporation of Toronto has acquired exploration properties in Tanzania and Peru with a friendly takeover of Pangea Goldfields Inc. for 204 million Canadian dollars, or $140 million. The cash offer of 7 Canadian dollars a share for Pangea, also based in Toronto, was 18 percent above Pangea's closing price on Thursday. Most of Barrick's mines are in North America, but it also has one in Peru and Pangea's Tanzanian property ''fits into our development program that is well under way in Tanzania,'' said Randall Oliphant, Barrick's president and chief executive. Timothy Pritchard

title: Senate Fight Ahead On Doctor Exemption
description: Doctors opened a campaign to persuade the Senate to exempt them from antitrust laws so they can bargain with insurance companies over fees and other issues. The exemption was approved overwhelmingly in the House early yesterday, but its prospects in the Senate were unclear.

title: No More 'Morning-After Pills' At School, French Court Says
description: France's highest administrative court today reversed a decision that had allowed nurses in high school health centers to hand out a ''morning-after pill'' to prevent pregnancies.

title: Miami's Hispanic Orchestra Offers Its Musical Patrimony
description: The Cuban diaspora in the age of Fidel Castro takes many forms, one of which could be seen and heard at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night. The Miami Symphony Orchestra was founded 11 years ago by Manuel Ochoa, born in Cuba and for many years active in that country's musical life. Most members of his board of directors in Miami are Hispanic, as are many of his players.

title: Finder's Fee Chases Second Jewel in Tiara
description: The Triple Crown may have produced three different winners this year, but the Triple Tiara still offers a historic opportunity for fillies, and, more precisely, for Finder's Fee, who will race six rivals today in the Mother Goose at Belmont Park.

title: Introduction
description: As might be expected, techies found promise and Luddites cause for alarm in the ''Catalog of the Near Future'' special issue. Other readers continued to advise Midwood High's young scientists, while several criticized our profile of the songwriter Diane Warren for overemphasizing her social life.

title: SEEKING OUT POWWOWS
description: THE shimmering heat of a summer's morning on the short-grass prairie of the Great Plains is unsettling. It's already so hot, and the wind never seems to let up. Stepping out of a truck onto the parched stubble in sandals is downright alarming, for with each footfall a thousand grasshoppers scatter.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Westchester and Putnam Counties this week. Items may be submitted by mail, at least three weeks in advance, to Westchester Cultural Calendar, North Salem, N.Y. 10560.

title: Columbia Journal; Battle Flag Is Lowered, But War Isn't Quite Over
description: As its reign atop the South Carolina Statehouse finally came to an end today, the Confederate battle flag had become almost as much a curiosity as an object of division, a symbol of the state's exhausted recent history even more than of its distant past.

title: Show of Floral Works, Some Inspired by Poetry
description: FLORAL painting has long been one of the staples of representational art. Because of its decorative quality, many see this form as craft; some artists, however, have managed to add something extra to this oft-too-familiar genre. Examples of both kinds of botanical works can be viewed at the current exhibition at the Chappaqua Library Gallery here, titled ''From the Garden.''

title: Baseball Books in Brief
description: THE GOOSE IS LOOSE

title: Godard's Mix Of Movies And Music
description: THE history of cinema parallels the history of recorded music in that both have been concerned, since the necessary technical discoveries were made at the end of the 19th century, with composing in time: composing images, and later sounds, in film; composing sounds alone where music is concerned. With a grand inevitability, therefore, Jean-Luc Godard's four-and-a-half-hour video ''Histoire(s) du Cinema'' presents itself also as, one might say, ''Histoire(s) de la Musique,'' and it is fitting that the soundtrack alone should be available. It comes from ECM (whose moving spirit, Manfred Eicher, has long been a friend and collaborator of the distinguished director) in the form of a smartly packaged set, purchasable online through Barnes & Noble (www.bn.com, $180). Five CD's are accompanied by four hardcover volumes presenting Mr. Godard's text, in English and German as well as the original French, with stills from the video.

title: June 25-July 1; The Toll on Beaches
description: Believers in the biblical injunction against building houses on sand found an ally in the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which published an analysis of shoreline building with an alarming conclusion: a quarter of the houses within 500 feet of the coasts on the ocean and Great Lakes are in danger of falling to the waves in the next 60 years.

title: A Weeping Willow In the Orchard
description: I would appreciate further details about the following statement from the article entitled ''A 1920's Estate Garden Is Carefully Restored'' (June 18): ''In other notes she left, Caroline Ferriday identified ancestry of a weeping willow in the orchard. The tree came from cutting of willow growing on Isle of Elba where Napoleon lived.''

title: Sculptor Harvests Brooklyn Boulders as Material for Art
description: When Boaz Vaadia, a sculptor, saw boulders being pulled out of the ground during sewer repairs near his Berry Street studio in 1989, he was determined to salvage them. So he found a forklift for sale at a local forklift dealership and wrote a check on the spot, for $3,000.

title: The Three Faces, All of Them Female, of Liberty
description: LONG before the Greco-Roman specter of Lady Liberty arrived in New York Harbor in 1886, another woman symbolized the United States, one long forgotten by most Americans. Sometimes known as L'Amerique, or the Indian Princess, she was a Native American figure who first appeared on maps in the 16th century. Wearing a feather headdress, accompanied by a parrot and perched on an alligatorlike reptile, she represented continental America alongside female allegories of Europe, Asia and Africa.

title: As Invasive Plants Spread, State Fights Back
description: PEOPLE are starting to realize that the Asiatic bittersweet, a pretty vine with orange berries and pointed leaves, has unattractive habits. It smothers bushes, wraps itself around poles and squeezes trees to death. It's so aggressive that this year state lawmakers tried to have the plant outlawed.

title: What Would You Do?
description: HERE'S a little real life morality play about suburban life and manners in sedate northern Westchester.

title: June 25-July 1; Scraping By in Japan
description: Last Sunday's parliamentary elections delivered a stinging setback to Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party. A surprisingly weak showing resulted in the party barely retaining control over the powerful lower house. Many already expect calls to replace the prime minister, Yoshiro Mori.

title: Lights, Action . . . Costumes
description: MOSQUITOES zoomed in squadron-style as dusk curtained Whitestone, Queens. Paranoia suddenly seemed to fill the air with their sinister whine. In recent news accounts, this area had become identified with ground zero for West Nile virus: a local chicken had reportedly become infected with the disease. As it would later develop, the chicken was in the clear. But the actors filming the new indie movie ''Dummy'' had no way of knowing that. And they were not leaving flesh to fate.

title: HYDE PARK: LOTS ACQUIRED
description: Scenic Hudson, an environmental group, is buying two parcels opposite the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Home and Library in Hyde Park for $3.1 million, ending a decade of conflict over development in the area. One of the properties, the Hyde Park Drive-In, was touched off controversy in the 1990's when a Wal-Mart was proposed. Scenic Hudson's purchase removes the land from development speculation. The organization has not chosen a use for the site, but ideas include a Depression and World War II-era museum, a transportation hub for the town and its historic sites, a village green and a period restoration of the theater. ROBERT WORTH

title: Tech 2010
description: Now I know why I am a Luddite. The image on your cover summarizes a wonder world of silver daisies and no-mow grass. I'm disturbed by the idea of a world of McWorkers who have forgotten rain forests but have nifty nanotech that produces oxygen.

title: TAX RELIEF FOR DISABLED
description: Disabled residents will receive property tax exemptions like those available to senior citizens under legislation unanimously approved by the Board of Legislators. The legislation, which takes effect immediately, says physically or mentally impaired residents will receive exemptions on a sliding scale based on income. ELSA BRENNER

title: Pull Down the Blinds
description: THE UNWANTED GAZE The Destruction of Privacy in America. By Jeffrey Rosen. 274 pp. New York: Random House. $24.95.

title: With Dessert on the Patio
description: Sauternes, from France, and trockenbeerenauslese, from Germany, thrive in cool weather and deserve crystal on formal tables. But moscato d'Asti begs for July, August and September on the patio, especially a version from Michele Chiarlo that floats as lightly as its name, Nivole, which means ''clouds'' in Piedmontese dialect.

title: The Revolutionary War Is Lost on Hollywood
description: LIKE fireworks -- loud, dazzling, pleasing and scary to the most impressionable -- ''The Patriot,'' the new movie starring Mel Gibson, will prove to many a satisfying way to spend a summer evening. It's got big battles and wrenching hand-to-hand combat, a courageous but conflicted hero and a dastardly and totally guilt-free villain, thrills, tenderness, sorrow, rage and a little bit of kissing. There is just enough brain bran to keep the post-film discussions from being dominated by people who want to focus on how cool it was when Mel hit that guy with the hatchet. Why, some may think it's the best Revolutionary War movie ever made.

title: Undergrads' Corner Tap, With a Twist
description: IT'S a hot summer Saturday and a bunch of college kids have congregated at a tavern in Rahway. But it's not what you think. These kids are lining up to sift dirt and stand neck deep in a 200-year-old privy, hoping to come up with an ancient bottle or prize chunk of porcelain.

title: A Coast Guard Team Based (Where Else?) in the Pine Barrens
description: Much of next week the Hudson and New York Harbor will be filled with tall ships, sailboats and other craft for OpSail 2000. The festivities will be overseen by the United States Coast Guard. One of the Coast Guard units on the scene will be the Atlantic Strike Team, which responds to environmental emergencies. The team is based at Fort Dix and consists of 38 men and women on active duty and 50 reserve. The commander is Gail Kulisch, a former Coast Guard ship commander, executive officer, navigator and marine environmental response officer. Commander Kulisch, who assumed her post June 9, talked recently about her team's work.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-2-00: Salient Facts; Sign of the Times
description: SO MUCH FOR THE PENMANSHIP LOBBYCongress just passed ''an act to regulate interstate commerce by electronic means by permitting and encouraging the continued expansion of electronic commerce through the operation of free-market forces and other purposes.'' Call it S.761 for short, or the electronic-signatures law. What it means: contracts with electronic signatures ''shall not be denied'' just because they happen to be digital. But because S.761 does not mandate a technological standard for electronic signatures, in this as in so many other parts of our lives, the marketplace will settle the score. A scanned version of your pen-and-ink signature may suffice, or perhaps a biological verification system involving a retina scan. But encryption, or the use of secret sets of numbers or keys known only to the parties involved, will probably be the first commonly accepted way to ''sign'' a document electronically.

title: Clicking the Habit
description: I wish I had the guts that Lynne Sharon Schwartz (Lives, June 4) showed by deleting computer solitaire permanently. I vow every day that I will not play computer games so that I, too, can finish my writing projects. Yet the lure is powerful. Besides solitaire, I am hooked on playing ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?'' online. Since I'm incapable of wiping out computer games, there is only one solution. I must destroy my computer and write in longhand. I won't let technology ruin my life.

title: The Makeup Artist
description: As a makeup artist, Leslie Lopez likes to have her way with color. When it comes to covering the faces of celebrities like Catherine Zeta-Jones and Cameron Diaz, Ms. Lopez is known for her less-is-more, natural touch. But her closet couldn't be more flamboyant. ''It looks like a parrot,'' she said, adding, ''I'm Cuban. We're colorful people. Color gives you flavor.''

title: CAMDEN GRANT
description: The state is granting $33 million toward replacing a high-rise public housing project in Camden with homes and apartments. The money, from the state Department of Community Affairs, would be used to demolish Westfield Acres, a substandard public housing project in a blighted neighborhood, and replace it with 523 homes and garden apartments, Jane M. Kenny, community affairs commissioner, announced last week. The hope is to attract $35 million more from the federal Housing and Urban Development department, which has twice turned down the Camden Housing Authority's request for funding. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: A Voice for the Outsiders
description: ON an exceptionally warm evening in May, perfect for strolling in Belgrade's romantic Kalemegdan Park, a threatening band of masked thugs, naked to the waist, broke into the university's school of architecture. Swinging truncheons, they attacked students who were occupying the building to protest the Serbian government's latest rash of academic firings and its crackdown on a growing political movement known as Otpor (Resistance). Scores were injured. One young woman lost an eye.

title: Controlling Drugs in Colombia
description: Congress has granted the Clinton administration the $1.3 billion it sought to help Colombia fight drug cultivation and trafficking. But before final passage of the legislation, Congressional conferees stripped away some of the important human rights and environmental safeguards added by the Senate. Without these restrictions on the use of American aid, the United States could find itself drawn into the long war between the Colombian government and leftist guerrillas, a war that neither side can expect to win by military means. It will now be up to the White House to make sure that American involvement neither prolongs war nor weakens democracy.

title: Don't Get Out Much? You'll Love This Store
description: THE sight of the couple draped across the bed engaged in cozy pillow talk was more than a little disconcerting. Stumbling on the scene, one wasn't sure whether to eavesdrop, look the other way or join the lovebirds on the sheets.

title: Tech 2010
description: Invoking Marx as a justification for high-tech theft is pitiful, and Andrew Sullivan doesn't give a thought to how musicians and writers are supposed to survive as long as we don't actually live in a communist society (The Way We Live Now: ''Dot-communist Manifesto''). Or perhaps he is advocating only stealing from musicians who are already rich -- because people bought their albums.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: COMBO TICKETS -- Admission to three attractions in Greater Cleveland -- the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, Six Flags Ohio and SeaWorld -- is combined in a Wild Thing ticket that costs $49.95; $39.95 for children under 48 inches tall. Tickets, valid through the Labor Day weekend, are on sale at the three sites as well as in the visitor information center of the Convention and Visitors Bureau of Greater Cleveland, in the city's Flats entertainment district along the Cuyahoga River. The regular combined admission is $79.77, and $52.63 for children. The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame is in downtown Cleveland; SeaWorld and Six Flags are in Aurora, about 25 miles southeast. Information: (877) 937-9453.

description: When Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist began his announcement that the Supreme Court had upheld its landmark Miranda decision by intoning, ''You have the right to remain silent,'' Americans of a certain age could be forgiven for thinking of Jack Webb.

title: Quest to Soothe the Savage Breast
description: IN May, an old friend came to town on business. We had lunch at the sort of late-80's restaurant that, with its Bisquick biscuits and corn bread and homemade lime soda, used to be called new American, and filled in the narrative blanks of our recent histories; it had been 15 years since we'd seen one another. Afterward, we picked our way through the rubble on North Moore Street, decorous in our polymide rainwear and neat black boots and -- this being a contemporary report -- repaired to my friend's tastefully beige room at the SoHo Grand Hotel to examine her week-old fake breasts.

title: Editor's Note
description: Caroline Woolsey Ferriday received the cutting from a Mr. Brooks, who, according to documents left by Ms. Ferriday, also sent cuttings from the Napoleon willow to others. ''In the spring of 53, true to his word, Mr. Brooks sent me 3 cuttings -- 2 throve and were subsequently planted in the orchard,'' Ms. Ferriday wrote in her garden notes. ''It comes from a willow whose ancestor overhung the Emperor's tomb at St. Helena and whose progeny have been carfeully preserved, ever since.''

title: Cheaper Than Psychotherapy: Take Your Troubles Out on Him

title: Political Briefing; For Some, Coattails Are Less Helpful
description: Richard Vinroot, the Republican nominee in this year's governor's race in North Carolina, seldom misses an opportunity to link his candidacy to that of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. Mr. Bush is running ahead of Vice President Al Gore in most Tarheel State presidential preference polls, and Mr. Vinroot, a former mayor of Charlotte, knows a coattail when he sees it.

title: A Summertime Success Story
description: IN 1983, Jean-Pierre Bonnefoux, recently retired as a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, was asked to take charge of the summer ballet school at the Chautauqua Institution, a gated community of 225 acres along the shore of Chautauqua Lake, in the northwest corner of New York State. The oldest summer arts festival in America -- last year its 125th anniversary was commemorated in ''Chautauqua: An American Utopia,'' published by Harry N. Abrams -- Chautauqua was founded as an educational center in 1874 and soon incorporated musical and dramatic performances. It boasted a resident symphony orchestra, opera and drama companies, attendant music, theater and art schools, but almost no dance, apart from the fledgling school that catered mostly to the children of festival visitors.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-2-00: The Ethicist
description: I am a Lutheran pastor living in a parsonage. Our school district is debating a building project to be funded by increased property taxes, a proposition I support (although I do not have any children enrolled in the system). As the parsonage is exempt from property tax, is it right for me to vote in the election, considering that should the project be approved, my portion of its taxation is passed on to neighbors? -- Douglas S. Larson-Sell, Lonsdale, Minn.

title: Learning to Live With Background Radiation
description: Miriam Goodman seems to have missed the significance of the concept of ''natural background radiation.'' This radiation is present in nature without any contribution by man and we can do nothing about it. Any contamination that does not increase levels above ''natural background radiation'' is therefore not worthy of any further consideration.

title: For Money? Hey, I Did It For Me
description: LAST week, Playboy magazine published nude photographs of Darva Conger, the 34-year-old emergency room nurse who agreed in February to wed the self-described real estate baron Rick Rockwell on Fox TV's ''Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire?'' title: MOUNT VERNON: PERFECT ATTENDANCE
description: Since her first day of school in pre-kindergarten classes, Chanel Offutt, a Mount Vernon High School senior who graduated last week, has never missed a day of classes. Perfect attendance runs in the family. Her mother, Alfreda, also never missed a day of classes when she was a student in Hinton, W. Va. And Candice Offutt, 19, Chanel's older sister, who graduated from Mount Vernon in 1998, also received the school's Perfect Attendance Award. ELSA BRENNER

title: Portland, Me.
description: The spirited waterfront city of Portland, Me., has quietly emerged from the shadows in the past few years. Residents these days don't need to explain to visitors quite so often that, well, the Trail Blazers play basketball in that other Portland. Two decades ago entrepreneurs reinvigorated the Victorian Old Port neighborhood, known for its exceptional brick architecture. The revival recently moved uptown to Congress Street, where an arts district is taking root, helped by the Maine College of Art's decision to fill an empty Beaux-Arts department store with students after its owners decamped to a mall.

title: Riding Into the Imagination
description: COLORFUL model engines like those shown here chug up rocky, wooded hillsides and wind among miniature evergreens and bright summer flowers in the Everett Children's Adventure Garden at the New York Botanical Garden. The Summer Train Show opened yesterday and will roll through the garden until Sept. 10. The trains pass intricate replicas of the homes of some of America's beloved storytellers and artists. The replicas are made of all natural materials and include Laura Ingalls Wilder's Little House on the Prairie, the farmhouse from Grant Wood's ''American Gothic'' and Edgar Allan Poe's Bronx cottage. The Summer Train Show is the work of Paul Busse of Applied Imagination, who is also the designer of the garden's Holiday Train Show.

The report, sponsored by the American Council of Trustees and Alumni, a Washington-based nonprofit group that promotes liberal-arts study, posed 34 high-school level questions randomly to 556 seniors at 55 leading colleges and universities, including Harvard, Princeton and Brown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERDOS, PAUL L.
description: ERDOS-Paul L. Age 86, died on June 28, 2000. He leaves his loving family: step-daughter Kathleen Mero Mogul and husband Louis Mogul; grandson Jeffrey C. Mogul and wife Patty Page; granddaughter Judith L. Mogul and husband Daniel Kramer and their three children Ilona, Hannah, Joshua; grandson Jonathan M. Mogul, wife Rebecca Friedman and their son Simon; and his devoted friend Eva Roberts. He was married to the late Helen Mero Erdos from 1950 until her death 1978. Born in Budapest, Hungary; he received a Ph.D. in Philosphy from PECS University; he emigrated to the United States. in 1939; founded and was President of Erdos & Morgan, market research firm; author of authoritative text ''Professional Mail Surveys'' and in 1982 won the prestigious Parlin Award in market research.

title: Scars Still Fresh, the Balkan Theater Plays On
description: THE Factory is a noisy place. Inside, by 9:30 on a Tuesday night, trails of moisture slither down the paint-splattered walls and a fat belly of cigarette smoke hangs in the air. But as crowds of fashionably dressed young Croatians gather expectantly outside the drab, inconspicuous entrance, work could not be further from their minds. The Factory, one of Zagreb's trendiest nightspots, has even more to offer than bottled beer and ubiquitous techno music: it has become one of the city's most popular theaters.

description: WHEN parents and students at Thomas Jefferson Elementary School in Yorktown Heights began thinking about an art project to mark the new millennium, someone discovered that the gateway arch in St. Louis was also named for Thomas Jefferson.

description: TWO glossy sources of awe and envy recently met in a Grasmere parking lot to signal that summer had come to Staten Island: a muscle car rally and the Hooters Calendar Girls. Cars and their owners gathered under the auspices of the Richmond County Corvette Club. The Calendar Girls were publicizing a Hooters restaurant that has been host to the club on Wednesday nights for two years. An otherwise unaffiliated group of men came to gawk.

description: A parade of past champions glided across a red carpet during an uplifting ceremony on Center Court today while the missing Pete Sampras sat in a training room with his left shin tethered to an electric stimulator.

title: And the Livin' Is Easy; Dancing and Flirting at Manhattan Movies
description: OPEN-AIR movie screenings have flickered around the city for years, popping up on sheets strung up in Little Italy, or gently bobbing on Pier 63, a barge in Chelsea. But the grande dame of outside cinema is the annual film festival in Bryant Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGGITT, RODGER C., M.D.
description: HAGGITT-Rodger C., M.D. The Board of Trustees, National Scientific Advisory Committee, and staff of the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America are deeply saddened by the tragic loss of our esteemed colleague and dear friend, Dr. Rodger C. Haggitt. A brilliant gastrointestinal pathologist, Dr. Haggitt had a profound impact on the care of people with Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. His commitment to CCFA led to the development of professional education programs of the highest quality. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family. May they be comforted by the knowledge that his contributions to medicine will continue to touch thousands of lives. Lisa H. Richardson, Chairperson of the Board Charles O. Elson, M.D., Chairperson, National Scientific Advisory Committee James V. Romano, Ph.D., President and C.E.O.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIND, JUDITH (ANDERMAN PERSON)
description: LIND-Judith (Anderman Person). The world lost a shining light on June 29, 2000. Judy's most joyous activities revolved around giving of herself & helping others. In this way, she was fulfilled. She touched many lives with her kindness, generosity, good humor and lust for life; and nobody could hug you like Judy. She is survived by her husband Robert Lind; Her two daughters and sons-in-law, Leslie and Graham Hobbs and Nancy Person and Gary Wasserman; Her sister, Cynthia Anderman; four stepchildren and their spouses; and nine grandchildren. A graveside service will be held on Sunday, July 2 at 11 AM at Beth David Cemetery on Elmont Road in Elmont, New York, 516-328-1300. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in her name to the American Cancer Society.

title: Personal Business; New Questions About Block's Lucrative Tax Loans
description: THE carefully constructed image of H & R Block as America's trusted tax preparer was marred a decade ago, when consumer advocates accused the company of marketing advances on customers' tax refunds at usurious interest rates.

The $7.5 million cash purchase price for the garage, just off the northeast corner of 48th Street and First Avenue, with entrances on both 47th and 48th Streets, works out to more than $40,000 for each space.

title: June 25-July 1; Live Long and Prosper
description: Good times lifted 1.1 million more taxpayers into $100,000 plus incomes in 1998, the Internal Revenue Service reported. A record 8.2 million returns, 1 in 15, were above that threshold. On the other end, one-third of tax returns, 40.1 million, showed less than $15,000 of income, but many of these taxpayers were children who sold stocks at a profit in their college funds. Capital gains accounted for 9 percent of all incomes, but 44 percent of the average $6,290 income in this lowest income class. DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

title: Watch Out Barney! Here Comes Zebby.
description: YOUNG children like to watch the same videos and listen to the same music cassettes over and over again. But repeatedly hearing their syrupy songs often makes parents cringe.

When enacted, the bill will mark the first major change in the nation's campaign finance law since 1979. Supporters like Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, said the measure was a small but important step toward broader election-law overhaul. ERIC SCHMITT

title: The Original Laureate Of an Abstract Poetry

He was cinema's Kandinsky, an animator who, beginning in the 1920's in Germany, created exquisite ''visual music'' using geometric patterns and shapes choreographed tightly to classical music and jazz.

title: The Boston Area Adjusts to Rent Deregulation
description: FIVE years after Massachusetts voters ended rent regulation or, more precisely, ended it in Boston, Brookline and Cambridge, the three cities that still had some form of rent control -- rents have taken sizable jumps, the cities are spiffier and less pockmarked by deteriorating neighborhoods and many poorer people have been forced to move to communities farther from the urban core.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, HAROLD, D.D.S.
description: SCHWARTZ-Harold, D.D.S. 79, of New York City and Candlewood Lake, CT, on June 30, 2000. Loving husband of Joyce Pomeroy Schwartz. Beloved father to David, Evan and Billy and their wives, Harriet, Kristine and Terry. Adored grandfather of Rebecca, Jonathan, Alix, Liam and Delaney. Dear brother of Doris Feldman and great friend and brother-inlaw of Lee and Sarah Pomeroy. Cherished uncle to Jordana, Jeremy, Ali Pomeroy, Ellen Goodgold and Nancy Feldman Sayres. A quiet man, he was an uncompromising professional of integrity and distinction who was loved and appreciated by his patients. He inspired and encouraged his children, younger colleagues and students to achieve excellence in their work and enjoy life fully. A specialist in prosthodontics in Manhattan from 1961 to 1992, he began practicing dentistry where he grew up, Belle Harbor in Rockaway, Queens. He was a Captain in the US Navy during World War II. A Clinical Professor of Prosthodontics at New York University College of Dentistry, he taught graduate and undergraduate students from 1962 to 1999, and was Assistant Clinical Professor at the University of Pennsylvania School of Dental Medicine from 1952-1962. A Fellow of the Academy of Prosthodontics, he served as President of the Greater New York Academy of Prosthodontics in 1978 and President of the Northeast Gnathological Society in 1983. Dr. Schwartz became a diplomate of the American Board of Prosthodontics in 1961 and was a charter Fellow of the American College of Prosthodontics and the American Academy of Aesthetic Dentistry. He was an avid athlete accomplished in water skiing, tennis, squash, badminton and ping-pong, and a member of the City Athletic Club since 1961. He loved gardening and with his wife shared an interest in Native American, African and contemporary art. Contributions can be made to ''The Harold Schwartz D.D.S. Memorial Fund'' to support prosthodontics at New York University College of Dentistry, Department of Development, 345 E. 24th St, New York, NY 10010. Services are Wednesday, July 5, 6 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: Susan Ann Ubhaus, the daughter of Eleanor and John C. Ubhaus of Edison, N.J., is to be married this evening in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., to Marcus Alan Motroni, the son of Myra and Hector J. Motroni of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Francis Maione, a Roman Catholic priest, is to officiate at the Woodcliff Lake Hilton, with Rabbi Shimon L. Berris taking part.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIMMEL, HARRIET
description: KIMMEL-Harriet. Of Yonkers, N.Y. Beloved wife of Jack. Dear sister of Muriel Feld. Beloved aunt. Services Sunday, 12PM at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: If the Roof Is Wood, Cease Fire
description: ON June 22, 1999, Louis F. Garcia, New York City's chief fire marshal, issued a directive that called for the arrest of anyone who uses a propane torch on a wood-deck roof in the city. But while Chief Garcia's directive went out more than a year ago, its full impact is only now being felt by property owners whose roof repair and installation costs are expected to increase by as much as 30 percent.

title: Polgar's Foe Misses a Move, And That's All She Needs
description: Looking back from the finish of the Sigeman & Company International Tournament in Malmo, Sweden, May 23 to May 29, one can pick out the third-round encounter between Judit Polgar of Hungary and Jan Timman of the Netherlands as decisive. Polgar won a turbulent struggle that eventually gained her first prize and relegated Timman to second place.

title: Israeli Incursions Add to Friction Over Border
description: The quick deployment of United Nations peacekeepers and Lebanese forces into the stretch of southern Lebanon that Israel abandoned in May after 22 years of occupation has been thrown into doubt with the controversy over a series of apparent Israeli incursions across a border line drawn in 1923.

title: Out On the Prairie, A Real River City
description: PROF. HAROLD HILL is back on Broadway, flashing $8 million worth of smile and what Meredith Willson termed his calling card of a suitcase. Nightly, the ''bang beat bell-ringin' ever'-time-a-bull's-eye salesman'' dissolves into a lovesick puppy as theatergoers wallow unashamedly in the old-time corn-pone verities.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-2-00: On Language; Dare
description: The waiter asked, ''Would you like a bibb lettuce salad?''

title: Antitrust Suit Born of Law, Not of Lobbying
description: IT is no secret that the rivalry between the software leaders, Microsoft and Oracle, is bitter. Still, the acknowledgement last week by Oracle that it financed a series of escapades intended to embarrass Microsoft provided some lively summer entertainment -- especially a Keystone Kops caper in which private investigators offered office cleaners $1,200 for the contents of a proMicrosoft trade group's wastebaskets.

title: Mallika Marshall, Jason Hurd
description: Dr. Mallika Joy Marshall, the daughter of Carole Simpson and James E. Marshall of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Jason Hansen Hurd, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Hurd Jr. of Wellesley Hills, Mass. The Rev. Janice M. Robinson performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Washington National Cathedral.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOHR, STEVE
description: LOHR-Steve. Devoted husband of Ruth, died suddenly on June 21st. Steve embraced life with rare zest and great joy and optimism. A delightful man, who will be sorely missed and always remembered by all those who had the opportunity to have known him. Sincere sympathies to Ruth.-A friend

title: Exchanging of Vows By Gays in Vermont
description: From Burlington to Brattleboro, with public hoopla or private solemnity, a scattering of gay couples across Vermont became the first in the country to legally take on the rights and responsibilities of marriage, in the first state to let them. Most town clerks were closed for the weekend, but a handful opened their offices in response to requests from gay couples who wanted to get all-but-married the very day that the state's ''civil unions'' law took effect.

title: Is Retirement a Gift or a Burden?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Madison Avenue Fantasy
description: THE hit television show ''Survivor'' is credited with rejuvenating CBS, attracting loads of those coveted viewers between 18 and 49. That means the network, which mature Americans have long called their own, can now sell more ads at higher prices.

title: Secret Status Flies From Behind And to Head of the Filly Class
description: Her name is Secret Status, a daughter of A. P. Indy and grand-daughter of Seattle Slew and Alydar, and the last time she ran was two months ago when she charged from 13th place into a six-length victory in the Kentucky Oaks. Secret Status showed her powerful closing ability again yesterday when she roared through the homestretch at Belmont Park to win the Mother Goose, the second race in the Triple Tiara series for fillies.

title: June 25-July 1; Drug Benefits for the Elderly
description: Defying a veto threat from President Clinton, the House approved a Republican plan to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly by offering subsidies to insurers to help defray the cost.

title: Corrections
description: An explanatory note with the Opinion essay last week, about standardized testing in schools, misstated the career of the author, Albert G. Craz. Though he was a teacher and administrator in Northport and other school districts in New York State for 35 years, he never taught in New York City.

title: Messier's Return To Rangers Is Looming
description: Mark Messier officially became a free agent yesterday. And there is little doubt around the National Hockey League that the 39-year-old center's next move will be to re-sign with the Rangers, three years after he left New York in a messy divorce and six years since leading the Rangers to their first Stanley Cup in 54 seasons. The Rangers have not been to the playoffs since Messier left.

title: Ringing Up Sales
description: Once, push-button phones were a novelty. Now, with new wireless services, phones can push your buttons. SmartRay .com, a wireless media network, and Inshop.com, a Web site that specializes in shopping information, have teamed up to deliver free shopping alerts to subscribers.

title: AT THE BOOKSTORE WITH/Stefan Kanfer; Behind the Mask: Following the Laugh Track With Groucho Marx
description: STEFAN KANFER, the author of the new biography ''Groucho: The Life and Times of Julius Henry Marx'' (Alfred A. Knopf), was Time magazine's film and theater critic in the late 1960's, and he met Marx on several occasions.

title: Baseball Books in Brief
description: LEVELING THE PLAYING FIELD

title: Tag, You're Fined
description: Angelo Cataldi insists he is still steamed about the day last August when he was ejected from the sands of Avalon for lack of a beach tag. In addition to talking about it on his sports-radio show in Philadelphia, he is fighting the conviction and challenging the beach-fee law in court.

title: International Paper Closing Tech Center
description: When the former Champion International shutters its 128,000-square-foot West Nyack technical center next fall, Rockland County will lose 109 jobs.

title: Rome Reduces Traffic By Limiting Tour Buses
description: All roads may lead to Rome, but these days not everyone traveling on them can reach downtown. Since April 6, tour buses have not been allowed to circulate freely or park within the historic center. City officials passed the regulations to avoid potential traffic jams as many thousands of pilgrims visit Rome in the Jubilee Holy Year.

title: . . . But This Is Not a Real Park
description: AMONG the city's neighborhoods, Brooklyn Heights is a jewel. The city's first landmarked historic district, its quiet ambience suggests a backward trip in time. Film makers frequently use streets like Joralemon Street to evoke early New York. Yet Brooklyn Heights has major problems. As one of the city's oldest neighborhoods, it lacks open green park space, and its narrow streets are often clogged with traffic.

title: Two Plans for White Plains Site
description: SEVENTEEN years after it first proposed developing portions of a 121-acre parcel adjacent to downtown, New York Presbyterian Hospital says it is time to act.

title: The Bike-to-the-Bus Falters, And the M.T.A. Tries a Fix
description: Last September, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority temporarily closed the walkway across the Marine Parkway-Gil Hodges Memorial Bridge. The agency is widening the roadway across the bridge, and the walkway will be closed until spring 2001.

title: Despite Speedy Accord, Long Road Ahead to Korean Unification
description: While the friendship and reconciliation that emerged from the Korean summit meeting two weeks ago was surprising, and sudden, officials here insist that actual unification is years, if not decades, away and can be achieved only gradually.

title: Food; The Stick Shift
description: Drifting through the Indonesian archipelago, we rarely committed to a full, Western-style meal. It was hot. The air was heavy and fragrant, and it descended from time to time in little spurts like the cough of an impatient god. Far be it from mere mortals to make long-term commitments. We snacked.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Angels Shift Crusade To Children and Internet
