description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: That Spit and Polish Can Come at a Cost
description: Eight hours before a $1,000-a-person fundraiser for his nascent campaign for governor, Mayor Bret Schundler stood before reporters and posed a question that to him was simple: ''Should police officers get overtime for shining their shoes, doing their laundry?'' he asked. ''I don't think so.''

title: Kathleen Buckley, Christian Bennett
description: Kathleen Anne Buckley, a daughter of Mary and Patrick Buckley of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christian David Bennett, a son of Simone Bennett and David Bennett, both of Melbourne, Australia. The Rev. Paul McCarren performed the ceremony at Epiphany Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Kobe Bryant's Dream
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Investing; Peer-Group Pressure Hurts a Ford Offspring
description: ACCORDING to Finance 101, when an old-line manufacturing company finds that one of its offspring far surpasses it in profit growth, the best course is to liberate this child star to soar on its own.

title: Cecilia Ahrbom, Andrew Weiler
description: Cecilia Ebba Ahrbom, a daughter of Ann-Charlotte and Per Ahrbom of Saltsjo-Duvnas, Sweden, was married yesterday to Andrew Charkin Weiler, the son of Eileen Weiler Judell of New York and the late Henry Weiler. The Rev. Inga Ahrbom, an aunt of the bride and Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the Saltsjo-Boo Old Chapel in Stockholm.

title: Deep in the Heart of Jersey
description: Clint Black is a pretty straightforward guy, but he does offer up one surprise. He's from Long Branch. That's New Jersey, not Texas. But it was his eventual move to the Lone Star state that propelled him into country music fame. In 1989, he led the new-country vanguard which included Garth Brooks, Alan Jackson and Trisha Yearwood and stood out with his fluid R&B-laced vocals and well-crafted accessible songs like ''Killin' Time.'' He performs at the PNC Arts Center in Holmdel Thursday, part of a tour supporting his latest album, the all-acoustic ''D'Lectrified,'' which includes a song from ''Monty Python's Meaning of Life,'' which has to be a country music first. As if that's not enough, his repertory covers country, rock, R&B and Dixieland. Not bad for a Jersey boy. ROBBIE WOLIVER

title: Press Baron's Progress
description: THE CHIEF

title: Wilhelmina Smith, Mark Mandarano
description: Wilhelmina Wolff Smith, a cellist, and Mark Theodore Mandarano, a conductor, are to be married today at the Harrington Meeting House in Pemaquid, Me. The Rev. Robert Ives, a Congregational minister, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Going For Broke
description: Whenever I start to get blase about today's amazing business world, I pull out my copy of John Kenneth Galbraith's ''New Industrial State,'' published in 1967. It's a reminder of how thoroughly the economy has defied the old conventional wisdom.

title: A Season Of Surprises, Mostly Happy
description: HATS off, gentlemen, to American Ballet Theater for a heroic season. The repertory looked better on stage than on paper and a clever Band-Aid approach kept performances at a high standard despite an inordinate amount of illness and injury among the dancers.

title: Bell Atlantic Victim Is Not Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Roxas, Robert Dobrish
description: Elizabeth Roxas, a dancer, and Robert Z. Dobrish, a matrimonial lawyer, were married on Tuesday. Judge Jeffrey H. Gallet of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York officiated at the National Museum of the American Indian in Manhattan. Justice Jacqueline W. Silbermann of State Supreme Court in Manhattan took part in the ceremony.

title: A Leader's New Focus: Reconciling Differences
description: If an anniversary offers a convenient way by which a person can measure life's progress, then June 24 was a remarkable date for the Rev. Syngman Rhee. On that day, he was elected moderator of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), the highest office in the nation's largest Presbyterian denomination.

title: Ideas & Trends; All That's Bare Is Fit to Wear, So Why the Stares?
description: BLAME HBO's ''Sex and the City'' or blame the decline of the ozone layer, but skin is in. American women are showing more of it than ever before.

title: Speaking Out Against A 7-Eleven for Holmdel
description: To the Editor:

title: Lining Up to Get In Burlington's Jail
description: Wandering through Burlington County's Old Prison, it is not hard to imagine prisoners in the 19th century locked up behind inch-thick oak and iron-banded doors inside their tiny fireplace-heated cells with little to do but contemplate their fate.

title: Molly Rauch, Benjamin Longstreth
description: Molly Elissa Rauch, the daughter of Betty and Michael H. Rauch of New York, is to be married today to Benjamin Hoyt Longstreth, a son of Clara and Bevis Longstreth of New York. Rabbi Sarah Reines is to officiate in Bear Mountain State Park on Iona Island, a bird sanctuary on the Hudson River, near Peekskill, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKES, ROBERT SETH, M.D.
description: WILKES-Robert Seth, M.D. In Novato, Ca., on June 20, 2000, age 65. Beloved husband of Barbara J. Wilkes. Loving father of Debra (Jason) McKinley, Jackie (Warren) Burks and Kenneth Wilkes. Devoted grandfather of five. Dear brother of, Leonard Wilkes and the late Conrad Wilkes. Loving uncle and great uncle. Dr. Wilkes practiced internal medicine for 35 years in Novato, Ca. Funeral was held June 23rd in San Rafael, Ca.

title: Armstrong Second After Opening Trial; 3 Fail Drug Test
description: With a strong but not dominating ride, Lance Armstrong opened the defense of his championship today in a Tour de France that was shaken just hours before the start by the ouster of three riders for failing a blood test that hints at the use of illegal drugs.

title: Life, Liberty, Cheap Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Brazilian Banker, The Highest Perch
description: THERE are the investment bankers who talk of things like deficit figures and inflation targets when discussing Brazil, Latin America's largest economy. Then there are the bankers, like Francisco Gros, who talk of Miss Piggy.

title: It's Not Just the Heat; There Are Any Number of Miserable Reasons Not to Like Summer
description: Ah. Summertime.

title: REPORTS SAY CHINA IS AIDING PAKISTAN ON MISSILE PROJECT
description: American intelligence agencies have told the Clinton administration and Congress that China has continued to aid Pakistan's effort to build long-range missiles that could carry nuclear weapons, according to several officials with access to the intelligence reports.

title: Political Briefing; Making a Point In Cold Cash
description: Ed Bernstein had a point to make.

title: Free Books, The American Story
description: The distribution of free books overseas by the grassroots Darien Book Aid Plan from the beginning had the support of Congress as well as the State Department and the U.S. Army (''Filling the Need to Read with Tons of Books,'' June 11).

title: Ann Arthur, Patrick Andrew
description: Dr. Ann Virginia Arthur, a pediatric ophthalmologist, and Patrick Curtis Andrew, an ironworker, were married yesterday in Brookville, N.Y., at the home of her brother Floyd Arthur and sister-in-law Lydia Andrew, the bridegroom's cousin. Justice Harold Silverman of State Supreme Court in the Bronx officiated.

title: This Time Braves Fall Apart Early
description: All was right with the Braves' world shortly before 10 p.m. Friday, reinforced by the Shea Stadium scoreboard that showed their comfortable 8-1 lead. But that promise soon gave way to dread when the Mets scored 10 runs in the eighth as they rallied to an 11-8 victory.

title: Old-Line Communists at Odds With Party in China
description: For more than 40 years, Zhou Wei found success as a Communist Party cadre in government bureaus and state-owned enterprises, the kind of loyal official whose hard work kept the gears of China's socialist industry turning. Colleagues and family say he was a brilliant, if prickly, man who loved -- and still loves -- the party.

title: Limiting Rent Increases
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 2, 2000
description: Weeks

title: The Makers of TV Are Happy to Mine Their Own Business
description: FOUR years ago, Brandon Tartikoff, the legendary NBC programming chief, proposed the Hollywood equivalent of building oneself a pyramid: a television series based on his own life. The former network president, who had overseen such hits as ''Cheers,'' ''Seinfeld'' and ''Law and Order'' during his decadelong tenure at NBC, felt the time was right for a prime-time version of ''Network,'' the 1976 Oscar-nominated satire of the television news business.

title: Classic Characters' Traits
description: YEARS ago, cartoons were modeled on real people and animals - or at least on sitcom versions of them, the way ''The Flinstones'' were based on ''The Honeymooners.'' Today cartoons and reality are virtually interchangeable, with films like ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit'' and this summer's ''Rocky and Bullwinkle,'' featuring marquee actors alongside cartoon critters, and ''The Flinstones in Viva Rock Vegas,'' starring Mark Addy as a flesh-and-blood Fred. Now that ''the circle is completed,'' as they say in the cartoon-turned-Broadway-show ''The Lion King,'' it may be a good time to test your knowledge of how it began.

title: Long Shots, on the Court and Off
description: FOR Terry Mollner, a pillar of socially responsible investing who made a run at acquiring Ben & Jerry's Homemade this spring, the triumph of the United States and its economic system remains incomplete. ''It's been more than 10 years since the end of the cold war, and there's been no bright light shone on how to improve capitalism,'' he said in a recent interview on the upstairs porch of his tidy frame house here. ''It's about time we got around to it.''

title: The Minority Quarterback
description: A late summer morning and the sun was already harsh on the dusty high school football field. The shirtless blond 19-year-old in shorts stained with sweat kept dropping back to pass, his hands at times so wet it was hard to grip the ball. He was throwing to a friend, working ''up the ladder,'' as it is called, starting with short passes and ending long.

title: 1 Close-Knit Village, 2 School Districts
description: TEN years ago, Stacy Weissman and her husband, Larry, moved into a house in the Westchester village of Rye Brook. This year, when the Weissmans and their two sons outgrew their quarters, Mrs. Weissman didn't think twice. They bought a larger new home in the village.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-2-00: Gallery; Flag Amendment
description: These images are taken from ''Stripes and Stars: The Graphic History of an American Icon,'' a new exhibition at the American Institute of Graphic Arts National Design Center in New York. The assorted flags, objects and works of art in the exhibit, which closes Aug. 25, come from the collection of Kit Hinrichs.

title: Ideas & Trends: Toffs and Machiavels; In Sports and On Screen, the British Don't Get No Respect
description: IN its understated way, Britain is the Edward I. Koch of nations, endlessly wondering ''How'm I doing?'' But unlike Mr. Koch, the self-congratulating former mayor of New York, Britain rarely expects a positive answer. And lately, a nation that is always sensitive about perceived slights to its international status has found more than usual to be upset about.

title: A Contender Survives, Then a Legend Loses
description: The witnesses to two epic matches today left the All England Club with their tennis addictions sufficiently stuffed. Just after Mark Philippoussis broke the tension on Court 2 by winning a near-record 20-18 fifth set, Martina Navratilova exited the grounds after losing the final set of her wrenching mixed doubles match, 18-16.

title: The Nation; Sometimes, a Half-Truth Shall Make You Free
description: ''ITHINK the truth is my friend in this,'' Vice President Al Gore said as he released the transcript of a contentious sworn interview with a Justice Department official over fund-raising in the 1996 election. Ordinary folks trying to untangle the 123-page document may wonder how Mr. Gore really treats his friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLLIGS, GEORGE
description: KOLLIGS-George. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of George Kolligs, associated with The Times from 1959 until retiring in 1988.

title: The View From/Ridgefield; Protagonist Gets Playhouse Under Way After Years of Conflict
description: LAST month's groundbreaking ceremony for the Ridgefield Playhouse for Movies and the Performing Arts ended a wearying debate over public funding for the arts in the community. The 512-seat theater, which is actually a renovation of the town's old high school, has been six years in the making.

title: Expansive Choices Highlight Italian Spot
description: DiMAGGIO'S, in Glen Cove, understandably attracted a large following during its relatively short history at 274 Glen Street (516-671-9323), with its vibrantly seasoned, authentic, Italian soul food and many early-bird dinner values. When the restaurant was sold a couple of months ago to the Mario Silvestri family, a friendly Italian crew who own ''A'' Tarantella in Brooklyn, it no doubt seemed logical to retain DiMaggio's menu while adding their own. Even before the restaurant's name changes, its menus proclaim ''DiMaggio's-soon-to-become 'A' Tarantella.''

title: Sainthood Quest for Knight of the Church
description: To his supporters, the Rev. Michael J. McGivney is nothing less than a saint. To get the Vatican to see it that way, now they have to prove it.

title: The Barns of Johnson County
description: IF you've never been to Iowa, you've probably never had a pie shake. The recipe is simple: toss a slice of crusty fruit pie into a milkshake and blend well. (Note: strawberry rhubarb pie and vanilla ice cream work best.) Serve in a tall waxed paper cup with a long spoon.

title: At Picnic in Pelham, James Joyce Lovers Celebrate a Devilishly Challenging Book
description: IT was a typical Sunday picnic in a backyard here. Except that most of the 25 or so guests were wearing identical black T-shirts with nonsense words printed on them. And leaning against a tree beside the picnic tables was a cardboard cutout of James Joyce.

title: Catherine Konovaliv, Andrew Raab
description: Catherine Susan Konovaliv and Andrew John Raab are to be married this afternoon by Mayor Ingrid Sheldon of Ann Arbor, Mich., at the Michigan League in Ann Arbor.

title: Fitting Taxis For Wheelchairs
description: NEW YORK CITY has started on a road that may lead to taxicabs that are able to accommodate wheelchair users in their chairs. The Taxi and Limousine Commissioner, Diane McGrath McKechnie, has submitted a proposal requiring that the city's medallion taxi fleet include such cabs, which are usually minivans modified to provide ramps that fold down in the back or on the side.

title: 'Long Goodbye,' No
description: To the Editor:

title: Footnotes
description: 1. The young German photographer Burkhard Schittny is inspired by Egon Schiele's ''fascinating bodywork, the movement, the expressions on the faces, the very thin, angular, undernourished bodies.'' Schittny creates his technofusion of art and fashion by reworking his transparencies on the computer, using Photoshop to add outlines, erase parts of the picture and heighten color in the manner of a Schiele drawing. And if you think Schiele is a stretch as a style icon, get this: Schittny also shoots fashion images inspired by Francis Bacon.

title: Hunting for Houses Online
description: WHEN Charles and Lisa Woodward first stepped into their dream house in Ossining in February, they had the feeling they had been there before.

title: MINORITIES STOPPED
description: Troopers stopped minorities on the turnpike more often than anywhere else in the state during the first four months of this year, according to figures released last week by the State Police. The report said that 38 percent of drivers stopped on the turnpike were nonwhite, compared with 26 percent statewide. It was submitted to comply with an agreement with the federal Justice Department in a racial profiling case last year, PETER BELLER

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARCUS, JEAN AND RITA
description: MARCUS-Jean and Rita. I think of you every day. -Alan

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Music in Her Own Words

title: He Blazed a Trail Now Well Traveled
description: IN contrast to Bill Willoughby's lonely teenage existence during his rookie year in the National Basketball Association, there are now eight players on N.B.A. rosters who eschewed college ball and went right from high school to the pros.

title: Campaign Contrasts Grow Starker
description: Gov. George W. Bush was all set and ready to go from New York City to Detroit on Tuesday when his campaign plane let out an enormous belch, drawing the attention of maintenance workers and stranding him and his entourage on the tarmac at La Guardia Airport. He seemed amused and unalarmed. ''This is an optimistic campaign,'' the Texas governor joked to the reporters who were sitting several rows behind but plenty close enough to see and hear him.

title: Tall Visitors to the Shore
description: Some of the tall ships that will sail through New York Harbor this weekend in OpSail will also visit Atlantic City. The ships will be open for free tours and the crews will hold demonstrations of different aspects of seamanship. The visits to Atlantic City are sponsored by Trump Marina and the Casino Reinvestmnent Development Authority.

title: A Modest Creator With a Gift for Gloss
description: IT is both a Hollywood legend and a fact that the people who create glamorous films and television shows are often not especially glamorous. Take the case of Darren Star: the son of an orthodontist from Potomac, Md., a boy who used his bar mitzvah money to buy a subscription to Variety, a quiet, friendly and modest 38-year-old writer and producer who eschews fancy clothes, clubs and trappings and somehow seems unlikely to have been involved in the hugely successful and unmistakably flashy shows ''Beverly Hills 90210'' and ''Melrose Place,'' as well as HBO's acclaimed ''Sex and the City.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, ELIAS A.
description: COHEN-Elias A. Although fortyeight years have passed, since our beloved founder, Elias A. Cohen, passed away on July 2, 1952, he is still remembered with love and reverance by the thousands of deserving boys and girls who were priviledged to come to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp for a few fun filled weeks each summer since July 1st, 1919. In the spirit of ''Noblesse Oblige'' his devoted family, his many loyal friends and a greatful Alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquillity Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that Tranquillity is now celebrating its' 82 year. Tranquillity Camp, Inc. Earlton, New York Pearl C. Miller, President

title: And the Livin' Is Easy; Barbecues? Fine. But New York also has citified rites of summer. Parties on pavement. Midnight ice cream runs. And outdoor movies with beaujolais and brie.
description: SUMMER in the city is all hard edges. New Yorkers tan on tar, grill on brick, take grounders off macadam, porch-sit on iron fire escapes. Band music doesn't waft from a gazebo on a green, it ricochets off marble columns at Lincoln Center plaza.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYARSKY, MORRIS
description: BOYARSKY-Morris. Beloved husband of the late Anna. Loving father of Linda and Allen Essner, and Isaac and Malkah Boyarsky. Devoted grandfather of Daniel, Deana, Naomi and Tamar. Services today, 12 noon, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: SOAPBOX; An Opportunity to Seize . . .
description: SEVENTY-FIVE acres of publicly owned land sits virtually unused on the Brooklyn waterfront. The views of the Brooklyn Bridge, Lower Manhattan and New York Harbor are unsurpassed. After almost 20 years, the vision of a waterfront park here is about to become reality. It will be a great gift for the 21st century: the Brooklyn Bridge Park.

title: MAMARONECK: INJUNCTION GRANTED
description: The State Supreme Court in White Plains has granted a preliminary injunction barring the village of Mamaroneck from giving a contract to a Long Island developer, Sportime, for a sports complex at Harbor Island Park. The current operator of the tennis courts in the park, Harbor View Racquet Club, had a right of first refusal, which the court upheld. The village had argued that Harbor View lacked the money and expertise to build the new facility. ''We're looking into an appeal,'' Steven Silveberg, the village attorney, said. ROBERT WORTH

title: Keeping the Elderly in the Towns They Helped Build
description: ALTHOUGH construction has barely started at the Meadows at North Valley Stream here on Dutch Broadway in this southwestern Nassau County community, people are constantly stopping by to inquire when the 104 co-op apartments will be available.

title: The Smart Set
description: After reading your provocative description of the Rube Goldberg cereal-preparation apparatus, ''Breakfast for One,'' my fellow patent attorneys and I shall never forgive you for neglecting to include a photograph of the inventors' prototype.

title: The Love Machine
description: Why does Rob Tannenbaum, in his fascinating article on Diane Warren (June 4), zero in on the fact that she has not been in a relationship for a long time? I wish Warren the best in her career and hope that someday -- but not a moment before she is ready -- she will fall in love, too.

title: HATE-CRIME LAW
description: New Jersey's 1981 law allowing judges to extend penalties for crimes committed because of a defendant's prejudices is unconstitutional, the United States Supreme Court ruled last week. The court ruled that a jury, not a judge, has to determine whether a crime was hate-related. The ruling was issued in a case involving a Vineland man, Charles Apprendi, who shot at the home of the only black family in his neighborhood. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: A Tropical-Asian-Caribbean Combo
description: THE idea is not new: A resort or restaurant in the Caribbean, where winter is the high season, opens a spot in the Hamptons and sends its chef and staff there for a busy summer. This year's entry is the Cerulean Restaurant, a spin-off of the Cerulean Villa in Anguilla.

title: Past the Highway of Memories, a Song and Dance Wonderland
description: NO matter what road you used to take to professional summer theater, odds are it will no longer lead you there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, HOWARD, M.D.
description: LESSER-Howard, M.D. It is with deep sorrow that the Lesser family mourns the passing of their beloved father and husband, Howard N. Lesser, MD who healed and photographed the world creating a beautiful life for his family, patients and friends. He is survived by his loving wife, Florence and his adoring childern, Steven, Robert and Carol Lesser, loving grandchildren Raphi, Uri, Nina, Eli and Courtney and his cherished niece and nephew Annette Karan and Joey Epstein. Services were held on Friday, June 30, 2000.

title: Of Being Owned

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIRKIN, LES, DR.
description: SIRKIN-Les, Dr. Eminent geologist, retired Professor of Earth Sciences at Adelphi University, and prolific author, died suddenly in his home on Block Island June 25, 2000 at age 66. Dr. Sirkin studied glaciated regions and coastal plains in the N.E. United States, S.E. Alaska, and the coastal regions of W. Mexico and the Baja. He published numerous research papers on various geological periods. He is the author of Block Island Geology, Eastern Long Island Geology, Western Long Island Geology, and co-author of Earth History and Plate Techtonics. Les truly enjoyed sharing his knowledge with others. He also had a passion for sailing and skiing. His unique sense of humor and quick wit was appreciated by all who came to know him. He will be deeply missed. Les Sirkin leaves behind his beloved, Judy FitzGibbon. He was the devoted father of Annie Ledoux, Emily Melcher, and Carolyn Sirkin (daughters with his late wife Joanne Sirkin) and loving grandfather of Olivia Melcher. A memorial servie on Block Island is planned for late summer. In lieu of flowers, a donation in his name can be made to the Nature Conservancy, Block Island. For memorial information, please write to: Sirkin Family, PO Box 779, Block Island, RI 02807 or email: petermelcher@hotmail.com

The bill approved last week would force certain tax-exempt slush funds that run campaign ads to reveal their spending and financing sources. By the time it was approved, many opponents had jumped on board and were actually trying to claim credit for its passage. Their belated eagerness to get right on this issue should now be exploited to make more progress on purging American campaigns of special-interest money.

title: Asphalt Blues
description: Depending on how you look at it, Route 66 was a strip of the true vernacular or an asphalt hustle. Perhaps it was always both. Route 66 was commissioned in 1926, fully paved in 1938, its last stretch replaced by an Interstate in 1984. During the Depression and World War II, it was a historic migratory corridor from the Midwest to the Southwest and California. In ''The Grapes of Wrath,'' John Steinbeck called Route 66 ''the mother road'' but also, more accurately, ''the road of flight.'' It was the road across ''the Western States,'' a road on which no one ever traveled east, on which caravans of drifters and laborers and uprooted families moved in the one iconic direction, toward the Pacific Ocean. ''Need,'' Steinbeck wrote, ''is the stimulus to concept, concept to action.'' The action that grew up along Route 66 during its boom years is legendary. That was where, and how, America learned what it means to be on the road with an automobile. Every motel, every auto camp, every drive-in along the way was somebody's pipe dream come true, and the road ahead was a pipe dream, too. The highway followed the lay of the land. It ran down Main Street and right out of town. It carried away the people you knew and brought strangers in their place.

After I noticed the other characters in the film address this fellow first as ''Mr. Grossmith'' and then as ''George,'' the penny dropped: Why, that must be George Grossmith -- the man who, after chucking his career with Gilbert and Sullivan, went on to write a book that I cherish above all others, a book that I have repeatedly rejoiced in reading, a book that has been my prop and stay in troubled times: ''The Diary of a Nobody.''

title: QUICK BITE/Swedesboro; The Are the Egg Men
description: I wondered how Swedesboro got its name -- for about 12 seconds. Then I saw the giant sign proclaiming that Swedes settled the town in 1638. Just below, I read of visits from Swedish royalty: Prince Bertil in 1938, and King Carl XVI Gustaf in 1976. I must admit, I was intimidated by the Swedish pedigree. My only brushes with the culture's cuisine have been Swedish meatballs and . . . . So it was with great relief that I stumbled upon Rode's Fireside, an old-fashioned American family restaurant. Within the unassuming exterior is a surprisingly spacious room, with ample tables and a large bar. (Covered outdoor seating is also available.) Above you are Tiffany lamps, ceiling fans, and hanging plants; below is a hardwood floor. And there's a big fireplace. After all, this isn't Rode's Space Heater Restaurant. I sat at the bar, because that is what lonely men do when they find themselves in Swedesboro on a Sunday afternoon. The wait staff, identically dressed in light red shirts, dark red aprons and khakis (I was assured this was not the national costume of Sweden), were all friendly and attentive. Like any self-respecting Pennsylvania border-town bar, Rode's offers Yuengling lager on tap. It nicely complemented an Old Hickory dhicken sandwich -- a juicy chicken breast, topped with cheddar, barbecue sauce and succulent bacon. But it's not just sandwiches; Rode's serves a full slate of pasta, steak, chicken, and seafood entrees, priced from $8.95 to $17.95. I saw a ''Fresh Eggs'' sign on the wall, and thought to myself, that it was one of those phony down-home decorations you see in T.G.I. Friday's. But back in the parking lot, I noticed a truck: ''Otto C. Rode Inc., Farm Fresh Butter & Eggs, established 1880.'''What can I say? T.G.I.Rode. JACK SILBERT

It's less than an hour before show time and she's alone. No make-up artist, no hair stylist, no vocal coach. She doesn't need a vocal coach because, while she has a voice that's nothing short of thrilling, she barely warms up. ''La-la-la-la-la-la-la-la,'' she sings, her voice gliding the scales, as she dabs on mascara. ''La-la-la-la-la-la-la-la.'' During her shows she routinely belts out thunderous notes worthy of Ethel Merman, which itself is a feat since she's 5-foot-2 and asthmatic, but she hardly raises her voice above a whisper when she's vocalizing.

As the third-round leader of this week's United States Senior Open at Saucon Valley Country Club, he has a great chance to pull off his most significant triumph yet.

title: MUSIC; Defining Two Roles: Diva and Soul Survivor
description: FOR a teenager living in the suburbs of Detroit in 1964, the royals of AM radio were alarmingly obvious: the Beatles were the imported kings of rock 'n' roll and Aretha was the native Queen of Soul. Then along came the pop princess Diana and her ladies in waiting, the Supremes. With a voice as pure and sweet as an ebony virgin locked in an ivory tower -- and the glamour and vanity to match -- Diana Ross led the Motown trio to the top of the charts 10 times in less than three years. In 1967 she became the headliner, and three years later, Diana Ross and the Supremes made their farewell appearance at the Frontier in Las Vegas, singing their final No. 1 hit. It was an end-of-the-affair, gospel-styled swan song filled with regret and hope and titled ''Someday We'll Be Together.'' No one, least of all Diana Ross, suspected that ''someday'' would ever come to pass.

That did not bother my planemate so much because she believed him when he said the woman came after him, and so did the jury at the trial. The inflatable kiddie pool, once reserved for Shirley Temple drinkers, is making a splash at grown-up cocktail parties, even among those who don't have a kiddie to go with their pool. Erik Hanson, a painter, gave a shin-soaking shindig last month at his Peekskill, N.Y., home for the opening of an exhibition he coordinated called -- no pun intended -- ''Floating Dialogues: Imagery and Abstraction'' at the Paramount Center for the Arts there. ''Some people didn't want to take their socks off at the party,'' he admitted. ''But with most people, once the ice was broken, a big smile came on their faces.'' Nancy Plominski, a guest at the party, said: ''It was perfect because my feet were killing me. I had on new shoes, and it was so hot that day.''

description: It wasn't a civil action but a civil war. That is how Dan Zegart of Titusville, in Mercer County, characterizes the legal crusade against big tobacco that he followed for five years and recounted in a book that is, in fact, titled ''Civil Warriors.'' A main warrior is Ron Motley of South Carolina, who had made a fortune suing asbestos manufacturers and promised his mother, a lifelong smoker dying of emphysema, that he would punish those responsible for her death. What followed is a tale of other determined lawyers, secret informers (one is called Deep Cough) and scientists willing to tell the truth about the tobacco companies who had employed them. Many of these people received death threats, and some scientists were advised by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to check their cars for bombs every morning. Mr. Zegart traveled with the lawyers and looked at thousands of pages of documents, weaving it all in with courtroom drama that reads like a novel. ''Civil Warriors,'' published in hard cover by Bantam Dell, is $25.95.

description: SCHWARTZ-Henry. 84, of Delray Beach, died July 2, 2000 after a brief illness. Mr. Schwartz was born May 16, 1916 in Brooklyn, New York, and moved to Delray Beach in 1981 from Floral Park, NY. He was a dress salesman for 48 years, before his retirement in 1981. He was a volunteer for the South County Mental Health Center, Delray Beach, FL and received their Volunteer award for distinguished service. Mr. Schwartz always said, ''I'm very content with my lot in life.'' He served in the U.S. Army Air Corps as a seargent and weather observer during World War II. Surviving are his wife of 51 years, Martha of Delray Beach, FL; son, Mitchell Schwartz of Lexington, OH; daughters, Nina Schwartz of Jacksonville, FL and Jill Rowan of Tallahassee, FL; sister, Mae DeCasare of Trenton, NJ; and six grandchildren. But what the San Francisco 49ers perfected in the last 20 years on offense and what the St. Louis Rams exuded last season in winning the Super Bowl has escaped the Giants. title: AFFILIATED COMPUTER SERVICES SELLING A.T.M. UNIT
description: Affiliated Computer Services Inc., which processes transactions for automated teller machines, agreed yesterday to sell its A.T.M. unit to the closely held Genpass Inc. for about $180 million in the first in a series of planned divestitures. The computer-services company said it planned to sell other assets by Sept. 30, mainly in its commercial services and systems-integration division. It did not immediately identify the businesses it would put on the block. Affiliated Computer Services, based in Dallas, said the A.T.M. unit and the assets scheduled for sale together accounted for about 15 percent of the company's revenue, which totaled $1.6 billion in 1999. The closely held Genpass is a newly formed company financed by GTCR Golder Rauner, a Chicago-based private equity firm.

description: The Mott's unit of Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. agreed yesterday to acquire the Mauna La'i brand from Mauna La'i Tropicals Ltd. The purchase price was not disclosed. Mott's, based in Stamford, Conn., which makes Mott's applesauce and Hawaiian Punch fruit drink, said the Mauna La'i brand was a line of tropical juice drinks that had sales of more than $20 million last year. The deal does not include any manufacturing facilities or equipment.

title: Studies Find Young Saltwater Fish Returning to the Fold
description: The typical saltwater fish's childhood is something of a lost time, at least for scientists trying to study it. Not much is known about what happens during most fishes' larval stages, when they are tiny and floating in the plankton in the swirling waters. And that has led to a great question in marine ecology: are fish populations open, with young fish shuttling in and out across great distances, or closed, with juveniles largely settling back where they were born?

title: Washington Reneges on a Bargain
description: Congress made a welfare deal with the states in 1996 that it now threatens to tarnish. Under the deal, the states relinquished their 60-year-old entitlement to additional federal money when their welfare rolls rise. In exchange, every state received a big fixed annual grant to cover its welfare costs. Congress also gave 17 needy states extra help in the form of supplemental grants. Congress now threatens to reclaim part of these supplemental grants.

title: N.T.T. RETREATS ON CONNECTION FEES
description: Shares of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, Japan's former telephone monopoly, climbed 6.4 percent after the company indicated it would bow to pressure to lower fees it charges other carriers to hook into its local network at a faster pace. N.T.T. also sharply increased its earnings forecasts to 172 billion yen from 99 billion yen because of growing dial-up Internet use by consumers. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

Unibanco agreed to buy Bandeirantes, Brazil's 18th biggest bank, from Caixa Geral de Depositos of Portugal. In the share swap, Caixa Geral gets a 14.8 percent stake in Unibanco. Producer prices -- the prices of goods ranging from textiles to cars as they leave the factory -- gained 0.9 percent from April and 6.4 percent from May 1999. The rise exceeded forecasts. Italy's annual inflation has exceeded the European Central Bank's threshold of 2 percent for seven months running.

title: A Threat By Austria On Sanctions
description: Austria's frustration over European Union sanctions, which had largely degenerated into a long-distance cat fight between Austria and France, led over the weekend to threats to block European expansion.

title: Naval Academy Athletes Charged With Rape
description: Two star football players at the United States Naval Academy were charged today with raping a female midshipman at a party off-campus, the police and officials at the academy said.

title: BT CELLNET FACES CHARGE
description: The telecommunications regulatory agency in Britain, Oftel, accused the wireless unit of British Telecommunications, BT Cellnet, of unfairly subsidizing its own customers by overcharging third-party operators that pay for access to use BT's wireless network. British Telecommunication denied the charge. Oftel mandates that BT Cellnet and Vodafone AirTouch allow third-party operators to resell air time on their networks at wholesale costs because of their dominant market positions in Britain. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: New-Look Isles Sign Haller as Free Agent
description: The Islanders continued their active off-season yesterday by signing Kevin Haller, a free-agent defenseman who played with Anaheim last season.

title: Teachers Union Leaders Oppose Push to Testing at the Expense of Curriculum
description: The leaders of the two national teachers unions today harshly criticized the movement to raise academic standards in public schools for misplaced priorities, each saying at their union conventions that politicians and educators should focus more on developing challenging curriculum and less on testing students.

title: Internal Inquiry Falls Short, Some Victims Contend
description: To Police Commissioner Howard Safir, the release of details yesterday of the department's investigation of its handling of the National Puerto Rican Day Parade and the Central Park sex attacks was a forthright and scalding self-analysis, a case of the police pursuing their own faults with vigor and speed.

title: Power to the People
description: To the Editor:

title: Uriah Jones 2nd, 75, a Pioneer for Black Fencers in the U.S.
description: Uriah Jones 2nd, who in 1968 became the first African-American to make a United States Olympic fencing team and who will be inducted into the United States Fencing Hall of Fame today, died June 14. He was 75.

title: Catholics in Essex County Get New Spiritual Leader
description: Pope John Paul II has chosen a son of Newark and a longtime educator to be the spiritual leader of Roman Catholics in Essex County, N.J., the Archdiocese of Newark announced yesterday.

title: Sorting Out Delusions In Therapy
description: When I spotted my new patient in the psychiatry ward in the small hours of the morning, she was in the custody of two police officers and was naked except for a toga made of brightly flowered sheets.

title: THE MEXICAN ELECTION: Man in the News; The 'Sell Me' Politician the Mexicans Bought
description: The confirmation of his election as president of Mexico was still hours away, the victory real only in the computers of his pollsters, but Vicente Fox Quesada was already three steps down the road. There would be a quick sip of Champagne, a victory speech, and then he would get to work.

title: Les Sirkin, 66; Geologist Studied How Glaciers Shaped Coastlines
description: Dr. Les Sirkin, a geologist who mapped the ways glaciers shaped Northern American coastlines from Long Island to Baja California, died on June 25 at his summer home on Block Island, R.I. Formerly of Garden City, N.Y., he was 66 and lived in Johnsburg, N.Y.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PREVENTION; Extra Benefit From Chickenpox Vaccine
description: The introduction of the chickenpox vaccine caused the number of cases in Los Angeles County to fall by 80 percent from 1995 to 1999, according to a study conducted by the county and the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: The Big City; A Tea Party Like Boston's, Over Wine?
description: TODAY, as we celebrate our independence from one form of tyranny, many New Yorkers may be consorting with a new foreign menace. They may be drinking out-of-state wine.

title: The Left-Handed Jones Starts Today
description: The Mets will start Bobby M. Jones against the Marlins on Tuesday afternoon, giving the left-hander his first start in the majors this year.

title: The Highest Honor
description: In late June 1776, British ships from Halifax appeared off Sandy Hook, N.J., just beyond the Narrows from the tip of Manhattan. The ships' masts resembled ''a wood of pine trees trimmed,'' one observer wrote. Soon British soldiers had landed on Staten Island and their flotilla was anchored offshore. On July 9, a Tuesday, Gen. George Washington mustered his troops in New York City for the reading, ''with an audible voice,'' of the Declaration of Independence, which had been signed five days earlier. The purpose was to inform each soldier gathered there that ''he is now in the service of a State, possessed of sufficient power to reward his merit, and advance him to the highest Honors of a free Country.''

title: Successful Recycling
description: To the Editor:

title: Brownstone (the Real Thing) Comes Back
description: Mike Meehan, a geologist who once explored for coal in the Appalachian Mountains, is supervising a crew of four men and a canary yellow backhoe, clawing away at the cliffs of the country's only operating brownstone quarry, trying to fill the orders that pour in every day.

title: Why I'm Running: The Nader Critique
description: To the Editor:

title: BIOSHIELD TECHNOLOGIES AGREES TO BUY AHT
description: BioShield Technologies Inc., which makes antimicrobial coating products, has agreed to buy the AHT Corporation for $20 million in stock to get AHT's software that allows doctors to send prescriptions electronically to pharmacies. BioShield Technologies will pay $1.75 of BioShield common stock for each share of AHT, which is based in Tarrytown, N.Y. That is 13 percent below AHT's closing price of $2 on Friday, although 87 percent more than AHT's all-time closing low of 93.75 cents on May 1. AHT's shares have fallen 68 percent this year, and it has lost money for the last eight quarters. Shares of BioShield fell 50 cents, to $11.50, while AHT declined 50 cents, to $1.50.

title: Stanley Ogilvy, 87, Sailor and Writer, Dies
description: C. Stanley Ogilvy, a mathematics professor who fell in love with the endless and evanescent possibilities of the ocean breeze, writing books about sailing as well as geometry, died on June 21 at his home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. He was 87.

title: TRADE FIGHT OVER RUM TRADEMARK
description: The European Union plans to ask the World Trade Organization to set up a panel to resolve a dispute with the United States over the use of the Havana Club rum trademark. The union is contesting a 1998 American law requiring foreign companies seeking to register trademarks that once belonged to companies expropriated by the Cuban communist authorities to get the original owner's permission. A United States appeals court invoked the law against a French-Cuban joint venture when it tried to defend the Havana Club trade name against the Bermuda-based Bacardi Ltd. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Lost Rivets and Threads, and Ecosystems Pulled Apart
description: In trying to illuminate what humans are doing to the natural environment, scientists and conservationists over the years have come up with a number of descriptive images. One of the best known is the metaphor of the rivets.

title: CATELLUS DEVELOPMENT TO SELL HOME-BUILDING BUSINESS
description: The Catellus Development Corporation, a large property developer in the western United States, agreed yesterday to sell most of its home-building operations to a new limited liability company managed by the Brookfield Properties Corporation. Catellus will sell about 900 lots with a projected value of about $130 million to the new company, called Brookfield Homes of California Inc. In return, Catellus will receive $147.5 million in cash and $22.5 million in retained interest in the new company. Brookfield, a large Canadian real estate company, plans to invest $22.5 million. Another $125 million in financing is being arranged with a group of banks led by the Bank of America Corporation. The shares of Catellus rose $1.625 each, to $16.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Williams Puts Value in Hard Work
description: There has been a significant change in Bernie Williams's life since he became the highest-paid player in Yankees history, he thinks: how others are observing him.

title: VITAL SIGNS: TREATMENTS; Getting Aggressive in Sickle Cell Fight
description: The most detailed study to date of the acute respiratory attacks suffered by sickle cell anemia patients has led researchers to call for more aggressive tactics in diagnosis and treatment.

title: Sports of The Times; Illuminating An Obscure R.B.I. Record
description: AT first glance, the streak seems to be one of those arcane achievements that only a statistics freak could know or care about. How significant could it be that Mike Piazza was approaching the major league record for driving in runs in consecutive games when the record-holder wasn't Hack Wilson or Lou Gehrig or Babe Ruth or anyone else of that stature?

title: Myth and Superstition in Ancient Medicine
description: ''The Mysteries Within: A Surgeon Reflects on Medical Myths'' by Dr. Sherwin B. Nuland (Simon & Schuster, 2000).

title: Gambill Earns an Appearance on Center Court
description: Jan-Michael Gambill was too numb from his victory today to let the reality of playing Pete Sampras in the quarterfinals on Wednesday crash his feel-good moment.

title: Greek Myths: Not Necessarily Mythical
description: Neither an archaeologist nor a paleontologist herself, Adrienne Mayor has nonetheless done some digging deep into the past and found literary and artistic clues -- and not a few huge fossils -- that seem to explain the inspiration for many of the giants, monsters and other strange creatures in the mythology of antiquity.

title: Truth About Alcohol
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Memo; Mayor Takes Issue With Issue of His Health
description: It has become an almost weekly routine. Reporters press Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for details on his cancer treatment deliberations. The mayor, sometimes in an irritated voice, other times in a stern but calm way, then tells them, in essence, to bug off.

title: Janus Fund Has Sales of $471 Million
description: The Janus Capital Corporation's newest fund, the Janus Orion fund, had $471 million in sales directly through Janus in its subscription phase, according to a spokeswoman for Janus, the fifth-largest United States mutual fund company.

title: Hingis Waltzes Into the Quarters For a Dance With Venus Williams
description: The wicked edges that typically mark the corners of Martina Hingis's mischievous Garfield smile suddenly vanished. At the mention of Venus and Serena Williams today, Hingis was less biting and all but cuddly as she unveiled a humble front.

title: Front Row
description: Singing, but Not for His Supper

title: BALFOUR BEATTY ACQUIRES INTEGRAL TECHNOLOGIES
description: Balfour Beatty P.L.C., an international engineering, construction and services group, said yesterday that it had acquired Integral Technologies Inc. for up to $50 million. Integral, a privately held company based in Indianapolis, Ind., develops digital imaging software and products for the security industry. Balfour Beatty, a British company, will pay $30 million in cash upon completion of the acquisition, with a further $20 million payable against the achievements of agreed financial targets.

title: Online School Plans I.P.O.
description: Online School Plans I.P.O.

title: A Bird Gains Species Status After a Life in the Shadows
description: Like a new image suddenly materializing on a tapestry, a new species of bird has emerged from research in the sagebrush ecosystem of western Colorado and eastern Utah, according to scientists working there.

title: Avoiding Seasickness
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Music to Hail A First Lady

title: Mother, I'm the Boss Now; Internet Executives Hire Their Parents And Traditions Fall
description: In some ways Lucille Lee is typical of many people who have cast their lot with Silicon Valley start-ups. Early last year, after many years as a software systems architect at I.B.M., she joined eCircles.com, a service based in San Mateo, Calif., for building virtual meeting places, where she puts in 60 to 70 hours a week as director of applications development.

title: Political Machine Dependent on Power Loses Its Power
description: The Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has governed Mexico since 1929, was formed to bring order out of the chaos of the Mexican Revolution.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: INFOCROSSING, Leonia, N.J., named Charles F. Auster president and chief executive. He had been executive vice president and chief operating officer at IXnet.

title: Specialist in Appeals Cases Is Added to Microsoft Team
description: The Microsoft Corporation added more firepower to the defense team in its antitrust case yesterday by hiring Carter G. Phillips, one of the nation's leading appellate lawyers.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Rolf Mageren, a German businessman who escaped a World War II British internment camp in India disguised as an Englishman, misstated the date of his death. It was May 5, not June 3.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT FALLS. Wheat plunged more than 5 percent on signs that increased spring planting this year will mean bumper crops. In Chicago, wheat for September delivery fell 13.75 cents, or 5.1 percent, to $2.575 a bushel.

title: Foreign Affairs; Just Do It
description: As it says in Ecclesiastes, for everything there is a season -- a time to be born and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to pluck up what is planted. The same is true in diplomacy -- there is a time to stall and a time to yak, a time to hide and a time to decide. For Israelis and Palestinians, this is the season for deciding, and President Clinton should usher it in by summoning the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to Camp David for one last cards-on-the-table, in-your-face, put-up-or-shut-up summit to finally, finally put an end to this conflict.

title: P.L.O. Decides on Early Statehood Move
description: Leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization decided late tonight in Gaza City that a Palestinian state should be declared by mid-September, whether or not a permanent peace deal has been reached with the Israelis.

title: 9 POLICE OFFICERS FACING  DISCIPLINE IN  PARK ATTACKS
description: Nine New York police officers, including six supervisors, will be disciplined for mistakes that allowed an unruly mob to turn a section of Central Park into a menacing gantlet where men sexually assaulted dozens of women after the National Puerto Rican Day Parade, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday.

title: A Few Ways to Spend $60 Billion
description: To the Editor:

title: Manufacturing Growth Rate Is the Slowest in 17 Months
description: Manufacturing expanded in June at the slowest pace in 17 months as companies started to feel the effects of six interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve the last year, new figures showed today.

title: True Blue Fireworks Made in China
description: The rockets' red glare, the bombs bursting in air, will give proof tonight that America's trade deficit with China is still there.

title: In a Miasma of Darkness, With No Parent or Wise One to Guide Them Out
description: WHAT WE DON'T KNOW ABOUT CHILDREN

title: Making Some Trauma of Heart Surgery Disappear
description: James Houpt was practicing magic tricks in front of his mirror recently, making coins disappear, when a reporter called to ask about his health. Mr. Houpt said he was fine. In fact, he had walked two-thirds of a mile that day. ''What's the big deal?'' he asked.

title: Shift in the Mix Alters the Face Of California
description: At some unknown moment between now and July 1, 2001, if demographers are right, California will become the first big state in which non-Hispanic whites are officially no longer a majority. Or, to put it another way, California will become by far the largest proving ground for what it may eventually be like to live in a United States in which no one racial or ethnic group predominates.

title: The Prize for Reality Is $1 Million. Isn't That Unreal?
description: It's a safe guess that few of the millions of young and middle-aged fans of ''Survivor,'' the smash hit CBS specimen of ''reality television,'' have ever heard of Daniel J. Boorstin. Yet the show's arrival certifies Professor Boorstin as a prophet in his time. (Speaking of prophecy, CBS is banking on a second reality series, ''Big Brother,'' which begins tomorrow and continues for five nights a week, to give a further lift to its ratings.)

title: A Crowning Defeat: Mexico as the Victor
description: At 11 p.m., with the returns showing that Vicente Fox Quesada had seized the presidency from the governing party, the man who went before the nation to concede defeat was not the losing candidate, but President Ernesto Zedillo.

title: Mexico's Democratic Breakthrough
description: Never before in the memory of living Mexicans has presidential power passed peacefully to an opposition party. But just such a transition is now under way, following the decisive victory of Vicente Fox Quesada and his center-right National Action Party, or PAN, in Sunday's Mexican elections. It is a great advance for democracy in Latin America's second-largest country and Washington's second-biggest trading partner.

title: Brazil Pulls Out of Bidding Process
description: Brazil dropped its bid to play host to the 2006 World Cup yesterday and threw its support (and the votes of the two other South American representatives on FIFA's committee) to South Africa.

title: Americans Capture Gold Cup In Rematch
description: Having relied on a coin toss to prevail over Brazil earlier in the Gold Cup, the United States achieved a more satisfying result tonight with a 1-0 victory in an important tuneup for the Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia.

title: Q & A
description: Facts of Life for Whales

title: PGA Seeks A Review Of Cart Suit
description: Does the Americans With Disabilities Act trump the authority of golf's organizing bodies to make their own rules? Or are professional golf organizations exempt from the act because the competitive nature of the sport would be forever changed?

title: INFORMIX WARNS ON PROFITS AND SHARES TUMBLE
description: Shares of the Informix Corporation fell nearly 37 percent yesterday, hitting a 52-week low, after the company, a software maker, said its second-quarter earnings would be below expectations. The stock closed at $4.6875, down $2.75, in Nasdaq trading. In addition, Informix, based in Menlo Park, Calif., said its acquisition of Ardent Software, which was completed on March 1, would not add to earnings for 2000, as previously expected. Informix said it expected to earn 1 to 3 cents a share for the quarter ended June 30, well below the 12 cents predicted by analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial.

title: Mexico's Moment; The Freedom to Oust
description: To the Editor:

title: Satellite Observes Solar Flares' Snap, Crackle and Pop
description: Like the painter Winslow Homer, who dismissed the North Atlantic as ''a duck pond'' when it was not blowing a good storm, solar physicists find the sun most fascinating when its atmosphere is erupting, flaring and flinging energetic particles into space.

title: ANTISMUGGLING MOVE IN CHINA
description: China said it would concentrate its export processing industry in 15 special zones to restrict smuggling and other illegal activities. Companies that import materials for processing and re-export will be required to operate in the zones, according to the state-owned Business Weekly. Many products now imported duty free for processing end up on the domestic market. Under the new plan, all goods sold from the zones to the rest of China would be taxed as foreign trade. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Survey Finds Snacks Driving Up Movie Costs
description: The cost of watching the latest Mel Gibson or George Clooney blockbuster has not risen much in the last year. But the price of a night at the movies for New Yorkers is mounting, mainly because the price of soda and popcorn has shot up an average of 6 percent citywide, according to an annual survey of movie theaters across the five boroughs.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''For me it is as if I had a new child. One hopes with great anxiety that he will be a good child.''

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Fishing for a Rebounder With Camby as the Bait
description: With a rebounding deficiency having paved their way to an early postseason exit, the Knicks hope to secure a menacing power forward during this month of shopping and recruiting in the National Basketball Association. While Sacramento's Chris Webber, who is not a free agent, would be a dream acquisition, the Knicks have their eyes set on two more realistic possibilities, Portland's Brian Grant and Boston's Danny Fortson.

title: The Invisible Matthau
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore and Bush Agree on Basics, But Differ Sharply on the Details
description: With their competing array of policy speeches, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush seem to be turning this election into a referendum on which candidate can best reshape government to meet the challenges of the New Economy.

title: VITAL SIGNS: CAUSE AND EFFECT; When School Brings On the Migraines
description: Migraine headaches strike teenagers most commonly on Mondays and most rarely on Saturdays, according to a study presented in June at a conference of the American Headache Society in Montreal.

title: Much-Derided Gettysburg Observation Tower Is Felled
description: One hundred and thirty-seven years after Union troops bested Gen. Robert E. Lee and his Confederate legions in their desperate gamble known as Pickett's charge, the National Park Service today demolished an observation tower that has been a magnet for criticism from historians, park officials and battlefield preservationists.

title: VITAL SIGNS: REMEDIES; A Weapon Is Found to Fight Scleroderma
description: A hormone produced in pregnancy has been found to reduce symptoms of scleroderma, a debilitating skin disease that has previously been considered untreatable, according to a study in last month's issue of The Annals of Internal Medicine.

title: British Wireless Venture Is in Talks to Sell a Stake
description: A British wireless telephone venture backed by the Hong Kong conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa and Telesystem International Wireless of Canada is in talks to sell about a third of the company to NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest mobile phone company, and Royal KPN, the Dutch mobile phone operator, for as much as $2 billion, executives close to the discussions said today.

title: E-Signing Law Seen as a Boon To E-Business
description: The law President Clinton signed last week allowing businesses and consumers to seal a variety of legally binding arrangements with electronic rather than handwritten signatures raised the speed limit on e-business development, analysts say.

title: 'Pomp and Circumstance' (They're Only 5)
description: To the Editor:

title: Beset by Critics, Utica Mayor Resigns, Citing Health Issues
description: The colorful mayor of the chronically depressed upstate city of Utica, Edward A. Hanna, resigned last night.

title: JAPANESE BAILOUT CRITICIZED
description: The credit rating agency Standard & Poor's panned the Japanese government's decision to bail out a struggling department store operator, the Sogo Company, calling it ''a potentially hazardous twist on Japan's road to financial reform.'' The agency, which has maintained its triple-A rating on Japan's sovereign debt while its competitors Moody's Investors Service and Fitch IBCA have downgraded it, said the government's forgiveness of some 97 billion yen in Sogo debt would sharply decrease pressure on the company to overhaul its operations. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: Echoes of Elian; A Father's Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Settle for the Real Fireworks?
description: Sure, the fireworks tonight will be spectacular. They're spectacular every year, and this time they're supposed to be bigger than ever.

title: Public Interests; A Fourth Of July Address
description: My fellow Americans.

title: Perils of Gene Manipulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Mapei Rider Is First for Second Time
description: Tom Steels, a Belgian with Mapei, won his second successive stage today by sprinting to victory in the 100-mile race from the hospitable town of Loudun to this city in western France.

title: Russia's President Hints He'll Act to Stem Inflation
description: Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, warned today that inflation is rising an annual rate of nearly 35 percent, a trend economists say could severely strain incomes of ordinary Russians.

title: VERIZON PUTS GTE CABLE SYSTEMS UP FOR SALE
description: Verizon Communications, the telephone company formed last week when the Bell Atlantic Corporation bought the GTE Corporation, is trying to sell GTE cable systems in Florida, California and Hawaii valued at an estimated $615 million. GTE recently hired Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment bank, to help it sell the cable systems with 123,000 subscribers, a spokeswoman, Bobbi Hennessey, said. Bell Atlantic completed the purchase of GTE on Friday, creating the largest local phone company in the United States. In its first day of trading, Verizon's shares rose $4.625 each yesterday, to $55, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: French Bishop, Disciplined Over 'Gay Pride' Issue, Still Speaks Out in Rome
description: Skirting a Vatican order to withdraw from a gay pride seminar on religion and homosexuality, Bishop Jacques Gaillot sat on a couch outside the hotel conference room today and explained where he thinks the Roman Catholic Church has erred.

title: In Mexico, a New Era and . . . a New Deal?
description: What does the election on Sunday mean for the future of Mexico?

title: For Some at Beach, Ocean Is Invitation To Tempt Fate; Despite Recent Drownings, Rules and Warnings Are Ignored
description: As the sun was setting last Wednesday, two hours after the lifeguards had left their perches along Rockaway Beach in Queens and whistled everyone out of the water, the Atlantic Ocean, wild and menacing as it can be on that vast sandy stretch of New York City, was still too tempting for some to resist.

title: U.S. Seeks China's Help in Slowing the Flood of Illegal Immigrants
description: The head of the American Immigration and Naturalization Service held talks here today with Chinese officials, hoping to get a commitment for more help in stemming the huge flow of illegal Chinese immigrants into the United States.

title: With Light Show, Jersey City Hopes to Make a New Name for Itself
description: Call it a case of light-show envy.

title: Rikers Guard Is Charged With Raping An Inmate
description: A guard at the women's jail on Rikers Island was arrested yesterday and charged with the rape of a 34-year-old inmate on Friday. He was suspended without pay pending the outcome of the case.

title: 5-Year-Old Critically Injured In Amusement Park Accident
description: A 5-year-old Connecticut boy who nearly drowned on Saturday after riding an amusement park water slide remained in critical condition yesterday at a children's hospital in Hartford.

title: Plane Towing Ad Crashes At Airport, Killing Pilot
description: The pilot of a small plane towing an advertising banner was killed yesterday in a crash at a municipal airport near the Jersey Shore.

title: Casting Into Past for Striped Bass Heaven
description: The boulders that loom in the shallows of Point Judith, R.I., are debris from the last ice age, having been scoured off the underlying stone some 12,000 years ago, only to be scattered, like so much construction rubble, when the ice retreated from the mouth of Narragansett Bay.

title: The Truest Measure of Patriotism
description: Commodore Stephen Decatur, freshly returned in 1816 from subduing the Dey of Algiers and swollen with nationalist fervor, rose to his feet at a banquet in Norfolk, Va., and offered a notorious toast. ''Our country!'' he said, glass held aloft. ''May she always be in the right; but our country, right or wrong.'' Decatur's salute is often cited as the quintessence of American patriotic feeling. It's also the kind of remark that has given patriotism a bad name.

title: INSIDE
description: Waging War on Syphilis

title: Big U.S. Automakers' Sales Dropped 1.4% Last Month
description: Americans bought fewer autos from General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler than expected in June, opting to buy vehicles made by Japanese and European companies or to keep the vehicles they own.

title: Film Fantasy As a Tonic For Refugee Children
description: It sounds like something out of a 1940's film archive: a group of Americans, driven by great human suffering, travel to a strange foreign land to offer succor to the needy. But this isn't a movie, though it is humanitarianism, Hollywood style.

title: OFFER FOR FRENCH RAILWAY COMPANY
description: A unit of ABN Amro Capital Investissement France has offered $427.8 million for a French railway equipment, engineering and forestry company De Dietrich. In a statement, the Paris stock exchange regulatory agency said companies owned by the Duval-Fleury family had agreed to sell their 21.7 percent stake in De Dietrich to the unit, Societe Industrielle du Hanau.

title: Saudi Arabia to Raise Oil Production 500,000 Barrels a Day
description: In a move to bring down stubbornly high oil prices, Saudi Arabia, the world's largest exporter of crude oil, announced plans yesterday to increase production by 500,000 barrels a day.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Sales in June for Big Three Were Less Than Expected

title: Corrections
description: A list of viewing locations in Weekend on Friday in a section on the Op Sail 2000 parade of tall ships on the Hudson River today misidentified some usable stretches of shoreline. Construction from 56th Street to 72nd Street makes that area unsuitable. The best viewing sites in Riverside Park are from 72nd Street to 82nd Street and from 101st to 110th Streets.

title: Oil Supply to Rise
description: Saudi Arabia announced plans to increase production, a move that could bring down high oil prices. But the increase would most likely not affect gas prices this summer.

title: Police May Drop Charge Against Fan
description: Local law enforcement officials were skeptical yesterday that the fan who was arrested for throwing a baseball onto the Shea Stadium outfield near John Rocker would be prosecuted. But prosecutors in Queens said they had not yet reached a decision on the merits of the case.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Belton, Tex.

title: Corrections
description: The E-Commerce Report in Business Day yesterday about companies that enable consumers to review the personal data that companies have collected about them misspelled the name of one of the companies. It is the Acxiom Corporation, not Axciom.

title: Change in Leadership Is Welcomed as an Opportunity for Greater U.S.-Mexican Cooperation
description: The Clinton administration welcomed the transition of power in Mexico, saying today that the election of Vicente Fox Quesada was evidence of the maturing of democratic institutions and that it set the stage for economic growth.

title: 'Lucia,' Move Over: 'Jane Eyre' as Opera
description: About 100 miles west of London, Cheltenham grew up two centuries ago as a spa town, for which purpose it acquired fine public buildings, a few comfortable hotels and street after street of modestly handsome houses faced with honey-colored stone from the local Cotswolds. Behind those regular, flat facades it would be easy to imagine families of Jane Austen characters who have arrived to take the curative waters, stroll in the parks and dance with young officers. Now, though, the place has to find other ways to attract visitors and to serve its permanent population, which includes a high proportion of retired people.

title: A Few Ways to Spend $60 Billion
description: To the Editor:

title: SIEMENS TO SELL EXCHANGEABLE BONDS
description: Germany's biggest electronics maker, Siemens A.G., is selling as much as 2.5 billion euros ($2.4 billion) in five-year bonds exchangeable into stock of Infineon, a German chip maker. Siemens, which owns 71 percent of Infineon, is selling 2 billion euros in 1 percent bonds and may sell another 500 million if demand warrants. They can be exchanged for Infineon shares, which have more than doubled since March, as of August next year. Several German companies are selling exchangeable bonds to reduce their holdings. As the government plans to slash a tax on such divestments, more bond sales are likely.

title: Devils Add More Muscle
description: The Devils added a little more muscle yesterday to an already physical team by signing Jim McKenzie, a free-agent left wing, who is 6 feet 4 inches, weighs 230 pounds and has firmly established a reputation for fighting.

title: Virtual Reality Finds a Real Place as a Medical Aid
description: James Pokorny sat upright in bed in his room at the University of Washington Burn Center at Harborview as a nurse prepared to unwrap his bandages. Working on a car when the fuel tank exploded, Mr. Pokorny received third-degree burns on about 42 percent of his body.

title: Mexico's Moment

title: Review/Fashion; The Apotheosis Of the Hustler: A Morality Cycle

title: EGL AGREES TO BUY CIRCLE INTERNATIONAL
description: EGL Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Circle International Group in a $543 million stock swap that will create a global freight transportation company with combined revenues of $1.4 billion. Each of Circle's common shares will be converted into one share of EGL common stock, valuing San Francisco-based Circle at $543 million, based on EGL's closing share price on Friday. Shares of EGL, which is based in Houston, fell $2.5156, to $28.2343 on the Nasdaq stock market while Circle shares rose $2.3125, to $27.4375. The combined company will have more than 8,300 employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTONE, ABRAHAM M.
description: GOLDSTONE-Abraham M. Of Forest Hills, NY and Bethlehem, NH, and formerly of Brooklyn, NY, passed away on July 4, 2000 at the age of 91. He was a graduate of Brown University and received his Master's from Columbia's Teachers College. After 37 years of service for the City of New York, he retired as Special Assistant to New York City's Director of Personnel, Harry I. Bronstein in 1974. Beloved son of Sarah and Jacob, he was the youngest brother of Rebecca, Al, Lou, Irving and Pearl. Adored by his wife Harriet, and his children, the late Susan and David, Abe was devoted to his family including his wife's mother, Anna Bloch, her twin sister Charlotte Schecter, his three wonderful nieces, Gail, Diane and Debbie, his daughter-inlaw Dorothy, and his beloved grandchildren, Joey, Daniel and Jenny. There was no limit to his generosity, love of learning, loyalty, friendship, and devotion to Judaism. He will be sorely missed by everyone whose life he touched from the Bethlehem Hebrew Congregation to the Jewish Communal Center in Brooklyn to Temple Gates of Prayer in Flushing. He is survived by his loving son, David, and his three grandchildren. Services Thursday, July 6, at 9:30 AM at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, New York. Shiva will be observed at David's home. Information: 718445-0300 or 718-261-7161.

title: IRISH BUDGET SURPLUS OF $3.5 BILLION
description: The Irish Department of Finance reported a budget surplus of 2.9 billion Irish pounds ($3.5 billion) for the first six months of the year, an increase of 44 percent over the comparable period in 1999. Government revenues from income tax increased 15 percent, despite the introduction of significant tax cuts in January. With increased spending the rest of the year, the Exchequer now anticipates a year-end surplus of 1.8 billion Irish pounds ($2.2 billion). Brian Lavery

title: MILITARY CONTRACT SECURED
description: A state-owned military contractor, Israeli Aircraft Industries, won a $270 million contract to build a spy satellite for Turkey based on its own Ofek reconnaissance satellite, company officials said yesterday, confirming Turkish news reports. France's Alcatel had also bid for the contract. The Israeli company is competing against United States and European concerns for a $4 billion helicopter order and a $1 billion airborne radar contract scheduled to be awarded by the Turkish military this year. William A. Orme Jr.

title: Reckonings; Mexico's New Deal
description: When things went wrong for global capitalism in the 20th century -- and they often did -- they tended to go wrong first in Mexico. The Victorian version of globalization -- which depended either on colonialism, or on the support of domestic elites so disconnected from the local population that they might as well have been colonists -- began to fall apart in 1911, when Mexicans rebelled against the rule of the ''scientific'' dictator Porfirio Diaz. The cocksure optimism of ''emerging market'' investors in the early 90's got its first serious warning at the end of 1994, when Mexico plunged into financial crisis -- a crisis that proved to be a dress rehearsal for the terrifying Asian crisis that began 30 months later.

While Salus officials said no agreement on a sale had been reached, an AmBev spokeswoman said the transaction would involve the purchase of about 60 percent of Salus. So far the company has not disclosed a value for the transaction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, DOROTHY HEALEY
description: CARR-Dorothy Healey, born on July 17, 1917, loving wife of Peter, & mother of Kevin, Brian, Michael, Kelly Anne & Colin, passed away peacefully June 25, 2000 at the San Diego Hospice. Dorothy suffered with CHF, COPD, HTN, Dementia of Alzheimer's Type. Following a family service at the Church of Nativity, Rancho Santa Fe, CA, her ashes were scattered at sea. After graduating Cum Laude from Trinity College, Washington D.C., Dorothy served in the last class of The Women's Auxiliary Service Pilots (WASPS) in World War II. Dorothy & Peter Carr were married January 23, 1954 at St. Patrick's Cathedral, NY where they resided until they moved to Greenwich, CT. in 1957. In 1983, the Carrs moved to Rancho Santa Fe, CA. In addition to her husband, Peter, Dorothy is survived by four of their five children. Michael passed away in 1995. Kevin, wife Randa & daughter Caroline reside in Simsbury, CT. Brian, his wife Nancy & their children Ryan, Victoria & Daniel are living in Cos Cob, CT. Kelly Anne, husband Neil Winterbottom & two girls, Caitlin & Jennifer live in San Mateo, CA. Colin currently resides in Terrebonne, OR. Those wishing to honor the memory of Dorothy Carr may make donations to the San Diego Hospice, 4311 Third Avenue, San Diego, CA. 92103.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, DUDLEY DEVORE
description: ROBERTS-Dudley DeVore. On July 3, 2000, at the age of 90 at his home in East Hampton, NY. Mr. Roberts was founder and President of Cinerama Productions, which pioneered wide-screen movies. He also founded Roberts & Company, an investment banking firm which later merged with Kidder, Peabody. During World War II Mr. Roberts served in the FBI's Special Intelligence Unit which was created by J. Edgar Hoover to handle highly sensitive missions worldwide. Mr. Roberts was the second American to receive a commercial pilot's license. He also was a world-class sports fisherman & noted amateur golfer. He served as President of The Maidstone Club from 1957-1961. Mr. Roberts is survived by his wife Laura Serra Roberts, three stepchildren, six step-grandchildren and 7 nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held on July 29, at 10:00 AM at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; Recombining Brazil's Cultural Mix

The book repeatedly makes the point that while Brazil never had what it desperately needed at any particular time (coal in the 19th century, gasoline in the 20th, etc.), it constantly revealed new, surprising lodes of natural wealth. The point Zweig was making, at a time when Brazil was in an economic shambles, was that the country always had the power to reinvent itself.

description: SOME restaurants arrive with expectations. Village is one of them. The expectations swirl around Stephen Lyle, Village's owner and chef, who made his mark at Quatorze and the Odeon, restaurants that pulled off the difficult feat of serving top-quality food in a hip environment. Quatorze, which opened in 1984 and closed a decade later, was the bistro that showed how a bistro should be done, years ahead of the current bistro boom. The Odeon, like Dick Clark, is perpetually ageless and definitively downtown. I never had a bad meal at either place and therefore stepped into Village with soaring hopes.

title: Charles Snitow, an Impresario Of Trade Shows, Dies at 93
description: Charles Snitow, who created some of the nation's largest trade shows and a series of trade fairs in New York that helped open Eastern Europe to commerce during the height of the Cold War, died on June 28 at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y., according to his daughter, Ann. He was 93.

title: A Director Expands Shaw Fest In Canada
description: Sipping a glass of pinot meunier in a local winery, Christopher Newton reminisced about his first few seasons as artistic director of the Shaw Festival. Audiences walked out of his 1980 production of ''The Philanderer,'' and his 1981 plan to stage ''St. Joan'' without its epilogue failed when the Society of Authors threatened to withhold the rights to the play. One critic suggested that Mr. Newton be fired or that the Shaw Festival change its name.

title: Struggling Hudson River Village Seeks Rebirth as a Tourist Haven
description: An odd coalition of idealists and entrepreneurs, ranging from the novelist Toni Morrison to a powerful Westchester County developer, has a vision. The goal is to turn this tattered village with a whopping view of the Hudson River into the next Piermont or Nyack or Cold Spring -- Hudson Valley towns that draw throngs of well-heeled tourists in search of small-town charm and inessentials like potted topiaries and pumpkin butter.

title: Corrections

title: Steep Rise Is Forecast for Winter Heating Bills
