title: Tea? Turmeric? The Quest for Safer Barbecue
description: THE height of the barbecue season is not when anyone wants to hear about the hazards of eating meat with a nicely blackened crust hot off the grill. But scientists have long known that substances created when meat and poultry are cooked at high heat can cause cancer in animals and that there is some evidence that they may have the same effect on humans.

title: Lemonade, From Plain to Perfected
description: FOR a drink that seems quintessentially American, lemonade is at its purest in France. Any cafe there will serve what is called a citron presse, a glass filled partway with pulpy, freshly squeezed lemon juice along with a carafe of water and a jar of simple syrup or superfine sugar for diluting and sweetening to taste. It is the essence of fresh lemons, the antithesis of the artificial or too-sweet lemonades so common in this country, where even children are considered capable of making a pitcherful to sell at a sidewalk stand.

title: A Misguided World Bank Project
description: Tomorrow the World Bank's board of executive directors will consider how to proceed with a $40 million loan to China. The loan would underwrite a dam and irrigation projects in a remote part of western China and resettle 58,000 impoverished Chinese and Hui Muslim farmers in lands that have traditionally been home to Tibetans and Mongol herders. The plan would thus threaten a distinct Tibetan culture, and should be stopped.

title: U.S. INVESTORS LOSE COURT DECISION

Edelman, to wrest control of Societe du Louvre of France from the Taittinger family, a court in Paris rejected a request to reduce the voting rights of the Taittingers, who control 55 percent of the shareholder votes in Societe du Louvre. Mr. Edelman and other American investors have been seeking control of Societe du Louvre; its assets include the elegant Hotel de Crillon in Paris and the Baccarat crystal works. The court ordered Mr. Edelman to pay $33,250 in damages to 23 shareholders of Societe du Louvre, including 20 members of the Taittinger family. The Taittinger family also owns Taittinger Champagne. A lawyer for Mr. Edelman said he would appeal the decision. John Tagliabue

But Royal Kabab and Curry, an unassuming restaurant near Morningside Heights, has perfected this dish, which makes a perfect summer appetizer or, with a double order, just the right light meal.

title: Immigration Injustices
description: With unemployment rates at a 30-year low and strong growth in the high-tech sector, many technology companies are hard pressed to find enough programmers and other skilled workers to meet their needs. One way industry has dealt with the labor shortage has been to hire skilled foreign workers who are allowed to come to this country under special, temporary H-1B visas. But now demand for skilled workers is outstripping the number of such workers allowed in each year by statute. Congress needs to raise the visa cap temporarily to ease the shortages. It should also correct some severe injustices in the immigration laws that have hurt immigrants who have been in this country for more than a decade.

title: KOREAN BANK WORKERS PREPARE TO STRIKE
description: South Koreans braced for impending financial chaos next week as tens of thousands of bank workers supported a nationwide strike set for July 11, according to preliminary results of a vote by some 50,000 industry workers. Around 90 percent of unionized bank workers at 24 financial institutions, including 8 of the nation's 10 major commercial banks, voted in favor of a nationwide strike to protest government plans to restructure the industry, which call for the consolidation of a number of banks. Union workers contended the plans would lead to major layoffs. The final results of the vote, which began on Monday, are expected early today. Samuel Len

title: Deadly Exports
description: New data from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms confirms that people living in states with strict gun laws are not insulated from guns imported from other states. This is largely traceable to Congress's failure to enact nationwide standards on interstate gun trafficking. The data, which appears in a new study by Senator Charles Schumer, the New York Democrat, shows that four states with weak gun control laws -- Florida, Georgia, Mississippi and Texas -- were the source of nearly a quarter of the 30,454 guns used in crimes committed elsewhere last year that could be traced back to dealers.

title: Mack-Cali Buys Buildings

Mack-Cali paid $85 million to buy four buildings that are part of the Mack-Cali Business Campus and Morris County Financial Center in Parsippany, N.J. In a second transaction, Mack-Cali paid $68.8 million to buy two other buildings that are also part of the Parsippany complex. Mack-Cali did not identify the sellers. The moves are part of a strategy by the real estate investment trust to sell buildings with lower growth prospects and reinvest the proceeds in properties with higher rent growth or development potential.

This one, for example, made with grilled scallops and a mesclun mix, takes only 10 minutes longer to make than an ordinary green salad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAYNE, DAVID MACGREGOR
description: PAYNE-David MacGregor of Lyme, Connecticut, peacefully of cancer on July 4, 2000, at Connecticut Hospice, Branford, age 80. A graduate of Yale University (1941), he served in the U.S. Navy during WW II as Commander of a PT boat Squadron in the Pacific. He joined the New York law firm Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam, and Roberts in 1948, retiring as partner in 1985. Inveterate explorer and mountaineer, dedicated bibliophile and community servant, he had also been a member of the Board of Directors of the Lyme Public Library and a Trustee of the Lyme Academy of Fine Arts. He is survived by his wife Sally, daughters Marion P. Klickstein and Margaret P. Lannamann, stepdaughters Lyn Littlefield Hoopes, Carol Littlefield McIntyre, stepsons William Littlefield and John Littlefield, and fourteen grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday July 8, 2000 at 11AM at the First Congregational Church of Lyme, Hamburg Rd (Route 156). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the Middlesex Hospital Hospice Unit, 28 Crescent Street, Middletown CT 06457 or Connecticut Hospice Inc, 110 Barnes St, Branford CT 06405

Planning to pick his pocket, I quickly exit the study, but I've forgotten that between the room and hall carpets there is a brief stretch of wooden floor, and the sound of my boots startles the guard.

title: Europe's Role in Colombia
description: In Madrid tomorrow, officials from industrialized nations and international organizations are meeting to discuss what, if anything, the rest of the world should do for Colombia now that Washington is giving it $1.3 billion -- much of it in the form of helicopters. The group, which is largely European, will not spend the money to match Washington's influence in Colombia. But a well-financed European program with input from Colombian society can help to minimize the chance that the military aid will weaken the civilian government, increase violence against peasants and harm the peace process.

title: The Perfect Equipment For Reading or Fantasizing

Abbey Lee and her husband, Ben, of Lubbock, Tex., own green-eggs.com., which sells a full selection of hammocks, including handmade ones from Mexico and Nicaragua. The site's sales have tripled since last summer. ''It's a great way to relax in a stressful world,'' Ms. Lee said, adding that people seem to like the hand-woven pieces, each one unique. There are countless hammock accessories available online, from stands (for those who don't have trees), pillows and liners to canopies, mosquito netting and hardware. And for those who prefer to do their swinging in the shade, there are portable outdoor awnings and collapsible gazebos.

The Novadigm merchandise will be sold with Hewlett-Packard's HP OpenView network-management products. Novadigm's shares rose $2, to $23.375, in Nasdaq trading. Novadigm's Enterprise Desktop Manager and Radia software allow information technology managers at large corporations to work on specific applications for as many as 100,000 computers. title: A House Held Up by a Bank; Renovation yields condos and an aerie.

But Laura Bohn and Richard Fiore never seem happier than when they are abandoning one renovated apartment to overhaul the next. The husband-and-wife team have lived through seven renovations, starting with the apartment Ms. Bohn was living in when Mr. Fiore met her 21 years ago. (''She told me that if she was going to allow me to stay there, I had to rebuild it for her,'' Mr. Fiore said recently, still amused.) Three years ago, they took on their riskiest project. They bought a bank.

title: Cable Network Chooses Harlem for Office
description: Black Entertainment Television, the nation's only 24-hour cable network meant for African-Americans, has selected an East Harlem office building for the location of a New York office and studio, company officials said yesterday.

title: CONSECO SELLING BANK CARD UNIT FOR $400 MILLION
description: Conseco Inc., the beleaguered insurer that is trying to sell its consumer lending business, has sold the unit's bank card portfolio to a division of Wells Fargo & Company for approximately $400 million. The company, based in Carmel, Ind., said the sale provided additional liquidity to Conseco Finance and is not expected to result in a material gain or loss. The size of the card portfolio was about $400 million, the company said. Conseco Finance, based in St. Paul, had assets of nearly $46 billion as of Dec. 31, 1999. The unit has been for sale since March 31, when Conseco announced a $350 million charge against 1999 earnings to write down the value of securities held on the finance company's books.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILICER, BERNARD
description: HEILICER-Bernard, 79, of Plainview died July 2, 2000, of natural causes after a short illenss. He enjoyed a successful career as an aeronautical engineer at Fairchild Republic. His loving and cherished wife of 57 years, Norma, passed on in September, 1999. Cherished father of Sandra Barmak, Lorraine Glaser and Shelley Gross. Loved father-in-law of Len Barmak, Gary Glaser and Michael Gross. Loving and adoring grandfather (''Pop'') of Allan and Julie Barmak and Lesley and Michael Reilly, Samantha and Evan Glaser, and Jeffrey and Amy Gross; loving and adoring great-grandfather of Taylor Barmak. Services on Thursday, July 6, 12 noon at Guttermans Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury. Donations may be sent to the Alzheimers Association or to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Center. He will be greatly missed.

title: EXECUTIVE DEPARTS SWISSAIR
description: Jeffrey Katz, chief executive of Swissair, is leaving after more than three years of trying unsuccessfully to improve profitability at the airline, Europe's fifth largest. Mr. Katz, 45, will become chairman, president and chief executive of Orbitz, a consumer travel Web site. Philippe Bruggisser, chief executive of Swissair's parent company, SAirGroup, will take over Mr. Katz's post. The company gave no explanation for the departure of Mr. Katz, a Californian recruited from American Airlines in 1997. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHAU, WALTER
description: MATTHAU-Walter. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed Member Friar Walter Matthau, on July 1, 2000. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: THE ESTEE LAUDER COS., New York, named Richard W. Kunes, vice president for financial administration and corporate controller, to the post of senior vice president and chief financial officer, effective Oct. 1. He succeeds Robert J. Bigler, who is retiring.

title: John Hejduk, an Architect And Educator, Dies at 71
description: John Hejduk, one of the most revered figures in American architecture and architectural education, died on Monday at his home in Riverdale in the Bronx. He was 71.

title: COMVERSE TO BUY EXALINK FOR ABOUT $480 MILLION
description: The software maker Comverse Technology Inc. agreed yesterday to pay about $480 million in stock to acquire Exalink Ltd., an Israeli company whose hardware and software connect wireless devices to the Internet. Based on Comverse's closing price on Monday, the 5.26 million shares it will pay are worth about $480 million. Exalink is privately held. Comverse said that the acquisition would give it both Exalink's mobile Internet platform and its database system for subscriber and platform management. Comverse, based in Woodbury, N.Y., makes computer and telecommunications systems and software for multimedia communications and information-processing applications. Shares of Comverse fell $8.125 each, to $83.125.

title: Metro Business; MediaNews Sells Papers to Advance
description: MediaNews Group Inc., the publisher of The Denver Post, said yesterday that it had sold its remaining New Jersey and Pennsylvania newspapers to Penn Jersey Advance, a subsidiary of Advance Publications Inc., for an undisclosed amount.

description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, have agreed to meet at Camp David next week for a summit conference intended to help them frame the peace agreement they hope to reach by September, President Clinton announced today.

title: Goldman Sachs to Allow Big Sale of Shares by Ex-Partners
description: The Goldman Sachs Group said yesterday that it would let its former partners sell as many as 18 million shares of stock in an offering that could be bigger than the firm's $3.66 billion initial public offering last year.

title: Giuliani, the Noncandidate, Faces New Scrutiny in 2 Books
description: They were supposed to be the hot properties of a big New York summer: two books about the private and public lives of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, published in the middle of his incendiary Senate campaign against the first lady. Instead, Wayne Barrett's ''Rudy! An Investigative Biography of Rudolph Giuliani'' and Andrew Kirtzman's ''Rudy Giuliani: Emperor of the City'' are now about a man of uncertain political future with only 18 months left in office.

title: All of the Ingredients for a Laid-Back Holiday Party
description: Maybe it was the effect of the holiday, but the hip-hop show at the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night unfurled as slowly as an afternoon barbecue. The crowd was sparse on this second night of the bill, and the mood was, as Snoop Doggy Dogg says, laid back.

title: Gustaw Herling, Polish Exile Who Wrote of Life and Death in the Gulag, Is Dead at 81
description: Gustaw Herling, whose memoir, ''A World Apart,'' was one of the first and among the most powerful and enduring accounts of life and death in the Soviet network of prisons and labor camps, died on Tuesday in Naples, Italy, the Polish Embassy in Rome said. He was 81 and lived in Naples.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MLOTEK, YOSL
description: MLOTEK-Yosl. The Workmen's Circle/Arbeter Ring (WC/AR) mourns the passing of foremost Yiddishist and pillar of our organization for almost half a century. Born in Poland, Yosl, forged a connection between Eastern European and American culture across generations, making Workmen's Circle the address for Yiddish in the world. He served as Educational Director of The WC/ AR, developing the Shuln Network and Jewish Cultural Experience program at Circle Lodge, innovating the Third Seder program, producing our radio program on WEVD and Yiddish Music Concerts in The Parks. Yosl leaves behind a family of tireless contributors to WC/AR, his wife, Chana, his co-editor of definitive collections of Yiddish song, sons, Zalmen, Director of Art Programming, and Mark, outgoing President, and sister, Sara, an activist in Montreal. We will miss his spirit of ageless youth.

description: FOR George Paap, the manager for e-business intelligence and research at Motorola Semiconductor Products, one of the most interesting moments in an online focus group occurs as soon as participants enter the virtual waiting room.

title: RUSSIA SELLING OIL SHARES
description: Russia's property ministry is expected to set the terms next week for the sale of an 85 percent stake in Onako, a state-controlled oil company. Its output is equal to about 10 percent of Russia's biggest oil company, Lukoil Holding, according to the United Financial Group, a brokerage firm in Moscow. The ministry also said it planned to sell a 4.5 percent stake in Lukoil on the New York Stock Exchange in August. The sales are expected to raise at least $714 million for the government. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

description: In a dramatically lighted room, two police officers stand over a criminal defendant. One reads the Miranda rights, and the accused closes his eyes. Suddenly, his chair seems more comfortable and the one-way mirror on the wall becomes a sea of interested faces. The female officer's uniform seems a softer shade of blue, and the look on her face becomes one of sisterly concern. The defendant opens his eyes and begins to recount his story.

title: Cordiant to Acquire Lighthouse Global
description: The Cordiant Communications Group in London said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Lighthouse Global Network in Chicago, an international network of specialist communications and marketing businesses, for $592 million in stock and debt.

title: DENIAL IN KAZAKH BRIBE INQUIRY
description: The president of Kazakhstan's state oil company, who has been linked to an investigation by United States federal prosecutors, has denied allegations that he took bribes from international oil companies, Russian news agencies reported. Kazakhoil's president, Nurlan Balgimbaev, was named in a United States Justice Department document that states that an American trade consultant may have passed on bribes from units of major oil companies like Phillips Petroleum, Amoco and Mobil. ''I can tell you right now, I am clean -- I guarantee it,'' said Mr. Balgimbaev, speaking in the Kazakh city of Atyrau. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

description: COHEN-David. My beloved grandpa, I miss you every day. I love you. Freya

title: LOPEZ CLOSER TO EXTRADITION
description: Spanish prosecutors have given preliminary approval for the former General Motors executive Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua to be extradited to the United States, where he is wanted on charges of stealing company secrets. Mr. Lopez is to appear in court tomorrow to state whether he will fight the extradition. He was indicted in May by a federal grand jury in Detroit. Benjamin Jones (NYT)

title: Windows Me, Microsoft's Latest, Is a Less Than Millennial Upgrade
description: THE first thing one needs to know about upgrading to the new Windows Millennium Edition operating system -- besides the fact that PC makers plan to offer it on new home computers this summer and that Microsoft will make it available as an upgrade for older computers in September -- is that the Uninstall routine is inside the Commands folder, which is tucked inside the Windows folder.

description: Relatives of some of the 10 Jewish men sentenced to prison in Iran on espionage charges met privately with President Clinton today to build pressure against the verdicts.

title: Vanguard Japan Venture
description: The Vanguard Group, the world's second-largest mutual fund company, said today that it planned to start offering United States mutual funds in Japan by the end of September. Vanguard, which is based in Malvern, Pa., will initially offer two funds: the Vanguard 500 Index Fund, based on the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, and the Vanguard Small-Cap Index Fund, based on the Russell 2000 index. The funds will be offered online through an arrangement with the online brokerage firm Monex Inc.

title: Online Shopper; Voyeur-Cams Come to Home Furnishings
description: LAST week, I was looking through a camera lens at a glass-topped coffee table for sale in a Houston store called Gallery Furniture. The table did not interest me.

title: APPEAL SEEN IN SMUGGLING CASE
description: The Canadian government is likely to appeal a United States judge's dismissal of a $1 billion lawsuit against R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings for reportedly smuggling two billion cigarettes into Canada between 1991 and 1994 to evade high taxes. In a decision made last week but released on Tuesday, Thomas McAvoy, a federal judge in Syracuse, said Canada's claim was not permissible under an 18th-century common law that prohibits courts from collecting taxes owed in another country. But lawyers for Canada noted that Judge McAvoy also said he thought the law was outdated. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Singling Out Sierra Leone, U.N. Council Sets Gem Ban
description: The Security Council voted today to impose a worldwide ban on the purchase of rough diamonds from Sierra Leone until its government can establish a system to certify the origin of stones being exported, and begins to assert its authority over the diamond fields.

title: Sports of The Times; And a Fond So Long To Oscar Madison
description: IF a sportswriter plans to write his autobiography, and believes he needs a little help, then it would seem natural for him to seek out another sportswriter. That, apparently, was what Walter Matthau did. Oddly enough, Matthau, the Tony Award and Academy Award winning actor, might be the most famous sportswriter of his time, Red Smith, Jimmy Cannon, Jim Murray and Dave Anderson notwithstanding.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the view of a former United Nations weapons inspector, Scott Ritter, that Iraq no longer possesses prohibited weapons of any importance misquoted a passage in an article he had written for the journal Arms Control Today. He wrote that ''it was possible as early as 1997 to determine that, from a qualitative standpoint, Iraq had been disarmed.'' He did not write ''from a quantitative standpoint.''

title: Halfway Measures Enough For Liberty
description: Maybe, the idea of playing the Portland Fire, an expansion team that has managed to win only four games this season, lulled the New York Liberty into a sense of complacency last night. Or maybe, it was just too much familiarity between the two teams. After all, there were three former Liberty players -- Sophia Witherspoon, Michele Van Gorp and Carolyn Young -- playing for Portland, and one former member of the Fire, Tari Phillips, playing for the Liberty. It appeared there were more hugs tossed about than practice shots before the game at Madison Square Garden.

title: SPAIN FACES LAWSUIT
description: The European Commission said it would go to court to force Spain to give up powers over formerly state-owned companies like Telefonica S.A., the country's dominant phone company. Spanish government opposition helped to torpedo Telefonica's planned takeover of a Dutch rival, Royal KPN, in May. The commission, the 15-nation European Union's executive agency, said it would call on the European Court of Justice to overturn Spain's ''unjustified restrictions on the free movement of capital.'' In the Telefonica case, the Spanish finance minister, Rodrigo Rato, said the government opposed the merger because the Dutch state still controlled a stake in KPN, the biggest Dutch phone company.

description: GEORGE ORWELL expected Soviet-style Communism to perfect the notion of a society monitored by an all-seeing ''big brother,'' but he did not realize that it would take capitalism to come up with the most efficient way for millions of people to be nosy.

title: A GOOD MONTH FOR PHILIPPINE AIRLINES
description: Showing headway in its rehabilitation, Philippine Airlines Inc. registered a record profit of 392.7 million pesos ($8.99 million) in April. The airline's president, Avelino Zapanta, said the April profit was the ''highest ever achieved by PAL in a single month in its 59-year history.'' He said the airline's previous profit record of 357.7 million pesos was recorded in December 1991. Philippines Airlines reported a net income of 44 million pesos for the fiscal year that ended on March 31, its first year under a rehabilitation program. The profit followed seven years of losses.

title: LAFARGE PURCHASES STONE QUARRY IN MICHIGAN
description: The Lafarge Corporation said yesterday that it had purchased the Presque Isle Corporation, operator of the nation's largest stone quarries, from the National Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for $56 million. The quarry, on the shore of Lake Huron in Presque Isle, Mich., produces more than eight million tons of crushed stone annually. Lafarge, based in Reston, Va., supplies construction materials.

title: AIRLINE IN IRELAND NAMES EXECUTIVE
description: The Aer Lingus Group P.L.C. appointed Michael Foley, president of Heineken USA Inc., as chief executive. He succeeds Garry Cullen, who resigned in February, saying he did not want to lead the state-owned airline through a planned public stock offering. Mr. Foley, 52, previously ran Murphy's Brewery, a Heineken subsidiary in Cork, and lived in Ireland until 1994. The Irish government hopes to privatize Aer Lingus through an initial public offering later this year. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Gibson's Precedent for Williams Sisters
description: When Venus and Serena Williams parade onto Center Court for their singles semifinal at Wimbledon today, Althea Gibson will settle in front of the television set in her New Jersey home and tell her friend, Fran Gray, ''I'll be in London today.''

title: FedEx and 6 Others Picked by Big Board For Decimal Trading
description: The FedEx Corporation, Gateway Inc. and Hughes Supply Inc. are among the first seven stocks the New York Stock Exchange will trade in dollars and cents as United States markets convert the pricing of stocks to decimals from fractions.

title: Sather Talks to Keenan and Eyes Messier
description: Glen Sather, the Rangers' new president and general manager, officially revealed his free-agent wish list yesterday: Mark Messier, Claude Lemieux and Vladimir Malakhov.

title: Russia to Protect Soldiers
description: OSCOW, July 6  Stung by rising casualties in Chechnya, President Vladimir V. Putin promised today to reduce the use of Russian police there and turn over more law enforcement responsibilities to pro-Moscow Chechens.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Monday about the naming of Martin Shaw as creative director at an advertising agency misstated the name of the agency. It is Posner Advertising, not Posner Communications.

description: Pharmacopeia Inc., whose shares have risen more than 65 percent this year, said today that the Pharmacia Corporation had ended a two-year research collaboration six months early.

description: It is the forbidden subject in Cambodia, but people cannot stop talking about it: who will eventually succeed King Norodom Sihanouk, the ailing and increasingly reclusive man who is the soul of his country?

title: Is It Fusion? To Say the Least
description: With Senor Coconut, the truth is stranger than the fiction, which is pretty strange itself. Released this week on the record label Emperor Norton, the second album by Senor Coconut, ''El Baile Alleman'' (Spanish for German Dance), masquerades as a collection of songs by the pioneering German electronic band Kraftwerk as performed by a Latin-music combo led by an eccentric South American composer, arranger and dancer known as Senor Coconut.

title: Summer School Opens, but Many Students Are No-Shows
description: Nervous, resigned and sometimes enthusiastic, thousands of New York City students began summer school yesterday in an opening that officials said went smoothly even though it was marred by widespread attendance problems.

description: AKS-Harold. Choral conductor and educator. 78, died Friday, June 30, 2000, of heart failure while vacationing in Canada. Mr Aks was a prominent figure in the New York musical world for over 50 years. He lost his beloved wife of 28 years, Patricia, in 1994. He is survived by sister and brother-in-law Esther and Robert Ray, daughter and son-in-law, Catherine Aks and Stanley Kushel, granddaughter, Miriam, son and daughter-in-law, David Aks and Ann Baltz, grand daughter, Julia, stepson, Michael Untermeyer, step daughter and son-in-law, Kathryn Untermeyer Atwood and James Atwood, grandsons, Samuel and Ethan, and his loving companion Lorie Hartman who made his last years so special. description: One of the world's great players and writers died in February at the age of 89. Bruce Bell was the Grand Old Man of bridge in New Zealand, and he was one of five people who have been honored by Queen Elizabeth II for services to bridge, becoming an Officer of the British Empire in 1979. The others are Rixi Markus of England and Keith McNeil of Australia, both deceased, Tim Seres of Australia and Nicola Gardener Smith of England.

title: Ad Spending Breaks a Record
description: Spending by advertisers in traditional media increased a strong 12.7 percent, to $22.2 billion, in the first quarter compared with $19.7 billion in the period a year earlier, according to Competitive Media Reporting. The $22.2 billion is a record for a first quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPOVSKY, ARTHUR JOSEPH, M.D.
description: LAPOVSKY-Arthur Joseph, M.D. Died peacefully in Columbia, MD on July 5, 2000 at the age of 95. A long time resident of Brooklyn, NY he was Clinical Professor of Neurology Emeritus at the State University of New York Health Science Center at Bklyn and beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, brother and friend. A renowned diagnostician and devoted teacher. He received his M.D. from the Long Island College Hospital and was certified in internal medicine, neurology and psychiatry. He was an integral part of the Department of Neurology at SUNY/HSCB and its residency training program for more than a half-century. He also served as attending neurologist at most major hospitals in Brooklyn and was a member of the Board of Trustees of the Brooklyn Neurological Society, serving as its president, in 1940 and 1948. His major area of interest was movement disorders and he pioneered the use of dopamine for the treatment of Parkinson's Disease. He was a World War II veteran and held the ranks of Captain and Major in the U.S. Army Medical Corp. He and his wife, the late Martha Schulman Lapovsky, were lovers of the arts with an intense interest in classical music. They supported the major cultural institutions in New York. As passionate travelers they visited many remote places before world travel became easily accessible. He is survived by a son, David Lapovsky; two daughters, Elizabeth Lapovsky Kennedy and Ruth Kasle; five grandchildren, Peter and Steen Strand and Jenni, Courtenay and Matt Lapovsky; two great-grandchildren, Will and Maren Strand and a sister, Shirley Schiffrin. Those who wish may contribute in his memory to the Arthur J. Lapovsky Fund For Neurological Research at SUNY/ HSCB, c/o Department of Neurology, Box 1213, 450 Clarkson Ave, Bklyn, NY 11203. A graveside service will be held at Knollwood Park Cemetery, 57-80 Cooper Ave, Queens at 2PM, Thursday July 6th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEJDUK, JOHN
description: HEJDUK-John. On July 3, 2000. Former dean of the Irwin S. Chanin School of Architecture at The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art. The college mourns the loss of this distinguished architect, teacher, humanist and friend, who until his recent retirement had been professionally associated with the school for a half-century. A Cooper Union graduate, John Hejduk devoted his life to advancing the theory and practice of the architectural art through education and personal influence, offering his talents in a variety of forms. Through his drawings, his theoretical work, his poetry and particularly his example, John Hejduk demonstrated to those around him the profound significance of the relationship between humanity and the structures it builds for its own home. His work will continue to guide generations of students and professionals, and his spirit and accomplishment will continue to grace the halls of the school to which he made such a significant and unparalleled contribution. The entire Cooper Union community offers its deepest condolences to the Hejduk family. Dr. George Campbell Jr., President John Jay Iselin, President Emeritus Robert A. Bernhard, Chairman, Board of Trustees The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

Like Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt when they gathered at Camp David at President Carter's invitation 22 years ago, Mr. Barak and Mr. Arafat must summon the courage to make difficult compromises or risk losing a historic opportunity to end the half-century-old conflict.

title: Aluminum Is Getting Hot
description: The spare, high-tech look is popular not only for homes and stores, but also in gardens. ''The ultimate luxury in New York is empty space,'' said Ken Smith, a landscape architect in Manhattan. When he designed an Upper West Side garden for Joel Kissen, an owner of Guastavino's restaurant in Manhattan, and Carlos Afonso, a designer, he created an austere place made mostly of industrial materials. Yet, water burbling down aluminum runnels (next to bottom, right) and a grove of bamboo trees, planted last year, below, make the space sensuous. From top to bottom, right, Mr. Smith created a rooftop terrace overlooking the garden. Aluminum screens gleam in the sunlight, while aluminum mixing bowls ($69 from R-S Restaurant Equipment on the Bowery) have become planters for boxwood and holly. The industrial materials are not only sturdy, Mr. Smith said, but ''also fire-resistant.'' His telephone number: (212) 791-3595.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, DR. JOSEPHINE D.
description: MARTIN-Dr. Josephine D. Died July 6, 2000, after a long courageous battle, stoic and still giving in her loving way. Her husband Robert Schwartz is deeply grieved and her loss is felt by her nephews Michael and Charles Diaz, and their children, Robert's daughterin-law Dr. Gail Ross, and his grandchildren. Jo, a dedicated doctor, gave deeply of herself, often without remuneration, a prominent civil rights activist, including participation in the Mississippi Summer, the unofficial doctor to SNCC. She practiced in NYC and in the British Health System in London. At Bellevue, she established programs for children and healthcare programs at welfare hotels. Her dedication in the perpetual struggle for healthcare, human rights and opposition to tyranny is an inspiration. There will be a commemoration shortly after Labor Day. Contributions can be made to the Josephine D. Martin Medical and Human Rights Committee, c/o ECAAR, 211 East 43 St, New York, NY 10017.

In its magic and mystery (there is a hint that Hermione perhaps never died but was kept in hiding until an oracle's prophesy was fulfilled) and in its deeply romantic reconciliation earned by years of despair, it possesses the kind of ingrained schmaltz that Hollywood regularly attempts but most often attenuates.

title: HUDSON TO SELL SOME INVESTMENTS AND BUY BACK STOCK
description: Hudson United Bancorp said yesterday that it would sell about $2 billion of its low-yielding investments in an effort to improve its balance sheet. Hudson United, based in Mahwah, N.J., said it would sell the investments, primarily linked to mortgages, to raise cash mostly to repay expensive debt. The bank said it expected to take a charge of $42 million for the revamping because it would not account for the investments as assets. The company also said its board had approved the repurchase of 10 million shares, or about 20 percent, of its 51 million shares outstanding. Shares of Hudson United rose 87.5 cents, to $24.25.

It's justification enough for her to look again at ''the beauty of desire,'' this time with blissful optimism. For Ms. Lang, summer is time for heady new romance and glimmers of retro pop. Writing with new collaborators, she harks back to 1960's styles without turning archival.

title: REPUBLIC GROUP SAYS IT IS CONSIDERING SALE OR MERGER
description: Faced with declining profits because of lower prices and slowing sales of gypsum wallboard, the Republic Group said yesterday that it was considering a sale or merger. Republic said it had hired J. P. Morgan Securities for advice on alternatives, which could include continuing business as is. Shares of the company, which is based in Hutchinson, Kan., rose $2.125 each, to $12.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. At the current price, the company's stock is worth $148 million. Republic's shares are still down 17 percent this year. Republic had sales of $138 million in its last fiscal year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANDEL, FRANCES WENDER
description: KANDEL-Frances Wender, beloved wife, mother, grandmother, second mother to several and cherished friend to many, passed away July 4 at the age of 67. Survived by her husband Al, daughters Wendy, Adrienne and Susan, grandchildren Anais, Felix, Max and Benjamin, sister Abigail Moss. Fran stands out for her ceaseless efforts to fix the world, on the larger scale through social activism and on the individual scale by teaching, mentoring, helping, inspiring, mothering, and loving people. Fran received last year's Distinguished Service Award for her volunteer work with the Woman Lawyers Association of Los Angeles, including 20 years of work on their jail project, and service as president and as Board member. WLALA also recognized her with a Pro Bono Service Award in 1993 and 1994 for work with Salvadoran refugees at El Rescate. She received the New (renewed) Volunteer of the Year award from the Harriett Buhai Center for Family Law in 1994 and was honored by the Legal Services Trust Fund Commission in 1996. Fran chaired the Prisoners Committee of the State Bar Legal Services Section, which she served for 20 years, and actively promoted justice as trustee, governor, or member of various other Bar committees and legal associations. Frances Wender Kandel was a people person-easy to talk to, animated, generous, loving, honest, indomitable, celebrating of diversity, and brilliant. She believed and proved that one person's life can make the world better.

title: Commandos Raid Camp of Islamic Cult In Malaysia
description: SAUK, Malaysia  Anti-terrorist commandos on Thursday raided the jungle camp of a heavily armed Islamic cult, capturing 27 men and ending a bizarre and violent episode that was one of Malaysia's worst security threats in decades.

title: Editor Takes Leap to Web, and Pets' World
description: LET'S skip the gamut of canine cliches -- ''he's gone to the dogs'' keeps trotting to mind -- and cut to the reaction that Arthur J. Browne's wife had when Mr. Browne, until last Friday the senior managing editor of The Daily News, told her that he was thinking about surrendering his 27-year tenure to join PetPlace.com, an Internet start-up dedicated to pet health.

title: Recipe for Weaker Schools
description: Private prep schools often provide a fifth year of high school for students who performed poorly in their earlier years and need to strengthen themselves academically before moving on to college. The American Federation of Teachers has suggested that public high schools formally add a fifth year for struggling students. That is not a good idea at this point. Public high schools need to make far better use of the four years they already have.

title: Business Links On Web Raise Antitrust Issues
description: As companies in practically every industry rush to join business-to-business exchanges on the Internet, regulators are growing concerned that they will face a rash of new antitrust questions for which they are not prepared.

title: German Parliament Backs Fund for Nazis' Slave Workers
description: The Parliament approved legislation today to govern a $5 billion fund for Nazi-era slave workers and other Holocaust-era victims.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS. Coffee dropped 3 percent on abundant supplies and little chance of frost in Brazil, the world's top grower. In New York, coffee for September delivery fell 2.7 cents, or 3.1 percent, to 85.4 cents a pound.

title: GERMAN JOBLESSNESS RISES
description: The number of unemployed people in Germany was higher by 2,000 in June, as construction companies in the eastern region cut jobs, the Federal Labor Office said. Unemployment in western Germany, which accounts for 90 percent of output, fell by 4,000 in June, while unemployment in the east rose by 7,000. The overall jobless rate was unchanged at 9.6 percent, the lowest level in more than four years. The 17.4 percent jobless rate in the formerly Communist east compares with 7.7 percent in the west.

title: HONDA ON TOP IN JAPAN
description: Claiming in June to have Japan's top-selling car for the first time, thanks to its remodeled Odyssey minivan, the Honda Motor Company displaced the Toyota Motor Corporation, which has led sales for more than a decade. Honda, Japan's second-largest automaker overall, sold 14,639 Odyssey vans in June, 450 more than Toyota's subcompact Vitz, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said. Toyota commands more than 40 percent of Japanese-made sales. The remodeled Odyssey was introduced in December, and sales in Japan have since reached about 70,000.

title: Safety Board Blames Pilot Error in Crash of Kennedy Plane
description: The cause of the plane crash that killed John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife and sister-in-law a year ago was probably that Mr. Kennedy, with hardly any experience flying his plane alone at night, became disoriented in haze, the National Transportation Safety Board said today in a staff report.

title: Over the Top And Proud of It
description: The unexpected success of ''American Pie'' last summer, in which a fresh crop of young actors obsessed about losing their virginity, and an apple pie was rudely disturbed in the process, has accelerated the trend toward vulgar, borderline-tasteless comedy and has some shaking their heads. How low will Hollywood go to lure young people into theaters? The most recent flurry of tsk-tsking occurred with the release of ''Me, Myself and Irene,'' a Jim Carrey comedy that pokes fun at mental illness and the disabled and does brazen things to a cow and a chicken.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The yen slid again after reports suggested Japan's economy might not be strong enough for interest rates to move higher. In New York, the dollar settled at 107.42 yen, up from 107.03 on Wednesday.

title: Teams Wooing as Fast as They Can to Land Hill
description: Picture the Knicks' Scott Layden, the Nets' Rod Thorn, Miami's Pat Riley, San Antonio's Gregg Popovich and Chicago's Jerry Krause standing in a hotel lobby making small talk while each nervously awaits his turn to speak with the coveted Grant Hill. The goings-on in Detroit this week have not been that dramatic, but that is essentially what is taking place.

title: Blair Son, 16, Is Arrested for Being Drunk
description: LONDON  The 16-year-old son of Prime Minister Tony Blair was arrested for being "drunk and incapable" after police officers found him lying on the ground in London's Leicester Square, the police reported Thursday.

title: RUPIAH WEAK AGAINST DOLLAR
description: The Indonesian currency, the rupiah, traded against the dollar at its lowest exchange rate in 16 months, and analysts in Indonesia said it was unlikely to rebound soon. The rupiah settled in Jakarta at 9,290 to the dollar and in New York at 9,252.50. Analysts said politics, not the economy, was pushing down the currency, adding that they did not expect a significant upturn in the currency's value until after a session of Parliament next month that is expected to be volatile. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: GENTEK AGREES TO BUY DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS GROUP
description: GenTek, a manufacturer of auto parts and wire and cable assemblies, agreed yesterday to acquire the Digital Communications Group subsidiary of the privately held Prestolite Wire Corporation for $90 million in cash. GenTek said Digital Communications, a Denver-based company that makes fiber optic and copper cable for telecommunications, would fit well with Krone, GenTek's principal telecommunications subsidiary. After the acquisition, GenTek's telecommunications arm would generate sales of more than $450 million. Paul M. Montrone, chairman and controlling shareholder of GenTek, is also the controlling shareholder of Prestolite Wire. Shares of GenTek, based in Hampton, N.H., rose 18.75 cents, to $12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, HERBERT O.
description: FOX-Herbert O. Columbia Artists Management Inc. is deeply saddened by the loss of our friend and colleague, Herbert O. Fox, on June 29, 2000. During his fifty-four years with CAMI, Herb Fox served in a number of important positions. At the time of his retirement in 1993, he was Senior Vice President of Columbia Artists Management Inc. and Chairman of Columbia Artists Festivals, the latter of which specialized in the touring of pop, jazz, ethnic, and dance attractions. Herb also served as Chairman of the Board of Community Concerts, and was the founder and first director of another CAMI subsidiary, the Broadway Theatre Alliance, which toured Broadway plays and musicals. Herb's remarkable humor, energy, enthusiasm, and vision were invaluable to CAMI and to the artists and attractions we represent. We remember him with great affection and esteem. Ronald A. Wilford, President And The Board of Directors of Columbia Artists Management Inc

title: F&M NATIONAL IN $70 MILLION DEAL FOR ATLANTIC FINANCIAL
description: The F&M National Corporation, a bank holding company, agreed yesterday to acquire the Atlantic Financial Corporation for about $70 million in stock. F&M, based in Winchester, Va., will offer 0.753 share of its common stock for each Atlantic share, valuing Atlantic at $16.85 a share based on F&M's closing price on Wednesday. Atlantic Financial, based in Gloucester, Va., is the holding company for Peninsula Trust Bank and United Community Bank, which operates in Virginia through 15 branches. F&M owns nine banks operating 125 branches in Virginia, West Virginia and Maryland. Shares of F&M fell 6.25 cents, to $22.3125, while Atlantic Financial jumped $1.6875, to $15.4375.

title: ARCH CHEMICALS MAKES $150 MILLION OFFER FOR HICKSON
description: Arch Chemicals said yesterday that it was making a cash offer of about $150 million for Hickson International of Britain. Arch would also assume about $50 million of debt in its planned acquisition of Hickson, a manufacturer and supplier of specialty chemical products and services. For the year that ended on Dec. 31, Hickson reported sales of about $330 million. Arch said it planned to sell Hickson's organic chemicals business, which accounts for about 30 percent of Hickson's sales. Arch, based in Norwalk, Conn., is a specialty chemicals company that reported $875.5 million of revenue for the last 12 months.

title: Preparing to Remake Mexico
description: Mexicans have understandably high expectations for Vicente Fox Quesada, the man they elected to break the 71-year presidential monopoly of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI. In the euphoria that has followed his decisive victory Sunday, they now look to Mr. Fox to eliminate the official corruption, economic inequalities and political repression that were the defining characteristics of PRI rule. Mr. Fox's initial declarations are promising. But he will need persistence and cooperation from Mexico's other parties to succeed.

title: Calcified As a Ritual Of Anarchy: Punk's Lot
description: ''I wasn't born yet,'' says Why-me, the first interview subject of ''The Decline of Western Civilization, Part III,'' Penelope Spheeris's latest installment in her documentary series on the social trajectory of the Los Angeles punk scene. In the first ''Decline'' (1981), the curdled fomentation of punk was young and looming. In the second (1988), she spun nasty jokes on rock 'n' roll, and in this third episode, which is minor but telling, the movement has become an institution. Many of the young punks interviewed -- many in their teens, like Why-me -- are inheritors of a movement that existed before they did and has calcified into ritualized anarchic behavior. One of them, caught in a crowd scene, says, ''I know a guy that can suck an 'Icee' through his nose,'' and seconds later, we see it.

title: A Flame in the Ashes of Postwar Berlin
description: The flame kept by the owner of a Berlin cigar store in 1946 seems unremarkable at first glance -- a wisp of fire produced by the kind of metal lighter that was seen in the hands of American soldiers in World War II so often that many civilians thought they were standard government issue.

Centrica will buy Direct Energy, a retailer of gas to 820,000 customers in Ontario, and Natural Gas Wholesalers, a customer services unit. Centrica supplies gas and electricity to homes and businesses in Britain.

title: BORDERS SAYS IT HAS ENDED ACQUISITION TALKS
description: Borders Group, the No. 2 United States book chain, said yesterday that it had ended acquisition talks and was exploring other alternatives, including a stock buyback. Shares of Borders fell $2.375, or nearly 15 percent, to $13.1875. The retailer did not say whom it had held talks with. The buyout firms Bain Capital, Apollo Management and Blackstone Group were all rumored to be considering bids in June. Borders said on March 3 that it had hired Merrill Lynch & Company for advice on ways to increase its share price, which had fallen 70 percent between 1998 and June. The retailer operates 293 Borders Books and Music stores in the United States, about 900 smaller Waldenbooks stores, and 32 Books Etc. and Borders stores in Britain.

description: State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer announced yesterday that he had reached a settlement with the Cipriani restaurant family that he hoped would end a tradition of barring women from the lucrative waiters' jobs at some of the city's most exclusive restaurants.

title: IRELAND CAPS LIQUOR PRICES
description: Worried about inflation, the Irish government froze liquor and some soft-drink prices in pubs, hotels and restaurants. An order from the minister for consumer affairs, Tom Kitt, limits prices to their level on May 15 for six months. Last month, the government took steps to control inflation in the housing market. Ireland's economic boom, high energy costs and the weak value of the euro have helped push its inflation rate to 5.2 percent, the highest in 15 years. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: ARMSTRONG IS SELLING AN INSTALLATION BUSINESS TO ARDEX
description: Armstrong World Industries, the flooring manufacturer, agreed yesterday to sell its Installation Products Group to the privately held Ardex Inc. for $86 million in cash. Ardex will purchase all inventory and assets of the group, including the Henry brand of flooring installation products, which Armstrong acquired in 1986. Armstrong said it would continue to offer a full installation system of products under the Armstrong name. The company, based in Lancaster, Pa., makes interior finishing materials for floors and ceilings and also hardwood flooring. Ardex, based in Aliquippa, Pa., manufactures products for the installation of floor and wall coverings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDKO, LIONEL
description: RUDKO-Lionel. Lionel Rudko was a companion, colleague and cherished friend for more than five decades. Ever since our first meeting in his record shop when he insisted that I hear the first recording of a young violinist named Isaac Stern we became close friends in music, musical ideas, and even more in our daily lives. We visited many other cities and countries together sharing a mutual zest for living. He worked together with me at Carnegie Hall and in my private office as my associate. In a long life, one meets many who become friends and, if one is fortunate, a few become a permanent part of one's life. It was so with Lionel. I mourn his passing as I would a brother but I celebrate his life with so many warm memories. Linda joins me in sending his wife Doris and daughter Lisa our most affectionate thoughts and we share their pain. Isaac and Linda Stern

title: EUROPEAN RATES UNCHANGED
description: The European Central Bank and the Bank of England left interest rates unchanged, reflecting views that Europe's big economies had been insulated against inflation by earlier increases. title: Croatia's Democratic Turn

title: Voting Rights in Kuwait

But if Kuwaitis are to achieve any semblance of the country's constitutional guarantee of ''equal rights'' for men and women, full political rights must be granted to women. That would serve as an example for other gulf nations that have yet to give women the right to vote.

The members of Cascade's management in the buyout group include C. Calvert Knudsen, the chairman of Cascade, and Robert Warren Jr., the company's chief executive. The group did not divulge any details on a possible buyout offer in the filing. Cascade's shares fell 6.25 cents, to $11.50. At that price, the stock has a total value of more than $130 million.

The judge will now investigate the case and then make a recommendation on extradition to a three-judge panel. The Spanish cabinet will make the final decision. Benjamin Jones (NYT)

The city was on the brink of bankruptcy, and many neighborhoods were declining. Chinatown was a rare area of growing prosperity in the tight times, emerging from an area occupying few city blocks to transform a dilapidated Lower East Side into a thriving community.

''Kim,'' one of the songs that has made Eminem's second album, ''The Marshall Mathers LP,'' a summer scandal, is a view of horrific domestic violence from inside the mind of the abuser.

title: BROADBASE SOFTWARE AGREES TO PURCHASE PANOP.COM
description: Broadbase Software Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay around $107.7 million in stock for the privately held Panop.com Inc., which makes software that recommends products to online shoppers. Under terms of the deal, Broadbase, an analytical applications maker, will issue about 3.18 million shares of its common stock, options and warrants in exchange for all securities of Panop.com. Panop.com, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., makes software that produces contextual personalized recommendations to shoppers on the Internet. Broadbase's software analyzes customer information to help Internet businesses improve service.

title: U.S. CHALLENGES HEINZ BID FOR BEECH-NUT
description: The H. J. Heinz Company's proposed $185 million purchase of the closely held Milnot Holdings Company, maker of Beech-Nut baby foods, was challenged yesterday by antitrust enforcers who said the transaction would hurt competition. The Federal Trade Commission voted 3 to 2 to challenge in court the combination of Heinz with the Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation, the No. 2 United States baby food producer. The F.T.C. said the combination would mean just two companies, Heinz and the Gerber Products Company, a unit of Novartis, would control 98 percent of the United States market for prepared baby foods. Heinz closed yesterday on the Big Board up 31.25 cents, to $45.50.

The NYC Central Labor Council, its officers, staff and members are saddened by the sudden death of our friend, longtime labor activist and 40year-member of L.3 IBEW. Ray was truly a ''volunteer extraordinaire'' to this Council, not only for the outstanding job he did in putting together our annual Labor Day parades, but for the millionand-one daily details, and for the permits and sound systems for rallies and demonstrations of our many affiliates. Ray was a warm friend to all, always joking and laughing, so loved his beautiful granddaughter Jessica, and was extremely proud of his daughter Lenore (a teacher), and his son Mario (NYS AFL-CIO public relations) and was looking forward to Mario's upcoming marriage to Andrea Curro. To his wife, Aurora, sister Erminia, his son-in-law George Viola, all his family, friends, and co-workers, our heartfelt sympathies. Ray will be sorely missed by so many. title: Bookend; Choose the Best Title for This Story
description: Word just came down that they're abolishing Titles & Subheads as a stand-alone department. Surprise, surprise. The e-mail blames ''escalating decay of the standard author-publisher interface model.'' Translation: spoiled-brat writers nowadays design the jackets, pick the typefaces and cram their own titles down the publisher's throat. Think a pro like me would ever have come up with ''A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius''? That's what happens when the authors get it locked into their contracts that they call the shots. Pure ego if you ask me. I'm the guy who changed ''Dollar Bills All Over My Lawn'' to ''The Millionaire Next Door.'' Made the guy a fortune. And suddenly I'm a superannuated hack cleaning out his desk.

title: WEB SITE FOR GAS PRICES

The county's Department of Consumer Protection has been surveying Westchester's 400 stations and is posting the information by ZIP code and municipality on the county's Web site: www.westchestergov.com. County Executive Andrew J. Spano said he hoped the site would help drivers obtain the best prices and spur competition among stations. ELSA BRENNER

title: Bringing Argentina Out of the Shadows

A vague image appears, as grainy as a newspaper photograph, as if summoned by the light itself. As the flashlight is moved toward the wall, the image comes into focus, stark and confrontational: a man is pointing a gun directly at the visitor. Wherever the light moves, the gun moves with it. There is no escape except to click off the light and plunge back into darkness.

title: Dealing With Grief and Memorials
description: WHEN a highway fatality takes place, people don't think twice about leaving a white cross, a bouquet of flowers or other memorabilia at the site of the crash.

title: A Different Elite
description: To the Editor:

title: Benefits of Sit-Down Contract
description: Q What are the benefits and drawbacks of having a ''sit-down'' contract of sale when purchasing real estate? . . . George M. Colt, the Bronx.

title: Susanne Vikoren, Christopher Clark
description: Susanne Hooshmand Vikoren, a daughter of Dr. Farah Hooshmand Vikoren and Harold Bartholomay Vikoren of New Hope, Pa., was married yesterday to Christopher John Clark, a son of Kathleen Kelly Clark and John A. Clark, both of Fremont, Calif. District Justice Robert A. Schnell Jr. of the Pennsylvania Court of Common Pleas in Buckingham, officiated at the Solebury Friends Meeting in Solebury, Pa. Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of Federal District Court in Manhattan, for whom the bridegroom was a law clerk, took part in the ceremony.

title: Shirttails Hang On
description: Claire McCardell and B. H. Wragge, who popularized the shirtdress in the 1930's, had it exactly right: women want comfortable summer fashion. Even the couture-clad Duchess of Windsor turned to Wragge, the New York men's shirtmaker who opened a women's business based on shirtwaists, for easy hot-weather styles. Today's woman has rediscovered the practical shirtdress in silk and cotton, and even beaded sparklers for evening, bottom right. In the 60's, the shirtdress was cut as a loose chemise, followed by the wrap style of the 70's. And for the summer of 2000, this American classic is back.

title: Two Apples for Gore
description: As expected, Vice President Al Gore received overwhelming endorsements from the two national teachers unions and enormous ovations when he visited their conventions. Mr. Gore spoke first to the American Federation of Teachers in Philadelphia, then flew to Chicago to address the National Education Association.

title: A Garden Grows With Dance
description: IT is the 10th anniversary of Dances for Wave Hill. The series consists of new works celebrating Wave Hill's public garden. On performance evenings, the audience moves to several sites, and can relax on the grounds of Wave Hill during performances. (Blankets and lightweight chairs are allowed, but picnics are not permitted.)

title: Value Stocks Helped Some Foreign Funds Beat the Trend
description: INVESTORS who thought they could lessen their risk by diversifying overseas found little solace last quarter in international equity funds, many of which underperformed their domestic counterparts.

title: HAVERSTRAW: FERRY SERVICE TO BEGIN
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has approved a demonstration project to provide rush-hour ferry service between Haverstraw and Ossining beginning next month. The goal is to relieve congestion on the Tappan Zee Bridge. Commuters can park in Haverstraw in Rockland County and take a NY Waterway ferry to Ossining. Service is to begin at 6:30 a.m. to meet a Metro-North express from Ossining due at Grand Central before 7:30 a.m. The combined ferry-train monthly commuting pass will be $198. A single ferry ticket will be $3.

title: Desperate Passage
description: When I looked at the cover of your magazine, I thought I was at the Louvre, looking at Gericault's painting ''Raft of the Medusa.''

title: Odetta, Still Singing the Blues
description: WHEN Odetta, the unofficial queen of American folk music, last released a blues album 38 years ago folk purists wagged their admonishing fingers at her for betraying them.

title: Restore, Don't Toss, Aging Metal Patio Pieces
description: LAWN furniture. You don't give it a thought all winter, and then take it for granted when summer rolls around. But then it happens -- -- rust on the edges of the table! Peeling paint on the chair arms! Cracks in the vinyl strapping of the chaise! And don't even mention the many hues of gray on what just last year was bright white plastic.

title: Family Matters
description: Marion Kirby, a Rye resident who is 107 years old, will preside over 150 members of her very extended family Saturday at a reunion of eight generations of the Kirby clan. The event, which is expected to draw Kirbys-by-birth and Kirbys-by-marriage from across the country, will take place at the Rye Recreation Center, not far from the house in which Mrs. Kirby still lives. It was organized by Thomas J. Maloney Jr., one of Mrs. Kirby's grandsons, Elaine Taylor O'Neill, one of her nieces, both of Rye; and Kirby Scollon, a nephew who lives in New Rochelle.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on June 18 with an article about changes at the Harvard Business School improperly compared one aspect of the school's admissions with a different aspect of admissions at the Stanford Business School. For Stanford, the chart showed the percentage of applicants who were accepted; for Harvard, it showed the percentage of applicants who were accepted and then actually enrolled. A corrected version, showing the acceptance rates for both schools, appears today on Page 9.

title: In the Region/Westchester; In White Plains, New Town Houses With a Twist
description: A LONG-AWAITED ribbon-cutting ceremony was held on June 28 for an unusual 14-unit low- and moderate-income housing development in a leafy suburban neighborhood not far from this city's downtown, capping an almost eight-year effort. The first residents -- including city employees and several formerly homeless families -- at the $2.5 million development, on two sites about five blocks apart, are expected to begin moving in later this month.

title: The Way We Live Now: 07-09-00: Word & Image; The Nirvana News
description: This being my last word in this space, I dare to imagine what will become of the news business. What will the newspaper of the future look like? Does it even have a future?

title: A Baby's Quilt to Sew Up the Generations
description: The stepgrandparents on the mother's side sent a photo of themselves in Pisa, Italy. Cousin Barbara sent a paraphrased quotation from ''The Little Prince'' that said, ''What is essential is invisible to the eye.'' From a maternal great-great-grandmother came a piece of her apron, on which was inscribed a cookie recipe.

title: Heather Rieff, Davis Barker
description: Dr. Heather Ingrid Rieff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward K. Rieff of West Nyack, N.Y., was married yesterday to Davis Austin Barker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Sherman Barker Jr. of Lakeville, Conn. The Rev. Maureen Orfino, an interfaith minister, performed the ceremony at the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville.

title: Computer Associates To Miss Revenue Estimate
description: Computer Associates International Inc. (NYSE: CA) warned that first-quarter revenues would be short of expectations, falling in the range of $1.25 billion to $1.3 billion, up from $1.22 billion last year. Analysts had also expected the company to earn 55 cents a share, according to research firm First Call/ Thomson Financial. Earnings-per-share figures are to be reported July 20.

title: Hip-Hop Soul at NJPAC
description: Mary J. Blige can be credited with creating a new genre of music -- hip-hop soul. Since her format-busting debut -- 1992's ''What's the 411?'' -- to the current high-gloss soul-pop of ''Mary,'' Ms. Blige has proven to be an artist of great merit. She's evolved from the raw heartbreak themes of her earlier work to the more spiritual and lush. There is still sadness inherent in most of her work, but there is great strength as well.

title: Habitats/Warren Street in TriBeCa; Landlord to Ex-Tenant: You Can Go Home Again
description: IN Manhattan, people usually struggle to find apartments, or at least they anticipate a struggle. No one expects a landlord to call up and say, ''Please come live in my apartment.'' Or, ''I'm so sorry I have to move you out, but I'll find you an even better place in the same building.'' .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, SARAH K.
description: FISHER-Sarah K. On July 7, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Milton Fisher. Devoted mother of Sandra Fisher, Laura Fisher Lerner, Barry Fisher and Cindy Wechter. Cherished grandmother of nine grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Religious services today, at 1:30, at ''Parkside Chapel,'' 98-60 Queens Blvd (corner 66th Ave) Forest Hills. Interment at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Family requests that contributions can be made to the Anti-Defamation League or the Lighthouse for the Blind.

title: N.F.L. Duly Notes Absence of Dayne
description: Ron Dayne, the Giants' first-round draft pick, has managed to get his National Football League career off to a rocky start. He has committed two no-no's. First, he missed the league-sponsored rookie symposium this month that is arguably the best program in sports aimed at teaching life skills to its new players. That leads to Dayne's second mistake: by skipping the mandatory symposium, he has irritated the league.

title: Sports of The Times; With One Pitch, A Day Goes Sour
description: THE good cheer of an original New York event on a crisp summer day disappeared just as the sun was sinking last night in the Bronx. The day-night doubleheader turned sour, in the manner of the most timeless of baseball episodes of dishonor, with a brushback fastball that wreaked far more havoc than its desired effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, JULIA ACHESON
description: THOMPSON-Julia Acheson, 84, a long-time New York City resident and recently living in Killingworth, CT. died Monday, July 3 with her family by her side. Born in Raymond, Washington, daughter of the late Barclay and Louise Acheson, she was the niece of the late Lila and DeWitt Wallace, founders of the Reader's Digest and was married to the late Fred D. Thompson, Vice-President of the New York Times. She is survived by her sons Geoffrey A. Thompson, Jonathan A. Thompson, Cameron A. Thompson, Kimberley A. Thompson all of New York City and her daughter, Kathleen T. McCurdy of Killingworth, CT; six grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. A memorial service will be held at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York on Wednesday, July 12 at noon. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Near East Foundation, 342 Madison Ave, New York, NY 10173

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2001 Mazda Tribute; A Small S.U.V. Fills a Yawning Gap
description: IMAGINE being a man of the 90's and not having a single pair of khaki Dockers in your closet. Mazda found itself similarly naked in recent years; without a sport utility vehicle, it was missing out on the hottest auto fashion trend of the decade.

title: Helping Jews Get Along With Other Jews
description: WILLIAM HELMREICH, 54, a sociologist from Great Neck, thrives on controversy. The first of his 10 books was about the Black Panthers. The next delved into the insular ultra-Orthodox yeshiva world and another explored stereotypes of different nationalities. As co-director of the City College of New York Center for Mediation and Conflict Resolution, he makes his living bringing diverse groups together: Dominicans and Puerto Ricans, blacks and Jews, high school students and teachers.

title: Seeking Elbow Room For Plovers and Terns
description: WHEN Valerie Stillman-Tidwell learned that a piping plover had nested on her property, she was thrilled. ''I feel like their mother,'' she said.

description: KAUFMAN-Burrell A. Metal Trader. On July 5, 2000 at age 61 in Tucson, AZ formerly of South Orange, New Jersey. A true, honorable, gentle man, loving husband, and adored father. Survivors include wife Frances, daughters Amy, Sara, and Julie, sisters Lynda Israel and Deborah Kaufman (Idrees Malik), sisters-in-law Sybil Kaufman, & Bette (Stuart) Lehman, nephews, nieces, & grand nieces & nephews. Norris Barnes III of Winston-Salem, N.C. The Rev. Lidabell Lunt Pollard, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the chapel on Chocorua Island in Squam Lake in Holderness, N.H.

description: A revolutionary court in the southern city of Shiraz convicted 10 of 13 Iranian Jews of spying for Israel. They received sentences ranging from 4 to 13 years in prison. The other three were acquitted.

description: Jennifer Lynn Brackett was married yesterday afternoon to Maurice Stuart Lathers Jr. at Bent of the River, an Audubon Society nature preserve in Southbury, Conn. The Rev. Walter Pittman, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Sarah Ann Sulick and Stanley Myint misspelled the name of the company at which the bride's stepfather, Stan Winnick, works. It is Bohn Fiore, not Bonn-Fiore.

title: Suburbs With a Healthy Dose of Fantasy
description: By the time you get to Orenco, you're thinking you might be on a wild-goose chase. The brochures tout the place as Oregon's exciting new urban village, but as the train trudges west from Portland, it's hard to escape the feeling that both urbanism and village life are receding in the distance.

title: Jane McManus, Steven Klurfeld
description: Jane Mason McManus and Steven Neil Klurfeld are to be married today at the Hammond Museum in North Salem, N.Y. Rabbi Roger Ross will perform a service incorporating Jewish and Christian traditions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMAR, NED
description: DEMAR-Ned. Beloved father of Paul, Richard, Joyce. Dear brother of Anna, cherished grandfather of Debbie, Matthew, Stacy. Greatgrandfather of Samantha and Amanda. Service will be on Sunday July 9, 2000, 12 Noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Slice of the Riviera, With a Familiar Bronx Twist
description: It's been nearly half a century, but Edward Karen's memory is still sharp as he recalls those hazy, humid days when he and his family would pack sandwiches, towels, sandals and a large blanket and set off by bus from their South Bronx neighborhood in search of serenity. Their destination was Orchard Beach, a sliver of sand amid lush tidal marshes and woodlands, a place utterly foreign to the concrete confines where he grew up.

title: Ideas & Trends; In the Crowd's Frenzy, Echoes of the Wild Kingdom
description: HIGHLY social species'': it sounds sweet and clever all at once, doesn't it? And there's nothing like a spell of hot weather to remind us of how much we have in common with chimpanzees, dolphins and other gregarious souls. Dining al fresco on crowded sidewalks with cell phones grafted to our ears. You scratch my back, I'll de-flea yours. Synchronized swimming, anyone?

title: Italy Supplants Spain in Bronxville
description: BORDERING the train tracks near Bronxville station, La Frontiera has set up its frontier in the space last occupied by Marichu. But unlike its predecessor, which dished up Basque and Spanish food, this newcomer offers Italian fare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERKINS, SHEILA R.
description: PERKINS-Sheila R. Of Milton, Massachusetts, June 23. Sheila Redmond Perkins, widow of Malcolm D. Perkins, mother of Malcolm Jr. of Seattle, Sara of New York, Samuel of Milton, and William of Baltimore. Sister of Sylvie Griffiths, Cynthia Mead, and the late Joan Read. She is also survived by three daughters-in-law and seven grandchildren. Memorial service at First Parish Unitarian Church, 535 Canton Ave. in Milton on Saturday, July 15 at 2 P.M. followed by a reception at the Perkins residence. Donations may be made in Sheila's memory to The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore, The Conservation Law Foundation, or The Natural Resources Defense Council.

title: MEDICINE MERCHANTS: Patents and Patients; As Devastating Epidemics Increase, Nations Take On Drug Companies
description: Until recently, Robert Nyantika, 30, was a strong, straight-backed police officer fighting ''shifters'' -- guerrillas and cattle thieves who make cross-border raids from Somalia. Now he is a stooped wraith unable to focus his eyes, bathe himself or walk without help. Speaking in a voice somewhere between a whisper and a song, he says his best memory is that his unit never left its wounded behind.

description: Despite recent problems at the state Division of Motor Vehicles inspection stations, including hours of waiting for the new automobile emissions tests, 80 percent of the people who have had their cars tested since December feel the new test is fair and said their wait was no longer than in the past. The general satisfaction with the new test and with the personnel administering it were reported in the latest Star-Ledger/ Eagleton-Rutgers poll released last week. KAREN DeMASTERS

description: WHEN Hector Negron received his diploma from Sleepy Hollow High School 10 days ago, he did the same thing at the ceremony he had done after his many wrestling triumphs.

description: It was instructional to read that the big developers' group -- we call it the Association to Blacktop Long Island -- has brought its campaign as far as East Hampton.

title: All Hail the Conquering Heros!
description: Run this through your Batcomputer: ''X-Men'' opens July 14. A live-action version of ''The Tick,'' starring Patrick Warburton as the big blue bug, makes its debut in January on Fox. Batman, Superman and Wonder Woman grace boxes of Kraft Macaroni & Cheese. Barbie is dressing like Wonder Woman. Christina Aguilera was last seen wearing a Supergirl shirt on the cover of Rolling Stone. Jet Li is set to play Kato in a big-screen version of ''The Green Hornet.'' A Spiderman movie is spinning into production for a Thanksgiving 2001 release. And a half-dozen more secret-identities-and-groovy-gadgets flicks are in development. Whassup? It's the return of the superhero. Holy do-gooders in tights -- or leather.

title: At Shea, Mets Watch Yankees Get Breaks and Victory
description: As soon as Chuck Knoblauch motored around first base and then ducked his left shoulder slightly while passing Todd Zeile, Lee Mazzilli moved out of the coach's box and started pointing and screaming. Mazzilli told the umpire Robb Cook that Zeile had obstructed Knoblauch, and Cook instantly waved his arms and made that exact call.

title: A Further Caution About Electrical Wiring
description: The wiring diagram of the duplex receptacle [''Electrical Grounding: How to Make Sure It's Done Right,'' July 2] shows the black hot wire connected to the neutral side of the receptacle and the white neutral wire connected to the hot side of the receptacle. This causes reverse polarity, which can lead to damage to electronic equipment like computers and stereo systems, and even personal injury.

description: Dana Forester Cornell, a daughter of Sharon Salembier Lawson of Armonk, N.Y., and the late John R. description: STROUSE-Alice. On July 6, 2000. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave., Monday 2-5 and 7-9. Service at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 5th Ave & 53 St., Tuesday 3PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to St. Thomas Choir School.
