description: Best Bet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIGHT, CHARLES ALAN
description: RIGHT-Charles Alan. The Council and members of The American Law Institute mourn the death of our President, Professor Charles Alan Right. For more than 35 years Charlie played leadership roles in the ALI's attempt to improve the law and the legal system in the United States and internationally. Our former colleague, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, described Charles Alan Right as ''a Colossus at the summit of the profession,'' and referred to ''his brilliance as a scholar, his courage, and his boldness and caring in pursuit of the well-being of our legal system and the men and women who strive to serve it honorably.'' We will miss and remember Charlie as we pursue the unending work of law reform. Michael Traynor, First V.P. Conrad Harper, Second V.P. Bennett Boskey, Treasurer Lance Liebman, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COURTIS, JOHN (TURK)
description: COURTIS-John (Turk). Passed away June 15 at age 73. Retired New York Times. Surviving are his wife Mary, a daughter Mrs. Kelly Flynn, three brothers, Tom of Patterson, James of Oakland and George of Totowa and two grandchildren, Kelly and Dina. Services were held at St. George Greek Orthodox Church, Clifton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEJDUK, JOHN
description: HEJDUK-John. In deep sorrow, we join Gloria and the Hejduk family in mourning the loss of John, one of the most esteemed graduates of Cooper Union. A giant of a man in many respects, he was a noted architect of the world, a dedicated educator, artist, visionary, writer and poet, bringing glory to his alma mater. John was the recipient of the college's Presidential Citation, the Augustus Saint Gaudens Award for his professional achievement and the first awardee of the Artists of the City medal. He touched the lives of many alumni as our mentor, teacher and dear friend. Marilyn Hoffner President The Cooper Union Alumni Association

title: Camp Clinton Opens For the Summer
description: President Clinton has invited Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, to Camp David this week to try to end a half-century of conflict. Administration officials cautioned that success was not guaranteed.

title: A Place of Their Own, With a Difference
description: JOSEPHINE BOJNOWSKI, 83, surveys her small but cheerful apartment at Lockwood Lodge, an assisted living center associated with Ashlar of Newtown, and smiles at the place she has called home for the past year.

title: A Believable Family
description: LIKE NORMAL PEOPLE

title: The Search for Gore's Gore
description: Despite his dignified pose and his made-to-order double-breasted suits, Warren Christopher goes virtually unnoticed as he makes his way these days, always unescorted, to the offices of Democratic governors, members of Congress and well-known party members no longer in government. Discretion is what Christopher is about: in his meetings with very important Democrats, aides know to leave the room, and the conversations are off the record. No tape recorder. No entourage. No small talk. Christopher, who is 74, has devoted much of his career to ticklish sub rosa missions. He negotiated the release of American hostages from Iran in 1981. He headed the commission that recommended sweeping changes in the Los Angeles Police Department after the beating of Rodney King. As President Clinton's secretary of state, he drew up a plan for sending American troops into the Balkans.

title: Odessa in the Bronx
description: The Black Swan

title: An Unusual Choice for the Role of Studio Superhero
description: IN his jeans and V-neck sweater, Bryan Singer walked into the commissary at 20th Century Fox at lunchtime this spring resembling a youthful and eager production assistant. And he was treated that way. He was escorted to a small table right beside the kitchen's swinging doors. He removed his sunglasses and rubbed his eyes. Around him, studio executives in more comfortable accommodations seemed oblivious to the filmmaker -- ironic since the studio's fortunes this summer have, to a degree, been placed firmly in the hands of a director whose career has centered so far on low-budget and independent-style films like ''The Usual Suspects'' and the less successful ''Apt Pupil.''

title: Airport Cuisine
description: To the Editor: Two days before the Practical Traveler column on airport improvements appeared (''Making Airports More Tolerable,'' May 21), I was stuck at O'Hare for seven hours, thanks partly to the weather, partly to United.

title: Setting Maladies to Melodies
description: IT is insensitive to be glib about troubled people who take the bold leap out of their personal closets or cages to reveal their fears and fetishes, compulsions and emotional paralyses, especially in a shared setting. Yes, we're talking group therapy.

title: The Way We Live Now: 07-09-00: On Language; Beachread
description: You're on vacation. Your stress is disappearing but your brain is vegetating. You long for intellectual meat with a spicy sauce. Try a language book.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Helping Campers to Stand On Their Own (Two) Legs
description: The stresses of modern life do not seem to concern one camp counselors' assistant who lives in upstate New York. While helping to teach children, she is more occupied with the cool country air and finds pastures particularly appealing -- the greener the better. And she knows how to manage a group of young campers: while chewing a tasty clump of grass, she keeps her four legs firmly on the ground and lets them milk her.

title: Midcentury Serialists: The Bullies or the Besieged?
description: COMPILING the history of American music in the fractious decades after World War II should not be so difficult, since so many witnesses are around to report on it firsthand. But it's amazing how much disagreement exists about a central -- perhaps the central -- issue of the period: the influence of composers who advocated 12-tone techniques, or serialism.

title: Ideas & Trends: Screen Hype; Be Afraid, Be Very Afraid
description: THOUGH ''The Perfect Storm'' is just now swamping theaters near you, a still more awesome, irresistible, force of nature threatens movie audiences not just this summer, but every summer. With monsoon-like predictability, the fierce winds, towering waves and torrential rains of movie hype roll in from California every year at about this time.

description: 2 Sides Subdued in Mideast

title: 2 Knights Run Roughshod Against the Hapless Bishops
description: You often hear that a player has the advantage of the two bishops, but what of the poor knights? No one ever brags about them. When they do triumph, they are never singled out for their trenchant performance, but are treated as though they were merely anonymous workhorses during the campaign.

title: Danielle Druck, Paul Hilbert
description: Danielle Chaya Mindel Druck, a daughter of Beverly Druck and Dr. Andrew B. Druck of New York, was married on Monday to Paul Avi Hilbert, the son of Sarah and Marc Hilbert of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Aaron Slonim performed the ceremony at the Westmount Country Club in West Paterson, N.J.

title: To Run Away And Create A Circus
description: YOU can't just run away and join the circus in France these days. First you have to go to school, one of some 500 circus schools of varying degrees of excellence that have sprung up across the land to serve the nouveau cirque, or new circus, movement. Then, with whatever skills you have honed, you go looking for a job in one of 300 circuses currently operating here. Finally, after a few years of touring as an employee, yes, you may run away -- to create your own troupe.

title: New York's Double Dose of Hardball Heaven
description: Dwight Gooden, a familiar name but a wholly unexpected hero of the day, was asked between games of the most novel baseball doubleheader in nearly a century how he liked the idea of playing two games in two ballparks in two New York boroughs on the same day.

title: A Youth Spot Gets Its Share Of Disapproving Glances
description: Frustrated that a gas station and convenience store near Van Cortlandt Park has become a hangout for rowdy teenagers, neighbors are asking the Getty Corporation to shut it until a more responsive operator is found.

title: Advocate of Moderation for Heavy Drinkers Learns Sobering Lesson
description: After she founded a self-help program called Moderation Management seven years ago, Audrey Kishline became a national spokeswoman for the notion that problem drinkers could be taught to cut back without abstaining altogether. Groups like Alcoholics Anonymous that favor abstinence sharply criticized her and the book she wrote, ''Moderate Drinking: The New Option for Problem Drinkers.''

title: A Setback for Clinton
description: The Clinton administration has so far reaped all of the disadvantages of its missile defense plan and none of the rewards. News analysis, Page 4.

title: Parading, Again
description: After an absence of more than 20 years, the Columbus Day Parade in White Plains will return Sept. 23. Mayor Joseph M. Delfino used to attend the parade and wanted to bring it back; no one, he said, could remember why the event had been discontinued. Sponsored by businesses and organizations, including the Sons of Italy, the parade will celebrate the discovery of America and Italian-American culture. The parade is being held before the official Oct. 9 holiday because its rebirth came on short notice and other events were already planned for that day. The two-mile parade route is scheduled to begin at the intersection of Bryant and Mamaroneck Avenues and end downtown on Main Street. PETER BELLER

title: MONEY STORE LAYOFFS
description: Late last month, First Union Corporation announced the closing of the Money Store, which offered secondary mortgages to people with bad credit. That has meant that more than 330 New Jersey employees are now out of a job. One of the three Money Store processing sites outside of its headquarters in Sacramento, Calif, was in Warren, with 140 employees, and another loan-processing office in Pennington with 190 employees, was also closed as was a sales office in Eatontown with around three employees. PETER BELLER

title: The Last Word
description: This week, Max Frankel files the last of his Word & Image columns. For nearly six years, he has discussed, with insight and fervor, the major trends of our information age. He has paid special attention to the growth of media monopolies, to the conflict in news organizations between profit-making and civic duty and to stories that have been forgotten, missed or simply mistold. At a time of media proliferation, he has written valuably about what constitutes news -- and what does not.

title: Hitters vs. Pitchers
description: Ask a baseball pitcher why so many home runs are hit these days and you will hear an impassioned speech from a member of an oppressed minority. You will hear how umpires are calling a fist-size strike zone (They're sticking it to us!), architects are designing ballparks that couldn't hold a Crackerjack box (It's a travesty!), the mounds are lower (They won't give us any edge!) and, of course, the baseball is different -- smoother, denser, more slippery, improperly cared for by umpires who should be more diligent about rubbing them with Delaware River mud (We're throwing golf balls out there!).

title: FIRST PERSON; Farewell to a Bungalow
description: I WANTED to photograph Rockaway. When my father announced the sale of our family bungalow there, in April of last year, I suddenly felt unhinged. Even though it was nearly a decade since I'd visited the beach house or stepped foot in the ocean town of Rockaway Beach, N.Y., I still felt a sentimental attachment, an ineffable connection, to the place that, for the first 16 years of my life, was synonymous with summer. Taking pictures there would, I had hoped, enable me to tap into these feelings and transform hazy memories into black and white images.

Since the advent of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, however, the festival's all-Mozart concerts are performed in Prudential Hall and in Princeton's Richardson Auditorium, with a lecture in the Newark Museum.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; Live from New York, the Trading Day

Perhaps he is also to blame for my current, more obscure obsession. Obscure, because I am not a broker, a financial adviser or even a day trader. Heck, I don't even own a single share of stock outright. So why can't I stop watching CNBC?

title: Word for Word: The 1910 Boy Scout Manual; Stoking the Campfire's Magic And Other Tips for 'Lusty Boys'

This message, the argument went, was right there in the Scout Oath and Law, the guiding principles that generations of boys have had to know by heart and regularly recite, raising their arms in that familiar three-fingered salute and promising to be (among many other things) ''clean'' and ''morally straight.''

When my husband, Bob, and I finally bought a town house on a cul-de-sac in Valhalla, I called the Fresh Air Fund and received a host application for the summer of '99.

title: MUSIC; 'King of Rai' Returns To His Roots
description: MOST pop musicians who revisit their musical roots tend to do so either because they can afford to or because they can't afford not to. When Bob Dylan re-explored standards of the American folk canon on early 90's albums like ''Good as I Been to You'' and ''World Gone Wrong,'' he had nothing left to prove. A few years ago, however, when the members of Kiss decided to make up their faces and play their early hits again, they had nothing left to lose. But with his new album ''Kenza,'' the Algerian expatriate singer Khaled presents another reason to explore one's roots: he never got the chance to do it before.

title: Getting the Best From Windows
description: THE first windows were holes in the walls that allowed an exchange of stagnant interior air with fresh outdoor air. Since they also allowed heat to escape they were probably small and covered with cloth, reed mats or leather. With the introduction of glass panes, windows became larger to let light in and provide a view. These windows had to be custom made for each house. Yet they were not well sealed, and they let cold drafts inside during the winter months. Still a window was a valuable commodity and in Colonial times, homeowners would remove their windows and take them along when they moved to a new house.

title: The Old Ball Game
description: The Bears are well into their first full baseball season at Riverfront Stadium in Newark. These Bears, that is. There were Newark Bears a half-century ago, and back then there was another team with an animal tag, the Newark Eagles. They both played in old Ruppert Stadium in the Ironbound district, but never against each other. The Bears were part of the all-white International Minor League and the Eagles in the National Negro League. The game, and the city, in those days is the subject of an exhibition called ''Pride of Newark: Baseball's Bears and Eagles'' at the New Jersey Historical Society into next summer. Using video, sound, photographs and more, the show will go beyond the game to examine the social milieu in Newark. New Jersey Historical Society, a half-block from the performing arts center is at 52 Park Place, Newark 07102; (973) 596-8500. It is open Tuesdays through Saturdays 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission is free.

title: Electronic Music, Always Current
description: IT takes maybe 15 minutes to input the first page of Stravinsky's ''Sacre du Printemps'' into music notation software on my computer. I press the space bar, and it plays back instantly, with simulations of the original woodwind tones. Compare that process with the dozens of hours it took pioneers like Milton Babbitt to get just a single tone out of a synthesizer 40 years ago -- or even with the hundreds of IBM cards I tediously punched in a computer music class only 20 years ago, with three notes to show for it -- and it is clear that the very meaning of the term ''electronic music'' has changed. In fact, as the millennium turns over, it is appropriate to ask whether the term still means anything at all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERMAN, RHODA TRUAX
description: SILBERMAN-Rhoda Truax. Born in New York City on October 28, 1901, died June 29, 2000 in Colorado Springs, where she had lived since 1992. Prior to moving to Colorado she was a resident of Cambridge, MA for many decades. She was a graduate of the Horace Mann School and Barnard College in NY. She was the daughter of Justice Charles Henry Truax of the New York State Supreme Court and his wife, Caroline Sanders. Rhoda Truax wrote 12 novels & historical books. Her best known book, ''The Doctors Warren of Boston'', is in the collection of most libraries in this country. Rhoda was the sister of Carol Truax of NY, who was the author of 24 cookbooks. In 1924 she married Dr. Robert Henry Aldrich of Boston. In 1955 she married Henry R. Silberman, a businessman of Boston. She is survived by her daughter, Carolyn Aldrich Frost, and her son-in-law, Hunter S. Frost, both of Colorado Springs, her grandchildren, Daniel Hunter Frost of Irvine, CA, William Truax Frost of Santa Barbara, CA, and Juliana Frost of Colorado Springs, and three great grandchildren, and also by a stepson, James H. Silberman of NYC, and by a step daughter, Dorothy Silberman Altman of Cambridge, MA. Gifts in memory of Rhoda Truax Silberman may be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Ave., Montgomery, AL 36104 or to Planned Parenthood, POB 97166, Washington, DC 20077. A private memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: An Evolution From Bricks To Subtleties Of the Mind

Dancers ducked as others threw bricks at them (the power of instinct); women in swinging hammocks swiped at men carrying eggs on trays (the fragility of male-female relations). The norm consisted of flying bodies, hairsbreadth timing, confrontational games and erotic aggressiveness.

Soon after it was completed, it was sold, and the new owners transformed it into a hotel that quickly became a favorite of the aristocracy. This is the third time the hotel has been completely restored; in 1958, a fifth floor was added, providing panoramic views of nearby monuments, such as the Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore and Giotto's Campanile.

title: RYE: HOUSING INCENTIVE FOR A CITY MANAGER

A search firm hired by the city to find a new manager told Rye officials that increasingly communities with high housing costs were offering housing allowances in order to attract qualified candidates. Mayor Otis said the median price of a house in Rye is $649,500, with the average sale price last year reaching $840,700. Rye's charter requires that its city manager live in the municipality. The city manager, Julia Novak, is living in a rented house in Rye until the housing allowance is negotiated, the Mayor said. Meanwhile, the city is paying $2,700 a month for a short-term home rental for Ms. Novak, her husband and two children. ELSA BRENNER

title: 'Grandest Sight I Ever Beheld'

Our trip began and ended in the vast, semicircular hall of photomurals in the Museum of Westward Expansion, at the foot of the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial in St. Louis. Here, on the west bank of the Mississippi, just a few miles downriver from the expedition's winter camp of 1803-4, we gazed up at the snow-capped Rockies, as glimpsed by the explorers for the first time; traveled mile upon mile on the upper Missouri River; and stood atop Lemhi Pass, on the Continental Divide, where Meriwether Lewis realized what a huge tract of wilderness still lay between him and the Pacific Ocean.

Things get cozy, and soon she's back in Australia rearing a son who doesn't know who is real father is. Geoffrey Rush, Sam Neill and F. Murray Abraham play the men in her life. Rachel Griffiths is terrific as her policewoman daughter-in-law. The film answers that burning question ''What do you wear on a dinner date with Stalin?'' title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Love Your Enemies, and All That
description: Bless Jim Lehrer. He's hard-working, diligent, productive, questioning, sometimes droll. In addition to his duties as a television journalist, he has a fiction habit that has produced several down-home comic novels, a Beltway thriller, a high-concept political campaign caper, a C.I.A. confection and now, in his 12th, THE SPECIAL PRISONER (Random House, $23.95), a serious and well-researched moral inquiry. Is homicide ever justifiable? In the Dallas-Fort Worth airport, John Quincy Watson, the 71-year-old retired Methodist bishop of San Antonio, recognizes the eyes of ''the Hyena'' -- the man who, half a century earlier, had tortured him in a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp. Watson follows the man, whose name on the airline manifest is Tashimoto, on the next flight to San Diego, finds his hotel and knocks on the door of room 1808. In alternating chapters the reader learns about Watson's brief, youthful service as a pilot during World War II and his harrowing experiences as a P.O.W., his postwar marriage to the nurse who accepted what torture had done to his ''basic equipment,'' his religious vocation and sustaining friendship with a few fellow survivors of that terrible camp. Those episodes are woven around the hotel room confrontation, the death of Bill Joe Tashimoto and the eventual murder trial. Before Watson is judged, the reader is asked to consider issues of wartime behavior, survivor's guilt, peacetime resolution and the notion of self-defense. Lehrer's research shows. There are even explicit bibliographic references to the important texts about Japanese war crimes, background surely for the carefully plotted set pieces. ''The Special Prisoner'' feels more like a study for the heir to the ''well-made play'' -- the well-made-for-television movie. Lehrer's book is worthy and wanting at the same time. Eden Ross Lipson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORBETT, JAMES DAVIDSON
description: CORBETT-James Davidson. Of Sarasota, FL and Huletts Landing, NY passed away on July 6, 2000 just shy of his 90th birthday in Sarasota. He was the son of Theodore and Achsah Davidson Corbett. Jim was born in New York City and grew up in New Rochelle and graduated from New Rochelle High School in 1928. He was a member of the Dartmouth class of 1932 and graduated from the Stern School of Business at NYU. Jim's career took him from Chase Manhattan Bank to Standard and Poors to Merrill Lynch, where he became the youngest Partner, ever, in 1952. He retired from Merrill Lynch in 1970 as head of the firm's research department. Jim is preceded by his wife, Amy, and his oldest daughter Suzanne Corbett Cooper, and his brother Theodore Graham Corbett. Survivors include his sister Elizabeth Corbett Skahan of Hague, NY, daughters Martha Corbett Leith, of Michigan and Huletts Landing, NY, Jane Corbett-Floyd, of Arizona and Huletts Landing, NY, grandchildren Amy Cooper Savage, Scott Floyd, Kevin Floyd, Corbett Leith, Sarah Leith and two great-grandchildren, Andrew and Suzanne Savage. Upon retiring he and Amy moved from East Williston, Long Island to Huletts Landing, on Lake George. Jim was very active in the Lake George Association, receiving the Charles E. Tuttle Award in 1985. He was also active in the Huletts Landing Fire Department and the Mountain Grove Memorial Church. Jim started The Fund For Lake George and continues as a Director Emeritus. It is his wish that memorial donations go to The Fund For The Lake, Inc., P.O. Box 349, Lake George, NY 12845. A memorial service will be held later this summer in Huletts Landing, time and date to be announced.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Respectable Rebels
description: Three Main Line Philadelphia women who became successful commercial artists at the turn of the 20th century -- it sounds like a Jane Campion movie. But THE RED ROSE GIRLS: An Uncommon Story of Art and Love (Abrams, $39.95), by Alice A. Carter, tells how Jesse Willcox Smith (1863-1935), Elizabeth Shippen Green (1871-1954) and Violet Oakley (1874-1961) became extremely successful illustrators for books and magazines, working in a profession largely dominated by men. They forged an unconventional communal relationship based on passion for their art and love for one another. Under the mentorship of their teacher, the illustrator Howard Pyle, they earned commissions from the nation's most prestigious periodicals, including Collier's and The Saturday Evening Post. (Oakley's paintings now hang in the Pennsylvania state capitol.) Carter, who teaches illustration in the School of Art and Design at San Jose State University, elegantly describes their emotional bond and the factors that caused it to end (one of the women married). Along with their friend Henrietta Cozens, they set up a household at Philadelphia's picturesque Red Rose Inn and called themselves the ''Cogs family,'' a name formed from the initial letters of each of their surnames. In their genteel way these women were rebels, and yet their story, often lyrically romantic, and their resolutely stylized illustrations (beautifully reproduced) were the epitome of respectability. Steven Heller

title: Powering a Hot City

Consolidated Edison has said the city's newly fortified neighborhood power grids are ready for soaring temperatures and power use. Still, there are reasons to worry about how the nationwide experiment with utility deregulation will affect the reliability and cost of power in a city that thrives on electricity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, ARNOLD M., PH.D.
description: FREEDMAN-Arnold M., Ph.D., Lt. Col., U.S. Army, Retired. Colonel Freedman was born in Manhattan on June 21, 1918. He attended St. John's University and the City College of New York. At the start of World War II, he was commissioned a 2nd Lieutenant and served as a combat Infantry Officer in the New Guinea, East Indies and Philippine campaigns. He received battlefield promotions to 1st Lt. and Captain, and was awarded the Combat Infantryman Badge, two Purple Heart Medals, the Bronze Star Medal for Valor, two Presidential Merit Citations, the Philippine Liberation Medal and four other medals. In the Korean War, he was promoted to Major and was a battalion Commander, 15th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Infantry Division. He was awarded a second Combat Infantry Badge, Silver Star Medal, a second Bronze Star for Valor, two Presidential Merit Citations and five other medals. Early in the Vietnam War, he was promoted to the permanent rank of Lieutenant Colonel. He commanded battalions in the 364th and 2nd Infantry Regiments. He served as Executive Officer and Second-in-Command of the 1st Infantry Training Regiment. For outstanding service in peace-time assignments, he was awarded the Army Commendation Medal four times. Upon retirement in 1962, Colonel Freedman pursued his long held interest in Latin American history, earning a Ph.D from the University of Florida. He was Professor of History and Political Science at Palm Beach Junior College from 1964 to 1987 and had been named Professor of Distinction. Colonel Freedman is survived by his beloved wife, Gabriella Irazabal Freedman of West Palm Beach; a brother and sister-in-law, Dr. Henry and Barbara of Princeton, NJ; a nephew, Dr. Jonathan Freedman of Boston; his mother-in-law, Sheila Irazabal of Miami; his brotherin-law and wife, Alexander and Elena Nauta; two nieces, Clementina and Silvia, and nephew, Alejandro; two sisters-in-law, Angelica Nauta and Veronica Irazabal; and his devoted dog, Pepa. Colonel Freedman was a life member of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, the Retired Officers' Asssociation, the 15th Infantry Regiment Association, the Military Order of the Purple Heart, the Society of the Third Infantry Division, and the Masonic Order, 32. We will miss the twinkle in his eyes, his sense of humor and his zest for life. He was blessed with a sense of duty and responded without hesitation. A graveside funeral service with full military honors will be held at 3:00 P.M., Wed., July 12, Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA.

There's Tevye and here's Dolly, in eternal visual testament to Jerome Robbins and Gower Champion. What do those gyrating dancers giving their bowler hats a workover signify if not ''Steam Heat''? After Bob Fosse, can Michael Bennett be far behind? A whole chorus line would be nice, but it only takes a few bespangled gypsies extending top hats along with high kicks to spark a singular sensation.

description: When Queen Elizabeth II knighted Sean Connery in his hometown, Edinburgh, the actor called the occasion ''one of the proudest days of my life.'' Shame on him. Didn't Mr. Connery know that for James Bond, the legendary superspy he portrayed in seven movies, the prospect of a knighthood was as horrifying as that of a vodka martini stirred, not shaken?

title: Introduction

For many, it recalled similar hopeless journeys in history, art and literature. And parents of children with Asperger's wrote to emphasize the positive side of the syndrome.

title: The Way We Live Now: 07-09-00; Summertime Dues
description: On my first summer job I learned to cheat. I was working in one of those cute, old-timey ice cream shops where the sundaes are decorated with toothpick flags and the staff sings ''Happy Birthday'' to the customers. The day I clocked in, the owner showed me how to scoop up a generous-looking ball of ice cream that was perfectly hollow in the center. The trick was in the wrist, and it took practice, but eventually I mastered the subterfuge and was serving up great gobs of rocky road that weighed, according to a hidden kitchen scale, exactly 1.5 ounces. I felt rotten. Kids would come in holding flimsy dollar bills -- all the money they'd ever had, it seemed -- and in return I would give them globes of air that collapsed inward the moment they were licked. I complained to the owner, who threatened to let me go and accused me of being a secret ''heavy scooper'' who didn't understand the ways of business.

title: NEWARK MONORAIL
description: Starting this weekend, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will add 57 buses and vans to the 62,000 vehicles on the roads at Newark International Airport each day. The shuttles will take up the slack as repairs begin on the airport monorail, which has carried 30,000 people a day. Initially only the ends of the 1.9-mile system will be closed, but after Labor Day the entire system will be closed for three months. RONALD SMOTHERS

title: Gore Ties Bush to 'Do-Nothing' Republicans in Congress
description: Vice President Al Gore today denounced the ''do-nothing-for-people Congress'' and challenged Gov. George W. Bush to ''make one phone call'' to instruct Republican leaders to pass major pieces of stalled legislation.

title: POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; Changing of the Old Guard Is Swift in Highland Park
description: In the sprawling suburbia that carpets much of Middlesex County, this borough of 14,000 has a small-town charm, with just one supermarket, one elementary school, and one busy street. It also happens to be heavily Democratic, with a decades-old machine that was as efficient as any in the county. For years along Raritan Avenue, politics rarely got in the way of neighborliness.

description: The idea of putting two well-off Americans on board a boat full of Haitian refugees to see what it's like was perverse. These reporters, with money and homes and rescue in the wings, could not possibly share the true horror of the experience.

title: Personal Business; How Best to Deduct the High Cost of Gasoline?
description: DESPITE recent signs of easing, high prices at the gas pump continue to stir political debate. They may also change the calculus for another, more personal question: Which method should taxpayers use when figuring deductions for business mileage: the standard rate or the actual-expense version?

description: When the city approved the Park Slope Historic District in 1973, only the most magisterial blocks clustered near Prospect Park and Grand Army Plaza made the final cut.

title: Kim Jordan, John Vaughn Jr.
description: The Rev. Phyllis Kimberleigh Jordan was married on Wednesday evening to the Rev. John Henry Vaughn Jr. at Riverside Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. James A. Forbes Jr., an American Baptist minister, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Dr. Barbara Austin Lucas, an African Methodist Episcopal minister, taking part.

title: Rem Koolhaas Builds
description: Before he could build, Rem Koolhaas wrote. Now that buildings of his design are cropping up everywhere, he continues to write. ''In my own mind, I am as much a writer as an architect,'' he says.

title: A 'Dreigroschenoper' With the Cachet of Its Era
description: WERE it not for the events surrounding the 250th anniversary of Bach's death and for the recent, seemingly spontaneous surge of interest in Shostakovich's music, this would be Kurt Weill's year: not only the 50th anniversary of his death but also the centennial of his birth. As it is, plenty of Weill's often uncategorizable works have found their way into concert programs in New York and elsewhere.

title: Weathering an Austrian Political Squall
description: THE Vienna Festival, which has been bringing innovative performances to attentive Austrian audiences since 1951, this spring presented among its many offerings a Verdi ''Macbeth'' with a chorus line of lascivious-looking witches doing kicks and bumps, a von Hofmannsthal ''Elektra'' in a spectacular set of iron bars and scaffolds and a site-specific play in which actors from 10 countries dramatized the life of Balkan refugees in hotel ''rooms'' created in an empty factory building.

title: Early Buzz: The Redskins Are a Lock
description: The whispers are beginning to build toward a bold crescendo. From top National Football League executives to frequent-flyer-mile-earning scouts to assistant trainers, there is a unanimous belief that the season need not even be played, because the Washington Redskins, after one of the liveliest off-season spending binges in league history, have already won the Super Bowl. Pencil them in, it is said.

title: West Nile Virus Detected in Birds in 3 New York Counties
description: Four more dead crows, two on Long Island and one each in Westchester and Rockland Counties, have tested positive for the West Nile virus, state health officials said yesterday.

title: Off-Duty Officer Suspended for Gunshot
description: An off-duty police detective fired a single shot from his fifth-floor apartment window at a gunman who was confronting another man in the street and who had ignored the detective's order to drop the gun, officials said.

title: Flowers Amid Evidence Of Life's Ordinariness
description: Donald Baechler

title: The Bibliophile in Bergdorf's
description: TUCKED all the way in the back of the top floor at Bergdorf Goodman, behind the pillows and the coffee tables, the Manon chocolates and the tins of caviar, is a book-filled nook titled Jane Stubbs. And tucked behind the stacks of rare and vintage books is a woman tucked behind an enormous shirt and thick glasses, with the milky complexion of an attic-dwelling bookworm who seems perennially startled at the notion of visitors. One shopper, surveying the mounds of books jumbled on tables and ladders and chairs, spotted her and asked, ''Do you ever look through them?''

title: Finding a Calling In Flamenco's Home
description: DAY and night, the plaintive sound of flamenco echoes in the narrow streets of Lavapies, the Gypsy quarter of Madrid. Behind heavy wooden doors and in smoky bars, the flamencos, as the Spanish call those who revel in the ancient Andalusian music and dance, prepare for performances or simply indulge in their art form. In a sense, this is their district, a working-class neighborhood where students of flamenco from all over the world have long come to learn from the masters.

title: IN THE GALLERY WITH/Helmit Zitzwitz; A Restorer of Paintings Applies the Right Touch Both Before and After
description: HELMIT ZITZWITZ wears three hats. He organizes art exhibitions at his gallery and runs a framing business. But his main business is restoring oil paintings and works on paper.

title: A Steal, With Right Touch, in Hamptons
description: ''IT was the right thing to do,'' said the concerned hostess at the new Georgica Grill in East Hampton. We had requested a doggie bag for our leftover pasta; instead it had inadvertently been thrown out. ''It happens,'' we said. ''Forget it.'' But she insisted on giving us a freshly made portion of the outstanding fettuccine with shrimp and broccoli.

title: Sydney Airport Gets Downtown Rail Link
description: Visitors to Sydney can now travel quickly to town from the Kingsford Smith airport by train. The recently completed domestic and international terminal rail stations are part of a new route segment that feeds into the city's extensive CityRail network. The train ride from the international terminal to Sydney Central, a main downtown transportation hub, takes 11 minutes and costs $5.35. Trains will run from about 5 a.m. to midnight daily. At peak hours they will run approximately every 10 minutes, at off-peak hours, approximately every 15 minutes.

title: 'Measure for Measure' Staged at Boscobel
description: THE entrance of the players, from the distant waters through the garden paths and across the immense verdant landscape, is by now an essential rite of summer here. Perhaps they have sprung, magically, fully costumed and all dry, from the Hudson. It happens, however, that the grand procession signals the beginning of summer revelry in these parts. Under the big tent, all the grass is a stage. The Boscobel estate is out back; the mountains and lights over the river provide the omnipresent backdrop.

A candidate is supposed to represent all of us, and it sounds as if Penn has figured out a sensible means to do it.

title: Sax in the City

''The world's largest saxophone!'' brags the advance publicity. This is always a dangerous claim to make -- who knows what monstrously enlarged instruments lurk in garages and attics in the neighborhood of, say, Three Mile Island? -- but the 6-foot-8-inch contrabass is certainly the largest saxophone likely to be played on the Jersey Shore this summer.

title: The Context Isn't Limited To The Visible

Is consensus essential for good architecture or does architecture do best without it? Who should speak for the public if not the architect, who is hired for his professional and artistic capacity to interpret a time and place?

A convicted murderer, Juan Raul Garza, is scheduled to be executed on Aug. 5, but the White House, citing concerns about the fairness of the death penalty and the absence of clemency procedures, is awaiting Justice Department regulations on how inmates on death row should seek clemency.

title: Business & Investing; From the Wild Blue Yonder To the Electronic Frontier

Rancocas rises eerily from a meadow just north of Exit 4 of the New Jersey Turnpike near here, 50 miles from the Atlantic coast. What looks like the top half of a Navy vessel is actually a lab where the Lockheed Martin Corporation tests its ability to knit together naval communications gear, sensors, radar, and controls used to fire weapons.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 11 about the New York City Rent Guidelines Board misstated the background to the state legislature's 1969 passage of the Rent Stabilization Law. The law was enacted in response to sharp increases in rents of apartments not subject to the Rent Control regulations, which covered buildings built before 1947. The law was not a response to harassment by landlords seeking to vacate rent-controlled apartments.

title: A Break on the Rent . . .
description: Yorktown Stage's shows will go on at the town's Cultural and Community Center, under an arrangement that the Town Board is expected to approve next month.

title: The Pedestal Is Cracking Under an Elite in France
description: Look carefully at the class pictures in the lobby of France's National School of Administration and you can find just about everyone who counts in French politics today -- back when they all still had hair.

title: Crime
description: The wit, erudition and stylistic elegance that delighted us in the three previous novels of Sarah Caudwell, who died earlier this year in London, are abundantly at play in her final book, THE SIBYL IN HER GRAVE (Delacorte, $23.95). Thumbing her nose at the conventions of the well-made whodunit, Caudwell ransacks the literary forms that amuse her -- from the English village mystery and the 18th-century epistolary novel to the academic screwball comedy -- to devise an ingenious plot from all the pretty pieces.

title: Sports of The Times; A Victory That Was Much More
description: VENUS WILLIAMS is not the classic pioneer. Not understated, muted, conciliatory. Not grateful. Maybe it's a sign of the times, maybe a mark of personality or the protective armor of the two black women who came to this title round before her.

title: A Shipwreck Fails to Halt The Technology Tide
description: FOR Keith B. Brown, the top marketing executive for the $512 million Amerindo Technology fund, one of the most prominent stars in the firmament of technology offerings, the second quarter was, if not the best of times, then not too shabby. Investors deposited some $12 million into his fund during the quarter -- even amid the gyrations of the technology-driven Nasdaq composite index.

title: Corrections
description: A brief review in the Book Review last Sunday, about ''Tales From the Dodger Dugout,'' by Carl Erskine, misspelled the name of the Brooklyn Dodgers' organist at Ebbets Field. (It was also misspelled in the book.) She was Gladys Goodding, not Gooding.

title: Less Money Than Meets the Eye
description: A trillion-dollar gift from the productive American economy has presented both the presidential candidates and voters with the possibility of addressing a number of competing national problems or political demands. According to revised budget estimates released last month, the government can expect an extra $1.3 trillion in revenue over the next 10 years, bringing the official surplus estimate to an astounding $4.2 trillion.

title: At 93, Author Finds It's Never Too Late for an Upside-Down Book
description: DOROTHEA SEEBER, 93, has always been a little ahead of her time.

title: WHITE PLAINS: OFFICERS PLEAD GUILTY
description: Two County Jail correction officers, Bradley Belcher and Yvette Washington, have pleaded guilty to narcotics charges in Federal District Court in White Plains. They were arrested in April on complaints that both officers received bribes in exchange for delivering contraband, including alcohol and what was claimed to be heroin, to a federal inmate housed at the jail. According to the complaints, the officers received cash ranging from $150 to $300. The officers supervised between 75 and 100 federal inmates. The charges were brought after a 13-month joint investigation by, among others, the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York and the Westchester County District Attorney's Office. The complaints charged that a federal inmate cooperating with law enforcement officers helped arrange meetings between the correction officers and a person outside the jail who was purportedly the inmate's relative but who in reality was an undercover agent.

title: Art or Visual Slur? Old Mural Is at Center of a Storm
description: An image of a barefoot black boy sits in the lower left corner of a mural in the lobby of Staten Island Borough Hall. The boy occupies an obscure spot in one of 13 painted scenes that depict Staten Island's history. But he is center stage in a controversy about whether the image trivializes African-Americans and their role in local history.

title: Gort: Easy To Miss, Hard To Leave
description: A CERTAIN town in the west of Ireland seems at first to offer no reason to linger beyond the time it takes to refuel your car. It has no shop selling Celtic knickknacks, no pub with performances of ditties on the half-hour. Even its name lacks the lyricism found in those of more famous Irish destinations. It is, simply, Gort.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Westchester and Putnam Counties this week. Items may be submitted by mail, at least three weeks in advance, to Westchester Cultural Calendar, North Salem, N.Y. 10560.

title: Housing Crisis Confounds a Prosperous City; In New York, Scarcity and High Costs Spur Competing Ideas for a Solution
description: As it enters the new millennium with restored can-do bravado, New York City has cut crime, welfare and taxes and added jobs and surpluses. New office towers are rising. City leaders are dreaming again, planning for a new stock exchange site, a new Pennsylvania Station, baseball stadiums, a train to the plane, even a Second Avenue subway.

title: First Save the Body, Then the Soul
description: BLOOD AND FIRE William and Catherine Booth and Their Salvation Army. By Roy Hattersley. Illustrated. 471 pp. New York: Doubleday. $26.95.

title: Everyone Comes to Nick's
description: WHEN Gurney's Inn emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy a year ago, ending five difficult years, 82-year-old Nick Monte led the family and senior employees in an impromptu celebration. The proud hotelier, who had always done things his own way, was already planning his next big move.

title: One Thing Right
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING: ENVIRONMENT; GYPSY MOTHS
description: After a 10-year absence, gypsy moths returned last month to strip the leaves of New Jersey's forests. The gypsy moth caterpillars, which defoliate such hardwoods as oaks, maples and hickories in hilly regions, have spread throughout six counties in North Jersey, affecting an estimated 100,000 to 150,000 acres. John Kegg, chief of the state department of Agriculture bureau of plant, pest and disease control, said that next spring the problem can only get worse as the eggs laid by the caterpillars-turned-moths hatch. The state plans to spray affected areas next spring. KUSHANAVA CHOUDHURY

title: SOAPBOX; Charged Card
description: IT'S nice when people think well of you, however misguided their opinion. For instance, today's mail brought the third letter this month offering me a platinum card. I'm not sure why banks I never heard of are rendering me such tribute, except that I have a discernible pulse. But I am not alone: it has been reported that, banks have issued 33 million platinum cards. Surely, with platinum so commonplace, its top-of-the-line cachet will not last much longer. A new card will be needed to continue the march of plastic status.

title: In Madrid, There's No Such Thing As Too Much Ham
description: MY first stop in Madrid, minutes after hopping off the bus from the airport, was the museum. No, not the Prado, but the Museum of Ham. The Museo del Jamon is the largest of several chains of delicatessen-lunch spots scattered throughout Madrid (the competing chains are called the Ham Palace, the House of Ham and Mr. Ham). The decor of these emporiums is straightforward: Formica counters, glass cases filled with cheese, chorizo and salchichones (spicy salamis) and, overhead, close to a thousand salty cured carcasses suspended from the ceiling by the hoof, like chandeliers.

title: Editorial Observer; The Coming Backlash Against 'the Big Test'
description: The national obsession with getting into a brand-name college has bled down into grade school, where children who have yet to reach puberty are biting their nails over the SAT. More than two million high school students will sit for the tests this year, after concerned parents have shelled out tens of millions of dollars for special preparation classes. In the frenzy of practice and preparation, students will ignore the carefully worded booklet from the College Board, which sponsors the tests. The booklet notes that the tests have nothing to do with innate intelligence -- suggesting that no such thing exists. Nor do they measure either what was learned in high school or motivation, creativity and special talents, factors that affect success in college. The SAT is rather a test of mental dexterity, one element among many in predicting college performance.

title: Rebuilding Democracy in Peru
description: This spring Alberto Fujimori mugged democracy in Peru, retaining his presidency by winning an illegitimate election and runoff vote. Although Peru erupted in protest and foreign governments rebuked him, Mr. Fujimori gambled that his adversaries would not have the stomach to make him hold a truly democratic election. Unfortunately, this cynical strategy is proving to be correct. It is still possible, however, to rebuild the democratic institutions that Mr. Fujimori has destroyed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VLOCK, LAUREL FOX
description: VLOCK-Laurel Fox. 1926-2000. Wife of Jay I. Vlock; daughter of Rose Greenberg and the late John J. Fox; mother of Daniel and Joyce, Michael and Karen, Sandra and Glenn; grandmother to Jonathan, Elizabeth, and Andrew Vlock, Allison and Dana Schwartz, Julia and Theodore Vlock, and Adam and Mira Arbonies; sister of Marian Wexler was suddenly and tragically taken from us Saturday, July 8. She received her AB from Cornell University and Masters at Queens College. More recently, she was awarded an honorary Doctor of Human Letters from the University of New Haven in January, 1999. She was an Emmy award-winning TV producer and former PBS co-anchor. For more than 30 years she was a documentary producer, writer, TV director and broadcast and film moderator. She was co-founder of the Fortunoff Archive of Holocaust Testimonies at Yale University, the original effort to record video testimonies of survivors of the Holocaust in 1979. She was a founder and chairman of Bridgeways Communications Corp., licensee of a local TV station. She received many awards and honors including the ''Silver Hugo'', the President's Medal from Southern Connecticut State University and the Torch of Liberty Award from the Anti-Defamation League. A private service will be held today. Plans for a memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Jewish Foundation of Greater New Haven, 360 Amity Rd., Woodbridge, CT 06525, or to the University of New Haven.

New York, of course, is unusual. There is only one other major league city, Chicago, with two teams in different leagues, and one would expect more interest in a crosstown rivalry than, say, an intrastate rivalry like St. Louis and Kansas City. Even so, the excitement reached World Series levels from the very first pitch, and when the last out had been recorded at Shea Stadium on Sunday night, New Yorkers had been treated to some sterling baseball and a few memorable moments.

title: Frisking Photo Puts Whitman On Defensive
description: After enduring two years of criticism for the racial profiling practices of state troopers, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is suddenly struggling with a self-inflicted public relations problem: a picture of the governor herself, grinning as she frisks a black man.

title: French Killer In Pivotal Case To Stay in Jail
description: Patrick Henry, whose trial in 1977 for killing a 7-year-old boy helped lead to abolition of the death penalty in France, has been refused parole.

title: Poll Finds Optimistic Outlook But Enduring Racial Division
description: Thirty-five years after the dismantling of legalized segregation, a majority of Americans maintain that race relations in the United States are generally good, but blacks and whites continue to have starkly divergent perceptions of many racial issues and they remain largely isolated from each other in their everyday lives, according to a nationwide poll by The New York Times.

title: Diminishing the Welfare Rolls
description: When Eli Segal started three years ago to round up corporations to hire welfare recipients, many of his C.E.O. friends scoffed. Experts told him that only about a third of the recipients were ready for steady work, the rest untrained, undisciplined or worse. Today Mr. Segal's group -- The Welfare to Work Partnership -- has grown from 5 companies to 12,000. They have hired more than 650,000 welfare recipients, a huge bite out of the welfare rolls that has helped shrink them to about 2.5 million adults.

title: Metro Business; AT&T Complaint Names Bell Atlantic
description: AT&T has raised the stakes in a dispute with Bell Atlantic in New York, charging in a federal complaint in Washington that Verizon Communications, a unit of Bell Atlantic, illegally steers customers to its new long-distance service.

title: Vigilance Urged in Detecting Nile Virus
description: West Nile virus, the mosquito-borne illness that for a year has scared people in and around New York, is harder to detect than generally realized, researchers say.

description: Thirty-two horses burned to death yesterday in a barn fire in northern Westchester County, the police said.

This is the second such alliance QXL.com has formed in the last year in Britain; it reached a similar agreement with BT Cellnet, Britain's second-largest mobile telephone operator. Yet when these and other even more personal items come up for auction here in December, the point of interest will not be their intrinsic value but their provenance.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The yen rose after the governor of the Bank of Japan revived expectations that interest rates will rise. In New York, the dollar settled at 107.10 yen, down from 107.84 on Friday.

title: Lincoln Center Leans Off-Center; Reaching Out to a Wider Audience, Summertime and Beyond
description: There was a time when the idea of reggae music pulsing through the hallowed concert halls of Lincoln Center might have seemed like sacrilege. But as the Lincoln Center Festival prepares to open its fifth season tonight, such fare is now almost taken for granted on Manhattan's main cultural campus.

title: Great Lakes Face Endless Battle With Marine Invaders
description: Engaged in daily combat on many fronts are swarms of invader species that number in the millions throughout the Great Lakes -- among them the Eurasian ruffe, the round goby, the zebra mussel and the sea lamprey -- and hundreds of single-minded biologists and wildlife managers who are trying to destroy them.

title: PETROBRAS SHARE OFFERING
description: Brazil's state-owned oil company, Petrobras, began the country's largest public stock offering, selling a 16.6 percent stake in the company for about $4.4 billion. Initially, shares will be sold to individual Brazilian investors and the government-managed salary- guarantee funds before they are available to domestic and international institutional investors sometime after Aug. 2. Petrobras is awaiting approval from the United Securities and Exchange Commission to sell American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange. The government plans to maintain a 51 percent stake in Petrobras. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: QUEBEC PAPER MAKER EXPANDS SOUTH
description: Canada's largest producer of specialty and fine papers, Domtar Inc. of Montreal, has agreed to buy the Ris Paper Company, a distributor based in Florence, Ky., for $90 million in cash and stock. Raymond Royer, Domtar's president and chief executive, said the purchase would link Domtar more directly with end users in the United States, where almost half its sales are made.

title: F.T.C. Moves to Halt Sale Of Database at Toysmart
description: The federal government sued yesterday to prevent toysmart.com, a bankrupt Internet toy retailer, from selling its database of customer information, asserting the company had assured hundreds of thousands of online visitors that their personal data would never be shared with a third party.

description: CARPENTER - Patricia, passed away July 8, 2000 at her home in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. She was 77 years old. Patricia was born on January 21, 1923 to Daniel and Dorothy Carpenter in Del Rosa, CA. Student Composition and Theory with Arnold Schoenberg, 1942-1949; Student Piano with Ethel Leginska, 1943-1948. Chairman Department of Music, Barnard College; 1974-. An Essay in The Phenomenology of Musical Form, 1971, Arnold Schoenberg: The Musical Idea, 1995. Patricia is survived by her long time companion Dr. Silvio Baez. Cherished neices and nephews; Patty Davis, Mike Staples, Laurie Mendiones and Pamela Andersen. Funeral services are private. title: Honeywell Warns That Profit Will Fall Short for Second Quarter and Year
description: Honeywell International, citing high raw material costs in some businesses, slow growth in others and high interest rates in all of them, told investors yesterday that its second-quarter profit would be 75 cents a share, about 3 cents less than the company had predicted earlier this year. The company also lowered its earnings estimates for the full year and for 2001.

title: NO KAZAKHSTAN INQUIRY ON CONSULTANT
description: James Giffen, an American trade consultant under investigation by United States prosecutors, has not broken any Kazakh laws and is not under investigation in Kazakhstan, the country's general prosecutor's office said. United States prosecutors are investigating whether Mr. Giffen, a consultant to the Kazakh government, funneled millions of dollars in payments from major oil companies to Kazakh officials. In the late 1980's, Mr. Giffen, a lawyer by training, led a coalition of American companies that was set up to form joint ventures in the Soviet Union. More recently, he brokered agreements between the Kazakh government and oil companies. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Report Challenges the Policymaking Elite : French Diplomats Told To Go Back to School
description: PARIS  France has decided to send its governing elite, including its redoubtable diplomats, back to school to learn how to cope with new challenges in a more competitive, globalized world.

title: San Salvador Journal; Pilgrims Take Inspiration From Martyrs of the 80's
description: Like a testament to life's stubborn triumph, a rose garden filled with thick, fragrant blossoms rises at the site where soldiers killed six Jesuit priests at the Jose Simeon Canas Central American University in 1989. Nearby, a votive candle flickers in the room where the soldiers then killed a housekeeper and her daughter, hoping to eliminate any witnesses.

title: DRESDNER-COMMERZBANK TALKS
description: One of Europe's longest and most public corporate mating dances -- the merger discussions between Dresdner Bank and Commerzbank -- could continue for a few more weeks. Bank officials confirmed they were considering an arrangement under which the two banks would form a single holding company and then organize individual businesses like retail banking and asset management into separate corporations. The approach is similar to one attempted in the failed merger this spring between Dresdner and Deutsche Bank. It would allow Allianz, the giant German insurer that is Dresdner's biggest shareholder, to buy a stake in the retail banking unit and perhaps other entities as well. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: WILMAR INDUSTRIES TO ACQUIRE HARDWARE DISTRIBUTOR
description: The privately held Wilmar Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $13.15 a share, a total of around $214 million, for Barnett Inc., a hardware products distributor and marketer. Shares of Barnett rose $1.8125, or 17 percent, to $12.3125 in Nasdaq trading. Barnett, which is based in Jacksonville, Fla., and Wilmar, based in Moorestown, N.J., are both direct marketers and distributors of plumbing, hardware, electrical and security hardware products. Barnett also announced that earnings for the fourth quarter ended June 30 would be lower than expected at 19 to 21 cents a share before the write-off of start-up expenses for its national distribution center.

title: Mob Leader in North Jersey To Aid in Crime Investigations
description: The head of a Philadelphia crime family's operations in northern New Jersey admitted today to conspiring to commit murder, extortion and other activities in the last three decades and agreed to aid in investigations of the three crime families, prosecutors said.

title: A Challenging Work in Search of Appreciative Listeners
description: Long before the American composer Hugo Weisgall died at 84 in 1997, he was regarded by many musicians and critics as a major figure in 20th-century opera. General audiences have been slower to catch on. Although Weisgall's operas are the products of a skilled dramatist, his musical language, steeped in fitful Expressionism and spiked with elements of 12-tone writing, is craggy and challenging.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on July 2 about a vote by the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) in favor of an amendment to the church constitution to bar ministers from officiating at same-sex unions misstated the purpose of an amendment ratified by the church in 1997. The 1997 amendment prohibits the ordination of anyone who is sexually active outside marriage, not just noncelibate gays and lesbians.

title: City Agrees to Expand and Speed Up Cleanup of Contaminants at Reservoir Gatehouses
description: In an accord with federal officials, New York City has agreed to expand and speed up a cleanup of toxic mercury, lead and PCB's in machinery that is used to control the flow of drinking water from two of the city's upstate reservoirs.

title: CYTOGEN AGREES TO ACQUIRE ADVANCED MAGNETICS
description: The Cytogen Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Advanced Magnetics Inc. for $60 million in stock. Under the terms of the deal, Advanced Magnetics shareholders will receive $8.75 worth of Cytogen stock for each outstanding common share. Cytogen develops products to improve the diagnosis and treatment of cancer. Advanced Magnetics Inc. is a maker of diagnostic contrast agents. It develops and commercializes pharmaceutical products for the diagnosis and treatment of cancer and other diseases. Shares of Advanced Magnetics, based in Cambridge, Mass., rose $1.8125, or almost 30 percent, to $7.875 on the American Stock Exchange, while shares of Cytogen, based in Princeton, N.J., fell $1.75 each, or 15 percent, to $9.5625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, IRVING
description: POLLACK-Irving. Died at 86 of Alzheimer's on July 5, exactly 32 years after his beloved wife Marcella. Devoted father of Darryle, Carla and Josh; loving grandfather of Rachel, Leah, Aaron, Alli, Nicholas, Daniel and Spencer. He was an important pioneer and visionary who helped develop Miami Beach into a thriving tourist area. Between the late 40's and early 80's he owned and operated hotels including the Surfcomber, Nautilus, Shelborne, and Newport. He grew up in Monticello, graduated from Cornell in 1935 and moved to Miami Beach after the war. Known as a successful businessman, he was totally dedicated to his family, who will always love and miss him.

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE GETS COURT APPROVAL ON ACQUISITION
description: Liz Claiborne Inc. said yesterday that it had received bankruptcy court approval to acquire most of the assets of Monet Group Inc. for about $39.5 million, after assumption and repayment of debt. Monet, based in New York, which designs branded jewelry sold mostly through department stores, filed for bankruptcy protection May 11. In the months before the filing, the company laid off 200 workers from its Rhode Island plant and moved all manufacturing to Asia. Liz Claiborne, also based in New York, designs and markets women's and men's clothing. It had sales of $2.8 billion in 1999. Monet is expected to have annual sales of $75 million in 2000, Liz Claiborne said.

title: FOREST OIL AGREES TO BUY FORCENERGY, A RIVAL
description: The Forest Oil Corporation, a natural gas and oil exploration company, agreed yesterday to buy a rival, Forcenergy Inc., for about $615 million in stock to add wells in Alaska and the Gulf of Mexico. Forest will swap 1.6 shares for each Forcenergy share, valuing Forcenergy at $25.60 a share, based on Friday's close. Forest holders will own 56 percent of the new company. The Miami-based Forcenergy emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in February. Forcenergy's shares rose 93.75 cents, to $22.125, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Forest, based in Denver, fell $1.875 each, or 12 percent, to $14.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACK, HAROLD
description: SACK-Harold. Preeminent dealer in Americana and authority in American Antiques, age 89, passed away July 9, 2000. Born of Israel and Ann Sack in Lynn, Massachusetts, March 6, 1911. Graduated Boston Latin School Class of 1928. Graduated Dartmouth College, Class of 1932. Magna cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa. He entered the family business to join his illustrious father Israel Sack in 1933. Israel Sack had established an enviable reputation as the Dean of American antiques during his Boston career. To revive the family business during the Depression, Harold Sack took charge as President and CEO. During his career in this capacity, he formed many major, private collections of Americana in whole or in part and masterpieces to the Metropolitan Museum and other museums. He headed the donation of the Israel Sack Galleries in the Metropolitan Museum and gave installation to the Hood Museum in Dartmouth as well as the Art Institute of Chicago. He served as the trusted adviser to Clem Conger in forming the Diplomatic Reception Rooms in the Department of State. Harold Sack and Lawrence Fleischman founded and chaired the Channel 13 auctions, which earned millions for Public Television. He served as Trustee in the Baltimore Museum of Art and the Museum had a special ceremony to honor his service. Together with his brothers Albert and Robert the firm Israel Sack, Inc. maintained the tradition set by Israel Sack and were to a great extent responsible for the present recognition of the importance of American furniture contributions. He lectured extensively and many of his articles were published in Antiques Magazine and elsewhere. His book: American Treasure Hunt, the Legend of Israel Sack and his contributions to the 10 Volumes of American Antiques from the Israel Sack Collection number his contributions. In 1996, Israel Sack and sons, Harold, Albert & Robert received the prestigious Henry F. duPont Award for outstanding achievement in this field, the only time this award was offered to a dealer. In 1989 he purchased at auction the Nicolas Brown desk and bookcase for 12.1 million dollars. This was the highest price paid at that time for any work of art outside of a painting. He leaves a devoted wife, Lauretta. Four sons: Dr. Kenneth Sack (Tiburon, CA), David Sack (Pearland, TX), Michael Sack (Philadelphia, PA) and Dr. Daniel Sack, (New York City). Two brothers: Albert Sack (New York City) and Robert Sack (Ossining, NY). Eight grandchildren: Darren, Jeffery, Elizabeth, Allison, Jennifer, Jacob, Myra and Leah. He leaves a legacy to future generations that will carry the banner of Americana. His warmth, his integrity, and the affection he inspired in those whose lives he touched matched his contributions. He will be missed. Donations to the National Hemophilia Foundation 116 West 32nd Street 11 Floor, New York, NY 10001 212-328-3700 or Diplomatic Receptions Rooms Office of the Director at Department of State Washington, DC 20520 will be greatly appreciated. SACK-Harold. The Board and Members of The National Antique & Art Dealers Association of America, Inc., mourns the death of our long-time and valued member, Harold Sack, an outstanding leader in the field of American furniture. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his partners, his brothers, Albert and Robert, and the family. Andrew H. Chait, Pres. Arlie Sulka, Sec'y SACK-Harold Albert. The Officers and Staff of William Doyle Galleries extend their deepest sympathies to the family of Harold Sack. His contributions to the field of american furniture will forever be remembered. SACK-Harold. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Harold Sack, and send condolences to his family.

title: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL TO BUY ZALE'S CREDIT BUSINESS
description: The Associates First Capital Corporation, the second-largest United States finance company, agreed yesterday to buy a $630 million credit card portfolio from the Zale Corporation jewelry chain. Associates, based in Irving, Tex., which issues Visa and MasterCard credit cards, will get 840,000 Zale credit card accounts and run Zale operations in Texas, Florida, Puerto Rico and Arizona. Associates already issues cards for retailers like the RadioShack Corporation and Staples Inc.. Associates is also the largest United States issuer of gas station credit cards. Associates First's shares fell $1.0625, to $22.25, in New York trading. Zale shares were unchanged at $40.75.

title: BRAZIL WIRELESS AUCTION

The licenses will permit companies to provide the latest technology in cellular communications, including high-speed Internet access. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

Once a fleck of dog dander, a remnant from a pet-owner who previously had his seat, sparked an attack. At school in Dillon, Colo., Drew's desk had to be far from classmates who owned furry animals. And that was despite high doses of asthma medications he took every morning

Nearly everywhere you go, you're likely to see someone carrying a water bottle. Even many backpacks and some belt pouches are now equipped with holders for water bottles.

Pushcart peddlers crowding the streets hawked fish and fruit, bread and boots, pots and pickles. And with minimum start-up costs, new entrepreneurs could scrape out a living provided they were willing to bear the long hours and exposure to the elements.

Simultaneously, dozens of detectives participated in an intense manhunt but failed to turn up the assailant.

title: Review/Fashion; Life as a Party, With a Fetishistic Back Room

Yet this sense of futility, combined with the prospect of renewal, is also what drives designers like Mr. Lagerfeld, maybe all creative people, and he likened it to the lash that keeps newspaper writers toiling in pulp.

The office released new guidelines that invite environmental groups to identify potentially damaging side effects of international trade deals -- like damage to forests or gaps in enforcement standards -- before negotiations start and while they are in progress. The Sierra Club and several other environmental groups that have opposed many Clinton administration trade initiatives for environmental reasons called the guidelines a positive step. It has a six-quart bowl with a wider mouth, a 525-watt motor (upgraded from 350 watts) and an angled dough hook. title: More Wendy's in Mexico

Wendy's, based in Dublin, Ohio, now has eight restaurants in Mexico. The first new Wendy's will open this month in Ciudad Juarez, and future expansion will focus on the northern part of Mexico before going nationwide. Wendy's is the third-largest hamburger fast food chain in the world.

title: BP AMOCO TO RAISE SPENDING

The company is ahead on its plan to cut costs, which will save $4.7 billion this year and $5.8 billion next year, the chief executive, Sir John Browne, told investors in London in an annual address. Of the $13.5 billion in spending, $8 billion will go to finding and producing oil and natural gas. BP is focusing on its most promising projects, in particular gas output from Trinidad and oil development in deep waters in the Gulf of Mexico.

description: The Park Place Entertainment Corporation, the world's largest casino company, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the Las Vegas Hilton to the Los Angeles real estate developer Ed Roski Jr. for $365 million in cash, receivables and assumed debt. Mr. Roski, president and chief executive of the closely held Majestic Realty Company, will assume $31 million in liabilities and Park Place will keep $28 million in debts owed by high-rolling gamblers. The sale will allow Park Place to focus on marketing Caesars Palace Las Vegas to wealthy international gamblers. Mr. Roski said he would renovate the Las Vegas Hilton.
