description: A LONG time ago my wife came back from the market and gave me some peaches that were as hard as a rock, as they too often are. I decided to slice them very, very thin and mix them with a crisp salad. The flavor wasn't right, so I tried the peaches in a coleslaw instead. Because we often serve lobster with fruit, like papaya, I put this coleslaw with it. The flavors are sweet and sweet, and it's a very refreshing summer dish.

title: Former Tennis Player Must Now Play Errant Shots
description: The last time Caryn Wilson played in a tournament in the metropolitan area was at the United States Open tennis championships in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARTER, PAULINE
description: CARTER-Pauline. Either we have squirrels in the attic, or you've got to stop walking around all night. It's been a year since you sat with me at the kitchen table while I had my Friday night salad, since we've gone for Saturday afternoon lunch at the Diner, since we've gone for Sunday night dinner at Scotto's, since you've listened to me play the piano, since I've seen you smile, since I've heard you laugh. Your tulips came up in May. I hung your geraniums on the terrace, put the pillows on your swing and planted your garden for your birthday. The house is just not the same without you. I miss you dearly. With all my love, Larry.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AKPATA, TOKS
description: AKPATA-Toks. Gone from our soul. Forever in our hearts. Mom, Reggie, Family and Friends

title: 'Big Brother' Bounces Back
description: In its biggest test, the new CBS reality series ''Big Brother'' rebounded with some promise on Monday night, once again leading in the 8 p.m. time period.

title: All Together Now: Follow Me to Camp Tuolumne! (It Rhymes)
description: MEMO from Northern California to those seeking longevity: Forget hemp nuts. Try bug juice and lanyards. Before moving from Brooklyn, N.Y., to Piedmont, Calif., less than a year ago, it would not have occurred to me that I would soon be taking family travel advice from a clinical sexologist I met at a workout studio in Berkeley. I surely never imagined that the following summer, along with my family, I would be sitting in a dining hall packed with fellow professionals and their families singing: Bruce! Bruce! Strong and able. Get your elbows off the table!

title: In the City of Lights or in the City of Angels, How to Go Local; Los Angeles: A Big, Clean S.U.V. in Basic Black
description: You are eagerly anticipating a trip to one of the world's great cities, but dreading the thought of looking like a tourist. What to do? Just leave those bright plaid Bermuda shorts at home, and follow these tips from Times correspondents.

title: In the City of Lights or in the City of Angels, How to Go Local; Paris: Classic Films Outdoors, Skates on the Rue
description: You are eagerly anticipating a trip to one of the world's great cities, but dreading the thought of looking like a tourist. What to do? Just leave those bright plaid Bermuda shorts at home, and follow these tips from Times correspondents.

title: From Ancient Chinese Wisdom, A New Vocabulary of Wine
description: How do you organize a list of more than 500 wines? By color? Done. By type of grape? Done. Dan Perlman, the wine director of AZ, a new Asian-fusion restaurant at 21 West 17th Street, consulted an ancient Chinese guide, the I Ching, or Book of Changes, to help sort things out.

title: Now for the Hard Part: It's Over
description: CHUCK MAIDA has always loved to travel. But years ago, when he was working as an accountant, each vacation ended with the awful realization that he had to go back to work, which literally made him sick. ''My stomach would get into knots,'' Mr. Maida said. ''I used to throw up when I got back. It was horrible. That's when I realized I was doing the wrong thing.'' Eventually, Mr. Maida quit his accounting job and started his own company, All Seasons Travel, in Jacksonville, Fla.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Tiffany F. Goldberg, who was attacked on Sunday with a piece of concrete on a Manhattan street, misstated the affiliation of the Marble Collegiate Church, where she sings in the choir. It is part of the Reformed Church in America, not the Presbyterian Church. The error was repeated yesterday.

title: Classic Rock Shaking The Body And Soul
description: Champions of rock's old ways gathered Sunday and tonight at the Jones Beach Theater to pay fervid tribute to their twilight-dodging gods. Many wore ceremonial garb -- well-washed concert T-shirts from past such rituals. Most were old enough to have attended one or two decades' worth of shows featuring the Who, the band that performed on Sunday, or Jimmy Page, the former Led Zeppelin guitarist who shared tonight's stage with the Black Crowes.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: New Rosa Mexicano

title: Short Stories by Writers Who Got Away; Bear, Baby and Bad Vibes
description: We usually think of vacation as a stratagem to divert your brain with new sights and tastes (a ''change''). The idea is to shed the worries of your life and restore your energy to face them again. I wonder, though, if that is often the result. The vacation I remember most was the one during which I realized I wanted to kill my husband.

title: In School Papers, a Slice of History
description: In an exercise in pedagogical archaeology, Harold O. Levy, the chancellor of New York City schools, recently ordered his legal staff to sift through more than 30 volumes of Board of Education regulations and bulletins accumulated over the last five decades with a kind of Jarndyce v. Jarndyce reverence for bureaucratic minutiae. After reviewing them, Mr. Levy eliminated 94 of 169 regulations and all but 150 of 1,500 special circulars. Like pottery fragments, the now obsolete documents trace the cultural history of the schools. They begin at a time of idealism and innocence, when space was a new frontier and every school had a piano (in tune), and end in the present era of grim pragmatism, marked by concerns about poverty, drugs, homelessness and union work rules. Here are some highlights.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHEPPS, HOWARD
description: SHEPPS-HOWARD. 9/1/53-7/9/92 HAPPY BIRTHDAY, WISHING YOU WERE HERE ... NOT ONLY TODAY...EACH AND EVERYDAY. WE ALL MISS YOU SO.

title: Oversight Failure Blamed In Financier's Fraud Case
description: Martin R. Frankel, who prosecutors contend masterminded an elaborate insurance fraud from his estate in Greenwich, Conn., might have been shut down as early as a decade ago if Tennessee regulators had done their jobs properly, Tennessee investigators said in a report.

title: The Grapes of Ire
description: To the Editor:

title: Feasting Lethally on California's Vineyards
description: THE big news in the California wine country two years ago was the victorious conclusion to the 15-year, multimillion-dollar war against phylloxera, a parasite killer that eventually wiped out some 50,000 acres of prime California vineyard land.

title: Procter & Gamble Payout
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, which reported in April its first decline in quarterly profit in nine years, said today that it would raise its cash dividend by 9.4 percent, about one-fourth less than its average annual increase since 1995. The company said the quarterly dividend on its common stock would increase to 35 cents from 32 cents, payable Aug. 15 to shareholders of record on July 21. Procter & Gamble has raised its dividend an average of 13 percent a year for the last five years.

title: Devils Sign Swedish Defenseman
description: The day after they lost defenseman Vladimir Malakhov to free agency, the Devils signed one of their top prospects yesterday, the defenseman Josef Boumedienne, a native of Sweden and the team's seventh choice in the 1996 draft.

title: The Condemned, And the Mistakes
description: To the Editor:

title: VIRGIN SEEKS AIR INDIA STAKE
description: The airline owned by the British entrepreneur Richard Branson, Virgin Atlantic Airways, wants to buy as much as 26 percent of Air India from the Indian government. Virgin Atlantic started international flights to India last week using Air India's unused slots. Air India uses only about half the 80 international routes it has the right to fly on. That is the main reason that Virgin Atlantic, as well as its archrival British Airways, Air France and Lufthansa have shown interest in the airline.

title: Business Travel; Oh joyous day! Virgin Atlantic makes it possible for passengers to use cell phones on flights.
description: MAYDAY! Mayday!

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the career of Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican Senate candidate, misquoted Marcy Rudner Flores, a prosecutor who once worked with Mr. Lazio at the Suffolk County District Attorney's office. Ms. Flores said of Mr. Lazio, ''He wasn't like a golden boy. He was one of the guys.'' Ms. Flores did not say that Mr. Lazio was the office ''golden boy.''

title: Technology Is Heightening Job Worries, Greenspan Says
description: Rapid technological change is making jobs less secure in the United States, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today, suggesting those anxieties would keep a cap on wage demands and inflation even as unemployment holds close to a 30-year low.

title: Young People Found Uninformed on AIDS
description: A dangerously large number of young people in the developing world do not know how to protect themselves from the virus that causes AIDS, according to a report from Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund.

title: How to Improve Summer School
description: Last year's mandatory summer school for public school students who failed year-end promotion examinations was chaotic and poorly managed. But the New York City schools chancellor, Harold Levy, has learned from the mistakes of his predecessor, thus far avoiding the staffing, transportation and record-keeping problems that proved so embarrassing a year ago. Even so, summer school attendance is disappointingly low -- and is unlikely to improve until the Legislature changes the state education code to make summer school attendance mandatory for students who fail during the regular school year.

title: Ah, Paris. The Sights. The Food. The Gap?
description: PARIS in the spring is an amalgam of every luscious cliche, all the 40's movies in which lovers stroll arm in arm along a misty Seine, all the scratchy Edith Piaf recordings paying tribute to romance and loss, all the Impressionist paintings that capture the verve and atmosphere of this most beguiling of cities. Yet there is something oddly familiar about the sight before my eyes -- perfectly folded stacks of stone-washed jeans, endless piles of rainbow-colored T-shirts, crisp arrangements of khaki pants and, most of all, the distinctive, no-frills navy and white logo.

title: Diamonds and War
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Mullen Clients Undertake Reviews
description: Two clients of Mullen Advertising are undertaking account reviews.

title: Cabbage, Coal and Integrity
description: As a teenager growing up in Indiana, I worked in my father's grocery for 75 cents an hour. Since I was the boss's son, I got all the lousy jobs, like cleaning up spilled milk that had soured in the refrigerator, so that no one would think I was getting special treatment. I was paid for a 40-hour week, but I was working my father's hours. We'd get up at 5:30 a.m. to stop by a market and pick up the produce, and we didn't get home until 8 p.m.

title: Rock Musicians Warn Legislators of Internet Piracy Peril
description: Celebrity and politics collided today on Capitol Hill, as a rock musician joined online music executives and members of the Senate Judiciary Committee to discuss the effects on the recording industry of downloading music from the Internet.

title: Former Rivals Moving in Different Directions
description: It seems only a video-replay moment ago: the Liberty was playing the Charlotte Sting in the decisive game of the two-of-three-game Eastern Conference finals at Madison Square Garden. The Liberty won the game, only to lose the Women's National Basketball Association championship to the Houston Comets.

title: Grant Heads to Town And Red Carpet Is Set
description: Scott Layden stood on the top floor of an abandoned town house in Harlem yesterday morning. His sleeves were rolled up after knocking down old drywall for two hours, which left the arms and the face of the Knicks' general manager caked with plaster, soot and sweat.

title: Restrictions Put on Lawyer In Bias Case at Coca-Cola
description: A federal judge yesterday ordered Willie E. Gary, a Florida lawyer who is representing four black former Coca-Cola employees in a racial-discrimination lawsuit against the company, not to interfere with the settlement reached last month between Coke and four other employees with similar claims.

title: Police Hunt Masked Slasher Of Four Men in Prospect Park
description: Police investigators were searching yesterday for a mysterious masked man who has attacked four men late at night in Prospect Park in Brooklyn over the last two weeks.

title: Our Towns; A Picture Of Tension Over Race
description: CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN always likes being one of the guys.

title: INFINITY BROADCASTING TO BUY 2 MEMPHIS RADIO STATIONS
description: The Infinity Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that it would buy two Memphis radio stations, WMC-AM and WMC-FM, from the privately held Raycom Media for $75.5 million. The deal is in keeping with Infinity's strategy of buying radio stations in the 50 largest United States markets. Infinity, which is owned by Viacom, operates 165 radio stations and is the largest outdoor advertising company in the United States. Besides radio stations, Raycom also owns 32 television stations and a sports marketing division.

title: Bush Proposes Move To Promote Adoption
description: Gov. George W. Bush declared today that ''foster care ought to be a bridge to adoption'' and called for measures to promote adoption, including grants to states and an increase in the adoption tax credit.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The stained glass ceiling has been pierced.''

title: More Foreign Workers?
description: To the Editor:

title: The 13th Grade, and Other Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer School Truancy Rate In New York Near 40 Percent
description: Despite an intensive weeklong campaign to round up truants, more than 130,000 students in kindergarten through 12th grade -- nearly 40 percent -- are missing from the most ambitious summer school program in New York City's history, the Board of Education said yesterday.

title: SPECIAL TODAY
description: Vacation

title: Vincent D. McDonnell, 81; Was Labor Mediator for State
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, whose witty charm as New York State's chief labor mediator helped to settle disputes involving workers ranging from gravediggers to Radio City Music Hall Rockettes, died on Saturday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Corrections
description: The By the Book column in the Dining section last Wednesday about two cookbooks focusing on old-fashioned desserts misstated an ingredient in a recipe for cherry pie in ''Diner Desserts'' by Tish Boyle, and then based its criticism of the book on that error. The recipe calls for fresh or frozen cherries and describes canned cherries as ''a distant third choice.'' But the column said it called for canned and added: ''That's the downside to throwback baking. It's too bad the author did not suggest fresh fruit as an alternative.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVIS, MRS. ELVERA, A
description: DAVIS-Mrs. Elvera, a/a ''Baby Sanchez''/d. New York Committee to Celebrate National Tap Dance Day mourns September 2 passing of its Advisory Committee member. Mother of Sammy Davis, Jr., strong supporter of our efforts for more public appreciation of the tap dance skill, Mrs. Davis was our link between today's young dancers and the older masters. We will miss her council and influence.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Smithers Addiction Treatment and Research Center of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center referred incorrectly in some copies to the publication date of an article in New York magazine. The article, reporting that the clinic was being steered toward treatment using controlled drinking rather than abstinence, appeared in the issue dated July 10, not June 10.

title: Museum Fashion Shows Win Over the Public but Can Cause Conflicts : Designers Are Playing to the Galleries
description: PARIS  What current fashion is wildly popular, enduring, international and pulls in big bucks? It is the museum show.

title: COMPENSATION FOR NUCLEAR FUEL
description: The nuclear processor British Nuclear Fuels P.L.C. said it would pay $:40 million ($61 million) in compensation to the Kansai Electric Power Company of Japan for falsifying safety data on a fuel shipment. Part of the compensation could be made in services. A shipment of mixed uranium and plutonium oxide fuel, which was found last year to have falsified safety information, will be returned to Britain. British Nuclear Fuels said last year that it had found ''some falsification'' of safety data on pellets used in the nuclear fuel rods it makes from reprocessed fuel at its plant in Sellafield, England. The problem led Kansai to reject a shipment of fuel last December.

title: QUANTA PURCHASES 7 BUSINESSES, LENGTHENING ITS REACH
description: Quanta Services Inc., an installer of power and phone lines, has acquired seven businesses that expand its services and geographic reach and add about $140 million in annual sales. Terms were not disclosed. The companies include an electric-power service provider as well as installers of cable television and telecommunications lines. The newly acquired companies are in Mississippi, Oregon, Massachusetts, South Carolina, New Mexico, Montana and Wisconsin. In May, Houston-based Quanta said it had bought six other companies with similar businesses. Quanta had 1999 sales of $925.7 million.

title: Edmonton Pipeline Delivers Low
description: The migration from Edmonton to New York continues. Ron Low, a former Oiler player and coach, will be appointed the head coach of the Rangers today, a little more than a month after Glen Sather moved from Edmonton to become the Rangers' president and general manager.

title: Private Business in China: A Tough, Tortuous Road
description: Yu Xianglin wants to build a blimp.

title: Rome Journal; Italy's Fascist Buildings in Style, and for Sale
description: In an inverted salute to Mussolini's dream of Fascism through physical culture, the Stadio dei Marmi, a 1937 track stadium ringed by colossal marble nude athletes is filled again -- this time by the Big Gym outdoor fitness center, a kaleidoscope of skateboards, paddle tennis courts, aerobics classes, blaring pop music and a two-story inflatable Pepsi can.

title: The Defiant Ones: 4 Mexicans Exult in Party's Fall
description: Luis H. Alvarez stopped eating for 40 days to protest electoral fraud. Sergio Aguayo endured death threats for organizing election observers. Homero Aridjis, a prominent poet was ostracized by official literary circles for exposing government failures on the environment.

title: Short Stories by Writers Who Got Away; It Wasn't Greek to Her
description: One spring when I was young, I quit a job, converted my assets to traveler's checks and took a three-month holiday in Europe. As this mad interlude drew to a close, I found myself in Athens with $200 to my name. In light of my reduced circumstances, I checked into the Pankration Pension for Young Ladies, a clean, well-lighted dormitory offering bed and shower for 90 cents a night.

title: Deutsche Telekom May Play Jealousy Card in Search of a Deal
description: In its mating dance with several United States and European partners, Deutsche Telekom's eye has turned toward a deal that would involve acquiring both the VoiceStream Wireless Corporation and Qwest Communications International Inc., executives close to Deutsche Telekom said today.

title: Short Stories by Writers Who Got Away; Making Bubbles in Calcutta
description: I was told that when in India I should under no circumstances allow tap water to pass my lips. So I packed carefully. I took watertight plastic tape to seal my mouth and swimming goggles to protect my eyes when in the shower. I'd rather look silly in the bathroom than nurse oozing boils on my corneas.

title: Merckx on the Tour: 'It's Over'
description: ''The Tour is finished,'' Eddy Merckx decided today. He found no dissenters. Who could disagree with a man who won five Tours de France and 520 other races? Who, furthermore, could disagree after watching Lance Armstrong break a lot of legs, as the riders put it?

title: Laurel F. Vlock, 74, Filmmaker Who Started Holocaust Archive
description: Laurel Fox Vlock, who was instrumental in the videotaping and archiving of many survivors' accounts of the sufferings caused by the Holocaust, died on Saturday in New Haven, Conn. She was 74 and lived in Woodbridge, Conn.

title: Silent Like the Forests
description: To the Editor:

title: The Condemned, And the Mistakes
description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln Read Here
description: The summer cottage where President Lincoln sought solitude and relief from the pressures of office was also the place where he wrote the Emancipation Proclamation, the most important document of his administration. Anderson Cottage, four miles north of the Capitol, has served as a summer home for at least five other presidents. It was a particular favorite of Lincoln, who would spend summer afternoons reading underneath the canopy of a copper beech tree that still stands by the cottage.

title: Touring the Campuses, And Kicking the Tires
description: A FRIEND told me recently that he'd just bought a car without driving it first. I was appalled. ''How could you buy it without getting the feel of it?'' I asked. ''But it's loaded!'' he responded. ''The leather, the CD player, all the goodies.''

title: Pains and Royal Pains
description: When I tell people at parties that I am a nurse, the question I often get is: How on earth can you bear to empty bedpans? I usually stop them short with this reply: ''My patients are too sick to use bedpans.''

title: The 13th Grade, and Other Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Short Stories by Writers Who Got Away; Oklahoma City Was O.K.
description: My husband grew up in Oklahoma City and he recently persuaded me to accompany him on a trip back home. Oklahoma? Must we, dear? It's one of those states of indeterminate character, officially Southwestern yet possessing neither the mountainous grandeur of the West nor the fabled charms of the South. It does not conjure up any images, except, perhaps, for a long-ago Broadway musical in which the corn was as high as an elephant's eye, lyrics that could lead one to think that elephants were an Oklahoma specialty.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PENTECH INTERNATIONAL INC., Edison, N.J., a maker of pens and other writing and drawing instruments, said it had received an unsolicited bid of about $20 million from RoseArt Industries Inc., Livingston, N.J. Jakks Pacific Inc., Malibu, Calif., a toy maker, raised its bid to $1.60 a share from $1.40 to match RoseArt's offer.

title: Gore Prods Bush and Congress on Patients' Bill of Rights
description: Vice President Al Gore prodded his Republican opponent, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, today to get behind a bipartisan patients' bill of rights now before Congress.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: Cattle Are Standin' Like Statues; Isn't It Time to Put Those Fiberglass Visitors Out to Pasture?
description: It's time to rain on the CowParade, the influx of painted bovine forms that has been choking the sidewalks and parks of New York City, Stamford, Conn., and West Orange, N.J., since mid-June. The 500 New York cows and their suburban cousins won't be leaving until fall, when they will be auctioned off for charity.

title: Testimony Implicates Union Negotiator in Vote Fraud Case
description: The former president of a union local testified yesterday that Dennis Sullivan, the chief negotiator for District Council 37, the union of municipal workers, helped rig the union's 1995 contract ratification vote.

title: Sherry, the Perfect Mate
description: IF you scoff at the notion that pairing particular wines and foods can create magic, here is a suggestion: get some good marinated Spanish olives and a bottle of dry fino or manzanilla sherry. Chill the sherry well, pour a small glass and taste it with the olives, then see if you don't agree that, like Bogart and Bacall, the two belong together.

title: Lucas Signed For One Year By the Jets
description: Chad Pennington was branded as the Jets' quarterback of the future when he was selected in the first round of the draft. But today, the Jets announced that they had signed Ray Lucas, the backup quarterback who salvaged last season after Vinny Testaverde was injured in the first game. Lucas agreed to terms for one year at $385,000 with several financial incentives. ''When you search for the heart of the team, there's a lot of heart in Ray Lucas,'' said Coach Al Groh.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of cultural events yesterday with an article about Lincoln Center's efforts to broaden its appeal misstated the directing credit for one event and the location of another. The opera ''Writing to Vermeer'' was directed by Peter Greenaway, its librettist, and Saskia Boddeke, not by Robert Wilson.

title: Paris Offers Corsican Separatists Some Autonomy
description: After months of negotiations with Corsican nationalists, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France has offered the small Mediterranean island a level of autonomy that no other French region enjoys, including a limited right to modify laws voted in Paris.

title: Cell Phones: Hold the Rage, and Smile at Progress
description: To the Editor:

description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Austin, Tex.

title: Leo Burnett to Form Health Care Unit
description: Leo Burnett USA in Chicago said yesterday that it would form a unit devoted to consumer health care advertising named LeoHealth, with more than 45 employees and billings estimated at $150 million from clients like Pharmavite, for Nature Made vitamins, and Procter & Gamble, for brands like Metamucil and Pepto-Bismol.

title: In the City of Lights or in the City of Angels, How to Go Local; Hong Kong: Another Hip SoHo to Check Out
description: You are eagerly anticipating a trip to one of the world's great cities, but dreading the thought of looking like a tourist. What to do? Just leave those bright plaid Bermuda shorts at home, and follow these tips from Times correspondents.

title: PINNACLE SKIDS ON NEWS THAT PROFIT WILL MISS TARGET
description: The shares of Pinnacle Systems plunged yesterday after the company, a maker of digital video-editing tools, said its fourth-quarter profit had missed analysts' estimates because of lower-than-expected sales. Pinnacle's shares fell 59 percent, losing $13.4375, to $9.1875. Earlier, they traded as low as $8.8125, a new 52-week low. The company said it expected to report a profit of 6 cents to 8 cents a share for the quarter ended on June 30, excluding charges related to acquisitions and other one-time items. Analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial had expected 16 cents a share.

title: Solving The Mystery Of French Steak
description: I DUG into my first real French steak, pan-seared, at a noisy, smoke-filled brasserie near Pigalle about 20 years ago. It was onglet, and I was immediately struck by its ropy, not-too-tender but not-too-tough texture and its strong, almost kidneyish flavor. This was not your generic slab of sirloin or rib-eye or pallid filet mignon. This was a cut of meat I'd never seen before. Strange, exciting, even a little scary. This, I thought, was eating.

title: No Headline
Residents' Thoughts Turn to Missing Couple
description: As firefighters and trained dogs searched for her body in the rubble of the leveled building at 420 State Street, Noreen Davidsen was some 60 miles away at her new cottage in, as her answering machine put it, ''beautiful Ocean Grove.''

title: In Paris, Bistros Still Draw a Full House
description: THE word ''bistro'' is used as promiscuously in Paris as the word ''deli'' is used in New York.

title: Afghan Women No Longer Permitted to Work With Relief Groups
description: Years of United Nations efforts to help women in Afghanistan return to work outside their homes have been set back in recent days by the radical Islamic Taliban movement, which controls most of the country, officials said here today.

title: AIDS in South Africa
description: South Africa, the host of the world AIDS conference this week, has 4.2 million people who are infected with the AIDS virus, more than any other nation. It also has the world's fastest-growing epidemic, with infection rates that rose from 13 percent to 20 percent in the last two years. While AIDS is tragic everywhere, it is particularly so in South Africa, a nation with a wealthier and more effective government and health care system than other sub-Saharan African countries.

title: Grand Tour Leaders? They Are Likely to Be Grandparents
description: THREE weeks ago, Pat Malloy of Polk City, Fla., climbed into her 35-foot motor home and drove five hours to Tallahassee to pick up her daughter and son-in-law, along with their 22-month-old daughter and 3-year-old son. They then took off for Timberville, Va., to visit Mrs. Malloy's son and his family before heading toward Lancaster, Pa., so the children could ride Tommy-the-Train-Engine at the Strasburg Rail Road nearby.

title: Blast Levels a Brooklyn Building; 3 People Are Missing
description: Three people were missing and feared dead last night after an explosion destroyed a three-story red-brick building near downtown Brooklyn and heavily damaged the house next door, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBERTS, PEGGY
description: ROBERTS-Peggy. We miss your smile, laugh, love, heart and companionship. Stanley, Robin, Jason and Sara

title: Sports of The Times; Boss's Views Are Merely Hocus Focus
description: GEORGE STEINBRENNER, who is to baseball what Matthew Brady, Edward Steichen and Richard Avedon are to photography, is an expert on focus.

title: Sparking Up Kiwi Fruit With a Touch of Gold
description: New Zealand's kiwi growers, seeking to revive the fruit's former glory, have developed a new yellow cultivar. Called a Zespri Gold kiwi, it looks much like the green variety on the outside, but its mustard-hued flesh has a custardy texture and almost melonlike taste. The kiwis are 50 cents each at Gourmet Garage, three for $1.20 at Fairway. MELISSA CLARK

title: If You'd Like to Take a Friend
description: IF you find yourself hankering to travel with Fido, Tweety or whatever you have dubbed your pet, and you're feeling apologetic about your obsessive attachment, drop the angst. You have lots of company.

title: 'Peru' Prompts Payday
description: ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' got its first chance to go head to head with ''Big Brother'' last night, and once again its timing was impeccable: the hit game show produced yet another million-dollar winner, its sixth.

title: Girardi's Surprise
description: When Katy Feeney of Major League Baseball contacted Joe Girardi on Monday afternoon and asked him if he could get to tonight's All-Star Game for the National League, Girardi was puzzled.

title: Waging a Battle Against Independence
description: After 14 years as an agent for the Allstate Insurance Company, Gene Romero thought he had mastered the art of keeping quiet. When the company required him to work weekends, he says, he did not complain. When it cut back on office help and had him do his own paperwork, he uttered no protest. At 51, Mr. Romero thought that his silence would pave the way to an easy retirement.

title: Short Stories by Writers Who Got Away; Time Off From Herself
description: My otherwise upstanding husband used to get sick the first day of every vacation. Now we have children: he can't get sick, so he doesn't. But in the olden days, he used to push and push work-wise, then take his temperature on the plane.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR IS MIXED. The dollar was little changed against the euro and the yen. In New York, the euro settled at 95.23 cents, down from 95.49 cents on Monday. The dollar traded at 107.08 yen, down from 107.10.

title: Holocaust Memoir Is Reissued, No Longer Designated Fiction
description: It was, critics said, one of the more harrowing Holocaust novels, a prominent German writer's stark tale of a Jewish stamp dealer's hairbreadth escapes from the Nazis, in the end hiding beneath the cellar of a Ukrainian.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in the Arts & Leisure section on Sunday for the Music Festival of the Hamptons included artists from last year instead of those scheduled to perform this week. This is a corrected listing:

title: G.O.P. Tries To Delay Vote In the Senate On China Bill
description: A majority of Senate Republicans today urged their leader, Trent Lott, to delay until September a vote on a major bill establishing permanent normal trade relations with China, an approach that Democrats and business leaders said could imperil the measure.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Steinway & Sons Factory Nears End of $5 Million Makeover
description: The sprawling 27-building plant in Astoria, Queens, dates back to just after the Civil War, and its cumbersome products are still built largely by hand.

title: New York and London Urged to Learn From Each Other
description: Does New York City need lessons in how to redevelop its waterfront? Take a look at what London has done. Does London need guidance in revitalizing old neighborhoods? Have a gander at New York's methods.

title: Spinoff of Janus May Be Held Down by the Companies It Keeps
description: What is Janus Capital worth?

title: In the City of Lights or in the City of Angels, How to Go Local; In Rio, Shed Those Inhibitions
description: You are eagerly anticipating a trip to one of the world's great cities, but dreading the thought of looking like a tourist. What to do? Just leave those bright plaid Bermuda shorts at home, and follow these tips from Times correspondents.

title: Rome Modernizes, and 'She-Wolf' Loses Her Babies
description: Forcibly separating a mother from her young children is always heartbreaking. It is even harder when they have been together 500 years. But that is what has happened here, where a bronze, ''The She-Wolf'' of the Capitoline Museums, has been separated from her legendary (and also bronze) children, Romulus and Remus, for an exhibition celebrating the myth of the founding of Rome.

title: City Needs More Power Plants, Lawmakers Are Told
description: The chairman of Consolidated Edison and New York State's top utility regulator, in their first joint appearance since a power shutoff in Manhattan last month, both said yesterday that New York City residents would have to accept a new generation of electricity plants to avoid a future of brownouts and soaring prices.

title: Influence-Peddling Trial Begins for a Pataki Fund-Raiser
description: Asserting that a ''pipeline'' of political corruption stretched from Gov. George E. Pataki's campaign headquarters to the highest levels of the state criminal justice system, a federal prosecutor charged yesterday that a volunteer fund-raiser had illegally promised favorable parole rulings for three felons in exchange for donations to Mr. Pataki's 1994 election campaign.

title: Henri Gault, a Champion of Nouvelle Cuisine, Dies at 71
description: Henri Gault, a journalist and food critic, who with his longtime colleague Christian Millau gave the name nouvelle cuisine to modern French cooking, died at his summer home at St.-Sulpice-en-Pareds in southwestern France Monday. He was 71.

title: Pollution Fight Moves to the Beaches
description: For years, Southern California has been engaged in an epic pollution battle, the struggle to get rid of the brown smog that hangs over the skyline on a hot summer day.

title: Porcini and Herbal Bouillon Cubes Act More Like Flavor Bombshells
description: Drop a little cube into boiling water and get, not everyday chicken or beef bouillon, but a porcini mushroom broth for making a risotto, mushroom soup or a stew. Plop another tiny cube, a creamy frozen square of minced garlic, into a pasta sauce, and watch it dissolve, releasing a sharp jolt of flavor.

title: MANAGEMENT: Taking at the Office Reaches New Heights; Employee Larceny Is Bigger and Bolder
description: Clifton Richards was more than just a mailroom clerk. He tackled the phones, mastered new software and bought supplies at the Social Science Research Council, a nonprofit foundation where he worked in Manhattan. Always friendly, invariably dependable, he seemed to be a true asset, his co-workers say. He even dressed better than many of the staff, they say.

title: Spending Her Vacations In Paradise, $2 at a Time
description: SARATOGA shimmered in my mind's eye long before I saw the real thing, and when I finally got there, taking a Trailways bus up from the Port Authority in the summer of 1969, the shock of recognition was acute. It was like seeing a famous painting for the first time after knowing it only from books. That analogy sounds strange, but, in fact, I have felt the full intensity of my first view of Saratoga only one other time, years later, coming upon Seurat's ''Sunday on la Grande Jatte'' on my first visit to the Art Institute of Chicago.

title: Pinstriped Nightmare Is Continuing for Cox
description: In their last eight World Series games and two All-Star Games, a team managed by Bobby Cox has been unable to beat a team managed by Joe Torre.

title: Big Book Fee Is Expected for Head of G.E.
description: John F. Welch Jr., chairman of General Electric and one of the most successful executives in business, is expected to become one of the highest paid authors as well.

title: Whitman Defends Frisking Of Black Man in '96 Photo
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today defended the 1996 trip to Camden in which she cheerfully frisked a black man while accompanying police officers, and suggested that a photograph of the encounter, which surfaced over the weekend, was being misrepresented and exploited by her political opponents.

title: Milestone Report on Mercury Emissions
description: A prestigious panel of scientists declared yesterday that levels of the most hazardous form of mercury in the environment posed an unacceptable health risk to children born of women who eat fish during pregnancy, and should be reduced.

title: INFOSYS'S PROFIT DOUBLES
description: The Indian software company Infosys Technologies Ltd., the first Indian company to list its stock in the United States, announced a profit of 1.27 billion rupees in the three months that ended on June 30, up from 606.1 million a year ago. The profit included an extraordinary gain of 54.9 million rupees. Total income rose to 3.71 billion rupees from 1.84 billion rupees. The rise in earnings was largely driven by a sharp jump in revenues from e-commerce projects. Infosys's chairman and chief executive, N. R. Narayana Murthy, said the company would continue to post earnings growth in line with the rest of India's software companies. P. J. Anthony

title: Traveling: A Box Score
description: A CENTURY ago, a vacation was the privilege of a minority of Americans. Today, it is held as a sacred right, even if many people do not seem to have time to take it. Below, a sampling of facts and figures on the true national pastime.

title: High School's President Counsels Survivors of Fatal Arizona Crash
description: The president of Chaminade High School last night assembled the students who survived a fatal highway accident in Arizona for a pastoral counseling session and a debriefing about what they had seen before a summer sightseeing tour ended in a crash that killed a student and a mathematics teacher.

title: As Problems Mount, Colombia's President Shuffles His Cabinet
description: In an effort to revive the Colombian government's sharply declining political and economic fortunes, President Andres Pastrana replaced more than a third of his cabinet today, bringing in several figures associated with opposition parties in hopes of dampening their campaign to cripple his government.

title: Talks Raising Temperature Of Politics In Jerusalem
description: As the Camp David summit meeting got under way today, Vered Melki stood on a curbside near the residence of Prime Minister Ehud Barak and held up a hand-lettered sign that said, ''Go -- bring us peace.''

title: Life Story of an Artist Who Embraced Mystery
description: BLACK ANGEL

title: Swiss Bank Is Acquiring PaineWebber
description: For several years, Donald B. Marron has waved off questions about when he would relent and sell the PaineWebber Group, the fourth-largest United States brokerage firm and the biggest one that is not part of a financial services conglomerate.

title: Short Stories by Writers Who Got Away; Rollin' on the River
description: My husband, Robert Morgenthau, and I thought it would be challenging to begin our marriage by circumnavigating the vast state of New York in his 32-foot wooden fishing boat. That was 20 years ago, and even then this boat, with its cabin in which only one person can comfortably stand (and touch the head, or toilet, the narrow bunks and the little fridge without moving an inch), was considered an antique. But The Souvenir took us through hundreds of miles of waterways, from the Erie Canal to the Oswego Canal, across Lake Ontario, through the Thousand Islands of Canada and back down the Richelieu Canal to Lake Champlain and the Champlain Canal back down to the Hudson. It was two weeks of floating through Theodore Dreiser country.

title: This Mousse Cake Needs No Bells or Whistles
description: It would seem to take an act of will for the delicately mellow chocolate mousse at Il Forno, a new bakery at 400 West 50th Street, to hold its shape as a cake. Consisting of little besides excellent rich chocolate mousse, it delivers an irrefutable argument for simplicity. The mousse cake is $3.25 a slice and $29 for a whole cake, which serves 12.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about the futurist who took the name FM-2030 rendered incorrectly the names and residences of his surviving sisters in some copies. They are Farideh Sadjadi of Baltimore, Fereshteh Jahanbani of New York, Forouzandeh Moghimi of Tehran, Iran, and Behjat Ghanbari of Bushehr, Iran.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Barnard Expands Creative Writing Program

title: Hollywood Is Asked to Join A Campaign Against Drugs
description: The drug wars are gearing up in Hollywood.

title: The 13th Grade, and Other Ideas; Readers and the SAT
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Doctor Charged in Death Of 3 Patients
description: Everywhere Michael J. Swango went, it seemed, death soon followed. In medical school, as a young intern, as a doctor, many of the patients he saw died. But he always managed to find new posts -- even after he was convicted of trying to poison several co-workers by putting ant killer in their doughnuts.

title: Jack Kerouac And the Beats, Off the Road And in a Film
description: ''A splendid entertainment for the entire family -- no sex, no violence'' was how Alfred Leslie archly plugged his new film ''Pull My Daisy'' in Variety in 1959.

title: Alexander Holds On
description: Carl Alexander of Glen Arbor, trailing Heath Wassem of Fenway by six strokes with nine holes to play, finished with a 70 for a 54-hole total of 213 to win the Westchester Golf Association Open by two strokes yesterday at the Rockland Country Club in Sparkill, N.Y.

title: Pep Talk for Cone
description: David Wells of the Blue Jays said that he plans to give David Cone a call before the second half of the season to give the struggling Yankee pitcher a pep talk. Wells, the Toronto left-hander, who pitched two scoreless innings as the American League starter tonight, said that he had already tried to call Cone but had not had any success reaching him.

title: The Perfect Tempest: A Sneak Preview of Ducasse
description: THE signing of the check at Alain Ducasse is a special moment. No matter how lively the chatter at the table has been, a hush descends, and tense faces regard the slick, itemized printout in their midst with unfeigned awe. With exquisite timing, a waiter appears and holds up a velvet display board containing a dozen finely made pens. It's hard not to feel that you are about to sign a document imposing humiliating terms of surrender. It's a measure of the delicacy at Ducasse that you are allowed to do it in high style.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RIEGELHAUPT, DORIS
description: RIEGELHAUPT-Doris. 5/30/31-7/12/85. 15 years, always in our hearts. Dick and Rona

title: Yahoo Reports That Earnings Beat Estimates by a Penny
description: Yahoo announced better-than-expected quarterly earnings today, quelling investor concerns that consolidation and business failures among struggling dot-coms might hurt its revenue base.

title: Quick Trips Through The Imagination
description: SUMMER makes us think of childhood. It means school is over. It means vacation time, trips to the beach, seersucker and T-shirts and sundresses. It also means, to many of us, novels and short stories -- fiction that offers rapid transport to other places, while allowing us to put down the highlighter and pencil, shrug off facts and figures and theories, and lose ourselves in a writer's imaginative world.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BRONSTEIN, MELVIN
description: BRONSTEIN-Melvin, M.D. 4/9/24-9/1/96. A unique man, so dearly missed by his wife and children. You are in our hearts and minds every moment. Gloria and children

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Yahoo's Quarterly Profit Beats Analysts' Estimates

title: Onions Sweet And Simple
description: COOKING onions very slowly brings out amazing flavor, a rich sweetness. Just by themselves they taste great, but when you combine them with the liquid exuded by olives and tomatoes, you get a gloriously juicy base for any fish fillet or steak. With meaty grilled tuna or swordfish, the onions make an easy summer dish with a Provencal accent.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REFALO, WILLIAM J.
description: REFALO-William J. September 3, 1930-August 5, 1999. Happy Birthday, Dad. I miss you every day. Marilyn

title: State Says Hartford Police Owes It Almost $800,000
description: Painting a picture of the Hartford police as a department in administrative disarray, Connecticut's chief state's attorney complained today that the force had failed since early last year to hand over about $775,000 in drug money and other criminal assets seized by its officers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KROUWER, HENRI
description: KROUWER-Henri. Happy birthday Henri. Loving you always. Nadi

title: Search Continues for Man In Street Attack on Woman
description: The hunt continued yesterday for the disheveled man who fractured a young woman's skull with a concrete block on a Manhattan street, but the detectives were unable to narrow their search to a single suspect and made no arrests.

title: Influenced by Many but Inspired by Mexico
description: FOR almost three years, Sue Torres was the chef at Rocking Horse Cafe Mexicano in Chelsea, a showcase for the possibilities of Mexican food beyond the tyranny of nachos, burritos and refried beans. When she left Rocking Horse to become the chef at Hell's Kitchen, which opened several months ago in Clinton, I couldn't help wondering which direction her cooking would take next.

title: Bereaved Muslims Return to Bosnia Massacre Site
description: Sitting on the grass weeping, Tima Mehmedovic pointed to the spot where she had last seen her husband. Five years ago to the day, he was among thousands of men from Srebrenica who were taken away by Serbian forces and killed in probably the worst massacre of civilians Europe has witnessed since World War II.

title: Irvin Makes Retirement Official
description: More than two years after a Sunday in 1997 when he stood on the sideline with tears streaming down his cheeks because he believed his team had quit, Michael Irvin was the one quitting yesterday, nearly in tears again as he described his passion for football, the Cowboys and the city of Dallas.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PETERMAN, TOMMY DAVID
description: PETERMAN-Tommy David. September 3, 1992 In fond, loving memory. Douglas

title: W. J. Randall of Missouri, 90; Lawmaker Led Immigration Inquiry
description: Former Congressman William J. Randall, a conservative Democrat who represented his native Independence, Mo., from 1959 to 1977, died there on Friday. He was 90.

title: Reckonings; Building Glass Houses
description: On Monday, when JDS Uniphase and SDL announced their plans for a merger -- at $41 billion the largest technology merger so far -- my reaction was the same as that of most other people: ''Who? What?'' After a bit of reading established that JDS is based in Ottawa, I supplemented that initial reaction with a hearty ''Eh?'' What ever happened to companies whose names are recognizable, or at least give some hint about what business they are in?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURNETT, ALTON R.
description: BURNETT-Alton R. 9/3/05-5/7/90. Dear father and grandfather. We miss you always. The family

title: Gallo Blue Chip Is Favorite for Pace
description: Gallo Blue Chip turned out to be a great horse after receiving a low ranking as a 2-year-old. He was ranked 21st but won all eight of his races.

title: America Online Launches Mexico Service
description: America Online Launches Mexico Service

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IMBARRATO, AURELIA CALIGURI
description: IMBARRATO-Aurelia Caliguri. September 2, 1917-August 28, 1992. ''Love is something eternal-the aspect may change, but not the essence''. Valerie and Julia

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: LOWE'S COS., Wilkesboro, N.C., named Robert A. Niblock, senior vice president for finance, to the post of chief financial officer. He succeeds Thomas E. Whiddon, who was named to the new post of executive vice president for logistics and technology.

title: MetroStars Rally To Beat Farm Team
description: The MetroStars rallied from a two-goal deficit last night for a 4-2 victory over the Long Island Rough Riders, their affiliate in the A-League. The annual exhibition was played at EAB Field in East Islip, N.Y.

title: Jeter Gives the Fans an All-Star Performance
description: Derek Jeter tucked his jersey into his uniform pants and listed the people who were at the All-Star Game to watch him start for the American League tonight. Jeter mentioned his parents, his sister and three of his friends from New York, shaking his head as he talked about securing enough decent tickets. But Jeter should not have stopped his list at six people.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SACHAR, RUTH
description: SACHAR-Ruth. 9/3/99. Our MomYour wisdom, beauty and love is cherished and gives you the gift of eternal life. Randi and Michae

title: Rings Make Jeter First Among Equals
description: Honus Wagner, Ernie Banks and Cal Ripken played in three different eras. They were the best at their position in those eras. Imagine if Wagner, Banks and Ripken played in the same era. That mental exercise shouldn't be too difficult. Just look at the present era and think Alex Rodriguez, Nomar Garciaparra and Derek Jeter. They are a conglomerate of shortstops the baseball world has never seen at the same time.

title: E.P.A. Institutes Water Regulations Before a Bill Blocking Them Becomes Law
description: The Environmental Protection Agency issued new water pollution rules today, trying to outmaneuver members of Congress who thought they had killed the measure two weeks ago.

title: SEMPRA TO INCREASE STAKES IN THREE ARGENTINE UTILITIES
description: Sempra Energy, owner of big California natural gas utilities, agreed to buy stakes in three Argentine utilities held by Dominion Resources Inc. for $145 million. Sempra Energy will get 21.5 percent stakes in companies that serve 1.2 million customers in Argentina, raising its stakes to 43 percent. The San Diego-based company is also buying 25 percent of a company with a controlling interest in an electricity supplier serving more than 400,000 customers in the province of Buenos Aires. Dominion Resources, based in Richmond, Va., took stakes in the Argentine companies in January as part of its $9 billion purchase of the Consolidated Natural Gas Company.

title: Parents Should Know Cost of Free Computers, Legislators Say
Short Stories by Writers Who Got Away; Plot Takes No Holiday
description: Writers in general, and novelists in particular, have a notoriously difficult time grasping the basic concept of the vacation. Leaving our desks is not quite the same as stealing a few days away from the office. For one thing, our fictional characters tend to go along with us, like a troupe of unwanted houseguests intruding on our holiday plans. All our obsessions concerning plot, tone and style are not about to lighten up; all the technical problems that bedevil us are not likely to solve themselves just because we announce we're taking a break.

title: SENATE CHAIRMAN OFFERS PROPOSAL ON DRUG BENEFITS
description: With the battle over prescription drugs shifting to the Senate, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee has broken with House Republicans and will propose a government-administered program to offer drug benefits to all Medicare recipients, senators of both parties said today.

title: ANOTHER DELAY ON BANESPA
description: In another postponement that threatens the privatization of the Sao Paulo state bank Banespa, Brazil's Superior Tribunal of Justice referred a decision over the constitutionality of the sale to a higher court. The Supreme Federal Tribunal, which will now hear the case, is on recess and is not expected to make a decision on the government's appeal of two separate injunctions blocking the sale until August. Experts say that a government defeat in the Supreme Federal Tribunal would probably cause the sale of Banespa to be postponed at least until 2002. The auction was originally scheduled for July 18. Jennifer L. Rich

title: In the City of Lights or in the City of Angels, How to Go Local; London: New Art, Then a Tube to Hampstead
description: You are eagerly anticipating a trip to one of the world's great cities, but dreading the thought of looking like a tourist. What to do? Just leave those bright plaid Bermuda shorts at home, and follow these tips from Times correspondents.

title: Ruling Gives Juries More Say In Personal-Injury Lawsuits
description: In a decision that could be costly for the state and for local governments, the New Jersey State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that it should be up to a jury, not a judge, to decide what constitutes disfigurement or loss of bodily function in a personal-injury lawsuit.

title: HarperCollins Plans to Buy A Small British Publisher
description: HarperCollins Publishers agreed yesterday to acquire Fourth Estate, a small and highly regarded British publishing house based in London, whose authors include the popular historian Dava Sobel and the novelist Annie Proulx.

title: Vitello Tonnato, With Plenty of Sinatra
description: AT Baldoria, your problem is automatically the problem of the owner, Frank Pellegrino Jr. He takes things personally, which is why a chance remark about the jukebox selections led to an instant summit conference at my booth. ''What would you like to hear?'' Mr. Pellegrino asked, whipping out a notebook and pen. Some Claudio Villa, perhaps. Or even some Carlo Buti. Actually, just about anything that might displace Neil Diamond and Mariah Carey. Mr. Pellegrino took notes furiously and promised to put his wife on the case immediately. ''She knows all these singers and brings back things from Italy,'' he said.

title: FRANCE AWARDS PHONE LICENSES
description: Introducing more competition for phone companies providing local connections, the French government awarded national radio phone licenses to FirstMark Communications Europe S.A. and Fortel Inc. Fifty-two regional permits were also allocated. Eight companies had applied for national licenses for so-called local radio loop technology, a wireless link connecting a fixed transmission site with end users.

title: Talks Stir Memories but Not Much Hope for Refugees in Lebanon
description: Ahmed Hajar carefully unfolded the tattered deed, written in Arabic script, dated 1946, and affixed with a double row of green and purple tax stamps from the British Palestine mandate that described the farm his family owned in what is now Israel.

title: Shredding the Campaign Laws
description: Using an array of dubious legal strategies, the Republican and Democratic parties have for years circumvented many of the nation's campaign fund-raising laws. Now comes word that the House Republican Campaign Committee is so worried about winning Congressional races this year it is considering defying a 1974 law that limits what state and national parties can spend in coordination with candidates. Such an action would be another flagrant violation of the spirit of the election laws at a time when the public has been disgusted by campaign spending and fund-raising excesses.

title: School Board President Is Elected to a Fifth Term
description: William C. Thompson Jr. was unanimously re-elected president of the Board of Education yesterday, and he promised that his coming run for city comptroller would not interfere with his duties on the board.

title: More Foreign Workers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Aftermath of Internet Pedophilia Case: Guilt, and a New Awareness of Danger
description: First there were cryptic notes left next to the computer. Then phone calls in the middle of the night. Sometimes, half asleep, she would hear the front door gently closing and someone whispering in the driveway. By the time she got up, her son would be gone. Off again with the high school's bad crowd, she supposed at first. Out of control.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GINGOLD, JEFFREY I.
description: GINGOLD-Jeffrey I. August 31, 1987. Much loved, much missed and always remembered. Your sisters, Arlene Letterman-Visakay and Bonnie Klein and their families.

title: Do Endorsements and Debates Count? A Lot, It Seems
description: Endorsements and debates played critical roles in this year's contests for presidential nominations, according to findings of a huge polling project conducted by the Annenberg Public Policy Center of the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Leopold & Franz & Anna & Vera in Berlin
description: Adapted from an early unproduced play by Rainier Werner Fassbinder, Francois Ozon's ''Water Drops on Burning Rocks'' never leaves the confines of a Berlin bachelor pad done up in exquisitely detailed mid-70's decor. After a credit sequence of generic French accordion music played over color postcards of the city, the camera settles in the empty apartment to await the entrance of Leopold (Bernard Giraudeau), the suave 50-year-old who lives there, and Franz (Malik Zidi), a 19-year-old redhead he has apparently just picked up.

title: I.B.M. Adds to Services
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, said today that it had acquired the closely held Aragon Consulting Group for undisclosed terms to add marketing research services for its Internet clients. Besides being the world's largest computer maker, I.B.M. is the world's largest computer services company. Aragon, founded in 1982, provides consulting services for large companies in the United States, Canada and Britain, focusing on market research, strategy, new products and brand positioning. Clients of Aragon, which is based in St. Louis, include Toyota, Bank of America, Blue Shield of California and The Chicago Tribune .

title: INTERWOVEN TO PURCHASE NEONYOYO FOR $70 MILLION
description: The Internet software developer Interwoven Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Neonyoyo, a privately held developer of wireless technology, for $70 million in cash and stock. Interwoven, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it would use Neonyoyo's technology in its own products. Neonyoyo develops technology to send Internet content to wireless devices, and will become Interwoven's wireless division, remaining in Austin, Tex. Interwoven, which makes software intended to help companies set up and manage large Web sites, said it expected to complete the deal later this year.

title: Democrats Build Edge in Cash In Battle to Control the House
description: In an aggressive bid to topple the Republicans' fragile six-seat majority in the House of Representatives, House Democrats have built a substantial financial advantage over the Republicans.

title: Poll Positions
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Strike Against Bandwidth
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AND VIETNAM ARE SAID TO AGREE ON NORMAL TRADE
description: The United States and Vietnam have completed a sweeping trade agreement that would allow generally unfettered commerce between the two nations for the first time since the end of the Vietnam War more than a quarter-century ago, people involved in the negotiations said today.

title: Economic Scene; When it comes to enforcing taste, it's best to tread lightly -- if at all.
description: ALL around the country, conflicts are brewing over aesthetics. Instead of tolerating sights they don't like -- from tacky porch furniture to innovative architecture -- more and more Americans are demanding a world free of ''visual pollution.'' Appearance is getting the sort of regulatory scrutiny once reserved for public health and safety.

title: Mexico's Ousted Party Tries to Regroup After Stunning Defeat
description: After 10 days of chaotic infighting, the elder statesmen of the recently defeated governing party have agreed on a formula aimed at maintaining internal discipline as the party's long monopoly over Mexican power and wealth draws to a close.

title: Tidying Your Hard Drive
description: To the Editor:

title: Success? It's No Balm for a Yearning Heart
description: Affluence is supposed to bring contentment: the satisfaction of basic physical needs, the resources to enjoy more refined pleasures. But in Dave Matthews's songs, affluence can't stave off a crisis that might as well be called spiritual. It leaves him confused, lonely, appalled at his own daily compromises and longing for release. Love would help; God might help, too. But he's not sure he can hold on to either one. At Giants Stadium here on Tuesday night, opening a three-night stand, Mr. Matthews sang, ''I can't believe that we would lie in our graves/Dreaming of things that we might have been.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMGOTT, MILTON
description: AMGOTT-Milton, lawyer and public servant, died in his sleep Tuesday at his home in New York City. He was 81 and suffered from depression. An attorney in private practice Mr. Amgott was active in New York State government and politics for decades. He served briefly as Assistant Attorney General of New York State or ''Attorney Colonel'' as he liked to say. He was counsel to several committees of the State Assembly and drafted the current statutes on eminent domain, the rights of mental health patients and the state's 5-cent deposit on cans and bottles. He was a longtime member of the Liberal Party. Mr. Amgott primarily represented writers including Robert Ludlum, Eric Van Lustbader and Donald E. Westlake, who dedicated his novel ''The Hot Rock'' to ''Milt Amgott, who helped keep me from a life of crime by making it superfluous.'' He also represented many science fiction writers including James Blish and Theodore Sturgeon. He loved words above all. In addition to writing laws and contracts for a living, he spoke several languages including Serbo-Croatian and Middle English, enjoyed mysteries and the late work of James Joyce, and inked in the New York Times crossword every day. During W.W. II he served in the Army preparing intelligence reports and debriefing German prisoners. He landed on D Day at Utah Beach carrying two typewriters and no rifle. Mr. Amgott graduated Phi Beta Kappa from New York University and received law degrees from NYU and Brooklyn Law School. He was born in New York City on August 13, 1918, the son of Meyer and Rose Kaminicker Amgott. He is survived by his wife, Madeline Karr Amgott; a daughter, Margo Amgott of Briarcliff Manor, NY; a son, Seth of Washington, D.C.; a stepson Andy Karr of Halifax, NS; a stepdaughter, Katharine Karr Kaitin of Lexington, Massachusetts; a stepbrother, Daniel Platt of Forida and four grandchildren. His sister, Fay Rotenberg and a former wife Janet Laib Gottlieb, predeceased him. Funeral services will be held at 11:15A.M. Friday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NY, NY. Burial will be private.

title: CURRENTS: RENOVATIONS; From Fending Them Off To Drawing Them In
description: In Vienna, again a hotbed of design, the Austrian Museum of Applied Arts (or MAK, its German abbreviation) is proposing transforming a World War II antiaircraft bunker in Arenbergpark into the Contemporary Art Tower (or CAT). The nine-story concrete flak tower, left, with walls up to 23 feet thick, could house commercial space, six gallery levels, rooftop restaurants and a Skyspace Bar by the artist James Turrell. Jenny Holzer has envisioned electronic signs on a new 300-foot-tall broadcast tower. Drawings and a model are up until July 28 at the Max Protetch Gallery, 525 West 22nd Street; (212) 633-6999. RAUL A. BARRENECHE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, MILTON
description: MILLER-Milton, of Boca Raton and New York, died peacefully July 11th. Recipient of the Distinguished Flying Cross in China theater in WWII. Past president of the 14th Air Force Association and founder and editor of the Jing Bao journal. Beloved husband of Faye, devoted father of Larry and Terry, loving grandfather. Services at Riverside 76th Street, Thursday, July 13th at 1pm.

title: The Chaos Outside Vermeer's Quiet Rooms
description: In ''The Letter,'' the painter Jan Vermeer looks through a threshold from a darkened room. The two women he sees make no attempt to seduce the eye. Their presence is as matter-of-fact as the domestic moment we have found them in, as if they had joined the pictures on the wall and checkered floor tiles as parts of a larger still life.

title: Despite Benefits, Democrats' Estate Tax Plan Gets Little Notice
description: Small-business owners and farmers whose Washington lobbyists are ardent backers of a Republican-backed plan to repeal the estate tax seem largely unaware that President Clinton -- who has vowed to veto the Republican proposal -- has said he would sign legislation that would exempt nearly all of them from the tax starting next year.

''It's exciting to think of sound not as a melody or phrase but as tiny frozen and unfrozen specks of sonic sparkle.''

When the plane pulled up to the gate and Brian Grant disembarked, it marked the start of the Knicks' biggest recruiting opportunity and a chance to again alter their aging team.

In April, the company postponed the sale of its shares abroad because of poor market conditions. It said it still planned to list its shares overseas but would wait for the market climate to improve. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: U.S. Judge Orders Iran to Pay Families of Bombing Victims
description: In a ruling that may be largely symbolic, a federal judge has ordered the government of Iran to pay $327 million to the families of a New Jersey woman and a Connecticut man who were killed in a 1996 terrorist bombing in Israel.

title: Freed Inmates Must Get Care If Mentally Ill
description: In a stinging decision, a state judge ruled yesterday that the Giuliani administration must arrange for the continuing mental health care of thousands of inmates before they are released from the Rikers Island jail, and not ''drop them in the middle of the night at a subway station with $3 in tokens or MetroCard fare.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEJDUK, JOHN
description: HEJDUK-John. The Irwin S. Chanin School of Architecture of The Cooper Union mourns the loss of its leader, Dean John Hejduk. We express our condolences to Gloria, Rafael and Renata and all of the Hejduk family. As an architect, an administrator and as an educator, we are all the beneficiaries of Dean Hejduk's generosity of thought and depth of spirit. Thanks to his dedication and vision, the school is a unique place where creativity, leadership and innovation thrive. Dean Hejduk's independence and his commitment to independence were an inspiration for over half a century. It was and will continue to be a privilege for us to work and learn in his Foundation Building. John Hejduk was a gentleman and a gentle man. His example will continue to inspire us all. John, you will be deeply missed. The Irwin S. Chanin School of Architecture of The Cooper Union

description: As he waited to board a flight back to his native South Korea, Kim Tae Won still could not believe the reception his 40-person theater troupe had received all week from standing-room-only audiences in this provincial capital in southern Japan.

title: Hoover's to Buy Powerize
description: Hoover's Inc., a publisher of business reference materials, agreed today to buy the closely held Powerize.com Inc. for $17.1 million in cash and stock to add a research Web site with 600,000 users. The transaction consists of $2.42 million in cash and 1.48 million Hoover's shares. Powerize.com, based in Linthicum, Md., sends customized e-mail alerts and industry newsletters and provides content to corporate Internet sites. Hoover's will gain more avenues for advertising, it said.

title: Russian Auto Executive Faces Tax Charges
description: The Russian authorities brought tax evasion charges against top executives at the country's biggest carmaker today as part of President Vladimir V. Putin's efforts to loosen the grip of Russia's richest men on the country's most profitable enterprises.

title: Twyla Tharp's Dancers
description: To the Editor:

title: Sometimes the Best Defense Is Also the Hardest to See
description: Three teams survive in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship, which began nine months ago. John Rengstorff, Adam Wildavsky, Jim Krekorian, Marty Fleisher, Chris Willenken and Jesus Arias are unbeaten. In the once-defeated bracket, teams headed by Willie Ehlers and Jon Greenspan face each other. The winner of that match would need to defeat Rengstorff twice to take the title.

title: A One-Ring Circus That Breathes Fellini
description: Toward the very end of ''Filao,'' when the members of the French circus troupe Les Colporteurs take up musical instruments and parade 10-strong across the single ring under the cramped little big top that is their home in Damrosch Park during Lincoln Center Festival 2000, a name comes to mind: Fellini.

title: Rite Aid, Its Profitability in Doubt, Sells PCS Unit
description: The troubled Rite Aid Corporation announced the sale of its PCS drug-benefit-management subsidiary yesterday for about one-third less than the company paid for it only two years ago. The move came a day after Rite Aid disclosed that its profits for 1998 and 1999 had been overstated by more than $1 billion and that it lost $1.1 billion in the fiscal year ended Feb. 26.

title: Festival Opens Door to Indian Theater
description: For Indian playwrights, involvement in New York theater has been more a flirtation than anything serious. That has meant mostly short runs, small theaters and few mainstream audiences even for celebrated Indian playwrights.

title: McEnroe, His Team Hurting, Turns to McEnroe
description: John McEnroe's star turn as the United States Davis Cup captain is not exactly unfolding the way he envisioned. In the space of two days, the capricious forces of injury and accident have deprived McEnroe of Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi for the Davis Cup semifinal against Spain July 21-23 in Santander, Spain. Instead, the first-year captain will take a team anchored by Todd Martin and including Jan-Michael Gambill and Chris Woodruff.

title: Bricks, Mortar And Coalition Building
description: It was an anonymous woman in the balcony who started the song, in a small voice, and as the notes drifted over the auditorium, heads turned and a hush fell.

title: Groh Set to Tackle Parcells's Shadow And Rebuilding Job
description: The specters tug at Al Groh, affixed to his sleeve as stubbornly as bubble gum on the bottom of a shoe. The three off-season losses suffered by the Jets loom larger than any free agent departure from any National Football League team as Groh tries to steady a franchise that endured a remarkably turbulent spring, lingering in the consciousness of a team that was defined in large part by the contributions of those three.

title: Strong Gains Return Nasdaq to Positive Ground for Year
description: Internet and other computer-related stocks surged yesterday, propelling the Nasdaq market to its biggest gain in more than five weeks and back into positive territory for the year.

title: Anthrax Vaccination Program Is Failing, Pentagon Admits
description: In unusually blunt language, Pentagon officials today acknowledged the failure of their ambitious policy to inoculate all military personnel against the deadly anthrax virus.

title: Raymond Ryan, 98, Leader Of Welch Juice Company
description: Raymond T. Ryan, a former president of the Welch Grape Juice Company who helped turn it into the country's dominant seller of grape juice, died on July 4. He was 98.

title: ENGLAND SELLS MORE GOLD
description: The Bank of England sold about 25 metric tons of gold at $279.75 an ounce in the seventh of a series of auctions aimed at cutting Britain's gold reserves in half by 2004. The central bank sold 804,000 ounces at $279.75 each, which was $3.125 below the price for immediate delivery in London at the time. Demand for bullion at the auctions has steadily fallen as investor interest waned. In January, the bank received bids for 100 tons, while the total fell to 75 tons in March, 66 tons in May and less than 33 tons yesterday.

description: Has Olivier Messiaen's time come? And if so, what does that arrival say about this time?

description: Christine Miller said yesterday that she would leave the Magazine Publishers of America in New York, where she had been executive vice president and chief marketing officer, to take the same post at Discovery.com in Bethesda, Md., and New York, part of Discovery Communications.

title: Governor Whitman's Gaffe
description: A startling photograph has surfaced showing Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey grinning while frisking a black man who has his hands up and is facing a wall. The picture was taken on a night in 1996 when she accompanied state troopers who were patrolling in Camden. The man she frisked had apparently already been searched by the troopers for weapons and drugs and then handed over to the governor. The man had not been accused of any crime.

description: The Democratic National Committee's new television commercial being broadcast in 17 battleground states shows Vice President Al Gore saying that he supports an amendment to the Constitution to protect the rights of crime victims.

description: Three wireless communications companies moved aggressively today to secure a presence in Europe, a highly promising region for the next generation of mobile communications.

title: A Promenade Emerges To Catch the Falling Sky
description: WHEN the ribbon of scaffolding and razor coils went up around his building on 101st Street and Broadway a few months back, Paul Byard took it as a harmless inconvenience. As an architect, he'd been responsible for his share of those steel and plywood constructions over the years. The awning was an eyesore, but a temporary one. Then, walking down Broadway on a recent night, he approached yet another makeshift overhang, this one more isolated, an ad hoc darkened alley.

title: Mayor Eases Reins On City's Spending As Economy Booms
description: From his first days in office, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani worked to build a reputation for fiscal restraint, prescribing for the city a sober regimen necessary to eliminate the excesses he said he inherited.

title: DELL PULLS WEB-BASED PC
description: Dell Computer of Round Rock, Tex., has pulled the plug on its Web-based PC for computer novices. The WebPC, introduced in November at $999, was neither simple nor inexpensive enough to catch on, and it has disappeared from Dell's Web site. Rather than chasing the market for inexpensive Net appliances, Dell introduced a midrange line, the Dimension 4100, this week. A Dimension 4100 computer with a 733-megahertz processor, 128 megabytes of memory, a 10-gigabyte hard drive and a 17-inch monitor costs $1,299.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; AOL STARTS SITE IN MEXICO
description: The Internet service provider America Online began its first Spanish-language Internet service, called America Online Mexico. AOL International's president, Michael Lynton, said the move opened up a Spanish-speaking market of more than 400 million potential users worldwide, including some 30 million in the United States. The company hopes to entice new Mexican Web users away from established Mexican service providers like Telefonos de Mexico, which currently dominates the market. Dan Fineren (NYT)

title: Investigators Suspect That Gas Leak Was Cause of the Blast
description: Three bodies were recovered yesterday from the rubble of a Brooklyn town house that exploded Tuesday night, and fire investigators said they strongly suspected that a gas leak had caused the blast.

title: Corrections
