title: A Trip Back to Hand-Screening And Dripping Chianti Bottles
description: Supergraphics and Chianti bottles with dripping candles? Why not? Some of you have heard about the 1960's, others may want to revisit them, a time when colors were vibrant and decorating was fun -- and affordable. Kristin Hein's hand-screened wallpaper panels were inspired by Japanese kimonos from the 1920's and 30's. The 24-inch-square papers, in cranes or butterflies, can be applied with vinyl wallpaper adhesive. They are $45 a square from the Room catalog, (888) 420-7666, or at Room's first New York store, opening at 182 Duane Street (Hudson Street) on July 25.

title: Stricter Sentences for Livery-Cab Crimes
description: Tougher sentencing laws have long been used to deter violent crimes against minority groups or those in dangerous public jobs, like police officers. But yesterday, Gov. George E. Pataki signed into law a bill meant to deter violence against a private occupation: livery-cab drivers.

title: Specs: Going for the Glow
description: DOORS and walls made of light-reflecting marble can be weighty, both in pounds and dollars. While the 3/4-inch marble used to face the loft's 450-pound wood and steel doors is $10 a square foot when unfinished, when cut, polished and installed, it costs as much as $100 a square foot.

title: On U.S. TV, Mideast's Talking Heads Turn Downright Neighborly
description: To American television viewers, it was probably unremarkable to see Avraham Burg, the Israeli Parliament speaker, and Hanan Ashrawi, a Palestinian legislator, bantering, teasing each other and debating peace issues on CNN's ''Crossfire'' on Tuesday night. That's what guests with opposing points of view do on such shows: they furiously argue in a stagey way that makes it absolutely clear that they are sparring intellectually, not personally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTOR, BERNARD
description: KANTOR-Bernard. On July 12, 2000, of natural causes. Bernie, without your warmth, generosity, and laughter, the world is a darker place. Rest in Peace. Services on Friday, July 14th, 12:45 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Slavery's Fellow Travelers
description: Retrospective apologies can be a kind of psychopolitics that makes the apologizer feel good without doing anything concrete about the enduring consequences of past injustices. But the recent apologies by two Connecticut companies, Aetna and The Hartford Courant, have a singular virtue: They remind us of the usually glossed-over participation of the North in America's slave system.

title: Netpliance Is Betting That Less Will Be More
description: Netpliance, the first company to offer a simple Internet appliance for people seeking something less than a full-fledged PC, says it is significantly upgrading its i-Opener device in preparation for a big retail push for the holiday season. But the price is quadrupling, to $399.

Memorial service 11 AM, Friday, July 14 at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York.

title: Yanks Skim The Cream To Acquire Neagle
description: Making a pre-emptive strike for the best pitcher available, the Yankees shipped a ransom in top prospects to the Cincinnati Reds yesterday for the left-hander Denny Neagle, a two-time All-Star whose style of pitching makes him perfectly suited to the dimensions of Yankee Stadium.

title: Siegelgale Selected By Marriott
description: Marriott International in Bethesda, Md., is naming Siegelgale in New York to handle advertising, branding and communications for its full-service Marriott and Renaissance lodging properties. The decision on the account, with billings estimated at $20 million, came without a formal review.

title: A Dollhouse for the Wallpaper Set
description: Bozart Toys of Philadelphia is introducing a modern dollhouse ($200) with furniture by contemporary designers. The dining room set (right, $22) is by Dakota Jackson, the living room (far right, $22) includes pieces by Karim Rashid, Ron Arad and Keiser-Newman. Bathroom fixtures ($22 for the set) are green porcelain, and an art collection ($15 each) has photographs by Laurie Simmons and Cindy Sherman, and sculpture by Mel Kendrick. The family is modeled on Ms. Simmons and the architect Peter Wheelwright, who designed the house; his son; and her daughter. Due next month at Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Robot Does Surgery, A First in the U.S.
description: ICHMOND, Va., July 12 (AP)  A woman's gall bladder was removed by a robot today in the first operation in the United States performed by the newly approved da Vinci Surgical System.

title: Capturing the Dawn's Early Light
description: INTO every dark loft, a lot of light can fall. When Dr. Tilman Friedrich and his wife, Carlota Vollhardt, bought their 2,500-square-foot TriBeCa loft in 1998, they chose it for its location. It was in an 1860 building, once a warehouse for cheese and eggs, on a street graced with a triangular park. Moreover, their favorite restaurants were only a few blocks away.

title: The Next Move Is Henson's
description: Drew Henson learned he now is property of the Reds, as the result of the Denny Neagle trade, when called yesterday morning by Mark Newman, the Yankees' vice president of baseball operations. title: An Everglades Action Plan
description: Just before the July 4 recess, a Senate committee approved a bill that, with some crucial adjustments, could provide the framework for the most ambitious environmental restoration project ever undertaken in the country. The stated purpose of the bill is to restore the historic flows of fresh water that once made the Everglades one of the world's most wondrous and biologically diverse ecosystems. It will cost $8 billion over 20 years, shared by the federal government and Florida, and is the product of seven years of work by the Army Corps of Engineers, the environmental community and the Clinton administration.

title: Death of Serb Named in Newspaper Sets Off a Battle Over News Media Restrictions in Kosovo
description: The publication by an Albanian-language newspaper of the name and photograph of a Serb accused by the daily of crimes against Albanians, and his murder soon after, has stirred passionate debate about press freedom and the need to stop revenge killings in Kosovo.

title: Baby Crib Safety First, Family Heirlooms Second
description: ONE of the great pleasures of parenthood is designing a nursery and choosing a crib. But the first consideration in buying a crib should be safety, not looks. While it is tempting to use family heirlooms, antique or vintage cribs can present hazards, no matter how many generations have slept in them. Most do not meet the current government safety regulations that apply to crib manufacturers.

description: In a move to help the American computer industry and keep up with the dizzying pace of technological change, the Senate voted overwhelmingly today to ease restrictions on exports of high-performance computers.

title: Down on the Farm, Up on Technology
description: FOR farmers, the months leading to harvest time are anxious ones, a time when things like weather, pest damage and soil conditions can be unpredictable. While farmers rely largely on experience and careful guesswork, many are beginning to practice what has come to be known as precision agriculture: the use of technology to cope with the variables that jeopardize their crops.

title: HANOVER COMPRESSOR TO BUY INGERSOLL-RAND SUBSIDIARY
description: The Hanover Compressor Company agreed yesterday to acquire the compression services unit of the Ingersoll-Rand Company's Dresser-Rand subsidiary for $190 million in cash and newly issued stock in an effort to get more customers. The Dresser-Rand unit rents compression equipment and provides related services. It also has a plant in Broken Arrow, Okla., that makes gas compressor packages and related equipment. The unit is expected to have $175 million in revenue this year. Hanover Compressor, based in Houston, had $317 million in revenue last year.

title: With Project Expanding Net's Reach, There Are No Strangers in Paradise
description: ON this remote South Pacific island, the students at Pago Pago Elementary School put on a show each year of traditional songs and dances to raise money for school improvements.

title: Israeli Court Orders Jailing Of Party Chief In Bribe Case
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the once-powerful leader of the strictly Orthodox Shas Party, Aryeh Deri, should be jailed for three years, upholding his conviction for bribery and fraud.

title: Global Crossing Sells Local Phone Unit to Citizens Communications for $3.65 Billion
description: Global Crossing, the telecommunications company, agreed yesterday to sell its local phone operations to Citizens Communications for $3.65 billion in cash, which Global will use to further its construction of a worldwide communications network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, HELEN
description: FOSTER-Helen. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member, Helen Foster. We extend our deepest sympathy to her entire family. James M. Dubin, President Martin Lowy, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMAI, JAMES VINCENT
description: TOMAI-James Vincent. 79 years old. A business executive, entered into eternal rest July 11, 2000. Mr. Tomai is survived by his wife of 54 years, Kathleen Egan Tomai, his seven children, and eighteen grandchildren. Mr. Tomai is predeceased by his son, James Vincent Tomai III, and his sister, Marian Jean Dabney. The family will receive their relatives and friends, today from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at The Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Avenue, Ridgewood, NJ (201444-7650). A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Friday 10 A.M. at Saint Elizabeth Church, Wyckoff, NJ (201-891-1122). Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family (strongly) requests contributions be made to The Tusculum College, PO Box 5040, Greeneville, TN 37743, The Valley Hospital Foundation, 223 North Van Dien Avenue, Ridgewood, NJ 07450, or The Ridgewood Symphony Orchestra, PO Box 176, Ridgewood, New Jersey 07450, in memory of James Vincent Tomai Jr.

title: Fabric Under Plastic
description: Encase elegant textiles between two sheets of plastic and the result is moire effects, translucency and subtle patterns. Knoll's Imago, a new hard-surface material, can be used in place of Formica or glass. The 4-by-8-foot sheets can be cut or bent into tabletops or shelves, wall panels and screens. It is available in eight patterns, including thin pinstripes, squares and moires, and 24 colors. It costs $12 to $38 a square foot for thicknesses from 1/16 to 1/2 inch. At Knoll, 105 Wooster Street (Spring Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Building Peace in Ulster
description: The summer parade season in Northern Ireland is always a time of volatility, and this year is no different. But even the recent disturbances have been overshadowed by a common desire among Protestants and Catholics to strengthen a still-fragile peace. This year's marchers, who commemorate Protestant victories long ago, are fewer in number and less violent than in the past. They are also more marginalized, criticized even by their traditional allies for their intransigence.

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC TO CUT 1,000 JOBS FOR COMING MOVE
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation said yesterday that it would shed 1,000 jobs and move 900 more to sites in Miami and Ireland in an effort to streamline manufacturing and release more money for research. The company, based in Natick, Mass., is a maker of invasive surgical devices. It said the plan would involve a net gain of 100 jobs in its Miami plant; 525 jobs in Cork, Ireland; and 275 positions in its plant in Galway, Ireland. The company will close plants in Plymouth, Minn.; Redmond, Wash.; and Watertown, Mass., and relocate its Medi-tech unit to Watertown. Boston Scientific's shares were up $2.1875, at $26.

title: Applying Cybergraphics to Criticism
description: As its title suggests, Aaron Betsky and Erik Adigard's new book, ''Architecture Must Burn'' (Gingko Press, $39.95), is a radical call to arms to supplant the conventional built environments of today with more ephemeral structures. While the book's medium (Day-Glo graphics and wide-measure type) may seem to overpower its message, the content rises to the challenge.

title: U.S. Assures Jesse Jackson It Is Pursuing Death of a Black Mississippi Youth
description: Attorney General Janet Reno and other top Justice Department officials assured the Rev. Jesse Jackson at a 90-minute meeting in Washington today that the department was actively investigating the hanging of a black youth in his front yard in Mississippi a month ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENIHAN, THOMAS, F.X., MD.
description: LENIHAN-Thomas, F.X., MD. Age 78, of Mahwah, NJ, formerly of Ridgewood, NJ, and Saddle River, NJ. Died July 11, 2000. A 1938 graduate of Xavier High School in Manhattan, he graduated Saint Peters College in Jersey City in 1941, and New York Medical School in 1944. He was affiliated with The Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, NJ, for 37 years. Beloved husband of the late Catherine J. Lenihan, loving father of Brian T., and wife, Carol Lenihan, Kathleen F. Lenihan, Patricia, and husband, Bennett Folmar, Daniel R., and wife, Suzanne Lenihan, Christine Lenihan, Maureen and husband, John Deuser, Sheila, and husband, Daniel Jordan, adoring grandfather of fourteen, & devoted brother of Margaret Egan, and Marie O'Grady. Funeral Mass Saturday 10 A.M. at Saint Gabriel R.C. Church, Saddle River, NJ, with interment to follow in Valleau Cemetery, Ridgewood, NJ. Visiting Friday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at The Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave., Ridgewood, NJ, 201-444-7650. Donations to The Valley Hospital Foundation, Pediatric Fund, 223 North Van Dien Avenue, Ridgewood, N.J. 07450, in his memory would be appreciated.

title: A Writer Rebuilds A Home Called Childhood
description: Tony Earley and his wife, Sarah Bell Earley, were standing in their mustard-yellow kitchen, opening mail. ''French's Mustard yellow,'' Ms. Earley said. ''If you hold the jar up to the wall, it's almost identical.'' The Earleys had been on the road for six weeks, promoting Mr. Earley's first novel, ''Jim the Boy,'' published by Little, Brown last month.

title: Sending Digital Photos Directly From a Camera
description: Shutterbugs with a passion for instantly shared experiences will soon be able to send their digital photos by e-mail without ever touching their computers. Wireless photo transmission is being made possible by Digita Post software currently available in Kodak DC290 digital cameras.

description: The Comcast Corporation, the third-largest United States cable television company, agreed this week to buy two sports networks from Viacom Inc. for an undisclosed price to add more broadcasts of professional basketball and hockey.

title: A Better Way to Build a Missile Defense
description: Far from lamenting last week's highly publicized test failure, advocates of a defense against ballistic missiles should rejoice. The move to deploy an ill-conceived system supported by the Clinton administration has been stymied, and the prospect of a far more effective defense is greatly increased.

title: Woman Slain In Robbery At a Home In Queens
description: A 24-year-old woman was slashed to death inside her Queens apartment yesterday by three men who also nailed the hands of her live-in boyfriend to a two-by-four and took thousands of dollars from a safe, the police said.

In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Joseph J. Ruvane Jr. Memorial Fund, Duke Cancer Center, PO Box 3828, Durham, NC 27710.

title: VOLKSWAGEN NAMES EXECUTIVE
description: Volkswagen A.G. said it had hired Viktor Klima, the former chancellor of Austria, to head its operations in Argentina. Mr. Klima, 53, will move to Buenos Aires in the beginning of October to take over his new position as president of Volkswagen Argentina S.A. Mr. Klima stepped down as head of Austria's Social Democratic party in February.

title: MICROSOFT BUYS NETGAMES USA TO ADD TO ITS GAMING SITE
description: The Microsoft Corporation, the world's largest software maker, said yesterday that it had acquired NetGames USA Inc. to add to its Zone.com Internet games site. Terms were not disclosed. The closely held NetGames, based in Shawnee Mission, Kan., provides live reports of scores, rankings, statistics and other features that Microsoft plans to add to Zone.com and some retail games like MechWarrior4: Vengeance, set for release later this year.

title: Anticipate Financial Crises And Prepare, Greenspan Says
description: Saying that globalization is showing no signs of slowing and that further international financial crises are all but inevitable, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, offered a wide-ranging set of prescriptions last night for preventing and coping with acute economic problems around the world.

description: United States and Vietnam In a Sweeping Trade Accord

title: High-Bandwidth Web Connections Will Let Passengers Surf as They Fly
description: MANY people have fallen for the lure of high-speed Internet access only to find it hard to get. Now Boeing is promising to make it available to people traveling 500 miles per hour at 30,000 feet.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the opening of an international conference on AIDS in South Africa misspelled the surname in some copies of a scientist who signed a statement affirming the link between H.I.V. and AIDS. He is Dr. Charles van der Horst, not van der Host.

title: Web Services Offer Solutions to Bookmark Overload
description: DEBBIE TEGARDEN'S bookmark file, with 600 or so Web sites, is like a house with overflowing closets. She would like to get rid of the clutter, but the thought of parting with even one item makes her cringe.

title: Motorola Net Raced Ahead On Strong Sales in Quarter
description: Motorola Inc., the telecommunications and semiconductor giant, reported strong sales and profit growth for the second quarter today that were in line with Wall Street estimates, despite lingering weakness in the sale of its cellular telephones in Europe.

title: Millions Offered for 2 Manuscripts Show High-Stake Gambles in Publishing
description: It's bemusing that within the last few days two books that promise to deliver the wisdom of two men celebrated for their economic and business prescience and perspicacity received bids so large that many are questioning the fiscal prescience and perspicacity of the publishers who offered the money.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a program that reaches out to immigrants in Mount Kisco, N.Y., misspelled the surname of a doctor who is organizing health screening for its participants. She is Dr. Amy Salerno, not Solerno. The article also misstated the birthplaces of her parents. Both were born in the United States.

title: Gore Gets Wild Applause At Meeting of N.A.A.C.P.
description: From his opening salutation ''I am a member of the N.A.A.C.P.; it's good to be home'' -- to his closing motivational cry -- ''I'm not asking you to read my lips; I'm asking you to read my heart!'' -- a spirited Al Gore summoned black voters today to support his presidential candidacy, reminding them of his long commitment to their cause and deriding Gov. George W. Bush as offering only words, not action.

title: Wireless Valhalla: Hints of the Cellular Future
description: IT is time for the ''S.M.S. Dating Game'' on Radio X3M. Romance is in the airwaves and Cupid carries a cell phone. Thumbs ready? In 160 characters or less, use the keypad on your mobile phone to type a description of yourself and your interests, and send it to the disc jockey's phone using the wildly popular Short Messaging Service.

title: Baring Chests And Emotions In an Eruption Of Energy
description: Throughout ''In Spite of Wishing and Wanting,'' a high-energy mixed-media production strong on primal screams and fierce physicality, the experimental Belgian choreographer Wim Vandekeybus and the American art-rock composer David Byrne manage to say something powerful about nonverbal expression.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSEL, WALTER
description: CASSEL-Walter. New York City Opera mourns the death of its friend and colleague Walter Cassel. He joined the City Opera in 1948 and, for over twenty years, provided us with many memorable evenings in the theatre. More recently, he became a noted vocal coach to young singers, thus providing his encouragement to the next generation. We send our deepest sympathies to his family, his colleagues, and his many friends. Paul Kellogg General Director

title: G.O.P. Attack Dog And Chief Hand-Holder; Lazio Adviser Has a History of Making Ads Snarl and Politicians Feel Confident
description: Mike Murphy, the campaign television advertising gladiator who brought you Senator John McCain, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Oliver L. North, was parked briefly the other 18-hour day in his editing room in Falls Church, Va., engaged in his usual multitasking. He simultaneously e-mailed a friend, talked on his cell phone, snacked on candy and, not least, eyed film footage of his latest client, Representative Rick A. Lazio, as Mr. Lazio announced his Senate candidacy against the first lady in a West Islip gym.

title: G.O.P. Bills To Cut Taxes Face Votes In the Senate
description: Republicans in Congress moved closer today to passing their two main tax-cutting bills, with the House's finishing work on a previously passed tax reduction for married couples and the two parties' agreeing to a vote in the Senate this week on a plan to repeal the federal estate tax.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEROSA, ANNE (ANTONY)
description: DeROSA-Anne (Antony). On July 11, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Salvatore. Devoted sister of Dr. Michael Antony and Thomas F. Anthony. Loving aunt of several nieces and nephews. Services will be held at St. Constantine & Helen Cathedral, 64 Schermerhorn St., Brooklyn, New York. Friday at 11AM. Visitation Thursday, 2-5, 7-9 at Mc Laughlin & Sons, Third Avenue at 97th Street, Brooklyn.

title: Old, Frail and on Costly Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Banks Agree to Stop Discouraging Basic Accounts
description: Four banks that serve about one-third of bank customers in New York State have agreed to stop discouraging consumers from opening low-cost basic accounts, state officials said.

title: Istanbul Journal; Turkish Brand of Extreme Polo Making Comeback
description: Clouds of dust enveloped the riders who galloped across a field, wooden spears in hand, on a recent Sunday afternoon in this former capital of the Ottoman Empire.

title: Amid the Flux, Gooden Explores His Options and Stays Upbeat
description: Ella Gooden received so many congratulatory phone calls about her son's return to the Yankees that she felt as if Dwight had pitched another no-hitter. Gooden had so many people plant their palms on his back after his five innings against the Mets last Saturday that he wondered if it was a dream. Had he ever left the Yankees? Could his comeback be this smooth?

title: Episcopal Bishops Bar Rites Outside Marriage
description: The bishops of the Episcopal Church, acting on the most contentious issue facing their denomination's General Convention, voted late today to reject a proposal that church officials develop rites to bless relationships between couples living together outside marriage, rituals that would probably be particularly applied to gay relationships.

title: Would a Few Celebrities Please Move Here?
description: ONE of the least examined mysteries of modern suburban life is the impact on a small community when its most famous citizen suddenly ups and leaves. Did residents of Nyack, N.Y., feel they had failed last year when Rosie O'Donnell packed up her three children and moved to Greenwich, Conn.? Will they feel redeemed if she indeed buys a house nearby and returns to the greater Nyack area?

title: Ah, Simplicity
description: To the Editor:

title: DELPHI AUTOMOTIVE TO SHED 900 MANUFACTURING WORKERS
description: The Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation said yesterday that it would dismiss about 900 manufacturing workers in France, Britain and Poland as the company, the largest auto-parts maker, reorganizes its European and Latin American businesses to cut costs. The job cuts are 1.9 percent of Delphi's 46,500 European employees. The company also said it wanted to trim the administrative staff at its headquarters in Troy, Mich., by hiring out work not directly related to its main business.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Caring for Fuchsia

title: PSION MAKES PURCHASE
description: Europe's largest manufacturer of palmtop computers, Psion P.L.C. of Britain, has agreed to buy Teklogix International Inc., a Canadian company that makes wireless communications equipment, for cash and stock valued at 544 million Canadian dollars, or about $370 million. Psion will pay the equivalent of 35 Canadian dollars for each Teklogix share, a 41 percent premium to the closing price on Tuesday. The founding shareholders of Teklogix, based in Mississauga, Ontario, will tender their 27 percent holding to Psion. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Yankees Lead Majors In Dollars
description: THE Yankees made a contingency trade for Juan Gonzalez. They needed a pitcher. The Yankees tried to make a trade for Sammy Sosa. They needed a pitcher. The Yankees traded for David Justice. They needed a pitcher. The Yankees yesterday traded for Denny Neagle. He is a pitcher.

title: Lord Runcie, Outspoken Anglican Leader, Is Dead at 78
description: Robert Runcie, the former archbishop of Canterbury known for his outspoken views on the royal family and the government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, died Tuesday night at his home in St. Albans, Hertfordshire. He was 78 and had prostate cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUCK, ANNETTE CAMPBELL
description: LAUCK-Annette Campbell. On July 11, 2000 in Princeton, New Jersey. Wife of the late Peter III. Mother of Louise L. Kingston, Lauren L. Bogue and Leslie L. Barron. Also survived by eight grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Memorial service Friday, July 14, 2000 at 11 AM at Trinity Church, 33 Mercer St., Princeton. Memorial contributions to the Princeton Nursery School, 78 Leigh Ave., Princeton, 08540 or to Vassar College, 124 Raymond Avenue, Poughkeepsie, N.Y. 12604.

title: VODAFONE SELLING MANNESMANN ASSET
description: The world's largest mobile telephone operator, Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C., said it intended to sell as much as 49.9 percent of Infostrada, Italy's second-largest telephone company, to the public before the end of the year. Vodafone received a 90 percent stake in Infostrada through its acquisition of Mannesmann A.G. of Germany. Vodafone has been looking to sell the fixed-line businesses it acquired through Mannesmann to finance the purchase of third-generation mobile telephone licenses throughout Europe. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Generic-Drug Maker Agrees to Settlement In Price-Fixing Case
description: One of the world's largest makers of generic drugs tentatively agreed today to pay $147 million to settle accusations that it improperly cornered the market on raw materials for two widely prescribed drugs and then raised the price of those drugs, in some instances more than 3,000 percent.

title: For Hunting Down The 'Perfect' Outfit
description: A FASHION guru I consulted last week told me that if I wanted to look ''daring,'' I should shop online for a certain outfit that consists of a peacock blue camisole and matching skirt, then accessorize with a turquoise necklace and wedge-heeled sandals to avoid concealing any toe ring I might happen to be wearing.

title: Lawmakers Seek Way to Note Slaves' Role in Building Capitol
description: Two centuries after George Washington signed into law a bill establishing a federal city on the Potomac, historians and lawmakers are now learning that most of the laborers who erected the White House and the Capitol were black slaves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAHAVY, EDITH
description: ZAHAVY-Edith. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Edith Zahavy, beloved wife of Rabbi Zev Zahavy, former Rabbi of Congregation Zichron Ephraim, mother of Dr. Tzvee and Bernice Zahavy, Dr. Miryam and Israel Wahrman, and Prof. Reuvain Zahavy. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONDELMAN, MADELINE
description: GONDELMAN-Madeline. On July 11, 2000 at the age of 95. Beloved wife of the late Albert, loving mother of Joan Katz and the late Martin Delman, cherished grandmother of David and Nancy Katz, Ronald and Cynthia Katz, Susan & Lee Schulman, Peter and Barbara Delman, and Nina and Jonathan Mattana. Devoted great-grandmother of thirteen. She lived a long full life, may she rest in peace. For information contact Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 888-377-7303.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWERS, MARCIA (PERGAMENT)
description: POWERS-Marcia (Pergament). Devoted mother of Garry and Mel; loving mother-in-law of Michael and Mary; cherished grandmother of Alicia and Paul, Holly, Lauren, Melissa and Dr. Michael Levine and great-grandmother of Benjamin. Always in our thoughts, forever in our hearts and still sadly missed

title: Magical Voice of Harry Potter and Friends
description: STEP in, please, and don't forget to pick your jaw off the floor. See the papier-mache elephant balancing on a tightrope. The Victorian hatpin, the turquoise sheen of its 21 hummingbird heads catching the light. Ceiling-to-floor pre-Raphaelite tapestries. Miniature wooden clowns. Tiffany chandeliers casting a warm glow in the museum-toy shop that is Jim Dale's Manhattan apartment.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD PLANS TO HIRE 2,500 OVER THREE YEARS
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that it planned to hire about 2,500 consultants and technicians in the next three years as part of the push by its chief executive, Carly Fiorina, to triple revenue from services to at least $15 billion by 2003. The new workers will represent an 8.3 percent increase to Hewlett-Packard's 30,000-person services work force, which installs and maintains companies' computer networks. The company, the No. 2 computer maker, is looking at acquisitions and partnerships in services, said Tom Ashburn, vice president and general manager of the services unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WULWICK, RONNE WOHL
description: WULWICK-Ronne Wohl. To Aunt Ronne, who, with our mother Helen, taught us how to be sisters and very strong women. We will try to live up to your legacies. Our never ending love and appreciation. Nita, Grace and Amy

title: Hopes for Anti-H.I.V. Treatment Dashed
description: Women at high risk of contracting the virus that causes AIDS should not use the widely sold spermicide, nonoxynol-9, because it may increase the risk of H.I.V. rather than protect against it, the United Nations warned today.

title: There Is No Time to Relax As 'Moon' Climb Looms
description: The Tour de France took a day off today and the riders relaxed, sleeping late, doing a little training, entertaining friends and families at their hotels. Whatever else the 160 men left in the race did, anybody who said he did not spend some time thinking about the giant of Provence, Mont Ventoux, was lying.

title: Court Ruling Backs Mayor Over Council On Cable TV
description: A state judge in Albany has ruled that the Giuliani administration, not the City Council, has oversight powers over cable television in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNSTEIN, VIVIAN
description: BROWNSTEIN-Vivian, former Chief Economist of Fortune magazine, died on Monday at the age of 69. Vivian Brownstein worked at the Federal Reserve Board in Washington, D.C., served on the Commission on Money and Credit, and ended her career as Chief Economist at Fortune magazine, where her column, The Fortune Forecast, was read by the business community and Washington policy makers. Since her retirement in 1995, Vivian Brownstein has been active serving as the President of the New York chapter of the NYABE, an officer of the Downtown Economists, and an officer and member of various community organizations. Vivian Brownstein is survived by Edward, her husband of 33 years, daughters Katherine, Alison and Nancy, son Glenn, brother Leon Rosenson, mother-in-law Bess, and grandchildren Nina, Samuel and William. Funeral service will be held on Thursday, July 13, 2000 at 11 A.M., at John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont, New York.

title: A Bucolic Meeting Place For City Park Volunteers
description: ''We wanted a building with a certain exuberance to it,'' said James T. Dowell, executive director of the Riverside Park Fund, about the Volunteer House, left, a light-hearted folly to rise next year above a one-story storage building near 106th Street. Today, it is pink-painted limestone with patches of graffiti (Mike Dottie 4life) underneath a verdigris coating of moss. The group, founded in 1986 to help pull the park's socks up, sees a day when gardening classes and volunteers will flock to this airy space nestled against the cliff below Riverside Drive.

title: Prospects Dwindle For Yanks
description: The Yankees have been hoarding prospects since making the trade for Chuck Knoblauch in February 1998, refusing to unload top minor leaguers in proposed deals for Randy Johnson, Jim Edmonds and Sammy Sosa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOETTEL, MANNY
description: GOETTEL-Manny. The Officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved member, Manny. He will be missed by all.

title: A Little Levittown on the Neva
description: SEVERAL homeowners, cell phones at hand, tend their lawns and gardens. Others are firing up a barbecue in the backyard, while on the street children ride mountain bikes or skate by on Rollerblades. Two little girls talk about going with their mothers to get a bite to eat at McDonald's.

title: Bar Code Software For Comparing Prices
description: Most people never even think about looking at the bar code on a book or CD they are about to buy. But new bar code software may cause some shoppers to hunt for those black-and-white symbols whenever they pick up a product.

title: Times and Holtzbrinck Group Agree to Revive Times Books
description: The New York Times and Holtzbrinck Publishers, the United States arm of the German media company von Holtzbrinck Group, agreed yesterday to restart the Times Books imprint and expand The Times's book development.

title: New Management At Initiative Media
description: Initiative Media Worldwide, the agency owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies that handles media services for accounts with billings estimated at more than $12 billion, is making top management changes as Larry Lamattina, the chairman and chief executive, prepares to retire, effective on Sept. 30.

title: At Columbia, Music Videos for Electronic Compositions
Classical Sheet Music on CD's
description: THE Theodore Presser Company started publishing sheet music in 1783. This week it will start to publish sheet music in a different form, as PDF files on CD-ROM disks.

description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro dropped as speculation mounted that more European acquisitions of American companies will spur demand for dollars. In New York, the euro settled at 94.18 cents, down from 95.23 cents on Tuesday.

title: New Hampshire's House Impeaches Chief Justice
description: In a historic first, the New Hampshire House of Representatives impeached the chief justice of the State Supreme Court today, accusing him of four ethical lapses and handing his fate over to the State Senate for trial.

title: Tracking the Tour de France on the Web
description: LAST year Lance Armstrong, of Austin, Tex., won the grueling Tour de France bicycle race after recovering from a brush with death from testicular cancer. Despite the attention Mr. Armstrong received, the United States remains one of the few places on earth where cycling fans can't get live television broadcasts of all 21 races that make up the Tour this year. That may be just as well. The time difference between here and France means that depending on where you are, catching an entire daily stage of the three-week Tour live would mean losing sleep or skipping work.

title: Corrections
description: The byline for the Currents column on June 29, with brief reports about Italy's new embassy in Washington and the United States pavilion at the Architecture Biennale fair in Venice, misspelled the surname of the writer and omitted his middle initial. He is Raul A. Barreneche, not Berreneche.

title: De Beers Halts Its Hoarding Of Diamonds
description: De Beers Consolidated Mines, the diamond company that reigned as one of the most powerful monopolies of the 20th century, announced yesterday in London a seismic shift in the way it does business.

description: To the Editor:

title: Profit Rises 6.2% at Abbott Laboratories
description: Abbott Laboratories said today that its second-quarter profit rose 6.2 percent as higher sales of some drugs made up for generic competition for another medicine and suspension of sales of some medical tests.

title: I.B.M. Establishes Family-Care Fund
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest computer maker, has established a $50 million fund to aid employees with child and elder care.

title: ISRAEL DROPS PLAN TO SELL AIR RADAR TO CHINA MILITARY
description: Israel announced today that it had canceled its sale of a sophisticated $250 million airborne radar system to China, a decision timed for the second day of the Camp David summit meeting and aimed at improving the mood in Congress, where heated opposition to the deal had threatened aid to the Israelis.

title: Torricelli Hints at Run For New Jersey Governor
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli, the state's ranking Democrat, has long been seen as the only serious threat to James E. McGreevey's plans to be the party's next candidate for governor.

title: Official Says Test Implicates Inmate Given Stay by Bush
description: A DNA test has failed to exonerate a Texas death row inmate whose case took on political significance last month when Gov. George W. Bush interrupted his presidential campaign to grant the man a stay of execution, say officials knowledgeable about the results.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; ANTITRUST PACT IS SIGNED
description: Mexico and the United States signed an agreement to help enforce antitrust legislation and coordinate efforts to combat monopolistic practices on both sides of the border. The agreement aims to protect both Mexican and United States consumers and complement the Nafta accord, though it does not alter existing legislation in either country. The cooperation agreement includes an exchange of personnel between antitrust authorities in a bid to avoid conflicts over the enforcement of antitrust legislation in either country. title: LUCENT WILL COMBINE OPERATIONS WITH USA DIGITAL RADIO
description: The Digital Radio unit of Lucent Technologies Inc. and the closely held USA Digital Radio Inc. said yesterday that they had agreed to combine their operations. The companies called the combination a ''merger of equals,'' though specific terms were not disclosed. Lucent will be the venture's single biggest investor, followed by Viacom Inc., one of 30 companies backing USA Digital., which is based in Columbia, Md. The new company, the iBiquity Digital Corporation, will develop and license software and patents for technology that enables broadcasters to offer digital radio service. Shares of Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., rose $1.8125 yesterday to close at $56.4375 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Two Who Fled Austria in Terror Return in Triumph
description: What really gets you is the red sweater with three white P's across the breast, the same hand-knit sweater a 12-year-old boy named Paul Peter Porges wore as he boarded a Kindertransport from Vienna to France on a wet, nasty night in March 1939, one step ahead of the Nazis. That this particular sweater has survived and is part of a retrospective honoring his life and work, along with that of his wife, Lucie, who also barely got out of Vienna alive, perhaps symbolizes what makes this exhibition compelling: the everyday details of life.

title: PACKETEER IN STOCK DEAL FOR WORKFIRE TECHNOLOGIES
description: Packeteer Inc., a maker of software that manages Internet data flow, said yesterday that it would acquire the closely held Workfire Technologies International for $73 million in stock. Packeteer will exchange two million shares for all of Workfire's common stock and options outstanding. Packeteer, based in Cupertino, Calif., makes software that helps control information flowing on the Internet. Workfire, based in Kelowna, British Columbia, makes software that speeds Internet data traffic. Packeteer's shares rose $5.50 each, to $36.50, in Nasdaq trading. Storm (Halle Berry) can control the weather, conjuring lightning bolts to do with as she will. The hotheaded, confrontational Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) has superstrength, healing abilities that allow him to recover from almost any injury, and a metal alloy grafted onto his skeleton that gives him claws he can project from his knuckles. And Rogue (Anna Paquin) absorbs the essence of others, which makes her an energy vampire; she discovers her power when she steals her first kiss and almost kills the boy.

Vinci offered 12 of its own shares for 5 in Groupe GTM, valuing each Groupe GTM share at 118.4 euros. Vinci changed its name from Societe Generale d'Entreprises this spring to denote a fresh start after Vivendi cut its stake from more than half.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MABEL, LEO P.
description: MABEL-Leo P., 71, retired publishing executive and member of the board of the Forty Fifth Street Community Clinic (Seattle). A world traveler and a citizen of New York City, Freeport (NY), London, and Seattle, he will also be remembered for his progressive politics and as a tennis player and folk musician. A graduate of Columbia University ('50), his career included stints as Vice President of Henry M. Snyder, The Macmillan Company (NY), and Crowell Collier Macmillan, as well as President of Collier Macmillian International. His proudest achievements as a publisher were the English translations of the Diary of Anne Frank and The Great Soviet Encyclopedia, as well as the ESL series English 900 and English This Way. He is survived by his sons Matthew Mabel (Dallas, TX) and Joseph Mabel (Seattle). His beloved wife Corinne Feigin Mabel died in 1973. No flowers please. Memorial donations may be made in his name to the Forty Fifth Street Clinic; 1629 45th Street; Seattle, WA 98103 (206.548.0431). title: Campaign Briefing
description: HE REPUBLICANSBUSH LIKES THE ATTENTION Gov. George W. Bush said today that he did not mind Vice President Al Gore's focus on him and calls for the governor to step into the debate in Congress. "I've been somewhat surprised by the reaction to this campaign by my opponent and the president," Mr. Bush told state party leaders at a Republican National Committee meeting in Austin, Tex. "They seem to be talking about me a lot. They're talking about me and I'm talking about me, and that's the way I like it. I must have the president worried because he spends time talking about our campaign. That's a good sign." He also scoffed at Mr. Gore's criticism of Congress as a "do nothing for people" Legislature. The polls show Mr. Gore with only 70 percent support among Democrats, while Gov. George W. Bush has 90 percent support among Republicans. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARSKI, JAN
description: KARSKI-Jan. The officers, members and staff of the American Jewish Committee deeply mourn the death of Jan Karski, a courier of courage. Jan Karski was a diplomat, a Righteous Gentile, a messenger for the Polish underground resistance during World War II, and an eyewitness to the systematic Nazi extermination of the Jews in Poland. He risked his own life to report the unimaginable atrocities he had seen to the Polish, British and American governments and to plead for help in saving Jewish lives. Modestly referring to himself as a ''human tape recorder'', he was, in actuality, a trumpet, heralding the harsh tones of human indifference and cruelty while at the same time personifying the indomitable spirit and inherent goodness that mankind can still possess. He devoted his postwar life to protecting the memory of the victims of the Holocaust, combating anti-Semitism and intolerance, and advancing the cause of human rights. In 1933, the AJC bestowed our highest honor on Jan Karski, and in 1999, he was the first recipient of the Eternal Light Award from the Center for Catholic/Jewish Studies, a collaboration of AJC and Saint Leo University. With great sorrow we now bid farewell to a dear frienda gentleman and a gentle man of enormous personal courage and profound moral integrity. We will cherish his memory as near to our hearts as he cradled the souls of the millions or Jews he never knew but tried to rescue. Bruce M. Ramer, President David A. Harris, Excutive Director

title: Political Memo; Lazio as the Conservative? Yes, but in Moderation
description: He has named his campaign bus the ''Mainstream Express,'' but called himself a conservative in a recent fund-raising letter. He modified that description in an interview to ''fiscal conservative and social moderate,'' and, in the same day, chuckled at but did not disavow Steve Forbes's description of him as a ''dyed-in-the-wool conservative.''

title: Japanese Bankruptcy Stirs Wider Doubts on Economy
description: The collapse of the Sogo Company, a department store operator that owed more than $17 billion, has cast a dark cloud over business activities here and resurrected anxieties about the fragilities in Japan's economy.

title: Huang Yong Ping
description: 'TaiGong Fishing, Willing to Bite the Bait'

title: Warm, Fuzzy E-Book
description: To the Editor:

title: General Mills Is in Talks to Buy Pillsbury Division of Diageo
description: In a move that could mean the corporate union of Betty Crocker and the Pillsbury Doughboy, General Mills Inc. said yesterday that it was in talks to acquire the Pillsbury division of Diageo P.L.C.

title: Leading the Baroque Back to Nature
description: If the three artists from Bologna named Carracci -- Annibale (1560-1609), his brother Agostino (1557-1602) and their cousin Ludovico (1555-1619) -- didn't exactly invent Baroque art, they gave their all to it. In the 1580's, unhappy with the Mannerist preciosity that dominated the art of their time, they started an academy that pushed for a return to nature and the classical heritage of the great Italian masters who preceded them, in particular Correggio, Veronese and Titian.

title: The Soul of a Culture Gleams From Countless Beads
description: A diaspora is a many-leveled thing, for the simple reason that people never travel light. No matter how meager their physical possessions, they carry beliefs, traditions, sensibilities, ways of talking, thinking, seeing and doing, all in their heads. Wherever they arrive, things are never the same: sooner or later there are modulations, great or small, in local habits of clothing, religion, diet and art and much else. Something new has been added.

title: The Getty Acquires A New Old Master
description: The J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles had its eye on several paintings at the old master auctions in London last week. It ended up buying an El Greco.

title: Army Colonel Is Sentenced to 5 Months for Failing to Report Wife's Heroin Smuggling
description: After being chided by a federal judge for not apologizing for his crimes, a United States Army colonel who once ran the government's antidrug operations in Colombia was sentenced yesterday to five months in prison for never reporting that he knew his wife was smuggling heroin through diplomatic mail from Bogota to New York City.

title: CANADA INFLATION INCREASES
description: Canada's annual inflation rate was 2.9 percent in June, up from 2.4 percent in May, and stronger than many economists had expected. Energy again supplied most of the cost pressure, with gasoline prices rising 6.3 percent in June, to stand 30.5 percent higher than a year earlier. Excluding energy, consumer prices advanced 1.4 percent in June. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Messier Returns, as Captain and Lifeline
description: ark Messier stood on the podium at Madison Square Garden yesterday morning during his reintroduction to New York and the Rangers, but he could not speak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, IRWIN
description: DIAMOND-Irwin. On July 12, 2000. Beloved husband for 53 years of Pearl, devoted father of Dennis, Matthew and Cori, father-in-law to Elizabeth Geiger, Rae Kraus, Steve Baustin and the late Art DeFrancis. Patriarch and leader, he leaves behind an adoring family including best friend and brotherin-law Irving Ziffer, grandchildren, Sarah, Jacqueline, Liana, Gabriel, Alexander and David, Angelia, Debbie, Barry, Steven and Jason, great-grandchildren, Rachel, Nicole, Sydney and Jessica, nephews and nieces, Marshall, Emily, Jody, Debbie, Harold, Wendy, Adam, Sarah, Ben, Jon, Sophie and Lily Karp. He was the foundation of our family and a true role model for four generations. Seders will never be the same. Funeral services will be held at 1PM today at Schwartz Brothers, Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Don Monti Memorial Research Foundation, 300 Community Drive, Manhasset, NY, 11030 in memory of Irwin Diamond.

title: FUEL INFLATION IN BRAZIL
description: Starting on Saturday, Brazilians will pay about 11.3 percent more at the gasoline pump because of government adjustments in prices to reflect the rising cost of fuel. At the wholesale level, the government increased gasoline and diesel prices by 15 percent, while kerosene, used as jet fuel, lost a government subsidy and jumped 34.5 percent. Butane gas, which most Brazilians use for cooking, will increase 18 percent. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: No. 2 Police Official Taking Security Job
description: The second-highest-ranking official in the Police Department said yesterday that he was retiring to take a job as the director of worldwide security for Merrill Lynch.

title: Stretching A DVD Package
description: At its annual meeting in Las Vegas last week, the video business acknowledged DVD -- a format that some in the industry have had their reservations about -- as its most positive development. It doesn't take a convention to gauge the rise of the disc and its player, about 13 million of which could be in use by early next year. On the release horizon, hundreds of films wait to join the current DVD inventory of about 6,500 movie and music titles.

title: '100 Years of Vernacular Signage'
description: Ricco-Maresca Gallery

title: Beyond 'Electronic,' a Range of Brash, Rich and Raucous Compositions
description: For many people the term ''electronic music'' still conjures images of passive audiences in darkened concert halls listening to tape-recorded collages of electronically altered sounds played through loudspeakers. One aim of the Lincoln Center Festival's ''Electronic Evolution: A Five-Part Series'' is to show that the range of compositions involving electronic techniques and, in recent years, computer software is so wide, rich and jumbled that the generic term ''electronic music'' may have outlived its usefulness.

title: Residential Real Estate; Summer Rental Market Booms for Only Some
description: From the coast of Maine to the Jersey Shore, brokers in summer resorts were salivating this year over the prospects of a record-breaking rental season. Prices were soaring and prospective tenants were pleading with them to accept deposit checks. He who hesitated was lost, agents warned clients. A house on the market one minute was sure to be snapped up the next.

title: John Chamberlain
description: PaceWildenstein

title: Gliding From Decorous Chamber Into Ethnic Verve
description: The excellent Osiris Trio, visiting the Frick Collection on Wednesday evening as part of the current Dutch musical invasion, started their program with a piano trio by Haydn, No. 25 in G major, whose first two movements gave them opportunities to show graciousness and musical fitness -- not least in how the violinist, Peter Brunt, and pianist, Ellen Corver, worked together, interlocking their tones in the opening gesture, for instance, to create a twist of edgy brilliance. (The cello here is a support instrument: Larissa Groeneveld's chances would come later.)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISS, BERTRAM LESLIE
description: WEISS-Bertram Leslie. Since your passing one year ago, my life will never be the same. I'm lost without you, my love. You are missed by all who love you. Jacquelin

title: Linked, Sooner or Later, In a Semiautomatic World
description: ''It's the Rage,'' which opens today at Cinema Village, begins with gunshots as a suburban homeowner (Jeff Daniels) accidentally shoots an intruder who turns out to be the business partner he has suspected of cuckolding him. From this promising film noir beginning, James D. Stern's debut feature quickly -- or rather, slowly, since the pacing is that of a long, talky evening of repertory theater -- becomes an excruciatingly literal-minded, floridly literary application of Chekhov's dictum that a gun on the mantelpiece in the first act of a play must be fired by the end.

title: James Hill, 83, the Baritone In a Venerable Gospel Group
description: James Hill, the leader and baritone voice of the Fairfield Four gospel group, died July 6 at a hospital in Nashville, The Tennessean reported. He was 83 and lived in Nashville.

title: Technology Shares Lift Nasdaq, but Wave Stops There
description: Strong quarterly reports from several companies touched off fresh buying in technology stocks yesterday, lifting the Nasdaq composite index to a second consecutive solid gain as the rest of the market mostly languished.

title: For Bush, Texas Deficit Becomes Issue in Race
description: For the past few years, Texas has enjoyed such a booming economy that any news about the state budget has usually been good. So when state lawmakers this week announced a $610 million shortfall, the bad news came as a surprise and prompted a pregnant political question:

title: New Scrutiny of Cheese Offends Refined Palates; Epicures Defend Unpasteurized Varieties As Regulators Look for Health Risks
description: In Manhattan's finer cheese departments, they rise like columns in a cathedral: 72-pound wheels of Parmigiano-Reggiano, half-moon chunks of cheddar, crumpets of pungent chevre. Oversized softballs of Greek sheep's milk cheese sit on slabs of marble. Gourd-shaped Sicilian caciocavalli hang from the rafters.

title: Chasing Nabokov's Elusive and Endangered True Love
description: The author of ''Lolita,'' ''Pale Fire,'' ''Pnin'' and ''Speak, Memory,'' Vladimir Nabokov is considered one of the greatest novelists of the 20th century. What is less well known is that he was also a lepidopterist who named dozens of new species and subspecies of butterflies. One of these, the Karner blue, is a resident of New York State and a federally endangered species.

title: GENTIVA SAYS IT IS CONSIDERING SALE OF STAFFING BUSINESS
description: Gentiva Health Services said yesterday that it was in discussions with ''a number of parties'' about the possible sale of its health care staffing business. Gentiva, a provider of home health care and related services based in Melville, N.Y., also said it had retained UBS Warburg as financial adviser about a possible sale. Gentiva reported a loss of $4.2 million on $1.5 billion of revenue for the last 12 months. The health care staffing unit accounts for about 8 percent of Gentiva's revenue, or about $120 million, the company said. Gentiva did not give a reason for the possible sale in announcing the discussions.

title: Marbury, in Role of Critic, Gives a Thumbs Up to Coach
description: Stephon Marbury leaned back in his chair and, as usual, surveyed the floor, a not-so casual observer nodding in approval.

title: Class-Action Bias Suits Name Two Insurers
description: The two largest American life insurance companies, MetLife and Prudential Insurance of America, have been accused in two class-action lawsuits of charging their black customers higher premiums for life insurance coverage than they charged white customers.

title: Mrs. Clinton Explains Kiss In Middle East
description: On a campaign swing yesterday through Queens, Hillary Rodham Clinton offered her most detailed explanation yet about why she kissed Suha Arafat, the wife of Yasir Arafat, after Mrs. Arafat made scathing remarks about Israel during a joint appearance in November.

title: Childhood Longings in a Grown-Up World
description: Shot in mostly hand-held video and featuring a character whose mental balance is questionable, to say the least, ''Chuck and Buck'' might be described as a Dogma 95 version of ''Disney's 'The Kid.' '' The two films share some underlying themes -- the pain of growing up, the persistence of primal fears and desires into adulthood, the desperate human need for love -- but their methods of exploring them could hardly be more different.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: TXU UNIT IS ACQUIRING A STAKE IN GERMAN ENERGY COMPANY
description: The TXU Corporation said yesterday that its TXU Europe unit had agreed to acquire a 51 percent stake in Stadtwerke Kiel of Germany for about $215 million. Stadtwerke Kiel is a municipally owned energy company with about 250,000 electric and gas customers in northern Germany. TXU, which is based in Dallas, provides energy to four million Texans, as well as customers in Australia, Mexico and Britain. It had revenue of $17.4 billion in the year that ended on March 31. TXU's shares slipped 25 cents yesterday, to $31.625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHINIZY, COLES
description: PHINIZY-Coles. On July 12, 2000. He is mourned and will be missed by his family and friends. For many years, a resident of Port Charlotte, Florida, he was born in Augusta, Georgia on September 29, 1919, son of Coles and Mary Harison Phinizy. He was a graduate of The Hill School, as well as Harvard College where he was Chairman of The Harvard Lampoon. He served as an army officer during the Second World War. He began a professional journalism career with Life Magazine, and, in 1954, became a ''charter member'' on the masthead of the first issue of Sports Illustrated, staying with that magazine as an editor, writer and photographer until retirement. He covered the first Australian Olympics in Melbourne in 1956, but his normal beat was on and under the water: SCUBA diving, swimming , and sailing. He made many technical contributions to underwater photography, and reported from Rhode Island on several America's Cup regattas. He spent a happy retirement boating and fishing on the Gulf of Mexico. Contributions may be made in his memory to Planned Parenthood Federation of America, 810 7th Ave, New York, N.Y. 10019. He is survived by his former wife, Helen Adams Phinizy of Stamford, Ct, a daughter, Catherine Phinizy Parys of Mystic, Ct, a son, Coles H. Phinizy, Jr. of New York, and two grandsons, as well as nephews and a niece.

description: LITT-Mary S. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the lost of Mary S. Litt, a dear friend of the Jewish community. As president of the Litt Foundation, Mrs. Litt embraced the humanitarian concerns of her late husband, Solomon, a remarkable leader admired for his wisdom and generosity. Their son, Mark, is perpetuating his family's cherished philanthropic traditions through his exceptional leadership and support. We extend our sincerest condolences to Mark; to Mrs. Litt's daughter, Susan McLeod; her grandchildren, Lauren, Steven, Cindy, Helen, Tammie, and Phillip; her great-grandchildren; and to the entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

description: KANTOR-Bernard. On July 12, 2000, of natural causes. title: Night Crawlers, Beware: You Could Lose Your Soul
description: For someone who can recognize a cliche when he hears one, Michael Holloway sure takes a long time to wake up, smell the mercaptan and realize that his newfound pal, Stuart Chapell, is not the big-time writer he professes to be.

title: VIVENDI DELAYS OFFERING
description: The Paris-based media and water company Vivendi S.A., which agreed last month to buy the Seagram Company for $29 billion, cut the price of the stock it is selling in its utility unit by about 10 percent and delayed the share sale a second time amid lackluster demand. The company said shares in the unit, Vivendi Environnement, would be priced between 33 euros and 36 euros, down from a previous range of 36 to 41 euros. It also postponed the share sale until next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, FRANK
description: POLLACK-Frank. Just shy of 100. Passed away in Florida leaving a devoted son Herbert. Beloved father to the late Alex and Albert. Loving husband to the late Lillian and Dora. Cherished grandfather of nine and great-grandfather to nine who will always remember him. He was the Founder of The Guaranteed Printing Company in New York City in 1931. Graveside services Mount Ararat Cemetery at 11 A.M. today.

title: ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL IS SELLING CHEMICAL UNIT TO APOLLO
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group agreed yesterday to sell a chemical unit to Apollo Management, a private investment firm, for an undisclosed sum. The unit, Shell's Resins and Versatics business, makes epoxy resins -- used for applications like coating the inside of beverage cans -- as well as materials used in products like paint. It has revenue of about $1 billion. Apollo, based in New York, has managed more than $13 billion in equity capital since it was founded in 1990, Shell said. Marvin O. Schlanger, a former president and chief executive of Arco Chemical, will be chairman of the new company. Shell, the large oil company, said the sale was in line with its strategy to focus its chemical business on so-called base chemicals.

title: Pedro Mir, Whose Poems Spoke To Latin Workers, Dies at 87
description: Pedro Mir, the poet laureate of the Dominican Republic, who gave voice to the emotions of multitudes of working-class Latin Americans, died on Tuesday in Santo Domingo, his country's capital. He was 87.

title: Matthaus Future Is Uncertain
description: Uncertainty surrounds the future of Lothar Matthaus with the MetroStars and Major League Soccer. Matthaus met with Nick Sakiewicz, the general manager, and Coach Octavio Zambrano at the team's office yesterday to explain why he spent time in St. Tropez, France, last week at a time he was supposed to be rehabilitating his injured back.

title: DVD Case Will Test Reach of Digital Copyright Law
THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE SOARS. Coffee surged as frost in Brazil heightened speculation that crops of the world's largest grower would be damaged. In New York, coffee for September delivery rose 9.7 cents, or 10.5 percent, to $1.022 a pound.

title: Following the Fickle Modern Beat
description: ''Manhattan Contrasts,'' an exhibition of generally conservative, representational paintings of 20th-century New York at the New-York Historical Society, is modest to a fault. Images are mostly of buildings old and new viewed from near and far, interspersed here and there with a few genre scenes. Quality ranges from journeyman competence to high academic proficiency. Hardly any very well-known artists are included.

title: Recalling the Smell of Love and Being Totally Out of Touch
description: ''The Five Senses'' engages the sense of sight. The director, Jeremy Podeswa, gives the picture the warm darkness of autumn, with shadows drifting through the scenes like lost thoughts. It's too bad narrative isn't a sense; the attempt to deal with each of the senses here is so schematic that the movie drifts just like those shadows.

title: A Bloodsucker Finds It Hard To Live Life As a Romantic
description: Whenever someone wears a collarless shirt in a movie, it's a signal that there's something otherworldly about him, part of the tradition that includes Bruce Lee, Steven Segal and Ben Kingsley in ''Gandhi.'' And such is the case with Steven Grslcz (Jude Law), the languid, parchment-pale vampire in ''The Wisdom of Crocodiles.'' It's the kind of picture in which the bloodsucker is so chic he probably uses the spelling ''vampyre.''

title: Colombians Tell of Massacre, as Army Stood By
description: The armed men, more than 300 of them, marched into this tiny village early on a Friday. They went straight to the basketball court that doubles as the main square, residents said, announced themselves as members of Colombia's most feared right-wing paramilitary group, and with a list of names began summoning residents for judgment.

title: After Wimbledon, the Lawn Needs Mowing
description: The sign by the door instructs visitors to Go Away. The sign by the doorbell offers reassurance, in French, that the linebacker-sized Labrador retriever inside this quirky Hamptons household -- in the backyard, a bionic Barbie doll guards the pool in her birthday suit -- is a pushover. Do signs lie?

title: A Chameleon Looking at Narcissism
description: Sandra Bernhard is the queen of ambivalence. A fashion maven who excoriates Seventh Avenue, a worshiper at the altar of fame who tosses poisoned darts at celebrities, she is a stage chameleon who from moment to moment swings between poles of beautiful and ugly, feminine and masculine, tender and vicious. In her monologues, the lines between reality and fantasy are blurred to the point that you begin to wonder if even she knows the difference between the two. (She does.) When she sings in a two-tiered voice that has several layers of affectation, it's often hard to tell whether she's putting us on or whether she envisages herself as a combination of Dusty Springfield and Janis Joplin, two singers to whom she pays tribute in her fascinating new cabaret show, ''Songs I Sang on the Kibbutz.''

title: CABOT IS SELLING GAS UNIT TO TRACTEBEL FOR $680 MILLION
description: The Cabot Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Cabot LNG unit to Tractebel Inc. for $680 million. Tractebel is a unit of the Tractebel Group, an energy and services company. It handles energy activities for the French conglomerate Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux. Cabot LNG imports and distributes liquefied natural gas to utilities and industrial companies in the Northeastern United States. It has annual sales of $425 million. The Cabot Corporation, based in Boston, is a specialty chemical, materials and energy company. It had 1999 sales of $1.7 billion. Its shares rose $1.625 yesterday, to $31.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIM, MISOON
description: KIM-Misoon. The National Jewish Outreach Program (NJOP) mourns the passing of Misoon Kim, beloved mother of Sandra (and Howard) Hoffen, distinguished supporters of NJOP, who have played a crucial role in NJOP's efforts to assure a Jewish future for American Jewry. Condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about efforts by Mexico's governing party to regroup after losing the presidential election misstated the name of a faction leader, the governor of Tabasco state. He is Roberto Madrazo Pintado; Tabasco is not part of the name.

title: Leatherhead Journal; The White Van Man of England: Oh, He's a Devil!
description: In his hands he has a wheel; in his ears, rings; on his arms, tattoos; and in his heart, loathing for anyone he sees through his windshield. He is known as White Van Man, and he is identified in motorist surveys as the scourge of the stressed-out British road.

title: On Convention Eve, Beating Mars Image of Philadelphia
description: All decked out in bunting and civic pride for the forthcoming Republican National Convention, this city today suffered the ignominy of seeing its police on national television beating and kicking a man accused of stealing a police car and shooting at an officer during a running gun battle through the streets.

title: Milton Amgott, 81, a Consultant To State Lawmakers in Albany
description: Milton Amgott, a Manhattan lawyer who counseled Albany lawmakers and counted some prominent American writers among his private clients, died Tuesday at his home on the Upper West Side. He was 81.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITT, MARY SCHWEITZER
description: LITT-Mary Schweitzer. On July 12, 2000, peacefully at her home in Pleasant Valley, NY, at age 96. Beloved wife of the late Solomon. Loving mother of Mark D. and Judith Litt of Larchmont, NY, and Susan L. and Roderick McLeod of Toronto, Ontario. Adored grandmother of Lauren Alwan, Steven Litt, Cindy Alwan, Helen Litt, Tammie Jennings and Philip Presnal; and great-grandmother of Sarah, Clayton, Davis, Elizabeth, Miles and Gabriel. Dear sister of the late James J. Sweitzer, formerly of Phoenix, AZ. A resident of Manhattan since early childhood, Mary spent the past five years at her beloved farm ''Basswood''. She loved and nourished her family & everyone who came to know her. She set high standards for herself and expected the same from others. Mary was an enthusiastic watercolorist whose subjects ranged from landscapes and cityscapes of Dutchess County, Europe, Mexico and Israel, to floral still lifes and nudes. She studied for many years at the Art Students League & the National Academy of Design in New York. Mary was a member and benefactor of the American Watercolor Society and a life member and benefactor of the Art Students League. Supporter of many cultural and charitable causes including the Holocaust Museum and Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, the NeoNatal Unit of Mt. Sinai Hospital in Toronto and the Pleasant Valley Library. Services Sunday, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Hospice Inc. of Dutchess County. Family will receive friends Sunday evening, 7-9 PM at 870 United Nations Plaza and Monday evening 7-9 PM at 27 Hall Avenue, Larchmont.

title: Ex-Police Head Criticizes Whitman on Suspect Search
description: As Gov. Christine Todd Whitman tried to quell criticism of her decision to frisk a black man in Camden while riding with the New Jersey state police in 1996, the former head of the state police came forward today to chastise the governor.

title: Book Advance For G.E. Chief Is $7.1 Million
description: Time Warner Trade Publishing yesterday acquired the right to publish a book by John F. Welch Jr., the widely admired chairman of the General Electric Company, for a record advance of $7.1 million, more than advances paid for books by Gen. Colin L. Powell or the pope.

title: Gundersen Acquires British Company
description: Gundersen Partners L.L.C. in New York, which specializes in executive searches for marketing, advertising and communications companies, has acquired Bucher/Rugman in London, which has similar specialties. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Renewing the Dance of Martha Graham
description: In most artists' lives, there is a tension between making new work and trying to control the work they have already made. There is no better example than the American dancer and choreographer Martha Graham, who died in 1991. Graham's legacy is now deadlocked. In March, after months of friction, the board of the Martha Graham Center for Contemporary Dance dismissed Ron Protas, the legal heir to Graham's work, as artistic director and a board member. In turn, Mr. Protas has refused to allow the Martha Graham Dance Company to stage her works, though he has licensed them to other performing groups. This week, in response, the Martha Graham Dance Company issued a public letter, signed by nearly every notable person in the dance world, urging other companies not to perform Graham's works until the company reaches agreement with Mr. Protas. Because of this turmoil and the inability to raise funds in such circumstances, the board of the Martha Graham Center has suspended operations.

title: MEASURE TO CURB INTERNET GAMBLING GAINS IN THE HOUSE
description: A tentative deal has been reached in the House of Representatives on a bitterly fought bill to ban most forms of gambling on the Internet, clearing the way for a floor vote as early as next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARP, IDA M.
description: KARP-Ida M. The family of Mrs. Ida M. Karp regrets to inform you that Ida quietly passed away on July 5, 2000. She spoke often of her many interests and friends and we are grateful for all the love, sharing and support that her friends, colleagues and family members gave her. She will be missed but remembered fondly by us all. She is survived by her children, Winifred and William; and two granddaughters, Audra and Isadora. In lieu of flowers, the family request that donations be sent to the following: Bank Street College of Education; Council Senior Center; Horizons Elderhostel and Youth Programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONNELL, VINCENT
description: McDONNELL-Vincent & Eileen. The Board of Directors and Members of The Association for a Better New York send heart felt condolences to the McDonnell family on the loss of their parents. A founder and advisor to ABNY at its inception, Vinnie will always be remembered not only for his advice and counsel on labor matters but in all general matters concerning the Association. Lewis Rudin, Chairman

title: Clinton Gets Hero's Welcome At Convention of N.A.A.C.P.
description: President Clinton strongly criticized Republicans today for blocking his African-American and Hispanic judicial nominees, and he urged delegates to the annual convention of the N.A.A.C.P. to elect Vice President Al Gore to ensure that the courts remained diverse.

title: O Dromio, Dromio! Wherefore Art Thou Dromio?
description: Whatever would Shakespeare have done without shipwrecks? So many of his plots turn on them that when a character in any play asks where someone is, I half expect the reply to be, ''Lost at sea.'' Well, life was tough in the old days if you lived on an island, I suppose. It was tougher on theater audiences; since staging a sinking was not possible, people had to sit through long descriptions of storms, broken masts and screams in the wind. None is more tortuous than old Egeon's speech at the opening of ''The Comedy of Errors'' -- so filled with incident that it induces amnesia, but if you forget any detail, parts of the rest of the play make no sense.

title: $12 Billion For Schools In New Jersey
description: In a surprisingly swift climax to a long-running battle over how to rebuild New Jersey's crumbling and overcrowded schools, the Assembly gave final approval today to the largest construction program in state history, a $12 billion effort with something for everyone, from the poorest cities to the wealthiest suburbs.

title: LOCKHEED MARTIN IS SELLING THREE BUSINESSES TO BAE
description: Lockheed Martin will sell its Sanders aerospace electronics unit and two other divisions to a North American subsidiary of BAE Systems of Britain for $1.67 billion in cash, company officials said yesterday. Lockheed Martin will retain $1.3 billion after taxes and transaction costs and take a third-quarter charge of $1 billion, or $2.50 a diluted share, for good will and intangibles. Besides Sanders, BAE North America is buying Lockheed Martin Fairchild Systems, in Syosset, N.Y., and Lockheed Martin's space and communications unit in Manassas, Va. BAE Systems is Europe's largest military contractor. It has 18,300 employees in North America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, RABBI RICHARD J.
description: ISRAEL-Rabbi Richard J. We record with profound sadness the passing of our beloved colleague. He had a distinguished career in Hillel, the campus rabbinate, as Associate Director at UCLA, as Director at Yale University, and from 1971-1985 as Executive Director of Hillel of Greater Boston. He instituted the Campus Rabbis Program at the Reconstructionist Rabbinical College and until his death, served as acting Hillel Director at Brandeis University. He was the author of Jewish Identity Games: A How To Do It Book, The Kosher Pig and numerous essays. We express our deepest condolences to his wife, Sherry, children, Alisa, David, Rachel and Dr. Joshua and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Vernon H. Kurtz, Pres. Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: WEAKNESS IN EUROPEAN AUTO SALES
description: Automobile sales in Germany dropped 19 percent in May, compared with a year earlier, according to the European Automobile Manufacturers Association. The severe decline in Germany was the main reason that car sales across Europe slipped about 4 percent in May. In Frankfurt, the German carmakers association reported today that German car production dropped 15 percent in June, compared with a year earlier. All of the major producers of medium- and low-priced cars in Germany -- Volkswagen, Ford Europe and the Opel subsidiary of General Motors -- recorded sales declines. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)
