title: Feeling the Burden of a Name, One Bush Focuses on Florida
description: As Gov. George W. Bush considers potential running mates, here is an appealing choice: He is a popular young governor from the fourth largest state, one where Democrats hope to compete ferociously. He is something of a policy wonk, a nice balance to Mr. Bush's celebrated aversion to minutiae. He is beloved among many Latino voters, a crucial voting bloc. He is Roman Catholic, a big plus since Mr. Bush faced accusations in the primaries that he was anti-Catholic. And he has star appeal as a scion of one of the most famous political families.

title: Drop in Power Delays Subways
description: Subway service in parts of New York City stopped briefly yesterday and then was delayed for about two hours after a disruption in a Con Edison line in Yonkers at noon caused a dip in electric power throughout the city and Westchester County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VLOCK, LAUREL F.
description: VLOCK-Laurel F. The staff and management of the National Jewish Television Network express profound sorrow at the tragic loss of our longtime colleague and cofounder, Laurel F. Vlock. For more than 15 years Laurel graced our airways with wit and charm, using her extraordinary skills to interview presidents and prime ministers, survivors of the Holocaust, and leading lights of the Jewish world everywhere. In 1981 she coanchored, with David Schoenbrun, our live coverage from Jerusalem of the World Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors, also carried on the PBS network and nominated for a national Emmy Award. May the wonderful legacy Laurel leaves behind be a source of comfort to her friends and family in this time of profound bereavement. Joel A. Levitch, President Aaron Etra, Chairman Executive Committee

title: Revolutionary Production
description: In St.-Ouen, a nondescript industrial suburb on the northern edge of Paris, Eric Rohmer is recreating the French Revolution inside a converted warehouse. His new film, ''The Lady and the Duke,'' promises to be the most expansive reconstruction of the era ever undertaken, a significant change of pace for a filmmaker famous for intimate romantic, philosophical dramas like ''Claire's Knee'' and ''An Autumn Tale.''

title: A Noisy Vision of the World as Endless Purgatory
description: Hard rock got turned inside out in the 1990's. Its insularity broke down as hip-hop and hard-core elements moved in; its blues roots receded further. It dismantled melody to keep its distance from the power ballads on MTV; it also moved toward extremes of speed or sloth. Its tone changed, too, so that hard rock was no longer a guaranteed blast of power or a foretaste of apocalypse. With the ascent of grunge and Nine Inch Nails, hard rock made room for self-doubt and private turmoil alongside the old rage.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SULLIVAN, THOMAS
description: SULLIVAN-Thomas. On Tuesday, July 4th, 2000 the Irish Tall Ship ASGARD II paused during the Millennium Tall ships parade to honor the life of Thomas F. Sullivan. Immediately, upon passing the Aircraft Carrier John F. Kennedy, with President Bill Clinton in attendance, the ASGARD II paused in the shadow of the Statue of Liberty for a eulogy & moment of silent prayer in the memory of Mr. Sullivan. Captain Tom McCarthy saluted Mr. Sullivan as an example of the contribution that Irish Americans have made to the growth of America. Captain McCarthy, with all hands assembled, spoke of Mr. Sullivan's career on the New York waterfront with the John W. McGrath and Universal Stevedoring firms. Upon completion of the ceremony, ashes of Mr. Sullivan who passed on March 31, 2000 were spread on the waters of New York Harbor. The ASGARD II then proceeded back to its honored Parade Position and fired its cannon repeatedly, passing many of the piers where Mr. Sullivan had worked. Tom would have been 84 today. God Bless

description: The $6 billion merger of Burlington Northern Santa Fe and Canadian National Railway will probably be called off now that a federal appeals court has upheld a temporary ban on railroad consolidations.

title: Clemens Just Sticks To His Game Plan
description: To Joe Torre, Roger Clemens seemed especially antsy pacing around the clubhouse before last night's game with the Florida Marlins. There was a look of concern on Clemens's stoic face, the look of a proud pitcher who knew there were still serious questions about his approach and about just how human he was.

title: U.S. PROPOSAL TO W.T.O.
description: The Clinton administration wants the World Trade Organization to make it easier for companies to sell services across international borders. The administration said in a framework paper submitted to the Geneva-based trade body that a current round of talks on banking, insurance, energy, postal, environmental, professional and travel services should become more ambitious and should aim for a conclusion by 2002 even if there is no new global trade summit meeting by then. The European Union wants to address services only as part of broader trade talks. Joseph Kahn

title: Cruelty-Free Diamonds
description: Tomorrow in Antwerp, the World Diamond Congress will meet to write new rules for the treatment of diamonds from war zones. Diamond traders and manufacturers are reacting to public concern about diamonds mined illicitly by warlords in Angola, Sierra Leone and Congo to finance wars fought largely for control of their country's mineral wealth. The industry, realizing that bad publicity could devalue a product whose only worth comes from consumer perception, is eager to certify that it sells only clean stones. An effective certification system, however, requires independent monitoring, which the industry has so far resisted.

title: CNBT BANCSHARES REPORTS OFFERS TO MERGE
description: CNBT Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it had received merger offers from undisclosed larger bank holding companies but had not entered into any agreements. The concern, a holding company for Citizens National Bank of Texas, hired Alex Sheshunoff & Company Investment Banking as a financial adviser to handle the inquiries. Ralph Williams, president of CNBT, said recent market activity indicated the company could no longer keep its merger activity confidential. The shares of CNBT rose 8 percent on Thursday before closing yesterday at $15, down 43.75 cents, in Nasdaq trading. At the current price, its stock is worth about $74 million. CNBT Bancshares, based in Houston, operates six community banking offices.

title: EIMO-YHTIOT OF FINLAND TO BUY TRIPLE S PLASTICS
description: A Finnish maker of plastic parts for cell phones, Eimo-Yhtiot, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Triple S Plastics Inc., based in Vicksburg, Mich., for $136 million to $161 million in stock. The final price will depend on the Triple S stock price when the deal closes. Eimo said it wanted to become a global company and increase its range of services. Triple S makes plastic parts for cell phones, medical equipment and cars. The company had $95.1 million in sales in its fiscal year ended in March. Triple S shares soared $8.25, to $30.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Dot-Com Revolution in China; Venture Capital Backs Talented Young Entrepreneurs
description: China's economy is throwing millions of people out of work each year, but an unemployed Internet journalist, Shao Ying, says she can get a job whenever she wants among the hundreds of Internet companies opening offices here.

title: DANCE NOTES
description: The dancers of the Martha Graham Dance Company are urging a boycott of Graham's works after the closing of the virtually bankrupt Graham company and school by the board on May 25 and amid the continuing discord between the board and Ron Protas, its former artistic director and Graham's heir. Mr. Protas owns the dances and directs the Martha Graham Trust, which licenses the dances.

title: Freedom, One Song at a Time
description: Napster, the wildly popular software that allows users to trade music over the Internet, could be shut down later this month if the Recording Industry Association of America gets an injunction it is seeking in federal court in California. The big record companies in the association -- along with the angry artists who testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee this week -- maintain that Napster is nothing more than a tool for digital piracy.

title: Teams to See More of Rivals
description: Baseball owners adopted an unbalanced schedule for 2001 yesterday, meaning teams will play an increased number of games against teams within their divisions. There will be no league realignment until at least 2002, however.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the Texas budget referred imprecisely to a $610 million shortfall. As the article reported, state spending will exceed the amount budgeted but will not exceed tax revenues; there is no deficit.

title: Rappers Keep Rolling (So Does the Uproar)
description: The continuing Up in Smoke tour, featuring the rap superstars Dr. Dre, Snoop Dogg, Eminem, Ice Cube and Nate Dogg, was supposed to clean up rap's reputation for attracting violence at concerts and other live events.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLOW, THOMAS T.
description: MALLOW-Thomas T., of New York and Florida, died on July 13, 2000. Survived by his beloved wife Roberta and loving children, Deborah Mallow (Brian) Chenensky and Peter (Miranda Benedict) Mallow. Adoring grandfather of Dean Harris Chenensky and David Robert Mallow. He will always remain in our hearts and minds a devoted, kind and loving soul. Private services will be held at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y.

title: FLOWSERVE AGREES TO SELL SOME ASSETS IN ANTITRUST CASE
description: The Flowserve Corporation, which makes pumps and valves for oil companies, agreed yesterday to shed some product lines to win Justice Department approval for its proposed $775 million purchase of the Ingersoll-Rand Company's pump unit. The products accounted for less than 3 percent, or about $57 million, of the combined companies' 1999 sales, Flowserve said. The Justice Department had raised antitrust concerns about sales of pumps used in oil refineries and power plants. Flowserve plans to sell the assets after completing the purchase of Ingersoll-Dresser Pumps next month. The deal will create the world's second-biggest pump company. Flowserve is based in Irving, Tex.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Gov. George E. Pataki's signing of a law intended to deter crimes against cabdrivers misspelled the surname of a law professor at New York University who explained its significance. He is Burt Neuborne, not Newborne.

title: Newsprint Operation Sold
description: Media General Inc., the publisher of The Richmond Times-Dispatch and other papers in the Southeastean United States, said this week that it had agreed to sell a New Jersey-based newsprint operation to the Enron Corporation for $72 million. The Garden State Paper Company, based in Garfield, N.J., employs 290 workers and can make 242,000 tons of recycled newsprint a year. Media General will keep a one-third stake in the SP Newsprint Company, with mills in Georgia and Oregon.

title: Sorenstam Is at Home Near Top of Leader Board
description: Annika Sorenstam is precisely where she wants to be going into next week's women's United States Open, which she has won twice in the last five years. After winning only twice last season following 10 victories in the previous two years, Sorenstam's game is good enough to challenge Karrie Webb for the top spot in women's golf.

description: Fund-raising results released yesterday by the four major Democratic candidates to succeed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani showed that each appeared to be accumulating war chests that would allow them to spend the most allowed under city election rules.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARSKI, JAN
description: KARSKI-Jan. The Board and staff of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research mourn the death of Prof. Jan Karski, heroic diplomatic envoy of the Polish governmentin-exile during World War II, eyewitness to the Warsaw Ghetto and the Nazi extermination of Jews in Poland, and a ''Righteous Gentile.'' At great risk, he personally reported what he had seen of the Nazi annihilation of Polish Jews to Pres. Franklin Roosevelt. His was a life of courage, moral integrity and commitment to protecting, then preserving, the memory of the destroyed civilization of Polish Jewry. We are proud that he established the Jan Karski and Pola Nirenska Award at YIVO in 1993 to honor his late wife. A true friend, his actions in a time of world war were beyond courageous. He was an example to us all. We will miss this unique man. May his memory be a blessing. Bruce Slovin, Chairman Dr. Carl J. Rheins, Exec. Director

title: China Puts Director In Suspense Over a Film
description: When Jiang Wen's powerful wartime film, ''Devils on the Doorstep,'' won the Grand Prize in Cannes in May -- second only to the festival's Palme d'Or -- the word was that he faced trouble with China's film censors.

title: Wiretaps Lift Brazilian Scandal Into Top Ranks of Government
description: A long-simmering political corruption scandal has now penetrated the upper echelons of the Brazilian government and prompted a sudden stock market downturn, thanks to the publication on Thursday night of what a Brazilian newsmagazine describes as transcripts from 400 hours of wiretapped telephone calls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, THOMAS A.
description: COLEMAN-Thomas A. Of New York City and Spring Lake, NJ on July 14, 2000 at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. Son of the late John A. Coleman and Ann Meehan Coleman and brother of the late John A. Coleman, Jr. Survived by his beloved sister Mary Ann Hagerty of Sea Island, GA., his niece Elizabeth H. Dessen of Ambler, PA, and his nephews John A. Coleman III of New York City, Harry C. Hagerty III of Osterville, MA, and John C. Hagerty of Summit, NJ. He was a long-time member of the New York Stock Exchange and a Senior Partner of Adler, Coleman & Co., a specialist firm on the NYSE. He served as a member of the Board of Directors of the NYSE, the New York Futures Exchange and the East River Savings Bank. Mr. Coleman was a graduate, Benefactor and long-time Trustee of the University of Notre Dame and served on the Advisory Board of the University's College of Business. He received Honorary Doctorates from both Notre Dame and St. Bonaventure University. Mr. Coleman was a long-time Benefactor of St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center and served most recently as Chairman of St. Vincent's Board of Trustees. He was an Honorary Commissioner of the New York Fire Department, the New York Police Department and the City of Philadelphia Police Department and was a Trustee of the NYFD's Honorary Emergency Fund. He served Notre Dame as Honorary Chief of the Fire Department and Honorary Director of Public Safety for the University. Mr. Coleman was past President of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York and member of the Board of Founders of the Knights of Malta. He served as a Trustee of St. Patrick's Cathedral, Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, the Alfred E. Smith Foundation, the College of Mount St. Vincent and the New York Foundling Hospital. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York on Saturday, July 15 and Sunday, July 16 from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian burial will be said at 10:15 AM on Monday, July 17 at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Coleman Family Center for Campus Ministry at the University of Notre Dame, South Bend, IN, the Honor Emergency Fund c/o New York City Fire Department; and the Police Relief Fund Inc., c/o New York City Police Department.

title: Report Links Fertility Aids To Small Size In Newborns
description: The proportion of low-birthweight babies, those born weighing less than 5.5 pounds, has been growing steadily since 1984, a federal report released this week says. Most of the rise can be attributed to the rapid increase in the number of multiple births, especially to older white mothers using assisted-reproduction techniques like in vitro fertilization and drugs that increase ovulation.

title: In the 'Greened' World, It Isn't Easy to Be Human
description: What could be wrong with saving a rain forest? Quite a bit, say a number of anthropologists who have become increasingly critical of what they call ''green imperialism.'' Portraying environmentalists as latter-day missionaries of a new universal truth, many see third-world conservation as a form of neocolonialism, the latest attempt by wealthy Westerners to move into poor tropical countries and tell the local residents what they should and should not do with their land.

title: RUMORS ABOUT TELEFONICA
description: Reversing an early dip, the shares of Telefonica S.A. ended higher after the company denied a report that its chairman, Juan Villalonga, might resign soon amid allegations of insider trading. Mr. Villalonga, 47, bought options on 264,224 Telefonica shares in January 1998, two months before announcing an alliance with WorldCom Inc. Although the market regulator cleared him of insider trading then, it opened a new investigation after the newspaper El Mundo said last month that he had bought the options after opening talks with WorldCom.

description: Prince Tomislav Karadjordjevic, the brother of Yugoslavia's last king and, until the birth of his nephew, next in line to the throne, died on Wednesday in his ancestral home 40 miles north of Belgrade. He was 72.

title: LABOR AND INFLATION IN IRELAND
description: Rejecting union demands that wages be adjusted to compensate for soaring inflation rates, the Irish Business and Employers Confederation reaffirmed its commitment to a two-month-old national wage agreement, which is scheduled for review on July 27. Irish union leaders accused the government of doing too little to combat inflation and insisted on higher wages or tax credits for its members. Brian Lavery

title: THOMSON SELLING 2 PAPERS TO COX RATHER THAN GANNETT
description: The Thomson Corporation, an electronic publisher of financial and legal information, dropped plans to sell two Ohio newspapers to the Gannett Company and agreed yesterday to sell them to Cox Newspapers Inc. instead. Financial terms were not disclosed. The change came after the closely held Cox exercised its right of first refusal to the newspapers: The Middletown Journal, The Hamilton Journal-News and 10 related nondailies. They originally were included in a group of 21 dailies that Gannett agreed to buy last month for $1.13 billion. Gannett, publisher of USA Today, will still buy 19 daily newspapers and 23 nondaily publications for a total of $1.03 billion.

title: Clouds Hanging Over Sogo Bankruptcy Lift a Bit in Japan
description: The gloom surrounding the bankruptcy of the Sogo Company, a major retailer that owes more than $17 billion, was dispelled somewhat today after Japan's Finance Minister said the failure would not undercut the economic recovery and Standard & Poor's called the bankruptcy necessary medicine for the Japanese banking system.

title: Abroad at Home; 'Measure Of Justice'
description: Last January I wrote about the case of Mary Anne Gehris, a Georgia woman who came to this country from Germany as an infant. She was facing deportation because she had pulled another woman's hair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRIVER, WILLIAM
description: DRIVER-William. The faculty, staff, students and alumni of Bard College mourn the passing of William Driver, Professor Emeritus of Theatre, who retired last year after 40 years of distinguished service to the College. Under his leadership, the drama/dance program at Bard flourished and became a centerpiece of the college's traditions. His tireless devotion to his students and to his high artistic ideals made him a charismatic mentor for generations of Bard graduates. His fire, elegance, and brilliance will be sorely missed. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab, II, Chairman, Board of Trustees

description: What would the music sound like if the Pied Piper of fairy tale fame led a punk band? One answer wafted through the air Tuesday at a packed Irving Plaza as Sunny Day Real Estate played for an enthralled, mostly college-age crowd. The Seattle band, touring in support of its stately new album, ''The Rising Tide'' (Timebomb Recordings), proved that young fans can be transported by artists dedicated to beauty instead of controversy or cash.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; LIMITS ON CZECH CENTRAL BANK

description: The tobacco industry may be forever changed by a Florida jury's stunning award of $145 billion in punitive damages in a class-action lawsuit brought on behalf of injured smokers in Florida. title: MSG Files Suit to Block Yankees' Network Plans
description: Madison Square Garden sued the Yankees in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday, charging that the team's plan to form a new network violates the MSG Network's right to match outside offers to carry the team's games after this season.

title: Man Given 4 Years Under New Jersey Hate Crimes Law for 1999 Incident
description: In a ruling that reassured anti-discrimination groups concerned that a recent Supreme Court decision would weaken New Jersey's hate crimes law, a state Superior Court judge today imposed a strict sentence on a man who had pleaded guilty to an anti-Semitic rock-throwing spree in a heavily Jewish section of the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITT, MARY SCHWEITZER
description: LITT-Mary Schweitzer. On July 12, 2000, peacefully at her home in Pleasant Valley, NY, at age 96. Beloved wife of the late Solomon. Loving mother of Mark D. and Judith Litt of Larchmont, NY, and Susan L. and Roderick McLeod of Toronto, Ontario. Adored grandmother of Lauren Alwan, Steven Litt, Cindy Alwan, Helen Litt, Tammie Jennings and Philip Presnal; and great-grandmother of Sarah, Clayton, Davis, Elizabeth, Miles and Gabriel. Dear sister of the late James J. Sweitzer, formerly of Phoenix, AZ. A resident of Manhattan since early childhood, Mary spent the past five years at her beloved farm ''Basswood''. She loved and nourished her family & everyone who came to know her. She set high standards for herself and expected the same from others. Mary was an enthusiastic watercolorist whose subjects ranged from landscapes and cityscapes of Dutchess County, Europe, Mexico and Israel, to floral still lifes and nudes. She studied for many years at the Art Students League & the National Academy of Design in New York. Mary was a member and benefactor of the American Watercolor Society and a life member and benefactor of the Art Students League. Supporter of many cultural and charitable causes including the Holocaust Museum and Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, the NeoNatal Unit of Mt. Sinai Hospital in Toronto and the Pleasant Valley Library. Services Sunday, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Hospice Inc. of Dutchess County. Family will receive friends Sunday evening, 7-9 PM at 870 United Nations Plaza and Monday evening 7-9 PM at 27 Hall Avenue, Larchmont.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, ROSLIND
description: ALBERT-Roslind. Peacefully, Friday, July 14. Cherished mother of Adrienne Albert Brecher, grandmother of Matthew, loving sister of Dr. Jason Miller. Her extraordinary spirit, humor and warmth will never be forgotten. Services Sunday, July 16, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, Madison at 81 St.

title: Beaten by the Police In Philadelphia
description: To the Editor:

title: Huge Rail Merger Is in Doubt After U.S. Court Upholds Ban
description: The American and Canadian railroads that were planning to combine resources to create a rail system spanning North America lost a court appeal yesterday and will probably end up scuttling their proposed $6 billion merger.

title: Aiding Mother and Child
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Lot of zeros.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Hartwig, Favorite in Pole Vault, Fails at the Trials
description: The United States track and field trials are often called the world's greatest track meet, but they are also the harshest. The first big shock of the trials occurred on the opening night when Jeff Hartwig, the American record-holder in the pole vault and an Olympic gold-medal candidate, failed to clear a height in the qualifying round.

title: Let Us Now Praise Books Well Sold, Well Loved but Seldom Read
description: The tale of the emperor's new clothes has been around a long time. But how about defining another category of mass delusion, the emperor's new book: the insanely popular, often intellectually intimidating book that sells hundreds of thousands of copies (sometimes even millions) but that few people actually read.

title: Strike at the Modern Derails a Summer Film Series
description: A continuing strike at the Museum of Modern Art has removed another event from its summer calendar. First Run Features, a New York film distribution company, has announced that it is postponing an eight-week retrospective that was to have run from July 27 to Sept. 12. Among the 40 to 50 films scheduled were documentaries, gay and lesbian and foreign films and new releases.

title: Ruling for Nonunion Ranks Is Derided by Management
description: A federal agency's ruling this week that a nonunion worker summoned into a boss's office can take along a fellow employee as a witness is being derided by management lawyers and praised by labor advocates. But both sides say the decision is unlikely to alter the dynamics of the workplace immediately.

title: Oh, So Sorry, No Regrets! Forgive Me?
description: THANKS go to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey for this week's lesson on the sorry state of being sorry in America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, SHIRLEY
description: FRIEDMAN-Shirley. 78, Died unexpectedly on July 14, 2000 in Westfield, New Jersey. Beloved wife of Charles Friedman for fiftyseven plus years, adored mother of Steven and David Friedman, loving mother-in-law of Pamela Boord, cherished sister of Gloria Winter and proud aunt of Seth and Susan Winter and their children Jesse, Jamie and Max. Shirley never had an unkind word to say about anybody, and persevered through years of increasing physical disability with courage, strength and a never-ending curiousity about life and interest in other people's well-being. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, July 16 at 9:30 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. in Manhattan. Contributions may be made to Masonic Camp Seven, 71 W. 23rd St., NY, NY, 10010, or to Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, 165 West 46th Street, NY, NY 10036.

title: Piazza Erases Any Doubts With 2 Homers
description: The Mets came back to beat the Boston Red Sox tonight, but a more significant comeback took place. Mike Piazza, it turns out, is just fine.

title: Police Search Home Of Brooklyn Man And Find Old Skulls
description: Three human skulls and a small cache of chemicals and gunpowder were discovered in a cluttered Brooklyn apartment early yesterday, initially stirring fears that the police had stumbled upon the gruesome lair of a serial killer.

title: After a Slow, Slinky Solo Come Pleas for Affection
description: Doug Varone loves to make dancers seem like people who are trying to get together and be sociable. That was clear when his company, Doug Varone and Dancers, performed on Wednesday night as part of the American Dance Festival on the campus of Duke University here. But this performance in Reynolds Industries Theater also suggested that Mr. Varone knows full well how difficult it can be for people to get together and remain together happily.

title: Starr Spokesman Depicted As Eagerly Telling Secrets
description: The Justice Department closed its criminal contempt of court case against Charles G. Bakaly III today by portraying the former spokesman for the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, as eagerly disclosing confidential information to make the counsel's office look important.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Spaniard Plays the Spoiler During a French Holiday
description: Francois Simon awoke this morning with a song in his heart. So did Christophe Agnolutto, Didier Rous, Stephane Heulot and nearly 30 other French riders in the Tour de France.

title: ACT MANUFACTURING IS ADDING BULL ELECTRONICS
description: ACT Manufacturing Inc. has agreed to buy the Bull Electronics Angers unit of the French computer manufacturer Bull S.A. for about $56.6 million in stock. The transaction is expected to close by the end of September, according to ACT, a provider of electronics manufacturing services, based in Hudson, Mass. The Bull unit also provides electronics manufacturing services. It owns and operates a plant in Angers, France, and has approximately 750 employees. ACT said late on Thursday that the acquisition would enhance its position in Europe and expand both its customer base and manufacturing capacity.

title: Whitman's Race Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Security Lapses Signal Unsettling Shift in U.S.-University Nuclear Tie
description: From the dawn of the nuclear age a half century ago, when J. Robert Oppenheimer moved from Berkeley to the New Mexico desert and led the effort to build the atomic bomb, the University of California has been the government's close partner in running its nuclear laboratories.

title: GENERAL BEARING GETS BUYOUT OFFER FROM MANAGEMENT
description: The General Bearing Corporation said yesterday that it had received a buyout offer from a management-led group to take the company private, valuing the company, which makes bearing components and products, at about $26.7 million. The offer for the company, which is based in West Nyack, N.Y., is for $6.50 a share in cash. The transaction would also include the assumption of $13 million of long-term debt. Senior managers decided to make the offer because the stock ''shows no relationship to the progress in the company,'' the chairman, Seymour I. Gussack, said. A committee of independent directors has been formed to assess the offer, which expires on Sept. 2. General Bearing's shares rose $1.1875, to $6.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COCHRAN, LEON KHAY
description: COCHRAN-Leon Khay. Son of Delores Cochran and Prince Bagration de Moucriani. Singer, former Wall Street broker, Farmer, collector of Russian art and many other areas, toured the world in the Don Cossack Choir, performed in summer stock, and in Russian theater in Manhattan for 40 years, a person of many talents, died July 11, at the age of 73, in the tragic explosion of his home in Boerum Hill in Brooklyn. A funeral and memorial service will be held Monday, July 17, 7 PM, at Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church at 85 South Oxford St., Brooklyn. He will be buried in his hometown, of Louisiana, Missouri.

title: Missile Shield: A National Priority?
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Playtime at an Electronic Hoedown
description: A large and enthusiastic, even jubilant crowd went to the auditorium of the Society for Ethical Culture on Thursday night for the second concert in the Lincoln Center Festival's Electronic Evolution series. Quite a crowd was there onstage, too, enthusiastic and even jubilant themselves, to play in Terry Riley's ''In C'' for an hour into the late evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, JAMES F.
description: COLEMAN-James F., 91, of Somers, NY, formerly of Chappaqua, NY, on Thursday, July 13, 2000. Husband of the late Alice Mannix. Father of Barbara C. Allman of Stamford, CT, and Martha Farquhar of Orleans, MA. Brother of Henry Coleman of Lima, OH, and John Coleman of Burlington, VT. Grandfather of six and greatgrandfather of four. Mass of Resurrection, Monday July 17, 2000 in Holy Innocence Church, Pleasantville, NY, 12 Noon. Interment Fair Ridge Cemetery, Chappaqua, NY.

title: High-Flying Lawyer Again Inflicts Damages on Tobacco Industry
description: Stanley M. Rosenblatt, the lawyer who won the biggest class-action lawsuit in history yesterday, is part of a husband-and-wife legal team that operates as lone eagles in the tobacco wars. They are not among the big-name plaintiffs' lawyers who sued the industry on behalf of the states and amassed hundreds of millions of dollars and great political power.

title: CONGRESS CLEARS A BILL TO REPEAL THE ESTATE TAX
description: The Senate voted today to repeal the federal estate tax, brushing aside a veto threat from President Clinton and giving Republicans at least a symbolic victory on an issue at the top of their election-year agenda.

title: Missile Shield: A National Priority?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge on Passaic River Burns, Filling Sky With Thick Smoke
description: The wooden bulkhead of a busy Conrail swing bridge over the Passaic River near Newark caught fire yesterday afternoon, creating dense columns of coal-black smoke visible throughout the New York metropolitan region.

title: CYRK MERGER IS BEING EXPLORED BY MAJOR SHAREHOLDER
description: The largest shareholder of Cyrk Inc. is considering a merger among possible methods for taking the promotions company private. The Yucaipa Companies, which acquired a 22.3 percent stake in Cyrk last November through a $25 million investment, said yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was ''exploring potential opportunities'' for ''an extraordinary corporate transaction that may include a merger.'' Ronald Burkle, a managing partner at Los Angeles-based Yucaipa, is also chairman at Cyrk, which is based in Gloucester, Mass. Cyrk makes custom-designed clothing that sports corporate logos for use in marketing promotions. Cyrk's shares rose $1.5625, to $6.4375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: TALKING ABOUT RACE
description: The Times's six-week report ''How Race Is Lived in America'' concludes with a special issue of The Times Magazine, presenting first-person observations on race from a variety of public figures and private citizens. They express themselves in memoir (including an extended account of growing up biracial by Don Terry), in documentary pictures with commentary and in dialogues across racial lines and within them. The voices reveal how race remains a source of misunderstanding and enlightenment, alienation and unity.

title: Bush Defends the Death Penalty to a Religious Audience
description: One of Gov. George W. Bush's campaign events unexpectedly turned into a debate over the death penalty yesterday when a black minister raised questions about the governor's compassion and told him that a recent execution in Texas was ''not a moral decision.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WAL-MART STORES INC., Bentonville, Ark., said a unit, McLane Co., which provides distribution services, had entered a five-year wholesale supply agreement with the Chevron Corp., San Francisco, under which McLane will distribute food and nonfood products to Chevron's 700 company-operated stores. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Keith Highet, 67, Specialist In International Legal Cases
description: Keith Highet, a lawyer who handled more cases before the International Court of Justice at The Hague than any other American lawyer, died on Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 67.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNY, STEPHEN J.
description: KENNY-Stephen J. of Briarcliff Manor died early Friday morning. Born and raised in New York City, he was graduated from Manhattan College in 1952, entered the U.S. Army, and served in Korea. In 1954 he began his career in the Municipal Bond industry with C.J. Devine & Co, later absorbed by Merrill Lynch, where he remained until 1979. He then joined Goldman Sachs & Co where, as Vice-President at various times, he managed trading, underwriting/syndication, and sales. Mr. Kenny was an active member of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board and an officer and Board member of the Municipal Bond Club of NY. After retiring in 1989, he served as a volunteer in the E.S.L. program, teaching English to inmates at Sing Sing Prison. Married in 1956 to the former Anne M. O'Brien, he is survived by his widow and their children and children-in-law: Suzanne and Jeff Mickelson of Wellesley, Ma, Stephen and Sheila Kenny of Glen Rock, NJ., Michael & Lauren of Rye, NY, Marie and John Foley of Norwich, Ct and Christine of Boston, Ma. He leaves eleven grandchildren, Stephen, Daniel, Benjamin, Patrick, Conor, Christopher, Allison, Anne, Maeve, Ryan and Timothy. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Be a Student's Friend fund of the Inner City Scholarship Fund, 1011 First Ave, Suite 1400, New York, NY 10022, or at their website: www.innercityss.org. Visiting Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, Briarcliff Manor on Saturday & Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass, Church of the Magdalene, Pocantico Hills on Monday at 10:30AM. Interment private.

title: Industry Crosses Troubling Line
description: For tobacco companies, getting the $144.8 billion punitive damage award handed down yesterday by a Miami jury reduced, and even possibly thrown out, may be the easy part.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday about an oil pipeline that is to run from Chad through Cameroon to the Atlantic Ocean referred incorrectly to construction in a Pygmy village. The road shown was cut by a logging company; construction of the pipeline has not begun.

title: In West Bank, Water Is as Touchy as Land
description: Rafat, a skinny 9-year-old too shy to supply a surname, heads every summer morning to the only swimming hole in this hardscrabble stretch of the Hebron hills. It is a stark stone cistern, about a 100 feet long and 50 feet across, built long ago to store the rains that fall only in winter.

title: Bush and Pataki Discuss Vice Presidency, but Doubts Are Plentiful
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas met privately this morning with Gov. George E. Pataki of New York to talk about the vice presidency, and Republican officials with ties to Mr. Pataki's office said that the hourlong discussion coincided with other signs that Mr. Pataki is being looked at for a spot on the Republican ticket.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the impending sale of The Connecticut Post, the daily newspaper in Bridgeport, misstated its circulation ranking in the state. The Post is No. 3 -- behind The Hartford Courant as well as The New Haven Register -- not No. 2.

title: Plan Would Give Boost To Middle-Class Teams
description: Seeking to correct a mushrooming competitive imbalance because of payroll disparity, baseball's latest economic study committee presented a plan yesterday that would seem to take from the rich and give not to the poor but to the middle class.

title: CBS Rechecking Background Of 'Big Brother' Participant
description: Reacting to the news that a participant in its new reality series ''Big Brother'' is a follower of the former Nation of Islam official Khalid Abdul Muhammad, CBS said yesterday that it was ''looking into'' the report but at the moment saw no reason to remove the man from the program.

title: Focus on AIDS Epidemic, Mandela Says
description: Closing the 13th International AIDS Conference today, Nelson Mandela urged scientists to move beyond their concerns about South Africa's president and to focus on combating the epidemic that is raging across the African continent.

title: DEMARCA WINS PLAYOFF
description: John DeMarca's par 4 on the seventh extra hole gave him the playoff victory over Chris Mazzuchetti for the New Jersey State Open championship at the Rock Spring Club in West Orange, N.J.

title: Multimedia Search Engine Retrieves Private Files
description: Multimedia Search Engine Retrieves Private Files

title: A Takeover Of Reliance Falls Through
description: A planned takeover of Saul Steinberg's Reliance Group Holdings collapsed yesterday amid worries that Reliance may be unable to pay debts that come due next month.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the architect and educator John Hejduk on July 6 misspelled the surname of a colleague at the University of Texas in Austin in the 1950's. He was Robert Slutzky, not Slutsky.

title: Gore Is Making Overtures, But Gephardt Is Resisting
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt has emerged high on Al Gore's list of possible running mates, people close to the vice president say. But there is a big problem: Mr. Gephardt's advisers insist that he wants his name scratched.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, DEENA SUSAN
description: SCHWARTZ-Deena Susan. 7/15/ '48-6/16/'98. You will always remain alive in our hearts. Happy Birthday, Mom & Dad

title: After Reluctant 'Yes' to Ministry, Confident Climb to Top
description: She knelt down in her stiff new robe stitched with purple and gold brocade, surrounded by a tight circle of four bishops and five elders. One by one, they laid their hands on the crown of her head in a mighty stack, consecrating her the first woman bishop in the African Methodist Episcopal Church.

title: Prolonged Chip Upswing to Help European Producers
description: Prolonged Chip Upswing to Help European Producers

title: When Child's Play Is Too Simple; Experts Criticize Safety-Conscious Recreation as Boring
description: Just as a society's ideas about nature can be read in the character of its parks, and its beliefs about education are often written in the look of its schools, the attitudes of Americans toward children's play can be traced in the changing face of public playgrounds.

title: U.S. Dumping Of Chemical Riles Koreans
description: SEOUL  The dumping of a toxic chemical at a U.S. military base here ignited a storm of protest Friday with implications for agreements governing the 37,000 U.S. troops in South Korea.

title: Experts Play Down ABM Test Failure
description: The second straight failure of a test for the proposed national missile shield has set off a barrage of criticism. But such breakdowns are routine in ambitious rocketry programs, even ones that eventually succeed, several military and industry experts outside the Pentagon say.

title: Collision Propels Garbage Truck Into Auto Repair Shop, Damaging Brooklyn Building
description: In an unsuccessful attempt to avoid collision with a livery cab early yesterday, a garbage truck crashed into an auto repair shop and an adjacent two-story building in Brooklyn, destroying the front of the store and forcing the evacuation of the building's two apartments, the police said.

title: Where Manners Still Matter
description: From complaints about impolite cell-phone users to gripes over bad service at restaurants, it seems that everyone's gotten a bit prickly over everyone else's manners -- or lack thereof. This perception that civility is on the decline has taken hold not only in places often associated with rudeness, like busy Eastern cities, but also in the supposedly more mannerly cultures of the South and Midwest.

title: Deborah Wallace, Christopher Ruddy
description: Deborah Marjorie Wallace, a daughter of Kathleen and Stratford Wallace of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher James Ruddy, the son of Cathey and Richard Ruddy of Baldwin, N.Y. The Rev. Brian E. Daley performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Art Appreciation for the Blind
description: The Venus de Milo and the Parthenon are part of humanity's artistic heritage. But appreciating that heritage has been harder for the blind.

title: Private Sector; Networking at the Exchange
description: Richard A. Grasso, chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, couldn't let pass a chance to urge John T. Chambers, chief executive of Cisco Systems, to switch his listing from Nasdaq. Mr. Chambers was at a stock exchange banquet on Thursday night to receive a chief executive of the year award from Chief Executive magazine, which is distributed to corporate leaders.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 2 about Mason City, Iowa, misstated the history of the building that houses the Charles H. MacNider Art Museum. It was built in 1920-21 and occupied by two families, and then served as a convent. The MacNider family bought the building in 1964 and turned it over to the city, but never lived in it.

title: Foie Gras and Fogas in Old World Settings
description: THE best restaurants in Budapest are Italian and French.'' Thus spake Laszlo Alkonyi, the editor of Borbarat, Hungary's leading wine review. Indeed, Fausto, his favorite, and Lou-Lou, Italian and French respectively, are very good restaurants in which you'll meet ''le tout Budapest.'' But they weren't my favorites. A week of dedicated dining in Budapest's Hungarian restaurants was as delectable as it was illuminating. I didn't find the Magyar Alain Ducasse, but I did eat really good local food and felt very much part of the life of the city.

title: An Encounter With a Television Psychic
description: SANDY SPECTOR went to see the medium John Edward because she wanted word from her husband, Marty, who died last month. Mrs. Spector, who attended one of Mr. Edward's group sessions here last week at the invitation of a reporter to serve as a control, received more information than she bargained for.

title: Jack Dalton, 92, Authority in Library Studies
description: Jack Dalton, who was dean of Columbia University's School of Library Services, died on July 7 at his home in the Morningside Heights section of Manhattan. He was 92.

title: Long Nights, Longer Days, All Filled With Music
description: EVERY year, around the summer solstice, this faded imperial city steps back into the limelight. On those long white nights, when the sun dips out of sight for only a few hours, crowds gather on the banks of the Neva River, even shabby hotels fill with tourists, and at the venerable Maryinsky (formerly, for a time, Kirov) Theater, the seats at the Stars of the White Nights festival are taken up by rich patrons from all over the world.

title: A Captivating Wit, Drawling His Way Toward Death
description: IT is a melancholy experience to make someone's acquaintance, become increasingly enthralled by his wit and passion, become aware that you're watching him waste away, and then have him die on you, all in the space of 80 minutes. That's what happens in Jem Cohen and Peter Sillen's documentary, ''Benjamin Smoke,'' opening on Friday. Benjamin, who went by just the one name (legally he was Robert Dickerson), was the singer and lyricist for a band called Smoke, hence the title. They were a local sensation in Atlanta and recorded two CD's (''Another Reason to Fast'' and ''Heaven on a Popsicle Stick'') for a local label, but they weren't well known elsewhere.

title: July 9-15; A Woman as A.M.E. Bishop
description: Black women are some of the nation's most powerful preachers. But it took until now for one of them, Vashti Murphy McKenzie, to be elected a bishop of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, the nation's oldest black denomination and now the first to have a woman bishop. As one of 20 A.M.E. bishops, she will have a prestigious post that she will likely hold until mandatory retirement in 20 years. She will spend her first four years supervising A.M.E. churches in southern Africa. Triumphant after the election at the church's quadrennial convention in Cincinnati, she said from the podium, ''The stained glass ceiling has been pierced.'' LAURIE GOODSTEIN

title: Details Needed
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Is a Harder Landing in the Works?
description: REMEMBER stagflation? That's when the economy slows and inflation rises -- the worst of both worlds. It was the curse of the mid-1970's, as the economy fell into recession and the Consumer Price Index rose 12.3 percent in a single year, 1974. And it returned in 1980, when the C.P.I. jumped 12.5 percent while the economy ground to a halt.

title: Prodigy Heads for Texas, With Incentives at Issue
description: Prodigy Communications Corporation, the nation's third-largest Internet service provider, is leaving White Plains for Houston, but not before possibly having to return some economic incentive benefits to Westchester County.

title: Children's Books; Pretty Good Junk
description: There is something essentially American about the compulsion to peddle one's junk to people who are equally eager to acquire it. Whether it's a garage sale, a yard sale, a flea market or a California swap meet, the exercise seems to feed a nation's need to uncover that irresistible bargain. Ah, the uses of disuse. Which is why Mitra Modarressi's YARD SALE! (DK Ink, $15.95; ages 5 to 9) should find a knowing and appreciative audience.

title: Family Strategy For San Diego
description: FOR visitors and San Diegans alike, the city offers some great attractions: the San Diego Zoo, San Diego Wild Animal Park and SeaWorld San Diego.

title: For Sipping and Touring
description: For New Yorkers, Millbrook, a serene semirural Dutchess County community, is both a destination for leisurely wine excursions and the brand name of a line of wines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, RICHARD J., RABBI
description: ISRAEL-Richard J., Rabbi. Hillel Council of New England notes with sorrow the death of our founding Director, Richard J. Israel. Dick's strength, intelligence, commitment and humor were major factors in the development of the community's concern for the needs of Jewish college students, particularly those at small schools without a Hillel Foundation. Our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife and our good friend Sherry and their children and grandchildren. ''Thou shalt be missed because thy seat will be empty'', 1 Samuel 20:18. Ruth Savin Greenberg, President Samuel I. Mendales, Executive Director Hillel Council of New England

title: CANCER DRUG DEBUNKED
description: Andrew J. Lane and his father L. William Lane have advocated the use of shark cartilage as a cancer cure. But federal officials say they want sale of the product halted. Lane Labs of Alendale settled a suit by the Federal Trade Commission this month that will cost the company $1 million for deceptively marketing the products called Benefin, SkinAnswer and MGN-3 as cancer cures. LISA SUHAY

title: Using Olives to Perk Up a Variety of Salads
description: I'M never without olives in the kitchen. Do I need a quick nibble with cocktails? Bring out the olives. Will I want to give a new look and taste to a stew? I'll add olives. And when it comes to salads, plump, glossy olives contribute a deliciously salty tang and meaty texture.

description: WHAT did you say?'' my friend shouted.

title: Elisabeth Topel, John Galotto
description: Elisabeth Suzanne Topel, a daughter of Sandra Topel and Dr. Howard Topel of Deerfield, Ill., was married yesterday evening at her parents' house in Reedsburg, Wis., to John Anthony Galotto, the son of Mary Kay Galotto and Dr. John Galotto of Potomac, Md. Commissioner Leo Grill of Sauk County Family Court officiated at the ceremony, which was led by Justice Seymour Simon, who retired from the Illinois Supreme Court and is a great-uncle of the bride.

description: Dozens of readers responded to Peter Applebome's July 2 column. Here is a sampling of their reactions.

description: THREE adolescent girls, down front on a blanket, by turns raptly attentive and gesticulating in mimicry of the actors, put on a free-flowing show of their own at the opening outdoors of ''The Comedy of Errors'' by Fleetwood Stage at Wildcliff here.

title: Cheri Wicks, John Shaw III
description: Cheri Elizabeth Wicks, an actress, and John Henry Shaw III, an investment banker, were married yesterday in Lewistown, Mont. The Rev. Carole Sims, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Symmes/Wicks House, a 1909 Arts and Crafts home that is now a bed-and-breakfast owned by the bride's parents, Carole and Charles Wicks.

title: Everett Crosses A Line With Ump
description: To the Boston Red Sox, it looked suspicious. On Friday, their manager, Jimy Williams, had ordered the umpires to check the baseball for scuff marks when the Mets' Dennis Cook was pitching. Cook later threw a pitch that hit their star center fielder, Carl Everett, who is noted for crowding the plate.

title: A New Era Brings A Different Bolshoi
description: POWER and passion: the Bolshoi Ballet's dancing has been synonymous with these qualities, making it a company like no other. Virtually sold out for its appearances at Lincoln Center Festival 2000 this week, as it was for its recent five-city United States tour, the fabled troupe from Moscow returns to New York for the first time in 10 years, and with its potent mystique intact.

title: A Great Escape
description: THE CAFE AT ROSEMONT is the sort of place you talk about reluctantly -- a secret you want to keep. It inhabits one of those corners of New Jersey that are vanishing as fast as developers can crack the zoning codes, a place of barns and cornfields and gentle hills, of two-lane roads where you half-expect to see Cary Grant and Katharine Hepburn coming over the next rise in a Packard convertible.

title: One Giant Step for a Sock
description: Not since Kermit and Kukla (Fran and Ollie's friend) has a puppet been so popular. The Sock Puppet became a media star last year as a puppyish mascot in television commercials for Pet.com, a pet-products Web site. The mutt on a mitt has since been a guest on morning chat shows and has floated down Broadway as a 36-foot balloon in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade. But the humans at Pets.com were not prepared for the aftermath of the puppet's spot broadcast during the Super Bowl in January. Traffic on the site that day more than doubled from the previous Sunday's. Some 10,000 Sock fans a month were asking by e-mail and phone, Does the Sock Puppet do weddings, birthday parties, interviews? And most of all, Where can I buy one? Fans were disappointed to learn that the Sock Puppet, who is rumored to have escaped from a washing machine, was not available for sale, rent or bar mitzvahs. No longer. In February, Pets.com auctioned one of the puppets on Amazon.com Auctions for $21,100, which was donated to Pets.commitment, a philanthropic program. And this month, the Sock Puppet went on sale online and off, for $20, along with apparel, toys and other licensed merchandise. JACK BELL

title: WHITE PLAINS: DEVELOPMENT DELAY

The hospital wants commercial and residential development on portions of its 121-acre downtown property in exchange for giving 60 acres of parkland to the city, a plan that only two of the seven Council members support. The hospital had asked for rezoning for the development. At a meeting last week, one of the supporters, Mayor Joseph M. Delfino, asked the Council to postpone a decision until Monday, so he could try to work out a compromise. PETER BELLER

The intricate twin cast-iron facades facing Chambers and Reade Streets are surprisingly intact, but the widening of Church Street in the 1920's exposed a 200-foot-long utilitarian side wall of unadorned brick. There is not too little of the Cary Building but too much.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Millburn Township, N.J.; A Town Where Both Halves Live Well
description: MILLBURN, N.J., is a township with a split personality. Its northern section, known as Short Hills, gives its name to an upscale shopping center, the Mall at Short Hills. The residential area of Short Hills is characterized by winding, hilly roads, bordered by thick stands of oaks. Behind them, often shielded from public view by sumptuous flower gardens, are some of the country's best examples of 19th-century residential architecture. The rest of the town, known as the Millburn section, is laid out more conventionally, with neat streets and a mixture of building styles -- small turn-of-the-century workers' houses, Victorians, Tudors, Cape Cods and 1950's ranches and colonials -- on smaller lots, some just 36 feet wide.

description: The mother of Kevin Lawless, an 18-year-old freshman at Iona College in New Rochelle who died of alcohol poisoning last year, is seeking up to $38 million from the school and the owners of two taverns. The suit alleges that Iona administrators and the owners of Ketch 22 North and the now-defunct Molly's Bar failed to control an atmosphere of rampant underage drinking and fraternity hazing. Mr. Lawless died Dec. 13, the final night of pledge period for Sigma Tau Omega, a fraternity banned by Iona in the 1980's for hazing and alcohol abuse. At the time of his death, he had a .34 percent blood alcohol level, more than twice the legal limit. ELSA BRENNER

title: Consumed By Race
description: The rooms on these pages represent how race is lived at its most basic level: in the kitchens and living rooms of our homes. Using information culled from several comprehensive demographic and consumer surveys (Sources, Page 79), we furnished and stocked the rooms to reflect the average American white household and the average American black household. Each item can be found in at least half of the households of that race, and except for the appliances, the most popular brand of each product is pictured. While they cannot capture the diversity of experience in the United States, the items show how statistical averages can tell us how different, and how similar, those experiences are.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; A Heritage Renewed
description: An invisible past is a diminished one. Deborah Willis, curator of exhibitions at the Smithsonian's Center for African-American History and Culture in Washington, has spent much of her career recovering the work of black photographers and trying to redress widespread ignorance of their accomplishments. REFLECTIONS IN BLACK: A History of Black Photographers, 1840 to the Present (Norton, $50), a historical and biographical survey with nearly 600 reproductions, is her latest effort toward this goal. Black Americans have produced photographs since the emergence of the daguerreotype, which was introduced in New Orleans by a free man of color named Jules Lion. Photography has always been practiced as a business, no less so by blacks who set up daguerreotype studios in cities or practiced their craft as itinerants. One notable example was J. P. Ball, a photographer and entrepreneur who established a large and successful portrait business in Cincinnati in the 1850's and won national recognition with his antislavery panoramas. Every style from the classic to avant-garde is represented in this book, and virtually every subject, including civil rights, spirituality, celebrity, culture and identity. Scenes of family life recur, ranging in tone from Allen E. Cole's rather stilted tableau of the 1930's, ''Home of Mrs. H. H. Sink,'' to the image of a mother-daughter face-off over the kitchen table by the contemporary photographer Carrie Mae Weems. In producing this handsome and ample book, despite its inevitable omissions, Willis has performed an important act of cultural and historical excavation. Rosemary Ranck

description: Dashing the hopes of thousands of scientists gathered in Durban, South Africa, for the 13th International Aids Conference, President Thabo Mbeki singled out extreme poverty, rather than AIDS, as the biggest killer in Africa. Mr. Mbeki has stirred a furor by entertaining the theory that poverty, not the H.I.V. virus, causes AIDS -- an argument most scientists say was debunked years ago. No one disputes the link between poverty and AIDS. But many scientists fear that Mr. Mbeki's comments will fuel confusion among ordinary people who may assume they can continue risky sexual behavior because the president has questioned whether H.I.V. causes AIDS. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, THOMAS A.
description: COLEMAN-Thomas A. Of New York City and Spring Lake, NJ on July 14, 2000 at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. Son of the late John A. Coleman and Ann Meehan Coleman and brother of the late John A. Coleman, Jr. Survived by his beloved sister Mary Ann Hagerty of Sea Island, GA., his niece Elizabeth H. Dessen of Ambler, PA, and his nephews John A. Coleman III of New York City, Harry C. Hagerty III of Osterville, MA, and John C. Hagerty of Summit, NJ. He was a long-time member of the New York Stock Exchange and a Senior Partner of Adler, Coleman & Co., a specialist firm on the NYSE. He served as a member of the Board of Directors of the NYSE, the New York Futures Exchange and the East River Savings Bank. Mr. Coleman was a graduate, Benefactor and long-time Trustee of the University of Notre Dame and served on the Advisory Board of the University's College of Business. He received Honorary Doctorates from both Notre Dame and St. Bonaventure University. Mr. Coleman was a long-time Benefactor of St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center and served most recently as Chairman of St. Vincent's Board of Trustees. He was an Honorary Commissioner of the New York Fire Department, the New York Police Department and the City of Philadelphia Police Department and was a Trustee of the NYFD's Honor Emergency Fund. He served Notre Dame as Honorary Chief of the Fire Department and Honorary Director of Public Safety for the University. Mr. Coleman was past President of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York and member of the Board of Founders of the Knights of Malta. He served as a Trustee of St. Patrick's Cathedral, Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, the Alfred E. Smith Foundation, the College of Mount St. Vincent and the New York Foundling Hospital. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York on Saturday, July 15 and Sunday, July 16 from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian burial will be said at 10:15 AM on Monday, July 17 at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Coleman Family Center for Campus Ministry at the University of Notre Dame, South Bend, IN, the Honor Emergency Fund c/o New York City Fire Department; and the Police Relief Fund Inc., c/o New York City Police Department.

title: Reckonings; Who's Acquiring Whom?
description: For those of us who remember the great wave of foreign investment in the United States between 1986 and 1990, it's starting to feel like deja vu all over again. Lately hardly a week goes by without news that yet another American business icon has become part of a foreign-based corporate empire. Some of the acquirees are the very companies that in the past tried to use their all-American identity as a marketing tool. For example, in the days of Lee Iacocca, Chrysler tried to convince people that there was something patriotic about buying mediocre cars festooned with chrome and simulated wood paneling. But now the minivan has married the Mercedes: Chrysler has become the junior partner in DaimlerChrysler. Seagram (strictly speaking a Canadian company, but with its center of gravity well south of the border) is being absorbed by the French firm Vivendi. And most recently, Union Bank of Switzerland has announced that it is acquiring PaineWebber -- that symbol of America's belief that it is both possible and good to become rich.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Last Words, Sort Of
description: When someone takes his own life, it's tempting to interpret everything he did and said near the end as a kind of warning. Such compulsive reductionism is particularly difficult to avoid in reading AN UNFORTUNATE WOMAN: A Journey (St. Martin's, $17.95), a book-length work Richard Brautigan completed a year before his suicide in 1984. In it, Brautigan creates what he calls ''a calendar of one man's journey during a few months in his life'' that, though labeled as fiction by its publisher, reads like memoir. The title refers to a friend who had killed herself and whose absence is the book's organizing force. Under the shadow of this event, Brautigan's familiar mix of wry stories and observations takes on a persistent mordancy. There are certainly moments here when he revels in the absurd, as when he relates his determination, while visiting Hawaii, to pose for a photo with a chicken. More often, though, he adopts a subdued tone that will surprise fans of his famously playful novels. After devoting so much thought to the question of individual freedom in a corrupt world, Brautigan seems here to concede, finally, that some things are inescapable. He dedicates his introduction to another friend who had recently died from cancer. It's possible to read countless other elements of the book as intimations of mortality, from Brautigan's compulsive traveling to his habit of concluding many sections with a date and the word ''finished.'' But just as evident, though overshadowed by subsequent events, is the author's determination to resist the bleak certitude of death. ''Life cannot be controlled and perhaps not even envisioned and . . . design and portent are out of the question,'' he notes at one point. Such a statement -- along with the rest of ''An Unfortunate Woman'' -- can be read as an expression of Zen-like peace or of helplessness verging on despair. Etelka Lehoczky

title: Rat Fears
description: When Joseph Mitchell wrote in 1944 that ''Rats are almost as fecund as germs,'' he was getting at something profound about our urban nightmares. We fear the creatures that proliferate wildly -- rats and cockroaches chiefly -- because to do so they must proliferate unseen. No really hard numbers exist on the rat population in New York City for that very reason. One of Mitchell's sources, an exterminator, estimated that the number of rats in the city had dropped from two per person around 1920 to one per person in the early 1940's, largely because of a reduction in horses and changes in construction. Since then, one rat per person in New York has come to seem like gospel.

I complained to one of the executive partners of the company, but they did nothing to change the caustic environment or to protect me from retaliation.

title: A Refreshing Curve In a Straight Summer
description: INSINUATING its way into a summer of movies of negligible ambiguity -- many are the attractions of ''Gladiator,'' ''The Patriot'' and ''The Perfect Storm,'' but their ability to provoke a tentative, questioning mood in the viewer is not among them -- comes one of the major chew bones of this year's Sundance Film Festival, ''Chuck and Buck.'' The movie, which opened on Friday, is about boyhood friends who re-encounter each other after many years; Chuck has gone on to become a Los Angeles record company executive, professionally accomplished and successfully affianced, while Buck hasn't gone on to anything except a huge case of arrested development, a large part of which involves keeping the memory of their boyish sex play burning like an eternal flame. It's a movie that careers into one cringe-inducing circumstance after another: the sexuality of children, the old relationship that will not die, the overweening confidence of jerks, the cruelty of the panicked, the geek who will not go away. And it's a comedy!

description: MECKEL-Wilfred J. July 14, 2000 at the age of 87. He died peacefully from Leukemia, which became aggressive in the last two months. Originally from Corona and then from Jackson Heights in Queens, his middle years were spent in Garden City and the golden ones in Baiting Hollow, NY. His wife of 61 years Emily, his son Billy and daughter Emilyann, his daughterin-law Gail, son-in-law David and his wonderful grandchildren Alexandra, Karina, Brad, Amanda and John are all saddened by his passing and will miss him forever. But living on is his genuine warmth, his friendliness toward all and the joy he always found in the simplest aspects of life. They paid the former Supreme Diana Ross a guarantee reported to be between $15 million and $20 million and set a top ticket price around $250. But none of Ms. Ross's surviving former bandmates deigned to join her on the tour, claiming that their pay was too miniscule compared with hers. Though a date at Madison Square Garden on July 8 sold out, other arenas have been half or even three-quarters empty. Last week, Ms. Ross issued a press release stating that the tour had been canceled against her will. But SFX, the tour's promoter, despite calling off almost each concert at the last minute since then, claims that the tour is still happening, leaving ticket-holders grumbling, ''You Keep Me Hangin' On.'' But after he died in 1940 the company's use of the building fell off and it was sold. Now, DaimlerChrysler A.G., the predominantly German-managed company into which the Chrysler Corporation was merged in 1988, said it was hoping to rent and renovate space in the building as a ''virtual headquarters'' where its board would meet and investor and public relations staffs would work.

title: Lifesavers and Lighthouses
description: Remember the Passaic Lighthouse? It was built in 1849 where the Passaic River meets Newark Bay. It's not there anymore, but there is a photograph of it as well as other lost beacons in ''Guarding New Jersey's Shore: Lighthouses and Life-Saving Stations.'' There were once 38 beacons dotting both the state's coasts (the Delaware had lighthouses, too); there are 18 still standing. Even the Statue of Liberty was a lighthouse, readers learn, from 1886 to 1901. The book is put out by Arcadia Publishing, which has produced books of old photos of towns in New Jersey and other states, sort of vanity publications with very local appeal. But through the research of David Veasey of Morris Plains, this one covers the waterfront. He tells readers that the United States Life-Saving Service, a forerunner of the Coast Guard, started in New Jersey. There are photos of early members and of stations, of which 20 stand. The book, in paperback, is $18.95 and is sold in bookstores or through www.arcadiapublishing.com.

title: Ideas & Trends; Refining the Cat's-Eye View of the Cosmos
description: STARTLING as life in the subatomic realm can seem, with particles existing both here and there or darting to and fro at the same time, people have been able to take some small comfort in knowing that the ''real'' world doesn't work that way. Though made of the very same stuff that marches to the dictates of quantum theory -- the laws that explain how particles behave -- solid objects obediently occupy one place at a time and are never seen moving in two directions at once. It may be hard to tell whether a torpid cat, barely blinking its eyes, remains among the living. But that is a far cry from the mythical cat in the physicist Erwin Schrodinger's oft-recited thought experiment, which is placed in a state of being dead and alive at the same time.

title: Lives; My Chinese Phase

We walked to grade school together, and when we went on to junior high I fell in with his nascent group of Chinese or quasi-Chinese friends. I say ''quasi-Chinese'' because the concept was loose. Anything Asian -- the word meant little in the early 70's -- was more or less Chinese. This looseness made perfect sense when we were 12, still just trying out the roles that we would later play. description: KENNY-Stephen J. of Briarcliff Manor died early Friday morning. Born and raised in New York City, he was graduated from Manhattan College in 1952, entered the U.S. Army, and served in Korea. In 1954 he began his career in the Municipal Bond industry with C.J. Devine & Co, later absorbed by Merrill Lynch, where he remained until 1979. He then joined Goldman Sachs & Co where, as Vice-President at various times, he managed trading, underwriting/syndication, and sales. Mr. Kenny was an active member of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board and an officer and Board member of the Municipal Bond Club of NY. After retiring in 1989, he served as a volunteer in the E.S.L. program, teaching English to inmates at Sing Sing Prison. Married in 1956 to the former Anne M. O'Brien, he is survived by his widow and their children and children-in-law: Suzanne and Jeff Mickelson of Wellesley, Ma, Stephen and Sheila Kenny of Glen Rock, NJ., Michael & Lauren of Rye, NY, Marie and John Foley of Norwich, Ct and Christine of Boston, Ma. He leaves eleven grandchildren, Stephen, Daniel, Benjamin, Patrick, Conor, Christopher, Allison, Anne, Maeve, Ryan and Timothy. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Be a Student's Friend fund of the Inner City Scholarship Fund, 1011 First Ave, Suite 1400, New York, NY 10022, or at their website: www.innercityss.org. Visiting Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, Briarcliff Manor on Saturday & Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass, Church of the Magdalene, Pocantico Hills on Monday at 10:30AM. Interment private.

title: Breathing Life Into City's Barren Plazas
description: AT first blush, it seems unfair that a city without an Olmsted Park should have a Balsley Park. Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), designer of Central Park and Prospect Park, transformed whole swaths of New York. The landscape architect Thomas Balsley (b. 1943) transforms far smaller plots, like the third of an acre on Ninth Avenue, between 56th and 57th Streets, once known as Sheffield Plaza, that now bears his name.

title: Solitary Performer On a Crowded Stage
description: THOUGH John Hejduk was little known outside the world of architecture, his influence exceeded that of many of its most prominent figures. His death earlier this month, at 71, leaves a profound emptiness -- a quality that, as it happens, Hejduk often reflected on in his work. Like many gifted architects, he was a contradictory figure: a solitary artist who chose to work in a highly social form of art. But he had a particular way of living out the contradiction. Instead of constructing social spaces with bricks and mortar, he fashioned one from ideas and emotions and peopled it with students and faculty members of the school he led for 25 years.

It was the opening weekend of ''Zoot Suit,'' the movie version of his 1978 musical play about the arrest, imprisonment and subsequent vindication of a group of young Chicanos in World War II Los Angeles: a project with which Mr. Valdez had a great deal of unfinished business.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-16-00: Round Table; Writing About Race (And Trying to Talk About It)
description: The Times Magazine asked eight New York Times editors and reporters to talk about working on the paper's ''How Race Is Lived in America'' project. Specifically, we wanted to know how their own attitudes about race were affected by the experience. The conversation, held at The Times on June 19, was moderated by Sam Roberts, a Times editor and host of ''New York Close-Up'' on NY 1. The panel consisted of two editors, Gerald Boyd and Soma Golden Behr, and six reporters: Steven Holmes (whose article dealt with race relations in the Army), Dana Canedy (race at a newspaper), Ginger Thompson (a former plantation), Janny Scott (the making of an HBO movie), Mirta Ojito (two Cuban friends now living in Miami) and Michael Winerip (New York City police officers). Holmes, Canedy and Winerip also acted as editors on the project.

title: Think Pasta, And Protect Basil
description: Fusarium wilt has been robbing basil growers of pesto for a decade. If your basil plants suddenly wilt and turn black despite good care, throw them away with the soil they were growing in. This fungus persists in the soil for years and is likely to infect healthy plants. Buy new plants and plant in new soil. Next year, try seeds of the first fusarium-resistant cultivar, Nufar. If your basil crop is healthy, harvest it often and don't let it flower.

title: Letters From the Web
description: My first extended contact with black people came at the age of 50, at a data-processing job at an insurance firm. There were 15 or 18 black women working there who ranged in age from their late 20's to their late 50's. Before that, race was something I had never thought about, so I expected these co-workers to be the same as any others. I was shocked by the vulgarity of their speech, their loudness and their inappropriate behavior. These were nice, capable women individually who as a group acted like teenagers. During the six years I worked there, I found myself increasingly uncomfortable around them and even came to resent them because their behavior wouldn't have been tolerated had they been anything but black.

title: Commercial Vacancy Rates Drop Countywide

title: MAMARONECK: TENNIS CENTER DISPUTE
description: There may be no indoor tennis available this winter at the courts in Harbor Island Park because of continuing litigation over a new sports center to be built in the park, Steven Silverberg, the Mamaroneck village attorney, said. The Village Board of Trustees has voted unanimously to appeal a preliminary injunction barring the village from contracting to build the new center with any company other than Harbor View Racquet Club, the current operator of the courts. Harbor View's agreement with the village expired in May, and the village board had hoped to grant a contract for new courts and a multisport center to Sportime, a Long Island company. The village had argued that Harbor View, which has operated the courts since 1978, lacked the money and experience to build the center. Harbor View, however, had a right of first refusal, which Justice John P. DiBlasi of State Supreme Court in White Plains upheld last month. ROBERT WORTH

title: BRIEFING: GOVERNMENT; CRANBERRY BAILOUT
description: The federal Department of Agriculature, which already gave the cranberry industry a boost by buying 14 million pounds of berries in the last two years, announced last week that it might buy more than twice that amount to bail out the industry, according to a spokesman for the agriculture agency. New Jersey has 47 cranberry growers and is the third-largest producer of cranberries in the United States, after Wisconsin and Massachusetts. A surplus dropped the price for farmers to less than $30 this year from more than $60 a barrel in 1996. Whether the government will buy another 30.4 million barrels will depend on whether enough uses can be found for the cranberries, Mr. Chartier said. KARDEN DeMASTERS

title: Sharks (in a Tank) In Charleston Harbor
description: Visitors to Charleston can explore Southern aquatic life at the South Carolina Aquarium, which opened on May 19. The aquarium, which juts into Charleston Harbor for 200 feet, will showcase plants and animals from five major regions of the Appalachian Watershed: the mountains, the Piedmont, the Coastal Plain, the coast and the ocean. The focal point of the 93,000-square-foot aquarium will be a two-story Great Ocean Tank Exhibit featuring about 800 animals, including sea turtles, sharks, stingrays and coral. The Blackwater Swamp Exhibit replicates the atmosphere of a cypress-tupelo swamp at twilight, using a spongy floor, fog, and twinkling lights to simulate fireflies. A 2,500-square-foot salt marsh, complete with palmettos, sandpipers and fiddler crabs, anchors the Coastal Gallery, which also boasts lively baby alligators.
