title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITT, MARY SCHWEITZER
description: LITT-Mary Schweitzer. On July 12, 2000, peacefully at her home in Pleasant Valley, NY, at age 96. Beloved wife of the late Solomon. Loving mother of Mark D. and Judith Litt of Larchmont, NY, and Susan L. and Roderick McLeod of Toronto, Ontario. Adored grandmother of Lauren Alwan, Steven Litt, Cindy Alwan, Helen Litt, Tammie Jennings and Philip Presnal; and great-grandmother of Sarah, Clayton, Davis, Elizabeth, Miles and Gabriel. Dear sister of the late James J. Sweitzer, formerly of Phoenix, AZ. A resident of Manhattan since early childhood, Mary spent the past five years at her beloved farm ''Basswood''. She loved and nourished her family & everyone who came to know her. She set high standards for herself and expected the same from others. Mary was an enthusiastic watercolorist whose subjects ranged from landscapes and cityscapes of Dutchess County, Europe, Mexico and Israel, to floral still lifes and nudes. She studied for many years at the Art Students League & the National Academy of Design in New York. Mary was a member and benefactor of the American Watercolor Society and a life member and benefactor of the Art Students League. Supporter of many cultural and charitable causes including the Holocaust Museum and Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, the NeoNatal Unit of Mt. Sinai Hospital in Toronto and the Pleasant Valley Library. Services Sunday, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Hospice Inc. of Dutchess County. Family will receive friends Sunday evening, 7-9 PM at 870 United Nations Plaza and Monday evening 7-9 PM at 27 Hall Avenue, Larchmont.

title: Letters From the Web
description: I was in a supervisory position at a previous job and I had to inform a woman who was black that her position was being downgraded. She could either remain at the downgraded position or try to find another job within the company. She was understandably angry about the situation and filed a grievance against me, claiming racial discrimination. She cited 26 separate instances of discrimination. Everything was investigated, and all 26 instances were proved false when the claim went before the grievance council. I am not a racist, and to have someone falsely accuse me of being one tore at my emotions. The good ending is that, while we have both moved on to different jobs, we have managed to become friends again.

He served as a Chemical Engineer in Building Defense Plants for Union Carbide Corporation during World War II which included assignments in Whiting, Indiana; Texas City, Texas; Institute, West Virginia and Oak Ridge, Tennessee. After the war he joined National Distillers Corporation in New York and later Koppers Coke Company in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania before founding his consulting firm, Keep Chemical Company and later, Emilia Ferrara Ltd., the producer of Timely Soap. He is survived by daughters Amy of Croton-On-Hudson, New York, and Alison A. F. Ely, Sr. Mr. Ely attended Deerfield Academy and received a BA degree in 1935 from Hamilton College, a law degree from Yale Law School in 1939 and an MBA from Harvard the same year. He served in the Army Air Corps during WWII. He returned to practice law with the firm of Miller, Hubbell & Evans and remained there with its successor firms until his retirement. As a child Mr. Ely spent summers in the Adirondacks; in later life he was on the Board of the Association for the Protection of the Adirondacks. He was also active with local charitable and community organizations, principally Faxton Hospital and the Chamber Music Society. He is survived by a nephew, James S. Ely, Jr. of Rochester, NY, and a niece, Nell E. Wendler of London, England, and several grand nephews and nieces. A memorial service was held at First Presbyterian Church, Utica, on Friday, July 14th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARSKI, JAN
description: KARSKI-Jan. The officers, members and staff of the American Jewish Committee deeply mourn the death of Jan Karski, a courier of courage. Jan Karski was a diplomat, a Righteous Gentile, a messenger for the Polish underground resistance during World War II, and an eyewitness to the systematic Nazi extermination of the Jews in Poland. He risked his own life to report the unimaginable atrocities he had seen to the Polish, British and American governments and to plead for help in saving Jewish lives. Modestly referring to himself as a ''human tape recorder'', he was, in actuality, a trumpet, heralding the harsh tones of human indifference and cruelty, while at the same time personifying the indomitable spirit and inherent goodness that mankind can still possess. He devoted his postwar life to protecting the memory of the victims of the Holocaust, combating anti-Semitism and intolerance, and advancing the cause of human rights. In 1993, the AJC bestowed our highest honor on Jan Karski, and in 1999, he was the first recipient of the Eternal Light Award from the Center for Catholic/Jewish Studies, a collaboration of AJC and Saint Leo University. With great sorrow we now bid farewell to a dear frienda gentleman and a gentle man of enormous personal courage and profound moral integrity. We will cherish his memory as near to our hearts as he cradled the souls of the millions of Jews he never knew but tried to rescue. Bruce M. Ramer, President David A. Harris, Excutive Director

title: War Without End in Sri Lanka

Since the spring, the war has heated up again with an anti-government offensive by separatist Tamils in Sri Lanka's north. But there has also been a positive development. The United States, India and other countries are increasingly united in trying to bring an end to the fighting.

He was a long-time member of the New York Stock Exchange and a Senior Partner of Adler, Coleman & Co., a specialist firm on the NYSE. He served as a member of the Board of Directors of the NYSE, the New York Futures Exchange and the East River Savings Bank. Mr. Coleman was a graduate, Benefactor and long-time Trustee of the University of Notre Dame and served on the Advisory Board of the University's College of Business. He received Honorary Doctorates from both Notre Dame and St. Bonaventure University. Mr. Coleman was a long-time Benefactor of St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center and served most recently as Chairman of St. Vincent's Board of Trustees. He was an Honorary Commissioner of the New York Fire Department, the New York Police Department and the City of Philadelphia Police Department and was a Trustee of the NYFD's Honor Emergency Fund. He served Notre Dame as Honorary Chief of the Fire Department and Honorary Director of Public Safety for the University. Mr. Coleman was past President of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York and member of the Board of Founders of the Knights of Malta. He served as a Trustee of St. Patrick's Cathedral, Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, the Alfred E. Smith Foundation, the College of Mount St. Vincent and the New York Foundling Hospital. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York on Saturday, July 15 and Sunday, July 16 from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian burial will be said at 10:15 AM on Monday, July 17 at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Coleman Family Center for Campus Ministry at the University of Notre Dame, South Bend, IN, the Honor Emergency Fund c/o New York City Fire Department; and the Police Relief Fund Inc., c/o New York City Police Department.

Shares of Cephalon, based in West Chester, Pa., rose $5.25, to $71.25, also in Nasdaq trading. Anesta had revenue of $6.52 million in 1999, while Cephalon's revenue was $44.9 million.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Credible Response
description: It is a sour coincidence that Hillary Rodham Clinton should be accused of using anti-Semitic language while negotiations are under way at Camp David that represent the best chance in decades for a comprehensive peace settlement in the Middle East. But in another sense, this juxtaposition of domestic politics and foreign policy provides an opportunity to examine a serious underlying principle. There is no doubt, in our view, that Mrs. Clinton, if elected to the Senate, would be a firm supporter of Israel's security, its aspirations for peace and its economic vitality. We say that without imputing any weakness on these issues to her Republican opponent, Representative Rick Lazio. Our intent is simply to say that this is one of those campaign moments when voters need to look at long-term policy prospects rather than the controversy of the moment.

Yet the Queens of the Stone Age show at Bowery Ballroom on Saturday night stimulated headbanging of the most refined variety.

description: TARLOW-William F., 87, formerly of Roslyn, NY, at home, Sunday, in Somers, NY, following a long illness. Husband of Glenys, father of Reuven, Lawrence, Lee Miller, and the late Andrew; grandfather of Jeffrey, Rachel, Henry, Yosef Yitzhak, Chana, & Shneur Zalman; brother of Jerome, Elayne, & the late Gertrude. Contributions in his memory may be made to Hospice Care of Westchester and Putnam, Inc., 100 South Bedford Road, Mount Kisco, New York 10549.

title: Senator Undergoes Surgery for Brain Hemorrhage
description: Senator Paul Coverdell of Georgia, a top Senate Republican leader, underwent brain surgery for a cerebral hemorrhage today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENRIGHT, ERICA
description: ENRIGHT-Erica. Died of cancer at her home in Los Angeles in the early morning of Sunday, July 16. She was 52 years old. Born and raised in New York, Erica studied drama at the University of Miami and the Herbert Berghoff School, appearing off-Broadway, in films and on television. Later turning to TV news, she wrote and produced at WNEW, WABC and ''Good Morning America'' in New York and at KCBS in Los Angeles. At the time of her illness, she was researching a book about criminal tragedy in Montana. The daughter of Stella and the late Daniel Enright, Erica is survived by her mother and her brother, Don. Services on Wednesday, July 19, at 3:00 at Pierce Brothers Westwood Village Memorial Park, Los Angeles. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to The Program to End Parkinson's, 201 Wilshire Boulevard, Santa Monica, California 90401.

title: 2 European Exchanges Eager to Join Nasdaq
description: Not content with orchestrating a merger with the London Stock Exchange, the chairman of the Frankfurt stock exchange said today that he wanted to explore a full merger with the Nasdaq market in the United States.

title: Drug War Awaits Attack of Killer Fungus
description: Dr. David C. Sands holds out a clear plastic petri dish filled with a white fuzzy fungus growing across the bottom. This substance, he believes, is the key to ending much of the world's production of illicit drugs.

title: Legal Pad Maker in Deal
description: The American Pad and Paper Company, which invented the legal pad in 1888, agreed today to sell its Williamhouse envelope unit to Saratoga Partners, a New York-based merchant bank, for an undisclosed sum. American Pad, which had 1999 sales of $573 million, is selling Williamhouse to reduce debt. In May, the company completed the sale of its Chicago-based Creative Card division to the Taylor Corporation. The company is also pursuing the sale of its Ampad and Forms divisions. In January, the Dallas-based American Pad sought United States Bankruptcy Court protection after bondholders filed an involuntary Chapter 11 petition.

title: Eschmeyer Puts Skills To Early Test for Nets
description: The hands are steady and, this summer, becoming more sure. But they are not the delicate tools of a surgeon, which Evan Eschmeyer once thought he might become after graduating from Northwestern with a degree in education and a minor in pre-med.

title: Armstrong and Pantani Bicker on Day Off
description: An unsuspected feud between Lance Armstrong and Marco Pantani burst into public view today as the American leader of the Tour de France angrily criticized the star Italian climber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYD, ROBERT NEILSON
description: BOYD-Robert Neilson. Born July 18, 1914. Died July 16, 2000 in New York City. Husband of Rosalind Boyd, father of Andrew Boyd. Emeritus Professor of Chemistry at New York University.

title: Nile Virus Found Again In the City
description: After finding two dead crows infected with the West Nile virus on Staten Island, New York City officials announced late yesterday that they would spray about half the borough with a pesticide starting tomorrow night to try to kill mosquitoes that carry the disease before it can spread again to humans.

title: CANADA PILOTS REJECT ARBITRATION
description: A showdown between Air Canada and its 2,200 pilots intensified as the pilots rejected management's request to submit contract issues over flight fatigue and pensions to binding arbitration. The Air Canada Pilots Association has yet to set a strike date, but the possibility remains that the pilots could shut down the airline by the end of the week. Timothy Pritchard

title: NORSK HYDRO'S PROFIT JUMPS
description: Norway's largest publicly traded company, Norsk Hydro, said its second-quarter profit more than doubled because of higher prices for crude oil, aluminum and fertilizers. Net income rose to 2.78 billion kroner ($319 million), from 1.26 billion a year earlier. Hydro is benefiting with oil prices near a nine-year high just as its chief executive, Egil Myklebust, sells peripheral businesses and cuts costs. Second-quarter sales rose to 36.5 billion kroner from 24.5 billion, while operating profit increased to 7.03 billion from 1.75 billion a year earlier. Of the sales increase, 4.2 billion came from higher oil prices.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Everybody used to talk about the go-go 80's like they were so wonderful. Well, the 80's were like child's play. It is ridiculous now. The amount of time and stress that my people have had to put up with is inhuman.''

description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUILICO, LOUIS
description: QUILICO-Louis. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of our beloved colleague and friend, Louis Quilico. A versatile and generous artist, he sang 278 performances with the company between 1972 and 1994, and created the roles of the Bishop in ''Esclarmonde'' and Coroebus in ''Les Troyens'' in the Met premieres of those works. He appeared in Met telecasts as Renato in ''Un Ballo in Maschera,'' Rodrigo in ''Don Carlo,'' and in the tile role of ''Rigoletto.'' We extend out deepest sympathy to his wife, Christina; our colleague, his son, Gino; his daughter, Donna; and all his family and friends. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: Trying a New Shoe on for Size; Can Owners of Skechers Learn From Their Mistakes?
description: Michael Greenberg, the founder and president of the trendy shoe company Skechers U.S.A., is so determined to put out his company's message that he follows a written outline when he recites a list of recent feats.

description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Milwaukee and Chicago

title: Online Investing Clubs Evolve, Thanks to One-Stop Internet Shops
description: Brittany Crist had bounced between three 401(k) plans in 12 years. She had been through a raft of Fidelity funds and bought shares in Intel, Oracle and Microsoft. She had even kept up with the very latest books on investing. But it was the Web that finally inspired her to form the Dart Throwin' Monkeys.

title: Starr's Former Spokesman Denies Deception in Contempt Case
description: Charles G. Bakaly III, the former spokesman for the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr, testified today that he never misled a federal judge about the role he had played as a source for a New York Times article that discussed whether President Clinton could be indicted while in office.

description: EUROPE

title: Public Interests; What Hillary Said
description: The Arkansas that Bill and Hillary Clinton used to live in does not seem to have been part of normal reality. It's more of a parallel universe, like the one the wizards inhabit in Harry Potter books, only uncharming.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERADA HESS CORP., New York, an oil company, agreed to buy an additional 2.1 percent stake in three Caspian Sea oil fields from Ramco Energy P.L.C., a British oil company, for $150 million.

title: Russian Tycoon in New Role As Organizer of Opposition
description: Boris A. Berezovsky, the archetypal Russian tycoon, politician and, until lately, a force within the Kremlin itself, said today that he would quit his seat in Parliament on Wednesday and try to form an alliance of big business and regional politicians aimed at curbing President Vladimir V. Putin's growing power.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PREVENTION; A Gum to Chew Away Tooth Decay
description: Chewing gum that contains a substance found in birch bark can help suppress the bacteria that cause tooth decay, The Journal of the American Dental Association reported this month.

title: As Tax Cut Vote Nears, White House Attacks Republican Plan
description: As the Senate moved toward passage of an election-year tax cut for married couples, the Clinton administration renewed its attack today on the tax agenda being promoted by the Republican majority in Congress, calling it a fiscally reckless attempt to help the wealthy at the expense of working people.

title: South America
description: Brazil's Coach Wanderley Luxemburgo is planning more changes for Brazil's World Cup qualifying game in Paraguay today. Luxemburgo is expected to make at least five changes from the lineup that struggled in a 1-1 tie with Uruguay last month at home. Luxemburgo is expected to play Sao Paulo's Edmilson and Palmeiras' Roque Junior in an untried central defensive partnership, and field a five-man midfield.

title: Officer Chasing Motorcyclist Dies After a Car Crash
description: A police officer pursuing a suspected motorcycle thief in a high-speed chase was killed yesterday after his unmarked patrol car spun out of control and hit a utility pole along a service road to the Staten Island Expressway, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORTH, WENDY
description: WORTH-Wendy, Ph.D. The staff of The VanItallie Center for Nutrition and Weight Management and the entire St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center family acknowledge with sadness the passing of our esteemed colleague and beloved therapist, Wendy Worth, Ph.D. Her dedication to her patients was unsurpassed, as were her skills in helping to develop a model for chronic care of obesity. To the Worth family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. We will all miss Wendy deeply.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; General Mills is under pressure to make its Pillsbury deal pay off.
description: IN announcing that it would pay $10.5 billion for Pillsbury, General Mills served notice yesterday that it wanted to be the king of convenience foods, an important area for time-pressed consumers and the companies that want their business.

title: Syrians, After Generations in Egypt, Are Still French
description: BIRDS OF PASSAGE

title: LEGRAND ACQUIRES WIREMOLD, A CABLE SYSTEMS PROVIDER
description: The French electrical equipment maker Legrand S. A. said yesterday that it had acquired the privately held Wiremold Company, a provider of wiring and cable systems, for $650 million plus the assumption of $120 million of debt. The move nearly doubles Legrand's United States business. The company, which had $2.5 billion in revenue last year, said that with the deal 25 percent of its revenue will come from the United States, up from 13 percent before the deal. Wiremold, which is based in West Hartford, Conn., is expected to have revenue of $460 million this year.

title: MEDIQ WEIGHS FUTURE OF ITS LIFE-SUPPORT SYSTEMS UNIT
description: Mediq Inc., a medical-equipment rental company, hired Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities yesterday to explore alternatives for its critical-care and life support systems unit and said it would cut 126 more jobs there because expenses grew faster than sales. The company said Donaldson, Lufkin would help Mediq/PRN explore ways to raise money. Generally in such situations, the choices include selling the unit. In March, the company eliminated 124 jobs at Mediq/PRN, which will have 1,200 employees after the job cuts. Mediq is a closely held company based in Pennsauken, N.J.

description: REISMAN-Philip. 7/18/04-6/17/92. You and no other. -LKR

description: Hugo Boss, the fashion designer, is finally opening a flagship store in Manhattan, among some of the most expensive shopping real estate in the country.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: GOODYEAR TIRE AND RUBBER CO., Akron, Ohio, named John Polhemus, head of the Latin American region, as president at its North American tire business. He succeeds William Sharp, who is retiring. Mr. Polhemus is succeeded by Chris Clark.

title: S.E.C. Workers Vote for Union
description: Employees of the Securities and Exchange Commission voted last week by more than two to one for union representation.

title: Bar Needs Raising on the Bottom Line
description: Page 84 of the 87-page blue-ribbon panel's report on baseball economics is the one that probably raises the most eyebrows. It lists each club's profit or loss over a five-year period, 1995 to 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, IRA I.
description: SCHREIBER-Ira I. The staff of the Kings County District Attorney's Office mourns with deep sorrow the untimely passing of Ira I. Schreiber, former Assistant District Attorney and brother of Deputy District Attorney Barry Schreiber. He was a dedicated public servant, serving the people of both Brooklyn and Queens. His grace, style, compassion, dignity and zest for life were an inspiration to all who knew him. His friends and colleagues send their heartfelt condolences to his parents, Alexander and Charlotte, Barry and Helana and the entire Schreiber family. He will be truly missed. Services Wednesday, July 19th, 11:30 AM, Boulevard-Riverside Park West Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. Charles J. Hynes, District Attorney and the Staff of the Kings County District Attorney's Office

title: Old Mall Rat T-Shirts Lead Hip New Lives
description: Courtney Love's band mates in Hole were probably the first to revive them, in long ago 1998. The fashion tyro Jeremy Scott is rarely seen without one, chosen from his extensive collection. Lara Flynn Boyle, the actress, sported a sequined version to the Golden Globe Awards. And the alternative rocker Perry Farrell, the model Shalom Harlow and the designer Stella McCartney are devotees of a fashion trend that originates in the least fashionable arena you can imagine. ''Arena'' is intended literally here. What these people are wearing generally started as souvenirs from that dubious rock genre: the big-hair, heavy metal band.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil fell after OPEC told its members to be prepared to increase output by 500,000 barrels a day to curb high prices. In New York, crude oil for August delivery fell 57 cents, to $30.83 a barrel.

description: White House Plans a Bill On Cyberspace Surveillance

title: VITAL SIGNS: OUTCOMES; A Lens, Some Sleep and Better Vision
description: By wearing contact lenses when their eyes are shut at night, mildly nearsighted people may be able to improve their vision enough to do without glasses or contacts, according to the July issue of Optometry and Vision Science.

title: Ruling in California Favors the Medicinal Use of Marijuana
description: Seriously ill patients with no alternative but marijuana to alleviate their conditions will now be able to obtain the drug legally from a group in Oakland, Calif., a federal judge ruled today.

title: Unbiased Accounting
description: Arthur Levitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, would not appear to be asking for very much. He wants independent audits of corporate financial statements to be just that, independent. Yet his seemingly innocuous proposals aimed at guaranteeing independence are drawing heavy resistance from the accounting profession and, because the industry is rich and powerful, from Capitol Hill. Ordinary investors should pull for Mr. Levitt to win this struggle because the rules he has proposed are calibrated to protect their financial interests.

title: People
description: * Dennis Eastham, president and chief operating officer at Brann Worldwide, Deerfield, Ill., part of Snyder Communications, was named chief executive, succeeding Chris Gater, who continues as chairman.

description: EIDINGER-Mildred, on July 16th. Devoted wife of the late Abe. Beloved mother of Karen Sue Eidinger of Potomac, MD., and Mark Neil Eidinger of Belle Harbor, NY. Dear sister of Lillian Markowitz of Brooklyn, NY, sister-in-law of Bea Adams of New York, NY. Service Wednesday, 11:30 AM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY (near Ave. V).

description: An article on Sunday about the fatal shooting of a nightclub owner in Manhattan gave an erroneous identification from the Police Department in some copies for the place where it occurred. The club was Dae Tong Ryung, in the basement of 6 East 32nd Street. (Club Nix, on the third floor of the same building, was not involved.)

title: NEWS SUMMARY

title: On Tap or Bottled, Pursuing Purer Water
description: Americans have long felt safe drinking their water out of the tap, and with good reason. For the most part, public water supplies and even well water throughout the country are highly unlikely to make anyone acutely ill.

title: Corzine Files to Sell $41 Million of His Goldman Sachs Stock
description: Jon S. Corzine, who spent a record $36.7 million to win the Democratic primary for United States Senate, filed yesterday to sell $41 million worth of stock in Goldman, Sachs & Company, which he once headed.

title: VITAL SIGNS: AT RISK; Teeth-Cleaning Guideline Often Ignored
description: Too few patients who need protective doses of antibiotics before dental cleaning are getting it, and too many patients who do not need the medicine are, according to a study published this month in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Giuliani Biographer as Driven as His Subject
description: THERE was a time when the mayor and the biographer were on good terms -- when the biographer is Wayne Barrett, investigative reporter for The Village Voice, heaven forbid anyone call them ''cozy.''

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; RENAULT TO RETURN TO MEXICO
description: The French carmaker Renault will begin production of its Scenic minivan at a Nissan Motor Company plant in Cuernavaca, a city close to Mexico City, by year-end, after a 14-year absence from the Mexican market. Veronica Diez, a spokeswoman for Renault Mexico, said the company would manufacture the Clio compact car at Nissan's plants in Aguascalientes beginning in 2001. Renault, which pulled out of Mexico in 1986 because of financial problems, bought 37 percent of Nissan in March 1999 and the two carmakers formed a global alliance that includes sharing vehicle production lines. Dan Fineren

title: Separating Research From News
description: The news seemed breathtaking. An Alzheimer's vaccine that had previously worked in mice now seemed safe in patients. Many newspapers ran enthusiastic articles; some even put the news on their front pages, signaling that it was among the most important events of the day. Radio and television programs were even more upbeat, hinting strongly that help was on the way for the four million Americans with Alzheimer's.

title: Ex-Doctor Pleads Not Guilty In Murder and Fraud Case
description: Wearing a blue V-neck prison shirt that resembled the hospital scrubs he once wore to work, a former doctor pleaded not guilty today to federal charges that he killed three patients in a Long Island hospital in 1993.

description: ROSEN-Michael. July 18, 1980. A special man, lovingly remembered always. Your Family

title: So, How About Those Viruses?
description: What kind of news are people really interested in? The National Science Foundation, always trying to reassure itself about the public's enthusiasm for taxing itself to support scientific research, has commissioned biennial surveys since 1979. Intended to gauge the level of public interest in science, with other issues thrown in as benchmarks, the surveys show some interesting patterns.

title: Mexico's One-Way Remedy
description: President-elect Vicente Fox of Mexico has wasted no time initiating a much-needed dialogue over U.S.-Mexican immigration issues. More than seven million Mexican immigrants now live in the United States, a number equal to 7 percent of Mexico's current population. And we get an additional 130,000 legal Mexican immigrants and 150,000 illegal ones annually. What Mr. Fox wants to do, however, is radical.

title: Water Remedies
description: To the Editor:

title: Britons Revamp American TV; Exporting 'Millionaire' and 'Survivor' Was a Hard Sell With Crosscultural Allies and a Detour to Sweden
description: One is a game show, the other a pseudo survival test on a desert island, but in terms of impact on American culture, ABC's ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' and CBS's ''Survivor'' qualify as another British invasion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASHAM, CHRISTIE RINEHART
description: BASHAM-Christie Rinehart. 68, of Washington, D.C. and Friendship, Maine, on Sunday morning, July 16 in her Washington home. Greatly beloved sister of Jonathan Rinehart, aunt of Annabelle and Clem and loved by many devoted friends, she was a distinguished and highly respected contributor to the development of network television news and a pioneer of opportunity for women in the field. Services will be held on Wednesday, at 2:00 PM at the Navy Chapel on Nebraska Ave. in Washington. Memorial contributions may be made to the Wildlife Conservation Society at the Bronx Zoo in NYC.

title: Foreign Affairs; Lebanon: Soul on Ice
description: Visiting Beirut for the first time in 16 years, I was asked by Lebanese friends what my impression was. Two things stand out -- one new and exciting, the other new and troubling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, GEORGE R.
description: WAGNER-George R. Of Rye, NY, died July 11, after a long illness. He was 83 years old. Following distinguished service in the U.S. Army during World War II, Mr. Wagner rejoined the ship brokerage firm of Charles R. Weber in 1946. Over the course of 40 years at the firm Mr. Wagner became a ''dean of the ship brokerage community'' in the words of one of his colleagues. In 1970 he became principal owner and president of the firm & served in that capacity until his retirement in 1986. He is survived by his wife of fifty-five years, Alice, & their three children, Robert, Kathryn and Richard, as well as three grandchildren. A private service will be held. Memorial donations may be made to the Joslin Diabetes Center, 1 Joslin Place, Boston, Massachusetts 02215, Attn: Development Office.

title: Knicks' Frustration With Weis Is Growing
description: He has been criticized for everything from his wind to his lack of toughness, and knowledgeable basketball people question whether the 7-foot-2-inch Frederic Weis will ever be good enough to move into the rotation of a National Basketball Association team.

title: It's going to prove more than a little difficult to escape from ABC's campaign for its fall lineup.
description: ABC will begin a campaign for its fall lineup that seems intent on all but stalking viewers, forcing them to be aware of ABC shows in almost every waking moment of their lives -- when they withdraw cash from an A.T.M., shop in the supermarket or use the urinal at the local bar and grill.

title: The Pride of New York
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The yen dropped after the Bank of Japan left interest rates unchanged, saying the economy might not be ready for higher borrowing costs. In New York, the dollar settled at 108.12 yen, up from 107.87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDNER, GEORGE
description: LINDNER-George, former Army Lt. Col. of Whitestone, New York. October 10, 1916-July 12, 2000 at the age of 83. Husband of the late Lillian Ruth Lindner. Beloved father of Barbara Winslow and Arthur Lindner. Brother of Beatrice Schecter and the late Abraham Lindner. Beloved grandfather, great-grandfather and uncle. In W.W. II, a Major in the US Army Signal Corps, he was in charge of setting up radar defenses in China, then under Japanese bombardment. A graduate of Pratt Institute, he was retired Dept. Engr. of the Board of Water Supply of the City of NY-involved in the design and construction of NYC water tunnel #

title: Accusations Against Day-Trading Concerns
description: The day-trading firms All-Tech Direct and Stock USA were accused today of supervisory failures, including what regulators called All-Tech's widespread use of misleading advertising.

title: Ex-Court Clerk Admits Stealing Malcolm X Diary
description: Three days into his trial on charges of grand larceny, a former court clerk pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing the personal diary of Malcolm X from a safe containing evidence in Manhattan State Supreme Court, where he worked.

title: A Frayed Tapestry
description: To the Editor:

title: Planned Merger Would Create One of Biggest U.S. Law Firms
description: Hoping to increase their presence on both coasts and overseas, two large United States law firms -- one in California and one in New York -- announced plans to merge yesterday.

title: President Turns From Peace Talks to a Problem Closer to Home
description: It was a quiet Sunday morning in the middle of the Middle East summit talks when President Clinton picked up the telephone at Camp David and tried to defuse a conflict closer to home.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on July 10 about Bill Bolster, the president of CNBC, misstated his role in the expansion of local morning news programming in New York City. What he started in 1992 was the first weekend morning program, not the first morning program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERSON, CHARLOTTE
description: BERSON-Charlotte. July 17, 2000. Age 83. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence. A very special mother to Bert, Judy, Eleanor (Lester), Marilyn (Barry) and the late Roz. Adored grandmother of Ilene, Gabrielle, Jennifer, Jonathan, Joanna, Stephanie, Amanda, David, Danny, Alana and Lee. Great grandmother of five. Devoted sister, aunt and friend. ''Granny'' to all. Service 10AM Wednesday, I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn.

title: Before Manila's Garbage Hill Collapsed: Living Off Scavenging
description: Maria Luz Ochondra ran for her life, pursued by an erupting volcano of garbage that roared like a wounded giant, heaved like a tidal wave, then burst into flames as it buried the shantytown where she lived, along with her little boys Raymond, Ruel and Ryan.

title: QUALCOMM PATENTS ARE UPHELD
description: Investors flocked to Qualcomm after Japan and Europe upheld three of the company's patents. Shares of Qualcomm, the digital wireless communications giant, rose $6.75, or 10.7 percent, to $69.813 on the Nasdaq stock market. The Japanese Patent Office backed up the Japanese version of the company's first code division multiple access, or CDMA, patent, originally filed in the United States in 1986. Also, two separate rulings by the European Patent Office upheld patents dealing with coverage and capacity technology to improve indoor reception and another for an audible feedback feature that lets users monitor fax transmissions. Six companies, including Nokia and Ericsson, challenged the CDMA patent in Japan in 1999.

title: Assad Looks at Syria's Economy in Inaugural Talk
description: In his inaugural speech as president of Syria, Bashar al-Assad focused today on repairing his country's ailing economy and gave no sign that he would be any more flexible than his late father in negotiating a peace deal with Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STEVEN LEWIS
description: GOLDBERG-Steven Lewis, M.D. The Faculty and Residents of The Department of Pathology at SUNY Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn, mourn the loss of our friend, colleague, and Faculty Member. An outstanding teacher and surgical pathologist, Dr. Goldberg's generosity, personal warmth, and willingness to share his knowledge, made every interaction with him a rewarding and stimulating one. He made an enormous contribution to our residency training program and to the pathology community at large. He will be deeply missed. We send our sincere condolences to his family, and to our colleagues at Staten Island University Hospital. Suzanne S. Mirra, M.D., Professor and Chair, Department of Pathology SUNY Downstate Medical Center, Brklyn

title: David Blechman, 76, Developed Twinlab With His Wife and Sons
description: David Blechman, a co-founder of the Twinlab Corporation, a nutritional supplement company that has grown with America's health consciousness over 30 years, died on July 7 at New York Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 76 and divided his time between Commack, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: U.S.O.C. Suppressed Doping Results, Lawsuit Charges
description: American athletes have won medals in the Olympics after testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs in Olympic qualification trials, a former senior official of the United States Olympic Committee said in a lawsuit against the committee filed today here in federal district court.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: MAIL-WELL SELLS JEN-COAT TO CRAVEY, GREEN & WAHLEN
description: Mail-Well Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell Jen-Coat, its coating and laminating unit, for about $100 million in cash. The buyers are Cravey Green & Wahlen, a private equity firm based in Atlanta, and Jen-Coat's management. The projected after-tax cash payment to Mail-Well of about $100 million will mainly be used reduce debt, Mail-Well said. Mail-Well is a printing company based in Englewood, Colo. It reported about $2 billion of revenue for the last 12 months. Its shares fell $1, to $7.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: The Mets Might Make A Deal
description: It has happened quickly for the Mets, and at a critical time. With losses in 9 of their last 13 games, the Mets trail the Atlanta Braves by five games in the National League East after last night's game.

title: Web Gambling Ban Falls Short in House
description: In a defeat for horse-racing interests and the casino industry, the House failed to pass a bill to ban most forms of gambling on the Internet, even though a majority of the members voted for it. Backers of the ban had wanted to speed its passage and presented it in a way that prohibited amendments but required a two-thirds majority for passage.

title: Big Tobacco, Duly Punished?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cone's Rough Season Gets Even Rougher
description: David Cone wanted the baseball last night even before the national anthem at Yankee Stadium. Cone's shoulders were hunched, and he looked as if he were walking uphill as he strolled to the mound and waved his glove toward Umpire Mark Hirschbeck. Hirschbeck did not respond and made Cone wait for the ball. The wait only delayed the start of another depressing night.

title: Shortchanging Foreign Aid
description: Although there are some positive elements in the foreign aid bill that the House passed last week, it is still seriously flawed and has rightly invited a veto threat from President Clinton. The basic problem is that the overall allocation is far too low to meet American foreign policy objectives. Both the House bill and the Senate version that passed in June are nearly $2 billion below the White House request for fiscal 2001.

title: HARLAND, CHECK PRINTER, TO BUY SOFTWARE MAKER
description: The John H. Harland Company, the second-largest printer of checks in the United States, agreed yesterday to acquire Concentrex Inc. for about $140 million, including debt. Concentrex Inc., based in Portland, Ore., makes automation software for the lending and customer service operations of about 5,000 banks and provides small businesses with online banking software. Harland, based in Decatur, Ga., also produces software for direct marketing and loan compliance companies. Harland said it was offering a price of $7 a share in cash. Shares of Harland fell 6.25 cents, to $14.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, while shares of Concentrex were up 70 percent, or $2.8125, to $6.8125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Same Chicken in Every Plot? 2 Accused of Reselling Poultry

title: APEX OIL RAISES ITS BID FOR CROWN CENTRAL PETROLEUM

Apex, based in St. Louis, is a privately held distributor of oil and a major shareholder of Crown Central. It said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had raised its cash offer on Friday in a meeting with a Crown Central board member, Michael Dacey. The board of Crown Central, based in Baltimore, has accepted an offer for $9.50 a share from Rosemore Inc., a company headed by the son of Crown Central's chairman and chief executive, Henry Rosenberg Jr. The Apex bid would value all of Crown Central's 10.1 million outstanding Class A and Class B shares at $105.7 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELANY, WILLETTA S.
description: DELANY-Willetta S. Age 93 on July 13, 2000. Beloved wife of her late husband, Judge Hubert T. Delany. Dear and cherished mother of Professor Madelon Delany Stent and Dr. Harry M. Delany. Sister of Ernest Smith of Yonkers, NY. She will be sorely missed by a host of nieces, nephews, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and other relatives and friends. Hers was a life of courage and commitment to the thousands of black and Puerto Rican children in need of adoption who in her own words ''were forced to spend their formative years in hospitals, shelters, institutions and boarding homes''. Willeta Delany was one of the earliest African-American women on the Board of Spence-Chapin Adoption Services. As President of ''Adopt-A-Child'', an interracial interface program of 14 public and private agencies which came together to find homes for Negro and Puerto Rican children of that day needing adoption, she played a vital role in organizing forums and interstate conferences to discuss the inequities and unique issues related to their adoption. She was active for many years with the Harlem YWCA and numerous civic organizations. Visitation will be Wednesday at Benta's Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Ave., between 1-8 PM. Funeral Services will be Thursday, July 20, 10 AM at St. Luke Episcopal Church, Convent Ave. at 141 St.

title: To Fight for Peace
description: The history of the Middle East is marked by bloody wars and breakthroughs for peace. But breakthroughs do not occur by chance. Rather, leaders who recognize the futility of war, leaders who have peered into the faces of victims who will not return, are prerequisites for peace. Intimate knowledge of the pain of war must also be coupled by the courage to conduct a process that will not always be accepted by everyone, or more accurately, will engender formidable controversy. Menachem Begin and Anwar Sadat were such leaders. And so was my husband, Yitzhak Rabin, may his memory be blessed.

title: TWO TOP EXECUTIVES QUIT DRKOOP.COM
description: Shares of Drkoop.com fell again yesterday, down 18 percent after it warned that its second-quarter losses would be more than Wall Street expected and that its chief operating officer and its chief financial officer had resigned. The company said it expected a net loss of $1.15 to $1.18 cents a diluted share for the quarter ended June 30, compared with a net loss of $1.28 in the same quarter last year. Analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial had been expecting the company to post a loss of 30 cents a share. Drkoop.com said revenue would be $2.5 million to $3 million, compared with $1 million last year. Dennis Upah, chief operating officer, and Susan Georgen-Saad, chief financial officer, would leave the company and serve as consultants. Shares of Drkoop.com, which once traded as high as $35, fell 31.25, to $1.28.

Although the price of aluminum dropped 9 percent in the second quarter from the first, Jacques Bougie, president of the Montreal-based Alcan, said the outlook for demand and prices ''remains encouraging.'' title: COMING SOON, THE WIRED ARENA
description: Buying the Dallas Mavericks may have been a fun way for Mark Cuban to spend some of the billion dollars he received after selling Broadcast.com to Yahoo, but the problem with athletes is they are so, well, analog. So leave it to Mr. Cuban find a way to make his new toy more high tech. He told a conference of Internet executives in Laguna Niguel, Calif., that he was going to put high-speed Internet jacks at each of the 20,000 seats of the team's new arena opening next year. Consumers will be able to plug in Palms or laptop computers to see statistics, player information, download a video of that amazing dunk, or play a video game on the jumbo screen during halftime against everyone else in the arena. And there's more. ''See a cute girl in the next section,'' Mr. Cuban said. ''Zap her an instant message, ''Hi. I'm Dave in row 37.'' Saul Hansell

description: As residents of Staten Island braced themselves yesterday for spraying with the pesticide Anvil in response to signs of West Nile virus there, Westchester County officials announced that they would also begin spraying the same chemical tomorrow.

McMoRan, based in New Orleans, said it would use the $66.5 million in proceeds to finance oil and gas exploration.

The original prognosis was for Hamilton to miss only a few weeks; instead he missed 13 games of the 1999 season. Then, he missed all of the team's spring minicamps this year. And yesterday, the Giants released Hamilton, saying they still did not believe his knee was sound.

title: Conventions Should Remember
description: One night at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago in 1996, I sat for a while with Michael Dukakis and George McGovern, both past presidential nominees of their party and mine. As we talked, high in the cheap seats opposite the platform, I asked them whether they had been introduced to the party faithful at the convention. Both shook their heads. No, they had not been introduced. And no, they weren't surprised to be unacknowledged. Chicago, they told me, was about Bill Clinton and Al Gore winning a second term and claiming the future. There was neither time nor sentiment about the past.

It shares the dry soil and hot sun with better-known herbs -- thyme, rosemary, sage, tarragon and oregano -- but lavender is the star, prized for its bouquet, a clean aroma at once floral and woodsy.

The price was not disclosed. International DiverseFoods, based in Nashville, has more than $100 million in annual sales. It distributes sauces, condiments and pancake mix to restaurants, food distributors and food processors. Heinz, which is based in Pittsburgh, said it wanted to expand its business of providing food to places outside of homes.

title: A Pro-Choice Chance for Mr. Bush
description: The conventional wisdom that the Republican ticket can never include a pro-choice vice-presidential candidate seems to be eroding. That is a good sign for the party's long-ignored moderate wing and for those who would like to see the Northeast play a stronger role in the G.O.P. The party's expected nominee, Gov. George W. Bush, ought to look closely at this chance to show that he has the spine to stand up to the intimidators from the religious right, a faction that exerted an outsized influence during his father's administration. By selecting a pro-choice running mate, Mr. Bush would also be pulling the party more into alignment with suburban moderates who in numerical terms are more important to the G.O.P. than the anti-abortion movement.

title: The Struggle Over Certified Teachers
description: New York State's education commissioner, Richard P. Mills, has issued a strongly worded order forbidding New York City to use uncertified teachers in low-performing schools beginning this fall. Some at the Board of Education have responded with skepticism, saying that the current teacher shortage will make it impossible to comply. But the commissioner has set the stage for a confrontation in court, saying that the State Board of Regents will no longer tolerate the city's habit of assigning the most experienced teachers to schools in middle-class neighborhoods while sending neophytes to impoverished schools where students desperately need skilled instruction. The commissioner has a valid point, and the city should promptly comply.

title: RISE IN IRISH INFLATION
description: The annual inflation rate for the Irish economy rose to 5.5 percent for the year ended June 30, an increase of 0.3 percent from May, according to figures published by the Central Statistics Office. While the increase was less than many analysts had feared, the Bank of Ireland forecast a rise to an annual rate of 6.2 percent in July. The Irish government has taken steps recently to hold down prices in the pub trade, health care and the housing markets, where inflationary pressures were greatest. This week, Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, above, instructed his cabinet members to ask industry leaders to avoid unnecessary price increases. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREIG, THEA DISPEKER
description: GREIG-Thea Dispeker. Born September 28, 1902 in Munich, Germany. Died on July 17,2000 after a long illness, at the age of almost 98, in her home in Manhattan. She grew up in a family of prominent lawyers, but soon music became the center of her personal and professional life. After her elevation to Musicologist, she worked in the late 20's until 1933 in Berlin at the Culture Ministry for Special School Music projects. With her family she emigrated in 1938 to New York, where she soon started to work for several artists' managements. In 1947 she founded her own: Thea Dispeker, Inc., one of the outstanding worldwide artists' representative agencies. For almost 50 years she ran her office and gave artistic and, more importantly, always great human support to every one of her artists. She was an exceptional personality in her business and enjoyed innumerable friendships all over the world. She leaves a niece, Fay Freed, and a nephew Stephen Schlesinger, and their families. Contributions in her memory should be made to The Thea Dispeker Voice Scholarship Fund of Mannes College of Music, 150 W. 85 St, New York, N.Y. 10024. A memorial will be held at Mannes College in September. Exact date to be announced.

title: Genes That Let Illness In
description: When a patient receives the diagnosis of cancer, a first question that springs to mind is: Why me? For those with a family history of the disease, like a woman whose mother had breast cancer or a man whose father had prostate cancer, the physician offers as a facile answer, ''heredity.'' The pernicious seeds of the tumor were presumed to be present in the blueprint of the person's DNA, drawn at conception and programmed to blossom decades later. For those with cancer in the lung or throat who smoked, the disease is readily ascribed to the carcinogens in cigarettes.

It's not for a lack of trying.

description: An Army investigation of events surrounding the murder of a gay private by a fellow soldier at a base in Kentucky has exonerated all officers of blame and has concluded that no climate of homophobia existed at the base, Pentagon officials said today.

description: The Coastcast Corporation, the No. 1 maker of stainless steel and titanium golf club heads, said yesterday that it had rejected several takeover offers as too low. Coastcast's shares fell 20 percent, sliding $3.75 each, to $14.25. The company did not identify the bidders. While improved conditions in the golf industry helped increase second-quarter Coastcast sales, revenue for the second half of 2000 will not be as strong as for the first half, said Hans Buehler, chief executive. The company said in May that it had hired Bear, Stearns & Company to advise it on strategic alternatives, including a possible sale of the company.

title: Introduction
description: Awhole fish is so much more dramatic and, in many cases, more flavorful than a fillet can be. But, unless you're a fisherman, the preparation of an imposing whole salmon or a red snapper is probably a relatively unfamiliar task and may well be an intimidating one, too. The irony is that, as scary as the prospect can seem, the process is relatively easy and involves a lot less fuss than you might imagine. Moreover, if ever there was a time of year to try poaching a whole fish (the subject for this lesson) or roasting one (next time) this is it. Served chilled or at room temperature it makes a wonderful warm-weather dish. Served hot it's great, too, of course -- any time of year.

title: Reality Intrudes, NBC Concedes
description: NBC's top entertainment executives offered some frank mea culpas in Pasadena, Calif., yesterday, confessing that they had misjudged the public interest in so-called reality shows and that NBC was now committed to finding a reality show of its own for next summer or sooner.

description: An hourglass sits on my desk. It symbolizes my extreme sensitivity to time. I like to pit myself against the clock to see how fast I can complete a task or project. I've been called a speed fiend. I own a Ferrari and a Porsche back in Geneva where the speed limits are higher.

Shares of TMP Worldwide fell $2.125 each, to $77.375, while shares of Affiliated Computer Services rose 43.75 cents, to $41.0625.

title: Reckonings; Delusions of Generosity
description: ''Mr. Clinton,'' declared the full-page ad in yesterday's New York Times, ''the American people would rather spend $40 billion to rescue Social Security than to rescue your legacy.'' The ad denounced the possibility that an agreement at Camp David might include substantial promises of aid to the Palestinians. Then it referred interested readers to the Web site of Americans for Responsible Foreign Spending, which -- like the ad itself -- gives absolutely no hint about who these ''Americans'' might be. There are no names of officers, no endorsements of the group by named individuals. Nothing in the ad or on the Web site refutes the hypothesis that the group is actually a front for Islamic militants, out to sabotage the negotiations.

title: CNH GLOBAL TO CLOSE PLANTS AND ELIMINATE 1,800 JOBS
description: CNH Global N.V., the world's second-largest maker of farm tractors and combines, said yesterday that it would close or sell seven plants in the United States and Germany, eliminating 1,800 jobs, or about 4.7 percent of its work force. Plants will be closed in Illinois, North Dakota and Wisconsin. The decision by the company, which was created last year through the acquisition of the Case Corporation by New Holland N.V., is part of plans announced in February to reduce its worldwide work force eventually by about 7,200 jobs to cut costs by $500 million a year. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: Court Strikes Down Rules For Phone Company Prices
description: A Federal appeals court handed local telephone companies a legal victory yesterday as it struck down pricing rules that Federal regulators had hoped would foster competition in local communications markets.

description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli has all but officially declared his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for governor, setting off a pitched battle with Mayor James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge, the party's nominee in 1997, for the support of officials across New Jersey.

title: Rating an Opera Festival, by Its Cachet and Its Travels
description: Europe's summer opera festivals are often judged by the cachet of those they attract, not only the artistic renown of the conductors, directors and performers but also the social standing of the audiences. But there is another less obvious gauge: which festivals stay alive during their long off-seasons by taking their productions to other cities, perhaps even to other festivals.

title: CHINA GROWTH SURPASSES 8%
description: China's economy grew at an annual rate of 8.2 percent in the first half of the year thanks to a multibillion-dollar government spending program that has halted a six-year slide in the country's economic growth rate. The economy grew 7.1 percent in 1999. But China's economy still has problems: foreign investment fell 7.5 percent from the corresponding period a year ago, meaning the government will have to keep spending its own money to drive growth. Government spending surged 12 percent in the latest six months. The two-year-old spending spree has opened a widening budget deficit. Craig Smith (NYT)

title: Colleges Seeing Shortage of Teachers for Teachers
description: When Dr. Alexandria Lawrence received her doctoral degree in May 1999 from Columbia University's Teachers College, she did not expect to end up as an assistant professor in Lehman College's education department.

title: NEXTEL LOSS NARROWS
description: Nextel Communications Inc., a nationwide wireless company controlled by the cellular pioneer Craig O. McCaw, said its second-quarter loss narrowed to $241 million from $268 million in the year-earlier quarter as it added a record number of customers. Sales rose 59 percent to $1.26 billion from $793 million a year earlier. The company, based in Reston, Va., said it added 677,000 digital-service customers in the quarter, including 560,600 in the United States. It had about 6.2 million worldwide at the end of the period. Bills for Nextel's United States customers average about $74, compared with $50 a month for the wireless industry.

title: PETROBRAS FACES FINES
description: Brazil's state-owned oil company, Petrobras, could be fined up to $84 million after an oil spill on Sunday polluted a river in the southern state of Parana. The 25,000-barrel spill came a week after the government had put about $5 billion of the company's voting shares up for sale to the Brazilian public. Investors have until the end of July to place their orders. The remaining shares will be sold to international investors. Last year, Petrobras was fined $29 million for a spill in Guanabara Bay in Rio de Janeiro. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Man Is Charged in Death Of Officer During Chase
description: A Staten Island laborer with a long record of arrests was charged with second-degree manslaughter yesterday for what the authorities said was his role in the death of Police Officer John M. Kelly, who died Monday after he crashed his patrol car during a high-speed chase.

title: VNU, A PUBLISHER, AGREES TO BUY A TRADE SHOW OPERATOR
description: The Dutch publisher VNU N.V. agreed yesterday to buy Miller Freeman USA, the second-largest trade show operator in the United States, for $650 million in cash and stock. The seller is the British media company United News and Media, which said it considered Miller Freeman USA a noncore business. Miller Freeman USA is part of United News's Miller Freeman subsidiary, the world's largest trade show operator. Miller Freeman USA has 800 employees and is expected to have $220 million in revenue this year. VNU also runs trade shows and publishes specialty magazines, including Billboard, AdWeek and Hollywood Reporter.

title: CARREFOUR SELLS 150 ARCADES
description: Europe's largest food retailer, Carrefour of France, said it would sell 150 shopping arcades to Fonciere Klepierre for about $1.4 billion. Fonciere Klepierre is a real estate unit of the French banking concern BNP-Paribas. Carrefour, which retains the property housing of its supermarkets and superstores, said the proceeds from the sale of the retail space, which is in France, Spain, Portugal, Greece and the Czech Republic, would be used to pay down debt.

title: Nothing Left But Its Accent
description: SORREL is that rare vegetable that becomes a sauce as it cooks, adding a creamy texture and lemony flavor to any dish. And so it could not be simpler as an unusual partner for braised chicken. Add it to the pan toward the end of cooking and it virtually disintegrates into a tangy liquid.

title: A Moment to Rethink Hate Crimes Legislation
description: HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON went to New York Presbyterian Hospital in Washington Heights yesterday morning to talk about health care. The room was packed with hospital workers, including doctors. Some of them had to be Jewish. This is New York City, after all. Yet Mrs. Clinton managed to rein in the darker side of her soul. She got through the morning without once walking up to any of those Jews and unleashing an anti-Semitic rant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUILICO, LOUIS
description: QUILICO-Louis. We note with great sadness the death of Louis Quilico, a colleague and performer with Opera Orchestra of New York. A good friend of Maestro Queler's since the day she played for his lessons with Martial Singher at the Mannes School, Mr. Quilico went on to sing the title role of Rossini's ''William Tell,'' Opera Orchestra's first performance at Carnegie Hall in 1972. After his big aria, an enthusiastic audience member shouted, ''Quilico sei un leone.'' Mr. Quilico sang in two other OONY productions together with Montserrat Caballe, Donizetti's ''Parisina d'Este'' and ''Gemma di Vergy,'' both of which were recorded by CBS. The world has lost a great Verdi baritone. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to his family and especially to his son, Gino, who also sang with the Company. Eve Queler and Opera Orchestra of New York

title: A Gallery In Harlem Beats the Odds; Out of the Mainstream, A Contemporary Art Space Continues to Surprise
description: In the fall of 1998 Christian Haye, a New York poet and art critic, opened a gallery of contemporary art in Manhattan. He called it the Project and presented an impressive lineup of artists from the Americas, Europe, Africa and Asia, many of them making local solo gallery debuts. Among them was Paul Pfeiffer, who went on to become a star of this year's Whitney Biennial and the recipient of that museum's first $100,000 Bucksbaum Award, currently the world's largest award for a visual artist.

title: MERIDIAN MAY BUY BACK STOCK FROM ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL
description: The Meridian Resource Corporation, an oil and natural-gas exploration company, said yesterday that it might buy back preferred and common stock from the Royal Dutch/Shell Group for $114 million to reduce its shares outstanding. Meridian bought an option to buy back all its preferred shares, valued at $135 million and convertible into 12.8 million common shares and 6 million additional common shares. Shell, the world's second-largest publicly traded oil company, obtained the securities in 1998 when it sold oil fields in Louisiana to Meridian. Houston-based Meridian is paying Shell a million shares, valued at $5.1 million, for the option.

title: Leaving Environmental Law Alone
description: Today is the final day for public comment on a proposed rule change in the Clean Water Act that would allow the environmentally destructive practice called mountaintop-removal mining, common in the coal-bearing regions of the Southeast, to continue unimpeded. In mountaintop-removal mining, the soil and rock above a coal seam are dumped into hollows and streambeds.

title: Putting a New Italian Spot to the Ninth Avenue Test
description: NEW YORK has so many Italian restaurants that anybody hoping to open another should have to take an entrance exam, as if applying to colleges. The test would consist of one simple question: What will your restaurant offer that all those others do not?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Campaign Briefing column yesterday about a USA Today/ CNN Gallup poll on the presidential race misstated the results in some copies. In a two-way competition, Gov. George W. Bush led Vice President Al Gore 48 percent to 46 percent. (The figures 45 percent and 43 percent were their showings in a four-way competition that included Ralph Nader and Pat Buchanan.)

title: Powerfully Persuasive
description: To the Editor:

title: Lemon Olive Oil Dressing
description: You'll notice in the preparation of this dressing that it is similar to the vinaigrettes we prepared in the previous lesson , but it has a higher proportion of oil.We do not add the herbs at the lemon juice stage because the acid in the lemon juice will tend to burn them. They are added only after the olive oil is in the mixture.

title: Russia and China Unite in Criticism of U.S. Antimissile Plan
description: The presidents of China and Russia denounced the United States's proposed missile defense program in a joint statement today and vowed to strengthen a strategic partnership between their nations.

title: Top Picks Give Jets A Reason To Sack
description: Long before Al Groh was an apple-cheeked assistant coach at West Point, there were a pair of Heisman Trophy winners at Army known as Mr. Inside and Mr. Outside. They were, respectively, the running backs Doc Blanchard and Glenn Davis.

title: Mattioli and Pocono Are Survivors
description: Finally, Doc Mattioli could do nothing but cry. There had been another late night at his northeast Philadelphia dentist's office, followed by a hurried trip to a Lions Club meeting, too much dinner too fast, late-night emergency work on two patients' wisdom teeth, then the ceremonial opening of another fresh carton of Parliaments to chase the anxiety.

title: Advertising as Farce Alongside the Tour de France
description: Christophe Benoit is spending three weeks in July traveling around France on a four-wheel motorcycle inside a huge pot of a pork-flavored pate. Mohamet, who declines to give any last name, is making the same journey inside a can of butane gas. Philippe Chapuis is going sometimes on roller skates, sometimes in the back of a car in the white doughboy garb of Bibendum, the Michelin man.

title: Man Frisked by Whitman Awaits Appeal in Unrelated Drug Case
description: Before a photograph of a man being frisked by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was released last week, the State Supreme Court had already agreed to hear the man's appeal in an unrelated drug case, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: Paying Is Half the Fun
description: To the Editor:

title: Estrada Vows to Crush Remnants of Muslim Force on Mindanao
description: MANILA  President Joseph Estrada vowed Tuesday to crush what the Philippine armed forces command here views as the scattered remnants of a rebel force in the southern island of Mindanao.

title: You Call Them Sundaes?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. OFFERS AFRICA $1 BILLION A YEAR FOR FIGHTING AIDS
description: The United States plans to offer sub-Saharan African nations $1 billion in loans annually to finance the purchase of American AIDS drugs and medical services, a program that greatly increases the money available to combat the disease in a region that has become its epicenter.

title: Our Towns; Inching Along In a Slow Lane To Frustration
description: IN the stampede of rages, it's not as menacing as road rage or as maniacal as kiddie sports rage, and it's more down to earth than air rage. But toll rage is real.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

Sports of The Times; Old Tom's Enduring Pro Shop
description: STADIUMS and arenas come and go every few decades. Yankee Stadium, Fenway Park and Wrigley Field have endured longer than most. Lambeau Field is a relative youngster. Madison Square Garden's address has never been the same for too long. But golf's spiritual stage, the Old Course at St. Andrews, is not that much different than when God designed it.

title: British Authorities May Get Wide Power to Decode E-Mail
description: As the Clinton administration formally enters the debate about law enforcement surveillance in cyberspace, the British government is about to enact a law that would give the authorities here broad powers to intercept and decode e-mail messages and other communications between companies, organizations and individuals.

title: Making Conventions Unconventional
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: One More Leaked Memo on Party's Woes Embarrasses Blair
description: For the second time this week, a damaging memo from Prime Minister Tony Blair's inner circle has been leaked to major newspapers and caused acute embarrassment to his government as it struggles to keep its once-high popular appeal from continuing its swoon.

title: Booting Up Overseas?Look Before You Plug
description: Booting Up Overseas? Look Before You Plug

title: Charges Offset Strong Results At Ford Motor
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that brisk sales of luxury cars and sport utility vehicles and growing profit from auto loans and leases lifted its operating earnings in the second-quarter. But a pair of one-time charges announced last week caused the automaker to post its first quarterly loss since the fourth quarter of 1992.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- No public events.

title: Cadets Become Black Knights
description: They've been called the Cadets as far back as anyone can remember, but from now on Army's sports teams will be known as the Black Knights. Officially, that is.

title: CONEXANT TO ACQUIRE 2 CONCERNS FOR ABOUT $285 MILLION
description: Conexant Systems Inc., a maker of computer chips for communications equipment, agreed yesterday to buy two closely held companies for about $285 million to add products that speed data on optical networks. Conexant will buy NetPlane Systems of Dedham, Mass., for 2.7 million shares, valued at $132 million at yesterday's closing price. Some of the price is contingent on future performance. Conexant will buy Novanet Semiconductor, based in Ra'anana, Israel, for 2.4 million shares, valued at $117.5 million. Conexant shares fell $2.50, to $48.9375.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Bank One Loss Fails to Scare Investors Away
description: A quarterly loss of more than $1 billion was not enough to scare investors away from the stock of the Bank One Corporation yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; It's Time for Captain McEnroe
description: WITH daylong sun to stoke his fire and a coastal breeze to cool his jets, John McEnroe's decision to deploy himself as a Davis Cup doubles player remains a point in progress, a mental rally in which his brazen side is attempting to reach the net for a winning volley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, MILDRED F.
description: KAPLAN-Mildred F. Wife of the late William. Mother of Patricia and Stuart. Grandmother of five. Great-grandmother of four and friend to many. Interment private.

title: GOLF; Open May Be Showdown For Sorenstam and Webb
description: Golf rivalries are an elusive commodity, often more hype than reality. But the women's game has a real one, and when the 55th United States Women's Open begins Thursday, much of the focus will be on Annika Sorenstam and Karrie Webb.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: COCA-COLA, Atlanta, named Alex Cummings, region manager for Nigeria, president at its Northern Africa group. He succeeds Brendan Harris, who was named president at its Italy-Alpine group this year.

title: Nine Top Riders Pass Surprise Blood Tests
description: At no time was the D-word uttered during the Tour de France today. On a day when Lance Armstrong maintained his lead while two other well-known racers dropped out of the event, a handful of the 20 teams were tested for drugs. Armstrong and the race's eight other top riders passed the surprise blood test taken in their hotel rooms.

title: GERMAN-CANADIAN TRUCK DEAL
description: The German auto giant DaimlerChrysler A.G. agreed to buy Western Star Trucks Holdings of Kelowna, British Columbia, for 670 million Canadian dollars ($456 million) and merge it into its Freightliner truck division. Western Star, which makes heavy trucks in Kelowna and transit buses in Mississauga, Ontario, and Oriskany, N.Y., had sales last year of $885 million, less than one-tenth of those of Freightliner. Timothy Pritchard

title: FOUNDRY SLUMPS ON SALES NEWS
description: Foundry Networks' shares slid $26, to $98.125, yesterday after the maker of computer-networking equipment reported second-quarter sales that rose at a slower pace than those of its rivals. Foundry, whose equipment routes and speeds up data networks run by Internet service providers and corporations, said sales rose 27 percent to $88.8 million, from $70 million in the first quarter. Some investors were disappointed with the increase, which trailed the gains reported by Juniper Networks and Alteon WebSystems, Alex Henderson, an analyst for Salomon Smith Barney, said.

title: David Merrick Recalled as a Singular Voice
description: On the stage where 48 feet tapped away in "42nd Street" and where Carol Channing descended the stairs in a glittering gown in "Hello, Dolly!" friends and associates of David Merrick paid tribute yesterday to the maverick showman who produced those shows and 93 others over a 50- year career. Mr. Merrick died on April 26 at 88.

title: TOUGH CONDITIONS FOR CLOTHIER
description: Britain's largest clothing retailer, Marks & Spencer P.L.C., said its sales in the 15-week period that ended last Saturday were little changed from a year earlier. Speaking at the annual meeting of shareholders, its chairman, Luc Vandevelde, said, ''The market will remain tough for the foreseeable future, and we have undertaken significant change within our organization to refocus on our customers and compete effectively in this environment.''

title: REMOVAL OF JUDGE SOUGHT
description: Defense lawyers asked an appellate court yesterday to remove the judge hearing a federal lawsuit against Eric Corley. Mr. Corley, publisher of the magazine 2600, was sued by eight movie studios after he posted a program on the 2600 Web site that could unscramble the encryption on DVD movie discs. The defense argues that Judge Lewis A. Kaplan has a conflict of interest because he once worked at a New York law firm that represented Warner Brothers, a plaintiff in the current case, on antitrust matters related to DVD's. Judge Kaplan had previously denied a motion by the lawyers asking him to recuse himself. Amy Harmon

description: A Sporting Chance

title: For Fans of the Big Screen (the Really Big Screen)
description: The speaker hanging on a pole has been replaced by an FM broadcast for the dialogue and soundtrack, but drive-in movie theaters still have huge screens, concession stands and children in pajamas in the back of the car.

title: Near Miss on Broadway
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by The Associated Press on Tuesday about the dismissal of a racial discrimination lawsuit filed against a Denny's restaurant near Syracuse, N.Y., misstated the number of plaintiffs and omitted some ethnic groups represented. Ten people sued, not nine. Besides one Chinese-American and three African-Americans, they included one Filipino-American, four Japanese-Americans and one white person.

title: What Happens After the Whistle Blows?
description: The whistle-blower finds comfort in her office these days, surrounded by books about Renaissance drama, her speciality. So long as Linda Bensel-Meyers can keep her mind in the past, she can forget about the lawsuits against her, the damage to her marriage, the anger of University of Tennessee officials and coaches, the threats by local fans who curse her as a traitor to the savage orange.
