description: To the Editor:

title: At St. Andrews, There's Woods and There's Everyone Else
description: Either Tiger Woods will win the career Grand Slam, or someone else will have a grand weekend.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil dropped on expectations that Saudi Arabia will lift output even though OPEC members say current supply is adequate. In New York, crude oil for August delivery fell 52 cents, to $31.42 a barrel.

title: Gore, Switching Campaign Plans, Heads for Texas to Focus on the State's Budget Woes
description: Seizing what he views as a golden chance to pierce the heart of Gov. George W. Bush's campaign, Vice President Al Gore said today that he would ride into Governor Bush's backyard in Texas on Thursday to highlight the state's budget woes.

title: Is the Customer Ever Right?
description: BRENDA WINEGARDNER has been having a nightmare that is increasingly familiar to most consumers. In it she wanders between reality and virtual reality, from voice mail to e-mail to customer service counter, trying to get her computer fixed. But it's not a dream.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATT, WILLIAM A.
description: MATT-William A. On July 8, 2000 at the age of 79. Beloved husband of Joan for 50 years, devoted father of Phil and wife Beth. Dear brother of Benjamin and of sister Teresa. Loving grandfather to Theo and Carolyn. Bill was the highly regarded proprietor, with his brother Benjamin, of D. Matt, Inc., master picture framers to major museums, designers, artist and collectors worldwide from their shop at 223 East 80th Street in New York. The business was begun by their father David Matt in 1920, and closed in 1989 when Bill and Ben retired. A largely selftaught cellist, Bill had an encyclopedic knowledge of classical music, and played with several amateur symphony orchestras on Long Island. His enthusiasm and wonderful, engaging personality made him a popular figure at the several private golf clubs in the New York area to which he belonged over the years. He obtained his baccalaureate degree from Brooklyn College, and his MFA from NYU. Bill will be missed by his family and many friends and business associates. Donations may be made to The Jewish Family Service of Rochester, NY.

title: North Korea Reported Open To Halting Missile Program
description: In an announcement intended to remove the prime rationale for an American missile defense plan, Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, said today that North Korea had offered to abandon its missile program if other nations would provide it with rockets to launch satellites into space.

title: Sites and Events This Week
description: Sites and Events This Week

title: Boy, 10, Critically Hurt in Five-Story Fall
description: A 10-year-old boy was critically injured yesterday when he fell five stories from a roof in Washington Heights while chasing a ball, the police said. The boy, Luis Santiago, underwent surgery at Columbia-Presbyterian Center last night, said Lt. Dennis Cirillo, a police spokesman.

title: Motorola Seeks Ideas For Global Strategy
description: Motorola is asking the three agencies that handle its advertising duties, with combined billings estimated at $150 million, for ideas that could be used for a global brand strategy.

title: Software Can Turn Notes Into Audio or Video Bookmarks
description: Note takers, take note: Software is now available for those who are tired of having to fast-forward through audio or video recordings in hope of finding that one significant moment they jotted down in their digital notepads.

title: Army Clears Officers in Death of Gay G.I.
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  An Army investigation of events surrounding the murder of a gay private by a fellow soldier at a base in Kentucky has exonerated all officers of blame and has concluded that no climate of homophobia existed at the base, Pentagon officials said today.

title: A Sudden Turnabout
description: Before the Camp David summit meeting, pronounced dead, was buried, it came back to life in a startling turnabout suggesting that the contemplation of failure raised prospects too grim for the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to accept.

description: To the Editor:

title: Empire Building on Gastronomic Memories
description: ALAIN DUCASSE is speaking through a translator -- his girlfriend, actually -- but you really don't need a lot of language to see that this is a subject of which he has grown fatigue.

title: Deutsche Telekom Bids for Wireless Company
description: In a move that advances the United States ambitions of Deutsche Telekom, Europe's largest telephone company, it has offered to acquire the VoiceStream Wireless Corporation for about $53 billion in cash and stock, according to a person close to the bid.

title: U.S. Loses Second Attempt to Seize Painting
description: A painting by Egon Schiele that was taken from its owner by the Nazis during World War II cannot be seized by the federal government as stolen property, a federal judge in Manhattan ruled this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSCHNER, HARVEY, MD.
description: KUSCHNER-Harvey, MD. Formerly of Baldwin, NY, died July 19, 2000, in Arlington, VA. Survived by His Wife Sue Marsh Kuschner; His Sons, Stuart, John, Robert and Ware; Five Grandchildren; and His Brother, Marvin Kuschner, MD. Services Private.

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS TO CUT 10 PERCENT OF WORK FORCE
description: Consolidated Papers Inc., a producer of printing paper, said yesterday that it planned to reduce its work force by about 10 percent, or about 700 employees, in a move to cut costs. Consolidated Papers, based in Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., said the layoffs had already begun. The cuts, which will affect hourly and salaried workers, are part of a two-year $100 million cost-reduction plan initiated in 1999 to make the company more competitive. Shares of Consolidated Papers, which had $1.8 billion in sales last year, were unchanged yesterday at $39.9375 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about work on the Staples Center in Los Angeles in preparation for the Democratic National Convention misstated the timing of the work shown. It was July 11, not this Tuesday.

title: Holocaust Group to Step Up Pressure on Austria for Reparations
description: An international organization that seeks compensation for Holocaust survivors said yesterday that it planned to pressure the Austrian government to acknowledge complicity during the Nazi regime and to improve reparations to Jews.

title: AOL Earnings More Than Double, Despite Weakness in Ad Revenue
A Tito Grandchild Battles Nationalism's Excesses
description: Svetlana Broz stands out in the lobby of Sarajevo's hotel, an elegant blond woman out of place amid the men in suits, members of the hard-line nationalist Croatian party who are here for a conference.

title: Ford, Sued in Air-Bag Case, Says Victim Was Strangled
description: The Ford Motor Company, accused by a New Jersey man of killing his wife when her air bag inflated in a crash three years ago, is defending itself by asserting that the woman was actually strangled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIGUORI, ROBERT T.
description: LIGUORI-Robert T. 67, of Ossining. Died after a long battle with leukemia on July 17, 2000. Visitation Thurs and Fri 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 at Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, Mt. Kisco, NY. Funeral Mass 10 AM Sat. at St. John and Mary Church, Chappaqua. Interment St. Raymonds Cemetery, Bronx.

title: Adkins's Tough Choice: Speed or Stable Moods
description: It could not have been a more perfect moment for Derrick Adkins to win an Olympic gold medal in 1996 in the 400-meter hurdles. He won in Atlanta, where he lived and had attended Georgia Tech. His parents and friends were in the stands and as he carried an American flag on a jubilant victory lap around the Olympic Stadium, cameras flashed like thousands of blinding fireflies.

title: Harris Assists in Courtship of Larkin
description: The utility man Lenny Harris is leading off and starting at third base for the Mets, and he may soon take on another role: recruiter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSENG, ANTHONY T.
description: TSENG-Anthony T. On the morning of July 19,2000, peacefully at home. Internationally recognized management consultant, President of Physical Distribution Dynamics, member of the Manhattan Rotary Club. Beloved husband of Sophia. Loving father of Robert, Roberta and Vivien. All of us who knew him was touched by his concern for others and his joy of life. He will be greatly missed. Family will receive friends Friday, July 21st from 10am to 12:30pm at Ballard Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains, NY. Interment to follow at Kensico Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ERNEST, JR.
description: KATZ-Ernest, Jr. Beloved husband of Liane. Father of Ernest, Michael, Larry and Jeffrey. Grandfather of James, Brad, Ainsley and Sarah. Forever in our hearts.

description: Final Notes From Streisand

title: Sounds of Almost Wordless Songs
description: The beauty of a diverse and multifaceted festival is that little connections pop up, too modest to qualify as full-blown themes and surely not planned as such. Two such connections arose on Tuesday evening, when Lincoln Center Festival 2000 introduced its three-part Meredith Monk retrospective, Voice Travel, featuring Ms. Monk as composer and conductor, with ''Solo Landscapes,'' a program at the New York Society for Ethical Culture.

title: The Slur Against Hillary Clinton
description: By now, most people have heard the sensational charge that Hillary Clinton let loose an anti-Semitic slur against her husband's Congressional campaign manager 26 years ago. The accusation appears in ''State of a Union,'' a book that purports to examine the Clintons' marriage and is yet another in a long line of books that delight in and profit from bashing the first couple.

title: Pregnant on Death Row
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dog's Life: Hidden Fences With a Bite Help Keep Rover Home
description: NO amount of scolding, begging or foot-stomping will keep most dogs home in their yards and out of the streets. So some frazzled owners try to turn their neighborhood travelers into docile homebodies with radio-controlled fences.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Open Tip From a Sage: It Won't Be Tiger in the Winner's Circle
description: HE is 68 now. He doesn't caddie anymore, but every day shortly before noon he is in the Dunvegan Hotel bar, perched next to the door. With a mischievous smile, he said, ''I try to get here eight days a week,'' and behind him was a small brass plate attesting to his stature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEBERDEN, DORIS ROSE
description: HEBERDEN-Doris Rose. Age 92, of Mt. Holly, NJ. Formerly of Lowell, NY. On July 13, 2000. Survived by sister Nancy Smith of Mt. Holly; niece Sheila Avruch of Fairfax, VA; nephew Richard Smith of Springfield Twp., NJ. Funeral services Friday, 12 noon at Perinchief Chapels, 438 High St., Mt. Holly, NJ. Interment in Lakeview Memorial Park will be private. Calling 11am-12pm at the funeral home.

title: ALLIANCE & LEICESTER PLANS CUTS
description: The No. 6 British mortgage lender, Alliance & Leicester P.L.C., said it planned to cut costs and to concentrate on customer groups, rather than products, as it tries to reverse a 38 percent stock decline this year. The company changed management lines so it is now targeting sales toward three groups: personal customers, smaller businesses and larger companies. Alliance & Leicester said it would outsource some transaction processing and give managers incentives to reduce costs. The lender also said it wanted to overhaul its computer systems.

title: Hey, Walkman: Time to Face the Music on a Chip
description: LESS than two years ago, the first handheld MP3 player was introduced, at a time when downloadable digital music was still a mystery to just about anyone who wasn't a college student or a basement-bound techie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARLIN, LOUIS
description: SARLIN-Louis. Died on July 19, 2000 at 88 years of age. A native New Yorker and graduate of Stuyvesant High School, Cooper Union, The Bank Street College of Education and recipient of a Doctorate in Education from New York University, he was a gifted and influential teacher. As a young artist, he worked with the Federal Arts Project at the New York World's Fair. A beloved teacher at the Little Red School House in Manhattan, he specialized in eliciting creative writing from young people, and inspired the careers of many writers, a number of whom have dedicated books to him. As a respected professor of education at Baruch College of the City University of New York, he influenced a generation of teachers. He was married for 49 years to the late Lilian Bass Sarlin, and spent 13 years with his companion, the late Frances Hill. He will be deeply missed by his sons and daughtersin-law, David and Istar Schwager Sarlin, Bob and Peggy Sarlin, and Don and Ruth Sarlin. Perhaps his greatest legacies of all are his bright and compassionate grandchildren; Kay, Alex, Asher, Benjamin, Jesse and Jonathan Sarlin. Services at 11:30AM on Sunday, July 23rd at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: BAUSCH & LOMB IN TALKS TO BUY PHARMACEUTICAL COMPANY
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. the second-largest maker of contact lenses, said yesterday that it was in discussions to buy an unidentified ophthalmic pharmaceuticals company outside the United States. Two months ago, the company failed in a bid to buy Wesley Jessen VisionCare Inc. The company's shares fell 22 percent, falling $17.0625 each, to $61.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. The plunge was linked to the company's disclosure that its second-quarter sales were little changed because of slowing demand for its lens-care products.

title: Loyalty Prized Above All In Heart of Bush Country
description: Walk through Gov. George W. Bush's campaign headquarters here and you encounter a remarkable sight: virtually the same lineup of senior advisers that he had a year ago and, at the uppermost echelon of the operation, an inner circle of trusted friends that is wholly intact from the days when Mr. Bush won his first race for Texas governor in 1994.

title: In America; The Crime Fighter
description: An important but frequently overlooked factor in the nationwide decline in crime over the past few years has been the corresponding decline in the unemployment rate.

title: Ten Iffy People, One Ugly House
description: MARIO BUATTA was watching the new CBS show ''Big Brother'' the other night, and he did not like what he saw. As a decorator to New York's moneyed classes, Mr. Buatta is not usually squeamish about Darwinian social experiments. But even so, he found himself discomfited by the show, which throws 10 strangers into a house for three months and records their every move. Mr. Buatta, like many viewers, was troubled by the show's intrusive peeping. But more than that, he had decor issues. ''It suffers from a lack of chintz,'' he said, getting right down to cases. ''It's like watching animals in an experiment. Chintz would help.''

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Decline in Computer Shipments Lifts Trade Gap to $31 Billion
description: The United States trade deficit widened slightly more than expected in May, to a record $31.04 billion, as both exports and imports declined for the second straight month, new figures show.

title: Profit at Tyco International Increases 42%
description: EXETER, N.H., July 19 (Bloomberg News)  Tyco International, the world's biggest maker of electronic connectors, said today that its third-quarter profit rose 42 percent, led by sales at its electronics and telecommunications units.

title: KPN TO SELL SHARES
description: The largest Dutch phone company, Royal KPN N.V., said it planned to sell shares and might sell convertible bonds in the fourth quarter to raise money to invest in new wireless licenses and expansion. The Dutch government will sell part of its 43 percent stake in KPN at that time, KPN said. The company did not specify how much money it planned to raise. It will give more details on Aug. 30, when it publishes its first-half earnings.

title: Booting Up Overseas? Look Before You Plug In
description: Q. I'm moving to Europe and wish to take my computer with me. Will I have a problem with the computer because of the different electrical standards overseas?

title: Havas Unit Named For Volvo in Europe
description: The Volvo Car Corporation in Goteborg, Sweden, owned by the Ford Motor Company, said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer/Euro RSCG in New York by naming the agency as the lead shop to handle its strategic and creative advertising for Pan-European markets. Billings were estimated at $50 million.

title: Clinton Leaves Peace Talks; Arafat and Barak Stay
description: In a dramatic turnaround, President Clinton announced early this morning that the Middle East peace talks that were described by his spokesman as having failed to reach an agreement, would remain intact, and that the Israeli and Palestinian leaders would stay at Camp David to continue meeting with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright.

title: Alice Lord Landon, 98, Diver And Pioneer in Water Sports
description: Alice Lord Landon, a pioneer in women's swimming and diving who was a presence on the American Olympic scene for eight decades, died last Thursday at her home in Ormond Beach, Fla. She was 98.

title: More Extensive Test Needed For Colon Cancer, Studies Say
description: The test most commonly recommended to screen healthy adults for colorectal cancer misses too many precancerous growths and should be replaced by a more extensive procedure that examines the entire colon, doctors are reporting today.

title: Japan and U.S. Reach Trade Pact on Telecommunications
description: With its ownership of nearly all telephone lines that go into Japan's homes and businesses, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone has long enjoyed a virtual monopoly in this country. Today, however, a United States-Japanese trade agreement was reached that would likely make telecommunications services in Japan far more affordable, competitive and diverse.

title: Economic Scene; The Internet is lowering the cost of advertising and searching for jobs.
description: IF you considered changing jobs lately, chances are good that you consulted the Internet to explore job opportunities.

title: The Emergence of Fledgling D.J. Bands
description: It must get lonely for a disc jockeys, barricaded behind turntables and mixers with nothing but the history of recorded music for company. That must be why they keep seeking other options.

title: William Corson, 74, Marine And Critic of U.S. on Vietnam
description: William R. Corson, a retired Marine lieutenant colonel who was an expert on revolution and counterinsurgency and was nearly court-martialed for writing a book venting his disillusionment over the Vietnam War, died on Monday at a hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 74 and lived in Potomac, Md.

title: High-Tech Executives Urge Action on World's Digital Divide
description: A group of high-technology executives urged the wealthiest nations today to take action to erase a growing digital divide resulting from the economic chasm separating the developed and developing worlds.

title: British Columbia Decides To Restrict Some Video Games
description: A week after it restricted sales of the Soldier of Fortune computer game to adults, the Canadian province of British Columbia announced that it will review and rate all electronic games.

title: Paul Young, 53, of Mike and the Mechanics
description: Paul Young, a British rock singer who sang with the group Mike and the Mechanics, died on Saturday at his home in Altrincham, near Manchester, England. He was 53.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLERMAN, RUTH (NEE SHARE)
description: KLERMAN-Ruth (nee Share). Beloved wife of the late Sol. Loving mother of Gary and the late Gail. Dearest sister of Harold and wife Sally. Devoted aunt of Vicki Share Fleiss, and Robert Share. Cherished partner of Joe Brinen. Donations may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

title: Clinton the Broker Puts the Other Summit on Hold
description: Bill Clinton today was a president caught between two summit meetings, one in Camp David dealing with the oldest and thorniest problems in diplomacy, the other in Japan approaching the newest and vaguest issues of global inequity.

title: Deal for Devils Is Delayed but Alive

title: AT HOME WITH/ARIANNA HUFFINGTON; Honing the Politics of Surprise
description: POLITICAL insiders may debate the motivations behind the latest evolutionary twist in the remarkable life of Arianna Huffington, but one thing is certain: Ms. Huffington understands the element of surprise. She stood by her desk in her elegant, sun-dappled home office on a perfect Southern California morning early this week, talking about her latest and indisputably biggest adventure. Up on a landing a library wall panel swung open, revealing a hidden room. A young woman popped out, and then a second entered from another part of the house, climbed the spiral staircase and disappeared behind the bookcase.

title: The Welch Mystique
description: When a magazine like Fortune or Forbes conducts a survey to determine who is the most admired businessman of the year, decade or even the century, Jack Welch of General Electric invariably finishes at or near the top of the list. In his 20 years as G.E.'s chief executive officer, Mr. Welch has generated enormous wealth not only for the company's stockholders but for hundreds of companies that do business with G.E. But is Mr. Welch worth $7.1 million as a writer? That is what Time Warner Trade Publishing has agreed to advance him for a book about his career, his business philosophy and whatever else Mr. Welch chooses to write about when he retires next year. It is the biggest advance in publishing history, exceeding the up-front money paid to Colin Powell and the pope.

With children now in school and her husband busy baking, she has opened a shop to sell her furniture and planters, which are bronze and coated in a dark brown finish. ''Bronze is a sensual material,'' Ms. Poilane said. She describes her pieces as heavy in weight but light in line and proportion. The side table below ($17,000) is five feet long and weighs 330 pounds. The shallow bowl ($2,900) is 15 inches across and 22 pounds. The company said the acquisition would help Motorola strengthen its digital satellite business by expanding its product lines and customer base, particularly in the international marketplace. Zenith Network Systems is a leading supplier of DVB satellite receivers to customers in Hong Kong, India, New Zealand, Brazil, and Mexico, as well as other markets in Asia and Latin America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISPEKER, THEA
description: DISPEKER-Thea. The Board of Directors, Artists and Staff of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center note with great sadness the passing of Thea Dispeker, one of the most distinguished vocal artist managers of the twentieth century. A friend of the Chamber Music Society since its inception in 1969, she brought countless singers to the stage of Alice Tully Hall and to the attention of the Chamber Music Society's audiences. The impact of her work is immense; her legacy is immeasurable. Thea's rare gift for recognizing extraordinary talent and her tireless enthusiasm for developing young singers will be greatly missed. title: SHILOH CONSIDERS SALE OF THREE PLANTS IN THE MIDWEST
description: Shiloh Industries, a supplier of automobile parts and processed steel to automakers, said yesterday that it was considering selling or consolidating three plants to focus on more profitable operations. The company said it expected earnings of only 25 cents a share in the quarter ending on July 31, below an average estimate of 37 cents by three analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. Shiloh said it was considering options for its Canton Tool and Die and Utica Tool and Die plants in Michigan, and the Valley City Steel plant in Ohio. The company also agreed to buy the closely held A. G. Simpson Inc. for $47.9 million to gain a Dickson, Tenn., plant that makes automotive stampings and assemblies. Shiloh shares fell $1.125 each, to $8.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASWELL, W. CAMERON
description: CASWELL-W. Cameron. Died July 18, 2000 following a stroke which occurred Friday evening July 14. A resident of Darien, Ct. and Sea Island, Ga., he was an early partner at McKinsey & Co, subsequently joining Dover Corp as SVP of corporate development for 17 years, and concluded his career as the SVP of North American Acquisitions at Axel Johnson Group. He also served as the Chairman of the Board of Finance for the Town of Darien. Caswell was a member of The Yale Club of New York City, Wee Burn Country Club of Darien, Sea Island Club of Ga, the Congregational Church of Darien and of Canaan Valley, Ct. and of the St. Simons Presbyterian Church of Sea Island. A resident of Darien since 1953, he was born August 14, 1916 in Boston. Raised in Brockton, Ma., Caswell graduated from New Hampton School and Yale University, Class of 1939, for which he served as Class Secretary for most of the 20th century. Following Yale, Caswell joined the 101st Cavalary as WWII began in what was this Country's last equine brigade. Following the War he remained active with the the 101st and served as an officer of New York's Squadron A. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, AdaChase Holcombe, originally of Farmington and Hartford, Ct., his four sons, W. Cameron Caswell, Jr. of San Carlos, Ca., John Marshall Holcombe Caswell of Salisbury, Md, Chase Caswell of Banner Elk, NC, and George Calvin Caswell II of New Haven, Ct, and five grandchildren. The Reverand Emily Holcombe will conduct a private service at the Caswell's Darien home on July 20. The family requests that memoriams be sent to the Post 53 Emergency Service of Darien.

title: ONE BID FOR PHILIPPINE BANK
description: Three months after the Philippine government, eager to refute allegations of cronyism, pushed Lucio Tan to sell his stake in Philippine National Bank, Mr. Tan appears likely to take control of the lender. After an auction for the government's 30 percent stake in the bank, officials said they would probably approve Mr. Tan's bid, as he was the only participant in its second attempt to sell the shares in six weeks. Mr. Tan, who controls one of the largest conglomerates in the Philippines, offered to pay 6.27 billion pesos ($140 million) -- or 61 percent above the current market value -- but will not have to come up with most of the money until July 2002.

Lazio, the Republican candidate for Senate in New York, took up the cause of the manufactured-housing industry in 1998, introducing a bill based on a proposal that its lobbyists provided that would change regulations, industry executives say. He has chaperoned the bill and subsequent versions, sometimes over the objections of groups worried that the changes would weaken consumer protections, and the House and Senate have approved versions of the measure.

title: F.B.I. Seizes Computer Drive in a China Nuclear Inquiry
description: Federal Bureau of Investigation agents seized a computer hard drive from the home of a former Energy Department intelligence official in an effort to determine whether he had disclosed classified information about the government's investigation into whether China had stolen United States nuclear secrets, officials here said today.

title: Ethnic Shots? So What Else Is New?
description: THE temptation, watching the dust-up over an anti-Semitic slur that Hillary Rodham Clinton might or might not have hurled at a Baptist campaign worker 26 years ago in Arkansas (as reported in a book by a former reporter for The National Enquirer) is to say hey, what took so long?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, FREDERICK HOWELL
description: LEWIS-Frederick Howell. On behalf of The Fresh Air Fund, we note with great sadness the death of Frederick Howell Lewis, Life Director of The Fund. For 25 years, Bud was The Fund's Executive Director until his retirement in 1971. His leadership of our Friendly Town program enable thousands of young New Yorkers to visit volunteer host families in 13 states and Canada. In addition, Bud helped establish The Fund's 3000-acre Sharpe Reservation in upstate New York, the site of five Fresh Air camps. Countless numbers of inner-city children have benefited from his vision, generosity and compassion. We offer his family our heartfelt condolences. Mrs. Donald Newhouse Chairman of the Board Jenny Morgenthau Executive Director The Fresh Air Fund

title: 13 Corporate Rounds, Mano a Mano
description: Children's swimming lessons always used to have a buddy system, a pairing of two novices, so each would always know where the other was in the water and come to the rescue in case of trouble. But in ''Never Swim Alone,'' a peculiar theater piece by a Canadian playwright, Daniel Mac Ivor, at the SoHo Playhouse, the two designated buddies try to drown each other as they dog paddle through the troubled waters of life.

title: A Bottleneck Between the Digital Player and the Ear: The PC
description: MAKERS of personal digital audio players readily concede that despite almost two years of gradual improvements, using the palm-size and smaller devices is still not nearly as simple as slapping a CD in a conventional CD player and pressing the Play button.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIU, KANG, JEN. PH.D.
description: LIU-Kang-Jen. Ph.D., of Pittstown, NJ, President of Union Resources and Technology, Inc., and President of United Innotek, Inc., on Monday, July 17, 2000. Loving husband of Linda and father of Larry and the late Lisa, devoted youngest brother of his brothers and sister, adoring uncle to his nieces and nephews. Funeral at Cusick Funeral Home, 80 Mountain Avenue, Somerville, NJ, at 10 A.M. Saturday July 22, 2000, with burial to follow at Kensico Cemetery, 273 Lakeview Avenue, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Kang-Jen Liu Memorial Fund, 4 Camilla Dr, Pittstown, NJ 08867.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I saw them jumping out the windows in 1992, looking for the next campaign. And that influenced me. Yeah, that influenced me. I worry that some may be wanting to be involved in my campaign to enhance their consulting businesses.''

title: Bill Would Lift Ban on Import of U.S. Drugs
description: The Senate today overwhelming voted to permit pharmacies and wholesale distributors of prescription drugs to import and sell American-made medicine that originally had been exported to foreign countries.

title: Olbermann Shifts Role at Fox Cable
description: Keith Olbermann is leaving Fox Sports Net's National Sports Report to anchor a Sunday night program of news, interviews and commentary for that sports cable network, industry executives said.

title: Land O Lakes in Deal With Farmland
description: ARDEN HILLS, Minn., July 19 (Reuters)  Land O'Lakes and Farmland Industries said today that they had agreed to merge their animal feed production units into a joint venture that will be the largest feed producer in North America.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Aetna Agrees to Sell Units To ING for $5 Billion in Cash

title: O. J. Simpson Is to Be Online, and on TV
description: O. J. Simpson will appear on a series of television programs next week, including ''Today'' on NBC and ''The View'' on ABC, to publicize a Web site on which he will take questions from the public.

title: China to Let Banks Set Own Interest Rates Over Next 3 Years
description: China's central bank chief said today that the country's banks would be empowered to set their own lending and savings deposit rates within the next three years, an important step toward opening the tightly controlled Chinese financial markets.

title: 'It's Time to Go, but Still We Sit, Lingering'
description: Everything came together in ''. . . Still We Sit,'' a little jewel of a new duet presented by Maxine Steinman on Friday night at Joyce SoHo. Choreographed and performed by Raymundo Costa and Ms. Steinman, a former soloist with Eleo Pomare, the piece was inspired by a poem by John Fuller, quoted in the program. ''It's time to go, but still we sit, lingering in our summer,'' the opening lines read. And the fragile looking Ms. Steinman and solid Mr. Costa, a handsomely complementary pair dressed in white brocade robes and pants, perfectly evoked that mystical sense of timelessness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIEN, JOHN MARSHALL
description: RUBIEN-John Marshall. On July 18, 2000. Dear father of David and Andrew Rubien and step-father of Andi, Peter and Samantha Billow. Cherished grandfather of Rowan and Tamar. Beloved brother of Roberta Wedeen and brother-inlaw to Richard. Loving uncle to Timothy. ''Golden lads and lasses must like chimney sweepers turn to dust''. Services Friday, July 21, 10 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAISER, CHARLES JR. (CHUCK)
description: KAISER-Charles Jr. (Chuck). Loving husband of Dale. Devoted and adoring son of Claudia Frenkel. Father of Kenneth and Andrew Kaiser and Chuck Hutchinson. A very special grandfather to Adam, Steven, Jordan, Margot, Katherine and Grant. His love grew unboundless as more children came into his family. Funeral service will be held at 11:30am on Friday, July 21 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made M.D. Anderson Cancer Research, PO Box 297153, Houston, Texas 77297 in memory of Chuck Kaiser

title: Prosecution Wraps Up Its Case Against I.B.F.
description: Asserting that boxing is a ''dying sport that has lost the trust of people,'' the prosecution in the federal racketeering and bribery trial of the president and founder of the International Boxing Federation today laid much of the blame for that state of affairs on a scheme of bribes in exchange for favorable rankings and matchups that the defendants are accused of running.

title: ALLOY ONLINE ACQUIRES DIRECT MARKETER FOR $53 MILLION
description: Alloy Online Inc., a leading Internet direct marketer that targets so-called Generation Y youth, said yesterday that it had acquired CCS Inc. for about $43 million in stock in an effort to expand its business. Under the agreement, Alloy will also assume $10 million of the debt of the privately held CCS, another leading direct marketer, based in San Luis Obispo, Calif. CCS focuses on Generation Y boys, who are generally between the ages of 10 and 24. Alloy, based in Manhattan, reported revenue of $36.3 million for the last 12 months. Shares of the company slipped 6.25 cents, to $12.9375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Lazio, a Leader on Housing Legislation, Collects Donations From the Housing Industry
description: More than 20 percent of the new single-family homes sold annually in the United States are made in factories and installed on site, ready-to-live-in realty born of assembly-line technology. This industry is governed by an obscure series of regulations that its lobbyists have long pressed Congress to overhaul. Now, the industry is close to its goal, in large part because of Representative Rick A. Lazio.

title: Attacks by Colombian Rebels Appear a Response to U.S. Plan
description: Apparently responding to the passage of $1.3 billion in aid for Colombia's armed forces in the United States Congress, the country's largest guerrilla group has made a series of audacious attacks on isolated towns and police headquarters in recent weeks, killing more than 200 people.

title: Allegations Against Rabbi Leave Many Feeling Betrayed by Orthodox Union
description: Allegations that an Orthodox rabbi in Paramus abused teenagers in his charge during a 30-year period continue to ripple through New Jersey Orthodox Jewish communities, with many people increasingly angry over allegations that his supervisors may have tried to cover up his abuses.

title: William Whyte, a Gang Sociologist, Dies at 86
description: William F. Whyte, a sociologist with a passion for reform who wrote ''Street Corner Society,'' the trailblazing 1943 study of Italian-American gangs in the North End of Boston, died last Sunday in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 86.

title: ADVANCE IN SUPERCONDUCTING
description: The American Superconductor Corporation and Rockwell Automation, a division of Rockwell International, said yesterday that they had passed a key milestone in government-sponsored research to develop high-temperature superconducting motors by successfully operating the world's first 1,000-horsepower unit using such technology. American Superconductor said it was on track to test a 5,000-horsepower unit -- the prototype for its first commercial product -- next spring. Harnessing superconductivity, a rare phenomenon in which electrical current flows without resistance, could save billions of dollars annually in energy costs for utilities and users of large motors. Barnaby J. Feder

title: APPROVAL FOR MOTOROLA EXPANSION
description: China's government has approved a $1.9 billion investment plan by Motorola Inc. to expand its semiconductor-making operations in the northeastern city of Tianjin. Motorola has already invested about $1 billion there in a silicon wafer fabrication plant and in factories that assemble chips as well as make the pagers and mobile telephones that use them. Craig S. Smith

title: For Fans of the Big Screen (the Really Big Screen)
description: For Fans of the Big Screen (the Really Big Screen)

title: When Intentions Fall Between the Lines
description: ARE the billboards in New York advertising the Grand Can, a swivel-top, orange-pop-colored trash can, a boast about the sophistication of its design or of its buyers?

title: MICROSOFT ADDING LONG-DISTANCE
description: Microsoft plans to announce today the availability of a technology that will allow consumers to make free long-distance phone calls in the United States and Canada while using the company's MSN instant messaging service on the Internet. The technology, which uses a network belonging to Net2Phone, a leading Internet telephony company, is expected to increase the popularity of making phone calls over the Web. Simon Romero

title: Taking the Bumps Out of International Online Shopping
Messiaen's Nature Worship Calls on Bird Song and Faith
description: ''Des Canyons aux Etoiles . . .'' is Messiaen's specifically American piece. Its putative subject is Bryce Canyon in Utah, but this 12-part, richly populated instrumental work was commissioned to be played at Lincoln Center, surrounded by the skyscrapers he detested. Its first performance was in 1974, as a musical prelude to the Bicentennial. It was successfully resurrected a year ago and appeared again at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night, put on by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center before a large and enthusiastic audience.

title: Subs Deliver Like Heroes As the Mets Rally to Win
description: The Mets' bench is largely a collection of players who were never part of the team's original plans.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: A Spirit of the Midcentury
description: Editions Norma, a small French publishing house specializing in decorative arts, has brought out another beautiful book about a nearly forgotten interior designer or architect. The 320-page ''Maxime Old: Architecte-Decorateur'' is the coffee table book of the moment for design-conscious Parisians. Old was most prolific in the 1940's and 50's, best known for work like the 1938 dining room (with expandable table) above. He was a contemporary of Andre Arbus, Jacques Adnet and Jean Royere. A show and sale of 30 pieces of his furniture (from private collections, including his family's holdings) at the Yves Gastou Gallery on the Rue Bonaparte sold out in a flash. In New York, the book, in French only, is $150 at Archivia, 944 Madison Avenue (74th Street).

title: Tagliabue Won't Suspend Ray Lewis
description: Ray Lewis has suffered enough, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue of the National Football League said in a conference call yesterday in explaining why he did not suspend the All-Pro linebacker who pleaded guilty to obstructing justice in a murder case.

title: A Dance of Remorse and Regeneration
description: The Bolshoi Ballet has returned to New York after an absence of 10 years, the same but different. Except for Nina Ananiashvili, who may never have been better than she was in Vladimir Vasiliev's superbly danced new staging of ''Giselle'' on Tuesday night, the current principals are unfamiliar to local audiences.

title: Siren Call of the Wireless Net
description: ASKING whether you need wireless Internet service for your handheld computer is like asking about the sound of one hand clapping. Just trying it out and seeing whether you like it is more practical. But then, when it comes to shiny new gadgets, I've always followed the path of buy first, ask questions later.

title: Some Floors You Can Look Up To
description: IMITATION straw rugs for the kitchen and beautiful pebbles for the shower are just two new stylishly textured options that can perk up a floor. Even when materials are not natural, the effect always is.

title: Higher Fuel-Product Prices Barely Affecting Consumers
description: Facing higher fuel prices, motorists are guzzling less gas -- but only slightly less.

title: MEDIATION FOR CANADIAN PILOTS
description: At the urging of the federal Labor Minister, Claudette Bradshaw, Air Canada and the union representing its 2,200 pilots have agreed to nonbinding mediation that could lead to a new contract. They have also agreed there will be no strike or lockout as long as the talks continue. They are expected to last at least two weeks. Air Canada handles more than 80 percent of Canada's domestic air traffic. The pilots have been without a contract since April 1. Timothy Pritchard

title: A Suspect in a Nightclub Killing Is Seized on Arrival in San Jose
description: A man the police say killed the owner of a Korean nightclub in Manhattan early Saturday in an argument over a $980 bill has been arrested in California and was on his way back to New York last night, a law enforcement official said.

title: ING TO TENDER BAAN SHARES
description: The largest Dutch financial-services company, the ING Group, said it would offer its 5 percent stake in Baan N.V. to Invensys P.L.C., which is buying Baan, a Dutch software maker, for 858 million euros ($790 million). ING's agreement to sell its shares helps clear the way for the takeover. Baan shares were as much as 8 percent below the 2.85 euro-a-share offer this week on speculation that ING would not sell its shares.

title: I.B.M. Earnings Gain 12%, Despite a Retreat in Sales
description: Despite declining sales, I.B.M. managed to surprise Wall Street yesterday with earnings of $1.9 billion for the second quarter, up 12 percent from the year-earlier period.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Analyzing the Id Behind the Wheel
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Auto Insurance Ruling
description: An appeals court has ruled that the state's stricter auto insurance requirements introduced in February by the State Insurance Department can not be implemented until a court case challenging them is resolved.

title: First Lady's Aide Asked Help on Slur Claim
description: For the last several days, Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign staff and her surrogates have worked behind the scenes and in public to snuff out the controversy over an allegation that she made an anti-Semitic remark long ago, a charge she has denied.

title: Grist for TV: Family Grief Since Killings At Columbine
description: When the shooting began at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., on April 20 last year, Craig Scott escaped from the library and later said God had told him to lead other students to safety through a back door. After he was safe, he learned that his sister Rachel, at 17 a year older than he was, had been shot in the head; she had been the first to die.

title: Knuckling Down in the World of Marbles
description: MARVIN GEORGE doesn't play for keeps.

title: Citigroup and Chase Post Earnings That Exceed Expectations
description: Citigroup, the biggest financial services company, earned more than $3 billion for the second consecutive quarter, despite a sharp drop in the performance of its Salomon Smith Barney securities unit. At Chase Manhattan Bank, the No. 3 United States bank, the drag on earnings came from its investments in private companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, WILLIAM
description: MURPHY-William, of Silver Lake, Staten Island on July 18, 2000. Beloved son of Stephen Murphy and Edith D'Ambra. Maternal grandson of Margaret Baetz. Loving brother of Leah Murphy, Steven D'Ambra and the late Stephen Murphy. Fond uncle of Danielle and Steven Bozzo. Funeral from the Richmond Funeral Home, 2052 Richmond Rd at Midland Ave., Staten Island on Saturday at 10:30 AM. A mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at St. Christopher's R.C. Church at 11 AM. Cremation Rosehill Crematory. Friends will be received Thursday 7-9:30 PM and Friday 2-4 and 7-9:30 PM.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Editorial Notebook; A Quiet Man in a Noisy Trade
description: Senator Paul Coverdell of Georgia was a mild-mannered Republican seasoned in political obscurity. As minority leader of the Georgia State Senate in the 1970's, he was part of a legislative bloc so small and impotent that it was ignored, steamrolled and sometimes openly ridiculed by the Democrats who controlled the legislature as if by birthright. None of us covering the Georgia Capitol in those days would have picked Mr. Coverdell, who died Tuesday at age 61, as a future United States senator. Now, in retrospect, we can see him as part of the second of two transforming waves that swept Georgia politics in the last third of the 20th century.

title: A Theater All Too Near You
description: To the Editor:

title: LEUCADIA TERMINATES AGREEMENT FOR THE RELIANCE GROUP
description: Reliance Group Holdings Inc., the insurer controlled by the former corporate raider Saul P. Steinberg, said yesterday that the Leucadia National Corporation had ended its agreement to buy Reliance. Reliance said it was working with its financial advisers to develop a plan to restructure its debt. The company has $237.5 million in debt due in August and $290 million due in November, according to the ratings agencies Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP., Santa Clara, Calif., one of the biggest makers of cell-phone chips, said it had bought the closely held Vivid Semiconductor Inc., Chandler, Ariz., to help it develop products for flat-panel displays. Terms were not disclosed.

title: CNet Is Buying What Remains Of Ziff-Davis
description: CNet Networks said yesterday that it would acquire Ziff-Davis, a trailblazer in the technology magazine industry, and its Internet subsidiary, ZDNet, for $1.6 billion in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMES, DEBRA
description: JAMES-Debra. It is with the deepest sadness that we mourn loss of our beloved friend and valued colleague, Debra James. Debra served this University with dedication and distinction for 25 years, most recently as a Senior Vice President. She helped create and guide some of its most important enterprises. However, she will be best remembered for her constant efforts to create a sense of community at NYU and to provide it with a heart. She worked tirelessly to convey a sense of family and closeness among students, faculty and staff. She was a champion of our community service programs, binding this institution with its neighborhood and leading its efforts to help those in need. She helped create the vision of what this Univeristy could be. Her parting came far too soon; she will be sorely missed. L. Jay Oliva, President

title: Project Gives Small Nonprofit Groups a Big-Time Mapping Tool
description: WHEN Matthew Bregman, the Brooklyn Academy of Music's development director, initiated a marketing plan to spur neighborhood real estate development for use by the performing arts, he searched for a way to project accurate images of the borough's landmarks, potential sources of financing and residential areas lacking access to the arts. He found the solution in the New York Public Interest Research Group's computer mapping software.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSELL, RUTH
description: WASSELL-Ruth. Loving wife of the late Myron. Survived by daughters Emily Kuriloff and Elizabeth Wassell. Services Friday, 9:00 AM at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Avenue at 76 Street.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO SLIDES. The euro fell on reports showing a slump in German business sentiment and construction industry orders. In New York, the euro settled at 92.41 cents, down from 92.65 cents on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PADNICK, EVA
description: PADNICK-Eva. Devoted wife of Bernard. Beloved mother of Steven and Danny. Cherished grandmother of Jennifer, Andrew, Charles, Jessica, Rachel and Emilie. Services today, 12noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

description: To the Editor:

title: Out of the Asylum, Into the Rich Club
description: ''The In Crowd'' could best be described as some community theater mix of ''Rebecca'' and ''Caddyshack.'' Warner Brothers has asked that the press not reveal the ending of the film, but probably the only people who could be surprised at this movie will be those who wandered into the wrong multiplex theater by mistake.

title: A Tax Cut in Small Slices
description: In early January, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert told the Republican leadership to abandon its effort to pass a single, hugely expensive tax-cut package in the face of opposition from President Clinton. Instead, he ordered up a series of narrow tax measures that could rise or fall not on their price tags but on their political appeal.

title: Information by Design
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHTEL, SABINA
description: WACHTEL-Sabina. Beloved wife of the late Alfred, dear sister of Harry Gordon, of Atlanta, GA, and Ceilia Lavove, of Bethesda, MD, cherished sister-in-law, aunt, and cousin. Memorial service Sunday 3:30 P.M. ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY (near Ave. V).

title: Vuckovich's Ban Reduced to 2 Games
description: Major League Baseball reduced the three-game suspension against the Pittsburgh Pirates' pitching coach, Pete Vuckovich, to two games yesterday. The coach was suspended on July 6 for bumping Umpire John Hirschbeck two weeks earlier during a dispute over a balk called on Pittsburgh pitcher Bronson Arroyo in a game against the Mets.

title: Clinton Tells of His Choices for Vice President
description: President Clinton has told friends and associates that two of his favorite choices for Vice President Al Gore's running mate are former Senator George J. Mitchell and Senator Bob Graham, both of whom he considered picking eight years ago.

title: Clinton's No. 2 Choices
description: President Clinton has told friends that his favorite choices for Vice President Al Gore's running mate are former Senator George J. Mitchell and Senator Bob Graham, both of whom he once considered picking.

title: Company's Insurance Should Pay for Contraceptives, Suit Says
description: In a case that could have broad impact on health insurance coverage of contraceptives nationwide, Planned Parenthood yesterday filed a class-action lawsuit charging that a company whose insurance plan covers most prescription drugs but excludes contraceptives is illegally discriminating against its female employees.

title: Cuban Slugger Makes It to U.S. On Second Try
description: Andy Morales, a standout with the Cuban national baseball team, has succeeded in his second attempt to flee Cuba for the United States.

title: Two New Shops That Are Cluttered and Quirky, and Proud of It
description: Zen is out, personal is in. Or at least that is what two new Paris clothing shops, Eric Bergere and Antoine & Lili, are saying with their anything-but-minimalist interiors. For Mr. Bergere's shop, left, near the Tuileries and around the corner from Colette, he asked the interior designer India Mahdavi to help personalize the space with black lacquer shelves and drawers, bright red furnishings, a kitschy wallpaper-panel forest scene and, for a touch of the Gothic, an iron chandelier. ''I wanted to tell a story and not just display products,'' Mr. Bergere said. The shop is at 16, rue de la Sourdiere; (011) 33-1-47-03-33-19.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lulled by the Clack of the Wheels
description: From La Sensitive come silk sleeping-bag sheets inspired by those used in French overnight trains. They fold up into a pouch. Singles cost $45, doubles $85, in rose, rusty orange, tea green, aubergine, salmon, eau de nil and taupe. Think of them as sheets for people who are trekking the world in style, or keeping laundry light between two homes. Made in Vietnam and available at Roberta Freymann, No. 5F, 23 East 73rd Street, in New York; (212) 585-3767.
