description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, WALTER
description: JAFFE-Walter. On July 18, 2000. Beloved husband of Mildred. Loving father of Eleanor and Edward Rosenberg and Judith and Gary Zucker. Cherished grandfather of Jeffrey, Steven, Douglas, David, Peter and Jason. Great-grandfather of Kyle. Dear brother of Florence Yellin. Services Friday, 11AM at Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Avenue at 246 Street, Riverdale.

title: To the Summit, Step by Step: Why Clinton Took the Risk
description: The notion of holding Israeli-Palestinian summit talks at Camp David gathered steam within the White House after the failure of President Clinton's meeting with Hafez al-Assad, the late Syrian leader, in Geneva in March.

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC RESULTS
description: The Canadian transportation and natural resource conglomerate Canadian Pacific Ltd. doubled its second-quarter profit to 379 million Canadian dollars ($258 million), far above expectations, on an 8 percent increase in revenue to 2.96 billion Canadian dollars. Four of the Calgary company's five operating divisions had record returns. Timothy Pritchard

title: A 'Missed Putt' at the Table Cost French Players $37,540
description: Those who watch golf on television sometimes hear a commentator say, ''If he makes this putt, he will finish third, and it's worth $30,000 to him.'' An exact bridge parallel occurred on a Sunday in May at the Cavendish Pairs in Las Vegas, where the Calcutta pool totaled $1,140,500, to be distributed among the successful players and their backers.

title: Earnings at United and American Beat Expectations
description: Earnings at the nation's two largest airline companies, the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, and the AMR Corporation, owner of American Airlines, handily beat Wall Street expectations yesterday. But the good news was tempered by United's warning of weaker earnings in the current quarter, igniting a large sell-off of airline stocks, led by UAL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUSCHOTZ, MURRAY
description: NEUSCHOTZ-Murray. Age 83. On July 19, 2000 in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of Ruth for 57 years. Loving brother to Bernie. Devoted father to Frieda and Ivor.Cherished grandfather to Jessica, Matthew, Rachel, Sasha, Anouchka, Nilson and Emily. We will miss your quiet manner, your generous heart and your dry wit.

title: Literary Wizardry
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's just been accepted that this guy exists.''

title: DNA Innovation Lets Team Undermine the AIDS Virus
description: Biologists at the University of Texas have invented a novel and apparently far-reaching method of singling out precise regions of DNA. The method can be used both to disrupt particular genes and to add new genetic material at a specific site.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Il Covo dell'Est occupies its corner of the East Village like the neighborhood's favorite uncle. The local style is tough, aloof and highly sensitive to the smallest possible gradations of cool, which makes Il Covo dell'Est, its doors thrown open to the sidewalk, seem like the antidote to everything the East Village stands for.

title: Earnings at Gillette Were Up 2.1% in the Second Quarter
description: Gillette, the world's largest maker of razors, said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 2.1 percent on increased sales of its Mach 3 blades in the United States.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: If Only Her Husband Hadn't Made That Horrible Mistake
description: Before moving on to more stately affairs (''Forrest Gump'' and ''Contact''), Robert Zemeckis was accomplished at good old-fashioned unclean fun. So it should come as no surprise that he has directed the new thriller ''What Lies Beneath.'' At the start, he zaps us with quick, glib scares, just to show he still knows how, but his heart isn't in this kind of material anymore. His reflexes are a little slow.

title: Draft Worldwide Buys Stake in Capita
description: Draft Worldwide in Chicago, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, said yesterday that it had made another acquisition, buying a majority interest in Capita Technologies in Chicago, an e-business services company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: The Fed Chief's Treatment; Slower Growth, but Don't Rule Out Rate Increases
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that there was not yet enough evidence to conclude that the economy had slowed to a noninflationary pace, and he left the door open to further interest rate increases as soon as next month.

title: Clawing a Way To the Top
description: Now it can be told: Hugh Jackman used to walk around the house with steel blades protruding from his knuckles.

title: How Gross-Out Got That Way
description: They wouldn't deign to in a million years, but those who deplore the adolescent vulgarity in films like ''Scary Movie'' might want to sit in on a commentary track done for the recent DVD of ''Kentucky Fried Movie'' (1977) from Anchor Bay. The important thing (only thing) to keep in mind is that John Landis made the film, really nothing more than a string of gags, the same year he made ''National Lampoon's 'Animal House,' '' the gross-out classic usually cited as a harbinger of the current mess.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, KATE
description: RUBIN-Kate. Dear mother, you were a very special person in my life. The things you taught me I will cherish. I will always remember you with love. Jeanne

title: Urban Nocturne by Firelight
description: Last New Year's Eve the unexpected happened. Cities everywhere planned pyrotechnic and other elaborate public displays to celebrate the millennium individually, but what evolved was a confluence of ancient rituals linked across time zones as the new year repeatedly unfolded out of darkness on television screens around the world. From the first torches lighted on South Pacific islands to fire dances in the Judean Hills in Israel and flames on the Thames in London, a global community of viewers was mesmerized not by technological razzmatazz but by age-old ceremonies featuring the primal elements of fire and water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, ESTHER
description: HOFFMAN-Esther of Boca Raton, FL, on July 18, 2000. Beloved wife of David; Cherished mother of Lesley (Edward) Cowen and Nina (Edgar) Otto; Special aunt to Lynne (Steven) Koffler; Dear sister of Herman Smith; Adoring grandmother of six and great grandmother of five. Services today July 21, 2000 at GuttermanWarheit Memorial Chapel in Boca Raton, FL 800-992-9262.

title: Backstage Drama And Bolshoi Power
description: Sheer dance power is what the Bolshoi Ballet has brought back to New York. There was no better showcase than its exciting second program of the season, which introduced a phalanx and variety of dancers on a mixed bill that ranged from Marius Petipa to George Balanchine.

title: VIETNAM OPENS STOCK MARKET
description: Vietnam's first stock exchange officially opened yesterday in a move by the communist nation toward economic liberalization. Trading, which will take place three times a week, is expected to begin within 10 days, securities commission officials said. With only four companies licensed to list on the exchange, initial trading is expected to be light and will mostly be in bonds issued by the government and state-owned banks.

title: Q & A / Adolf Ogi : Switzerland in No Rush to Join the EU
description: With full United Nations membership on the horizon and a recent vote supporting economic alignment with the European Union, Switzerland seems ready to break with the neutrality of its past. In Bern, Adolf Ogi, the president and defense minister, discussed the new outlook with Robert Kroon of the International Herald Tribune.

title: How Can Musicians Protect Their Art?
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; Ahoy! Cars That Move on Surf or Turf
description: HAS your car left you up the creek without a paddle? If you had an Amphicar, you'd simply float back to shore. Or you could relax, catch some rays and have a cool drink after you drop the anchor. (What? Your car doesn't have an anchor?)

title: Metro Business; Designer Chosen for Project
description: A Miami firm, Arquitectonica, will design a $230 million residential and commercial project on 2.9 acres on Manhattan's Lower East Side in the Cooper Square area, city officials said yesterday.

title: Warnaco Says It Will Once Again Miss Earnings Projections
description: Every time it appears that the Warnaco Group, the maker of Calvin Klein Jeans and underwear, has hit bottom, another shoe drops.

title: Everett Needham Case, 99, Ex-President of Colgate U.
description: Everett Needham Case, a former president of Colgate University who was also the chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in the late 1960's, died on Tuesday in Waterville, N.Y. He was 99.

title: KOREAN JOBLESSNESS FALLS
description: As economic growth created more jobs in construction and other industries, South Korea's jobless rate in June fell to the lowest level since December of 1997, when the Asian economic crisis drove Korea into recession, the National Statistical Office said. The seasonally adjusted jobless rate fell to 3.8 percent last month from 3.9 percent in May, and the number of unemployed workers fell to 793,000, down 35,000. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: Beyond the City Limits: Art for the Summertime
description: THE fresh crop of shows in museums outside New York City this summer include several about artists prominent around the same time. ''Calder in Connecticut'' at the Wadsworth Athenaeum is a homegrown affair: it includes ''Very Flat Cat,'' which he made from an old oak post that he picked up on a visit to the town of Sherman, and ''Stegosaurus,'' his 40-ton stabile, which lives permanently at the museum.

title: Indoor-Outdoor Relations Along the Hudson Valley
description: For anyone venturing north of New York City with contemporary art in mind, two destinations are not to be missed this summer. Storm King Art Center in Mountainville, N.Y., just south of Newburgh, is presenting recent works by the English sculptor Andy Goldsworthy, and the Center for Curatorial Studies at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., has mounted a three-decade retrospective of the works of the Russian conceptualist Ilya Kabakov, including paintings, drawings and installations. You could take in both shows in a day if you set out early, but give yourself more time. One requires a lot of walking, the other a lot of reading; both are worth the effort.

title: When Disaster Strikes, He's a Lifesaver
description: THINK disasters. Think ''Ghostbusters.'' Put them together and you've just -- too glibly -- summed up Raymond M. Downey's job as chief of Rescue Operations for the New York City Fire Department. It is a job that on a good day makes you feel like a lifesaver, and on bad days, like the day of a Brooklyn brownstone collapse that killed three last week, makes you nothing but numb.

title: It's Speed Season. Got a Great Kick?
description: ''Attaway, Marc, you're right in there -- stick with it,'' my coach, Bobby Gordon, mercifully shouted to me as I churned my legs around the quarter-mile track at the Fort Monmouth Army base in Eatontown, N.J. It was a warm evening in May, and I was running faster than I had in years. A lifelong runner with plenty of marathons and five-kilometer runs under my belt, I sought a new challenge: track racing. My goal was simple, to run a mile.

title: Picking a No. 2: The Abortion Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety in Playgrounds
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Revisits the Decade of Nude Happenings
description: The highlights of the summer in New Jersey are retrospectives of artists who happened to be in or around New York more or less in the 1960's. They had nothing whatsoever to do with one another. The New York art world is really different coexisting but independent worlds, as these exhibitions remind us.

title: For Children, A Language To Vex Their Parents With
description: In ''Pokemon the Movie 2000,'' Pikachu and his fellow mystical creatures pursue two new adventures. This program, which seems to have been cobbled out of several episodes of the syndicated television series from Japan, is probably about as good as cut-rate animation that seems to consist of screen savers can be.

title: A Bridge Across the Rio Grande
description: To the Editor:

title: How Can Musicians Protect Their Art?
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; Good Fences ...
description: When you drive east from Jerusalem today, and cross the border from Israel into Palestinian-controlled Jericho, the only armed policeman you are likely to see is an Israeli cop with a radar gun, trying to catch Israelis speeding to the Palestinian casino in Jericho -- where Israelis gamble away about $1 million a day at Yasir Arafat's blackjack tables. (For now, Israel makes microchips, the Palestinians make poker chips, and all the money gets neatly recycled.)

title: Plans to Build Paper Recycler In South Bronx Are Called Off
description: From the time the Bronx Community Paper Company was conceived, the paper-recycling venture was viewed as a model of urban manufacturing: an environmentally friendly company that would employ 400 full-time workers and create $200 million a year in revenues in a neighborhood hungry for an economic lift.

title: When Horses Could Roam The Heavens
description: The Scythians, the fierce nomadic tribes of Central Asia that swept as far west as the Danube from the eighth to the fourth century B.C., did not limit themselves to plundering Europe. Skilled horsemen, they rampaged across ancient Eurasia as far east as China. ''Their country is the back of a horse,'' Herodotus wrote.

title: United Criticizes Mechanics For Delays in Maintenance
description: United Airlines, already reeling from the refusal of many of its 10,000 pilots to work overtime, is now facing similar difficulties from its 15,000 mechanics.

title: America Online Registers Strong Profit for Quarter
description: Signaling that the problems of many Internet start-ups are not hurting their larger cousins, America Online yesterday reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $338 million, up 115 percent from a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANIN, MARTIN
description: CANIN-Martin. A former artist and teacher at Parsons School of Design died July 19 in Rhinebeck, NY. Memorial may be made to The Alzheimer's Association. Dapson-Chestney Funeral Home (845876-6000).

title: F.C.C. Promises Close Scrutiny Of German Bids
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said today that because Deutsche Telekom was controlled by the German government, any offers it makes to buy an American telephone company would face heavy regulatory scrutiny.

title: U.S. Says Cheaper Fares Sometimes a Mouse Click Away
description: U.S. Says Cheaper Fares Sometimes a Mouse Click Away

title: Glittering Determination: A Toast to a Life of Excess
description: ''The Eyes of Tammy Faye'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Elvis Mitchell's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 31. The film opens today at the Quad Cinema, 13th Street, west of Fifth Avenue, Greenwich Village.

title: TEREX IS SELLING FORKLIFT BUSINESSES TO FINNISH COMPANY
description: The Terex Corporation, a maker of cranes, forklifts and other equipment for mining and construction, agreed yesterday to sell its truck-mounted forklift businesses to a unit of the Partek Corporation of Finland for $144 million to help repay debt. Terex, based in Westport, Conn., said the sale included the truck-mounted forklift unit of Powerscreen, which was acquired in mid-1999, and the Princeton/Kooi units, which Terex also acquired last year. Terex, which had $1.9 billion in sales last year, said it expected to complete the deal in the third quarter. Terex's shares rose 68.75 cents, to $15.3125.

title: Jerusalem Arabs Look Expectantly and Anxiously to Camp David
description: For 10 days now, Arab residents of East Jerusalem have followed the reports from Camp David with rising anticipation -- and anxiety.

title: Giants' Fassel Gambles on Shuffled Lineup
description: After three seasons as Giants coach, Jim Fassel has hardly carved a public image as a swashbuckling risk-taker. Fassel may put his boat in the Hudson to cruise and relax during the off-season, but no one has ever called him a riverboat gambler.

title: COWAN TAKES TITLE AGAIN
description: P.J. Cowan shot a one-over-par 71 and finished with a 54-hole total of 209 to win the MONY New York State Open yesterday for the third time in the last four years.

title: The Marriage Tax on the Poor
description: Congress has agreed on a plan to eliminate the ''marriage penalty'' long embedded in our tax laws -- the tax advantage that the Internal Revenue Code now confers on couples who choose to live together outside of marriage, or who get divorced. The House has voted to double the standard deduction and the ceiling on the 15 percent tax bracket for married couples, and the Senate is expected to follow suit.

title: VENTURE CAPITAL CONCERNS TO MERGE
description: First Tuesday, a company that holds regular events around the world for entrepreneurs and venture capitalists, said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with Yazam, an early stage investing and business development company. The companies hope to leverage First Tuesday's access to business plans and industry experts with Yazam's venture capital fund. Terms were not disclosed. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Mrs. Clinton Attacks Lazio Over Position On Loan Limit
description: Suggesting that her opponent cared more about wealthy campaign donors than about constituents, Hillary Rodham Clinton attacked Representative Rick A. Lazio yesterday for trying to kill legislation in 1998 to expand a program that helps first-time home buyers obtain mortgages.

title: Residential Real Estate; From Dormant Armory to Middle-Income Rentals
description: An empty wreck of a building since the late 1980's, the Clermont Armory in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, has sprung back to life over the last 15 months as a rental apartment complex for middle-income tenants.

title: BANK SETTLES SECURITIES VIOLATIONS
description: In a settlement with the Ontario Securities Commission for unlawful stock trading, the pension management division of the Royal Bank of Canada has agreed to pay a fine of 3 million Canadian dollars ($2 million) and pressured seven senior officers and traders to resign. The Toronto Stock Exchange has also levied suspensions and 400,000 Canadian dollars in fines against 12 traders involved in the transactions. The division, RT Capital, admitted to pushing up the price of shares with trades late in the day to artificially raise the performance of its portfolios. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Many TV Stations Reject Police Union Ad
description: With a week of negotiations left before its contract with the city expires, the police union is stepping up its campaign for higher wages with a television advertisement depicting a fallen, bleeding officer that some stations have rejected as too graphic.

title: Long Island Shows Its Adopted Brood
description: In museums and galleries Long Island is paying attention to its own, or at least to some of its adopted sons and daughters. They include artists past and present, one art-bedazzled poet and an art-aspiring seasonal migrant, namely Hollywood.

title: New Warning, And Deeper, From Lucent
description: Lucent Technologies said yesterday that its financial results would fall short of expectations for the next two quarters, at least in part because the company had been caught off guard by slower demand for traditional communications systems and the rising importance of newer technologies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARARI, HANANIAH
description: HARARI-Hananiah. Age 87, of Croton, on July 19, 2000. Survived by his wife, Shirley, and 5 children. Renowned artist. Funeral on Friday at 10:00am at Edward F. Carter Funeral Home, 41 Grand Street, Croton, NY 10520. Burial at Sharon Gardens. Memorial donations may be made to Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Ave, Hawthorne, NY 10532 or the Croton Caring Committee, c/o the funeral home.

title: With Gore Jabbing at Bush, Texas Takes It on the Chin
description: For months, Vice President Al Gore and other national Democrats have depicted George W. Bush's Texas as all but a third-world country. Pollution? Mr. Gore says Texas is the most polluted state in America. Poverty? Mr. Gore says that too many of Texas' people are poor and that the state does too little for them.

title: LEGAL CLAIMS FILED AGAINST OFFICERS DECLINE SHARPLY
description: After a five-year climb, the number of legal claims accusing New York City police officers of using excessive force or other misconduct has dropped sharply, by 25 percent over the last year, according to city statistics.

title: MVP.com Leaves Leagas Dealany
description: MVP.com, the online sporting goods retailer founded by John Elway, Wayne Gretzky and Michael Jordan, and its agency, the San Francisco office of Leagas Delaney, have parted ways after nine months. Spending for the account was initially estimated at $50 million, but has recently been around $15 million.

title: Africans Fault Rich Nations On Aid to the World's Poor
description: With leaders of the world's industrialized countries gathering in Japan for their annual meeting, a handful of major third world nations took center stage today and lambasted the richest nations on behalf of the world's poor.

title: HOME VIDEO
description: The Beach

title: Sun-Drenched Okinawa Is an Uneasy Place to Meet
description: Of the many locations Japan considered for the annual summit meeting of the world's leading industrialized nations, this resort town in the country's southernmost island, Okinawa, seemed a most dubious choice.

title: I.B.F.'s Lawyers Criticize Prosecution
description: Lawyers for the leaders of the International Boxing Federation, who are on trial for racketeering and seeking bribes in exchange for boxer rankings, said today that their clients are victims of a ''selective prosecution'' of the sport's only black-controlled sanctioning organization.

title: William Mote, 93, Millionaire And Developer of Marine Center
description: William Russell Mote, a millionaire businessman whose love of the sea led him to build the Mote Marine Laboratory here into a major research center, died on Tuesday at his home on Longboat Key. He was 93.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Ex-Manager Suing Over Singer's Deal

title: INCOME DOWN FOR VOLVO TRUCKS
description: The Swedish company Volvo said its operating profit was 4.32 billion Swedish kronor ($477 million) in the first six months of this year, exceeding analysts' expectations. But operating income for Volvo Trucks, the company's largest segment, declined to 31 million kronor in the second quarter of 2000, from 859 million kronor a year earlier. Volvo's leaders were not overly concerned that the recent acquisition of the Mack truck unit would leave the company overexposed in North America. The chief executive, Leif Johansson, said Mack was strong in construction vehicles while Volvo, which is owned by the Ford Motor Company, was more prominent in long-haul trucks.

title: Persistent Protesters From Banned Sect Keep Beijing Police on Edge
description: The police and Falun Gong followers played a grim game in Tiananmen Square today, with lean young cadets dashing across the vast open space to snatch down ocher banners briefly unfurled by middle-aged members of the banned spiritual discipline.

title: Mattel and Hasbro Say Profits Fell During Second Quarter
description: Mattel and Hasbro, two of the world's largest toymakers, said today that their second-quarter profits fell as sales slowed and an increase in the value of the dollar hurt earnings from overseas.

title: FRENCH BID FOR EQUIPMENT MAKER
description: Furthering its ambition to expand in North America, Rexel S.A. of France, one of the world's largest distributors of electrical equipment, has made a friendly bid to buy Westburne Inc. for 987 million Canadian dollars ($670 million). If successful, Rexel will become the third-largest supplier in North America, up from fifth-largest. Westburne, a Montreal-based distributor of electrical, plumbing and other equipment, has 546 branches, including 143 in the United States. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELOCK, WILLIAM HAWXHURST, II
description: WHEELOCK-William Hawxhurst, II. Of Easthampton, NY. Passed on July 18. Bill was a graduate of St. Paul's School in Concord, NH, Class of '55; Hobart College in Geneva, NY, '59. He leaves his two brothers, Frederick and Morgan; two children, Lindsay and Bill; and one grandson, Hawk. He will be remembered for his tours of Long Island, his broad smile, deep bass voice and enthusiastic character. A memorial service will be held at 4PM, July 22 at St. Luke's Church in Easthampton.

title: Gore, on Rival's Home Turf, Says Bush Is Soft on Big Oil
description: Vice President Al Gore blew into Gov. George W. Bush's home territory today to try to undercut the governor's popularity, suggesting that Mr. Bush's priorities were skewed and had made Texas a backwater where big oil interests are more important than children's health.

title: A Bridge Across the Rio Grande
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMERIO, JAMES J.
description: PALMERIO-James J. On July 15, 2000. Beloved brother of Maria A., Julia M. and Anthony J. Palmerio. Reposing at Albert R. Conner Colonial Funeral Home, 4955 Broadway, until Saturday 9:30 AM. Funeral Mass 10 AM at the Cabrini Chapel. Interment Cemetery of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary, Southampton, NY. Calling hours Friday, 2-4 and 7-9.

title: Candidates in 2001 Races Raising Funds Now
description: Fund-raising for the 2001 races for New York City comptroller, public advocate and the five borough presidents has been early and aggressive, according to records released this week.

title: G.M. OPENS BRAZIL PLANT
description: Betting on improved demand for cars in Brazil, the General Motors Corporation inaugurated a $600 million subcompact car plant in the southern state of Rio Grande do Sul. The plant can produce 120,000 cars a year of a new one-liter engine model called the Celta. The property will also hold factories for 16 of G.M.'s suppliers. G.M. plans to invest $1.5 billion in Brazil by 2003. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Justice Denied in Senegal
description: Six months ago the Pinochet precedent spread to Africa when Senegal decided to try the former dictator of Chad, Hissene Habre, on charges of torture. It was the first time an African country had brought human rights charges against another nation's head of state, and it energized democracy activists -- and terrified other former tyrants -- across the continent. But Senegalese courts have now dropped the charges after what looks suspiciously like interference from the country's new president. Chad's torture victims have appealed. Their plea should be heard by a court independent of executive branch pressure.

title: Ten of 22 Umpires May Be Rehired
description: Ten of the 22 major league umpires who lost their jobs last year could get those jobs back. But their future employment depends on two agreements: one between Major League Baseball and the umpires' new union on a new labor contract and one by the ousted union to settle its grievance against baseball.

title: Tests Rule Out West Nile Virus In Death Of Man, 71
description: A 71-year-old man who died in Staten Island on Wednesday was not infected with the West Nile virus, city officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STODDARD, GABRIELLA (GAY) CLARK
description: STODDARD - Gabriella (Gay) Clark. Of New York City and Sharon, Connecticut. On July 19, after a valiant battle with breast cancer. Beloved wife of Jonathan, devoted sister of Virginia (Ginny) and Gordon (Don), loving aunt of Douglas, David & Daniel, step-mother of Kristi, dear and cherished friend. Funeral service at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th St, 10:00AM, Monday, July 24. Blue Hill Troupers will sing. In lieu of flowers donations can be made in memory of Gabriella to Breast Cancer Research Fund at Weill Cornell Medical College, 525 East 68th Street, New York, NY 10021. She lives in our hearts.

title: Strong Sprint Helps Italian Steal Stage
description: Five low-ranked but aggressive riders jumped away early today in the Tour de France, built a lead of nearly 28 minutes through the gingerbread villages of Switzerland and held more than half of it at the finish before enormous crowds in Germany.

title: Effort to Soften a Tax Cut Only Hardens Opposition
description: Hoping to make it harder for President Clinton to veto a measure they see as having tremendous political appeal, Republicans have unveiled a new version of their tax cut for married couples, but as the bill passed the House today, they promptly found themselves under fire for making the bill cost $44 billion more overnight.

title: Metro Business; Economy Still Growing
description: New York State's economy has continued to grow over the last year, with private-sector employment up and unemployment rates down both downstate and upstate, the state's chief economist said yesterday.

title: Study Says That Napster Increases Music Sales
description: Study Says That Napster Increases Music Sales

title: Phone Carriers Are Sued By 8 States Over Ads
description: Connecticut and New Jersey were among eight states that filed lawsuits today against AT&T, Sprint and WorldCom, the nation's three largest long-distance telephone carriers, accusing them of misleading consumers in television commercials that offer low per-minute rates.

title: AGILENT FALLS ON PROFIT WARNING
description: Agilent Technologies warned yesterday that it would earn 18 cents to 22 cents a share, well short of the 35 cents a share forecast by analysts. In after-hours trading, the stock plunged $18, or almost 25 percent, to $55. Agilent attributed the expected shortfall to capacity constraints and component shortages.

title: SHARES OF FEDERATED DROP 12.6% ON PROFIT WARNING
description: The shares of Federated Department Stores fell 12.6 percent yesterday after the company said it expected earnings to be significantly lower than analysts' expectations. Federated, based in Cincinnati, said it expected to lose $150 million from its Fingerhut unit, the No. 2 United States catalog retailer, in the second quarter before interest and taxes, reducing earnings by 43 cents a share. Analysts polled by First Call/ Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 65 cents a share. Shares of Federated, which owns department stores like Bloomingdale's and Macy's, dropped $3.375, to $23.50. The stock has fallen about 59 percent since the beginning of the year.

title: AT&T TO OFFER AD-SUBSIDIZED WEB ACCESS
description: AT&T said yesterday that it would start an advertising-subsidized Internet access service to match free offerings from competitors like NetZero. Users of the AT&T service, which will cost $4.95 a month, will be required to register and will be assigned an anonymous identification number that will allow tracking of the Web sites they visit. The service will display advertisements in a narrow window that users will not be able to remove from their screens. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 8.

title: Study Finds Region of Brain May Be Key Problem Solver
description: Addressing a longstanding debate among scientists over how much of the brain is activated to perform a difficult task like taking an I.Q. test, researchers have found that a surprisingly small and specific region of gray matter may be the brain's master problem solver.

title: Protest Backs Schools Chief In Brooklyn
description: About 50 parents, teachers and students protested yesterday in front of the Board of Education headquarters, expressing anger that the board had not renewed the contract of a popular district superintendent in south Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SONNETT, CARL
description: SONNETT-Carl. Forever in our hearts, always in our thoughts. We miss you. Love, your children and grandchildren

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, HELEN (BROWN)
description: HELLER-Helen (Brown). Born August 19, 1909 in Brooklyn, NY. Died July 19, 2000 peacefully at her Florida home. Beloved wife of the late Irving. She was affiliated with Hadassah and the Lighthouse For the Blind. Survived by dearest sister, Evelyn Heimbinder and ten loving nieces and nephews. Funeral services at Mount Hebron Cemetery, July 21 at 1 PM.

title: ARCHSTONE IS BUYING BACK SHARES FROM SECURITY CAPITAL
description: The Security Capital Group, one of the largest United States real estate investment concerns, agreed to sell 17.5 million shares of Archstone Communities Trust to Archstone for $400 million in cash and notes, reducing its stake. Archstone, the third-largest apartment real estate investment trust, is to pay $178.7 million in cash and $221.3 million of mortgage notes of Homestead Village, a unit of Security Capital. Security Capital, based in Santa Fe, N.M., will use money from the sale to reduce debt and buy back its stock. It has been looking to raise cash and lift its share price by selling holdings. As of April, Security Capital held almost 53 million Archstone shares, or about a 38 percent stake, making it Archstone's largest shareholder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOCHNAK, ROBERT J.
description: BOCHNAK-Robert J. Died suddenly on July 19, 2000. Chairman of the Parks Group, Inc. Former Director of Labor Relations for Pan Am. Survived by wife, children, grandchildren, a mother, and sisters. Reposing Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, 45 South Highland Avenue/Route 9, Ossining, NY on Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass St. Augustine Church, Route 9, Ossining, on Saturday at 9:15AM. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Augustine's Elementary School, Eagle Park/ Route 9, Ossining, NY 10562.

title: Wise Up, Bonnie and Clyde: You're No Babes in the Woods
description: Francois Ozon's new film, ''Criminal Lovers,'' is such an amalgam of fairy tales, old movies and tabloid stories that it never develops a life of its own. It's like the world's chicest term paper, quoting from ''Night of the Hunter,'' ''Bonnie and Clyde,'' ''Gun Crazy,'' ''They Live by Night'' and true crime stories told through the eyes of Larry Clark (the director of ''Kids''), sharing his fixation on the hairless chests of teenage boys. (Some will note resemblances to ''The Blair Witch Project,'' but ''Criminal Lovers,'' which opens today at the Quad Cinema, was completed first.)

title: Accidental Light
description: Among the small, anonymous photographs hanging in the Gilman Gallery at the Metropolitan Museum in New York, there is a picture of a young boy fielding a ground ball on a rural ball field -- almost a pasture -- somewhere in America in 1931. He has ranged far to his left, the way a shortstop does to cover a ground ball up the middle, and he has stooped so far forward while still keeping a leg under him that it looks as though he is bowing in deep humility to the baseball in his glove. Strangely, it is an image of complete lassitude, a perfect rendering of the weariness that always steals over a game of catch played in a land of bad hops.

title: Candidate Begs to Lose In Florida Election Twist
description: Like most candidates for public office, Douglas Couvertier needed a clear, strong message, something that would cut through the other candidates' talk about what they would do for the voters, if elected.

title: Jets Counting on Rookie For Fresh Start at Tight End
description: On the day that Coach Al Groh spoke of wanting to teach young players about what it means to be a Jet, which players they are following and the culture of the team, perhaps he should have added:

title: Panel Backs World War II Memorial on Mall in Washington
description: The old soldier, his voice cracking with emotion and his battle-shattered right hand held against his chest, pleaded with a federal panel today to finally approve the first national World War II memorial before all his aging comrades died.

title: Begay Finishes With Flop
description: Notah Begay III is one of 15 players tied at three under par (69), but he had been alone in first place at seven under until he made a triple-bogey at No. 17 and a bogey at No. 18.

title: Video as Art in a World on Tape
description: THE chorus to an old John Prine song asks, ''Wouldn't we be in good shape/if our lives were on videotape?'' We shouldn't have to wait too much longer for an answer, since it often seems these days that no aspect of our private and communal lives is shielded from the patient, prying lens of the video camera -- though the tape itself, in the digital era, may soon be obsolete. From amateur pornography to security surveillance loops, from home movies of weddings, childbirths and family reunions to C-Span and ''Big Brother,'' video records and shapes what we know of reality. It takes our confessions, tells our secrets and presents our public rituals of shame and celebration. So, what kind of shape are we in, anyway?

title: Environmentalists Burn Over Malaysia's Refusal to Release Air Data
description: KUALA LUMPUR  There are two seasons in most of Southeast Asia  wet and dry  but in recent years some countries have come to expect a third: the "hazy" season, when fires set by farmers and plantation owners to clear brush send thick clouds of smoke across parts of Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Brunei and southern Thailand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIEDER, ELAYNE
description: WIEDER-Elayne. On July 20, 2000. Beloved daughter of Beatrice Wieder. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday, July 21, 11:30AM. Interment to follow at Maimonides Cemetery, Bklyn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, PATRICK R.
description: THOMPSON-Patrick R. A very good man. A very good friend. We shall miss you. Marty Greenberg, David Greenberg and the entire staff of Sterling Commodities.

title: Latin Culture's Collision With the New World, Translated Into Choreography
description: It is not all that hard to imagine the genesis of Bill T. Jones's new ''You Walk?,'' performed on Wednesday night at La Guardia Concert Hall as part of the Lincoln Center Festival. Mr. Jones is not only a passionate and intelligent modern-dance choreographer but hot as well, the commissioning city of Bologna might have reasoned. What better addition to the festivities for its European City of Culture 2000 designation? At the same time, most dance companies have never met a commission they didn't like. And who would want to pass up a gig in Italy?

title: Scientists Detect Elusive Building Block of Matter
description: What many physicists consider to be one of the last pieces of the theoretical puzzle that explains the structure of matter has been detected at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory near Chicago.

title: Swept Off Jetty, Girl Drowns And Toddler Is Critically Hurt

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POGASH, ISRAEL
description: POGASH-Israel. Israel Martin Pogash, founder of Pogash & Company, CPAs, which operated in NJ and NY for more than fifty years, died at the age of 99 on July 8 in his Palm Springs home. His wife, Sylvia Namm Pogash died a year earlier. Mr. Pogash was born in Volochisk, Russia. The eldest of 7, Mr. Pogash was the son of Minnie and Harry Pogash, an egg candler and grocer. Recognized for his mathematical acumen by his school principal, Martin Luther Cox, Mr. Pogash was skipped several grades. It became increasingly difficult for the young boy to be a ruffian when he was treated as a serious student. Lacking a middle name, Mr. Pogash took that of Martin in honor of his principal. At 13, he worked as a hat check boy at the Downtown Club, the eating place for top professionals, where he placed a hat on the head of Thomas Edison who Mr. Pogash said had a very large head. Many years later, Mr. Pogash became President of the Downtown Club. He was graduated with honors from NYU in 1922. He set up offices in Newark and later was joined by his brother David Martin Pogash, 17 years his junior. Mr. Pogash became one of the first forensic accountants, handling some of the leading cases of his day. Mr. Pogash retired at the age of 90. He was a 60-year member of Mountain Ridge Country Club and a former member of the Board of Trustees of Temple B'nai Jeshurun. He is survived by his daughters Susan Pogash of Chicago, Carol Pogash of Orinda, California, grandchildren Jacob and Rachel Wood, his sister Augusta Krumholz of Springfield, NJ and his brother, David Martin Pogash of South Orange, NJ.

description: SINNOTT-Richard Larkin, Sr., age 64, Bainbridge Island, WA died July 17, 2000 at his home. He was born February 3, 1936 in Chicago, Illinois to Richard Joseph and Kathryn Larkin Sinnott. Dick earned his degree in journalism from Notre Dame University in 1958. His early work career was in Chicago where he became involved in politics as a confidante of Mayor Richard Daley and once was the Grand Marshall in Chicago's St. Patrick's Day Parade. During the Nixon Administration, Dick was the Economic Development Administrator for the Department of Commerce. He was instrumental in a large number of projects throughout the country and particularly proud of the role he played in saving Pike Place Market in Seattle. He later owned R.L. For the past three years Dick worked with the Washington DC law firm, Patton Boggs. He is survived by his former wife, Barbara Sinnott, Bainbridge Island; two sons, Brendan Keith Sinnott, Bainbridge Island; Richard Larkin Sinnott Jr., Virginia; four daughters, Margaret Mary Mejia, Virginia; Elizabeth Ann Pash, New York City, NY; Jennifer Marie Sinnott, Washington, DC; Anne Ryan Sinnott, Virginia; seven grandchildren; cousins, Maureen O'Connor and Anne F. title: Welcome to the Big City: Sometimes It's a Bit Cruel
description: Teenage romantic comedies, a staple of every movie season, are often treated with contempt and condescension, not least by the people who make them, who seem to believe that young audiences will swallow a hackneyed, slapdash piece of work as long as there are cute actors and a good soundtrack. Forgettable, virtually interchangeable movies like ''She's All That,'' ''Whatever It Takes'' and the nondance parts of ''Center Stage'' operate on the disastrous assumption that since young love is trivial, stories about it can be flimsy and secondhand. But movies about adolescent longing (as distinct, for the sake of argument, from adolescent lust) are the culture's last vital link to the great studio comedies of the 1930's. If this proposition seems laughable, that's because, owing to the cynicism and laziness of filmmakers and production executives, the genre has been bled dry of its innocence, its charm and its essential seriousness.

title: A Dying Hipster Full of Song, Poetry and Sweet Nonsense
description: At the beginning of ''Benjamin Smoke,'' some lines from a Patti Smith poem appear on screen, and later Ms. Smith herself appears, to recite the poem and pay tribute to the life and music of the film's subject, an Atlanta musician, hustler, and occasional drag queen known to his fans and collaborators as Benjamin. Ms. Smith's presence is especially fitting, and not only because of her personal connection with Benjamin, who opened for her shortly before he died in 1999 from liver failure linked to hepatitis C and AIDS. From Jim Morrison to Kurt Cobain, she has always been a connoisseur of rock 'n' roll martyrdom, and Benjamin, born Robert Dickerson in rural Georgia in 1960, seems to have materialized from one of her songs -- a wispy, sensitive, self-destructive soul full of sweet beatnik romanticism, pop poetry and entertaining nonsense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSBLUTH, EDITH
description: WEISSBLUTH-Edith. On July 20th. Devoted wife to Jack. Loving mother of Jill, Andrew, Jay and Joy. Cherished grandmother and sister to Charles. Services 11:30AM Sunday at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

title: A Divided French Family, Unhappy in Its Own Way
description: Andre Techine is the most novelistic of filmmakers, by which I don't mean that he stints on the visual aspects of his craft. On the contrary, his new film, ''Alice and Martin,'' like his masterpieces ''Ma Saison Preferee'' and the scandalously underrated ''Wild Reeds,'' is full of gorgeous photography, swift, elegant editing and meticulously composed scenes. Mr. Techine's camera captures the dazzling yellow of a meadow in southern France, the deep grays of Paris at night and the rhythms of the sea beating against russet rocks on the Spanish coast.

title: Modis Discovers a Way to Keep Its Owners in the Dark
description: ANALYZING financial reports can resemble detective work. Sometimes a certain fact is crucial; sometimes it is irrelevant.

title: Picher Journal; Waste From Old Mines Leaves Piles of Problems
description: The problem is chat. Not the Internet variety or the kind swapped over coffee at Rascal's Truck Stop on the highway leading into this hardscrabble town of 1,800, but huge hills of processed rock left after the lead and zinc mines closed in the 1950's.

description: Expanding their legal attack on the exchange of copyrighted works on the Internet, the motion picture and music industries today sued to shut down Scour.com, a venture the industries say permits the free trading not just of music but of movies, in some cases as soon as they open in theaters.

description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today said that Con Edison was not ready to reopen the Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor with its existing steam generators. The decision makes it less likely that the plant will resume operations this summer and more likely that consumers will see higher utility bills.

description: Candidates are used to sharing the stage at presidential debates with television anchors and print reporters. But this year, they may also be joined by Paul Shaffer and the CBS Orchestra.

description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York said its Web site was broken into this week and material was posted there in support of the actors' strike against broadcast advertisers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUBER, A. ANDERSON
description: HUBER-A. Anderson. Of Ennice, NC, formerly of Atlanta and Bedford, NY. Passed away on Tuesday, July 18 in his home at the age of 70. He was surrounded by his family. Mr. Huber was born February 7, 1930 in NYC to Walter Huber and Margaret Goss Huber. After serving in the 82nd Airborne Division of the U.S. Army during the Korean conflict he graduated from Cornell University in 1954 with a degree in agriculture. During his distinguished business career he was an Executive Vice President of the First National Bank of Atlanta and a Senior Vice President with the Bank of America. He also served as Junior Warden of Holy Comforter Episcopal Church, Chairman of the United Way of Atlanta and President of the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. Mr. Huber is survived by his wife Frances Robinson Huber formerly of Atlanta; his daughter, Elizabeth Rhett Huber; his son and daughter-in-law Edward Merritt and Jan Jenkins Huber and their sons, John Merritt Huber and Edward Blake Huber, his son Timothy Norman Huber, his son James Robinson Huber, all of Atlanta; his son and daughter-in-law A. Anderson and Pamela Polley Huber of Darien, CT and their sons, A. Anderson Huber, III and Wesley Baxter Huber and daughter Kathleen Frances Huber; and his daughter, Phred Huber of San Francisco, CA. He is also survived by three brothers and a sister and numerous nephews and nieces. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers donations may be made to Christ Church (Episcopal), Building Fund at P.O. Box 1866, Sparta, NC 28675.

title: Ex-Aide Faces Sharp Questioning On Favors in Pataki Campaign
description: A former top aide to Gov. George E. Pataki came under vigorous cross-examination yesterday during a trial centering on charges that a Pataki fund-raiser solicited donations in exchange for political favors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDOUGAL, PHYLLIS M.
description: McDOUGAL-Phyllis M. of Garden City, NY on July 20, 2000 at the age of 73. Survived by her husband, Walter A. McDougal; her daughters, Mary O'Connor of San Rafael, CA, Eileen O'Connor of West Hempstead, Julia Kelly of Manhattan, Moira Murtagh of Hicksville, NY; sons William O'Connor Jr., of Manhattan, Terrence O'Connor of Sacramento, CA, Edward O'Connor of Southampton, NY, John O'Connor of Ipswich, MA, Thomas O'Connor of Garden City; brothers Dr. John P. McCloy of Melville, New York, and William J. McCloy of Englewood, FL; 7 stepchildren and 32 grandchildren. Born Mary Phyllis Veronica McCloy in Queens Village, NY on June 9, 1927, graduate of Fordham Law in 1949 where she met her first husband, William C. O'Connor, who died in 1977. Visiting on Friday from 2-5 & 7-9:30 at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Avenue, New Hyde Park, New York. Holy Mass will be celebrated at St. Anne's Church, Garden City on Saturday July 22nd, followed by interment at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: Connecticut Covers 3 Centuries Lightly
description: Connecticut can't really be considered out of town, frequented as it has been over the years by New Yorkers seeking a break from urban life. While the New York art scene simmers down for the summer, Connecticut museums offer a kaleidoscope of exhibitions that range from American Impressionism of the 19th century to video imagery for the 21st, with Connecticut itself or art produced there as a prime subject.

title: Calder's 'Eagle' Lands in Seattle
description: For a year ''Eagle,'' a monumental sculpture by Alexander Calder, has stood in front of the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Now the 39-foot-high biomorphic steel structure is heading to Seattle, where it is to become the centerpiece of a sculpture park scheduled to open in 2003.

title: Those Other Billboards
description: To the Editor:

title: RATES LOWERED IN BRAZIL
description: The Brazilian central bank's monetary policy committee lowered a benchmark overnight interest rate 50 basis points to 16.5 percent in a move that surprised economists. The central bank has reduced the benchmark rate two percentage points in the last month on improved inflation estimates for the next two years. Economists say that the government may also be using a more liberal interest rate policy to stimulate growth ahead of local elections in October. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the contest between Senator Robert G. Torricelli and Mayor James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge for the Democratic nomination for New Jersey governor misstated the context for a statement by Mr. McGreevey. Responding to Mr. Torricelli's suggestion that he was too beholden to a few powerful state lawmakers, Mr. McGreevey said, ''Considering Senator Torricelli's track record, that indeed is a remarkable comment,'' but would not elaborate. Later Mr. McGreevey said he had been implying that the senator had been just as dependent on the same legislators for his election in 1996, and that the comment was not a reference to past questions about Mr. Torricelli's ethics.

title: Amsterdam Journal; The Joy of the Red-Light District: A Police Guide
description: Rule No. 1, according to the new police guide for tourists to Amsterdam's red-light district, is: Have FUN, but act in a NORMAL manner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKMAN, DR. LEONARD
description: ZUCKMAN-Dr. Leonard. 79 years old. Died July 19, 2000. Respected clinical psychologist. Admired and loved by all who knew him. A man of great compassion, strength and integrity. A warm hearted loving man with a sense of humor, a great laugh and an optomistic view of life. A loving and devoted husband and best friend to his wife Gloria. A role model and hero to his children Tina (Stanley), Donna (Marc) and Michael (Mimi). He was the best Dad in the world. Big brother, father and friend to Irving and Sylvia. A loving brother-in-law to Marty and loving grandparent to Joshua, Nikki, Chelsea, Lindsey and Jake. He will be deeply missed by all. ''In the final analysis'' that's what counts.

title: COOKIE MANAGEMENT FOR EXPLORER
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it would test several privacy-enhancing ''cookie'' management features for its Internet Explorer Web browsing software. Cookies are small files placed on the hard drives of Web site visitors, and are often used to capture data about online behavior for personalization and advertising purposes. Microsoft said the new features, which had been distributed to 2,000 test subjects, would offer users more information about the types of cookies used and their origins, and would make it easier for them to track and delete the files.

title: GOLF; Mallon Uses Detour on Way to Lead
description: Meg Mallon knows that the route to success in the United States Women's Open traditionally demands few detours, but she made an unusual one today while taking the first-round lead.

title: Allen Paulson, 78, Owner of the Race Horse Cigar, Dies
description: Allen E. Paulson, who set speed records as a pilot and airline executive but became world famous as the owner of the renowned race horse Cigar, died Wednesday night at Scripps Hospital in La Jolla, Calif. He was 78.

title: New Party Mission, Old Party Hands
description: Has there ever been a presidential campaign headquarters more boring than George W. Bush's? The Bush people don't have staff shake-ups. They haven't had to move the offices so the candidate could find himself. They don't even spend their days gossiping on the phone or backbiting their superiors.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Wednesday about changes in the market for stock options misstated the name of a new exchange that trades them. It is the International Securities Exchange, not the International Stock Exchange.

title: Yanks Feel They Gave One Away
description: Visitors to Yankee Stadium yesterday would be forgiven if the baseball game passed unnoticed, if they were distracted by the parade of snow-white clouds outlined in blue. Midsummer felt like early fall, incredibly.

title: Boom in Gene Testing Raises Questions on Sharing Results
description: As genetic testing becomes increasingly common, those who choose to learn their genetic risks, and the health professionals who treat them, are facing difficult decisions about how -- and whether -- to share the results with family members who share their genes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGER, MOSHE
description: LANGER-Moshe. Riverdale Jewish Center mourns the loss of its member Mr. Moshe Langer, beloved husband and father of our members Zmira and Sidney Langer. We express profound condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: A Bridge Across the Rio Grande
description: To the Editor:

title: Overtime at Camp David
description: No one knows at this point whether the Camp David meetings will eventually bring a Mideast peace agreement. This is the first time Israeli and Palestinian leaders have tackled the most difficult issues, like sovereignty over Jerusalem. But the fact that Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, decided to stay on after President Clinton's departure for Okinawa yesterday morning is encouraging. Neither man wants to walk away from the chance of ending a half-century of destructive conflict.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ''THE ADVENTURES OF MAY A THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. The elaborate puppets range from a pugnacious Maya, who looks like a winged preschooler who has sprouted wings, to a dragonfly resembling Mae West. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212)539-6644.

title: 'Human/Nature'
description: Caren Golden

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a plan by manufacturers to disclose the levels of radiation emitted by cellular telephones misstated the placement of the notices. They will not be on the packages but on pamphlets inside.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the discovery of West Nile virus in dead birds on Staten Island and several other articles since March 10 used an incorrect New York City Health Department breakdown of the figures for illnesses caused by the virus in the New York region last year. The 62 confirmed cases in 1999 included 7 deaths from encephalitis, an inflammation of the brain, and 55 other cases of serious illness, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The 62 cases of illness were not in addition to the deaths.

title: Among Israelis, Congratulations and Condemnation
description: For a moment early this morning, when she heard the announcement that the Camp David talks had ended with no agreement, Gaby Bar-Zakai breathed easier.

title: ING Agrees to Buy 2 Aetna Units
description: The Dutch financial services company ING Group N.V. said today that it had reached agreement with the United States health care company Aetna Inc. to buy two units.

title: Time to Swim in the Hudson, State Says
description: After years of cleaning up the garbage and pollution that gave the Hudson River a bad name, New York State officials are now trying to bring back public beaches and swimming areas along its shores.

title: High Drama at U.S. Track Trials
description: It's that time of the quadrennium for fickle viewers to regain their interest in track and field after not caring a whit for it outside of Olympic years when track meets fail to attract all the sport's top stars and the few televised events generate low ratings.

title: Cuban Defector Kisses the Ground in Miami
description: Andy Morales, a Cuban baseball player whose second attempt to defect to the United States was successful on Tuesday, kissed the ground in Miami today.

description: Sega Cracks Down on Software Pirates

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZABARSKY, JOAN RUBIN
description: ZABARSKY-Joan Rubin. Age 70, of 3 Westomere Terrace, New London, died peacefully at her home on Wednesday. She was born on June 12, 1930 in New London, CT, the daughter of Louis and Sara Rubin. Mrs. Zabarsky graduated from Smith College in Amherst, MA. She later received her masters degree from University of RI. Mrs. Zabarsky retired as a Media Specialist from the Groton CT school system in 1990. She last worked as a teacher in Boca Grande, FL, teaching reading and writing. She was married to Robert S. Zabarsky who died in February of 1999. She is survived by a son, John Zabarsky of Southbury, CT; a daughter Katherine Zabarsky-Washburn of Stowe, VT. A memorial service will be held on Friday, July 28 at 1:00 PM at the Thomas L. Neilan & Sons Funeral Home, 12 Ocean Avenue, New London. The burial is private. There are no calling hours.

title: Christie Basham, 68, Television Executive
description: Christie R. Basham, a former executive producer of ''Meet the Press'' who was one of the first women to work as an executive in television network news, died on Sunday at her home in Washington, D.C. She was 68.

title: House Approves Easing of Embargo on Cuba Trade and Travel
description: Metropolitan DeskThe House of Representatives tonight approved measures to bar the Treasury Department from enforcing restrictions on travel to Cuba as well as on the sale of food and medicines to the island.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE PLUMMETS. Coffee tumbled 13 percent as concern faded that cold weather in Brazil would damage the world's biggest crop. In New York, coffee for September delivery fell 14 cents, to 97.75 cents a pound.

title: Annals of India Through One Family's Conflicts
description: Mahesh Dattani's play ''Dance Like a Man'' opens with a young dancer, Lata, bringing her fiance, Viswas, home to meet her parents. Their hopes, and the family histories that emerge from their conversation, are quietly amusing, and the missteps and misunderstandings that trip up everyone when Lata's parents return to the house are very funny. It is also somehow reassuring to know that families on the other side of the globe are as fractious and occasionally dysfunctional as our own.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FLOWSERVE CORP., Irving, Tex., a chemical plant equipment company, agreed to sell a pump plant in Tulsa, Okla., in an attempt to win approval from the Justice Department for its proposed $775 million purchase of Ingersoll-Dresser Pumps, a unit of the Ingersoll-Rand Co., Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: This Finesse Is So Deep, It's Practically Subterranean
description: If it were possible to stage the bridge equivalent of a Ryder Cup, North America against Europe, there would be no clear favorite. But if the contest were at junior level, the Europeans could be expected to win because they have vastly more international experience.

title: Debating Risks in the West Nile Fight
description: Camille Glad and Daiva Kezys are close in age, live in the same borough and spent part of yesterday a yard from each other on a commercial strip in northern Queens. But when it comes to their opinions on how the city should deal with the threat of the West Nile virus, the two could not be farther apart.

title: Citing Broken Bargain, Court Frees Inmate
description: A federal appeals court has freed a man who spent eight years in a New York State prison, ruling that the state violated a plea agreement when a Brooklyn judge sent him there.

title: Thomas Sardino, 72, Syracuse Police Chief
description: Thomas J. Sardino, who as Syracuse's police chief strove to defuse demonstrations, disorders and racial tension in the early 1970's, died July 14 in Syracuse. He was 72 and lived in Syracuse.

title: Anglo American Offers $1.8 Billion for Iron Mine Operator
description: Making another move to expand outside South Africa, Anglo American P.L.C., the world's biggest mining company, announced today that it had offered $1.8 billion to take over the Australian iron miner North Ltd.

title: Lightening Up a Legacy to Make It New
description: At certain points along the spectrum of popular music, lightness and sophistication bend to embrace each other. Bossa nova, as well as some of the music it has inspired, is one of those points. It began in the late 1950's as a music of reticence, seriousness and high craftsmanship; less than a decade later, bossa nova had become an instantly recognizable but sloppily applied brand, used in embarrassingly hard-sell ways in the pursuit of the sweet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLINGTON, THOMAS DUTTON
description: WELLINGTON-Thomas Dutton. 78. Of Princeton, NJ. Died July 19, 2000. Survived by his wife Margaret, daughters Margaret Constantine, Irene Wellington and Sarah Wellington, son Peter Wellington and five grandchildren. Also stepchildren John, Sarah, Thomas and Fairlie Myers. A service will be held on Tuesday, July 25, Princeton University Chapel at 4PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Habitat for Humanity or Doctors Without Borders.

title: Gore, With Gusto, Attacks Bush on Budget
description: Cramming several weeks of attacks on Gov. George W. Bush of Texas into one speech, Vice President Al Gore asserted today that the governor's handling of the state's budget proved he would be an incompetent steward of the national economy, inclined to squandering the surplus on tax cuts for the rich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, JOAN LARKEY
description: SOLOMON-Joan Larkey. On July 21, 2000. Beloved wife of George, cherished mother of Andrew, Barney and Elizabeth, mother-in-law of Elizabeth Bartman and grandmother of Daria Solomon, and dear sister of Lewis, Morris and James Larkey. Services will be held at Gramercy Park Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, Sunday, July 23 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Gynecological Oncology Research Fund, NYU School of Medicine, C/O James Speyer, M.D., 160 East 32 Street, NY, NY 10016.

description: The Yankees made a trade with the Chicago Cubs last night for a right-handed-hitting outfielder with some pop in his bat. But it did not involve Sammy Sosa and it did not mean they were through trading.

description: IT isn't every day that you get to talk about legal negotiations in which the silent partner is the angel of death. That may seem like a melodramatic way to begin, but the description is accurate all the same.

title: China to Merge Domestic Carriers in Reorganization
description: China announced a large reorganization of domestic airlines today, merging seven carriers into the three largest to reduce the overlap of routes and the number of half-empty planes that have plagued the industry for years.

title: Anne Faces a Messy World Far From Green Gables
description: In ''Anne of Green Gables: The Continuing Story,'' Anne Shirley makes her way to a publishing house in New York to peddle a manuscript. It's 1915, but her meeting with the company's head would sound familiar today. After complaining about the sorry state of the business, he compliments her work and then rejects it.

title: Ivory Coast's Junta Tries To Block Comeback Bid
description: This onetime redoubt of political stability and steady growth in West Africa has been through a lot in the last year: the fall of an unpopular president, the first coup in its history and military misrule that twice in the last month raised the possibility of another army uprising.

description: THE YEN FALLS. The yen dropped as recent bankruptcies and a stock market slide cast doubt on the strength of Japan's economy. In New York, the dollar settled at 108.88 yen, up from 107.67 on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAURER, JAMES L.
description: MAURER-James L., age 65, of Lakewood, NJ, died Thursday at his home. Mr. Maurer worked for the F.W. Woolworth Co. of New York as a Senior Toy Buyer for 46 years, retiring in 1997. He then worked for Imaginarium of North Jersey as a Senior Toy Buyer. Mr. Maurer was a founding member and past president of the Agnes Trapp Memorial Association, which was started 45 years ago in memory of his grandmother. He was a communicant of St. Joseph R.C. Church. Born in North Bergen, NJ he lived in Princeton Junction, NJ before moving to Lakewood 1998. Surviving are his wife Margaret Ann Maurer, son David Maurer of Hamilton, NJ. Sons & daughters-in-law: James J. & MaryAnn Maurer of Ramsey, NJ, John M. & Diana Maurer of Ewing, NJ, Paul T. & Julia Maurer of Hamilton, NJ, Daniel E. & Lori Maurer of Robbinsville, NJ. Brothers & sisters-inlaw: Joseph & Carol Maurer of Pocono Pines, PA, Vincent & MaryLou Maurer of Beachwood, NJ, Eugene & Betsy Maurer of Cranford, NJ, Robert & Mary Maurer of Metuchen, NJ, Thomas & Sharon Maurer of Middletown, NY. Sister & brother-in-law: Marion & Robert Forenza of Pocono Lakes, PA. Seven grandchildren: Lindsay, Stacy, Hunter, McKenzie, Ashley, Caroline & Kelsey Maurer. Visitation will be held Saturday 7-9 and Sunday 2-4 & 7-9, at the Kedz Funeral Home, 1123 Hooper Ave. Toms River. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 10:00am Monday at St. Joseph R.C. Church, Hooper Ave. Toms River. Interment will follow at Holy Cross Cemetery, N. Arlington, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Jude Childrens Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis TN 38105, in his name would be appreciated.

title: Thousands of Dismissed Tickets Raise Question of Police Quotas
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that investigators were reviewing why five New York City police officers from the same Queens precinct had written thousands of parking tickets that were later dismissed with unusual regularity.

title: FPL GROUP, A UTILITY OWNER, CANCELS POWER CONTRACTS
description: The FPL Group, the owner of Florida's largest electric utility, agreed yesterday to pay more than $222.5 million to cancel 30-year contracts to buy power from two plants in its service area. FPL estimates the settlement will save customers more than $350 million when compared with payments due under the power-purchase agreements. The company owns the Florida Power and Light Company, which has 3.8 million customers. The money will go to holders of $288.5 million in tax-exempt bonds that helped finance construction of the Okeelanta and Osceola plants in Palm Beach County. FPL shares fell 43.75 cents, to $52.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.(Bloomberg News)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about criticism from Ambassador Richard C. Holbrooke that Washington was not providing adequate financial support for United Nations peacekeeping missions misstated the amount Congress is being asked to approve. The administration has proposed spending $1.7 billion, not $7.1 billion, for emergency relief for peacekeeping.

title: Excerpts From Preface to Special Counsel's Report
description: Following are excerpts from the preface to the interim report of John C. Danforth, the special counsel, which cleared the government of any wrongdoing in the deaths of 80 people at the Branch Davidian compound outside Waco, Tex., in 1993.

title: UNION SETS DEADLINE
description: The new umpires' union has given the old union until Aug. 1 to accept a tentative deal with Major League Baseball that would restore the jobs of 10 of the 22 umpires who lost their positions last year.

title: Surveillance Firm Bought
description: TransCore, which supplies transportation services like electronic toll collection, said this week that it had bought American Traffic Systems, a maker of video systems for enforcing speed limits and stop lights. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. American Traffic, said its products had cut the number of drivers running red lights by about 40 percent in the 40 United States cities where it helps enforce traffic laws.

title: Campaign Inquiry On Torricelli Aides Said to Be Renewed
description: As Senator Robert G. Torricelli prepares to seek the Democratic nomination for governor of New Jersey, federal prosecutors are intensifying their inquiry into the role that his office may have played in a series of illegal contributions to his 1996 Senate campaign, lawyers and others familiar with the case say.

title: Truth or Lies? In Sex Surveys, You Never Know
description: Wardell B. Pomeroy, one of Alfred Kinsey's associates in the 1940's, was interviewing a man about his first ejaculation. He asked, ''When?'' The man answered, ''Fourteen.'' Pomeroy then asked, ''How?'' and was surprised to hear: ''With a horse.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RAFSKY, ROBERT ALAN
description: RAFSKY-Robert Alan Lovingly remembered today and every day.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article about a vote by the House of Representatives to ease restrictions on travel and the sale of food and medicine to Cuba was omitted from some copies yesterday. An article on the vote appears today on Page A3.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Many trained and skilled women and girls must stay at home because of social and traditional obstacles from their families. Many men in our society don't want their wives working outside the home. But this is going to change. The process is unstoppable.''

title: Man Tried to Impale a Neighbor With Wooden Stake, Police Say
description: Anyone who relishes scary stories knows that there is one sure way to slay a vampire: drive a sharp wooden stake through his heart while he sleeps.

title: New York Still Needs Patches of Green
description: As a landscape architect in New York City, I have often been hired to design or redesign so-called bonus plazas, the small islands of green space that the city's zoning laws encourage developers to include when building new towers in certain zones.

title: Putin Bends Clinton's Ear Hoping to Halt Missile Shield
description: At the summit meeting here of eight world leaders, where the focus was unremittingly on harmony, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met with President Clinton on Friday night to argue against American deployment of a national missile shield.

title: Armstrong Wins a Stage; Paris Awaits
description: Lance Armstrong, who says he draws his motivation from both positive and negative sources, had both of them at his disposal today and blended them expertly to win a long individual time trial in the Tour de France by 25 seconds and solidify his overall lead.

title: DAEWOO AUDIT DEEPENS
description: Auditors at the Daewoo Group found evidence of further false accounting, leading the South Korean government to extend an audit. Around 23 trillion won ($21 billion) out of the conglomerate's total assets of 80 trillion to 90 trillion won has been confirmed to have been hidden in various accounts and manipulated, said Chung Ki Young, an official at the financial watchdog agency in charge of auditing Daewoo's financial records. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGOLF, SUZANNE (NEE BRAGG)
description: EGOLF-Suzanne (nee Bragg). 61, of Tucson, AZ. Died on July 14, 2000 of an accidental drowning. Born and raised in Harrison, New York, graduated Harrison High School 1956, Northwestern University 1960. Survived by husband James Egolf, daughter Lisa Kraas, son Kevin Kraas and her brothers, Spike and Mike Bragg.

title: TOP CHOICE SEEN FOR BUSH'S NO. 2
description: Richard B. Cheney, the former defense secretary who is heading Gov. George W. Bush's search for a vice presidential nominee, has emerged as a leading contender for the job, changing his voter registration today to make his selection possible, Republicans close to the governor said this evening.

title: HONEYWELL TO BUY BACK UP TO 40 MILLION SHARES
description: Honeywell International, a diversified maker of aerospace and automation products, said yesterday that it would buy back up to 40 million of its shares, estimated to be worth $1.5 billion at current market prices. The buyback, which Honeywell expects will not take place until the end of next year, represents about 5 percent of the company's stock outstanding. Companies use buybacks to increase earnings per share by reducing the number of shares outstanding. Honeywell, based in Morristown, N.J., had $23.7 billion in sales last year. Its stock fell 68.75 cents yesterday, to $35.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.(Dow Jones)

title: Kodak Second-Quarter Profit Rises 4.5%

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIGGS, FRIEDA WILDY
description: RIGGS-Frieda Wildy. 92, died on July 20, 2000 at home in Bronxville, New York. Born on September 8, 1907, in Hemingford, Nebraska, Frieda was the daughter of Calvin and Anna Wildy. She graduated from the University of Colorado at Boulder, and received a master's degree in social work from Bryn Mawr College. After a career in social work, she was a devoted volunteer with her church, the Bronxville School, and the Public Library. Frieda was predeceased by her husband of 53 years, Arad McCutchan Riggs, and her sisters, Lois Wildy and Ruth Wildy. Survivors include one sister, Mary Wildy Zimmer of Denver, Colorado; two children, Robert McCutchan Riggs of Bronxville, New York, and Meredith Riggs Spangler of Charlotte, North Carolina; daughter-in-law Wendy Riggs; son-in-law C.D. Spangler, Jr.; granddaughters Anna Wildy Spangler Nelson, Abigail Riggs Spangler, Jennifer Lois Riggs Vetter, and Sarah Brenda Riggs; and one great-granddaughter, Meredith Spangler Nelson. A memorial celebration of Mrs. Riggs' life will be held on Friday, July 28, 2000 at 3 o'clock p.m. at the Reformed Church in Bronxville.

title: Outsiders Venting Their Inner Darkness

Heavy rock is an outsider's pleasure, and tattoos are permanent emblems of the soul's insurrection. Seriously tattooed people, with ink on the neck or down both arms, can alienate employers, family and people in line at the supermarket. They incorporate confrontationalism into their very membranes.

Was it party chants, boasts, storytelling, social comment, preaching, audio cinema, history, advertisement? Was it limited to two turntables and a microphone, or could it add any sample or studio music a producer wanted to use? Should it be realistic, cartoonish, self-aggrandizing, community-minded? United Musical, based in Elkhart, Ind., sells band and string instruments. It is expected to have $70 million in revenue this year. Steinway, which had $304.6 million in sales last year, is the largest maker of band instruments in the United States.(Dow Jones)

title: Listen to the Radio and Get an Earful
description: In the early 1970's, my feminist friends and I roamed New York with our ''This exploits women'' stickers. Whenever we saw egregious examples of female objectification -- in advertisements, on billboards, in store windows -- we'd slap on those signs, naively believing that once our outrage had been expressed, people would see the folly of their behavior and change it, and a more egalitarian society would emerge. Our actions seem remarkably quaint now, and not just because of our innocence about the ways of the world.

title: Cooler Subways
description: If you stand on the subway platform at Grand Central you will hear a vague, rumbling hum, but not from the number 6 train snaking around the corner. If you stand in just the right place, you will feel a cool draft, but not from the street. The source of both the noise and the cool air is a series of impressively large black boxes suspended from the ceiling over the middle of the platforms. These are air coolers, and at Grand Central they are making the platform more bearable. While the new technology has not totally solved the heat problem, and so far has not confronted anything like last summer's stifling humidity, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority deserves thanks for giving its long-suffering passengers a measure of relief.
