title: AIRCRAFT RULING AGAINST BRAZIL
description: The World Trade Organization affirmed that Brazil erred in failing to end illegal subsidies to its aircraft industry. Canada successfully argued that the subsidies to the regional jet maker Embraer hurt revenue at the Canadian-owned Bombardier in the flourishing market for small passenger planes. Last summer the trade organization ruled that each country's financial support for its aircraft makers violated global trade rules and set a deadline of November 1999 for compliance. Talks on a compromise failed. On Wednesday the trade body will rule on Canada's request for $3.3 billion in sanctions. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISPEKER, THEA

As an artist's manager, she nurtured some of our finest talents and as our friend, she was warm, always in good humor, and above all, faithful. She will be greatly missed. Barry Tucker, President The Richard Tucker Music Fdtn.

title: SALE OF STAKES IN TWO CABLE NETWORKS IS PLANNED
description: AT&T, which is the largest United States cable-television company, is considering the sale of stakes in two TV networks -- Outdoor Life and Speedvision -- which it obtained when it acquired the MediaOne Group last month. The possible sales were disclosed by AT&T in a filing with the Federal Communications Commission. AT&T did not give a reason. AT&T has a 15 percent stake in Outdoor Life, a channel that provides shows on fishing, hiking and similar recreational activities. It owns 13 percent of Speedvision, which provides shows on racing cars, boats and motorcycles. Speedvision has about 27 million subscribers. Outdoor Life is available in 26 million homes.(Bloomberg News)

description: MUTUAL FUNDS benefit investors by reducing risk through diversification. In theory. In practice, at least lately, diversification has meant spreading money among all sectors of the economy as long as they involve technology.

Her event will be included in the Olympics for the first time at the 2000 Summer Games in Sydney, Australia. First, however, she must make the American team. The thought of failing to clear any height in today's qualifying round at the Olympic trials had left her so nervous and irritated in recent weeks that it had begun to affect her jumping.

title: ABITIBI-CONSOLIDATED PLANS CUTS AT NEWSPRINT PLANTS
description: Abitibi-Consolidated, the world's biggest newsprint maker, said yesterday that it would close a United States mill and reduce output at a Canadian plant by about a third in a bid to improve profit. An unprofitable 130,000 ton-a-year newsprint plant in West Tacoma, Wash., is scheduled for closing at the end of the year, Montreal-based Abitibi said. The mill employs 180 people. Abitibi also is set to shut down a 50,000 ton-a-year paper machine at its Wayagamack plant in Trois-Rivieres, between Montreal and Quebec City. Abitibi is in talks with unnamed bidders to sell the factory, which employs 540.(Bloomberg News)

What intrigues us at the moment is Mr. Torricelli's eagerness to leave the Senate after only four years, and the light this sheds on the relative appeal of the Senate and the statehouses. The Senate has been described as ''the greatest deliberative body on earth.'' Even so, Mr. Torricelli wants out, believing that as a governor he has a better chance of getting things done and, further, a better chance to achieve higher office should he ever seek it.

The company's chief executive and president, Edward S. Rogers, above, said, ''The second quarter showed strong progress in all areas of the company.'' Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

Rock-Tenn will cut 80 to 100 jobs the next 30 to 60 days and 100 more the next six months, a spokesman said. The company has about 8,500 employees and operates 20 United States plants. Rock-Tenn. based in Norcross. Ga., will take a charge of about $1.3 million, or about 4 cents a share, to close the plant. Shares of Rock-Tenn rose 18.75 cents, to $9.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHAN, RICHARD L.
description: COHAN-Richard L. 73, of New York City, on July 20, 2000, died peacefully after a long and valiant battle with kidney cancer. Most beloved husband of Felice (nee Schramm) for 48 years. Cherished father of Betsy and Cathy and loved father-in-law of Bob Zorowitz. Adored grandfather of Sydney and Jane Zorowitz. He was born on November 26, 1926 in New York City, where he was raised and lived except for 27 years during which he was a resident of Westport, CT. He was an alumnus of Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School, Class of 1944, after which he served in the U.S. Navy. He was a member of the Class of 1949 at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. His lifelong work involved international sales and marketing in several industries until his retirement from Wyant Health Care. An avid angler and wildlife preservationist, Dick will be missed by his family and many friends and business associates. Donations in his memory may be made to Gilda's Club, 195 West Houston St., NY, NY 10014 or Kidney Cancer Association, 1234 Sherman Ave., Ste 203, Evanston, IL 60202. He called it a human error and an example of ''the perils of modern technology.'' Steve Ploski, a Yonkers Democrat who plans to challenge Mr. Abinanti in a primary for the State Senate seat, filed a complaint with the Westchester County District Attorney's office, calling for an investigation of Mr. Abinanti's use of the Legislature e-mail address. title: The Vanity of Volunteerism
description: Sara Mosle (July 2) aptly pointed out that volunteers cannot succeed alone. While they are in no way dispensable, volunteers need the support and structure provided by a professional staff and by government programs and financing. This partnership ensures that the clients receive the continuity they deserve. The government also benefits since volunteers provide a large portion of social service work and, in doing so, help government funds go further. It is essential that we not create a false dichotomy between volunteers, or ''charity'' as a whole, and government. Each strengthens the other.

title: Music for Children (and Adults)
description: Tom Chapin is a rare breed. He is a children's music artist who doesn't scare off parents, and actually raises the bar for children. The younger brother of the late folk singer Harry Chapin, Tom is an accomplished musician on his own. Performing with his band, the amiable Mr. Chapin, offers up a sweet mix of folk-based music in a two part concert -- one for the adults, and the other for younger listeners, who have most likely grown up listening to his clever, educational, entertaining and thought-provoking music. The host of the television series ''Make A Wish'' will perform favorites from his children's recordings like ''Family Tree'' and ''Mother Earth, as well as his soon-to-be-released grown-up folk-rock album, ''In the City of Mercy.'' Children will have a blast singing ''There are two kinds of seagulls, shegulls and hegulls,'' as well as other Chapin hits like ''Picnic of the World'' (get ready to reel off those nations), and ''Stone Soup.'' Mr. Chapin offers up a free evening of family entertainment -- devoid of silly purple dinosaurs, La-La's and Po's -- on Thursday at 7:30 p.m. on the Buccleuch Park Concert Lawn in New Brunswick. ROBBIE WOLIVER

She graduated from the University of Colorado at Boulder, and received a master's degree in social work from Bryn Mawr College. After a career in social work, she was a devoted volunteer with her church, the Bronxville School, and the Public Library. Frieda was predeceased by her husband of 53 years, Arad McCutchan Riggs, and her sisters, Lois Wildy and Ruth Wildy. Survivors include one sister, Mary Wildy Zimmer of Denver, Colorado; two children, Robert McCutchan Riggs of Bronxville, New York, and Meredith Riggs Spangler of Charlotte, North Carolina; daughter-in-law Wendy Riggs; son-in-law C.D. Spangler, Jr.; granddaughters Anna Wildy Spangler Nelson, Abigail Riggs Spangler, Jennifer Lois Riggs Vetter, and Sarah Brenda Riggs; and one great-granddaughter, Meredith Spangler Nelson. A memorial celebration of Mrs. Riggs' life will be held on Friday, July 28, 2000 at 3 o'clock p.m. at the Reformed Church in Bronxville.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-23-00: Counter Culture; Promotion of the Fittest
description: When you first think about it, it's a no-brainer. When the final stages of mapping the human genome were hyped last month, both President Bill Clinton and Prime Minister Tony Blair called for a swift, extensive ban on using genetic information to discriminate in employment or insurance. Clinton had already signed an executive order back in February, banning such discrimination for federal employees. True to form, both politicians had polling data to support them. A 1998 survey of 1,000 randomly selected Americans found that 63 percent of them balked at any genetic testing if an employer or health insurer could have access to the data. So a ban on genetic discrimination not only secures privacy and fairness; it also protects good research by reassuring study volunteers that the information they provide is in completely safe hands.

title: You Spigotty Anglease?
description: WITH trout fishing in full swing, I find it timely to make a revolutionary declaration about the most inexplicable work of fiction ever written, James Joyce's ''Finnegans Wake,'' his so-called ''Work in Progress'' on which he labored for 17 years. My declaration is this: Fish and fishing, fly-fishing in particular, constitute the major theme in the ''Wake,'' as Joyceans call it. The evidence that I have discovered is so overwhelming that the ''Wake'' must be considered as belonging in great part, albeit a bizarre part, to angling literature.

title: The Great American Novel, on Dime Store Paper
description: The Firestone Library at Princeton University is the archive of the manuscripts and correspondence of F. Scott Fitzgerald. The library also has other collections relating to the writer, including his personal library; the manuscripts of his wife, Zelda, and her correspondence with Fitzgerald; and the archives of Charles Scribner's Sons (including the correspondence between Fitzgerald and his editor, Maxwell Perkins). Fitzgerald attended Princeton but left in 1917 to join the Army. Recently, the library became one of the first recipients of a Save Our National Treasures grant from the National Park Service to preserve and restore about 30,000 items written in Fitzgerald's hand. Don C. Skemer, curator of manuscripts, Princeton University Library Department of Rare Books and Special Collections, Library, spoke about the collection..

As the director casts, shoots and edits, an additional camera crew will follow behind and shoot the ready-made ''making of'' documentary. Youths with a bohemian bent will tune in to ''Greenlight'' to learn a lesson that could save their parents millions of dollars in film-school expenses: the life of the auteur is hard. And dull.

title: HOME DEPOT TO TRY AGAIN
description: A long-dormant plan to build a Home Depot in Mount Pleasant has been given new life since Justice W. Denis Donovan of State Supreme Court in White Plains held that town planners wrongly rejected the company's proposal on environmental grounds. ''The project has been revived,'' said Paul D. Sirignano, a lawyer for Home Depot. He said the company had invested $3 million since 1993 trying to build on Route 9. The town Planning Board denied the company a site plan and freshwater wetlands permit, but the judge on July 11 said that ruling was arbitrary and capricious. The matter has been sent back to the Planning Board, but William Agresta, the town's outside planning consultant, said that in his opinion, ''the board reached an appropriate decision in denying the applications.'' AL BAKER

title: Political Briefing; An Outspoken Ally Has Advice for Gore
description: Gov. Paul E. Patton of Kentucky has good ties to Vice President Al Gore and will help preside over the Democratic National Convention next month, when Mr. Gore is officially nominated. But he worries about how Mr. Gore is playing around the country, especially in Kentucky, considered a swing state this year.

title: Austria Politician Sometimes Down but Never Out
description: There is a beloved figure in Viennese folklore named Dear Augustin, a musician who got so stupefied while pub-crawling during the 1681 plague that he was taken for dead and thrown in a ''pestilence pit.''

title: A Dose of Reality Shakes Up Investors
description: Wall Street was heartened last week by Alan Greenspan's assurances that the soaring economy is finally winding down to a more manageable pace. Then reality set in.

title: Now, a Permanent Record
description: You work abstractly with sounds in your head on pieces you may never hear. The fruition of your art largely depends on others, for a cost you can barely afford. To make matters worse, no one is longing for your finished product -- indeed, your audience clings to masters of the past. You are a classical composer, swimming against the tide of popular culture.

title: Ann Schiffers, Adam Anuszkiewicz
description: Ann Lisa Schiffers, a daughter of Anita Schiffers of Mission Viejo, Calif., and Edmond Schiffers of Jacksonville, Fla., was married yesterday to Adam John Anuszkiewicz, the son of Sarah and Richard Anuszkiewicz of Englewood, N.J. Canon Bernard Dooly performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Cathedral in Jacksonville.

title: Johnson Sustains Cramp, and Is a Maybe for Showdown With Greene
description: After Maurice Greene sprinted the 200-meter preliminaries in 20.28 seconds today, he rolled his shoulders, raised a finger in the air and motioned toward Michael Johnson as if to say, ''Bring it on.''

title: The Vanity of Volunteerism
description: Sara Mosle's heartfelt article does nothing more than hem readers into the same choice we've heard about for years: either individuals or the government must do more. Neither is necessarily true. What poor children clearly need are families who can adequately care for them -- which means the ultimate responsibility lies with parents who ought not to bring children into the world without the proper means to raise them.

title: When to Fight, and When to Make the Best of It
description: ''POWER PLAYS'' has its roots in a course that John O. Whitney originated at the Columbia Business School. Of late, Professor Whitney and Tina Packer, the book's authors, have shared the teaching, as they explain in these excerpts from an interview. FRED ANDREWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEYGER, PAT
description: BEYGER - Pat. Banks, near Brampton, Cumbria. Died in a car crash July 4, 2000, in Queensland, Australia, while visiting relatives.

title: July 16-22; Plan to Breach Dams Delayed
description: A plan that could have led to the breaching of four dams on the Snake River in the Pacific Northwest has been postponed. The plan was aimed at easing the way for endangered species of salmon to return to spawning grounds. But the White House chose instead to embrace an alternative course. Trying to balance voters' support for the salmon with regional officials' opposition to any breach, it will propose smaller steps to help the species while deferring until at least 2005 any razing of the dams. DOUGLAS JEHL

title: A Big Idea About Money
description: Millionaire

title: A Mister Softee Who Found His Calling
description: WHERE Tyrone Laws is going today, he will not need chimes. He will not need Firecrackers or Warheads or many of the individually wrapped treats that make up the average ice cream man's arsenal. He will not swing out his ''Slow Children Crossing'' sign, and he will not patrol suburbia. He might not even see a child today.

title: A Hard Life for Amerasian Children
description: Shortly after moving to this military town in Okinawa two years ago, Etsuko Higashiyama, a 29-year-old secretary, fell in love with a United States marine from Arkansas. They dated for more than a year, and when Ms. Higashiyama became pregnant, the couple considered marriage, she said.

title: Sophie Brown, Val Hawkins Jr.
description: Sophie Stephanie Pezon Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Gardner Brown of Lake Forest, Ill., was married on Thursday to Val Parham Hawkins Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hawkins Sr. of Alexandria, Va. Guy Lebleu, a deputy mayor of Amboise, France, officiated at the town hall there. Yesterday, the couple had a Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Denis in Amboise.

title: Record 'Brown Tide' Reaches Quantuck Bay
description: Brown-tide algae is at record levels in Great South Bay and has spread to Quantuck Bay in Southampton, a Suffolk County official said last week.

title: Crime
description: Four years after the 1831 slave revolt led by Nat Turner in Virginia, black Americans were still being worked like livestock and their white owners were even more fearful of insurrection. In a masterly piece of historical storytelling, Barbara Hambly calls up the horrors of slavery in SOLD DOWN THE RIVER (Bantam, $23.95), the fourth and most unsettling chapter in her remarkable series featuring Benjamin January, a freed slave whose Paris education earns him a living in New Orleans and whose refined sense of justice puts him in peril wherever he goes.

title: Profiles in Courage and Cowardice
description: While agonizing over whether to challenge President Lyndon Johnson in 1968, Robert Kennedy was advised by a friend to stay out of the race but to demand an antiwar plank in the Democratic platform. R.F.K. scoffed, ''When was the last time millions of people rallied behind a plank?''

title: Political Briefing; Mississippi Democrat Is an Also-Ran Again
description: Back in 1964, Mamie Cunningham, then a 22-year-old college student, was one of the black Freedom Democrats from Mississippi who journeyed to the Democratic National Convention in Atlantic City to challenge the all-white makeup of her state's delegation. The challenge caused considerable turmoil, but in the end she was not allowed to be a delegate and was forced to observe the proceedings from the boardwalk outside the convention hall.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: TO KILL THE POPE

title: In a Drug's Journey to Market, Discovery Is Just the First of Many Steps
description: Pharmaceuticals are a risky, but lucrative, business. Drug companies turn scientific advances into life-saving medicines that can generate millions of dollars in sales each day, but the process takes time -- an average of 12 to 15 years -- and money.

title: Lowering the Global Thermostat
description: To the Editor:

title: July 16-22; The Elian of the Animal Kingdom
description: On one side stands a teary-eyed Russian couple whose Brooklyn community has vowed to go to any length to help them keep their adopted pet monkey. On the other side is an adamant state government backed by a host of monkey experts and the power of the endangered-species law.

title: Taxed, Over and Over
description: To the Editor:

title: Hauling Backpacks, And Grades for Gym
description: To the Editor:

title: Beetles by Day, Weevils by Night
description: Japanese beetles, viburnum leaf beetles and Colorado potato beetles are feeding by day, and black vine weevils and twobanded Japanese weevils by night. Handpick them and crush or drop into soapy water. To control the next generation of weevils, drench soil with beneficial nematodes until early fall. Lots of rain and temperatures above 75 are perfect for the fungus phytophora, which afflicts snapdragons and other popular annuals. If they suddenly wilt, remove and destroy them. PATRICIA JONAS

title: MetroStars Enter Break With 5 Straight Victories
description: The MetroStars keep marching over opponents the way they were stepped on last season, when they finished last in Major League Soccer. After today's 4-2 triumph over the Miami Fusion at sunbathed Giants Stadium, the MetroStars have the most points (41) and most victories (13) going into the league's All-Star Game next Saturday.

title: Corrections
description: The Correspondent's Report article on Page 3 of the Travel section today includes an outdated reference to a bill in the House of Representatives dealing with travel to Cuba. On Thursday, after the section had gone to press, the House approved a measure to bar the Treasury Department from enforcing restrictions on travel to Cuba. No companion measure was before the Senate.

title: Reckonings; Saints and Profits
description: ''Saints,'' wrote George Orwell, ''should always be judged guilty until proved innocent.'' I don't think he was talking about garden-variety hypocrisy -- although many supposed ascetics do turn out to have something to hide. The more important point is that there are other temptations besides those of the flesh. And those who renounce small pleasures may be all the more susceptible to monomania, to the urge to sacrifice the good in pursuit of the perfect. In other words, beware the cause of the rebel without a life.

title: The Education Of a Holy Warrior
description: I'm struck by the similarity between Haqqania madrasa students and the home-schooled children of Christian fundamentalists. Neither group confines its religious fervor to its members, but seeks to change the world around it through both political militancy and personal evangelism. I'm alarmed to see one considered a threat to national security and the other a counterculture curiosity.

title: Window Shoppers
description: Things are looking brighter, quite literally, for the Valhalla Union Free School District because of a $100,000 donation, the biggest the district has ever received.

title: Maggie Tucker, James Gwertzman
description: Maggie Tai Sakaki Tucker, the daughter of Nancy Tucker of Manhattan and Nanao Sakaki of Izu, Japan, was married last evening to James S. Gwertzman, a son of Marie-Jeanne and Bernard Gwertzman of Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. Alma Daniel, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Boathouse in Central Park.

title: July 16-22; Internet Gambling Bill Fails
description: In a blow to casino owners, the House failed to approve a bill to curb the exploding $1.2 billion industry of Internet gambling. Most lawmakers favored banning online casino-style games, sports wagers and lottery sales. But despite wide backing -- from Christian evangelists to liquor store owners -- they fell short of the votes needed to limit debate.

title: Installing a Floor-Mounted Toilet: A Tight Seal Is Important
description: INSTALLING a floor-mounted toilet -- as opposed to the type mounted on a wall -- is not difficult, but it has to be done carefully and methodically or else the toilet will leak.

title: July 16-22; Congress Approves Tax Cut To Help Married Couples
description: Congress finished work on a Republican bill to give an election-year tax break to married couples. But President Clinton, saying the measure was too costly, promised to veto it. The bill would provide $292 billion in tax cuts over the next decade, and was intended in part to address the marriage penalty, the quirk in the tax code that forces many two-income couples to pay a higher tax bill than they would if they had remained single. Democrats said they also want to address the penalty, but do it in a less expensive way that directs more benefits to low- and middle-income people. RICHARD W. STEVENSON

title: Clock Is Ticking for Mets and Larkin
description: The Mets are prepared to go to great lengths to persuade Barry Larkin to join them. But the one thing they are unwilling to do is the one thing Larkin most wants from them. Because the Mets will not give him a contract extension, the 36-year-old Cincinnati Reds shortstop seems likely to stay put.

title: Discovering Borders That Blend, a la Monet
description: GERTRUDE JEKYLL may be the Elvis of the gardening world. Dead since 1932, her presence is everywhere. Gardeners from Trenton to Tokyo speak her name in reverent tones, and make pilgrimages to Munstead, her English home. A pair of her gardening boots is even enshrined in the Museum of Garden History in London.

title: When Do an Ex-Spouse's Obligations End?
description: THEY were married for almost 18 years and had a nice lifestyle: no children, great apartment near Lincoln Center, travel, dinner parties. He was a respected research scientist. She ran her own public relations firm.

title: DEVELOPMENT PLANS REJECTED
description: The White Plains Common Council has rejected two plans for development of a 121-acre parcel of land adjacent to downtown and owned by New York Presbyterian Hospital. The first plan, a request for rezoning, called for commercial and residential development over much of the open portions of the site in return for a donation of 60 acres to the city for use as a park. After the council rejected it 5-2 early Tuesday morning, they unanimously refused the hospital's second effort, a more modest plan for development that did not include a park. That move has prompted the hospital to consider a lawsuit which, according to city attorneys, the city is likely to lose. PETER BELLER

title: Sports of The Times; Victorious Spain Says It's All About Team
description: SPAIN has been one big happy tennis family here this week, including its latest addition, Joan Vehils, the television journalist who married Arantxa Sanchez-Vicario on Friday night in Barcelona, a wedding attended by 650 and featuring a cake that was bigger than the bride.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Will Work With Fujimori

title: Streetscapes/245 Fenimore Street in the Prospect Lefferts Gardens Historic District; Two Opposing Sides in the Debate Over Vinyl Siding
description: WANT to bring a room of preservationists to a rolling boil? Just say two words: ''vinyl siding.'' In many communities you'll see plenty of nice old houses cloaked with vinyl, aluminum and asphalt coverings. It's just the kind of thing historic district regulations are designed to prevent, and even dedicated vinyl lovers in historic districts don't even bother to apply because they know they'll be turned down.

title: Drug Overdose Kills Man In Chelsea Club, Police Say
description: A student visiting New York from Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore died early yesterday, apparently from a drug overdose, after collapsing on the dance floor of a popular nightclub in Chelsea, the authorities said.

title: Where's the Outrage?
description: To the Editor:

title: Festival of Music To Skate By
description: IT was a mix of music and motion that came to a lot near the boardwalk in Asbury Park last weekend as the Warped Tour 2000 made its second of two stops in the state. It had played earlier in the week in Camden. This is the sixth year for the traveling punk rock festival, which makes 40 stops across the country and in Canada in a six-week run. The tour ends on Aug. 6 in Texas.

title: Applause Greets Mrs. Clinton at Long Island Synagogue
description: In her first public appearance before a Jewish audience since she was accused of making an anti-Semitic slur, Hillary Rodham Clinton attended Saturday services at a synagogue here today and received a generally warm welcome.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for JEFFREY SKILLING; Turning Broadband Into a Commodity
description: ENRON, the Houston-based utility and energy giant, last week announced a 20-year agreement with Blockbuster to deliver movies on demand into homes, as a digitized video stream over fiber optic lines, including the thousands of miles installed by Enron itself.

title: Laura Whipple, Kristian Whalen
description: Laura Cook Whipple, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Whipple III of Meadowbrook, Pa., was married yesterday to Kristian Michael Whalen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Terrence M. Whalen of Mississauga, Ontario. The Rev. Dr. Raymond Roberts performed the ceremony at Grace Presbyterian Church in Jenkintown, Pa.

title: Corrections
description: Two picture credits with the cover article on Pages 4 and 5 of the Television section today, about the Lifetime series ''Strong Medicine,'' misstate the surname of the photographer. He is Robert Voets, not Boets.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about talent agents who represent workers in various fields misspelled the name of a Boston agency whose clients are Web designers and other computer workers. It is Aquent Inc., not Aguent.

title: Toronto Transit
description: To the Editor: As an ex-New Yorker, now a resident of Toronto, I thought that ''Toronto: Melting Pot With a Dash of Disco'' (June 25) covered well the major good points of the city. The only thing I would disagree with is renting a car. Toronto has one of the best and safest public transit systems in North America. Moreover, parking is neither plentiful nor cheap. For a mere $7 Canadian a day, the cost of a day pass, a person can travel all over the city and even to such distant parts as the zoo, on the eastern fringe of the city.

title: Death, Taxes And Letting The Heirs Foot the Bill
description: AMERICANS should not be taxed when they die,'' declared Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the Republican chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, just before the House voted last month to end what opponents of the estate tax call the ''death tax.''

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Keeping Down the Competition; How Companies Stall Generics And Keep Themselves Healthy
description: The stakes were high on Feb. 2, 1998, when Zenith Goldline Pharmaceuticals and Abbott Laboratories squared off here in patent court. For three years, the companies had been fighting about whether Zenith could market a generic version of Hytrin, Abbott's $500-million-a-year drug for high blood pressure and prostate enlargement. Now a federal appeals judge would hear them out.

title: THEATER; A Pitiless Mirror Where Audiences See Themselves
description: IN the second act of Rebecca Gilman's play ''Spinning Into Butter,'' Sarah Daniels, a dean at the fictional, small and overwhelmingly white Belmont College in Vermont, confesses to a colleague something that few white people would admit even to themselves: she is a racist who hates black people.

title: With Click of a Mouse, Records Get More Public
description: WEEKS ago, when officials here put individual tax information on the Internet, opposition came from the most unlikely source: the town clerk, Alfreda A. Williams. She was no stranger to documenting information, having spent the last seven years recording everything from births to deaths to dog licenses. But she did not like the idea that the click of a mouse could give anyone a titillating glimpse of people's most intimate living spaces, from the size and shape of bedrooms and baths to whether a house is split level or ranch, has a pool or a fireplace.

title: The Hidden Language of the Charts
description: FINANCE professors are by their nature a skeptical lot, but their disdain for the forecasting practice known as charting has been especially notable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, GERALD
description: EPSTEIN-Gerald. My beloved brother. A unique, wonderful man; how I shall miss you. Irma Stecher

description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Bury the Sword But the Question Is Where
description: Just when it was supposed to be safe to go back into Democratic waters, the sharks are out again. And it seems only a matter of time before body parts begin washing up on shore.

title: The Smoke-Free Diner
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil-Tank Cleanups Caught In the Web of Bureaucracy
description: If it takes the Department of Environmental Conservation 13 months to satisfy the liability concerns of just one innocent landowner to win access to investigate a single leaking underground storage tank, one wonders in what new millennium the D.E.C. is planning to survey the other 500,000 tanks on the Island.

title: Clinton Calls Tax-Cut Bills By the G.O.P. Ill-Advised
description: Saying that Republicans in Congress were treating the projected federal budget surplus ''as if they'd won it in the lottery,'' President Clinton today defended his promise to veto the main tax cuts passed by the House and Senate, and he called for bipartisan cooperation in setting the nation's fiscal priorities.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Taking the Big Tepee From the Bronx to Maryland
description: IF you've ever wondered how museums move their collections back and forth, Scott Merritt has the answer: very, very carefully.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q&A column last Sunday about shareholders' ability to claim interest and property-tax deductions on their federal income tax returns misstated the classification of interest earned on a reserve fund. As noted, at least 80 percent of a co-op's income must come from shareholders in order for them to claim the deductions. Interest on a reserve fund is not countable as coming from shareholders, no matter how the fund is used.

title: Chicago Hotel Serves Up Original Art
description: Chicago has a new luxury hotel, and it has designs on being something of an art gallery as well. The Park Hyatt Chicago opened last month in the new 67-story Park Tower at 800 North Michigan Avenue with 203 rooms and a number of works by well-known artists in its public spaces.

title: Our Towns; Public Health Meets Public Relations in the Battle of the Bugs
description: WEST NILE II, the summer sequel, was ready to air. Television cameras recorded the trucks waiting to roll from Westchester County's fire training center, and a demonstration run of a pesticide truck had been held in time for the late news.

title: Great Outdoors Is Now a Game
description: Sports has gone to the dogs, and fish, and ax-wielders. In its never-endingpursuit of programming, ESPN created and organized the Great Outdoor Games, which started Thursday and end today in Lake Placid, N.Y. More than 200 competitors in 21 events are vying for $300,000 in prizes.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Bone by Bone, by Peter Matthiessen. (Vintage International, $14.) The last of three novels about the life and times of Edgar J. Watson -- cane planter, entrepreneur and mass murderer -- recounts his conquest of Florida's Gulf Coast, an obsession with echoes in the imperialistic impulses of a growing America. ''This is a work of genuine dignity,'' Sven Birkerts wrote in the Book Review in 1999.

title: Nancy Harrison, Michael Lascher
description: Nancy Lynne Harrison, a daughter of Shelley and Gilbert Harrison of New York, was married last evening at her parents' house in Southampton, N.Y., to Michael Eric Lascher, a son of Sheila Bordo Silver of Newburgh, N.Y., and the late Gerald B. Lascher. Cantor William Satzman officiated.

title: Summer's Destinations
description: In support of Hamptons art and New Jersey history.

title: Schubert Takes a Hand In a Clever Film Score
description: ONE of the cleverest moments in the clever score for Istvan Szabo's film ''Sunshine'' occurs toward the end, when old Uncle Gustave Sonnenschein returns home to Budapest from abroad. He goes to the piano, ostensibly to play the opening of Schubert's four-hand Fantasy in F minor, which has served as the movie's leitmotif. But to remind us that he is a socialist, the tune immediately turns into the ''Marseillaise.''

title: Niche Marketing
description: To the Editor:

title: TAG Aviation Forms Partnership With Cessna
description: Cessna Aircraft Company and the Harrison-based TAG Aviation U.S.A. have formed a new company to serve the expanding ''fractional ownership market,'' whereby businesses acquire a share of an airplane rather than buying full ownership.

title: 20 Terms, and Still Counting
description: JACK LOMBARDI, 75, is broad shouldered and silver haired and has the vigor of a man much younger. In a clipped voice, he asks questions of everyone he meets.

title: Hall Opens Its Doors to a Star Once Shunned
description: Last spring, an off-Broadway theater presented ''Cobb,'' an intriguing play about a well-documented baseball icon from the early 20th century. Three actors portrayed Ty Cobb at different periods of his life. Meeting moments after the death of the Georgia Peach, the three Cobbs debated his athletic greatness, his racism and his fiery temperament.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on July 9 about the reopening of the Savoy Hotel in Florence referred incorrectly to the first occupant of the building. The banker for whom it was built in 1893 was Italian; a news release referred to him as an Israelite because he was Jewish, but Israeli nationality has existed only since 1948.

title: Island's Nuclear Era Is Ending
description: JOANN MAGNUS was suffering from glioblastoma multiforme, a lethal form of brain cancer. Doctors told Ms. Magnus, a 50-year-old Westbury woman, that she would be fortunate to live for a year, but she had heard about an experimental program at Brookhaven National Laboratory that could give her more time.

title: Where Patrons Can Watch the Sunset
description: DINERS who frequented Coolmore on this pretty spot in the Vista section here will feel at home at the newly named Saratoga Grill. Excepting the name, not too much has changed. A half-hearted racing motif persists in racing silks hanging about and racetrack related photographs and posters, but this theme is still a bit of a stretch, conflicting as it does with terra cotta tiles, stonework and arches, which were custom made to reflect the Tuscan interior of an Italian restaurant that once occupied this site.

title: One Foot in Motown, One in Led Zeppelin
description: ON a hot July night, the Bowery Ballroom on the Lower East Side was packed with lager-sipping hipsters waiting for the arrival of rock's next big thing. She was an hour late, but when she bounded onto the stage in a floor-length red suede skirt, a white tank top and gold hoop earrings, the crowd chanted her name: ''Ki-na! Ki-na!''

title: Without a Bridge, Community Awaits Its Fate
description: GEORGE KOSTA got his wish of living in a serene island setting about 21 years ago when he bought a three-bedroom cottage on the 145-acre, sandy peninsula known as Pleasure Beach Island.

title: No Longer Bulletproof, but Feeling Bullish Again
description: TOO much, too soon.

title: Taking Names in Vaduz
description: Simultaneously sustaining an air of rectitude and a tradition of banking secrecy is getting harder and harder.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Lissie Backus, Michael Donnelly
description: Allison Christiana Backus, a daughter of Theresa and Dennis Backus of Mill Neck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael H. Donnelly, a son of Theresa and Kenneth Donnelly of Toms River, N.J. The Rev. Bernadette M. Sullivan performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, N.Y.

title: Anne of Green Gables, Married Lady
description: That freckle-faced, red-haired orphan girl with a knack for trouble is back.

title: Corrections
description: A map on May 28 with the What's Doing column, about Salt Lake City, mislabeled a street. A reader's letter received June 12 pointed out that the street was 800 West, not 8th West. This correction was delayed by an editing oversight.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing on Page 33 of Arts & Leisure today for Lincoln Center Festival 2000 misstates the days for two events in the ''Caribbean Roots: Caribbean Routes'' series and omits one event. ''Nyabinghi Spirit: The Heartbeat of Reggae'' is tomorrow at 9, not today. ''Griots of the West Indies: Dub Poetry and Calypso'' is Thursday at 8, not Wednesday. The listing omits ''Mizik Racine and the Rhythm of Vodou'' with Boukman Eksperyans, Wednesday at 9 at the Society for Ethical Culture, Central Park West at 64th Street.

title: Ideas & Trends; Under the Influence of Gifts, Coupons and Cash
description: IF money changes everything, why not use it on people?

title: Bobby Labonte Seeks To Regain Momentum
description: Jimmy Makar suddenly noticed something wrong with Bobby Labonte's bright green race car Friday afternoon. Makar strode purposefully over to the front fender, fished in his pocket, pulled out a pocketknife, then meticulously whittled away a loose sliver of fluorescent red tape no more than a quarter-inch wide.

title: Laura Kresch, Charles Curran III
description: Laura Emily Kresch, the daughter of Sheila and Robert Kresch of White Plains, is to be married today to Charles Christopher Curran III, a son of Dianne Curran of Bothell, Wash., and Mr. Curran Jr. of Seattle. Rabbi Ari Fridkis is to perform the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Jostle Controls Pace and Race At Belmont
description: The 3-year-old filly Jostle found a new way to endure a distance race and outrun the championship ambitions of Secret Status yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALVO, ANTONIO
description: CALVO-Antonio. Born in 1907 in Riobao, Sada, Spain. Died peacefully at his home on July 21, 2000. Beloved husband of Erundina for 60 years, cherished father of Asuncion (Sue) Otero, father-in-law to Joseph A. Otero, adored grandfather of Alessandra Otero Reiss, Antonio Jose Otero and Mark R. Reiss, great-grandfather of Matteo Joseph Reiss, and dear uncle of many. Ex-President of ''La Nacional.'' Founding member and former President of Spanish American Citizens Club of Queens. Member of ''Casa Galicia.'' Reposing at Peter R. Angerame Funeral Home, 27-12 23rd Ave., Astoria, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday, 9:30 AM, at St. Francis of Assisi R.C. Church, 21st Ave., Astoria.

title: In Williamsburg, a Club Tests Tolerance for the Hip
description: How hip is too hip? It depends on which Williamsburger you ask.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about investing in Audiovox, the mobile telephone handset provider, misstated its closing stock price and price-to-earnings multiple for Friday, July 14. The stock closed at $20.625, not $31.375, and was trading at 10.9 times estimated 2001 earnings, not 17.

title: A Quintet of Jerusalem Hotels
description: ON Israel's independence day this May, the electricity in our Je rusalem apartment suddenly blew out. We knew the holiday would make it impossible to get an electrician until the next morning.

title: The Microsoft (and Gates) of the Genome Industry
description: WHEN President Clinton announced last month at a White House ceremony that scientists had effectively mapped the human genetic code, the man who was arguably most responsible for the achievement was not in the room. The man, Michael W. Hunkapiller, was home with chicken pox.

title: Coming Unwired
description: SUNNYVALE

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last week about comparisons between the Israeli-Palestinian and Northern Ireland conflicts misstated the date of the Good Friday peace agreement in Northern Ireland. It was 1998, not 1988.

title: NEW JERSEY & CO.; Have Food Truck, Will Travel
description: The parking lot on College Avenue has the feel and the smell -- of a Middle Eastern bazaar on wheels. A cacophony of sales pitches emanate from the eight food trucks that enclose the lot.

title: Russia's Venue of Choice for Cops and Robbers
description: IN Soviet days, filmmakers came to this graceful city looking for a backdrop for historical dramas with men in top hats and ladies smothered in furs dashing along snowy streets in horse-drawn sleighs.

title: Gay and Lesbian Couples Head for Vermont to Make It Legal, but How Legal Is It?
description: This week, Jennifer Kacak and Jill Poste drove more than five hours from their home in Suffern, N.Y., to this maple-sweet Vermont town to get as close as they could to marrying.

title: Switching Careers, and Continents
description: So what do you do if you're 53 and have already had a been-there-done-that academic career? If you're George Stephanopoulos -- no, not that George Stephanopoulos; this one, unrelated, is a professor of chemical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology -- you switch careers and hemispheres. He is taking a stab at turning Japan's largest petrochemical company, Mitsubishi Chemical, into a force in the risky but profitable world of nanochemistry, microreplication and the like.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IT seems a little too 60's now, with those strange insets and pretentious split screens, but they're only in a few scenes. What makes Ralph Nelson's CHARLY (1968) a must-see-again is the remarkable (Oscar-winning) performance by Cliff Robertson. The story, from Daniel Keyes's ''Flowers for Algernon,'' is about a gentle mentally retarded man who becomes a genius through experimental surgery, then learns that it's all too good to be true. It's not Mr. Robertson's protrayal of Charly's early limitations that's impressive; it's the evolution of the character into all kinds of awareness, conveyed with subtleties that most actors can only read about. Claire Bloom is lovely as the teacher who guides him through the changes and becomes more involved than she'd intended - Sunday at 2 p.m. on A&E.

title: A Big Crowd That Aspires To Be a Mob

Actors including Avery Brooks, Susan Sarandon and Meryl Streep are helping promote the state's ''Discover Jersey Arts'' effort, intended to make residents and visitors more aware of the Garden State's theaters, museums, galleries and concert halls. One television ad features a sultry Ms. Sarandon, who was born in Edison, traveling on the New Jersey Turnpike and stopping to collect a few stares as well as a brochure about the arts. Other celebrities in the campaign, which began this month, have ties to the state; some, such as Mr. Brooks (''Star Trek: Deep Space Nine''), are residents. title: One Clinic, Two Very Different Doctors

This year, CBS's ''City of Angels,'' an inner-city hospital drama that is struggling in the ratings, will return for a second season while ABC's ''Wonderland,'' set in a mental hospital, was canceled shortly after its pilot was broadcast in March.

title: Food; The Death of French Food, Part 1
description: After mother's milk, the three greatest cuisines in the world are French, Chinese and Junque. (I have a special unpublished hot line for chauvinists from Italy, Japan and Myanmar who think otherwise.) We are a nation dedicated to novelty, and thus chaotic fusionists, vertical foodites and Those Who Would Put Mangoes on Beefsteak currently overrun our trendier eating establishments. Classic French food, once dismissed for its fussiness and barbell content, now seems simple and authoritative by comparison. Recent French food seems even more so.

title: Real C.O.O.L.
description: The New Jersey State in Camden is reaching far beyond the state waters for its latest exhibition, Conservation Outreach and Observation Lab or C.O.O.L., which opened this month. C.O.O.L., which features unusual animals of South and Central America, the Caribbean and the Pacific and Indian Oceans, is designed to promote conservation of endangered and threatened species and habitats. The keel-billed toucan from South America, which has a rainbow-striped beak, is part of the new South American bird aviary. A coral reef with colorful and unusual fish has been added. Other exhibits include such animals as the South American coypu (shown), a cousin of the beaver. The female of the furry, three-foot long animal has mammary glands on its back so it can feed its young while it is swimming. The Indo-Pacific C.O.O.L. animals include the Banggai cardinal fish, which is part of a breeding program at the aquarium designed to save the species from extinction. KAREN DEMASTERS

title: Corrections
description: A review of ''Marie Antoinette: The Last Queen of France,'' by Evelyne Lever, in the Book Review last Sunday referred incorrectly to some relationships within the French royal family and misspelled the name of one figure. Marie Leszczynska (not Leszcynska), wife to Louis XV, was a great-granddaughter-in-law of Louis XIV and his queen, not their daughter-in-law. Louis XV had no sisters; he had seven daughters, and four of them lived well into the era of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette or survived it.

title: The End of Innocence

Scott writes (The Way We Live Now, July 2), the zeal for Harry Potter is simply part of the ''blockbuster-driven culture'' in which ''new books linger on the front tables of Barnes & Noble for a few weeks, then head for the pulp mills,'' why has the first book in the series lingered on the best-seller list for 80 weeks in hardcover? The real story isn't the consummate marketing of Harry Potter; it's the fact that our generation is lucky to have a novelist who brings magic to storytelling. Scholastic's marketing department could not have ''cooked up'' this kind of excitement; J.K. Rowling did, and more power to her.

Many of my friends also oppose this discrimination but plan to continue in scouting anyway. Aren't they wrong to do so? -- Lynn Winter, Port Washington, N.Y.

title: Tales From Aloft
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''How to Survive Economy Class'' (June 25): I have discovered a way to fight back against the person in front of me who keeps the seat tilted back all the way. I wait for the passenger to go to the toilet, or even to lean forward for a few seconds, and then I quickly push the seatback forward several inches. It moves easily. Nobody has yet noticed the difference.

title: QUICK BITE/Montclair; A Curry, and Tandoori and a Story
description: Cousin Helen went to India once and never needs prodding to talk about the trip. Nestled in a cozy Indian restaurant, her tales flow like the Ganges itself: There's the one about the snake charmer who wouldn't let him take his picture unless she gave him 100 rupees. Or the one about the elephant guide who charged her pennies to ride his lumbering pachyderm down a canyon, and a hundred times that to get back up. And Helen's description of the Taj Mahal -- a shimmering marble jewel in a sea of poverty -- is likely to move one to tears. The backdrop for her latest reverie proved equally powerful. Karma Kafe, a stylish ''Indian bistro'' owned by Mehernosh Daroowalla, host of the more traditional India on the Hudson in the Mile Square City, offers a nifty seven-day-a-week lunch special for budget-minded folks who hate fussing with menus. Only $8.95 and you eat for as long as you can take the heat. Gurmeej Singh, the chef, has assembled the perfect sampler of popular dishes: tandoori chicken, saag paneer (creamed spinach cooked gently with Singh's handmade cottage cheese cubes), dal tandoori (hot lentil sauce) to spoon over your pea-and-rice pulao. There's chicken curry, peas and potatoes, and plenty of naan to sop it all up, not to mention a bowlful of dill yogurt to cool your palate for dessert. That dessert'll be extra, big spender, but worth the splurge. The regular menu offers Indian dishes for us chic western types: tandoori wraps and crawfish vindaloo, anyone? There's a hip-looking bar, a window seat, and a televison that, alas, does not broadcast classics from Indian cinema. Your own tales of the East will have to suffice; Cousin Helen does not do parties.

He said he had no ''magic wand'' to reform the ailing state-run economy, would not budge from his father's rejection of any compromise with Israel and invited Syrians to express themselves -- but only with ''positive criticism.'' title: Getting A Message Across, Loudly

He is an old-school free-jazz preacher, ordained in the church of John Coltrane and Pharoah Sanders. A fierce and seemingly inexhaustible improviser, he favors gnarled, guttural utterances that slowly build into shattering crescendos. It's as if he were fighting against the limits of his instrument to evoke the throes of spiritual ecstasy. He's not especially subtle, but he gets his message across efficiently and at a volume where it cannot be ignored.

title: Home, When the Heart Is Elsewhere

Yes, I realize, I'm totally exhausted. I stroke our cats, defrost some homemade soup and soon send my husband, James, to his office so I can luxuriate in having the house to myself. No, I am not going to travel again for a long time. Months and months, maybe longer. Who knows when I'll ever be ready to study another guidebook or decipher another map? I am tired of looking at menus. I can't bear to sleep in any more strange bedrooms. I want to forget all those uneasy searches for public toilets.

description: Court proceedings inside the Immigration and Naturalization Service jail on Terminal Island, 30 miles south of Los Angeles, are customarily conducted out of sight -- the I.N.S. does not welcome press and public -- and out of mind of the world at large. The judge, without benefit of a court reporter, pecks notes into a laptop, periodically interrupting testimony to change tapes on a cassette recorder. Lawyers, guards, defendants' families and the very occasional reporter cram into three short rows of wooden benches. There is little majesty of the law here.

title: Another View On Watersheds
description: To the Editor:

title: MEAT PACKER CHARGED
description: The owner of a slaughterhouse in Salem County has been charged for the third time in 14 years for environmental violations.

title: Can REIT's Become A Technology Play?
description: REAL estate investment trusts have played yin of late to the technology sector's yang.

title: Slipping Through Stream and Bay by Kayak
description: EACH morning, when the skies above the sea are still shot with pink, Brian Coen rises, dresses and hurries out to keep his date with the tide. By 8 a.m., his boats are ready by the dock in Harvey Cedars, when tourists start showing up.

title: A Salty Sliver of Island Life; In the City of Change, a Pocket of the Bronx Is Content to Stick to Its Small-Town Ways
description: Jacqueline Kyle Kall was doing what she does best, talking. Here she was coming into Artie's restaurant for lunch. Everyone seemed tickled to see her. She ate here a lot. The waitress plunked down her usual drink, a double martini, known as Jackie's Martini.

title: Suffolk Buys 36 Acres, Blocking Housing Plans
description: The Suffolk County Parks Department has bought a much-disputed 36-acre parcel of land in Stony Brook, blocking a planned housing development.

title: Co-op Board's Powers
description: Q: Do co-op boards have the right to unilaterally make decisions such as cutting down trees without consulting other members of the co-op? What recourse do I have? Can I take out an injunction? . . . Kathryn M. Mets, Forest Hills

title: Video Store Closing After 16 Years
description: Video Connection, a rental store at Broadway and 80th Street, is closing at the end of the month. The retailer has been a neighborhood fixture since opening in 1984, not only as a source for unusual movies but also for social life.

title: Beyond the Fringe And Off the Radar
description: SOMETIMES, in a busy life, the need to make art wells up unexpectedly and turns that life around. There is no way to predict the onset of this condition, nor is there any known cure. It can strike anyone, anywhere.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Joe Eszterhas; The Id That Had Polyps
description: GEORGE W. was getting into full stride and pulling some pretty decent laughs. Bill Clinton was making some comic headway explaining the cosmic unfairness of the whole Monica thing. (''A little reward. Just a little reward. A piece of angel food cake to recharge my batteries.'') Monica told all, once again, to Linda Tripp. And Joe Eszterhas, sitting front row center at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater on Monday night, listening to the words of his ''American Rhapsody'' wash over him, expertly delivered by seven actors, looked like a happy man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, WILLIAM
description: MURPHY-William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William Murphy, associated with The Times since 1983.

title: Josephine Martin, Healer of Rights Workers, Dies at 84
description: Dr. Josephine D. Martin, a psychiatrist who helped rootless children, troubled adolescents and terrified civil rights activists in a lifelong crusade to weld the healing of personal and social wounds, died on July 6 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. She was 84.

title: Retirement Plans, Made Easier
description: In an effort to bolster retirement savings by middle- and lower-income families, the Treasury announced tax rules last week intended to encourage more employers to automatically enroll workers in retirement plans.

title: HATE CRIME RESENTENCING
description: The prison sentence for a Vineland man was reduced last week to 7 years from 12 years to conform with a recent ruling by the United States Supreme that overturned New Jersey's 1981 bias crime law. Charles Apprendi, who had shot at the home of the only black family in his Vineland neighborhood, had pled guilty to three weapons charges and his sentence was extendedby Superior Court Judge Rushton Ridgway, who decided the crime was motivated by bias. The Supreme Court ruled that only a jury, not a judge, should decide motivation, as New Jersey allowed, and that Mr. Apprendi's sentence had to be reduced.

description: The Hillary Trap

title: Voodoo Box Office: PG-13-Ness
description: THE story goes like this: Several people are walking down the middle of the street in the middle of the night. Suddenly, a truck comes along and flattens them. How can you tell which one is the movie studio executive? He's the guy who jumps up and says, ''Here's why that just happened.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACKSTON, JESSIE
description: BLACKSTON-Jessie. On May 2, 2000. Beloved mother of Richard Blackston of New York City and Evelyn Smith of Memphis, TN. She worked in the NYC Board of Education System. She was Chairperson of Local No. 372 Union, For School Health Aides and was an Executive Board Member. She was Chairperson of the Consumer Advocate Committee and The Coalition of Black Trade Unionists. She was a Full Service Missionary in her home as a mother and community activist where she truly walked in the Christian way. Along with her two children she will be missed by her mother, Laura Myers; her sister, Ethel Corbin; and a host of cousins, nephews, nieces, grandchildren, greatgrandchildren and other relatives and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPORTE, MARGERY COLEMAN
description: LaPORTE - Margery Coleman. Died on Wednesday of heart failure at her nursing home in Illinois. She was the wife of the late Walter LaPorte; mother of Stephen, David and Tom LaPorte, Marjorie Brillhart and Ann Colton; grandmother of six grandchildren, and sister of Patricia Gehron and Joan Coleman. In lieu of flowers, kindly donate to your local hospice.

title: U.S. RECOMMENDING STRICT NEW RULES AT NURSING HOMES
description: Federal health officials have concluded that most nursing homes are understaffed to the point that patients may be endangered. For the first time, the government is recommending strict new rules that would require thousands of the homes to hire more nurses and health aides.

title: For Bus Line, a Question of Where to Turn
description: A proposal by the Metropolitan Transit Authority to use three Riverdale side streets to turn buses around has upset some neighborhood leaders and residents of this quiet area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENNETT, ROCHELLE
description: SENNETT-Rochelle. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Rochelle Sennett, beloved sister of our devoted members, Stephanie and Elliott Burko. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, DR. NORMAN
description: MORRIS-Dr. Norman. Of New York City, though he suffered with Parkinson's Disease for years, he died suddenly on July 16, 2000. He was recently widowed from Virginia Arnett. Survived by his children, Julie Morris, Adam Morris and Alissa Abelson, also his brother Danny, his nephew Steven, his cousin Robert and their families, and his grandchildren Kate and David Abelson. He graduated from NYU Medical School in 1954. He worked in Bellevue, Beth Israel, Sloan - Kettering, Greenpoint and Brookdale Hospital specializing first in head and neck surgery, then emergency room care. He was also a Medical Examiner for NYU for many years. He was involved in the Civil Rights Movement and marched with Dr. Martin Luther King in Selma, AL. He will be greatly missed. There will be no funeral service as per his wishes. Anyone wishing to remember him in a donation to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, care of Columbia University Medical Center, would be greatly appreciated.

title: What If You Made a Classic, and No One Cared?
description: EVERY up-and-coming rock band knows how unpleasant it is to haul around vanloads of heavy equipment, but the Jayhawks' burden is worse than most. In addition to amplifiers, monitors and bulky instrument cases, the members have to deal with the daily grind of hoisting the massive chip they carry on their collective shoulders. Before a recent show at Maxwell's in Hoboken, N.J., Gary Louris, the lead singer, spoke about his motivation for making ''Smile,'' the Jayhawks' sixth and latest album. ''I think we feel like we don't get the respect or the attention we deserve,'' he said. ''I think we feel a little bit slighted on both ends, on the artistic and the commercial sides. For some reason we still feel like we want to prove something.''

title: What Would You Do?
description: HERE'S a little real life morality play about suburban life and manners in sedate northern Westchester.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Moods of the Rich and Famous
description: What is most striking about the celebrity portraits that Arnold Newman photographed for Life, Look and other magazines is their elegant simplicity. As shown in ARNOLD NEWMAN (Taschen, $39.99), the photographer has focused his camera primarily on artists, writers and political figures for the past 60 years. He usually captures his famous subjects with revealing backgrounds or telling compositions. A pensive Stravinsky is seated at a grand piano that dwarfs the composer as its raised lid resembles an abstract sculpture of a musical note. Poised on a sofa with wide stripes -- and matching wallpaper -- an amused Diana Vreeland makes her fashion statement with a robe that clashes, yet oddly complements the pattern. Robert Moses is depicted standing messianically on a steel beam suspended over the East River, with blueprints in hand and the Manhattan skyline as backdrop. As if to remind us that photography is, in a sense, painting with a newfangled brush, Newman had several artists pose with an easel or a blank canvas framing their heads, including Mondrian, de Chirico, Man Ray, Georgia O'Keeffe and Hans Hofmann. Recent photos of Woody Allen and President Clinton testify that Newman has lost none of his skill for apprehending an inner mood with an outer expression. David Kaufman

title: An 'Antigone' From Africa, By Way of France
description: THE French choreographer Mathilde Monnier thrives on the unexpected. Her version of the Greek tragedy ''Antigone,'' for example, unfolds on a minimalist African landscape with a car seat and corrugated-tin siding as decor.

title: Using Parsley on Its Own as the Main Ingredient
description: PARSLEY rarely plays a leading role in a dish. Most often it serves as a useless piece of decoration. ''It takes up little space in the literature of food, probably because it is so ubiquitous that it has become commonplace,'' Waverly Root wrote in ''Food.'' ''Its presence is so much taken for granted that nobody remarks on it.''

title: Polar Opposites? Not Where It Counts; Warren Buffett Gets All the Attention, But Hank Greenberg Is Posting Better Returns
description: ONE plays the part of the hayseed, the other the quintessential New York tough guy, complete with flinty stare and a vocabulary that might stun the crowd at a hip-hop concert. One loves bridge and jokes that he reluctantly drags himself around a golf course; the other is a bundle of energy whose idea of relaxation is rocketing down a frozen ski trail.

title: Katharina Plath, Paul Kaminski
description: Katharina Elisabeth Margarethe Plath and Paul Dallan Kaminski were married on Friday by Manfred Hulsenbruch, a civil marriage official at Schloss Friedrichstein, a baroque castle in Bad Wildungen, Germany. A church ceremony took place yesterday at the Philipp-Nicolai Church in Alt Wildungen. The Rev. Ulrich Branner, a Lutheran minister, officiated with Msgr. Edward Baldwin, a Roman Catholic priest from Detroit.

title: Lives; As Is the Daughter, So Is Her Mother
description: To all my kind friends and professional associates who have shown such tender concern for my psychological health recently, I want to say thank you, I'm fine, really. The truth is, I'm very happy for my mother. Not as in, ''No, really, I'm happy for her.'' I love my mother. Just because she's becoming a celebrity does nothing to lessen my feelings for her. It's not as if I'm too busy to give Entertainment Weekly a quick quote about what she was like before her novel came out.

description: The Kimco Realty Corporation of New Hyde Park (NYSE: KIM) declared a regular quarterly dividend on its Class A preferred stock of 48.4 cents per depository share, to be paid Aug. 15 to shareholders of record on Aug. 1.

title: Cindy Breslawsky, Jason Drahzal
description: Cindy Robin Breslawsky, the daughter of Debbie and Marc Breslawsky of Weston, Conn., was married yesterday to Jason Edward Drahzal, the son of Ellen Bragan of Punta Gorda, Fla., and John Drahzal of Brewster, N.Y. Roger Sirlin, the village justice for Mamaroneck, N.Y., and an uncle of the bride, officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

description: CELESTE LOPES sang out as she galloped around the outdoor arena astride her chestnut show horse, Trocaire, whom she affectionately calls Pumpkin.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about living in Millburn Township, N.J., misstated the range of ticket prices at the Paper Mill Playhouse. It is $36 to $60, not $18 to $38.

title: Tales From Aloft
description: To the Editor: Nowhere in the ''To Do'' list with David Leonhardt's article ''Promises in the Sky'' (June 25) did I see any promise by the airlines to expedite the movement and handling of people on the check-in-lines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERNSTOFF, MARIAN SCHECHTMAN
description: ERNSTOFF-Marian Schechtman. Adored wife to Sam Ernstoff; Devoted Mother to Susie, Jeffrey and Nessa. Beloved relative and friend; Sisterhood President of Temple B'nai Israel, Midwood; Teacher in Belle Harbor, NY and CT; President of CT Club, Century Village, Boca Raton. She endures in all those touched by her playfulness, intelligence and loyalty.

title: July 16-22; Missile Offer by North Korea
description: America needs a missile defense, some say, because of countries like North Korea. One solution, according to Vladimir V. Putin, Russia's president, who is rallying opposition to themissile plan, is to remove North Korea from the equation. So he traveled to Pyongyang, coming away with a North Korean offer to drop its missile program -- if other nations provide it with rockets to launch satellites. But that's a big if. As a former Pentagon official put it, it's still unclear just ''what is going on in North Korea.'' HUBERT B. HERRING

title: Smitten by the Subway
description: IF you have set foot on a subway platform during the last 20 years, there is a decent chance he has been standing there next to you, a small, smiling man in no hurry to catch a train.

title: Commercial Property/Creating an Online Lease Market; Can Office Space Be Traded Like Winter Wheat?
description: TOM FALUS said he was feeling a lot like Chuck Yeager these days. Just like the first man to break the sound barrier in aviation, Mr. Falus is trying to push the envelope of real estate transactions by helping develop a system for doing the often-complex deals over the Internet.

title: Thai, Where a Pizza Hut Once Ruled
description: TINGLING taste buds, full stomachs and intact wallets result from a visit to the seven-month-old Lemongrass Grill, a Thai bargain in East Patchogue. What was once a Pizza Hut, at 760 Montauk Highway (631-475-8288), is now a serene, subdued spot, serving front-and-center Thai dishes. The assertive flavors of dried chili peppers, lemongrass, coconut milk, coriander seeds, basil and numerous other Thai herbs pervade the peppery preparations.

title: A Tintoretto Reappears In Rural Pennsylvania
description: THE Jesuit Center here stands in a lush, rolling, Gainsborough-like landscape some seven miles west of Reading. Opened in 1930 as a novitiate, the imposing, slightly incongruous red brick building now serves as a Jesuit retirement home. As in most small, contained communities, the residents are not accustomed to seeing strangers. When the elderly priests look up from their dinners to watch the Rev. J. A. Panuska, who directs the Jesuit residence, lead a visitor into the refectory, they already know what has brought the outsider here.

title: Colleges to Collaborate On Commerce Links
description: Pace University has formed a partnership with SUNY New Paltz and Marist College in Poughkeepsie to link computer science research to electronic commerce services.

title: PULSE; Working for Carrots
description: Most people know Amy Sedaris as the sister of the writer David Sedaris or as Jerri Blank, the 47-year-old ex-con high-school student she plays on Comedy Central's ''Strangers With Candy.'' What people don't know is that when Ms. Sedaris is not cooking up goofball comedy bits, she's busy with a baked goods business called Tattletail, specializing in homemade cupcakes and cheese balls. Tattletail, named after Ms. Sedaris's pet rabbit, began two years ago in the kitchen of her Greenwich Village apartment as an answer to sleepless nights and a means to keep her bunny pampered.

title: A Glossy Fund Sets Its Debut
description: Wired and Fortune magazines are used to competing for advertisers, circulation, staff members and attention. So why not mutual fund dollars?

title: Keeping Their Eyes On High-Tech Fortunes
description: Americans who have grown rich in high-technology industries are highly likely to have made plans to preserve their wealth and to pass it along to their heirs, the United States Trust Company found in an annual survey.

title: Mideast Talks Take a Shift To Low Gear
description: The peace teams at the Camp David summit meeting moved into a waiting-for-President-Clinton mode today as the Jewish Sabbath imposed an informal day of small group discussions.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Self-Storage Goes High-Tech
description: WITH its double-height windows, two-story-high entrance lobby, clock tower and landscaped parking lot, the white concrete building at the corner of Route 110 and Executive Boulevard could pass for an office building if not for three loading docks at the front and a sign that reads, ''Self-Storage Made Easy.''

title: SOAPBOX; I Love NJY
description: Merger mania continues, with the recent announcements by Phillip Morris/Nabisco Holdings and Vivendi/Seagram. Good mergers benefit customers and owners alike, and not only in the private sector. We recently received this press release.

title: Protesters Warm Up; Mayor Upset; Los Angeles Ready for Democrats
description: Scores of would-be protesters have bivouacked in the Malibu mountains at a training camp featuring vegetarian cooking and classes in climbing skyscrapers. The mayor has published a stern warning against violent protest and nonviolent civil disobedience, with tough talk about rubber bullets and pepper spray, stiff fines and jail. And a federal judge has ruled that the police department's initial plan to keep demonstrators fenced far away from the entrance to the Democratic National Convention was unconstitutionally restrictive.

title: A Canary Island, Away From the Flock
description: IF there is such a thing as tourist hell, it might look something like the view from my taxi as I rode from Tenerife Sur airport in the Canary Islands to the ferry dock: a wall of anonymous concrete-box condos along a beach covered with a thousand blue deck chairs, lined up like parading soldiers. I smiled, for this tourist was only passing through on her way to a place she was pretty sure would be paradise, just an hour's hydrofoil ride away.

title: Learning From the Actors
description: DAVID WILTSE started his career over 30 years ago as a playwright who happened to write novels. Today he considers himself a novelist who writes plays.
