description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STODDARD, GABRIELLA (GAY)
description: STODDARD - Gabriella (Gay) Clark. Of New York City and Sharon, Connecticut. On July 19, after a valiant battle with breast cancer. Beloved wife of Jonathan, devoted sister of Virginia (Ginny) and Gordon (Don), loving aunt of Douglas, David & Daniel, step-mother of Kristi, dear and cherished friend. Funeral service at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th St, 10:00AM, Monday, July 24. Blue Hill Troupers will sing. In lieu of flowers donations can be made in memory of Gabriella to Breast Cancer Research Fund at Weill Cornell Medical College, 525 East 68th Street, New York, NY 10021. She lives in our hearts.

title: Where Sinatra Fills Your Ears, if Not Your Eyes
description: Here's what the critics are saying about Cary Hoffman, the Sinatra interpreter who can be heard every weekend at the Carnegie Club on West 56th Street in Midtown: ''Dead On!'' raves The New York Times.

title: Meredith Bowne, Paul Bove
description: Meredith Sara Bowne, a daughter of Nancee and Edward Bowne of Caldwell, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul E. Bove, a son of Susan Fainstein of New York and Roger Bove of West Chester, Pa. The Rev. Gordon H. Tremaine performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Essex Fells, N.J.

title: Hamptons Serenade
description: Somehow, it is hard to think about the Hamptons in this summer of excess without also thinking about F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''Great Gatsby.'' Though the novel is set in West Egg on a different shore of Long Island, Fitzgerald might as well have been describing the Hamptons in July and August -- ''a night scene by El Greco: a hundred houses, at once conventional and grotesque, crouching under a sullen, overhanging sky and a lusterless moon.'' Like West Egg, the South Fork of Long Island, once a potato patch, is now a land of tycoons and movie stars and models and the kind of people who attend publicity parties for perfumes and wristwatches.

title: SOAPBOX; Simon Who?
description: For generations musical chairs has been harmless fun for children, but a booklet launched by Britain's Labor government urges teachers to ban the game on the ground that it encourages aggression. -- Reuters

title: What Dance Has to Say About Beauty
description: It's probably not surprising that, at the start of a new millennium, artists are reviving old issues with new points of view. Since the advent of modernism, beauty had been questioned as a sufficient, or even necessary, requirement for art. Most recently, it had been dismissed as irrelevant to the avant-garde's concerns with identity and culture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JESSUP, HENRY HERBERT, JR.
description: JESSUP-Henry Herbert, Jr. died peacefully July 19, 2000 at the age of eighty-two at Ron Calli Health Center in Waterford, CT. Beloved husband of Diane Jessup and stepfather of Elisabeth. Loving father of William, Henry, Martyn and Eugenia and grandfather of Brooks, Alex, Olivia, Audrey, Katie, Kelly and Christopher, and brother of John Baker Jessup. Yale graduate 1940, J. Walter Thompson executive, avid sailor, great swimmer, and reader. A memorial service will be held on July 31st, 11:30 am at Christ Church, Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions to Ron Calli Sunshine Fund in memory of Henry H. Jessup, Jr., 7 Rope Ferry Road, Waterford, CT. 06385.

title: CAMDEN PIER
description: The South Jersey Port Corporation will receive $5.4 million from the Delaware River Port Authority to rebuild a terminal in Camden to accommodate the battleship New Jersey while it is being refurbished. The battleship is now docked at the Philadelphia Navy Yard. Once the refurbishing is completed, the ship will be moved to a permanent home on the Delaware near the New Jersey State Aquarium. Karen DeMasters

title: Installing Floor-Mounted Toilet: Seal Is Critical
description: INSTALLING a floor-mounted toilet -- as opposed to the type mounted on a wall -- is not difficult, but it has to be done carefully and methodically or else the toilet will leak.

title: COMMUNITY COLLEGE TUITION
description: One of New Jersey's 19 community colleges will reduce its tuition this fall for in-county students and 11 will hold tuition rates steady, the New Jersey Council of County Colleges announced last week. Sussex County Community College will reduce tuition from $70 per credit last year to $65 this coming year. Community colleges freezing tuition are those in Atlantic-Cape May Countiesone school for both counties and in Monmouth, Burlington, Camden, Cumberland, Hudson, Morris, Passaic, Salem, Union and Warren Counties. The seven colleges increasing tuition raised rates between 1.7 percent and 3.4 percent. Karen DeMasters

title: Nader Talks, Labor Listens and Many Democrats Worry
description: Ralph Nader was on a tear, railing against chief executives' salaries, the corporate-dominated campaign finance system and cuts in factory inspections. Several of the steelworkers seated around him were nodding, and then nodding again, in silent approval.

title: July 16-22; A Slippery Particle Is Found
description: An elusive particle that had been on physicists' Most Wanted list for 25 years has finally been detected, scientists announced at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory. Called the tau neutrino, it is the last of a notoriously slippery family of particles to be seen. Those particles, all neutrinos of various kinds, pass through other matter almost without a trace. But they are crucial elements of the theory that particle physicists believe explains the structure of all matter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAIGE, PETER
description: PAIGE-Peter. Died at Meadowedge, his home in Bellport, NY, on July 21. Peter is survived by his bride of 56 years, Natalie Lambing Paige; three sons, Peter Otis Paige of Yardley, PA, Douglas Warner Paige of Robbinsville, NJ, and Lee Allen Paige of North Andover, MA; two sisters, Mary Paige McGuirk of Bel Air, MD, and Sheila Paige Dominy of Shelter Island, NY; seven grandchildren; and countless friends and loved ones. Born in Bellport in 1917 to Douglas Warner and Julia Edey Paige, Peter attended the Choate School and Princeton University. He joined American Airlines but was soon called to serve in the U.S. Army Air Corps' Air Transport Command during WWII. After the war, he became one of the first employees of Brookhaven National Laboratory. He retired from the Lab in 1981 as Personnel Director. A life-long sailor, Peter was known and respected the length and breadth of Great South Bay. In particular, he achieved great racing success in the Star class, winning several regional and national trophies. The Bellport Bay Yacht Club, where he served four years as Commodore, aptly celebrated him as ''sportsman, raconteur, dog lover, genial host, Post Commodore, Regatta Committee member, skipper par excellence, cruising buff and all around Bon Vivant'' when they awarded him the Commodore Paul S. Bigelow Award in 1967. Peter had a long history of service to his community and his presence will be deeply missed. In addition to serving as Commodore of the Yacht Club, he was a Chief and life member of the Bellport Fire Department, captain of the Department's engine company. He was a member of the United Methodist Church. He was also a 30 year member of the Board of Directors at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital and served as Chairman of the Board from 1984 to 1988. Peter was one of the earliest proponents of Brookhaven's Hospice Program and was in the care of hospice and family members during his last days at home. A memorial service will be announced later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERERA, ANNA RHOADS
description: PERERA-Anna Rhoads. Lived in the Riverdale area of the west Bronx and for 36 years was a volunteer at the Presbyterian Hospital in New York City where she also served as President of the Women's Auxiliary and Volunteer Director. She continued her volunteer work in several capacities at her retirement community, Kendal at Longwood in Kennett Square, PA where she died peacefully on July 18, 2000. She was 88. Anna is survived by her husband, George A. Perera, MD, her daughter Marcia Perera Van Dyck of Princeton, NJ, her son David Rhoads Perera, MD of Seattle, WA, eight grandchildren and three great grandchildren.

title: An Adventurer Who Operates Outside the Boundaries
description: PROLIFIC and unpredictable, Patrice Leconte is an anomalous figure in today's French cinema.

title: Oil Riches, and Risks, in Tiny African Nation
description: With no luck at all, the Spaniards and then the French long searched for oil in the waters around this tiny nation, half of which sits on the Central African mainland and half on an island in the Atlantic.

title: Murphy Shoots 65 To Share Lead
description: On the first hole yesterday at the Instinet Classic in Princeton, N.J., Bob Murphy carded a bogey that dropped him five shots behind the leaders. But from the fifth hole to the 15th, Murphy birdied eight of the 11 holes, and his seven-under 65 tied the Jasna Polana course record set by Tom Jenkins in the opening round on Friday.

title: Postings: New Hotel on West 56th Street; A Downtown Look in Midtown
description: Art lovers who stay at the Chambers Hotel now under construction on 56th Street just west of Fifth Avenue will hardly find it necessary to venture out to nearby galleries to indulge their interest. The 77-room hotel, rising on a 50-foot-wide site that was formerly a parking lot, will contain more than 400 pieces of art by some 100 artists, with a minumum of three works in each room. The hallways will be decorated by different artists, each of whom will have license to do whatever they wish.

title: The Green, Not Mean, Of Bed-Stuy
description: It is not easy being a tree in New York City, the tour guide ventured to guess yesterday as he walked a group of nearly a dozen guests through Fulton Park in Bedford-Stuyvesant.

title: Arts Center in South Orange
description: Downtown South Orange will soon have an arts center with a 340-seat stage and a five-screen movie theater. Construction of the $10 million project, which has been in the works for three years, will begin in November next to the train station bordered by South Orange Avenue and Sloan Street, according to Bill Calabrese, the village president. The 32,000-square-foot space will house a banquet hall for classes, rehearsals and small productions during the week, and social events on the weekends, in addition to the live stage and the movie theater, which will show art and children's films as well as commercial pictures. Along with some state money and private donations, Essex County has pledged $5.4 million with an additional $3 million coming from the federal government. A nonprofit organization will be created to run the center, headed by a board, which will be appointed by Mr. Calabrese and the town's board of trustees. While the town has not accepted gifts in return for naming buildings, officials would like to see an endowment formed from private money. The New Jersey State Opera and Seton Hall University have expressed interest in using the space. PETER BELLER

title: Tales From Aloft

I wonder how many readers remember that steerage referred to the cabins on the trans-Atlantic liners that were in the back of the ship over the propellers and rudder.

If what we have in Minnesota is good, I shudder to think what things must be like in the rest of the country.

Titled ''Immersion,'' her work, like the piece at left, interweaves photographic interpretations of the rain-soaked city streets with movie stills and overlaid text messages. The still photographs and the words that accompany them are positioned in midair behind a translucent screen, seeking to create the appearance of a dream sequence in which viewers participate.

title: The Novelist

A 20-something features' editor at GirlTime magazine, Helen wears only black, which is appropriate because she is also mourning her father's recent death. By contrast, Ms. Maxted, 31, has cultivated a hip literary uniform of trousers, Agnes B. cardigan and high-heels. ''If I feel short, I don't feel ready to face the world,'' said Ms. Maxted, who is 5 foot 1. ''Heels give me inspiration to write.''

title: Editorial Observer; Real Elections Can Be Dangerous to Dictators
description: From Communist general secretaries to Latin American generalissimos, dictators have long confirmed their rule with what they called ''elections.'' Occasionally, however, autocrats hold somewhat free elections -- and to their great embarrassment, they sometimes lose. Augusto Pinochet in Chile, Ferdinand Marcos in the Philippines, the Sandinistas in Nicaragua and the Communists in Poland in 1989 were all voted out of office. Now another undemocratic group, Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary Party, has lost an election.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; An Offshore Farce
description: Everything about William Monahan's assured first novel, LIGHT HOUSE: A Trifle (Riverhead, $21.95), is tremendously knowing. Tim Picasso -- the beautiful, brilliant, insipid hero -- has become a drug runner because he is too talented and uncompromising to make it in the commercial art world. A brief life of crime ensues; Picasso steals from the wrong man, a gangster named Jesus Castro, and then hides out at the Admiral Benbow Inn off the coast of Massachusetts. We meet a satisfyingly ridiculous cast of characters, including Prof. Menelaus G. Eggman, who is ''flickering at the edge of literary relevancy'' and holding a writing seminar, and a bitter, failed writer named Glowery (''the sort of damaged marginal that the magazines troll for in catch-and-release experiments'') who is en route but gets stuck in a bar dressed as a pirate. The fantastically inarticulate Jesus Castro shows up, followed by a dominatrix and some henchmen, while a crusty old New Englander tries to escape the house of the title. ''Light House'' is a sort of old English farce that allows Monahan, formerly an editor at Spy magazine, to skewer whatever comes to mind: modern art, magazine writing, education, the young. But the setting is pervasive and rendered with immediacy. The book is also very funny, and Monahan's cocksure prose gallops along. ''Lighthouse'' is an antidote to everything it rails against. William Georgiades

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARSKI, JAN, DR.
description: KARSKI-Jan, Dr. The American Gathering of Jewish Holocaust survivors deeply mourns the passing away of Dr. Jan Karski at age 86 in Washington, D.C. He will forever be known as the courageous ''man who tried to stop the Holocaust''. In 1942, at the risk of losing his life, Jan Karski, having escaped German torture and imprisonment for being a member of the Polish underground, delivered messages to the Western World (including President Franklin D. Roosevelt) and presented evidence he had gathered on the horrors of Nazi atrocities being committed, the ongoing extermination of the Jews in Poland and details of Hitler's Final Solution. To his great dismay, nobody believed him. After the war, he refused to return to Poland, and made the U.S. his home. He was made an Honorary Citizen of the State of Israel. In Jerusalem a tree bearing his name has been planted in the Alley of the Righteous Gentiles Among the Nations. The world has lost a truly great human being and we have lost a friend. Benjamin Meed, President Roman Kent, Chairman

title: American Megamillionaire Gets Russki Space Heap!
description: This is a story about wealth and space and America and Russia, and it begins with one man, Walter Anderson -- a man with white hair and pale skin, square, gold-rimmed glasses and a physical presence so profoundly unprepossessing it's almost impossible to remember what he looks like. Anderson is 46 and worth almost a billion dollars. He lives in Washington -- the city he grew up in, a city he hates; his hatred of the government is, as he puts it, ''personal'' -- in an apartment adorned with a painting he commissioned based on a Smashing Pumpkins lyric, ''I am still just a rat in a cage.'' ''That's what we are,'' Anderson explains, ''rats in a cage. And we're going to gnaw through the bars because we've got about a 30-year window here, and we'll starve if we don't get out.'' The cage Anderson refers to is the planet earth itself, and he has taken it upon himself to ensure we get off. In 1989, Anderson gave $80,000 to finance the International Space University; in 1991, $100,000 to found the Space Frontier Foundation; in 1994, $5 million to start the Foundation for the International Nongovernmental Development of Space; and between 1996 and 1999, $40 million to build the Roton, a manned, reusable spaceship. Then a few months ago, in one of his eriodic calls to me, he rang me up: ''I'm in Russia!'' Anderson was midway through three days of talks with Yuri Semyonov, president of the private Russian space corporation Energia, and in a move that would later marginalize NASA from the Anderson-Russia-America love triangle, he was arranging for a new company, called MirCorp, to lease the space station Mir.

The salary of the lowest-paid workers will increase by two-thirds and high-end workers will receive five 3 percent increases during the next four years. The contract will expire in October 2004. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAIGE, PETER
description: PAIGE-Peter. Died at Meadowedge, his home in Bellport, NY, on July 21. Peter is survived by his bride of 56 years, Natalie Lambing Paige; three sons, Peter Otis Paige of Yardley, PA, Douglas Warner Paige of Robbinsville, NJ, and Lee Allen Paige of North Andover, MA; two sisters, Mary Paige McGuirk of Bel Air, MD, and Sheila Paige Dominy of Shelter Island, NY; seven grandchildren; and countless friends and loved ones. Born in Bellport in 1917 to Douglas Warner and Julia Edey Paige, Peter attended the Choate School and Princeton University. He joined American Airlines but was soon called to serve in the U.S. Army Air Corps' Air Transport Command during WWII. After the war, he became one of the first employees of Brookhaven National Laboratory. He retired from the Lab in 1981 as Personnel Director. A life-long sailor, Peter was known and respected the length and breadth of Great South Bay. In particular, he achieved great racing success in the Star class, winning several regional and national trophies. The Bellport Bay Yacht Club, where he served four years as Commodore, aptly celebrated him as ''sportsman, raconteur, dog lover, genial host, Post Commodore, Regatta Committee member, skipper par excellence, cruising buff and all around Bon Vivant'' when they awarded him the Commodore Paul S. Bigelow Award in 1967. Peter had a long history of service to his community and his presence will be deeply missed. In addition to serving as Commodore of the Yacht Club, he was a Chief and life member of the Bellport Fire Department, captain of the Department's engine company. He was a member of the United Methodist Church. He was also a 30 year member of the Board of Directors at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital and served as Chairman of the Board from 1984 to 1988. Peter was one of the earliest proponents of Brookhaven's Hospice Program and was in the care of hospice and family members during his last days at home. A memorial service will be announced later.

But in every piece she invites you to bypass the part of your brain that craves logic and understanding and to respond intuitively to the wondrous qualities of her strange, sometimes tender and often downright silly sounds and images.

title: Editorial Observer; How Slavery Fueled Business in the North
description: The German Parliament hoped to discourage a wave of lawsuits -- and close the door on an ugly past -- when it voted to support a fund through which corporations will compensate people who worked as slave laborers in Germany during World War II. But by agreeing to pay reparations, corporations like DaimlerChrysler, Deutsche Bank, Siemens and Volkswagen are tacitly admitting that German corporate wealth rests at least partly on slave labor extracted from Jews during the commission of crimes against humanity.

description: New York racing ended its spring and summer meeting at Belmont Park yesterday with some losses in attendance and betting handle, but with the exhilarating prospect of six weeks in Saratoga Springs starting on Wednesday.

description: Republicans warn of the dangers of a big ''one size fits all'' prescription drug program for the elderly, run by the heavy hand of government bureaucrats. Democrats rail against the prospect of elderly Americans at the mercy of profit-hungry pharmaceutical companies, and scoff at Republican efforts to provide drug coverage through the private sector.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, FREDERICK, EDD.

title: Caramoor's Annual Show Of Respect For Bel Canto
description: Will Crutchfield may still be best known from his tenure as a music critic for The New York Times, from 1983 to 1989. He left daily journalism to become a vocal coach and conductor. But in taking up conducting, he was resuming an earlier career in music, which began when he was a rehearsal pianist and accompanist with the Virginia Opera Association.

He claims to have held the South hand in a money game and heard his right-hand opponent open seven spades.

description: To Gail Berman the cultural chasm is not especially wide between serious plays like Athol Fugard's ''Blood Knot'' or David Rabe's ''Hurlyburly'' and television shows like ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'' and ''Malcolm in the Middle.''

title: The Myth Of Perfect Nuclear Security
description: When the Los Alamos National Laboratory opened for business in April 1943, the irony of volunteering to live behind barbed-wire fences was not lost on the Jewish physicists who had escaped from Nazi Germany and would now lead the development of the world's first atomic bombs. Understandably, they found the implication that they might be disloyal to the United States offensive.

title: If Your Man Treats You Bad, It's Great to Break Loose but Even Better to Get Even
description: The Dixie Chicks paused during their concert on Thursday night at Radio City Music Hall for a slide show of their own goofy baby photos and high school fashion errors: what they called ''the really ugly pictures.'' With country music well into its video era, when hit makers like Shania Twain and Faith Hill pose like models, the Dixie Chicks have some sympathy for the unglamorous. ''You may still be ugly, but there's hope for everyone,'' said Natalie Maines, the group's lead singer.

title: Neagle, Left-Handed Prankster, Fits In With Yanks
description: Denny Neagle was quietly pulling on his uniform yesterday when a piece of fruit glanced off him. The new Yankee and eternal prankster turned and only saw reporters, so he resumed getting dressed. But Neagle was plunked by another slab of fruit a few seconds later and it baffled him. Who was toying with him on the only day when he is serious?

description: New York City's war on the West Nile virus is intensifying, with Mayor Rudolph W. This victory pleased him more, he said, since he viewed it as confirmation of his talent, proof that the first triumph was not a fluke, as he thought was implied by some rivals who were absent then.

After graduating from Pratt Institute in Brooklyn and serving in the U.S. Army Air Corps in Burma during WWII, he went on to become a commercial artist and fine artist. title: New York Magazine: End of a Beginning

Printed two out of every three weeks (the third week was originally reserved for crossword puzzles devised by Stephen Sondheim), the contest, known as the New York Magazine Competition, quickly became a mainstay of the magazine, its mix of wordplay and puns beloved by readers and contestants alike.

title: CAMP DAVID TALKS AT A CRUCIAL POINT

title: 2 Seasons Left for Summerall
description: Pat Summerall will announce today that he will call two more seasons of National Football League games for Fox Sports and conclude his career with the 2002 Super Bowl.

title: 7 Guitarists Take On the Brooklyn Bridge
description: Glenn Branca's symphonies go backward and forward. Their grand, stormy electric-guitar sound became an aural icon of American underground music in the 1980's, and it is a sound that is still demanded of him by commissions. On the other hand it's clear that where he wants to go -- as shown by several recorded pieces over the last five years -- is writing for a large acoustic orchestra and attaining a greater range of expression and nuance, rather than dealing in sheer power.

title: In Guernica, Determination to 'Forgive, but Never Forget'
description: Strolling around the serene square of this Basque town not far north of Bilbao, it is hard to imagine the scene as it was some 60 years ago, when an indelible atrocity took place here on the eve of World War II. Only a few outward marks of physical devastation are still visible, but the human damage remains embedded in people's minds.

title: More Than Advertisers Are Feeling the Effects of the Actors' Strike

But the talks broke down almost immediately -- apparently dashing hopes for a resolution of the long and bitter labor dispute, which has battered many small businesses that play a role in the production of commercials.

title: Morgan Wins by 4 Shots By Toying With Par 5's
description: Gil Morgan started the day tied with Bob Murphy and Tom Jenkins, but he used his length from the tee in virtually ideal conditions today to pull away and capture the Instinet Classic by four shots. Morgan feasted on the par 5's at Jasna Polana, playing the holes at 10 under par for the three days.

title: Ernst Jandl, 74, Viennese Poet of Many Moods
description: Ernst Jandl, an internationally known Viennese lyric poet whose work could be lighthearted or despairing, died on June 9 in Vienna. He was 74.

title: He's On the Road Again, Calling Up a Metaphor
description: When Steve Earle sings about losing everything, he doesn't have to strain for realism. His voice provides that on its own; it's scarred and raspy and eroded, with nothing but ornery determination to keep it going. In his songs he makes it the voice of someone who knows he's wrecked every good thing he had and can never make amends; all he can do is persevere and move on. And there's always another highway beckoning.

title: MCCAW TAPS NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Craig O. McCaw has named Greg Clarke, left, a 42-year-old telecommunications and Internet services executive from Britain, to be chief executive of ICO-Teledesic Global Ltd., the holding company Mr. McCaw created recently to control his satellite ventures. Mr. Clarke was until recently chief executive of Cable and Wireless Communications, a subsidiary of Cable and Wireless P.L.C. In his new post, he will oversee putting together and marketing a venture that is years away from offering its first satellite-based phone and data services. ICO-Teledesic recently announced investments that will finance its development until the middle of next year, but still needs to raise billions of dollars more before it can launch the satellites needed to begin service. Barnaby J. Feder/NYT

Advanced Energy makes electricity conversion and control products for makers of semiconductor equipment, data storage products, and flat-panel displays. Sekidenko, based in Vancouver, Wash., is a supplier of optical fiber thermometers to the semiconductor capital equipment industry.

The DocuTech 6115 Production Publisher, which can print 115 pages a minute, will cost $272,395. Xerox also cut the price of the DocuTech 6100 Production Publisher, a digital black-and-white printer, 11 percent to $232,195.

Elizabeth Watson, her sister Margaret E. Watson, and her brother Francis E. Watson. Memorial celebration of Susan's life will be announced at a later date. title: GAY FINANCIAL SITE TESTS ADS

The humorous spots -- by Mad Dogs and Englishmen, a creatively focused New York agency -- are part of a campaign that began appearing in February in mainstream media as well as in publications aimed at gays. ''We're hoping this will resonate for gay and straight audiences alike,'' said Walter B. Schubert, chairman and chief executive of the Gay Financial Network in New York, which offers information on investing, insurance, real estate and personal finance. The test will cost $8,000 to $10,000, he said. Stuart Elliott/NYT

title: INTERNATIONAL SPECIALTY PRODUCTS HAS HERCULES STAKE
description: International Specialty Products Inc., which was rebuffed last month in its bid to take over the Dexter Corporation, reported yesterday that it had a 10 percent stake in Hercules Inc., the world's largest producer of paper-making chemicals, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Alcoa also plans to reduce regular and overtime work that will be the equivalent of 70 full-time positions. After buying Reynolds in May for $5.8 billion in stock and debt, Alcoa said it expected to cut annual costs by $150 million within a year.

Kodak said it paid less than $10 million for an equity stake in the Los Angeles-based company, its third investment in an Internet-based photography company as it seeks to bolster its traditional markets for film and photo-finishing against digital cameras, which store images electronically. Kodak said it chose to invest in ememories.com because of its business model, which tries to stimulate picture taking by promoting new uses for photos. This fall, for example, ememories.com's customers will be able to print hardbound books with text and graphics using their own photographs. Shares of Kodak fell $2.25, to $55.75.

description: Amid the overheated words and overheated hamstrings at the Olympic track and field trials, Marion Jones showed cool restraint in the way she spoke and the way she ran. She did not blow up on the track or at any of her competitors. Instead, she assuredly dominated the sprints, won the long jump and emerged clearer than ever as the focus of the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Slide on Worries About Computer Shipments

title: CENTRAL PARK SHUT TO SPRAY FOR VIRUS
description: The nation's most famous urban park was closed last night -- and a New York Philharmonic concert postponed -- after city officials announced that they had found mosquitoes infected with West Nile virus in Central Park and would spend the night blanketing the 843-acre park with pesticides.

title: Former Newark Mayor Is Charged With School Construction Fraud
description: Kenneth A. Gibson, who as Newark's mayor for 16 years was the first black person elected to lead a major Northeastern city, was indicted today on federal fraud, bribery and conspiracy charges in connection with his consulting firm's management of a $50 million school construction project in Irvington.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Weekend Outings for the Inmates of Camp David
description: The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, is known back home for his love of military history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEAT, IRMA
description: KEAT-Irma. Of Somers, N.Y. died on July 21, 2000. Beloved wife to the late Frank Keat and loving mother to David and Stephen. Cherished grandmother of four. A memorial service will be held on Thursday 1 PM at the Oelker & Cox Funeral Home, 262 Main St., Mt. Kisco, NY. (914) 666-5891.

title: Losing Meat, but Keeping a Child's Diet Balanced
description: After seeing the movie ''Babe'' at age 9 and realizing the source of what was on her plate, Lauren Pierpoint of Boulder decided to stop eating meat. At age 6, Nathan Kessel of Boston was given a choice by his parents between a vegetarian diet and eating meat regularly; he has been a vegetarian for three years now.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Austin, Tex.

description: To the Editor:

title: RHODIA, A FRENCH CHEMICAL MAKER, IS ACQUIRING CHIREX
description: ChiRex Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the French chemical company Rhodia S.A. for $31.25 a share, or a total of about $510 billion. Rhodia, the biggest maker of ingredients in aspirin, expects to start the offer by Aug. 4. Chirex, which had revenue of $147 million last year, provides advanced product development services and manufacturing to the pharmaceutical industry. It is based in Stamford, Conn. Chirex's shares rose $10.5625 each yesterday, to $30.6875, in Nasdaq trading. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: Gaelic Comes Back on Ireland's Byways and Airwaves
description: From this isolated region of rock and bog on the wind-blasted western edge of Ireland, there rises a television tower more than 100 feet into the air. Its purpose is to make the ancient Irish language ready for prime time.

title: Judge Allows School Wrestlers To Avoid Trial in Hazing Case
description: A Superior Court judge here agreed to a request today from three former Trumbull High School wrestlers to avoid a trial on charges arising out of a violent hazing incident on Feb. 1.

title: Tough Test Is Awaiting U.S. Men
description: After Sunday's 2-1 loss in San Jose, Costa Rica, left them in last place in the four-team group, the Americans find themselves in a precarious position only two games into qualifying matches for the 2002 World Cup.

title: Giants Rookie Brings Art to the Deal
description: When Dhani Jones, the Giants' sixth-round draft pick, agreed to a contract two weeks ago, Giants executives were stunned when Jones refused to sign the deal in the team's offices.

title: DNA Test May Lead to Pardon in Texas
description: A Texas inmate whose rape conviction attracted national attention in 1998 after the state's highest criminal court disregarded DNA evidence and refused to grant him a new trial is now receiving a recommendation that he be pardoned.

title: SIGNS OF TRUCE IN DIAMOND TAKEOVER
description: The South African mining concern De Beers Consolidated Mines has extended the deadline for shareholders of Winspear Diamonds Inc. to consider its $175 million takeover bid. In return, Winspear said it would not invoke its shareholders' rights plan intended to thwart a hostile takeover, and both companies have dropped legal filings against the other. De Beers made an offer for Winspear a month ago. The Canadian company called the offer inadequate. Timothy Pritchard

title: FreeMarkets Beats Analysts Forecasts, Sees Big Revenue Jump
Nortel in Talks With Corning On Optics
description: The telecommunications equipment giant Nortel Networks is discussing a complex transaction to sell its fiber optics components business to Corning Inc., the leading supplier of glass fiber, according to people close to the negotiations. But some analysts and industry executives say the plan is so cumbersome, and expensive, that the deal may never get past the talking stage.

title: Rare Seals Captivate A Beach
description: The recent birth of an endangered Hawaiian monk seal on a popular public beach in Kauai, Hawaii, has pitted conservationists against the organizers of a surfing event at a festival to be held there next week.

title: BP Amoco wants to sell much more than gas at its new stations.
description: BP AMOCO introduced a new model of gas station yesterday, and the least important item for sale is the gas.

title: ALLTEL WILL ACQUIRE BENCHMARK CONSULTING
description: The Alltel Corporation, an information-technology company, said yesterday that it would acquire the Atlanta-based BenchMark Consulting International for an undisclosed amount. The privately held BenchMark is a consulting firm that specializes in measuring, designing and improving operations processes for financial service providers. The company will operate as a business unit within Alltel Information Services.

title: Ralcorp to Close a Plant
description: Ralcorp Holdings Inc., the maker of store-brand crackers and cereal, said today that it would close a Baltimore mayonnaise factory by January and dismiss its 195 employees to reduce costs. Ralcorp said production of salad dressings will be shifted from its Martin Gillet & Company unit, which has been operating in Baltimore since 1811, to a plant in Dunkirk, N.Y., that it acquired this month with its $132.5 million purchase of the Red Wing Company. Ralcorp expects to add an unspecified number of jobs at Durkirk and at a Kansas City, Kan., plant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICOLI, DONNA SPARLING
description: PICOLI-Donna Sparling. Of Old Brookville, N.Y. On July 24, 2000. Beloved wife of Robert C. Mother of Eden Barnes, Megg Hoffman and Robert C. Jr. Sister of Barrie D. Sparling. Grandmother of six. Great-grandmother of one. Service private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary, Inc, 134 Cove Road, Oyster Bay, N.Y. 11771.

title: More Ads in California Papers Help Knight Ridder's Results
description: Knight Ridder said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 12 percent, helped by increased advertising at The San Jose Mercury News and The Contra Costa Times.

title: U.S. Has Underestimated Flight Delays, According to a Study
description: Since 1988 the two government agencies that track airline delays have underestimated the amount of time lost by passengers by a total of 247 years, according to a study scheduled to be released today.

title: Monarchs of Their Sports
description: There are few obvious analogies between endurance cycling and professional golf. Tour de France cycling, for all its strategic interest, is consummately a physical sport, while professional golf is consummately a strategic sport, though its young players are growing physically stronger and stronger. Perhaps the greatest similarity between Lance Armstrong, who won his second consecutive Tour de France on Sunday, and Tiger Woods, who won the British Open at St. Andrews, Scotland, on the same day, is their ability to demoralize the competition, to leave everyone else playing for second place.

title: A Rare Plant Community Is Vanishing
description: On a clear, warm day recently, Dr. Thomas Armentano picked his way through a stand of red mangroves near the southern edge of the Florida peninsula and stepped into a bone dry stretch of marl prairie littered with scores of uprooted, sun-bleached buttonwood trees.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Meeting Up With an Alter Ego

title: Team Signs Picks
description: The Rangers agreed to terms yesterday with a pair of goalies, Johan Holmqvist and Vitali Yeremeyev, they had selected in entry drafts.

title: Looking for Just the Right Fit, Bush Finds It in Dad's Cabinet
description: In the main lobby of the George Bush Presidential Library, about 90 miles east of here, Richard B. Cheney has a prominent place in an enormous oil painting that is the first and pretty much only thing to catch a visitor's eye.

title: Seton Hall Professor Is Killed With Family in Copter Crash
description: The usual stillness of summer on the Seton Hall University campus here was broken over the weekend by news that a popular economics professor, his wife and their two children had been killed on Friday in a helicopter crash in Hawaii.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMES, DEBRA
description: JAMES-Debra. A dedicated and inspiring advocate of all at NYU. We will miss our kind and caring friend whose outstanding efforts created a true sense of community and who touched our hearts with her warmth and sincerity. We mourn her loss and extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Administrative Management Council of New York University

title: Armstrong Not Aiming To Achieve Long Reign
description: Lance Armstrong celebrated his second successive Tour de France victory in ways expected -- a glass or two of Champagne, a party with hundreds of his closest friends and sponsors; and in ways unexpected -- with nine other cancer survivors, he signed the Paris Charter Against Cancer, an information service.

title: American Topics
description: In 1985, Thomas Turnipseed began cultivating loblolly pines on a corner of his 500-acre (200-hectare) soybean farm outside Montgomery, Alabama. Now, logging is his sole cash crop. Nor is he alone. Small rural loggers like Mr. Turnipseed and big commercial loggers like Georgia Pacific have been thriving in Alabama.

title: Wasp Invades a Spider and Puts It to Work
description: There are few things more creepy than alien possession, the notion of one creature taking over another's body and bending it to different purposes. Though this may happen every day on other planets, an egregious example has come to light on earth too, and as close to home as the forests of Costa Rica.

title: I.B.M. AND CISCO EXPAND IN IRELAND
description: The Industrial Development Authority of Ireland won investment contracts from I.B.M. and Cisco Systems. I.B.M. announced plans to spend $119 million in placing its online business-to-business procurement services near Dublin, while Cisco Systems was reported to have acquired a site that would employ 1,500 to make equipment for the Internet industry. Brian Lavery

title: Metro Business; Executive Sentenced In Investment Fraud
description: The president and chief executive of the Golf Emporium Corporation is headed to prison for defrauding investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, MANFORD
description: MELTZER-Manford. Died at home on July 21, 2000, age 91 after a courageous struggle with Alzheimer's disease. Survived by his beloved wife Theda (nee Spatt), his sons Peter and James and his granddaughter Alexandra. He was a lawyer and a businessman, and always an elegant gentleman. Services Sunday, July 23, at 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside,'' Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

title: Musical Lease Game Over, Accounting Firm's Rent Soars
description: The dearth of office space in Manhattan sparked a cutthroat game of musical chairs earlier this month among some of the city's top corporations that stretched from Fifth Avenue to Times Square and will cost both the winners and the losers millions of dollars.

title: In a Fat-Filled World, Some Sound Advice
description: Are you confused about dietary fats? Well, you're not alone. Judging from the sometimes conflicting reports recently presented at a scientific conference, experts in the field seem to be having the devil's own time sorting out which fats and oils and how much of them are likely to be most beneficial to health and at the same time acceptable to consumers and food producers.

title: Sports of The Times; Cone Sold His Soul To the Devil
description: LIKE Shoeless Joe from Hannibal, Mo., David Cone from Kansas City, Mo., sold his soul to the Devil. There is simply no other explanation.

title: 2 Flrs, Furn., Nice Vu (But a Little Shaky)
description: Two weeks ago today, at 10:20 a.m., the Northridge earthquake struck again.

title: BBDO Resigns Netpliance Account
description: BBDO Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, said yesterday that it had resigned the account of Netpliance after only five months, citing a significant cutback in ad spending. Netpliance sells the I-Opener, an Internet appliance offering e-mail without a computer.

title: Two Fine Minds, Tested by Failing Bodies
description: In her 1961 poem ''Grace,'' Maxine Kumin described hens pecking on gravel and the invincible armor one might gain by similarly ingesting small stones. ''I find it good to line my gut,'' she wrote, ''with tidy octagons of grit.''

title: Following the Game Rules With an Air of Spontaneity
description: For the past two weeks, the Mannes College of Music has been presenting its second annual International Keyboard Institute and Festival, a series of lectures, master classes and concerts, directed by the pianist Jerome Rose. The final performance in the festival was a recital on Saturday evening by Anton Kuerti, a pianist who in recent seasons has been heard in New York mostly in chamber music and in an annual New Year's Eve marathon in which he plays all five Beethoven concertos with the Jupiter Symphony.

title: The Prozac Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Regulators Step In to Oversee a Troubled H.M.O. Unit
description: Insurance regulators in Florida have placed a subsidiary of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York under special supervision and given the subsidiary until tomorrow to come up with a plan to cover a $4.8 million shortfall in its reserves.

title: Offspring of the Imagination, Nurtured and Set Aloft
description: Along the one-lane roads of America, you can sometimes spot a depository of the imagination. Giant insects sculptured from scrap metal, apocalyptic visions painted on fence slats, a flower bed in the shape of a heart: these things become folk art when documented, but in their own backyards they're magically animate. This home-birthed art has its equivalents in rock, including a recent style influenced by Pavement, the band out of Stockton, Calif. Literary and homespun, dilapidated and grand, it allows outsider auteurs to present epics on a foundation of bent guitar chords. Grandaddy, Home and Bright Eyes, leading lights of this backyard school, played on Friday night at the Bowery Ballroom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, SCOT
description: SIMON-Scot, 46, of New York City. Passed away July 22, 2000. Son of Sherman and the late Muriel. Life partner of Richard Long, in addition he is survived by his brothers Paul (Mimi) Simon, Jeffrey (Bonnie) Simon, nephews Brian, Richard, Charles and Peter. His artistic talents encompassed many mediums and enlightened many lives. Scot was kind and gentle, a great friend to many and sensitive to all. A.O.L, A.O.L. Funeral service will be held 10:45 AM Tuesday, July 25, 2000 at Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, 1920 Alton Rd, Miami Beach, FL with entombment to follow at Lakeside Memorial Park. (305) 531-1151.

title: AT&T WIRELESS AGREES TO BUY SBC INDIANAPOLIS UNIT
description: The AT&T Wireless Group agreed yesterday to acquire the Indianapolis wireless system of SBC Communications Inc. for about $530 million in cash. AT&T Wireless said the deal would add more than 113,000 subscribers. So far this year, AT&T Wireless has acquired or announced plans to acquire wireless systems in the San Francisco Bay area, San Diego, Houston and Florida. AT&T Wireless, based in Redmond, Wash., is the second-largest mobile phone operator in the United States. SBC, based in San Antonio, is the second-largest local phone provider in the United States.)

title: Experts Find Early Clues of Alzheimer's
description: Alzheimer's disease, which robs people of their most basic neurological functions, may give subtle clues to its approach years before clear symptoms emerge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLMES, HERBERT
description: HOLMES-Herbert, M.D. Departed this life July 22, 2000. Loved by all who knew him. The ultimate friend. He lives on in the hearts of all whose lives he touched. Wm. ''Footsie'' Edmondson, M.D.

title: PRICELINE.COM LOSSES NARROW
description: Priceline.com reported a smaller-than-expected second-quarter loss of a penny a share as its sales more than tripled. Investors were not impressed, however, as the Norwalk, Conn.-based company's shares plunged 22 percent. For the quarter ending in June, the company reported that excluding several one-time items, it lost $1.6 million, or 1 cent a diluted share, compared with a loss of $13.9 million, or 10 cents a diluted share, in the second quarter of 1999. Analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial had predicted a loss of 3 cents a share. Revenue was $352.1 million, 216 percent greater than year-earlier revenue of $111.6 million. Priceline.com's shares fell $8.9375, to $31.125.

description: Judge to Be Asked for Major Ruling in Napster Case

title: The Internet Can't Free China
description: While the Senate holds back from voting on normal trade with China because of hesitation about Chinese nuclear help to Pakistan, the senators should take another look at something else in the trade debate: the questionable argument that modern technology will force China to liberalize its political system.

title: Everett's Bat Falls Silent As He Starts 10-Game Ban
description: Just as suddenly as he erupted in fury at an umpire, Carl Everett yesterday surprisingly dropped his appeal of a 10-game suspension and a $5,000 fine for his actions toward the umpire. Everett, the center fielder for the Boston Red Sox, began his suspension last night with the game against Minnesota and will be eligible to return against Kansas City on Aug. 4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILES, LORETTA D.
description: MILES-Loretta D. (Dalton), 96 years. On July 23, 2000. Former New York City schoolteacher. She is survived by a niece, Sr. Grace E. Butler, RSCJ of The Sacred Heart School, Lawrenceville, New Jersey. Funeral service information: call M. David De Marco Funeral Home, 732-521-0555.

title: Orderly Hurtling In Matter Over Mind
description: Mark Foehringer, the director of the Western Ballet of Mountainview, Calif., made a good case for pretty, lyrical dance with nothing much on its mind on Saturday night at the Joyce SoHo. Mr. Foehringer, a former member of the Cisne Negro Dance Company in Brazil, presented a fifth-anniversary program of new and recent work performed by a chamber group of dancers drawn from Lines, the Oakland Ballet and other California troupes.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro dropped as European acquisitions of United States companies increased speculation that demand for dollars would rise. In New York, the euro settled at 93.27 cents, down from 93.69 cents.

title: Colorado Fire Nears Old Indian Cliff Dwellings
description: Nearly 700 firefighters struggled today to get in front of a blaze that had burned some 22,000 acres of brush in the Mesa Verde National Park and was closing in on the park's famous ancient Indian cliff dwellings.

title: The Business of Politics; Corporations Pour Money Into the Political Conventions
description: For Philip Morris, the imminent political conventions are not so much about nominating presidential candidates and building party loyalty as they are about, well, macaroni. Macaroni in the shape of donkeys. Macaroni in the shape of elephants. Macaroni the company plans to hand out to delegates.

description: Al Groh understands what Bob Sutton is undertaking these days. Both left the college ranks to coach in the National Football League under the man they had replaced.

title: R. P. Thompson, 51, Executive
description: R. Patrick Thompson, the president of the New York Mercantile Exchange since 1989, died Wednesday in Bethesda, Md. He was 51 and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Jakarta Lawmakers Press Leader on Ousters
description: A surly standoff between Parliament and its first democratically elected leader dragged on today as more than 200 members rejected President Abdurrahman Wahid's explanation for why he had ousted two popular cabinet ministers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CALLAWAY GOLF CO., Carlsbad, Calif., named Brad Holiday executive vice president and chief financial officer, effective Aug. 15. He succeeds David Rane, who resigned. Mr. Holiday had been vice president for financial planning and analysis at Gateway Inc.

title: For Most Part, Doctors Concur on Cheney
description: Richard B. Cheney's personal cardiologist said last night that the man Gov. George W. Bush has apparently chosen to be his running mate was in good health and had no symptoms of heart disease.

title: Broad Reorganization at I.B.M. Hints at Successor to Gerstner
description: In the seven years since he took over, Louis V. Gerstner Jr. has led a striking revival in the fortunes of I.B.M., the world's largest computer company. Yet Mr. Gerstner, the chairman and chief executive, has decided that what the company most needs now is a good shake-up -- to accelerate its growth and achieve its goal of being the leading supplier of technology and services for the Internet economy.

title: Expensive Tax Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: Robert B. Sims, senior vice president at the National Geographic Society, Washington, was promoted to executive vice president and president for the magazine group, a new post, overseeing publications like National Geographic and National Geographic Traveler.

title: Scalping Ring Shut Out Baseball Fans, Prosecutors Say
description: They may not patrol the outfield like Bernie Williams, or strike out batters, like Mariano Rivera. But the ticket agents at Yankee Stadium have some raw power of their own: their kiosks are often the first stop for fans who want to see their World Series winners in action.

title: Company Linked to Russian Tycoon Cleared of Money Laundering
description: Boris A. Berezovsky, the top Russian executive and onetime insider, who has denounced a Kremlin crackdown on rich businessmen, received a measure of vindication today when international auditors exonerated one of his companies in a long-running investigation into embezzlement and money laundering.

description: BERELSON-Thelma D. On July 22, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Loving mother of Ellen and her husband Lawrence Franks and the late Philip. Dear sister of Elca Branman and sister-in-law of Elliot Berelson and his wife Suzanne. Board member of the League for the Hard of Hearing and President of The Theodore H. Barth Foundation. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Tuesday 11:30 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing, 71 West 23rd Street, New York, NY 10010.

title: Excerpts From President's Interview in Campaign Finance Inquiry
description: Following are excerpts from an interview President Clinton gave to Justice Department investigators in a campaign finance inquiry in April. The president was asked about conversations with an Indonesian businessman and campaign contributor, James T. Riady, who gave $100,000 to a close friend of Mr. Clinton, Webster L. Hubbell.

title: Air and Oceans Keep the Earth Wobbling Along
description: The Earth wobbles because the atmosphere and oceans are pushing it around.

title: The Big City; Don't Shop, But Protest Till You Drop
description: NEW YORKERS have been organizing against a new store, which is not in itself an unusual social activity. Protesting new stores is the local equivalent of a barn-raising. But this crusade offered a rare glimpse into the native psyche.

title: Varian Seeking Life-Science Acquisitions
description: The chief executive of Varian Inc. said today that the company, a maker of scientific instruments, was actively pursuing acquisitions in the life-sciences industry, looking to extend a pattern that has fattened profit margins since last year.

description: Giorgio Armani S.p.A. and the men's wear maker Ermenegildo Zegna said today that they were forming a joint venture to produce and distribute the Armani Collezioni men's line.

description: Most people who are allergic to pollen presumably make it a point to avoid blooming fields of ragweed or goldenrod.

Rogers, chief executive of Rogers Communications of Canada, which posted improved second-quarter results. The second showed Lord Hollick, head of United News and Media, which called off a deal with Carlton Communications.

description: Percent

title: Maybe Not Tanned, But Rested
description: We are in what's advertised as the season of snorkeling, roller coaster riding and cross-country hikes. But with jobs and workplaces getting more intense by the day, an old truth about vacations may be truer than ever: They're about rest. Whether it's at the beach, in the mountains or in the Tuscan hills, sleeping in can be better than venturing out.

title: Reports of a Dead Mars Are Greatly Exaggerated; Red Sands Show Marks of Recent Water and Lava
description: The first spacecraft to probe Mars ended up shattering ages of myths and delusions. This was no sister planet to Earth lush in lakes, canals and vegetation, as some astronomers had imagined after seeing elusive dark patches and white ice caps that seemed to change with the seasons.

title: The Day the Music Died From the Mosquito Menace
description: After years of settling for a spot far to the rear, Lou Cizek of Teaneck, N.J., thought he had found gold yesterday, arriving at the Great Lawn in Central Park early enough to stake out a patch of green close to the stage where the New York Philharmonic would perform.

title: Back in Business After a Tempest And a Tea Room; Storm Doomed Eclectic Gallery, But Owner Finds a New Venture
description: Bettina DeCaumette wanted the old red jukebox out of the bar, rejecting it in the process of ending one business and starting another. So her bartender and partner grabbed the box from the dusty corner where it had blared out tunes like Bing Crosby's ''Too-Ra-Loo-Ra-Loo-Ral'' for at least three decades, gave it a shove, rolling it into a small pantry in the back.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: They Oughta Be In Pictures; Comic-Book Heroes are Naturals, But Too Often Films Fail Them
description: In his 1965 book, ''The Great Comic Book Heroes,'' which features the best essay ever written on the subject, the cartoonist Jules Feiffer described comics as ''movies on paper.'' Both art forms exploit action and express character through movement. These peculiarly American forms of juvenilia have probably forever changed the fantasy lives of children, giving them the superpowers to defeat the monsters in their dreams.

title: Checking Into the Roach Motel, Permanently
description: You know this movie is in trouble when you find yourself rooting for the killer cockroaches. The humans in this insufficient melodrama warrant neither sympathy nor interest.

title: Hananiah Harari, 87, Artist Who Championed Modernism
description: Hananiah Harari, an American painter and illustrator, died on Wednesday in Halthorne, N.Y. He was 87.

George W. Bush of Texas.

title: Notorious Killer Among Inmates Freed From Ulster Prison
description: Michael Stone, a Protestant guerrilla who killed three mourners in a Belfast cemetery during an Irish Republican Army funeral in 1988, left prison today, the first of 88 jailed fighters who will be freed this week in the last wave of early releases mandated by the Northern Ireland peace accord.

title: A Hunk of Starry Dynamite Burns in Cygnus
description: The future appears to be very bright, though brief, for a star known as KPD1930+2752, in the constellation Cygnus. According to astronomers at the University of Southampton in England, the peculiar star is destined to explode in a supernova.

title: EMUSIC SUBSCRIPTION SERVICE
description: Shares of EMusic.com rose nearly 33 percent after the company announced a monthly subscription service providing unlimited MP3 music downloads. The stock ended regular trading Monday at $2.406 in Nasdaq trading, up 59.3 cents. EMusic, an online music distributor based in Redwood City, Calif., is offering the subscription plans at $9.99 to $19.99 a month.

description: Much of the music world heads for the hills of New England during the summer, and so, in a Bach year, does Bach.

description: To the Editor:

title: Former Governor to Replace Georgia Senator
description: Gov. Roy Barnes today appointed his popular predecessor, Zell Miller, to succeed the late Paul Coverdell as United States senator, a choice that instantly changed the partisan political calculus both in Georgia and in Washington.

title: Blair's Close Political Confidant Spins Into a Spotlight
description: Alastair Campbell, the press spokesman for Tony Blair, holds a job that has traditionally been cloaked in anonymity, but the onetime ''source close to the prime minister'' has now gone high personal profile. He is the subject of a book, the focus of probing newspaper articles and broadcast pieces and the star of a BBC documentary that has just aired.

title: Increase in Mad Cow Deaths Alarms Experts
description: Deaths from the human form of mad cow disease appear to be increasing, British health officials have reported, but they say it is still unclear whether the increase is the start of an epidemic or merely a statistical blip.

title: Surhoff Is Next Object Of the Yankees' Ardor
description: Leery of trading their best prospect to get Rondell White from the Montreal Expos, the Yankees are negotiating to make a deal for B. J. Surhoff, Baltimore's veteran left fielder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAUBE, MILDRED
description: TRAUBE-Mildred. Died on July 21, 2000 at age 90 at her home in NYC. Wife of the late Shepard Traube. Mother of Victoria Traube and Elizabeth Traube. Contributions may be made to the SSDC Foundation for the Mildred and Shepard Traube Fellowship, 1501 Broadway, NY, NY 10036. Services Wednesday, July 26, 4 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: TOMKINS PUTS ITS SMITH & WESSON UNIT UP FOR SALE
description: Tomkins P. L. C., a British engineering and construction company, said yesterday that it would put its Smith & Wesson Corporation unit, the biggest United States handgun maker, up for sale as it focuses on automobile and home-building materials. The company has not yet held talks with any potential buyers, a spokesman said. The sale plan was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal. Tomkins agreed last week to sell its European food unit for $:1.1 billion to Doughty Hanson & Company. Smith & Wesson contributes less than 1 percent of Tomkins' annual revenue of 5.6 billion [pounds].

title: Study Finds Internet Costs State, Local Governments a Lot in Taxes
description: Study Finds Internet Costs State, Local Governments a Lot in Taxes

title: It's Only Checkers, but the Computer Taught Itself
description: Ever since an I.B.M. computer defeated Garry Kasparov, the world chess champion, in 1997, much of the suspense has gone out of the old battle of man versus machine: the machine won. But the lessons of a much humbler game have again made that battle fascinating. The game is, of all things, checkers.

title: In Justice Inquiry, Clinton Denies Seeking Financial Help for Friend
description: In an interview with a senior Justice Department prosecutor in April, President Clinton denied any recollection of a pledge for a $1 million campaign donation by the Indonesian businessman James T. Riady and denied asking Mr. Riady to help financially the former Justice Department official Webster L. Hubbell.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: More Steak in Midtown

title: Trucks Are to Spray in Manhattan Tonight
description: After blanketing Central Park, Staten Island and parts of Queens with pesticide in a stepped-up campaign to knock out the West Nile virus, city officials were preparing to spray Roosevelt Island and a large section of Manhattan tonight.

title: For Kitchens With Chateau Envy
description: HOW many food experts could possibly write a cookbook titled ''From My Chateau Kitchen'' and expect to be taken seriously? Would anyone not fortunate enough to live in a chateau be able to duplicate the recipes?

title: EARNINGS SOAR AT REUTERS
description: The news provider Reuters Group P.L.C, said its earnings for the first half of the year jumped 75 percent, in part because revenue rose at its online trading network, Instinet. The company said net income jumped to $:353 million, or $535 million, from $:202 million a year earlier, beating analysts' expectations. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Cheney as the Finalist: Bush Did the Screening
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 25  In the end, it was Gov. George W. Bush himself who did the final, most sensitive background check on the man who was supposed to be the one running the vice presidential screening process.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO GAINS. The euro rose after consumer price reports suggested interest rates in Europe would rise closer to those in the United States. In New York, the euro settled at 93.85 cents, up from 93.27 cents on Monday.

title: Cheney as the Finalist: Bush Did the Screening

title: Rusch Shifts Mets Into Cruise Control for an Easy Victory
description: General Manager Steve Phillips sat comfortably in the first-base dugout at Shea Stadium, answering questions about his wishes and his hopes for making the Mets better. Phillips never mentioned Curt Schilling's name, but he talked about a specific starting pitcher who would immediately improve the Mets, and it was obvious that he was referring to Schilling.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit was omitted in Business Day on July 14 with an article about Airbus Industrie's development of a double-decker jumbo jet. The picture, showing employees beneath a full-scale mock-up of the plane, was by Alain Ernoult.

title: For Running Mate, LoyalFriend and Ex-Member of Fathers Cabinet
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 25  Gov. George W. Bush formally introduced his running mate, Dick Cheney, to a cheering crowd here today, praising the former defense secretary and longtime family friend as a man of "great integrity, sound judgment and experience."

title: Dick Cheney's Political Resume
description: Because he never served in Congress, Gov. George W. Bush does not have a voting record. But he acquired one yesterday with the selection of Richard B. Cheney as his running mate. Republicans were cheering the sound judgment and broad foreign policy experience that Mr. Cheney, a former secretary of defense and White House chief of staff, brings to the Republican ticket. But Democrats were eyeing the hard-line conservative votes that Mr. Cheney cast during a 10-year House career. From Vice President Al Gore's perspective, Mr. Cheney adds weight to the G.O.P. ticket, but he also opens up promising lanes of attack.

title: People
description: * John Schmitz, vice president for creative at iXL, New York, was named to the new post of chief creative officer. Also, Kristen Beveridge, creative director, was named to the new post of director for the design group and David Warren, also a creative director, was named director for a new content group.

title: New U.S. Guards Promised Against Steel Import Surges
description: The Clinton administration plans to take aggressive new steps to protect domestic steel producers from import surges, speeding up its use of antidumping measures and providing faster relief for companies and workers, according to a report the administration will release today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, DAVID Z.
description: HERMAN-David Z. The Partners, Attorneys and Staff of Certilman Balin Adler & Hyman, LLP mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend and partner, David Herman. We are grateful for his legal guidance and dedication he provided during his 16 years of service with our firm. David was a valued partner and highly regarded expert in the field of Real Estate Law. He will be truly missed by all of the people whose lives he touched with his wisdom, generosity and humor. To his beloved wife, Barbara, and his adoring children, Tara, Jeffrey and Joshua, we offer our heartfelt sympathies.

title: U.N. Weighs Rebuilding Its Complex
description: The United Nations is considering spending nearly $1 billion on a six-year rebuilding program to address the structural and environmental woes of its aging headquarters buildings -- potent, though tarnished, symbols of postwar cooperation and enlightened urbanism.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINKELSTEIN, BILL
description: FINKELSTEIN - Bill. Memories keep the heart strong. Many occasions, new people to share with you but you are gone. Our love will light this candle and sing a special song. Happy Birthday in Heaven. Daughter, Lisa

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLICKER, DR. STANLEY
description: OLICKER-Dr. Stanley. The members of Shelter Rock Tennis Club record with great sorrow the passing of our member, Dr. Stanley Olicker. He was a friend to all and will be sorely missed. Our sincere condolences to his wife, Sydell, and the entire family. Joel Jacobson, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCATO, HELEN STANCLIFFE
description: MARCATO-Helen Stancliffe. On July 24 in Larchmont, NY. Wife of the late John. Mother of Susan M. Nielsen, David N. Marcato and Robert W. Marcato. Also survived by seven grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Visitation will be 3-5, 7-9 afternoon and evening at John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont. A funeral is planned for Thursday, 10am at Sts. John & Paul Church in Larchmont, with burial to follow in Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Mount Pleasant.

title: Pesticide Effect, Hard to Assess, Stays in Shadow Of Disease Fight
description: The aggressive expansion of pesticide spraying in New York this week, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's comments that some local species, including some fish, could become casualties of war in fighting the West Nile virus, have raised new concerns among environmentalists that the region's fragile ecosystem could fall victim to the anxiety over public health.

title: PAPERLESS REAL ESTATE TRANSACTION
description: In what participants assert was the first fully electronic mortgage loan and home purchase, a Procter & Gamble manager acquired a three-bedroom town house in the Fort Lauderdale, Fla., suburb of Weston yesterday. The loan to the buyer, Jose Ignacio Arroyo, was provided by the Irwin Mortgage Corporation of Indianapolis through Mortgage.com and sold to Fannie Mae. The paperless transaction included all filings with Broward County. Title documents were signed and fees transmitted electronically. EOriginal, which supplied the technology to authenticate the transactions and insured the deal, said up to 100 similar deals are set over the next month. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: 113 Die in First Crash of a Concorde
description: An Air France Concorde carrying mainly German tourists bound for a cruise ship in New York crashed in flames shortly after takeoff from Charles de Gaulle Airport outside Paris today, killing all 109 passengers and crew members on board as well as at least 4 people on the ground.

title: AOL Competitors Agree on Standards for Instant Messaging
description: AOL Competitors Agree on Standards for Instant Messaging

title: CIRCUIT CITY STORES TO ELIMINATE 1,000 JOBS
description: The Circuit City Stores, the second-largest United States consumer electronics chain, said yesterday that it would close eight distribution centers and cut 1,000 jobs, or 1.7 percent of its work force, as it remodeled most superstores and stopped selling appliances. Circuit City's shares fell 19 percent after the company also said it expected second-quarter earnings of 32 cents, less than the 43-cent average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. In June, the company warned that gross-profit margins would be narrower than expected, hurt by a drop in demand for major appliances. Shares of Circuit City fell $6.375 each, to $26.25.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a major accounting firm that lost its lease for prime Manhattan office space misspelled the firm's name in some copies. It is Arthur Andersen, not Anderson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUY, JOHN R.
description: GUY-John R. Of New York City, died on Sunday July 23, 2000 after a brief illness. Born January 25, 1920 in Jacksonville, Florida, Mr. Guy was a graduate of Emory University in Atlanta, and a Navy Veteran of WW II. Mr. Guy retired from a career in optical equipment and was long involved in opera and music in New York and Atlanta. He was a member of the Metropolitan Opera Club and an officer of the Southeastern and Eastern Regional Auditions of the Metropolitan Opera and the National Auditions of the New York City Opera. Mr. Guy was married to Herma Chanin Guy who died in 1995. He is survived by sisters Francis Erickson of Homosassa, FL., and Patricia Andes of Park Ridge, IL, as well as two step-sons, three step-grandchildren and a step-great grandson. A private service will be held. The family requests that donations be made to the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions-Eastern Region in care of John Vinsser, 336 Central Park West 8-D, NY, NY 10025.

title: Mets Eye Pitcher They May Not Get, While Yanks May Get Richer
description: Status report from Shea Stadium: a careful check of the names and numbers above the lockers in the home clubhouse yesterday revealed no ''11 Larkin.''

title: CHINA SIMPLIFIES STOCK TRADES
description: China plans to unify the trading systems of its two stock exchanges giving investors the ability to trade through a single account on both exchanges, which are in Shenzhen and Shanghai. The change will be the first step toward broader stock market reforms under consideration, including allowing foreigners to invest directly in shares denominated in China's local currency. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Tastemakers First
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  THOMPSON, R. PATRICK
description: THOMPSON-R. Patrick. We are deeply saddened by the passing of R. Patrick Thompson, President, New York Mercantile Exchange. Serving as President for more than a decade, Mr. Thompson will be remembered as someone whose hard work, dedication and unique vision was integral in elevating the futures industry to new heights not only in the U.S., but globally as well. His presence will be missed, but his legacy shall endure. We also would like to extend our sincerest condolences to Mr. Thompson's family and friends. The Sydney Futures Exchang

title: PHOENIX HOME OFFERS TO BUY REST OF PHOENIX INVESTMENT
description: The shares of Phoenix Investment Partners jumped 28 percent yesterday after it received an offer of $225 million late on Tuesday from the Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company for the shares it does not already own. Phoenix Home Life is planning a conversion to a stock company. The Hartford mutual life insurer offered $12.50 in cash for each of the roughly 18 million shares it does not own in Phoenix Investment. The stock jumped beyond the offer price, gaining $3.0625 a share, to $13.875. Phoenix Investment Partners is an investment management company, with assets under management at the end of the first quarter of $66 billion. Phoenix Home already owns about 60 percent of Phoenix Investment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, JOSEPH
description: LERNER-Joseph. The Board of Governors and members of The Forest Hills Van-Court Association mourn the passing of our beloved vice president, Joseph Lerner. His wisdom was a guiding light to us all. We offer deepest sympathy to his wife, Judea, and family. Brian Nixon, President

title: A Safe Pick Is Revealing
description: In the most momentous decision of his campaign thus far, Gov. George W. Bush took the least adventurous and least sensational course possible.

title: Fruity Japanese Treats
description: Just walking into Minamoto Kitchoan, the Japanese confectionary shop at 608 Fifth Avenue (entrance on 49th Street), is a cooling experience. The display cases brim with pastel fruit-based items, the most alluring of which are made from white peaches.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: The Choice for a Running Mate; Excerpts From Statements by Bush and His Running Mate
description: Following are excerpts from the announcement yesterday by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Dick Cheney that Mr. Cheney would be Mr. Bush's running mate, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Foreign Affairs; It Ain't Over Till It's Over
description: In the wake of the collapse of the Camp David peace talks there will be a great temptation to pronounce the Israeli-Palestinian peace process over. That would be a great, great mistake. The truth is, it has just begun.

title: A Symbol of France Crashes in Flames
description: Witnesses described the brief, fiery flight of AF 4590 as a vision of hell or a kind of bomb, in flames from the time it rolled down the runway at Charles de Gaulle airport until it smashed three minutes later into a tiny, wooden hotel.

title: SEMCO ENERGY CONSIDERS SALE OF THE COMPANY
description: Semco Energy Inc., which owns natural gas utilities in Michigan and Alaska, said yesterday that it was considering options, including a sale of the company. Semco, which has a market value of about $261 million, hired the investment banking firm Banc of America Securities L.L.C. as its financial adviser. The company, based in Port Huron, Mich., said it might not be big enough to compete in the consolidating utility industry. Semco has more than 350,000 gas customers, builds pipelines and distributes propane. Semco shares rose $1.5625, to $14.5625.

title: Hot Schools, Hot Pursuit And a Touch of Hot Air
description: LAST fall, convinced that it could attract more students if it could just show them what happens in the classroom, Mount Holyoke College tried out a new marketing strategy: it sent professors to three cities to teach hourlong lectures, much like those they would teach back on campus, to prospective applicants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFRO, PAUL
description: SAFRO-Paul. Bnai Zion mourns the loss of our former President. Paul was an ardent supporter of Israel, a fellow of the World Zionist Organization and an inspiration to many. His generosity was legend. Our sincerest condolences to his wife Rose, his children and grandchildren. Hon. Alan G. Hevesi, President Michael J. Lazar, Chairman Mel Parness, Exec. Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUCH, ROXANE S.
description: RAUCH-Roxane S. On July 24, 2000. Beloved mother of Janine Rauch Eagle and David Rauch, grandmother of Jaclyn Rae Eagle, sister of Susan Cardon. Accomplished fashion promoter, public relations expert, and journalist. Services today at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center, Norris Cotton Cancer Center, Memorial Donation for Roxane Rauch, One Medical Center Drive, Lebanon, N.H. 03756. She is cherished by her family and will be deeply missed.

title: MetroStars Move On In U.S. Cup
description: Along with being the team with the most victories in Major League Soccer right now, the MetroStars are also presenting a challenge for the U.S. Cup title. They reached the quarterfinal stage of the 87-year-old competition tonight with a 3-0 victory over the Tampa Bay Mutiny before 5,183 at the Mitchel Athletic Complex.

title: 5 Spots Nominated For Emmy Award
description: Five spots have been nominated for an Emmy Award for outstanding television commercial in the annual competition sponsored by the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. The winner will be announced next month during the presentation of the 52nd annual Emmy Awards.
