title: Business Travel; Timely, detailed, foreign exchange data can be invaluable. A Web site makes it more accessible.
description: HERE's a conversational icebreaker for those interminable hours that you may be spending in airport lounges as this summer of endless flight delays grinds on: Did you know that 10 Bolivian bolivianos got you 3.4 Bulgarian levs at the money-changing counters yesterday? How about that Cyprus pound, one for $1.62. Or that Indonesian rupiah -- 9,100 for $1 today.

title: Senator Moynihan Objects to Being Spliced in Step With Lazio
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the Republican Leadership Council plans to begin broadcasting this week. It features President Clinton praising the leadership of his wife's Republican Senate opponent, Representative Rick A. Lazio. The advertisement includes videotape of Mr. Clinton praising Mr. Lazio and the man he hopes to replace, retiring Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. The council says it is independent of Mr. Lazio's campaign, and thus can use largely unregulated ''soft money,'' which is supposed to be used mainly for party building and not for urging votes for particular candidates, to pay for the ad.

title: New Zealand's Contender
description: OVER the last 15 years, New Zealand has earned a reputation for producing superb sauvignon blancs, but if you speak to New Zealand winemakers, you sense they would rather talk about something else. ''If you think the sauvignon blancs are good, wait until you taste our chardonnays and pinot noirs,'' they will say.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS DROPS. Natural gas fell on expectations that mild weather would reduce the need for fuel to generate electricity for air-conditioning. In New York, natural gas fell 5.5 cents, to $3.66 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: AT&T Quarterly Profit Surpasses Forecasts
description: AT&T reported quarterly earnings yesterday that modestly exceeded analysts' expectations. But the company's revenue growth continued to slow amid deepening erosion in the core consumer long-distance business.

title: AKAMAI SHARES SLUMP
description: Shares of Akamai Technologies, which posted a wider second-quarter loss on Monday, fell 21 percent on concerns over an increase in marketing spending. Investors are concerned because the company, which operates a global network of 4,000 Internet server computers, said during a conference call with analysts that it planned to increase spending on marketing and hiring, said Nitsan Hargil, an analyst at Kaufman Brothers. ''People are afraid that Akamai is about to turn into another one of these Internet companies that spends its way into oblivion,'' Mr. Hargil said. Akamai's loss widened to $243.2 million from $35.4 million in the first quarter. Its stock fell $22.875, to $85 a share.

title: Metro Business; Settlement Reached On Frozen Accounts
description: The New York Board of Trade and the New York Mercantile Exchange said yesterday that they had settled a lawsuit over customer accounts frozen by the Board of Trade when Klein & Company Futures defaulted on stock options trades.

title: Michel Richard
description: I HAVE thought a lot about fried chicken because Americans love it. The idea for a potato crust on it came to me from frozen Tater Tots. I loved their crunch and thought if I coated the chicken with potatoes instead of bread crumbs the crunch would be better. It's more work, but it's more than worth it.

title: Swiss Take New Look at Transfers of I.M.F. Aid for Russia
description: Swiss officials are investigating whether $4.8 billion paid to Russia by the International Monetary Fund in 1998 was laundered through Swiss banks in transactions involving the Bank of New York, according to investigative documents that revive questions thought to have been resolved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, LILLIAN H.
description: ROSENBERG-Lillian H. Beloved wife of the late Meyer Rosenberg & Arthur Tanza. Devoted mother of Rachel R. Rose, Sheva R. Miller and the late Ellen R. Murphy. Dear sister of Irving Hoffman. Loving grandmother of eight, great-grandmother of three. Services were held on Monday. For information, call Bernheim-ApterGoldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, Maplewood, New Jersey, 1-800-938-6372.

description: EUROPE

title: Seeking Laws For Disabilities Of the Attitude
description: Ten years ago today, when the Americans With Disabilities Act became law, the unemployment rate among disabled people was 70 percent. It still is, almost everyone agrees. And the stories of Sarah Triano and Richard Clark help explain why.

title: 2 Oil Giants Register Record Earnings
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation, the largest publicly traded oil company, and the Chevron Corporation, the No. 2 United States oil company, said today that second-quarter earnings reached records as oil, natural gas and gasoline prices surged.

title: Arafat's Allies Say He Stands Taller at Home for Firmness at Talks
description: Palestinian officials said after the Camp David summit meeting ended without an agreement today that they would press ahead with plans to declare an independent state on Sept. 13, whatever the consequences.

title: Article 2000072693072804103 -- No Title
description: In a legal document filed today, Microsoft said the complexity of its antitrust case made it completely unsuitable for direct appeal to the Supreme Court. The Microsoft argument rests heavily on a scathing attack on the handling of the case by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who heard the suit in federal district court.

title: On the Edge of Little Italy, a New Definition of Chinese
description: CHINESE restaurants are often easy to pigeonhole. Food can be classified according to region, while design (or the lack of it) falls into predictable categories. But Funky Broome, an unusual restaurant that opened three months ago in a fringe of Little Italy that has been absorbed into Chinatown, is trying to sidestep those definitions.

description: AN INVISIBLE SIGN OF MY OWN

title: Article 2000072693341338887 -- No Title
description: GONESSE, France, July 26  The engine that caught fire moments before a Concorde crashed into a hotel near Paris underwent repairs just before takeoff, officials said today.

title: A Chill in the Air for Free-Range Chickens
description: IMPORTED free-range chickens processed by a new method are winning converts among New York chefs and could be in supermarkets this fall.

title: Nasdaq Open Short Sales Up
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market rose 4.5 percent in the most recent month, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which operates the market, said yesterday.

title: New Jersey's Flood Victims Get $11 Million More in Aid
description: New Jersey received an additional $11 million in federal aid yesterday for some of the poorest residents affected by flooding in the aftermath of Tropical Storm Floyd last September.

title: A Candidate Seeking the VH1 Vote
description: Faced with a bank of microphones, the candidate reached not for a canned speech, but for an acoustic guitar.

title: A Long Long Trail Is Awinding, Right Across Canada
description: Here on North America's northern edge, a treeless peninsula offers a timeless scene: slabs of whale meat drying in the 24-hour summer sun, a chained husky barking at visitors, and a chill wind blowing off polar ice, only 10 miles offshore.

title: Mama Is a Bounty Hunter, Just Making an Honest Living
description: Look, it's another vulnerable single woman with a heart of gold, just trying to find her way along life's rocky road, which is strewn with all the wrong men. But Dottie Thorson stands out from the pack. She drinks, smokes, cusses and uses her 19-year-old daughter and large firearms as accessories in her work. Dottie is a bounty hunter, making ends meet by hauling in miscreants who have jumped bail.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about George W. Bush's decision to name Richard B. Cheney as his running mate misidentified the agency formerly headed by Mr. Cheney's wife, Lynne. It is the National Endowment for the Humanities, not the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Genzyme Files Patent Infringement Suit Against Transkaryotic
description: A second biotechnology giant, the Genzyme Corporation, has filed a patent infringement suit against Transkaryotic Therapies Inc., the upstart company locked in a closely watched patent battle with Amgen Inc.

title: Clueless And Angry In a Small 70's Town
description: Mooney Pottie (her given name is Agnes Marie) is a dreamy, bookish teenager living in Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, in the mid-1970's and longing to be anywhere else. Life in her close-knit, conservative small town seems unbearably drab; even the riot of ill-matched plaids that seems to be New Waterford's idea of fashion can't overcome its essential grayness. This is the kind of place where thrift and common sense dictate that a shotgun wedding at the local church double as a funeral, in spite of the inconvenience of sorting out condolence cards from congratulations. No wonder Mooney dreams of Rome, Paris and above all, Manhattan.

title: Ozzy Osbourne, Without the Birds and Bats
description: At 11 on a Monday morning, heavy metal fans don't usually get the chance to swig a beer and plunge into a mosh pit. They did when Ozzy Osbourne's annual Ozzfest came to the PNC Bank Arts Center here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICOLI, DONNA SPARLING
description: PICOLI-Donna Sparling. Of Old Brookville, N.Y. On July 24, 2000. Beloved wife of Robert C. Mother of Eden Barnes, Megg Hoffman and Robert C. Jr. Sister of Barrie D. Sparling. Grandmother of six. Great-grandmother of one. Service private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary, Inc, 134 Cove Road, Oyster Bay, N.Y. 11771.

title: OGDEN TO SELL GROUND SERVICES UNIT TO BRITISH CONCERN
description: The Ogden Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Aviation Ground Services business to John Menzies P.L.C. of Britain for about $117.8 million. John Menzies will also assume an unspecified amount of Ogden debt. The sale is part of Ogden's strategy to sell its entertainment and aviation businesses to concentrate on its energy business. Ogden, based in New York, reported $1 billion in revenue for the last 12 months from its entertainment, aviation and energy businesses. Its ground services unit consists of ramp, passenger and cargo handling operations at 61 airports worldwide. The Menzies Aviation Group -- which has annual revenue of about $150 million -- is a leading independent supplier of aviation services in Britain.

title: Goalie on the Spot Seeking Spotlight
description: As he skated around the ice, it was difficult to tell Rick DiPietro, the Islanders' No. 1 draft choice, from the kids he was teaching at a goaltending clinic. Wearing a sweater with the No. 1 and his name on the back was all that seemed to distinguish DiPietro from the campers, some of whom were only three years younger than the 18-year-old goaltender.

title: Bush Names Cheney, Citing 'Integrity' and 'Experience'
description: Gov. George W. Bush formally introduced his running mate, Dick Cheney, to a cheering crowd here today, praising the former defense secretary and longtime family friend as a man of ''great integrity, sound judgment and experience.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: Failure at Camp David
description: The collapse of the Camp David talks is a wrenching setback for Israel, the Palestinians and the cause of Mideast peace. Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, came remarkably close to agreement on some of the most difficult issues of the 52-year-old conflict. But they stumbled at the most sensitive point, sovereignty over East Jerusalem. On that subject Mr. Barak found Mr. Arafat unprepared to make the kind of hard compromises needed to seal an agreement.

He offers not only the most seductively menacing voice ever heard from a good guy in a G-rated movie, but also a vigor not normally seen in such a picture. The amiable torpor of the film is left in a shambles after each of his scenes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZUR, ABRAHAM
description: MAZUR-Abraham. The Faculty and Staff of the Chemistry Department of the City College of New York deeply regret the loss of our former Chair and colleague, Professor Abraham Mazur. Professor Mazur, an outstanding biochemist and a recognized authority in the area of hemoglobin, ferritin and iron metabolism, was also noted for the introduction of biochemistry into the undergraduate curriculum. Professor Mazur was held in high regard by his students and colleagues, and they will miss him. At this very difficult time, we extend our condolences and sympathy to his children, Ellen and Stephen.

description: GOODMAN-Ruth Katz Peyser. On Monday, July 24. Beloved wife of the late Monroe Goodman. Loving mother of Michael and Barbara Goodman of Merrick, New York, and Andrew and Nancy Goodman of Bettendorf, IA. Proud grandmother of Mark and Kim Goodman, Andrea and Brian Wasserman, Rachel Goodman and Matthew Goodman and greatgrandmother of Rebecca Madison, Jami and Jason. Sister of Walter Katz and the late Cecile Marek. Graduate of Smith College, class of 1936 and The New York School of Social Work, class of 1939. She went on to become the esteemed Director of Social Work at Payne Whitney Clinic, Division of New York Hospital/Cornell Medical Center. Her family will miss her wit, insight, joy of life and her love. No services will be held at her request. Donations in her memory to the Columbia University School of Social Work, 622 West 113 Street, NY, NY 10025, attn Alumni Relations would be appreciated.

title: BRAZILIAN UNEMPLOYMENT DROPS
description: Brazil's unemployment rate hit a six-month low in June, falling to 7.4 percent from 7.8 percent in May. The decline in unemployment, along with a reduction in interest rates of two percentage points, to 16.5 percent, in the last five weeks, is expected to aid consumer spending. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

description: The Internet networking company Cisco Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Komodo Technology, a privately held Internet telephony concern, for $175 million in stock.

title: Tracing Beer and Wine Through History
description: The making -- and drinking -- of beer and wine has been a venerated tradition throughout human history, a fact brought to life in ''Drink and Be Merry: Wine and Beer in Ancient Times,'' an exhibition opening on Sunday at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue (92nd Street). It includes nearly 200 objects from Greece, Rome, Egypt and the Middle East, like Italian wine jars inscribed to King Herod and a portion of the Dead Sea Scrolls on a festival of new wine, perhaps the Beaujolais of its day. There is also a reproduction of an ancient wine shop. At left is an Egyptian figurine of a woman making beer circa 2035-1650 B.C.

title: 'True West' Is Closing
description: ''True West,'' a revival of Sam Shepard's 1982 play, is to close after the evening performance on Saturday at the Circle in the Square Theater, 50th Street and Broadway. Directed by Matthew Warchus and currently starring Josh Brolin and Elias Koteas, the play will have run for 154 regular performances and 21 previews.

title: Protection From the Perils Of the Kitchen
description: Usually the only gloves in a home cook's kitchen are under the sink, for washing dishes. But anyone who has shaky knife skills might also consider a protective glove, like one of the lightweight knit ones made of synthetic fibers reinforced with stainless steel from Chefwear in Chicago (800-568-2433). There's a thin silver one for $17 (below, right) and a heavier ivory one (center) for $19. They might even motivate a pro to chop or slice faster, but take care; they're not 100 percent puncture- or slice-proof. These gloves can also be used when opening clams or oysters, though for that job you might splurge on a glove of stainless-steel mesh (left) like the chain mail of yesteryear; it's $134 from Savoir Vivre in Philadelphia (215-625-7964). And remember: the glove goes on the hand not wielding Excalibur.

title: KLM PROFIT UP 23%
description: The big Dutch airline KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said its first-quarter profit rose 23 percent, as higher fares and economic growth in Europe helped to insulate the carrier from fuel prices, which doubled. Talks to merge with British Airways P.L.C. are continuing, KLM said, as it reported profit of 43 million euros ($40 million) in the three months through June. KLM, emerging from a price war that hammered 1999 earnings, is benefiting from 3.5 percent annual growth of Europe's economy as well as cost cuts and a 3 percent fare increase.

title: On the North Fork, Dreams of Napa
description: It's high summer out here on the North Fork of Long Island. The corn is sweet, the first peaches are in, and in the vineyards, the still-green merlot and cabernet franc are looking good. It will be long weeks, maybe two months, before the pickers arrive and the air grows heady with the seductive aroma of crushed grapes.

Rob Burgess, Macromedia's chief executive, said yesterday that sales of Flash were expected to exceed $100 million in fiscal 2001, up from $40 million to $50 million in fiscal 2000, which ended March 31. description: The Norton Company agreed yesterday to buy the Chemfab Corporation for $141 million in cash to add its line of industrial fabrics made from glass fibers. Norton, a subsidiary of Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, the French company that is the world's largest glassmaker, will pay $18.25 a share, a total of $136 million, for Chemfab's stock and spend $5 million for outstanding options. It will also assume $30 million in debt. Chemfab, a maker of specialty chemicals, based in Merrimack, N.H., had sales of $125 million in the year ended June 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHR, ELAINE OAKLEY
description: BEHR-Elaine Oakley. 82. Died on July 23 at her home in East Hampton, New York after a long illness. She was the daughter of R. Lawrence Oakley and Sarah Perot Oakley of Greenwich, CT and East Hampton. She graduated from Rosemary Hall in 1936 and from Sarah Lawrence College in 1938. She is survived by her husband of 53 years, Karl Howell Behr, Yale '37. Residents of Princeton, N.J. for many years, they now reside in Mountain Lake, FL. Mrs. Behr was a talented interior designer, a gifted equestrian & an avid golfer, but most of all, she was devoted to her husband, her family, her friends, and the places where she lived and loved. She will be greatly missed. She is also survived by her sister Audrey Oakley Johnson of Basking Ridge, NJ, her daughters, Susan Travers of Princeton, N.J., Sally Ogden of Greenwich CT, Helen Sanford of Princeton, N.J. and Elaine King of Dover, MA., 10 grandchildren and 2 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be planned for a future date.

title: DVD SOFTWARE TRIAL ENDS

Kaplan told lawyers he had been impressed with testimony from a defense witness as to why computer software code should be protected by the First Amendment. Eight movie studios have urged the judge to stop a Web site operator from distributing a software program that unscrambles the encryption on DVD movie discs. Judge Kaplan ordered attorneys to submit their final briefs in the case by August 8. They may reconvene for closing arguments later this week. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Driving Up Drug Prices
description: Two recent antitrust actions by the Federal Trade Commission and a related federal court decision have exposed the way some pharmaceutical companies conspire to keep low-priced drugs out of reach of consumers. Manufacturers of patented drugs are paying tens of millions of dollars to manufacturers of generic drugs if they agree to keep products off the market. The drug companies split the profits from maintaining a monopoly at the consumer's expense. The commission is taking aggressive action to curb the practice. It needs help from Congress to close loopholes in federal law.

title: THE BOSS; All Hail the Taxi Business
description: My father and I are probably two of the only people in the United States not to have made money in real estate in the last 20 years. In 1987, when I was getting my M.B.A., we bought 100 acres of land in Old Westbury, N.Y. We wanted to develop luxury homes, but the project ended up being a 12-year ordeal. It took us five years to subdivide the land, and we didn't sell off the final lot until last month. We barely broke even. That taught me that I didn't know as much I thought I did. It also reminded me of the motto that my father has passed down to me, ''In niches, there are riches.''

Glass and steel doors swing into a high-ceilinged foyer with smiling receptionists. And in recent years the Concordes in commercial service -- all built in the 1970's or early 1980's -- had begun to show their age.

title: Taking Fusion Cuisine Into New Territory

AZ is now pronounced like the first and last letters of the English alphabet, a shrewd move, for two reasons. Diners who try to pronounce the letters as a word could easily come up with Oz or As. And how many who don't would figure out the French wordplay?

Unlike Cheddars and chevres, it doesn't wear a brand name or come in different shapes. It's one cheese, all the time.

The three nights he spent sleeping next to his mother's body when, unable to care for her three children alone, she poisoned herself. The yellow beret his uncle gave him when he was sent to the orphanage in the mountains.

title: 2-Year-Old Fillies to Go First at Saratoga
description: They called it Horse Haven when racing was inaugurated at Saratoga Springs in 1863 for a meet that lasted three days. But the next year, the ''new'' Saratoga Race Course opened on Union Avenue. And on Wednesday, for the 132nd year, it will open for racing again, starting a prestigious six-week schedule that will feature 35 stakes races carrying purses of $8.7 million along with historic reminders that the stately old track has also grown to become ''the Graveyard of Champions.''

title: Music as Background at a Pleasant Party
description: The Vans Warped Tour, which came to Randalls Island on Monday for a sixth-anniversary show, asks the question, what is punk besides an explosion? The music and the lifestyle intertwined with it were designed to rip apart routines, in the rock scene and in the larger culture. But punk's bomb has gone off intermittently for over two decades, and its adherents stay alive within the rubble. They form a society of outcasts, the teenagers (and, eventually, adults) who don't conform to standards of beauty, power and propriety, and support each other as they fight to stay true to themselves.

title: For Summer, Fast Food From the Sea
description: Slather some fresh sardines (that have been gutted but not boned) with good olive oil, tuck some herbs in the cavities and set them on a hot grill. In minutes you will have a summer feast that, with some slices of ripe tomato and a wedge of lemon, may transport your imagination to St.-Tropez or a port in Morocco. Fresh sardines are now about $4 to $5 a pound (six to eight fish) in several fish markets, including Fairway, Agata & Valentina Citarella and Balducci's.

title: LODGIAN SELLING 10 HOTELS TO SUNSTONE FOR $132 MILLION
description: Lodgian Inc. agreed yesterday to sell 10 hotel properties to the privately held Sunstone Hotel Investors L.L.C. for $132 million in cash as part of an effort to pare its debt. The company expects a pretax loss of about $50 million because of the sale, while cutting $11 million from its annual interest expense. The Atlanta-based Lodgian said it would sell five Holiday Inns, two Hilton Garden Inns, one Sheraton, one Courtyard by Marriott and one Marriott, totaling 2,135 rooms. Sunstone Hotel Investors, based in San Clemente, Calif., takes over and renovates mid- to luxury-level hotels.

title: I Say It Tastes Like Spinach
description: In the house where I grew up in Brooklyn, food was a religion. Christmas dinner would last four hours. You'd have the appetizer, talk about it, have another course, talk some more. You were aware of not just what went into the meal, but what the textures were supposed to be like, why one dish was better than another.

title: BUCKEYE TECHNOLOGIES BUYS A CELLULOSE PLANT IN BRAZIL
description: Buckeye Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the cotton cellulose business of Fibra S.A. of Brazil for $35 million. Buckeye, a maker of cellulose and absorbency products, is set to take over the operation, which is in Americana, Brazil, on Aug. 1. Buckeye also agreed to supply Fibra's Brazilian staple-rayon operations with cotton cellulose from the newly acquired plant. Buckeye's specialty cellulose and absorbent products are used in food casings, automotive filters, stationery, and beauty and personal hygiene products. It operates plants in the United States, Canada, Germany, and Ireland.

title: EATON EXPANDS STOCK BUYBACK PROGRAM BY $500 MILLION
description: The automotive and aerospace product maker, the Eaton Corporation, said yesterday that it would buy back up to another $500 million of its stock, about 10 percent of its outstanding shares, in an expansion of its share-repurchase program. The latest buyback should be complete by year's end. It is in addition to a $500 million five-year repurchase program that the company announced in January. Companies use buybacks to increase earnings per share by reducing shares outstanding. Eaton, based in Cleveland, had annual sales of $8.4 billion last year. Eaton's shares were down 75 cents at $67.625.

description: Researchers from Italy have provided the first genetic evidence linking sudden infant death syndrome to a rare heart disorder called long-QT syndrome, they are reporting today in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: The Citadel Wagner Built, Under Siege Inside and Out

Listeners and artists alike would make the short climb between rows of sheltering trees and find in the theater he dedicated to himself refreshment and renewal.

title: Shhhhh! Sleepwalking Diplomat at Work
description: MR. SNOOZLEBERG, sound asleep, walks in slippered feet toward the lion's cage. If the cage door is closed, he will bump into it and awaken, finding himself in his pajamas, miles from home, confused and penniless. If the cage is open, he will walk into the lion's mouth. And if he somehow gets by the lion, he still has a couple of seals, a gorilla and several very prickly porcupines to get past. It's a good thing you're watching out for the poor guy.

title: Poetry in Motion in the East Village
description: CHRISTMAS 1978 wasn't very merry in certain quarters of the East Village. Hard drugs, sold openly on street corners, were a present of choice for some. The air echoed with the wails of sirens, as hook and ladders put out fires set by addicts in dozens of abandoned buildings. As for good will toward men: the Ninth Precinct reported 54 assaults, 157 robberies and 4 murders for that December.

title: Utilities Take Stake In Power-Trade Site
description: Abandoning plans to create their own Internet energy-trading exchange, the Duke Energy Corporation, the El Paso Energy Corporation, the Southern Company and three other power-trading companies acquired a stake in IntercontinentalExchange, an online power and metals trading site.

title: Corrections

title: CURRENTS: FACADES; A Drugstore Keeps Times Square Flavor

Still, Duane Reade added some neon pizazz (text above the two story windows, a bulls-eye around the ''DR'' logo and a zippy canopy) to the facade. Brendan Sexton, head of the business district, likes the store, but he said, ''We didn't even know about it until it arrived.''

title: FRANKLIN RESOURCES UNIT BUYS FUND MANAGER IN CANADA
description: Franklin Resources Inc., the sixth-largest United States mutual fund company, agreed yesterday to buy Bissett & Associates Investment Management Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, for $95 million to expand in Canada. The purchase by Franklin's Templeton Management Ltd. unit will add $3.75 billion to the assets it manages in Canada, bringing the total to $26 billion. Over all, Templeton oversees $229 billion. Templeton agreed to pay 20.50 Canadian dollars a share for the 18-year-old fund manager, which serves individual investors through Bissett mutual funds, Atlas mutual funds and several alliances.

title: 2 Agencies Agree To Be Acquired

title: QUARTERLY LOSS FOR SONY
description: An extraordinary write-off from expenses in the film business caused the Sony Corporation to report an 88.29 billion yen ($810 million) loss for the April-June quarter, compared with a profit of 18.43 billion yen the year before. But even when the one-time expense is excluded, Sony's profits fell 20 percent to 33.7 billion yen ($309 million), reflecting the impact of the strong yen and weakness in its PlayStation business. Strong sales of Sony's hardware products worldwide like the Vaio brand of personal computers, digital cameras and DVD video players helped to compensate for the weakness. Sony sales for the quarter rose 5.4 percent, to 1.56 trillion yen. Miki Tanikawa

description: Joe Montana steps into the Pro Football Hall of Fame on Saturday in Canton, Ohio. It never bothered Montana that some people might frown over his selection of Eddie DeBartolo as his presenter.

title: Turnpike Stops Worth the Trip
description: THE scenery along the Ohio Turnpike -- an east-west melding of Interstates 80, 90 and 76 -- will never be confused with that along, say, the Pacific Coast Highway or the Blue Ridge Parkway. But weary travelers this summer are encountering something that may compensate: a new generation of service plazas, providing the amenities of home or at least those of a decent airport terminal.

title: Schilling To Arizona, As the Mets Just Shrug
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks didn't need a No. 1 starter, but they secured one anyway yesterday. Randy Johnson, meet Curt Schilling.

title: A Roundabout Journey to Glamour; Nonprofit Rise From a Chelsea Basement to New Times Square
description: Not so long ago the nonprofit Roundabout Theater Company was performing plays for 150 people in a supermarket basement on West 26th Street where a scene from Ibsen or Shaw might well be accompanied by the sound of rolling meat carts rumbling through the ceiling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUAIN, LEON
description: QUAIN-Leon. On July 26, 2000. Coowner of the famous ''Hotel Elysee'' and The Monkey Bar. Dear brother of Dr. Samanto Quain, Alyce Jacobs and Rachel Pinto. Service Friday at 11:15 AM at the ''Riverside'', 76 St & Amsterdam Avenue, New York City. Visiting Thursday evening 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLAH, SAM
description: MALLAH-Sam. Born May 5, 1908, died July 25, 2000. A survivor of The Holocaust who will be missed by all the lives he touched. He is survived by his daughters Lily and Alice, his son-in-law Richard, his grandchildren Charles and his wife Sangeeta, Shari and her husband Laurence, Lisa and her husband Stuart and Seth and his fiance Lisa, and his pride and joy his greatgrandchildren Natalie, Rebecca and Zamir. He will be greatly missed but will always be remembered with love. Services Friday 9:30AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Wiretapping in Cyberspace
description: Millions of Americans now log on to the Internet as naturally and as frequently as they pick up a phone. Technology has created a revolution in personal communications, but technology is also making it possible for government and even employers to monitor private conversations as never before. Telephone-era laws must be updated to address these new challenges to privacy.

title: Learning How to Run: A West Texas Stumble
description: George W. Bush was seething with frustration. Here he was, feeling as Texan as the chaw he liked to tuck under his lower lip, and he had to smile gamely while the audience snickered at him as an alien in cowboy boots.

title: Behind the Music: Organs Go Electronic
description: THE imposing facade of the main pipe organ at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan looks about the same as it did before its recent overhaul. And its thousands of pipes still produce celestial blasts of trumpets in the treble and rumbling thunder in the bass.

title: Gore Calls for Defeat of G.O.P. 'Old Guard'
description: Warning against apathy within the Democratic ranks, Vice President Al Gore today urged members of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's organization, the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition, to set aside doubts about him and work to defeat the Republican ''old guard'' embodied in the ticket of Gov. George W. Bush and Dick Cheney.

description: PORTNOY-Charlotte S. (Kavanau), July 25, 2000. Loving wife of Isidore. Beloved mother of Miriam, Barbara, Gail and Joyce, and mother-in-law of Jack, Paul, Stan and Robert. Adored grandmother of Garrett, Joshua, Hilary, Deborah, Hana, Gregory, Elie, Liana. Devoted great-grandmother of Isabella. Proud student of Fordham University, and a wonderful nurse to many. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Heart Association, 122 East 42 Street, NY, NY 10168.

description: Randy Thomas and Ryan Young are sauntering into the Hofstra cafeteria for another lunch together, another day side by side, preparing for a season in which they will spend much of their football time -- and off time -- together. Thomas and Young are the sturdy duo who emerged on the right side of the offensive line last year, the two rookies who, first Thomas, then Young, won starting spots next to each other, just as they live much of their day.

title: ITS MANAGEMENT DIVIDED, KROLL-O'GARA PLANS SEPARATION
description: The Kroll-O'Gara Company said yesterday that it had formed a preliminary plan to split its two main operations -- security products and investigations -- into independent publicly held corporations. The company announced in April that it was exploring the separation of its operations in an effort to resolve differences among top management. Under the proposed realignment, the two operating segments will be the Security Products and Services Group, which will be run by Thomas and Bill O'Gara, and the Investigations and Intelligence Group, under Jules B. Kroll. Both companies will continue to hold a stake in Kroll-O'Gara's Internet security subsidiary, Securify Inc., which will be spun off as a private company,

title: TECHNOLOGY BRIEFING: E-COMMERCE; NO DECISION ON ONLINE CUSTOMER LIST
description: A federal bankruptcy judge in Boston said she would not override a Federal Trade Commission ruling on the sale of a customer list by a defunct online toy merchant, Toysmart.com. Judge Carol Kenner is scheduled to hold a hearing within the next month on how or whether Toysmart can preserve its pledge to safeguard consumer information while selling its Web site, customer lists and other corporate assets as the company is liquidated. Several states have said any sale of customer records should be preceded by notification of the people affected.

title: With Debts Paid Online, Check Is in the E-Mail
description: THE check was not in the mail, not for the last 10 years. Serdar Danis, a Philadelphia salesman, had lent $15 to a walletless friend one night a decade ago but had never been paid back. As time passed, it just seemed too petty to mention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVESAY, DARDEN RAWLES, SR.
description: LIVESAY-Darden Rawles, Sr. Of Stamford, CT and Long Boat Key, FL, died July 24, 2000 in Vancouver, BC. He was 65. He is survived by his loving wife Paulette, his three sons Darden Rawles Livesay, Jr. of Wilton, CT, Gregory Paul Livesay of Rye, NY, and Andrew Watkins Livesay of Stamford, CT. He is also survived by three grandchildren, Anastasia, Darden Rawles Livesay, III and Brandon Gregory Livesay. A sister, Joyce Harding of Emporia, VA, also survives. Calling hours are Saturday from 7-9 PM and Sunday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Mass of Christian Burial is Monday 10:30 AM at St. Leo's Church, Roxbury Road, Stamford, CT. Interment will follow, Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; Armstrong Sees Beyond A Handlebar
description: SEE his picture on the front page of newspapers and magazines, catch him on the network news, read about him in newspaper editorials usually reserved for world-imposing figures and events and shake out the contents of a cereal box with his image on the front, and the theme is invariably the same: Lance Armstrong is a hero.

title: CURRENTS: BAUHAUS DESIGN; Breuer Collection Bows in America
description: For the first time ever, Marcel Breuer's angular birch furniture is available in the United States. The pieces, originally designed by Breuer, a Bauhaus master, in 1936, are now manufactured in Britain by Isokon Plus. The collection includes seating with curving wooden arms, upholstered in neutral shades of linen, cotton, or wool (sofa, $6,500; armchair $3,500), and a set of nesting tables with rounded tops that fold into triangular legs ($1,145 for three).

title: Multinationals Sign U.N. Pact on Rights and Environment
description: Executives of DaimlerChrysler, Nike and Royal Dutch Shell filled a chamber today where diplomats usually conduct business, as the United Nations recruited many well-known multinational companies to help protect workers and the environment in places where governments do not.

title: Shares Fall on Worries That Earnings Will Begin to Fade
description: Stocks tumbled yesterday after several companies warned that their profits would be lower than expected in the second half of the year.

title: DUPONT APPROVES $1.8 BILLION STOCK BUYBACK PROGRAM
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said yesterday that it was expanding its share repurchase program by $1.8 billion. The plan would expand the December 1998 authorization to acquire as many as 20 million DuPont shares. DuPont has purchased about four million shares, leaving about $700 million available under the 1998 program. DuPont's shares have fallen about a third this year as materials costs soared and investors have worried about future profit growth. The company said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 7 percent, to $949 million. DuPont's shares rose $1.3125, to $44.9375.

title: DVD's Move to the Really Small Screen
description: MY friend Laura once pitched an article called ''Guy Bait'' to a major women's magazine, for which she wanted to take nifty gadgets into bars and see how long it took patrons of the male persuasion to sidle over for casual conversation and a little technology cruising. If portable digital video disk players had been on the market then, I suspect that she would have had the men sidling in from 10 blocks away.

title: ARTS ABROAD; A Roving Show Fixates on Europe's Border Obsession
description: Sleek electric signs appeared in late June over the neo-Renaissance balustrades that frame the walkways of the Tromostovje, or Three Bridges, at the heart of this capital. Had the signs offered directions to the business district or a historic landmark, they would have attracted scant attention in a city where past and present mingle easily. But these signs, created by Selja Kameric, a Sarajevo artist, are meant to conjure up the new Europe, or one vision of it.

title: FILM SERVICES CONCERN TO MAKE $125 MILLION ACQUISITION
description: The Liberty Livewire Corporation, a provider of post-production services for film and television, agreed late on Tuesday to buy the Video Services Corporation for about $125 million in cash, stock and assumed debt. Liberty Media Group, the media arm of AT&T, owns a majority of Liberty Livewire's shares. The shareholders of Video Services will receive 0.104 of a share of Liberty Media Group's Class A stock and $2.75 in cash for each Video Services share. The transaction values Video Services, based in Northvale, N.J., at about $125 million, or $5.23 a share. The stock fell 12.5 cents, to $4.625, on the American Stock Exchange. Video Services has annual revenue of about $100 million and employs about 500 people. The shares of Los Angeles-based Liberty Livewire fell $3.50 yesterday, to $63.

title: CURRENTS: UTENSILS; Eliminating The Rind Grind
description: Tired of sticky fingers from peeling oranges? The German manufacturer Mono Tabletop has an almost perfect solution -- a curved, stainless steel peeler called Citro ($22). The ergonomic gadget will neatly score the fruit, top to bottom, with surgical incisions.

title: Padres Scouting a Prospect in Columbus
description: A scout for the San Diego Padres is tracking the Yankees' Class AAA affiliate Columbus as possible preparation for a swap of highly touted young players, a deal that could lead to greater things for the Yankees.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN INFLATION OUTLOOK
description: A Bank of Mexico survey of economists shows they expect the inflation rate to ease to 9.2 percent this year, down from an annualized rate of 9.67 percent at the end of the first quarter and well within the central bank's target rate of 10 percent. But the Bank of Mexico said the growing economy and higher-than-expected salary increases could imperil its goal of reducing inflation to 3 percent by 2003, suggesting it will need to tighten monetary policy. Dan Fineren

Lazio, a relative newcomer to statewide politics, went on something of a philanthropic binge this month, giving a total of $72,500 on the same day to all 62 Republican county committees in the state. title: As Deregulation Begins, New Yorkers' Power Bills Soar

The cost, she said, jumped to $78 in June -- even though she spent an entire week out of town with the air-conditioning off -- compared with $35 for the previous month.

The Adelphia Communications Corporation, the Comcast Corporation and Cox Communications Inc. signed agreements to sell the WorldGate service. Charter Communications Inc. extended a previous accord.

title: Metro Business; Contract for Taconic
description: The Thalle Construction Company, a road and utility contractor based in Briarcliff Manor in Westchester County, has been awarded a $29 million contract for the latest reconstruction work on the Taconic State Parkway. The work is to involve rebuilding stretches of the parkway and making safety improvements in Yorktown.

title: Kentucky Steps Up Fight on Illiteracy
description: Statisticians call Marsha Hendrickson, a coal miner's daughter and the mother of four, functionally illiterate. With the national economy bubbling along, soaking up workers and spreading wealth, she and much of Appalachia live not only with poverty and unemployment but also with the humiliation of being taken for ignorant.

title: ECONOMIC SCENE; The Internet carries profound implications for providers of information.

This fact has profound implications for the economics of industries that provide such information. The most recent example is Napster, the music directory service available over the Internet.

title: With Plane on Fire, Pilot Couldn't Halt Takeoff

title: A Missile Message From North Korea
description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia came back from North Korea recently reporting a tantalizing offer. The North, he said, would give up its menacing long-range-missile program if other countries would launch at least two North Korean space satellites a year. If, as Mr. Putin believes, Pyongyang envisions sending its satellites abroad for launching, the proposal merits serious consideration. But if North Korea expects other countries to provide it with advanced rockets it could learn to copy, the risks are unacceptable.

title: Preschool Programs Still Substandard, Poor Districts Say
description: Five months after the New Jersey Supreme Court chided state officials for not moving quickly enough, lawyers for 30 poor urban school districts said yesterday that the State Department of Education was still not meeting the court's repeated orders to provide meaningful preschool programs for 49,000 eligible 3- and 4-year-olds.

title: Gulf War Led Cheney to the Oil Boardroom
description: Four years after helping to win the Persian Gulf war and liberating the oil fields of Kuwait, former Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney went from fighting for oil to running a Dallas-based business that he has helped transform into the world's largest oil field services company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHER, EILEEN A.
description: MAHER-Eileen A. Of Centereach, NY, in her 79th year, on July 24, 2000. Former resident of Peter Cooper Village, NYC. Retiree from the Mobil Oil Corp. Survived by her cousin, Ruth Stephani of Patchogue, NY and her nephew, Paul Kelley of CT. Predeceased by her parents Arthur and Margaret Maher; her brothers, A. Chisholm, Stuart, Robert and Rev. Gordon Maher; her sisters, Helen Maher McKernon, Florence Maher Kelley and Sister Mary Gratia Maher, R.S.M. Reposing at the Ruland Funeral Home, 500 North Ocean Avenue (South of LIE Exit 63) in Patchogue. Family received friends Wednesday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Memorial donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Lizards Behind PC Glass (Whew!)
description: Lizard fans will be in herpetology heaven at Discovery.com's ''Lizards!'' (www.discovery .com/exp/lizards/lizards.html), a virtual exhibition developed with the American Museum of Natural History. Visitors can see the common flying dragon, a five-inch lizard from Southeast Asia, glide from tree to tree, and hear the raspy call of the panther chameleon of Madagascar. The cold-blooded beauties also include the thorny devil of eastern Australia (right), which typically eats 2,000 ants at each meal. SHELLY FREIERMAN

title: Tyson to Fight In Michigan
description: The former heavyweight champion Mike Tyson is tentatively scheduled to fight David Izon, a 31-year-old heavyweight from Ghana, on Sept. 8 or 9 in Auburn Hills, Mich. It would mark his second fight in the United States since being released from jail 14 months ago.

title: Simplicity And Power Are Driving Data Delivery; A Little-Known Company May Mirror the Future
description: For a glimpse of the telecommunications industry's probable future, visit the 22nd floor of the cavernous networking center at 60 Hudson Street in Manhattan.

title: COMPAQ FINED FOR OVERCHARGES
description: Compaq Computer has agreed to pay $4.5 million to settle claims that Digital Equipment, which it acquired in 1998, had overcharged the government for installing computer equipment, Justice Department officials said. Digital admitted in 1995 that it had submitted inflated labor costs to the Defense Department for work done in Orlando, Fla., and in Frankfurt. Government investigators subsequently found that Digital had also converted costs for some computer parts, shipping and warehousing into labor charges, billed travel time as direct costs and charged a higher billing rate for some work than the contract permitted, officials said.

description: Sites and Events This Week

title: Half Revival, Half Rockers, But Proselytizing Throughout
description: Nyabinghi music is to reggae what campfire spirituals are to gospel, and the Mystic Revelation of Rastafari, performing on Monday night at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, delivered a concise, presentable version of it. They were partly re-enacting one of the religious conventions, called ''grounations,'' that they regularly hold in their West Kingston stronghold: Rastafarian revival meetings of dancing, singing, playing, cooking and worshiping that last for days.

title: Yielding to Pressure, Japan Delays Sale of Nippon Credit
description: Japanese regulators today postponed by one month the sale of the nationalized Nippon Credit Bank to a group of investors led by the Softbank Corporation, one of the world's largest Internet investment companies.

title: A Festival of Animation, Animatedly
description: An army of samurai come roaring on horseback down a medieval hillside in a driving rain, kicking up mud and water. Several of them dismount, swords and spears spinning, and break into a brutal ballet of combat and impalings. One of them takes an arrow through the throat, an image lifted directly from Akira Kurosawa's ''Throne of Blood'' and given a fresh twist in this bleak, computer-generated landscape.

title: Metro Business; Shortfall Proposal By HIP Subsidiary
description: A Florida subsidiary of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York proposed yesterday to gradually eliminate a $4.8 million shortfall in its reserves by laying off 41 workers, cutting other costs and raising insurance premiums, company officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLIES, CAROL ZAISER
description: GILLIES-Carol Zaiser. July 24, 2000, aged 68, at Cabrini Hospice, NY, of breast cancer, which for eight years she fought without quarter, to the very end: valiant, uncomplaining, a model of how life should be lived. Her husband, Ewen Gillies; sister, Marilyn Ott; stepsons Lindsay, Elliot and Adrian Gillies, stepdaughter Sarah Robertson Gillies; niece Carolyn Martin, nephew Dr. Kevin Martin; their families and a host of loving friends survive her. Contributions in her name should go to the Oncology Research Fund, NYU School of Medicine, c/o Dr. James Speyer, 160 East 32 Street, New York, NY 10016.

title: Long Beach, in Los Angeles's Shadow, Strives for a Spotlight
description: To hear municipal officials here tell it, there is no more enduring, supportive relationship in a region known more for affairs and heartbreaks than the bond between this industrious, muscular port and that livable but, let's be honest, tough if not troubled city just north, Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLICK, FRANCES
description: MARGOLICK-Frances. Died on Tuesday, July 25th after a long illness. Beloved sister of Moses. Sister-in-law of Gert and Evelyn. ''Auntie Frances'' or ''A.F.'' to many nieces and nephews, to whom her tiny apartment on the Upper West Side was a compulsory stop and a safe, loving haven during periodic visits to New York. She will be missed by her family and by her many friends at The New York Times, where she was longtime Secretary to the cultural news editor. Funeral services on Friday in Montreal.

title: Though Retired, Way May Be Most Valuable
description: At the National Football League coaching symposium in Baltimore last May, the Giants decided on a plan that would change one man's life and potentially affect many more. St. Louis Coach Dick Vermeil, still glowing from his Super Bowl victory, was asked for the biggest reason his team won the championship. He didn't cite the arm of quarterback Kurt Warner or the speed of his defense. He talked about a person in the Rams' front office who was the team's troubleshooter, the one whom players confided in when turmoil was brewing in their lives. Without him, Vermeil said, the Rams never would have made it to the big game.

title: Tax Company Raided by I.R.S.
description: Treasury and Internal Revenue Service agents yesterday raided the South Carolina headquarters of J. K. Harris Inc., the nation's largest company helping people settle back tax debts at a discount.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SONIC AUTOMOTIVE INC., Charlotte, N.C., the second-largest publicly held auto dealer, said it was in talks to acquire dealerships with combined annual revenue of $500 million by the end of the year.

title: JDS Uniphase Fourth-Quarter Profits Exceed Estimates
description: The JDS Uniphase Corporation, a fast-growing maker of components for fiber optic networks, reported fourth-quarter earnings today that exceeded analysts' estimates when excluding charges for the company's wave of acquisitions.

title: UTILITY SUPERCONDUCTORS
description: The Wisconsin Public Service Corporation yesterday began reinforcing a section of its power grid with five energy storage units employing superconducting magnets, the first commercial use of superconductivity in public power distribution. The devices, manufactured by American Superconductor of Westborough, Mass., will be protecting the region around Wausau and Eagle River from voltage spikes and dips as well as blackouts and should increase the capacity of that portion of the grid by 15 percent, according to American Superconductor.

title: For the Thorny Devil Lizard, Ants Are a Picnic.
description: For the Thorny Devil Lizard, Ants Are a Picnic.

title: Saving The Nation's Digital Legacy
description: THE Library of Congress is charged with collecting the creative work of the American people. This has come to include such varied output as the papers of Thomas Jefferson and the Wright brothers, the original compositions of Leonard Bernstein and the video archives of the Martha Graham Dance Company.

title: Religion and Its Landmarks
description: Under the banner of religious liberty, Congress is nearing approval of a law that could make it harder to use zoning laws to save landmarked churches and church property from the wrecking ball. Senators Edward Kennedy and Orrin Hatch have rallied behind this bill -- known as the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act -- as a way to remedy abuses against religious groups by zoning boards. But it tilts the balance in favor of church administrators who may wish to use their properties for development and against local communities that may wish to preserve things as they are.

title: Federal Judge Allows Spraying to Continue
description: A federal judge yesterday cleared the way for New York City to continue spraying pesticides to control the spread of West Nile virus, but steady rain forced the city to postpone for a day its plans to spray much of Manhattan and Roosevelt Island.

title: CURRENTS: HOUSING; Hoboken With a View
description: Sergio Guardia, an architect in Manhattan, is trying to change the face of housing in Hoboken, N.J., with a 64-unit rental apartment building (computer renderings, above and below) that weaves together three new structures and two old renovated factories at 332 Jefferson Street. Courtyards, decks and gardens will ''break the boxes a little,'' Mr. Guardia said. Rents have not been set for the one- to three-bedroom apartments (some with views of Manhattan), but Mr. Guardia says a two-bedroom will cost up to $2,200 a month. The project, just under way, joins a similar one by Mr. Guardia, near completion at 1017 Jefferson Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEON, LEE
description: LEON-Lee. We celebrate the life and mourn the death of Lee Leon of Beverly Hills (formerly of Scarsdale) who peacefully passed away Saturday July 22, 2000. Devoted wife of Sol, beloved mother of Steven, Susan and Andy (Fredman), adored grandmother of Josh and Ali, dear sister of Jean and Joyce and cherished friend of many. Service Thursday 12:30pm at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Rd, Mamaroneck, NY 1 - 888 - 381 - 1809, for directions www.zionmemorialchapel.com. Interment to follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Saint Luke's Episcopal Church Memorial Garden Fund or The Salvation Army.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEN BROEDER, FREDERICK
description: den BROEDER-Frederick, who died in New York City on July 8 at the age of 64 made significant and original contributions to the field of 18th-century Roman studies with the first catalogue and exhibition in the US (1973) on the subject, The Academy of Europe: Rome in the 18th Century, for the William Benton Museum of Art, University of Connecticut, where he had become curator after receiving a Ford Fellowship at the Cleveland Museum of Art. He continued to publish important articles that, with his wide-ranging art historical and cultural knowledge and his sensitive and discerning eye, informed his later work as independent scholar, curator and consultant, including the exhibition and catalogue Old Master Drawings from the Collection of Joseph F. McCrindle, for The Art Museum, Princeton University, 1991. In later years he became an avid horseman and had moved recently to Tucson, Arizona.

title: Israeli and Palestinian Leaders Vow to Keep Working for Peace
description: Ehud Barak and Yasir Arafat each pledged today to keep working at their halting quest for peace despite the breakup of the Camp David summit meeting.

title: HYUNDAI DEBT TERMS EASED
description: Creditors of South Korea's largest business conglomerate, the Hyundai Group, agreed to postpone debt repayment obligations for a leading affiliate of the conglomerate. Although Hyundai Group officials denied rumors of a severe cash shortage, the Hyundai Engineering and Construction Company was a day late in paying its employees this month, raising concerns about the conglomerate's financial condition. Debts at the construction affiliate totaled 5.1 trillion won at the end of 1999, of which 2.2 trillion won is due by the end of this year. ''We agreed to extend maturity on loans extended to Hyundai Engineering and Construction, in order to ease its short-term cash shortage,'' said Lee Youn Soo, vice president of the main creditor, Korea Exchange Bank. Samuel Len

title: Mets Find Their Pitcher, Roberts From the Minors
description: The soggy field was covered with a blue tarpaulin and the clubhouse was almost empty after the Mets postponed last night's game against the Expos and scheduled a doubleheader for today. The handful of players who trickled into Shea to work out were intrigued when they learned that the Mets had added a new pitcher to start the first game of the doubleheader.

title: PROFIT DOUBLES AT SIEMENS
description: The earnings of Germany's largest electronics company, Siemens A.G., more than doubled in its third quarter as profit soared at its semiconductor unit, but the company's shares fell on the worry that growth had peaked. The company's profit in the period that ended on June 30 rose to 832 million euros ($783.6 million) from 356.4 million euros a year earlier. Earnings at Infineon Technologies, the chip maker 71-percent-owned by Siemens, rose more than sevenfold. But Siemens reiterated that earnings growth could slow in the fourth quarter.

title: Last-Minute Repair to Engine That Caught Fire on Concorde
description: The Concorde that crashed into a hotel near Charles de Gaulle Airport outside Paris on Tuesday, setting off a fireball and killing 113 people, had been delayed from taking off by last-minute repairs to the engine that burst into flames, officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a Nassau County jail guard who won a lawsuit contending that he was harassed for being gay misstated his reason for filing under the equal protection clause of the 14th Amendment to the Constitution. No federal, state or Nassau County law prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation. But such laws indeed exist in some jurisdictions in the state: 17 other municipalities, including 10 counties, have them.

description: Federal authorities announced today what they called the largest seizure of the hallucinogenic drug ecstasy, nearly 1,100 pounds.

title: Amazon Reports Losses of $317 Million in the 2nd Quarter
description: Amazon.com said yesterday that it had lost $317 million in the second quarter of the year, slightly less than analysts had expected, and asserted that it had stanched the heavy drain on its cash reserves that has raised doubts in the minds of many investors.

While this was the first crash of a Concorde, it was not the first of a supersonic airliner; a Soviet Tupolev 144 crashed at the Paris Air Show in 1973, and another crashed on a test flight in 1978.

description: Like a number of lesbian couples, Christine T. and Janis C. wanted children. They were blessed with two, a boy and a girl, now 4 and 2. Christine was ''Mommy,'' Janis was ''Momma,'' and the children used both women's surnames. The couple decided that Janis would support the family while Christine stayed at home in Harrison, N.Y., with the children.

title: A 'Tough' Plane, Almost All the Time
description: In the aftermath of the crash of an Air France Concorde near Paris, some of the pilots who have flown them pondered a paradox today. The supersonic airliner, according to one, is tough and robust, with ''tremendous reserve capacity'' to power its way out of trouble. But, according to another, if the plane lost a side-by-side pair of its four engines at low speed just after takeoff, it would be ''impossible to control.''

title: FORD SAID TO PLAN IMPROVED MILEAGE IN SPORT UTILITIES
description: The Ford Motor Company has decided to increase the average fuel economy of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent over the next five years, people involved in the company's plans said today. The increase, amounting to roughly five miles a gallon, would be the first significant change in the fuel economy of any class of passenger vehicle in almost two decades.

title: CURRENTS: POTTERY; Taking a Jitney To the Birdhouse
description: The potter Jonathan Adler has created the perfect ceramic birdhouse for nature-loving Hamptonites who aren't afraid of windstorms. The fragile house ($250, about eight inches tall, above) features his signature retro curves, with a shape reminiscent of vintage Christmas ornaments and a hole. It's part of a collection of glazed, handmade pots and vases he created especially for the new East Hampton outpost of Jonathan Adler on Broome Street. Hand-painted (if your birds care); 1 Main Street, East Hampton, N.Y.; (631) 329-6499.

title: In Design, Svelte From the Veldt
description: FEMI DAWKINS, a Jamaican artist, and Anna de Boer, a Dutch artist, create walls and floors in vibrant colors, inspired by the Ndebele and Yoruba peoples of Africa. They commute from Amsterdam to clients in New York and Los Angeles, who relish their European-African mix. ''A true middle ground,'' Ms. de Boer said.

title: Promising Giants Rookie Tears Ligament in Knee
description: The Giants' promising rookie linebacker, Dhani Jones, a sixth-round draft choice from the University of Michigan who was having a spectacular training camp, tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee today in a special teams drill and is out for the season.

description: RICHARD C. VISCONTI is talking about the highs and lows of a job -- his -- and tracing a jagged shape in the air. A mountain he'd love to ski? The Manhattan skyline his job makes him responsible for? No digressions, please. Mr. Visconti is methodical, focused, exacting, and not one to humor us by going off on tangents about metaphors.

title: The First Stop on the Way Home: A Visit With Mubarak
description: Trying to mine some hope from the failed Camp David peace talks and prepare the ground for new negotiations, Egyptian officials today welcomed the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, for consultations on his way home from the United States.

description: Former President Suharto will be charged with corruption in a few days, Attorney General Marzuki Darusman said today.

description: The Xerox Corporation said today that its second-quarter profit fell by half on lower sales and that efforts to turn around operations would take longer than expected. Per share earnings declined 17.5 percent.

description: Something was missing from the Yankees in the first three months this season, and maybe it was desperation. The Yankees were desperate to establish themselves in 1996, desperate to make their mark on history in 1998 and desperate to play through personal traumas in 1999.

title: Henry Mayer, 59, Historian Known for Book on Abolitionist
description: Henry Mayer, a historian and critic best known for his award-winning revisionist book ''All on Fire: William Lloyd Garrison and the Abolition of American Slavery,'' died on Monday while on a bicycling trip with his wife in Glacier National Park in northwestern Montana. He was 59 and lived in Berkeley, Calif.

description: A federal appeals panel here struck down as unconstitutional New Jersey's ban on so-called partial-birth abortions. The decision today mirrored a United States Supreme Court ruling in June.

description: EVEN among serious students of Bach, only the most privileged ever hope to examine the composer's handwritten scores.

description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Tuesday about the purchase of ChiRex, a manufacturer for the pharmaceutical industry, by the French chemical company Rhodia misstated the price. It is $510 million, not $510 billion.

title: Voting Record Dogs Cheney As G.O.P. Team Campaigns
description: Gov. George W. Bush and his new running mate, Dick Cheney, made a whirlwind visit today to the vice-presidential contender's home state, defending Mr. Cheney's conservative voting record and vowing that the ticket would ''renew America's purpose.''

title: Samaranch Says I.O.C. 'Has a New Philosophy'
description: With only 50 days remaining before the opening ceremonies of the Summer Olympic Games in Sydney, Australia, Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, was interviewed yesterday by Christopher Clarey of The New York Times. The interview took place in Samaranch's office overlooking Lake Geneva at the I.O.C.'s headquarters in Lausanne, Switzerland, and it covered a wide range of topics, from preparations for the Summer Games to the continuing investigation into possible bribery and fraud in Salt Lake City's bid to be host of the 2002 Winter Olympics.

description: ABC News is revamping the executive structure of its newsmagazine division amid a general decline in ratings for the magazine-style programs at all of the major broadcast networks.

title: Using an Opponent's Bid To Beat the Odds on a Slam
description: Many contracts at the bridge table are not as good as they appear. In the diagramed deal, the North-South hands are a good bet for six no-trump. That will succeed if the spades divide evenly or if the heart finesse wins, giving the contract a 68 percent chance.

title: SEVERN TRENT ENDS TALKS TO BUY WASTE MANAGEMENT UNIT
description: Severn Trent P.L.C., Britain's second-biggest water company, said yesterday that talks to buy the Swedish unit of Waste Management had ended after the parties failed to resolve ''significant issues.'' Severn Trent did not disclose the value of the aborted acquisition from the Houston-based Waste Management, North America's largest refuse hauler. Severn, the owner of Britain's fourth-largest landfill site, is the country's biggest waste-management operator.

title: CABOT TO SELL STAKE IN MICROELECTRONICS UNIT
description: The Cabot Corporation said yesterday that it would spin off its remaining 80.5 percent stake in the Cabot Microelectronics Corporation, a producer of chemicals used in making computer chips, three months after it first sold shares to the public. The shares of Cabot Microelectronics, which is based in Aurora, Ill., rose 37.5 cents, to $48, more than double the price of $20 at which they were first sold to the public on April 4, and the total shares are worth more than $1 billion. The Cabot Corporation, a Boston-based maker of chemicals used in tires, polishes and oil-drilling fluids, said the spinoff would be distributed as a dividend to Cabot Microelectronics shareholders. The parent company's stock rose $1.8125 a share, to $33.50.

title: Upstaging the Mosquitoes at Last, With Gaiety and Introspection
description: Neither a postponement nor fear of mosquitoes or insecticide, much less the overcast skies, kept listeners away from the New York Philharmonic's rescheduled concert on Tuesday evening in Central Park. The Philharmonic and the Parks Department estimated that there were 35,000 people on the Great Lawn.

title: New York Transport Chief Leaving to Take Bridgeport Police Post
description: Wilbur L. Chapman, the city's transportation commissioner and one of the few high-ranking black officials in the Giuliani administration, is resigning to become the police commissioner of Bridgeport, Conn., officials in that city said.

title: Alexander Dallin, 76, Dies; Precise Historian of Russia
description: Alexander Dallin, an American historian of the Soviet Union whose family took part in the Russian Revolution but who was widely respected for the scholarly detachment with which he viewed Communism, died of heart failure on July 22 in Stanford, Calif. He was 76.

title: Talks Intensify With Ex-Chief Of Sotheby's
description: Discussions to win the cooperation of Sotheby's former president and chief executive, Diana D. Brooks, in the federal antitrust investigation of Sotheby's and Christie's have intensified, lawyers and others close to the case said this week.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Two reports see exchange-traded funds as a logical extension for mutual fund companies.
description: EXCHANGE-TRADED funds are gaining favor among investors and may soon evolve into a viable alternative to a broad range of traditional mutual funds, two new reports predict.

description: Three pictures on the front page of The Times told the Camp David story: Ehud Barak stunned and dismayed, Bill Clinton shattered -- and Yasir Arafat grinning broadly.

title: Race Issues Folded Into The Caldron Of Academe
description: Clearly the question isn't only, ''What do we mean when we talk about race?'' It's also, How do we sound despite what we mean or what we feel or want to feel? That's what happens when two languages share one space: anger and shame, for instance, or confrontation and equivocation. Language can rule and reduce us. We get stuck with (and in) the same old phrases when we want to say and feel something new, or (uglier and scarier) we devise a new vocabulary to disguise the same old thoughts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODELL, JILL S.
description: MODELL-Jill S. On July 25, 2000 at age 55, after a courageous struggle, from breast cancer. Passed away peacefully at home with her family at her side. She is survived by her husband Jerry of 34 years, her mother Arleen Meyers, her children Jonathan and Samantha, her brothers Michael and Donald Ostrower. Founder and President of Fiber-Seal of Long Island. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Susan G. Komen New York Race for the Cure, 341 W. 38 St., 10th Flr, N.Y., N.Y. 10018. title: The Conservative Agenda: A Big Flush

description: Even the darkest clouds have a silver lining, and Mesa Verde National Park officials are clinging to such optimism as firefighters struggle to contain a wildfire that has burned 23,000 acres in and near the park.

title: Restaurants Are Updating Their Appearance, Tile by Tile ...
description: Tile is bringing stylish design to restaurant dining rooms all over town. The right glazed white tiles give the chic Pastis its Parisian look. Guastavino takes its name from the terra cotta tiles that wrap its soaring vaults. Hugh Hardy of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates, who designed Guastavino, said that ''after 10 years of display kitchens in restaurants, the kitchen has started extending its powers into the dining room.'' At Brasserie 8 1/2, which opened last week at 9 West 57th Street, Mr. Hardy collaborated with Joel Berman Glass Studios in Vancouver to create the iridescent yellow-orange wall tiles, left. ''We wanted something you'd see from the street, that would relate to the red 9,'' Mr. Hardy said, referring to the sidewalk icon by Ivan Chermayeff. The 6-by-6-inch tiles handcast of textured glass have an orange luminescent holographic film on the back; $65 each from Berman Studios, (888) 505-4527. His glass tiles without the optic film, 4 by 4 inches, are $9 each at Ann Sacks Tile and Stone, 5 East 16th Street.

description: AOL Agrees to Make Service Accessible to the Blind

title: Officer in Shooting of Diallo Is Not Liable in Earlier Death
description: One of the four police officers who shot Amadou Diallo has been cleared of wrongdoing in another fatal shooting, prompting that man's father to denounce the judicial process yesterday.

title: Oscar Shumsky, 83, Violinist In the Grand Romantic Tradition
description: Oscar Shumsky, a violinist and conductor who was renowned for the beauty of his sound and the luminous musicality of his performances of Bach, Mozart and Brahms, died on Monday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 83.

title: Peace, One Step at a Time
description: Israeli-Palestinian peace talks ended Tuesday without a comprehensive settlement, but there were encouraging signs that both sides moved toward peace on some issues other than Jerusalem. The challenge now is to see whether the parties can build on this apparent progress, or whether they will slide back toward recriminations and violence.

title: In the Art Of the Craft
description: To chew over The New York Times's fiction best-seller list is to be reminded that an author doesn't necessarily need media anointment or a splendid critical sendoff or an otherwise powerful launching to be a striking commercial success. Often all it takes is the gradual accumulation of popularity, the gathering together of heaps of devotees for the writer's books, one after another, until there is a critical mass of ardent fans.

title: BANK OF AMERICA TO BUY BACK UP TO $4.8 BILLION IN STOCK
description: The Bank of America Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back up to 100 million of its shares, worth about $4.8 billion at the current market price. The buyback, which will take place over the next 18 to 24 months, represents about 6 percent of Bank of America's stock outstanding. Companies use buybacks to increase earnings per share by reducing shares outstanding. Bank of America, based in Charlotte, N.C., had sales of $51.6 billion last year. Its stock was down $1.125 a share, at $47.125.

title: First Lady and Health Care
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign began broadcasting a new 30-second advertisement downstate Tuesday. Unlike previous health care commercials by her campaign, it does not feature or mention her Senate opponent, Representative Rick A. Lazio. Instead, in another first, it directly addresses Mrs. Clinton's leading role in the Clinton administration's failed 1993 health care proposal.

title: The Pentagon's Anti-Gay Policies
description: No amount of anti-harassment training can correct the injustice of the ban on openly gay service members in the United States military. Last week Defense Secretary William Cohen released yet another set of guidelines on how to stop anti-gay harassment. But this new action plan, like previous guidelines, will most likely prove ineffective because the ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy on which it is based is unworkable. The way to curb harassment is to allow gays to serve openly without fear of expulsion if they report harassment.

title: Guide Helps Mac Users Get Out of the House
description: In the city that never sleeps, it can sometimes be difficult to decide what to do. Vindigo, a ''personal navigation'' program for Palm and Handspring Visor electronic organizers, can be considered a digital replacement for the entertainment listings in the newspaper or weekly city magazine -- with a little something extra.

title: Frustrated Customers
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief of Spain's Big Phone Company Quits
description: Juan Villalonga, the chairman of Spain's vast telecommunications company, Telefonica, resigned today, leaving a once-stodgy Spanish monopoly that he had turned into a giant with fast-growing holdings in Latin America and the Internet.

title: Wired Cyclists Connect to Computers to Measure Pedal Power
description: LAST winter, when people were still thinking about skiing, the American cyclist Lance Armstrong was beginning the training that led to his second consecutive Tour de France victory last Sunday.

title: Casting a Spell With Infernal Goings-On
description: In ''Fiends Angelical,'' a Paul Taylor dance piece that received its premiere on Tuesday at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, a man and woman in an energetic tribe go at each other's throats. After their mutual strangulation, the local priestess, with horns on her head, bites apart the long red gut that has been pulled out of the happy couple's innards.

title: Roaming Buffalo Find No Place Like Home
description: There were still a few buffaloes roaming around the woods yesterday, but the northern New York town of Malone was managing to recover from four days in which 16 of the animals stampeded through potato, corn and dairy farms.

title: Germans Led By Schroder In Mourning Their Dead
description: Flags flew at half-staff throughout Germany today as the country mourned its 96 victims aboard the Air France Concorde airliner that crashed Tuesday near Paris.

title: Corrections

Sun Chemical, a unit of Dainippon Ink and Chemicals, is based in Fort Lee, N.J., not in Japan.

title: ITXC TO ACQUIRE SOFTWARE MAKER
description: The ITXC Corporation, which uses the Internet to route telephone calls, agreed to buy eFusion Inc. for about $165.5 million in stock to add software for integrating voice and Internet communications. Holders of the closely held eFusion will receive 5.66 million shares of ITXC common stock, plus additional shares to cover eFusion's cash on hand when the transaction closes. EFusion's products include Push to Talk, which adds voice communications to Web sites.

title: CURRENTS: ARCHITECTURE; Putting More Spring Into a Dancer's Step
description: Ronnette Riley, a Manhattan architect, seated at left, transformed a standard-issue apartment on the Upper West Side into the perfect live-work environment for Bruce Wilson, an actor and dancer, left. Ms. Riley, who also designed the new Restoration Hardware in SoHo, created a living room-dance studio, with a spring-loaded wooden floor like those onstage. The floor's maple finish merges seamlessly with the rest of the apartment. But this one stands up to high-performance dance. Ronnette Riley Architect, (212) 594-4015. A spring-loaded floor is $45 a square foot, installed.

title: Over the Years, Cheney Opposed U.S. Sanctions
description: During his early years as a White House official and member of the House, Dick Cheney, the expected Republican vice presidential candidate, consistently opposed unilateral American sanctions against nations including Iran, Cuba and South Africa.

title: Napster Faces the Music
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
