description: For years, automakers insisted that the technology did not exist to improve the fuel economy of sport utility vehicles and that Americans were not especially interested in gas mileage.

title: Manipulated Images Toy With Facets of What Is
description: Reality is tricky business. Just how tricky it can be when photographers get their hands on it is on display in two summer group shows, ''Architectural Constructs in Contemporary Photography'' at the Julie Saul Gallery in SoHo and ''Alternative Realities'' at the Laurence Miller Gallery in Midtown.

title: Ex-Boyfriend Is Convicted of Murdering Columbia Student
description: A Manhattan jury yesterday convicted a young New Jersey man of murdering his former girlfriend, a Columbia University law student found in her apartment with her throat slashed in 1998.

title: Southeast Toyota Narrows Its Review
description: Southeast Toyota Distributors in Deerfield Beach, Fla., owned and operated by JM Family Enterprises, said yesterday that it had narrowed a review for its consolidated account to four finalists. Spending was estimated at $70 million.

description: Swiss Institute

title: Ford's Clean Air Breakthrough
description: The various industries responsible for much of the country's air pollution -- the oil companies, the automakers, the big utilities -- have usually resisted federal clean air regulations, routinely overestimating the costs of the regulations while underestimating the ability of their engineers to satisfy them. In the 30 years since the passage of the Clean Air Act, industry has rarely been out in front of government. Yesterday, however, the Ford Motor Company reversed this paradigm with the announcement that it would increase the average fuel economy of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent over the next five years. It did so even though Congress recently rejected yet another effort by environmentalists to tighten up fuel economy standards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLANAN, PHYLLIS THERESA
description: CALLANAN-Phyllis Theresa. Of Southold, NY formerly of NY City on July 27, 2000. Devoted sister of Carol Wise. Cherished aunt of four nieces and two nephews. Also survived by twelve grand nieces and nephews. Visiting hours today 2-4 P.M. at DeFriest Funeral Home, Southold, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Sat. 8:45 A.M., St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Southold. title: Commercials by Gun Industry Will Try to Counter Litigation
description: Asserting that gun manufacturers are in dire jeopardy from a raft of lawsuits by state and local governments, the firearms industry plans to start running commercials during prime-time coverage of the Republican National Convention next week attacking President Clinton and other politicians, mostly Democrats, who support the litigation.

title: COFFEE CROP DAMAGE
description: Severe droughts and unusually cold weather in Brazil's south and southeast could sharply reduce next year's coffee crop, to 25.9 million 60-kilogram bags, from potential production of 35 million bags, according to preliminary government estimates. The state of Minas Gerais, which produces about half of Brazil's coffee crop, is expected to lose about a third of its beans this year, while production in Parana, where a recent cold front hit the hardest, may be down 85 percent. Brazil is the world's largest coffee producer. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Officials Question U.S. Tribal Recognition Process
description: Concerned that the federal government may soon recognize two more Indian tribes in Connecticut, two state officials said today that they planned to convene dozens of state and city officials in September to discuss the legitimacy of the tribes' land claims and the validity of the recognition process.

title: A War the Accountants Will Lose Even if They Win
description: ARTHUR LEVITT, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, wants to end his term by enacting new rules to increase the independence of auditors from their corporate clients.

title: Postal Service Gives 'Check's in the Mail' A Whole New Twist
description: In the annals of poor excuses, ''the check is in the mail'' has an exalted place. But it turns out that tens of thousands of taxpayers can rightly blame the Postal Service for delays of a month or more in delivering their payments to government offices around the country.

description: Between games of a doubleheader yesterday, Pat Mahomes asked Mike Hampton if Hampton was going to pitch nine innings. Hampton, the Mets left-hander, said he would.

description: The expression ''still as a statue'' won't apply to the works at Storm King Art Center tomorrow. With the help of Annette Lipson, some children and a little imagination, the pieces in this 500-acre sculpture park in Orange County will appear to move, vibrate, soar and even sing.

title: WorldCom Earnings Increased By 53% in the Second Quarter
description: WorldCom Inc., the nation's second-largest long-distance company, reported a 53 percent rise in second-quarter earnings before charges yesterday, matching Wall Street expectations. But the company also warned that sales growth for the rest of the year would be at the low end of its previous estimate, and WorldCom shares tumbled as much as 15 percent before recovering somewhat.

description: The Yankees like to have multiple lines dropped in the trade waters at all times, and at any time between now and Monday's trade deadline, the slight tugs they have been getting from other teams could turn into something more.

title: Supermarket Worker Is Killed By Cardboard-Box Compactor
description: A worker at an Upper West Side supermarket was crushed to death by the store's cardboard-box compactor yesterday as he was loading boxes into it, the police said.

description: Claude Sautet, an award-winning director whose films focused on the lives of the bourgeoisie, died on Saturday in Paris. He was 76.

title: A Way With Cutlery She Can't Resist
description: Over the last two decades or so, sex in movies -- even French movies -- has become demystified, conventional and, well, unsexy. Even the most artfully directed writhing, the most ardently counterfeited sighs and moans can seem a bit pro forma. And so ambitious filmmakers -- especially French ones -- are faced with the challenge of how to bring genuine erotic heat to the screen.

description: Fortis, the Dutch-Belgian insurance and banking company, said yesterday that its United States unit, Fortis Inc., had agreed to buy the American Memorial Life Insurance Company for $200 million in cash. American Memorial Life, based in Rapid City, S.D., will be purchased from the Service Corporation International, a Houston-based funeral and cemetery company. As part of the deal, Fortis and Service Corporation also signed a multiyear marketing agreement to allow for the sale of prearranged funeral contracts exclusively through funeral homes owned by or affiliated with Service.

title: MCKESSON HBOC IS PLANNING $250 MILLION STOCK BUYBACK
description: McKesson HBOC, the largest United States drug wholesaler, said yesterday that it planned to buy back as much as $250 million of common stock, which has fallen 22 percent in the last year. That represents 10.2 million shares, or about 3.6 percent of its shares as of June 30, based on McKesson's closing price on Wednesday. The company said it planned to repurchase the shares in the open market or through private transactions. Shares of McKesson rose 18.75 cents, to $24.6875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Sports of The Times; Kid Pitcher Won't Forget His Debut
description: IN two months, nobody will remember this weird game except for Grant Roberts. Played partly in a soft mist, the game will recede into the mists of memory except for the kid pitcher who made his major league debut, quickly and erratically.

title: DRAFT  PLATFORM FOR G.O.P. SOFTENS HARD-LINE STANCES
description: The proposed Republican platform would drop several of the more hard-edged conservative positions adopted four years ago -- like calling for the abolition of the Department of Education -- and transform much of the document's tone to reflect the ''compassionate conservatism'' of Gov. George W. Bush.

title: SYMANTEC BUYS A RIVAL FOR $975 MILLION
description: The largest maker of computer security software for consumers, Symantec, agreed yesterday to buy a rival, Axent Technologies Inc., for about $975 million in stock. Axent shareholders will get half a Symantec share, valued at $31.84, for each share they own. That is 67 percent more than Axent's closing price on Wednesday. The purchase of Axent gives Symantec, the maker of the Norton AntiVirus software, security programs that help protect corporate computer networks. Demand for such products is growing as more businesses engage in electronic-commerce, Symantec said. Symantec shares fell $13.4375, or 21 percent, to $51.25. Axent shares rose $4.9375, or 26 percent, to $24.

title: 7 States in West Reach Outline On Sharing of the Colorado River
description: California and the six other Western states that rely on water from the Colorado River have reached the outlines of an agreement that would let California gradually reduce its over-dependence on the river through extensive conservation and underground storage measures during the next 15 years, officials here said today.

title: Abandoned on Okinawa
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Would Oppose a Gun Ban Near Schools? Maybe Neighbors
description: Gun violence involving children -- or any gun crime, for that matter -- has not been a problem in this quiet middle-class suburb 10 miles west of Newark. And the Borough Council moved last month to keep it that way, passing an ordinance that makes it illegal to have a gun within 1,000 feet of a school, park, playground or library.

title: Tea With a Twist
description: Afternoon tea is a charming and relaxing way to escape the bustle of the city for an hour or two. Here are several of the most interesting tea places in Manhattan. title: D.H. Blair and Executives Indicted in Fraud Case
description: D.H. Blair & Company, a defunct Manhattan brokerage firm, and 15 of its officers and employees were indicted yesterday on securities fraud charges by a grand jury in Manhattan. The firm's executives, prosecutors said, reaped illegal profit by manipulating stock prices, engaged in high-pressure sales tactics to generate excessive commissions and stole investor data from other firms to increase their customer base.

title: John Tukey, 85, Statistician; Coined the Word 'Software'
description: John Wilder Tukey, one of the most influential statisticians of the last 50 years and a wide-ranging thinker credited with inventing the word ''software,'' died on Wednesday in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 85.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sailing Poetically Into the Hip-Hop Paradox
description: It was smart of the organizers of the first New York Hip-Hop Theater Festival to make Sarah Jones's one-person play ''Surface Transit'' the centerpiece of its presentations at P. S. 122 through Aug. 26. Ms. Jones first presented it a couple of years ago in the East Village, and since then she and the play's director have continued working on it; she and the show have grown, and she is a tremendous draw with the downtown crowd. Since she performed her solo show ''Women Can't Wait'' at the United Nations for its international conference on women in early June, she has also grown a bit beyond the neighborhood. But, more important for this festival, among artists most respected by other hip-hop poets and performers, she has the clearest sense of distance; she can satirize the phenomenon in ways that open it up for people who think there is something mysterious about it.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend last Friday about exhibitions in Connecticut, including a display of sculptures by Alexander Calder in Hartford, and a brief report in the Inside Art column about the Seattle Art Museum's acquisition of a work of his called ''Eagle'' each misstated the year of his death. It was 1976, not 1973.

description: Museums and Sites

title: 2 Defendants Plead Not Guilty In Killings of Wendy's Workers
description: The two men accused of killing five workers in a massacre at a Wendy's restaurant in Queens on May 24 pleaded not guilty yesterday to murder charges.

title: Potent New Greenhouse Gas Is Found, but It's Quite Rare
description: Scientists have found rising concentrations of a newly identified gas in the air that traps heat more effectively than all other known greenhouse gases, the dozens of compounds released by industry and the burning of fuels that act like a greenhouse roof and may be warming the global climate.

title: Mad Scientist's Weight Loss Formula for Disaster
description: Poor Eddie Murphy. He gave the performance of a lifetime in ''The Nutty Professor,'' with the kind of professional breakthrough that showed he had become an actor with serious chops, and yet Jim Carrey gets all the reviews. In ''Nutty Professor II: The Klumps,'' Mr. Murphy again displays enough agility to show that he deserves to be taken seriously. We probably shouldn't feel too bad for his being overlooked; after all, the first ''Professor'' was a big hit. And this one will be, too.

title: Breakthrough in Lasers, With Many Potential New Uses, Reported
description: Researchers at the Bell Laboratories of Lucent Technologies have created the first solid laser from organic materials that is electrically powered, a breakthrough that they and other researchers predict will lead to a wide range of new uses for laser light in communications and information storage.

title: One Thing 'Monday Night Football' Will Not Have Is the Luxury of Time
description: Pay no attention to the exhibition football game being played Monday at 7 p.m. on ABC. Ignore Al Michaels's new playmates. Heed not the verbal gyrations of Dennis Miller, who is making his debut as a comedian-turned-sports analyst.

title: Big House on the Plantation Has a Family Secret
description: Sam Waterston plays a complicated hero in ''A House Divided.'' He's a slave owner who rapes his house servant, a black teenager, and then -- many years later -- hires a lawyer to make sure their daughter isn't denied her inheritance.

title: Senate Approves a Budget Of $288 Billion for Military
description: The Senate today joined the House in approving a military spending bill of $287.8 billion for next year, an amount that is more than $5.1 billion more than requested by the Pentagon or the White House.

title: CISCO IN STOCK DEAL FOR NUSPEED
description: The top maker of computer networking equipment, Cisco Systems Inc., agreed to buy NuSpeed Internet Systems Inc., a closely held networking start-up, for about $450 million in stock to add products that strengthen its network-connecting capabilities. Cisco said NuSpeed's technology would allow it to offer customers a product that helps blend data and storage networks into one system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADEL, HAROLD
description: NADEL-Harold, 82. Of Boca Raton, FL., formerly from Harrison, NY. Beloved husband for 47 years of Dale, loving father to Lawrence Robert and Richard Dore. Dear cousin of Arnold Danzig, brother to Alexander Nadel and Sylvia Golber. Before his retirement, Harold was President of Power Oil Company in Mount Vernon, NY. Funeral Service will be at Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel in Boca Raton, FL., 800-992-9262 on Sunday, July 30, at 10:00 AM.

Another Slice Of Roast Boor, En Croute
description: A LIFE-GIVING blast of anarchy sweeps the stage late in the soggy revival of ''The Man Who Came to Dinner'' that opened last night at the American Airlines Theater. The gale is named Lewis J. Stadlen, who improbably appears to be impersonating all of the Marx Brothers at once and, even more improbably, succeeding at it.

title: Islanders Sign More Forwards
description: The Islanders yesterday signed three veteran free-agent forwards: Robert Petrovicky, Jeff Toms and Jesse Belanger.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; When Losing a License Is No Curb on Driving
description: REVOKING or suspending a driver's license is one of the most severe punishments for moving violations. But the police and some safety advocates suspect that often it is no punishment at all, and no protection for other people on the road, because in many cases it does not stop the violator from driving.

title: 20,000 Miles To London Via Beijing
description: HOW many flat tires would you expect to get driving around the world? The ''China Clipper,'' a 1949 Buick Super wood-paneled station wagon, handled the 20,000 overland miles with none.

title: The Album Of the Week
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''Heroes and Villains: Music Inspired by the Powerpuff Girls'' (Rhino/Cartoon Network). Those mutant X-Men are confronting all comers at the box office, but there are champions much tougher than that movie's confused adolescent, Rogue. The Powerpuff Girls, created by Craig McCracken for the Cartoon Network, give young viewers a taste of unequivocal female punch. Buttercup, Bubbles and Blossom talk like the Chipmunks, chew gum, think fast and defeat baddies like the monkey Mojo Jojo without mussing the bows in their hair.

title: Kazakhstan Is Suspected Of Oil Bribes In the Millions
description: Swiss and American authorities have blocked Kazakhstan's government from access to bank accounts holding roughly $100 million that they suspect Western oil companies may have used to bribe senior Kazakh officials, according to officials with knowledge of the action.

title: Playing for (Political) Time on China Trade
description: When Commerce Secretary William M. Daley laid down the Clinton administration's strategy this past spring for forcing the China trade bill through a reluctant Congress, he insisted repeatedly that, win or lose, Congress had to vote before the summer political conventions.

title: Once Again, Cheney Confronts the Questions
description: Dick Cheney tried today to beat back questions about his conservative voting record, appearing on the morning news programs of all three major networks as the Bush campaign fought to keep from being defined by the second man on the ticket.

title: Finding the Beauty of Life In a Rural Corner of Iran
description: Near the end of ''Taste of Cherry,'' the Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami's lavishly acclaimed 1997 film, an elderly taxidermist delivers a wise and rueful soliloquy on the value of life, a sympathetic critique of the main character's suicidal despair.

title: Moving Around The Categories

Each time, executives say, the change is to ''reflect current collecting patterns,'' meaning Christie's is trying to match the art with the right buyers.

title: Conseco, Needing to Pay Debt, Plans Job Cuts at Finance Arm
description: Conseco Inc., the troubled insurance and finance company, said yesterday that it planned to eliminate 2,000 jobs from its Conseco Finance operation and sell numerous assets as it sought to raise cash to meet debt payments coming due.

GSD&M in Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group, creates ads for Pennzoil motor oil, but those for Quaker State in the United States are created by the Tucker Partnership in New York.

title: Sweet Lines Boyfriends Might Say (In a Dream)
description: Cameras were everywhere when 'N Sync started its sold-out four-night stand at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday. There were video cameras to feed the screen onstage; cranes and overhead cameras preparing for yesterday's live HBO telecast of the concert; news crew cameras stirring little sectors of frenzy and pocket cameras in the hands of girls who only stopped shrieking long enough to snap photos of their favorite group member. The audience was at least 90 percent female and nearly 100 percent vocal; Joey Fatone of 'N Sync hardly needed to ask, though he did, ''Are you ready to scream?''

By 11 p.m., he had linked his computer to one of several underground networks that allow users to do the same thing as the popular Internet music-swapping service does, only without providing a central target.

title: STING LOSES ON DOMAIN NAME
description: The British pop star Sting lost his attempt to claim the Internet address sting.com at the World Intellectual Property Organization. In separate decisions, the board ruled in favor of Microsoft and Reuters in disputes over domain names. Sting became the first celebrity to lose at the Geneva-based organization, which ruled in favor of the Hollywood actress Julia Roberts in a similar dispute. In Sting's case, he could not prove that Michael Urvan of Marietta, Ga., had registered sting.com in bad faith. Mr. Urvan denied that he had sought $25,000 from Sting for rights to the name, and Sting's lawyers produced no evidence. Sting's lawyers could still appeal to a court in the United States. And Mr. Lazio's use of that dodge is the latest signal that the State Legislature still needs to fix a campaign financing system that is nothing short of a national embarrassment.

title: RELIANT ENERGY FILES PLAN TO DIVIDE INTO 2 COMPANIES
description: Reliant Energy said yesterday that it had filed a plan with the Texas Public Utility Commission to divide into two publicly traded companies, as part of an effort to be more competitive. The reorganization will separate the regulated and unregulated businesses of Reliant, based in Houston. The unregulated company will own a part of Reliant's power generation and related energy trading and marketing operations. The regulated business will include Reliant's electricity and natural gas companies, domestic interstate pipelines and interests in Latin America. Reliant plans an initial public offering of about 20 percent of the common stock of its unregulated operations late this year or early in 2001. Shares of Reliant rose $1.5469, to $33.5625.

title: GUILFORD MILLS IS MOVING SOME OPERATIONS TO MEXICO
description: Guilford Mills Inc., a fabric maker, will move some operations from two plants in Greensboro, N.C., to Tampico, Mexico, dismissing at least 400 people. The job cuts at its Fishman plant are about 8.3 percent of its total United States work force. It will stop dyeing and finishing fabric at the plant once current production is complete. Work will be reduced at its Greenberg plant in the first quarter of 2001. The company has not determined how many people will be affected there. Guilford shares fell $1.5625, to $4. After the dyeing and finishing operations are closed at Fishman, Guilford will have 4,400 employees in the United States. It currently has 650 employees in Mexico. Guilford is also suspending its quarterly dividend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, OLCOTT DAMON
description: SMITH-Olcott Damon. Former Chairman of Aetna Life and Casualty Co. and Of Counsel to Day, Berry & Howard attorneys, died Monday, July 24, 2000. He was 93 years old. He was born in West Hartford, Connecticut, on June 17, 1907, and lived there and in Farmington, Connecticut all of his life. After graduation from Yale University in 1929 and Harvard Law School in 1932, Mr. Smith joined the law firm of Day, Berry & Howard, in which he was a member for over thirty years. During World War II he joined the Office of the General Counsel of the U.S. Navy. In 1945 he returned to Day, Berry & Howard, practicing law until 1962 when he left to become Vice Chairman of Aetna Life and Casualty Company. In 1963 he became Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, retiring from that position in 1972, but continuing as Chairman of its Executive Committee until 1977, when he returned to Day, Berry & Howard as Of Counsel. Mr. Smith was director of many public companies, among them Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York and United Technologies Corp. His interest in business, civic and community affairs continued throughout his life. He received honorary L.L.D. degrees from Trinity College and the University of Hartford. In 1933 Mr. Smith married Lucy Bulkeley Brainerd, who died in May 1982. They had four children: Damon B. Smith of Old Saybrook, CT, Wendy M. Brainerd of Old Lyme, CT, Tyler Smith of Hartford, CT, and O. Whitman Smith of Charlotte, VT. On November 26, 1983, Mr. Smith married Catharine Carton Swett, who survives him. Mr. Smith is also survived by his four children, twelve grandchildren, and nine great grandchildren and three stepsons.

The new offer is 17 percent more than an agreement reached in April by Cohoes and Hudson River Bancorp. Last month, Cohoes rejected Ambanc's offer of $15.25 a share, or $120 million in cash. Hudson River plans to pay 1.185 shares of its common stock for each share of Cohoes, valuing Cohoes stock at $14.07. Shares of Cohoes rose 68.75 cents, to $14.625, in Nasdaq trading. Ambanc fell 18.75 cents, to $15.0625. Hudson River was unchanged at $11.875.

title: Alvin Alm, 63, a Leader in Environmental Policy
description: Alvin L. Alm, a businessman and senior government official who helped create environmental and energy policy in Republican and Democratic administrations for four decades, died on Monday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 63.

title: Government and Church Reviewers Agree to Disagree on Mexican Cardinal's Slaying
description: After years of investigations, federal, state and church authorities said today that they had agreed to disagree about the events that led to the slaying of one of Mexico's two Roman Catholic cardinals in 1993 in a shootout at an airport.

title: AOL and Time Warner Face Criticism at F.C.C. Hearing
description: Stephen M. Case and Gerald M. Levin came to Washington today to defend the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner against a rising tide of criticism that the new colossus will be so anticompetitive that it must be reined in by regulators even before its creation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, RUTH. PAYNE
description: GOODMAN-Ruth. Payne Whitney Clinic Social Workers of the Ruth Goodman era note her passing with sadness. She was a Director whose clinical acumen was enriched by her sharp wit and deep love of family. Sue Matorin

description: Despite a policy prohibiting military involvement in partisan politics, members of Congress and guests at the Republican National Convention will have an exclusive viewing of some of the Pentagon's latest hardware, including an aircraft that the expected Republican vice-presidential nominee, Dick Cheney, tried to kill when he was defense secretary.

description: The House today passed legislation that would reduce taxes on some Social Security benefits, giving Republicans another victory in their effort to make tax cuts a defining election-year issue.

title: It's a Sequel? O.K., I'll Take It
description: These days home video is especially keen on its own progeny: those feature-length films, animated and live action, that go straight to cassette and disc without playing in theaters. Not that there has been too much of a critical sea change. Direct-to-video movies still couldn't be any good, or so goes the view even of most video dealers, who regard a movie's record on the big screen as vital to its appeal at home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLICKER, STANLEY, MD.
description: OLICKER-Stanley, MD. We note with sorrow, the passing of a pediatrician who was widely respected by his colleagues and his many friends. Stanley Olicker's career was distinguished by devotion to his patients, enthusiasm for teaching new physicians, and his active role as a member, and as President of the medical staff. Our deepest condolences are offered to his loving family. Mervin Silverberg, MD. Chairman, Department of Pediatrics North Shore University Hospital

title: Residential Real Estate; Keeping Some Peace at Co-op and Condo Meetings
description: Sometimes, even the presence of an independent monitor -- studiously staying aloof from issues that may make a mockery of a building's sense of being a cooperative -- cannot quell the passions aroused by the annual shareholders' meeting and election of the board.

title: Gunman Frees Hostage Pilots After Escape Of Passengers
description: A man carried a handgun onto a National Airlines jet at Kennedy International Airport at 10:15 last night, shushed the passengers and walked calmly into the cockpit, taking the pilot and co-pilot hostage for two hours, passengers and the authorities said. Neither the seven crew members nor the 143 passengers were injured in the incident, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Like a Horse and Carriage, but There Are Roadblocks
description: The battle lines for ''Avow,'' Bill C. Davis's new broadside against the Roman Catholic Church, are drawn in the spare set that greets the audience as it enters the theater. In center stage stands a large bed, a symbol for the war about to be waged between religious conviction and sex. Guess who wins.

description: Pat Hearn Gallery

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 15 about potential running mates for Vice President Al Gore misstated the middle initial of Warren Christopher, who is leading the search. It is M., not G.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The guacamole rolls on at the new Rosa Mexicano across from Lincoln Center. It comes to the table unassembled on a wheeled cart crowded with piles of avocados, glass bowls filled with onion, tomatoes and chilies, and the lava stone bowls known as molcajetes.

title: Frierson Mee Opening Paris Office
description: Frierson Mee & Kraft in New York is opening an office in Paris with six employees and two accounts with combined billings estimated at $45 million: a new Esprit fragrance line to be sold by the Lancaster Group Worldwide, part of Reckitt Benckiser, and Mumm Champagne, owned by Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst. The office will be headed by Patricia Rigaud as general manager; Ms. Rigaud, 39, had been the general manager at the Paris office of Select Communications.

title: Knicks Will Open Against the 76ers
description: The Knicks will open their 2000-1 season with a home game against the Philadelphia 76ers on Oct. 31, according to the National Basketball Association schedule released yesterday. The Nets will play at home against Cleveland that night.

title: He Tells of a 2d Kidnapping by Rebels : German Journalist Freed in Philippines
description: ZAMBOANGA, Philippines  A 47-year-old German journalist was freed Thursday, 25 days after what he described as "a splinter group" of Muslim rebels tricked him into captivity by telling him he could help rescue another German prisoner.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BUSINESS INCENTIVES
description: The government of South Africa proposed labor law changes that are intended to encourage expansion and investment by companies that have complained that the country's employment and pay regulations stifle business growth. The bills would eliminate automatic overtime pay for employees working on Sunday, streamline the grievance process for dismissed employees and allow employers to place new workers on probation for six months. Henri E. Cauvin

title: How Can the Web Help Democracy?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Specter of Saladin
description: I am sitting in front of the television in the living room, seeing Yasir Arafat receive a triumphant hero's welcome in Gaza, and all this for having said no to peace with Israel. The whole Gaza Strip is covered in flags and slogans proclaiming the ''Palestinian Saladin.'' ''Welcome home, Saladin of our era'' is written on the walls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALKOW, GEOFFREY MATTHEW
description: SALKOW-Geoffrey Matthew, 33, of Naples, FL, on July 23, 2000 in Banner Elk, NC. Services will be held at 2 o'clock Friday, July 28, 2000 in Greenlawn Funeral Home Chapel. Interment will be in Greenlawn Memorial Park. Visitation was last night at the funeral home. Memorials may be made to the Pi Kappa Alpha Fraternity at the University Of South Carolina. There will be a memorial service to be held at a later date in Naples, FL. Greenlawn Funeral Home of Columbia, SC is in charge. Mr. Salkow, born in Holmdel, NJ, he was the son of Gregory Salkow and Susan Regan Salkow. He graduated from high school in Holmdel, NJ, a graduate of USC with a BS Degree in Finance and Real Estate, a member of the Pi Kappa Alpha Fraternity at USC. He trained on Wall Street with Bear Stearns after USC then moved back to Columbia where he worked for Prudential Security until he married in 1995, then he and his wife, Brenda began Colonial Capital Management. The company currently has offices in Naples, FL, New York City and London. He and his family also maintain a residence in Charlotte, NC. He is survived by his wife Brenda Shirah Salkow; his parents Gregory & Susan Salkow of Naples, FL; a sister, Regan Salkow of Clifton, NJ; his paternal grandmother, Anne Salkow of Matawan, NJ.

title: Hamilton Journal; To Texas Farmers' Burdens, Add the Grasshopper
description: With grasshoppers pinging off the windshield like hailstones, Marvin Schrank mows through row after row of ripe milo maize, swarms of the insects rolling in waves of dust just ahead of his John Deere combine.

title: EARTHLINK LOSS NARROWS
description: The Internet service provider EarthLink reported a smaller-than-expected net loss for the second quarter yesterday, as revenue at the Atlanta-based company rose by more than 40 percent. EarthLink said its second-quarter loss, excluding special items, was $35.2 million, compared with $50.9 million a year earlier.

title: Trade Accord With Vietnam: Exports in Place of Enmity
description: Just a few weeks ago, foreign executives here looked at Vietnam and saw a Communist backwater dabbling halfheartedly in free enterprise and foreign investment.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The dollar strengthened as economic reports fueled speculation the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates again. In New York, the euro settled at 93.23 cents, down from 94.14 cents on Wednesday.

title: Jets' Ward Is Growing Into Role as Receiver
description: Even in this quietest of training camps, Keyshawn Johnson still hovers over the Jets, every view of the wide receivers infused with a comparison to the exiled star who seems to have grown mythically tall since his departure.

title: Big East Favorites? Vick of the Hokies, Then Miami
description: By the end of last year's magical football season at Virginia Tech and well into this spring, Michael Vick could no longer walk into the Wal-Mart in Blacksburg, Va., without being followed down every aisle.

title: New Calendar Of Primaries For G.O.P. Clears Hurdle
description: The Republican National Committee voted today to make the presidential nominating season last until May by requiring big states to hold their primaries last. But the plan faces a stiff fight in the national convention's rules committee on Friday and perhaps on the convention floor next Monday.

title: CHINA EASES RESTRICTIONS ON SURVEYS
description: In a break for foreign companies seeking market research on China's consumers, the government rescinded restrictions on poll taking in the country, saying foreigners can order surveys without having first to submit their questionnaires for government approval, as long as the surveys avoid politically related topics. Survey results no longer have to be reported to the government, China's National Bureau of Statistics said. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: San Francisco Newspaper Can Be Sold, Judge Rules
description: A federal judge in San Francisco ruled yesterday that the Hearst Corporation's $660 million purchase of The San Francisco Chronicle did not violate antitrust laws and that the company would have had legal justification for closing The San Francisco Examiner had it chosen to.

title: Cheney Slips in Explaining A Vote on Freeing Mandela
description: As he made the rounds of the television talk shows this morning, Dick Cheney confidently defended his votes in the 1980's against gun control, abortion rights and education spending, but he slipped when he tried to justify his opposition to an obscure resolution in 1986 that called on South Africa to release Nelson Mandela from prison.

title: Olcott D. Smith, 93, Chairman Of Aetna and a Hartford Leader
description: Olcott Damon Smith, who as chairman of Aetna Life and Casualty led the formation of its international and financial services divisions, died on Monday in Avon, Conn. He was 93.

title: DELCO REMY WILL ELIMINATE 860 JOBS AS IT REORGANIZES
description: Delco Remy International, an auto-parts maker, plans to eliminate 860 jobs, or 12 percent of its work force, and take a $22 million charge in its fourth quarter to reorganize in the United States, Britain and Canada. The charge, which totals 84 cents a share, will mainly cover the cost of worker buyouts, early retirements, severance and other payments. About 800 of the jobs will be eliminated in the United States and Canada. The reorganization will save $20 million a year. Delco Remy, based in Anderson, Ind., makes starter motors and alternators and remanufactures engines, transmissions and other auto systems. The company's shares fell 37.5 cents, to $8.1875.

title: Breaking Down the Barriers With Hand Clapping and Prancing
description: Over the years many new-music ensembles have tried to break down categories between contemporary concert music on the one hand and, on the other, rock, jazz and all the idioms that are dubbed ''popular,'' for want of a better term. The Absolute Ensemble has joined the cause. This New York-based ensemble first appeared a few seasons back as a traditional contemporary chamber group, directed by a young Estonian-born conductor steeped in the classical tradition, Kristjan Jarvi, whose father is the noted conductor Neeme Jarvi.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS.Natural gas rose after an industry report showed that inventories are growing more slowly than expected. In New York, natural gas for September delivery rose 5 cents, to $3.843 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: LOSSES GROW AT STORAGENETWORKS
description: Shares of cobiStorageNetworks Inc. fell after it reported that despite a sharp jump in revenue its net losses increased tenfold in the second quarter from a year earlier. The data storage company based in Waltham, Mass., reported a second-quarter net loss of $31.3 million, compared with $3 million a year earlier. The shares fell $7.625, to $130. NYTimes.com/TheStreet.com

description: The soprano Carol Vaness has withdrawn from two performances at the Mostly Mozart festival at Lincoln Center next week because of the death of her father. She will be replaced by Christine Brewer at the festival's gala opening concert on Tuesday in arias and vocal excerpts from Beethoven's ''Fidelio'' and at a repeat performance on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, LOIS (NEE LEVINSON)
description: HIRSCH-Lois (nee Levinson). Beloved wife of Myron for 52 years. Devoted mother of Marilyn (Gary) and Barbara (Eric). Loving grandmother of David, Gabrielle, Kevin and Ross. Contributions in her memory may be made to: Don Monti Memorial Research Foundation, C/O North Shore University Hospital, 300 Community Drive, Manhasset, New York 11030.

title: J. H. Morrison, 91, Louisiana Congressman
description: Former Representative James Hobson Morrison, a populist Democrat who represented southeastern Louisiana in Congress from 1943 to 1967, died on July 20 in his native Hammond, La. He was 91.

description: It is just a Kansas school board election, a primary election at that. But no one in Kansas or anywhere else is taking this race for granted.

title: Abortion Ban Kept as Plank By the G.O.P.
description: Republicans fought passionately today over abortion, with the anti-abortion forces easily prevailing, as the platform committee made its way through a document intended to balance the party's core conservatism with Gov. George W. Bush's effort at a more centrist appeal.

title: Unions Angered by City's Proposal That Police Officers Defer Two Weeks' Pay
description: The Giuliani administration has proposed that the city's 27,000 police officers accept a two-week deferral of pay as part of any new labor contract, a demand that has angered leaders of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

description: With the political conventions and the campaign trail beckoning, Democratic and Republican lawmakers left town this week uttering freshly coined slogans that they hope will help voters choose sides in the November election.

description: Are you in despair over the hateful state of rock? Buck up, music consumers. This summer offers plenty of chances to vote with your dollar against homophobic and sexist rock artists and for earnest, love-struck alternative rockers!

description: To the Editor:

title: Trusting in God is one thing, but saying all things are possible with God is quite another. Or is it?
description: In Ohio, with God all things are still possible. At least for a few months anyway.

title: Hyundai Unit in Debt Crisis
description: A subsidiary of Hyundai, South Korea's largest conglomerate, requested emergency loans from creditors today, raising concern that another big bankruptcy was in the making, a year after Daewoo collapsed under debts now estimated at $80 billion. The subsidiary, Hyundai Engineering and Construction, needs $161 million to repay short-term debt to nonbank creditors, including nearly $117 million due today. The subsidiary's debts totaled about $5.7 billion at the end of 1999, half of that due this year. Earlier this week, Hyundai Engineering was a day late in paying its 19,000 employees, and banks agreed to extend some debt maturities.

title: A Park at Brooklyn Bridge
description: Brooklyn's ragged waterfront has long taunted civic leaders, developers and ordinary dreamers with the possibility of a shoreline park with stunning views of Manhattan and the New York harbor. Now, for the first time in decades, a reasonable plan has managed to win the support of various neighborhood and political groups. The proposal for a 70-acre strip of parkland and commercial space called Brooklyn Bridge Park has also won approval and a big piece of the funding from Mayor Rudolph Giuliani.

title: Journal; Don't Worry, Be Happy!
description: The press is bored. The public is bored. Even Dick Cheney looks bored. It wasn't until George W. Bush chose a man who makes Brian Lamb seem like Jerry Springer that I fully appreciated the sheer genius of his presidential campaign.

title: Economy Grew at a Robust 5.2% Rate in the Second Quarter
description: Despite a pullback in consumer spending, the American economy grew at a surprisingly robust 5.2 percent annual rate in the second quarter, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

title: Was It Paradox or Passion That Rocked the Boat?
description: Bargemusic has done its self-appointed job so well for so long that it is too easy to take for granted. As has often been said, the room in a barge moored in Brooklyn under the Brooklyn Bridge is one of the best places in the city to hear chamber music. The acoustics are right and the scenic surroundings superb.

title: Mayor's Past and Present Meet as a City Goes on Display
description: WHEN Mayor John F. Street set out in politics 20 years ago, he was a classic insurgent firebrand, living and breathing protest as he belabored incumbents for neglecting the outlying neighborhoods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEISLER, MELVIN
description: GEISLER-Melvin. A fond farewell to our friend and relative, Melvin Geisler. Husband of the late Rochelle. Services Sunday at ''The Riverside'', 180 W. 76 St., 10:30 am.

title: GRANADA BUYS BRITISH TV ASSETS
description: Spurred by a challenge from cable and satellite operators, Granada Media P.L.C. agreed to buy the television assets of United News and Media P.L.C. for $2.64 billion in cash and stock, beating Carlton Communications P.L.C. for dominance of Britain's most popular channel, the Independent Television Network. Granada shares, which went public this month at 515 pence, jumped to 616.5. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: There's No Trademark on Concern for Kids
description: If plagiarism is the sincerest form of flattery, I am more than happy to be flattered that the theme of the Republican National Convention's opening night on Monday is ''Leave No Child Behind(TM)'' -- the four words that constitute the Children's Defense Fund's trademark.

title: For Negotiator, Career Ends as It Began, in Crisis
description: It was Detective Sgt. Daniel Karas's last day on the job. Sergeant Karas, a hostage negotiator for the Port Authority police, was eating a piece of his retirement cake and preparing to turn in his badge and gun on Thursday night when the police radio crackled: a gunman had taken over an airplane about to leave for Las Vegas and was holding hostages.

title: Arctic Shortcut for Shipping Raises New Fears in Canada
description: In this Arctic village, beachfront real estate means a summer view of polar sea ice glinting a few miles offshore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADEL, HAROLD
description: NADEL-Harold, 82. Of Boca Raton, FL., formerly from Harrison, NY. Beloved husband for 47 years of Dale, loving father to Lawrence Robert and Richard Dore. Dear cousin of Arnold Danzig, brother to Alexander Nadel and Sylvia Golber. Before his retirement, Harold was President of Power Oil Company in Mount Vernon, NY. Funeral Service will be at Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel in Boca Raton, FL., 800-992-9262 on Sunday, July 30, at 10:00 AM.

title: Audit Faults Firm Seeking City Contracts
description: State auditors in Wisconsin said yesterday that Maximus Inc., the nation's largest operator of welfare-to-work programs, had billed Wisconsin for $466,000 since 1997 in improper or questionable expenses, including more than 300 hours that its employees spent seeking contracts in New York City.

title: Lucas Grits His Teeth and Tries to Be a Team Player
description: At this time last season, Ray Lucas was struggling to make the transition from special teams player to quarterback and striving just to make the Jets roster. Now, after having helped salvage the season with a 6-3 record after Vinny Testaverde tore an Achilles' tendon and Rick Mirer faltered, Lucas is a substitute scorned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ROSLYN B.
description: STERN-Roslyn B. On July 27, 2000 at age 88. Beloved wife of the late Irving, loving mother of Peter and his wife Joan, loving grandmother of Jeffrey & Amy & her husband David. She lives on in the hearts of all who knew her. Services at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC, 11:30 AM, Sunday, July 30, 2000.

title: A Robust Economy Raises Interest Fears
description: The American economy grew at a surprisingly robust 5.2 percent annual rate in the second quarter. The news of the unexpectedly strong growth sent stocks plummeting as investors feared the Federal Reserve might increase interest rates again. The Nasdaq composite index plunged 4.7 percent, finishing the week off 10.5 percent, its third worst week. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 74.96 points, to 10,511.17, and was down 2.1 percent for the week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUKEY, JOHN. DONNER
description: TUKEY-John. Donner Professor of Science Emeritus, Princeton University, and Associate Executive Director of Research, AT&T Bell Laboratories, on July 26. Survivors include first cousins Clayton Tasker of Jekyll Island, GA, and Wilder Tasker of New Bern, NC; and the Francis Anscombe family of New Haven, CT. His wife of 48 years, Elizabeth Rapp Tukey, died in January 1998. The funeral service will be Monday, July 31 at 1:00 PM at Trinity Church, Mercer St., Princeton, NJ and will be open to the public. title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about efforts to revive the use of Gaelic in Ireland mistranslated the word ''macushla,'' a term of endearment cited by a professor to illustrate the beauty of the language. It means ''my pulse'' and can mean ''my heartthrob''; it does not mean ''my colt.''

title: First Stakes Victory for Hap
description: Bill Mott and Jerry Bailey again demonstrated their dominance of turf racing as the lightly raced Hap roared home a winner in a crowded 13-horse field in the Grade II Bernard Baruch Handicap yesterday at Saratoga Race Course in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: Ransom Money Buys Guns, Gold and Jade : Filipino Rebels Discover Kidnapping Is Lucrative
description: JOLO, Philippines  Jewelers are trekking into the jungle surrounding this once-flourishing commercial center of the southern Philippines in search of new customers for gold and jade. Gun dealers are offering American and Chinese rifles and pistols. Drug dealers provide shabu, an amphetamine called the "poor man's cocaine," produced in makeshift local laboratories or smuggled from China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPERLING, BEVERLY
description: SPERLING-Beverly. Age 76, on July 27, in Lexington, KY, native and long-time resident of New York City. Beloved wife of the late Leon. Mother of Robin. Grandmother of Alexis and Danielle. Dear sister of Renee Hanover, of Chicago, Illinois. Admired aunt of Stanley Paul and Nancy Hanover. Funeral service is on Sunday, July 30, at Schwartz Brothers & Jeffers Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. Burial at Old Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, Queens. For further information call 818-986-1735.

title: Many Switch to Gnutella
description: Many Switch to Gnutella

title: Corrections
description: A picture with the Theater Guide in Weekend yesterday was published in error. It showed a scene from ''Proof,'' a one-act play by Jeff Reich that was part of the Ensemble Studio Theater's ''Marathon 2000'' in June -- not from ''Proof,'' the play by David Auburn that closes tomorrow at Manhattan Theater Club.

title: Napster Wins A Reprieve, For the Moment
description: Two federal appeals judges in Northern California delivered a last-minute reprieve for Napster Inc. this afternoon, overriding a judge's injunction and ruling that the Internet music-swapping service could continue to allow its users to trade copyrighted music.

title: VOLKSWAGEN PROFIT JUMPS
description: Europe's largest carmaker, Volkswagen A.G., said its second-quarter profit rose 57 percent and predicted that pretax profit will grow by a fifth in 2000. Net income rose to 770 million marks ($367 million) and sales rose 9.6 percent, to 42.31 billion marks. Analysts said net income rose faster than sales mainly because of a drop in Volkswagen's tax bill. The chief financial officer, Bruno Adelt, told analysts to count on a tax rate of about 50 percent for the year. The German government plans to cut taxes next year, further reducing Volkswagen's tax bills.

title: SONERA DENIES SALE REPORTS
description: The shares of Finland's largest phone company, Sonera, fell after it denied it had put itself up for sale for at least $35 billion. ''There is absolutely no truth in that,'' said Jari Jaakkola, Sonera's communications manager. ''We are still looking for a strategic partner, but we are not for sale.'' Finland's government won parliamentary approval last month to sell its controlling stake in Sonera, leading to talk that it would offer the stake to a rival phone company.

title: A Crucial Deal Helps Win The Von Zedtwitz Semifinals
description: The Greater New York Bridge Association's Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship moved a step closer to a conclusion this week. Playing in the semifinal at Honors Club in Manhattan on Tuesday, Jon Greenspan, Bjorn Fallenius, Jim Sampson, Kent Mignocchi, Glenn Milgrim and Jared Lilienstein won by 29 imps against a group led by Will Ehlers. Greenspan, who lost a match in an earlier round, will now have to win twice against John Rengstorff's undefeated squad to take the title. Their first attempt will be on Aug. 21.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNT, DIANA
description: HUNT-Diana. July 22, 2000. Diana had a long and distinguished career in the theatre. Following her first job as director of operettas for the Shubert Organization, she became an agent for actors and writers. She helped launch the careers of many talented artists. title: Dated? Perhaps, But His Insights Remain Powerful
description: How quaint the literary criticism of Lionel Trilling can seem, now that successive waves of structuralism, deconstruction, cultural studies, postcolonialism and other literary technologies have transformed university departments of literature. It has been a quarter-century since Trilling died, and more than a half century since he published ''The Liberal Imagination,'' his first collection of essays -- and most important book. Who now would think to write essays called ''Art and Neurosis'' or ''Manners, Morals and the Novel'' -- except to question whether the words ''art,'' ''neurosis,'' ''manners,'' ''morals'' or ''novel'' have any permanent meaning?

title: STMICROELECTRONICS BUYING REST OF WAFERSCALE
description: STMicroelectronics N.V., Europe's biggest semiconductor maker, agreed yesterday to pay $68 million to acquire the part of closely held Waferscale Integration Inc. of Fremont, Calif., that it does not already own. Before the acquisition, STMicroelectronics owned a 14.5 percent minority stake in Waferscale, a maker of reprogrammable chips. Waferscale's programmable system devices can retain data even when a device is turned off through so-called flash memory. Flash memory chips are found in mobile phones, pocket organizers or digital cameras. ST's U.S. shares were down 31.25 cents, to $54.6875.

title: CHURCH & DWIGHT IS CLOSING SYRACUSE PLANT

The plant, which makes liquid laundry detergent and cat litter, will shut early next year. Its work force represents about 13 percent of Church & Dwight's employees. The company, based in Princeton, N.J., will take charges of about $20 million for severance and other costs, mostly in the third quarter, and will have about $3 million in start-up costs over the next year. Church & Dwight brands include Brillo and Super Scoop.

The appeals court, noting that substantial new legal questions had been raised in this case, has scheduled oral argument for September. In the meantime, Napster will continue operating.

title: PHILIP MORRIS IS RAISING CIGARETTE PRICES BY 3%
description: The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest tobacco company, is raising United States cigarette prices to distributors by about 3 percent to increase its profit and help pay for rising legal settlement costs. The company, which makes Marlboros, Benson & Hedges and Virginia Slims, raised wholesale prices by 6 cents a pack, effective on Monday. Analysts expect rival United States cigarette makers to follow. The move comes after increases of 13 cents in January and 18 cents last August. The increase could come out to about 8 cents a pack at checkout counters, according to Bonnie Herzog, a Credit Suisse First Boston analyst.

title: FRENCH UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS
description: As strong business confidence promoted hiring, unemployment in France, the second-biggest European economy, behind Germany, edged down further in June to 9.6 percent, from 9.8 percent in May, its lowest level in almost nine years. ''The improving economy is pushing us to hire,'' said Serge Weinberg, chief executive of Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, Europe's largest specialty retailer. The company will create 800 to 1,000 new jobs in France for a third year, he said. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWERS, RUTH PEDERSEN
description: POWERS-Ruth Pedersen. Died July 25, 2000 in Saint Louis, MO. at the age of 93. She had a long, effective career as a social worker in Buffalo with the Family Service, and in New York City at Travelers' Aid & Community Service Society. Ms. Powers was born in Brooklyn and moved to Stroudsburg, PA. during her high school years. She graduated from Cornell University, with a B.A. and from the New York School of Social Work with a MSW. At Travelers' Aid, she was in charge of the Port Department in the years after WWII, assisting the displaced persons arriving at the New York docks. She then worked at Community Service Society where she managed the Homemaker Service Program that offered temporary support to help clients weather a variety of domestic crises. After her retirement from CSS, she lived an active, independent life in Morningside Gardens where she enjoyed serving as surrogate grandma to several foreign students. For the past three years, she suffered from Alzheimer's Disease, finally succumbing, reluctantly to its complications. She was briefly married to Wollerton Powers and had two daughters, Elizabeth Harris of New York & Susan Lagunoff of Saint Louis, MO. She has five grandchildren, Nick and Sam Jordan, and Rachel, Liza and Michael Lagunoff, and one great granddaughter Sasha Lagunoff Eberhardt. An older sister, Laura Henninger lives in Seattle. Memorial contributions may be made to Habitat for Humanity, 334 Furman Street, Brooklyn, New York 11201.

title: MP3.COM SETTLES MUSIC SUIT WITH EMI GROUP UNIT
description: MP3.com Inc. has settled a copyright infringement suit with a unit of EMI Group P.L.C., allowing MP3.com eventually to resume online distribution of songs owned by EMI, the world's third-largest music company. EMI said it had entered into a nonexclusive North American licensing agreement with MP3.com. At a court hearing yesterday in Manhattan, Michael Robertson, chairman of MP3.com, declined to provide details of the settlement. MP3.com has previously reached settlements with the Music Group of Time Warner Inc., with which EMI is merging, and with the BMG Entertainment unit of Bertelsmann to end online copyright disputes.

title: The Ingratiator
description: Rick Lazio, the Republican candidate for Senate in New York, is post-everything. Born in 1958, he came along too late to be influenced by the civil rights struggle, the Vietnam War, the 60's, Watergate. The first presidential campaign Lazio volunteered to work on was Gerald Ford's in 1976. This is not just a matter of historical curiosity. Our political life is dominated by figures who came of age in the 60's and whose views bear the mark of these great events, just as the outlook of preceding generations was shaped by the cold war, World War II and the Depression. Think of Hillary Clinton, Lazio's opponent, who was born into a Midwestern Republican family and whose complacent sense of the order of things was upended by the liberal social gospel of her Methodist church. Even Gov. George Pataki, a genial Republican who is an ally of Lazio's -- and with whom Lazio is often compared -- became a Goldwater conservative in the 60's. Large, polarizing events force choices, and those choices create a certain crispness in point of view.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Too Big for Thinking
description: There are about 100 billion galaxies in the universe, each with about 100 billion stars. It would take 10,000 years to tally them if every human being on earth counted them at the rate of five per second. Sounds crowded out there, right? Yet if the solar system were the size of a coffee cup, the Milky Way would be as big as North America. And if you could collapse the Milky Way into that cup, the nearest sizable galaxy, Andromeda, would drift in space about seven feet away. Here's the capper: there is less than one atom per cubic yard floating in intergalactic space, while on earth one cubic yard of air holds about 50 trillion trillion atoms. These are among the mind-blowing revelations in ONE UNIVERSE: At Home in the Cosmos (Joseph Henry/National Academy Press, $40), an insightful primer on all things great and small. Loosely organized around the three basic principles driving the universe -- motion, matter and energy -- the book features crisp, rarely patronizing writing to describe the current state of knowledge of everything from the tiniest subatomic particles (with exotic names like fermions, bosons and leptoquarks) to superstring theory and other ''grand unified theories'' that seek to meld cosmic forces with the principles of quantum mechanics. The authors (Neil de Grasse Tyson, the director of the Hayden Planetarium, Charles Liu, an astrophysicist at the American Museum of Natural History, and Robert Irion, a science journalist) employ everyday analogies to explain the four basic forces of nature -- gravity, electromagnetism and the ''strong'' and ''weak'' forces at play in an atom's nucleus -- and the many fascinating ways these building blocks manifest themselves and interact. There are many helpful illustrations and color photographs, notably a riveting two-page photo showing a long string of burning fragments of Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9 being pulled to the roiling surface of Jupiter. What's most refreshing about this road trip through the heavens is the humility of its authors in the face of so much that is unknowable or dimly understood, even as they patiently but eloquently provide one-stop shopping for students of the cosmos. Scott Veale

Yet the film's larger subject is the bliss of being alive and adult in the Eisenhower era, smoking and listening, drinking and dancing, when jazz was not only popular but a liberating force in the American identity.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-30-00; School's Out For Never
description: In the late 70's, when I was a high school student, you went to summer school if you (a) had failed a class or (b) had absolutely nothing better to do. At my high school, (b) meant a choice of health and hygiene, taught by the football coach; driver's ed, taught by a short-tempered Algerian man with an uncertain command of English (''Fascinate your seat belts!''); introductory Spanish, taught by a blowsy recent divorcee who openly favored the boys; typing, taught by a woman with an undue interest in the paranormal; or ''sociology,'' taught by a Weird Al Yankovic look-alike who wrote ''Stay in touch -- all over my body!'' in the girls' yearbooks. No one under the age of 15 even went to summer school -- they were off at day camp making lanyards or singing ''There's a Hole in the Bottom of the Sea'' or hanging upside down on the playground monkey bars or chasing the ice cream truck or something.

It's another way to entertain business clients, a chance to get off one's feet while shopping or doing the galleries. But in Connecticut there are gardens, a flourishing selection of distributors, retail shops and tearooms, tea caterers, art museum teas, a magazine called Tea, a tea calendar and a new tea school.

Al Gore cannot hope to be the first president elected in the 21st century if he's still practicing the politics of the 18th. It is preposterous to suggest that not one woman or person of color merits consideration to be the nominee for vice president. If his campaign continues to demonstrate this lack of imagination, Gore is guaranteed a trip home in January.

In the shelter of a Raj-era, colonnaded musical pavilion, a yoga teacher showed me how to twist, stretch and balance myself in the ancient poses, or asanas, of the cobra, the tree, the cow face and the dead man.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-30-00: Salient Facts; Cab Checker
description: MEAN STREETSYou thought hailing a cab during rush hour in New York City was difficult? Until recently, Seoul's taxi drivers -- wary of communication problems -- simply avoided anyone who looked like a foreigner. Desperate tourists had to rely on official interpreters, who would handwrite them lengthy memos with directions in Korean. But in anticipation of the World Cup, coming to South Korea in 2002, the city of Seoul recently introduced the free Pick Up Phone Taxi Interpretation Service. China and Japan are looking into developing similar programs in their countries in the next year or two.

title: Incarcerated But Not Without a Free Spirit
description: AN exhibition at Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks that consists of art by inmates of Connecticut state prisons cannot help seeming a little wistful. An airport's business is flight and a prisoner's life is all about staying put. Fortunately there is the Prison Arts Program; it is run by a group called Community Partners in Action. As the organization's publicity says, artists and writers conduct workshops with the aim of ''assisting inmates in finding ways to use their prison sentences constructively.''

title: Scorching the Drag Racing Track in Her '83 Chevy
description: Raceway Park in Englishtown holds quarter-mile, blink-and-you'll-miss it drag races. Usually on the card are low-slung dragsters that go against each other at up to 250 miles per hour, snowmobiles retrofitted to race on pavement and souped-up motorcycles. Then comes something different. They call it the Advanced Trophy Division and it's held most Sundays. It is wide open, which means that as long as you have a car, a drop of gas, a seat belt and a helmet (they are for rent), you can enter. A procession of 50 cars made its way toward the starting line on a recent Sunday and the drivers were teeming with bull-in-a-chute energy. They were big men, small men, bearded men, pot-bellied men, men yelling unprintable words, men in leather, men in jeans, shirtless men. And then there was Shannon Zulla, 20, a soft-spoken woman from Piscataway, who has delicate wire-rimmed glasses and a smile that holds a hint of mischief. She talked about her passion for drag racing.

title: July 23-29; A 19-Under Wonder
description: Tiger Woods looks as comfortable making history as he does holding a golf club. Championship next month, he will become the first player since Hogan (1953) to win three consecutive majors. Stay tuned. CLIFTON BROWN

title: Sue Zesiger and Reeves Callaway

title: July 23-29; A Link for SIDS
description: Researchers in Italy discovered a genetic link between some cases of sudden infant death syndrome and a rare heart disorder, long-QT syndrome. Their report, published in The New England Journal of Medicine, said all newborns should be given electrocardiograms to detect the treatable heart problem, which may account for 10 to 30 percent of the 2,800 sudden infant deaths a year. But most American experts oppose routine electrocardiograms, saying they would not save enough lives to justify the expense. DENISE GRADY

title: July 23-29; Not Quite Certifiable
description: Taxpayers who spent $2.65 extra for certified mail when they sent their money to the Internal Revenue Service and other tax agencies may have noticed that their checks went uncashed for weeks. The reason? The United States Postal Service delayed using new technology and lacked workers, causing tens of thousands of certified letters, with hundreds of millions of dollars of checks, to languish. To add insult to injury, New York City tax officials dunned hundreds of property owners on the assumption that they had failed to pay. DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

title: THE MEDIAN PRICE RISES
description: A short supply of houses and a jump in the sales of high-priced homes has caused the median price of a house in Westchester County to rise to $400,000, from $355,000, in the past year, according to the latest quarterly figures from the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service. The prices might stymie first-time home buyers but should correct themselves as the decline in inventory eases, said P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. Mr. Mercurio said a vigorous market caused sales to outpace supply and drive up prices. Constance DeFilippis, co-owner of Gains Realty in White Plains, said, ''Where a $200,000 home used to be the starter home, it is now over $300,000.''

title: An Accidental Icon of American Pop
description: OF all the things that roll down American highways, few are as strange and perfect as the Airstream, the R.V. for the Atomic Age. Produced since 1952 at a factory in Jackson Center, Ohio, the cylindrical, self-contained Airstream ''land yacht'' has become a middle-American answer to luxury on the high seas. By the 1960's, the distinctive trailers were available in a range of models, from the little bubble of the 18-foot Bambi to the 30-foot Sovereign Double, an airship for the road. At one time or another, every corner of the country, much of the world, and countless envious gawkers have been reflected in the Airstream's shining aluminum skin.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-30-00: Questions for Yusuf Islam; Pilgrim's Progress
description: Q: You've been retired from the business of being Cat Stevens since you converted to Islam in 1977. During that time, you established four Islamic children's schools in London and the Mountain of Light record label. This summer, your old records are being rereleased. How did that decision come about?

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Here's what we learned from this shoot: some kids are born photographers. Robert Chamberlain was especially adroit at capturing a moment -- and he knew it. He would shout, ''Yes!'' and pump his arm after every good shot. In this candid behind-the-scenes photo, he caught a quiet moment between Cooper Witte and Yasmine Alfakey, in sunglasses, who has on a Barbie shirt ($19.50) and Tina Neumann pants ($70).2. We also learned that kids don't look at labels; adults do. And for those who care, Gucci has introduced Gucci Baby, a new line of luxe children's clothing. Now you can bring your newborn home from the hospital wearing (a) booties with the double-G logo. From $90 to $165. Or for cold nights in Aspen, try (b) a white mink coat ($4,250). Or deck your kid out in (c) black canvas and leather (biker jacket, $995, and pants, $295) to minimize damage if he falls off his Razor scooter. (All at select Gucci stores.) Prada is also expanding its line to include (d) sports shoes for children. Five styles will be available at Barneys New York, Neiman Marcus and most Prada stores in November. The price range is $130 to $160, so under-age Prada junkies -- the few who do label-watch -- should start saving their allowance now.3. Some camera representatives have a lot of patience. Ray Acevedo was dispatched by Olympus to help teach the kids how to use the C3030 Zoom digital. Even our littlest photographer, Messiah Bailey (a), a mere 4, picked it up. Cameras ($999.99) were loaded with 64 MB Smartmedia cards ($179) and set at Super High Quality (SHQ-jpeg), allowing the kids to take 27 photos before having to download. All in all, Acevedo downloaded about 450 photographs -- roughly the same amount generated by a normal fashion shoot. Since there were only two C3030's (along with Smartmedia cards, available at Alkit Image Express, 820 Third Avenue), Jade Smith (b) and the other children were each given a Kodak Max one-time-use camera.4. Some kids are born stylists. Cooper Witte eyed the rack keenly, immediately chose the outfit she wanted (a), a CK Calvin Klein Jeans Kids top ($17 at Sears and Stern's) and Gap skirt ($48, at Gap stores nationwide), and never looked back. In fact, while the other girls were still pulling on pants, Cooper was the first to the accessories table, where she grabbed the crown jewel, the Judith Leiber of kids' purses (b): a Hello Kitty sequined change bag ($15 at Kobe Alley Corporation, 8 Elizabeth Street). Or check out the Web page, www.sanrio.com, for a store near you.5. It wouldn't be a fashion shoot if a model didn't cry. Spencer Clayton is smiling in this picture as he considers different hats, but his mood took a dive moments later when he tried on an H&M; T-shirt that resembled a sheriff's outfit. Although adults told him he looked handsome, Spencer didn't feel handsome. He stood in a corner, brooding. When he was asked if he was O.K., his eyes filled with tears. ''I don't want to wear this,'' he said, and was quickly reminded that he could wear anything he wanted. Seconds later, the shirt was off and Spencer, having replaced it with a Ralph Lauren jersey ($25, at Polo Ralph Lauren), was cool again.6. Finally, the girls love products. They all went crazy over a table filled with makeup. Big winners were (a) Sweet Georgia Brown's Rockin' Roll Body Glitter ($1.99 at Rite Aid), Z New York's Barely Blushing Gel ($13 at Zitomer, 969 Madison Avenue), Girl Eye Shadow and sparkle nail polish from Stuf by Lafco ($10 and $7 at Nordstrom) and Wet 'n' Wild Lipstick (99 cents at Rite Aid). While Yasmine Alfakey experimented with blue mascara on her eyebrows and cheeks, most girls, like Jade Smith (b), were pretty in pink. -- Text by Nell Scovell

title: WILLIAM PATERSON EXPANDING
description: William Paterson University has purchased the 150,000-square-foot Union Camp Corporation headquarters in Wayne, about a mile and a half from the campus, for $9.5 million to house its business school and expand its office space. The 50-acre property was owned by International Paper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ROSLYN B.
description: STERN-Roslyn B. On July 27, 2000 at age 88. Beloved wife of the late Irving, loving mother of Peter and his wife Joan, loving grandmother of Jeffrey & Amy & her husband David. She lives on in the hearts of all who knew her. Services at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC, 11:30 AM, Sunday, July 30, 2000.

title: Keep Your Eye on the ... Golfwear
description: LET'S just say that golf is not my sport. First of all, my hand-eye coordination is bad enough that I still button my shirt wrong. Second, the idea of getting up at dawn for anything is out of the question. And third, do I have to even say it? Those clothes! Bathroom wallpaper with collars for the women, not to mention lime green pants for the men, with navy whales -- or ducks -- embroidered on them. And all in the name of a sport, to hear devotees describe it, that is the ultimate contest of man versus himself. Well, here's a news flash. With ducks on your pants, you just lost. Both of you.

title: Virginia's Desperate Step To Protect the Blue Crab
description: In the face of economic and environmental warning signs, state fishery authorities have taken the drastic step of declaring a vast 665-square-mile fishermen-free sanctuary through the heart of the lower Chesapeake Bay to provide safe passage for the millions of female blue crabs now on the southward trek to their high-salt spawning grounds.

title: An Iranian Star at Home in Northern California
description: For the hundreds of thousands of Iranian expatriates in the Bay Area of Northern California, the soccer star Khodadad Azizi was hailed as a national hero when he arrived last March (along with his wife and 3-year-old daughter) and signed a four-year contract to play for the San Jose Earthquakes of Major League Soccer. Unlike many of the aging players who have left leagues in Europe and South America, Azizi, 29, came to the five-year-old American league in his prime, having played three seasons in Germany for F.C. Cologne.

title: Bookend; Dostoyevsky At the Table

description: HARRIS-Paula (nee Jacoby). Beloved wife of the late Jerome, adored mother of Marjorie and Bert Rothstein and Judi and Michael Rosen.
