description: CONTEMPORARY wood turning turns adventurous when artists are challenged to create work symbolizing personal exploration and artistic growth.

title: QUICK BITE/High Bridge; Milk, and Good Stuff Made From It
description: I don't know how many times I've hunkered down with a hoagie at some small roadside joint and thought, ''I wonder what they've got for dessert.'' Often I'm left weeping into my fries, because the heartless rules of take-out commerce demand grab-and-run fare. The folks behind the counter act as if no one, least of all them, has time for sweets, except perhaps week-old bagged cookies or slabs of pound cake. But this is never a problem at Gronsky's. Shed a tear and the teenage waitress has every right to rap your noggin as she quips, ''Uh, hello? This is the Milk House, remember?''

title: Leviathan
description: HERMAN MELVILLE

title: Summertime Dues
description: Walter Kirn's article reminded me of my first job, at age 14, at a fish-fry restaurant in Vermont. We were terrified of the owner, so rather than face his wrath when any food items dropped on the floor, we quickly returned them to their original places. I learned a valuable lesson from this experience: don't eat at fast-food places.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, LOIS
description: HIRSCH-Lois. We mourn the loss of our cherished friend, Lois Hirsch. Her radiant spirit and extraordinary courage will always be an inspiration. We will forever remember her generosity, kindness and vitality. Our sincere condolences to her dear husband Myron and her family. Barbara and Richard Kahn, Esther and Lester Sparberg

title: Robert McFarland, 62, Broadcast Journalist
description: Robert McFarland, a former correspondent, producer and Washington bureau chief of NBC News, died on Tuesday at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 62.

title: A Tribute to Parker by a Peer of Parker's
description: THERE are few musicians alive who can do justice to a Charlie Parker celebration better than the saxophonist James Moody. That's why he's anchoring the Caramoor Jazz Festival next Saturday at the Venetian Theater at Caramoor in Katonah. ''Charlie Parker was my ideal,'' said Mr. Moody, who will perform with his quartet, including Phil Woods, Charles McPherson and Jon Faddis. ''When he and Dizzy hit it, that was it for me.''

title: July 23-29; Schooling Details
description: Educators and policymakers with funds would do better buying curricular materials or PC's for teachers than raising salaries, according to a new analysis linking test scores to state policy initiatives and education spending patterns. The study, by the Rand Corporation, suggested that reforms over the past 15 years are showing success with smaller classes in the early grades and access to preschool. JODI WILGOREN

title: Country, Off Center
description: Part of the alternative-country crowd that doesn't get much respect from Nashville, Robbie Fulks is an insurgent singer-songwriter who bites the hand that feeds him. He writes irreverent songs, with wry wordplay, traditional country sentiments and roots-based rock.

title: July 23-29; Economies of Scale at Ford
description: Since the early 1980's, automakers have made small fuel-economy gains on some models only to make other vehicles larger and more powerful, with poorer mileage. The result has been ever-increasing emissions of global warming gases and more dependence on foreign oil. Ford Motor changed course, vowing to increase the average mileage of all its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent, to 23 miles a gallon from 18, by 2005. Ford will also improve the fuel economy of its other models. KEITH BRADSHER

title: Robert G. Crowder, 60, Expert on Memory
description: Dr. Robert George Crowder, an experimental psychologist and an authority on memory, died Thursday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 60.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KARNACEWICZ, MICHAEL ALEXANDER
description: KARNACEWICZ-Michael Alexander. With love from your family & friends on this first anniversary of your death. We miss you always.

title: Plenty of Old Money, but Not Much Limelight
description: THEY may not be as well known as the Fords or the Rockefellers, but the Dorrances live up to the stereotypes of old wealth. They spend their time raising horses and frequenting upper-class haunts like Newport, R.I. Except for a flurry of news reports about a decade ago, when the question of whether they would sell the Campbell Soup Company last arose, they mostly stay out of the papers and keep low profiles. They did not return repeated phone calls over the last month seeking interviews.

title: Saratoga
description: This has been the Whitney century at Saratoga Springs.

title: Strapped for the Right Handbag? Get a Grip
description: Handbag lovers who keep up with the trends have a heavy must-have list this fall. You can't carry a black and silver purse with next season's brown tweeds. And that satin Gucci clutch with the gold chain strap certainly does not go with autumn's Manolo herringbone stilettos. To accommodate the overextended fashionista, the latest accessories innovation is handbags with detachable handles. Givenchy offers the Charade bag, far right, named after a style Audrey Hepburn had in the 1963 film of that name. The rectangular purse, available in black or polished calf for $760, has eight handles. Purchased separately, they include a pony skin strap with a graphic print, $180, and a Swarovski-crystal-encrusted one, $500. Searle offers a less pricey transformable pocketbook called Bag du Jour, left, in denim with python or ostrich trimmings, and in beachy canvas. The bag, with no handle, costs $48, or $68 for the tote size. Leather handles, $55 each, come in brown, green, red, lavender, blue and six other shades, and they clasp through holes in the top with a fishing-style hook. What's next? Shoes with removable heels? One can only hope. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: Science Fiction
description: THE FOUNTAINS OF YOUTH (Tor/Tom Doherty, $24.95), by Brian Stableford, purports to be the true story behind Mortimer Gray's monumental work of scholarship, ''The History of Death.'' Written by the famous historian himself, it answers pressing questions like: Why did Gray begin writing death's obituary? Why did he take five centuries to finish it? And what is he doing for an encore?

description: Metropolitan Life, which owns and operates Peter Cooper Village, is seeking a rent increase for major rewiring of the 2,480 units in the sprawling complex east of First Avenue between 20th and 23rd Streets. Some tenants, many of them elderly, long-term residents on limited incomes, say they cannot afford the monthly increase that Met Life wants, which will amount fo $44 per room.

title: PRIVATE SECTOR; Gray Flannel Suit at the Dot-Com
description: CHARLES M. PECK, introduced earlier this month as the new chief executive of Theglobe.com, looks as if he stepped out of the pages of ''The Organization Man,'' with his graying, short-cropped hair, herringbone sports coat and Marine Corps demeanor. His resume could induce somnolence in all but the most open-minded Silicon Alley denizen: salesman for Xerox, executive at Levi Strauss, PepsiCo and Booz Allen & Hamilton, in-house strategist for the New York Stock Exchange, Viacom, Standard & Poor's, and most recently, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDIMAN, SAMUEL
description: ANDIMAN-Samuel. Passed away peacefully on July 29th at the age of 86. Adoring husband of the late Carol Lynne; loving and proud father of Suzi (Scott Fischman) and Lori (Michael Randall). Cherished grandfather of Benjamin Joseph, the light of his life. Dear brother of the late Jeanne Benson and Al Andiman. Caring uncle, great-uncle and cousin and friend to many. He was a rare individual of superior intellect, an avid reader, poet, family scribe, numismatist, philatelist, talented gardener and artist and a gentleman. Lifelong Mason and public school teacher for 40 years. Dearest Mephie, rest in well-deserved peace. Funeral services Monday at 12:30 at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to the Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, NY 11590 or B'Nai Israel Nursery School, 6301 Montrose Road, Rockville, MD 20852. Our deep appreciation to the staff of 5 Central (Greenberg Pavilion) New York Hospital.

title: PULSE; It Will Curl Your Eyelashes
description: For those who puzzle over the continuing beauty mystery -- why do Frenchwomen always look so good? -- here's a new clue. While American women still torture themselves with eyelash curlers, the French subscribe to a more lasting approach to lash maintenance: eyelash perms. They have recently become available in New York at the Ella Bache Spa at 8 West 36th Street. ''Frenchwomen don't use eyelash curlers,'' said Anne-Cecile Curot, the manager. In an exacting process, Ms. Curot glues one of three sizes of miniature rollers to the client's lashes, then applies a perming gel, whose active ingredient, ammonia, is what gives hair salons their pungent smell. Asked about the solution's safety, Ms. Curot replied, ''It is formulated to be close to the composition of tears.'' The 40-minute procedure, which, unlike eyelash dyeing, is legal in New York, ends with a collagen-based neutralizing treatment. ''It's great in the summer, when many women don't like to wear mascara,'' Ms. Curot said. The perm lasts six to eight weeks and costs $50. DEBRA SCOTT

title: Unmistakably Dutch
description: LEIDEN, a walkable city on two small branches of the Rhine River, is something more than a nice little Dutch town, as it was once described to me by a friend who lived there. Although unmistakably Dutch in appearance -- with quiet neighborhoods of gabled, canalside houses and a small open-air market selling North Sea herring and wax-covered wheels of Gouda -- Leiden's window on the world is larger than its population of 117,000 would indicate.

title: PATERSON MAYOR INVESTIGATED
description: The F.B.I. is investigating Mayor Marty Barnes of Paterson to determine if trips he took while in office, some of which were paid for by contractors doing business with the city, constitute a conflict of interest, said Thomas C. Rooney Jr., a city councilman who has led the council's questioning of the expenses. In his three years in office, Mayor Barnes, and sometimes his wife and a contingent of people from City Hall, have visited Switzerland, the Dominican Republic, Russia and Brazil. The mayor has not provided the council with details of his trips, despite requests. The F.B.I. would not comment on whether an investigation is under way. Karen DeMasters

title: Identity Restored to 100,000 Louisiana Slaves
description: From the darkness of history they emerge out of a silver spinning disc: two black slaves sold by a sugar plantation owner named Levi Foster on Feb. 11, 1818, to his in-laws. The first slave, named Kit, was 28 years old, and sold for $975. The other, named Alick, was 9, and was possibly Kit's son. He was sold for $400.

title: Heather Kaye, Ross Nussbaum

description: There comes a time when even the most devoted gardener has to take a rest. Ease the guilt of not working in the yard (if you feel any) by lying in a hammock or sitting on the beach with one of Ann Ripley's garden-themed mysteries.

description: The Irish in New York City may be famous for many things, but merengue is not one of them. Yet Patrick Shannon, a newly established merengue singer, grew up blue-collar Irish in Flatbush, Brooklyn.

title: July 23-29; A Strain of Mad Cow
description: In Britain, mad cow disease is scarier than ever. Fourteen people have died of it already this year and five more are dying, compared to 14 in all of last year. Experts say the rising death toll might presage an even higher death rate.

title: Sheila Ohlsson, William Walker
description: Sheila Jane Ohlsson, the daughter of Mariza B. Ohlsson of Seattle and Dr. John T. Ohlsson of Denver, was married yesterday to William Mallory Walker, a son of Diana H. Walker and O. Mallory Walker Jr. of Washington. Lea Flocchini, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the bridegroom's family's home in Sun Valley, Idaho.

title: Rem Koolhaas Builds
description: Arthur Lubow (July 9) writes that ''the critics' favorites are also the public's favorites,'' as though this were now general wisdom. The story of 20th-century architecture has been the defiance of the tastes, desires and needs of the public in favor of the dictates of a hyperintellectual status game played among an elite. Most people -- of all levels of education -- vastly prefer a good Beaux-Arts building to any of the cold monstrosities created by Koolhaas and others playing the postmodern game. Most of us are all too familiar with the pointless and arrogant ''nose-thumbing gestures'' that have been inflicted on us by modern architecture.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Home Town, by Tracy Kidder. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $14.95.) Through personal profiles and historical and demographic digressions, the author takes the pulse of Northampton, Mass., a city of 30,000 highly diverse people. Most of the natives leave when they reach adulthood, and are replaced by newcomers. Kidder's ''smart and gently ironic writing is always good company,'' Ben Yagoda wrote here in 1999.

title: ONLINE HELP FOR YOUNG AND OLD
description: Westchester has set up a Web-based Community Help Desk to help young people and the elderly who need professional services. The Help Desk, found on the county's Web site at www.westchestergov.com, provides information from more than 40 experts. For example, a person concerned about a youngster in emotional trouble can be directed to a youth officer or a help line. The site is expected to be expanded to include other areas of government, including welfare programs and the use of county parks. The program will also eventually set up appointments, offer applications for services, provide directions and bus schedules, arrange for transportation and offer live contact, where a user can talk to someone through the computer. Elsa Brenner

Other tenants are willing to trade windows for renovations and new appliances, but a Buildings Department spokesman said that nothing justified bricking up windows and that the department was investigating.

title: Man Behind the Butter Pat Now Lets You Hold the Mayo, One-Handed
description: SANFORD REDMOND was peering in at his latest invention, a machine that cranks out small plastic containers, more than a thousand every minute. It was clapping, stamping and swooshing with a roar that could make a dog hide under a bed. But Mr. Redmond stood still, looking on with the placid expression of a man admiring his grandchildren.

title: Next Steps in the Mideast
description: Israelis and Palestinians are trying to pick up where they left off at the unsuccessful Camp David summit meeting and continue moving toward a final peace agreement. It is now critically important to sustain some of the positive momentum established there.

This, Groh explained, was just like all the times he went to work as the coach of the Jets linebackers, simply an opportunity to meet the competition, only now on a larger scale.

title: Meaghan Shaughnessy, Andrew Cahill
description: Meaghan Maureen Shaughnessy, a daughter of Collette and Michael J. Shaughnessy of St. Paul, Neb., was married yesterday to Andrew Forrest Cahill, a son of Dr. Teena L. Cahill of Princeton, N.J., and Dr. James F. Cahill of Richboro, Pa. The Rev. David Cooper performed the nondenominational ceremony at Regis University in Denver.

title: Anger and Pain Over Nude Photos
description: When Marian Rubin picked up her photographs at Moto-Photo here last February and found the police waiting for her, she had no idea that she was under suspicion of being a child pornographer for taking nude pictures of her two granddaughters, ages 3 and 8.

title: MUSIC; Country Gets Back To an Old Standard: Music for Grown-ups
description: COUNTRY music has long traded in themes that speak directly to its adult audience. Hank Williams sang about how his son called another man Daddy; Merle Haggard about the working-man blues; Loretta Lynn, a mother of six and a grandmother at 29, about getting on the pill. Rock 'n' roll has always enjoyed its share of youth appeal, but country has first and foremost been music for grown-ups.

title: New Grandmaster Changes Tune to Win a Quiet Game
description: The Jack Collins International Tournament at the Marshall Chess Club in Greenwich Village June 12 to June 23 honored the man who trained and coached some of America's leading players, beginning more than 60 years ago. It was also intended to give the current crop of young players the chance to achieve the qualifications for grandmaster.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Blameless

title: Our Towns; With G.O.P. Guests, Camden Tries to Paint Over Its Rot
description: FOR just one evening, this city is trying not to ooze misery. It deployed the Public Works Department's only grass cutter to mow vacant lots downtown, forsaking 2,000 others that need tending. The streets need cleaning, but the city's seven sweepers are old and broken. Camden has 3,500 vacant buildings, but only a three-man crew to keep them boarded up.

title: President Extols His Partner and Her Party
description: Heaping lavish praise on his wife as the most intelligent and passionate person he had ever met, President Clinton exhorted a small but generous clutch of contributors in Manhattan yesterday to guard against complacency in a time of prosperity and to remember the vast differences between Republicans and Democrats.

title: For 25 Years, a Point of Light
description: When Sister Mary Vincent Sharp got the call that there was some free furniture at a house in Northeast Philadelphia, she had to get there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLOR, MILDRED
description: KLOR-Mildred (1914-2000). Wife, mother, grandmother. Retired Abraham Straus employee and tireless volunteer. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Roslyn Senior Citizens Inc., 1489 Old Northern Boulevard, Roslyn, New York 11590.

title: The Nation; A Convention for Everyone, One at a Time
description: AT this summer's political party gatherings, where the outcomes are preordained, the hottest activity may be interactivity. For the Republican National Convention this week, for example, Chris Long wants to put you in the director's seat. On C-SPAN's Web site, run by Mr. Long, users will be able to click on one of several distinct video feeds from the convention hall, or even choose to watch the action from the vantage point of the C-SPAN control booth.

title: Democrats Pick an Odd Time To Fight Over a Distant Race
description: Leave it to those fractious Democrats to remind everyone what is important in New Jersey politics.

title: Before Bluegrass, Bill Monroe Was Already a Star
description: SO closely is the late Bill Monroe identified with his musical creation, bluegrass, that it's almost as if man and music called each other into being. The notion of a pre-Monroe bluegrass obviously makes no sense, yet it's almost as hard to imagine a pre-bluegrass Monroe. What? Without his big white Stetson? Without the Blue Grass Boys, deployed in their immutable formula of guitar, banjo, fiddle and bass? It's like trying to picture Bob Wills without a western swing band.

title: Comparing Costs of Buses Against Those of Trains
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Woof Wishes
description: IT used to be that a growling German shepherd or wiggling poodle at a wedding was as unwelcome as a former spouse. Guests assumed that disaster, or multiple personal injuries, or both, were imminent. But nowadays, dogs (and ex-lovers) are increasingly present at weddings and much better behaved than one might expect.

title: Street Crime
description: To the Editor: Alan Cowell's report on London in ''Crime Takes a Vacation (Yours)'' (July 16) implies that if you fear being robbed there, then trick the thieves with a fake Rolex. But a dear friend who lives in London's upscale St. John's Wood neighborhood was recently attacked in broad daylight as she entered her house. She was thrown to the floor and her Rolex ripped from her wrist, leaving her scarred, bruised, bleeding and traumatized. Her purse, jewelry and home were untouched.

title: The L.I.R.R. Train That Lays Its Own Track
description: THE machine is almost a quarter-mile long and creeps along at 800 feet an hour, replacing old track with new. This behemoth, right, is being used by the Long Island Rail Road to replace old wooden ties with concrete ones, which last three times longer and require less maintenance. The machine pulls up the old rail, removes the ties, plows out the track bed and installs the rails on new concrete ties.

title: NEW SITE FOR SCHERING-PLOUGH
description: Schering-Plough Corporation, based in Madison, will purchase the Summit site now owned by Novartis Pharmaceuticals Corporation, which includes two million square feet of research and development, laboratory and office space.

title: July 23-29; A Creeping Tale for $1 a Chapter
description: The horror writer Stephen King became the first major author to self-publish over the Internet when he released the first chapter of a serial novel called ''The Plant,'' about a vine that terrorizes a publishing house.

title: Lives; Welcome to the Jungle
description: Right around the time I moved to New York from Texas nine years ago, the city led the nation in robberies. I have always been proud that I played a small part in keeping it atop the rankings: my roommate and I were robbed -- or at least the robbery got under way -- just five minutes after we eased the U-Haul along the curb in Brooklyn, basking in the glow of our new urban sophistication. Inevitably, whenever the dog days of summer return, my thoughts return to that day. And I must admit that in a slightly perverse way -- as I watched the city's per capita crime rate dip below that of Boise -- I have even found myself growing a little nostalgic for the guy who left us about $500 poorer.

title: POSTINGS: Sohmer Building Being Converted to Apartments; From Piano Keys to Condo Keys
description: The century-old, 13-story Sohmer Building at 170 Fifth Avenue, at 22nd Street, which once attracted piano purchasers to its showroom, is being converted to a residential condominium as its commercial tenants leave. Topping the building is a $7.5 million, 4,936-square-foot duplex that includes a golden-domed octagonal cupola featuring a 360-degree view, a 40-foot-high ceiling and a band of eight 8-foot-high clerestory windows atop another set of eight 10-foot-high windows at living-room level.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTH, SEYMOUR
description: BARTH-Seymour. Beloved husband of Sheila. Loving father of Joel, Edward and Sharon. Adored grandfather of Gabriela, Susan, William and Victoria. Devoted brother of Morris & Lenore. Dear father-in-law of Ana and Judy. Cherished uncle of nine nieces and nephews. Retired founder and CEO of Astrosystems Inc. His passing leaves a great sadness in all who knew and loved him. Funeral services Sunday, 11:30AM at Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center or Temple Beth Sholom.

title: For Once-Gritty TriBeCa, a Golden Glow
description: TRIBECA, the old butter-and-eggs district of Lower Manhattan, isn't sizzling any longer. It's deafening.

title: Three Revisits That Were Worth the Trip
description: NOTHING about a restaurant is preserved in amber. The kitchen may become stale, or newly inspired. A chef leaves, another arrives. Owners sell or become absentee. Even the food is subject to the vagaries of fads and fashions.

title: Memories of A Now-Lost Tree
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathryn Hunt, Gerritt Graham
description: Kathryn Lynn Hunt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Hunt Jr. of Orchard Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Gerritt Thomas Graham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Graham Jr. of Southport, Conn. The Rev. John B. Smiley, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Westminster Presbyterian Church in Buffalo.

title: Today's Starter
description: As is traditional at a baseball game, major or minor league, before the first pitch is thrown, the crowd rises for the national anthem. But in some parks, the tradition ends there. It is not a celebrity (or local with a wavering tenor) singing. It is David Demsey, a professor of music at William Paterson University, who lives in Wayne, and he is playing the anthem on a saxophone. For the past four years, Mr. Demsey has been starting the games for the Trenton Thunder and the New Jersey Cardinals, as well as the Philadelphia Phillies and the minor league Scranton Wilkes-Barre Red Barons and the Staten Island Yankees. Mr. Demsey got the job when he was attending a game and was recognized by a minor league executive who also happened to be a fan of the saxophone. Although saxophone is not the usual instrument on which the national anthem is played, Mr. Demsey says that the crowd reaction is enthusiastic and that some players consider his performance good luck. KAREN DEMASTERS

title: Introduction
description: Most readers found that Arthur Lubow's profile of Rem Koolhaas showed the architect to be cold and overintellectual, both personally and in his designs. Readers were split about Walter Kirn's take on summer jobs -- some waxed nostalgic, while others wanted to take him out behind the woodshed.

title: P.B.A. and Rights Group Join to Protest Spying on Officers
description: In an unusual alliance, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association is joining the New York Civil Liberties Union and groups representing black and Hispanic police officers to discuss their concerns about the Police Department's possible monitoring of the groups, which are often critical of the department.

title: Eastern Phenomenon
description: To the Editor:

title: A Landscape That Carries a Life's Worth of Emotion
description: EMILY NELLIGAN's charcoal drawings are almost all the same size: 10 inches wide by 7 inches high. Some are dark as a moonless night, some pale as fog. They all depict the same landscape: Great Cranberry Island, southwest of Mount Desert Island in Maine. Twenty-six of them, reticent and lyrical, ring a galley at the Bowdoin College Museum of Art here. In their minimal steel frames, they hang like sudden windows: instants of light and air translated into black and white.

title: Debra Denenberg, Kenneth Marcus
description: Debra Lynn Denenberg, the daughter of Betty Denenberg and Dr. Allan Denenberg of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to Kenneth Robert Marcus, a son of Ellen and David Marcus of Manhattan. Rabbi Abner Bergman officiated at the Water's Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Potato Barn Images
description: Like the widow's walk on the homes of yesteryear's fishermen, the potato barn, a relic of such hardscrabble republican virtues as agrarian self-reliance, still casts a spell over North Fork old-timers.

title: Stand Out Or Else Stand Back
description: Personal style stands tall in a summer drowning in a deluge of bland-looking megabrands. Individuality has nothing to do with age and everything to do with flair: right, a bespoke suit made from 1930's-style necktie silk; left, classic equestrian patterns and a shoulder bag in the shape of a riding saddle; bottom far right, a study in gray, black and white, and dolman sleeves; top far right, a suit jacket shaped with a sash, and a towering straw hat secured with red ribbon, worn by a free spirit in an age of conformity.

title: St. George Weight Lifters Prove No Match for Worms
description: In a David vs. Goliath development, dozens of Staten Island weight lifters were defeated last week, at least temporarily, by a horde of tiny borer worms.

title: Arbitrator Grants Police Higher Pay in Suffolk
description: An arbitrator decided last week to give Suffolk County police officers a four-year contract that effectively raises their salaries -- already among the highest in the nation -- by 20 percent and will result in a 20 percent increase in homeowners' police-district taxes next year.

title: Museum Shows Off Dr. Seuss' Serious Side
description: This summer and fall, fans of Dr. Seuss can attend an exhibition of his work without a single taste of green eggs and ham. Through Oct. 16, ''The Political Dr. Seuss'' assembles about 50 of his political cartoons at the Connecticut Valley Historical Museum in Springfield, Mass., the city where he was born and grew up.

title: A Doo-Wop Festival That Didn't
description: Sometimes you give a party and no one comes, but in Wildwood, people tried to come to the Doo-Wop Festival and found it wasn't there. Notice of the Doo-Wop Festival, scheduled for July 7 through 9, appeared on promotional tourism calendars and placards up and down the Boardwalk, but no one was rocking on the Holly Beach Mall.

title: Cabletron Is Preparing To Divide and Conquer
description: ARE four spinoffs better than one whole company? That is the puzzle facing holders of Cabletron Systems.

title: Look Tough, Feel Good
description: To the Editor:

title: In Portland, Me., a Lobster in Every Pot
description: FOR a city of only 65,000, Portland, Me., boasts more high-quality restaurants than most cities twice its size. Nourished by fishermen, farmers and ranchers in the region, local chefs have an enviable larder with which to work. And in summer, when gardens are burgeoning and there is a lobster in every pot, visitors can enjoy some splendid fare, and at very affordable prices.

title: Drug Runners Are Finding the Going Easy in Haiti
description: For Del Lydes, the drug planes that circle over the cornfields have become as common as the flies that buzz around his cows. They swoop down past the trees and roll to a stop along the two-lane road that slices through the fields. Then men with machine guns stash their cargo -- cocaine -- into cars.

title: School in East Hampton Gets Regents Charter
description: After a half-dozen drafts, a proposal that the Child Development Center of the Hamptons become the second charter school on Long Island was unanimously approved this month by the State Board of Regents. The first approval went to the Children's Academy in Roosevelt.

title: Washington Monument Is Ready to Reopen
description: After being closed off and on for the last three years for renovation, the Washington Monument is to reopen to visitors tomorrow, missing its Fourth of July goal by four weeks.

title: Measuring a Maestro For the Ages (Again)
description: EVEN those unmoved by Leonard Bernstein's exuberant musicianship find it impossible to deny his magnetism. As conductor and pianist, Bernstein energized audiences. His exciting podium presence was the stuff of legend, and caricature. Yet his enthusiasm for music was real -- innate, even -- and not merely generated for public consumption.

title: Look for a Board With a Lot to Lose
description: Outside directors who hold significant stakes in the company's stock are widely regarded as a good sign for investors; the thinking is that they will be motivated to watch out for shareholder interests, especially when they conflict with the interests of insiders.

title: Zinnias Galore; Green Thumb Not Needed
description: LAST year, I renewed one of my first loves and learned to enjoy growing zinnias again.

title: Traditional Italian With Elegant Decor
description: THE JONES BEACH HOTEL, almost three-quarters of a century old, is a local legend. Hidden away on a dead-end street in Wantagh, this spic and span spot has a restaurant that is remembered by generations of Long Islanders as everything from a modest eatery serving fixed-price Italian meals to a college hangout, to a teenage meeting and drinking rendezvous and, most recently, to a run-down bar. But never has it been what it is now, a place of unexpected luxury with easy-to-take prices and often commendable food.

description: A deeply disgruntled Yasir Arafat left his base in the Gaza Strip today on a diplomatic tour aimed at solidifying international support for the Palestinians in the wake of the Camp David talks.

title: The Designer
description: In reaction to the rage for techno fabrics and screaming-to-be-seen styles, Andy Spade is reviving a preppy look that harks back to a simpler, less flashy time. A year ago, Mr. Spade, the husband of Kate Spade and chief executive of her accessories company, started a line of men's designs inspired by carpenters' tool bags. Called Jack Spade, they are sold at a SoHo boutique of the same name. A retired farmer from Kansas is the lone salesman at the store, which also carries Jack Spade mackintosh raincoats and retro items like Ray-Ban Wayfarer sunglasses, vintage thermoses and Tretorn sneakers. ''Everyone I know is wearing Prada, and every magazine I pick up isn't about personal style,'' Mr. Spade complained. ''I like things that are both timeless and functional.''

description: Q What does it mean when a mortgage lender insists that a title company provide ''affirmative insurance'' before allowing a property to close? . . . Karl Anichev, Kew Gardens, N.Y.

description: The front office lacks a carpet and the ceiling paint is still dimpled, but most of the damage to the Bloomingdale School of Music has been mended after a boiler problem caused a major flood in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEYMAN, SANDER
description: HEYMAN-Sander. Deceased July 3, 2000. Survived by daughters Susan Bell of Manhattan Beach, CA, Nancy Ostlund of Tucson, Arizona and sister Rosalie Heyman of White Plains, NY. Born January 26, 1908 in Brooklyn, NY. Educated at City College of NY and Brooklyn Law School. Acted four years in NY theatre and movies. Wrote sketches for Broadway plays as well as gags for radio and comedians. His long career in advertising began as a copywriter with BBD&O. Fourteen years with The NY American and Herald Tribune Newspapers doing advertising and editorial work. His career for over 20 years with Schenley Distillers included serving as sales and marketing management, public relations, advertising director and vice president. Sander spent 26 productive retirement years serving as a consultant to Rhinebeck Savings Bank, as an advisor to the Astor Home, and as a devoted, motivated volunteer engaged in fundraising, advertising and marketing for Northern Dutchess Hospital. There his friends and colleagues established The Sander Heyman Fund in Support of Volunteerism so as to honor him for his years as a dedicated volunteer. He spent the last five years of his life in Tucson, Az in order to be close to his daughters, where he attended The Lions Club and edited his residential home newsletter. He continued to maintain his independence, quick wit, creativity and positive attitude to the end. Few men have given so generously of their time to their work, their family, their community and their friends as did Sander all his life. During his lifetime he helped many friends and colleagues with their problems, showing concern, encouragement and generosity. He was loved by all and will be greatly missed.

title: Make Room for Buds
description: To keep new flowers developing on butterfly bush (Buddleia davidii), cut spent flowers back to the next set of buds. Keep deadheading cosmos, snapdragon and calendula. Thin sprawling asters to keep them from overwhelming their neighbors.

title: Image Struggle in Philadelphia
description: The accepted wisdom nowadays is that the national political conventions are little more than expensive relics, and it is true that the major events of the Republican jamboree that begins tomorrow in Philadelphia are largely foreordained. Gov. George W. Bush's nomination is secure, his vice president chosen. Yet this is a supremely important and surprisingly suspenseful time for Mr. Bush. The image of the man who promised a future based on ''compassionate conservatism'' is murkier than it was a few weeks ago, as is the very meaning of his trademark term. The Philadelphia convention will be an exercise in political packaging whose decisive moments will be Mr. Bush's acceptance speech, the final drafting of the G.O.P. platform, and Richard Cheney's reintroduction to the national audience. All these, in turn, will determine whether Mr. Bush puts his stamp on the Republican Party or the party's right wing draws a hard-edged, highly ideological template for his candidacy.

title: A Star Emerges From the White House Halls

Her elegance is outsize, like everything else about her -- the fully 6-foot frame; the long, expressive arms; the wide, ringed eyes; the sparkling burgundy voice. Her elongated face can darken with anxiety or crack open in a broad, raucous laugh. And since she holds her head high as she moves through the White House, she often seems to be floating.

In other families it's violence and depression, or stupidity or sex or money, or even genius. The human condition can probably be defined as the stuff that families won't talk about.

title: RYE: SCHOOL RULED NOT LIABLE

In a unanimous decision based on an opinion written by Justice Howard Miller, the four-member panel dismissed the high school, the city school district and the board of education from the case. But Lawrence T. D'Aloise Jr., a lawyer for the family of the injured student, Ian Convey, said he will pursue a suit against the family of Peter Lauria, the other boy involved. The students were throwing seed pods or pine cones at each other on the school's front lawn for less than a minute before the injury occurred. ''Absent some extraordinary security and supervision it is unavoidable horseplay that occurs on every playground in every suburban school yard in this country,'' said Joseph J. title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Pains of Apostasy
description: The Japanese novelist Shusaku Endo (1923-96) is best known in the West for ''Silence,'' his historical novel of Christian martyrs in 17th-century Japan. A Christian himself, Endo wrote from the straddled vantage of a Japanese man who embraced a Western philosophy; his fiction is at once the work of an insider and an alien. The stories collected in FIVE BY ENDO (New Directions, paper, $7) are among his best, and they are published here in a sleek, inexpensive volume. In ''Unzen,'' a middle-aged man with an unnamed guilt visits the sulfurous valley where Christians were tortured centuries before. Endo's prose is unadorned, yet in his hands sainthood becomes ambiguous: the martyr blazes with glory, but the cowardly apostate ''endures a pain none of you can comprehend.'' Sin, in Endo's view, is sometimes nothing more than the failure to acknowledge common humanity. ''Japanese in Warsaw'' follows a group of touring businessmen as they ''waddled in single file like ducks'' in search of souvenirs and cheap sex, unable to make any connection between the city's tragedies and themselves. Things, as much as people, can be storytellers: in ''The Box,'' old photos unlock the forgotten history of a half-Japanese Christian interrogated by the military police during World War II. Haunted by the relics the woman left, the narrator muses that ''trees and rocks and even postcards saturated with the thoughts of men must all speak to one another in hushed voices.'' In Endo's hands, the past is always vital in the present and how we judge history is in turn a judgment on ourselves. Janice P. Nimura

title: July 23-29; Music Industry and Napster

Then it was a defeat, when an appeals court granted a stay of the preliminary injunction issued a day earlier by a United States district judge that would have shut down Napster, the Internet music-swapping service that the major record labels have charged with contributing to widespread music piracy. Either way, as millions of Internet users stampeded to Napster and alternatives, the legal wrangling raised the question of whether enforcing copyright law in a digital age might take more than winning in court. title: Taking a Break From Scenic Vermont
description: EVERY year, as my husband and I pack the car for our August vacation, we look around at the impossibly green, impossibly beautiful Vermont landscape and ask each other if we are crazy. Why would anyone leave Vermont in the summer, when there are so many swimming holes to splash in, so many country fairs to visit, so many trails to hike. Why would anyone leave during the time of year when our down-country friends would trade in their theater tickets to stay even in the sagging old farmhouse we live in, and a chance to watch the sun set over the mountains and hear the crickets at night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORCESTOR, DEAN KIRKHAM, JR.
description: WORCESTOR-Dean Kirkham, Jr. Of New York City, July 15, 2000, age 77. Loving father of Charles L. of Medford, MA, Edward D. of Seattle, WA., and Amanda W. Swinchoski of Watertown, MA. Grandfather of James and Louisa Swinchoski. Also survived by sisters Shirley Braun of New York City and Sue Light of Suffield, CT. Former husband of Barbara Pennypacker Worcestor of New York City. Graduated from Brooks School, North Andover, MA, 1940. He served in North Africa and Italy from 1942-1945 in the Army Signal Corps. After receiving his BA from Yale in 1947, Dean attended Cambridge University, England (Peterhouse) where he received his Doctorate in History and was awarded one of the first Fullbright Scholarships. His Doctoral Thesis examined a diary of an English villager in the mid 1700's and was later basis for the book, ''The Diary of Thomas Turner'', edited by David Vaisey. Dean worked for Doubleday & Co. and Banker Trust; member of the Blue Hill Troupe and Canterbury Choral Society. He will be greatly missed by family and friends. Memorial service at the Church of the Heavenly Rest will be held at a later date. Memorial donations may be made to: New York Public Library, 5th Avenue and 40 St, NY, NY 10018.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, JAMES M., MD
description: BARRETT-James M., MD died on Monday, July 17, age 59. Dr. Barrett was born in Jacksonville, FL and was raised in New Orleans, LA. He attended medical school at Louisiana State University and did his residency at Johns Hopkins University, Maryland. In 1973, Dr. Barrett moved to South Florida and began his practice with Dermatology Associates. He loved his work so much that he continued working even after he became ill. Board certified with the American Board of Dermatology, the American Board of Dermatopathology and the American Board of Pathology. He was an assistant clinical professor at the University of Miami School of Medicine. He was also a former trustee for the American Skin Association. Dr. Barrett was a lover and supporter of the arts. He was a founding member of the Society for the Performing Arts, which became the Florida Philharmonic Orchestra. He was a former trustee at the Morikami Museum and board member of the Palm Beach County Council of the Arts. An amazingly gifted man and enormously generous of spirit, Dr. Barrett will be dearly missed by all. He is survived by his beloved wife, Millie; his adoring children: Ashley, sonin-law Paul Dalzell; Nicole, Connor and Hadley Barrett.

It took only a few weeks of reading grant applications from educational, cultural, social, environmental and even journalistic groups to realize that the foundation world is equally burdened with limp, lazy usages. The beauty aerie, which opened this month on the top floor of the Fifth Avenue department store, has a far more Zenlike approach to retail. David Mann of M.R. Architecture designed the space to look like an elegantly appointed lounge somewhere in the Far East. Poured concrete floors are raked to look like a Japanese Zen garden, or framed in marble and pressed with tatami mats. Spherical silver-leaf light fixtures are meant to recall the ripple effect of a stone thrown into a pond. Where are the products? title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: LOUKA, an unmarried 55-year-old cellist in Prague who looks a bit like Sean Connery, is down on his luck. Otherwise he would never have agreed to a fake marriage to help a Russian woman get her Czech papers. In the exquisitely made KOLYA (1996), Louka (Zdenek Sverak) gets the 40,000 crowns he was promised and more. The bride promptly runs away to Germany, leaving her 5-year-old son, Kolya (Andrej Chalimon), behind. Louka has no intention of playing father (it interferes with his active love life, for one thing), but he's stuck. What could have been a sticky-sweet tale of an adorable child transforming a grumpy old man is a gentle but thoroughly unsentimental gem of a movie. Mr. Sverak wrote ''Kolya,'' which won the best foreign film Oscar; Jan Sverak, his son, directed - Thursday at 10 p.m. and Thursday/Early Friday at 3:35 and 11:45 A.M. on IFC.

title: Summertime Dues
description: I know it's hip to be cynical, but Walter Kirn (The Way We Live Now, July 9) is way too hip for my blood. He seems to take pride in having learned to lie, cheat and steal at his summer job. My summer job -- waiting on tables from 10 p.m. to 6 a.m at a Howard Johnson's -- let me meet ''working stiffs'' delivering bread to the A.&P., alcoholics who stopped in to sober up and salesmen lonely for home. I learned that the difference between blue-collar and blue blood had nothing to do with heart or with the size of my tip. I learned that all jobs have their mundane tasks that must be endured as well as moments of joy. Defending my dissertation was a breeze; I'd explained my topic to customers for years. I waited on Rick Pitino and Allen Ginsberg (not together). We learn what we want to learn. Walter Kirn learned to cheat and steal. That says more about him than about his summer employment.

title: WHITE PLAINS: DIAMOND FEUD RESOLVED
description: A 12-year legal feud between two brothers over the diamond fortune and business left by their father, Harry Winston, ended Monday with one brother, Ronald, 59, gaining control of the business and the other brother, Bruce, 56, pocketing $54.1 million. The company, Harry Winston Inc., which was founded in 1932, is known for lending gems to Hollywood stars for the Academy Awards. Harry Winston donated the 44.5-carat Hope diamond to the Smithsonian Institution in 1958. The settlement was reached in Surrogate's Court in White Plains with a handshake between the brothers. Judge Albert J. Emanuelli said on Wednesday that he was pleased to have ''brought a family back together again after they were at odds for years.'' Elsa Brenner

Other sectors of American society (e.g., sales versus service; engineering versus production; administration versus teaching) can benefit from the study of the clubhouse of a successful major-league team.

title: Fusing Beauty And Terror, Reverence and Desecration

One hundred fourteen people died as a result of last week's crash. Compared with a single life, the plane itself is nothing, just metal, rubber and oil. These were nonetheless combined into one of the most important cultural artifacts of the 20th century. In the 31 years since the first Concorde was rolled out, only a select few have flown on it. But this swan of a craft has winged through the imaginations of millions more. It's not just the French or the British who look up admiringly when the Concorde flies overhead. title: Asylum Plea by Chinese Sect's Leader Perplexes the U.S.
description: A request for political asylum in the United States by the leader of one of China's largest spiritual movements has put Washington in the difficult position of harboring a possible criminal or handing over to Beijing a man hunted for his beliefs.

title: Late Start Can't Stop A Chase For Gold
description: The Olympic swimming star Claudia Poll and her longtime coach, Francisco Rivas, both laugh when they share memories of their early days together at a country club in Costa Rica. Poll, 7 years old at the time, was hardly the model student.

title: Republican Pleasantries
description: Gov. George W. Bush knows that he cannot be elected president unless he gets votes from many people who do not agree with him or the Republican Party platform on issues such as abortion, gun control, capital punishment and the privatization of Social Security. That is why today is gear-shifting day in Philadelphia. The selection of Dick Cheney as his running mate and the deliberations of the platform committee all emphasized the conservative part of Mr. Bush's background and core vote. Once the first session of the Republican National Convention opens this evening, the nation will see four nights devoted to what Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster, calls the politics of pleasantry.

title: Free Speech Rights For Computer Code; Suit Tests Power of Media Concerns To Control Access to Digital Content
description: It was perhaps the most arcane statement in all the hours of acronym-filled testimony, one that came on the last day of the six-day trial. But it may have been a turning point in an important battle over the limits of a new copyright law, a potential landmark case that ended its trial phase last week in Manhattan and now awaits a verdict by the judge.

title: Jose Angel Valente, 71, Poet Who Knew Purity of the Word
description: Jose Angel Valente, a cerebral Spaniard who believed writing poetry should begin with the word and not with the real-life world, died on July 18 in a hospital in Geneva. He was 71.

title: The World Gets Bigger For Martin
description: The bullies on the bus in Dallas did not know whom they were picking on, they only laughed at the small boy's stutter, his light skin and his clothes, playing the cruel game of childhood.

title: Reggae and Bossa Nova Shake Up the Beguine
description: French-Caribbean pop has long had its own distinct personalities (in types of song like compas and zouk), but it's also fascinating to see what other elements emerge from it; musicians from Martinique, Haiti and French Guyana have become repositories for other kinds of music of the Western Hemisphere. In Saturday night's concert at Avery Fisher Hall, ''The French Connection: Rising Stars of Creole Song'' -- the closing concert of the Caribbean-music series in Lincoln Center Festival 2000 -- Brazilian bossa nova and MPB (or musica popular brasileira) were among the core elements, beside reggae, funk and rumba.

title: Media; Don't Apply for the Top Job at Harper's Bazaar: It's Not Open
description: There are few areas of modern society that are as nasty, brutish and just plain catty as the world of fashion magazines. Fueled by skim cappuccinos infused with Sweet 'n Low and the rather desperate illusion that this month's hemline length is a matter of grave importance to the world's population, the fashion-editor's world is a place that embraces the casual morsel of malicious gossip and recycles it over and over again until it snowballs, in a frenzied crescendo of hushed cell-phone conversations and secret e-mail messages, into something resembling truth -- which, of course, it rarely is.

title: U.S. Urging Milosevic Opponents to Unite for September Vote
description: American officials are putting strong pressure on the president of Montenegro and the leader of Serbia's largest opposition party to take part in Yugoslav elections called in September, according to Yugoslav politicians and Western officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNUKAU, WALLACE MANAIAOKALANI
description: KUNUKAU-Wallace Manaiaokalani. Born November 4, 1940, in Lahaina, Maui, Hawaii. Died July 28, 2000, in NYC. Brother of Mary and Thomas Apo, Alexander and Janet Kunukau, and Melvin and Laverne Kunukau; and uncle to numerous nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Wally was Managing Editor of Family Circle Magazine and a founder of the Gotham Volleyball League in NYC. He graduated from Kamehameha High School in Honolulu and received a bachelor's degree from the University of Hawaii and master's degree from NYU. He served in Vietnam in the U.S. Army. title: Digging for Forgotten Treasure; Museum Opens Its Vaults for New Exhibition Space
description: Here are some long-missing treasures that are soon to be revealed: a 1914 brass time capsule that was supposed to be opened on Wall Street in 1974 but wasn't, because no one could find it. A hide-covered bass drum that took two Confederate bullets at the First Battle of Bull Run. An ornate chair believed to be Napoleon's. And a fresco of Venus from Pompeii.

title: Corrections
description: An electoral college map on July 21 with a front-page article about the presidential campaign misstated Nebraska's method of allocating electoral votes. Like Maine, Nebraska awards one elector for the winner in each Congressional district and two for the statewide winner. It does not use the winner-take-all system followed by all other states and the District of Columbia.
